taxon_text_1_1:
Stauromedusae are a small group of sedentary medusae that are attached ‘upside-down’ to the substratum by an adhesive disc. From the basal disc arises a stalk that spreads out into an umbrella-like oral disc with a central mouth encircled by short arms, which normally bear clusters of small, knobbed tentacles. There are only about 50 described species worldwide and only 4 in South Africa.

This recently discovered species was only formally named in 2017 and is currently known from only a small area extending from False Bay to Betty’s Bay in the SW Cape. It has a very short stalk and four widely spread, stiff, reddish-brown arms, each of which branches near the tips, which are armed with tufts of short tentacles. The upper surface is covered in nodular lobes (hence the allusion to pearls).
taxon_text_3_3:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Very restricted known range from False Bay to Betty’s Bay.
taxon_text_4_4: This little-known but interesting upside-down jellyfish is known from relatively few published records across a very small range and is usually found attached to the fronds of kelps and other large algae.
taxon_text_5_5: Thought to feed on small crustaceans, especially copepods, amphipods and ostracods that live on the surfaces of the host algae.
taxon_text_6_6: Unlike most jellyfish Stauromedusae do not have an alternating polyp and medusa lifecycle. Sexually mature medusae release sperm and eggs into the water, which merge to form creeping planula larvae that settle and develop directly into new attached Stauromedusae.
taxon_text_7_7: A second member of this genus, C. capensis is known from just a single South African specimen collected from Sargassum in an intertidal rockpool near East London in the 1930s, and has subsequently been recorded from just one other individual collected in Brazil! It is more upright and has pad-like adhesive structures at the base of the arms beneath the tentacles. It would be exciting to try to rediscover that species and determine its true distribution.
taxon_text_8_8:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Miranda, LS, Branch, GM, Collins, AG, Hirano, YM, Marques, AC & Griffiths, CL (2017). Stalked jellyfishes (Cnidaria: Staurozoa) of South Africa, with the description of Calvadosia lewisi sp nov. Zootaxa, 4227(3), 369-389.
taxon_text_1_4500:
Stauromedusae are a small group of sedentary medusae that are attached ‘upside-down’ to the substratum by an adhesive disc. From the basal disc arises a stalk that spreads out into an umbrella-like oral disc with a central mouth encircled by short arms, which bear clusters of small, knobbed tentacles. There are only about 50 described species worldwide and only 4 in South Africa.

This species can be white, orange or green and is elongate and tubular with the gonads showing as double rows of paler bulges along the column. Distally 8 short arms are armed with knobbed tentacles.
taxon_text_2_4501: Up to about 20 mm in height when extended.
taxon_text_3_4502:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.  Previously published records from Australia and New Zealand are now thought to represent a distinct species.

Local/Regional: Hondeklip Bay on west coast to Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_4503: This little-known but interesting upside-down jellyfish is known from relatively few published records, but once one knows where to look for it, it is in fact quite easy to find and common. Best found attached to large seaweeds in sheltered pools and usually occurs singly, the body colour usually matching that of the host alga. Can relocate by detaching and somersaulting and is predatory, feeding on small invertebrates that stumble into the tentacles.
taxon_text_5_4504: Feeds on small crustaceans, especially copepods and ostracods, and other invertebrates that live on the surfaces of algae.
taxon_text_6_4505: Unlike most jellyfish Stauromedusae do not have an alternating polyp and medusa lifecycle. Sexually mature medusae release sperm and eggs into the water, which merge to form creeping planula larvae that settle and develop directly into new attached Stauromedusae.
taxon_text_7_4506:
By far the most common stauromedusa in the region but can be confused with two rarer species of the related genus Calvadosia that also occur in the region.

The first of these, C. lewisi, was only described in 2017, and has a much shorter column and 4 arms that are divided near their tips and are held out horizontally like a cross. It occurs on kelps and other large algae in the Western Cape.

Another species, C. capensis is known from just a single South African specimen collected from Sargassum in an intertidal rockpool near East London in the 1930s, and has subsequently been recorded from just one other individual collected in Brazil! It is upright and has pad-like adhesive structures at the base of the arms beneath the tentacles. Probably it is widely distributed, but often confused with D. africana and it would be exciting to rediscover this species and determine its true distribution.
taxon_text_8_4507:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 50).

Miranda, LS, Branch, GM, Collins, AG, Hirano, YM, Marques, AC & Griffiths, CL (2017). Stalked jellyfishes (Cnidaria: Staurozoa) of South Africa, with the description of Calvadosia lewisi sp nov. Zootaxa, 4227(3), 369-389.
taxon_text_1_4510:
Stauromedusae are a small group of sedentary medusae that are attached ‘upside-down’ to the substratum by an adhesive disc. From the basal disc arises a stalk that spreads out into an umbrella-like oral disc with a central mouth encircled by short arms, which bear clusters of small, knobbed tentacles. There are only about 50 described species worldwide and only 4 in South Africa.

This unusual species is pale and transparent with white dots. It has a wide funnel- or bell- shaped body with a 4-chambered central mouth. Around the perimeter of the bell are 8 short, flat lobe-like arms with no obvious tentacles.
taxon_text_3_4512:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Still Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_4513: Very little-known but interesting upside-down jellyfish recorded from a few mostly photographic records and a handful of actual specimens. Usually seen under boulders in intertidal pools or attached to rocks to a depth of 23 m.
taxon_text_5_4514: Unknown, but probably feed on small crustaceans and other small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_4515: Unlike most jellyfish Stauromedusae do not have an alternating polyp and medusa lifecycle. Sexually mature medusae release sperm and eggs into the water, which merge to form creeping planula larvae that settle and develop directly into new attached Stauromedusae.
taxon_text_7_4516: Unmistakable and the only species in this family in South Africa and only one of 3 globally, all of which are known from one to a very few samples! Almost nothing is thus known about the biology of this strange group.
taxon_text_8_4517:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 50).

Miranda, LS, Branch, GM, Collins, AG, Hirano, YM, Marques, AC & Griffiths, CL (2017). Stalked jellyfishes (Cnidaria: Staurozoa) of South Africa, with the description of Calvadosia lewisi sp nov. Zootaxa, 4227(3), 369-389.
taxon_text_1_5452: Sturdy and hard-bodied with elongate protective side plates. Antennae of equal length. Eyes pale and vertically elongated. Second pair of legs (gnathopod 2) lack nippers. Side plate of third abdominal segment upturned, with a small hooked ‘pocket’ above corner, from which common name is derived.  Colour usually banded red and white, often with blue side plates.
taxon_text_3_5454:
Global: Widespread in Southern Hemisphere, including southern Africa, Australia and New Zealand

Local/Regional: Mozambique to Namibia
taxon_text_4_5455: Common under intertidal boulders and in seaweed holdfasts, etc.
taxon_text_5_5456: Assumed to be a scavenger of seaweeds.
taxon_text_6_5457: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release.
taxon_text_7_5458: The only representative of this genus in the region. The upturned pocket on abdominal side plate and colour make this species easy to recognize when fresh, although there are several other similarly-shaped species in Family Lysianassidae.
taxon_text_8_5459:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_19:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form school on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This relatively small species is best characterized by its unusually large eye, its silvery-bronze colour and the fact that the rear edge of the operculum and the lateral line are black. Small juveniles are bright red.
taxon_text_3_21:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_22: Found around shallow reefs to a depth not much exceeding 30 m, juveniles in shallow water, even rockpools. Forms small aggregations and sometimes mixes with the Cape seabream, Pachymetopon blochii.
taxon_text_5_23: Generalist predator, feeding on various benthic invertebrates such as tunicates, molluscs, worms and crustaceans. Also take algae, but these are not digested and it is thought they are eaten for the attached invertebrates growing on their surfaces.
taxon_text_6_24: Much remains to be discovered regarding the reproductive strategy of the Fransmadam, though it is currently thought to be a rudimentary hermaphrodite (i.e. a late gonochorist). The species spawns in spring and summer, with eggs developing in plankton.
taxon_text_7_25: The large eye and black edge to operculum are fairly diagnostic, but sometimes confused with the Steentjie Spondyliostoma emarginatum, which also has an unusually large eye, but no black on the operculum and several faint horizontal golden stripes along its sides.
taxon_text_8_26:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 288).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 215).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 293).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 222).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 582).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 35).
taxon_text_1_37:
Ampeliscidae are a common and diverse family of benthic, tube-dwelling amphipods, fairly easily recognized to group by the fact that most species have two pairs of red eyes, each topped by a round, shiny corneal lens. Their bodies are soft and laterally flattened, the antennae generally long and hairy, the claws weak or absent and the first two pairs of walking legs contain cloud-like spinning glands used to secrete the tubes.

There are more than a dozen hard to identify species in the region and these are separated largely by detailed structures of the last pair of walking legs (see Griffiths, 1976 for guide to species). This species is particularly large and common and is featured here mainly because it can be fairly readily identified by the conspicuous rounded lobe on the posterior of the last walking leg.
taxon_text_2_38: Adult up to 12 mm body length (excluding antennae).
taxon_text_3_39:
Global: Europe, Mediterranean and South Africa (the South African form likely is distinct from that in Europe).

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_40: Like most other ampeliscids found in dense colonies occupying soft sediments to depths of at least 200 m. Occupies delicate vertical tubes spun from sediment particles and extends the setose antennae from the tubes to capture fine organic particles which are sorted by the mouthparts and either ingested or used for tube construction.
taxon_text_5_41: When feeding the antennae are projected out of the burrow opening and are used to filter organic particles from the water passing overhead.
taxon_text_6_42: Sexes separate. Females brood their eggs in a marsupial chamber between the legs, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles which are then released into the water.
taxon_text_7_43: There are over 200 species globally in the genus Ampelisca, of which 14 are found in South Africa. These are mostly difficult to separate, so only this species is featured to represent the normal sediment dwelling forms. The only other species described on this site is the strange A. excavate, which has the unique habitat of taking over the abandoned burrows of dead burrowing barnacles and has a modified body structure to adapt itself to this habitat.
taxon_text_8_44: Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 23).
taxon_text_1_46:
Most easily identified by its unique habit of occupying the empty burrows of dead acrothoracican barnacles, which are most commonly excavated into the shells of mollusks, but can also occur in sheets of coralline algae.

There are three pairs of eyes, and as with other members of the family Ampeliscidae (but very unusually among other amphipods) each bears a rounded corneal lens. Antennae 1 and 2 are red, short (about one-third body length), equal, thick and setose. Last three pairs of walking legs are short, with expanded bases and are spinose, the basal segment (article 2) of last pair being strongly excavate behind (hence species name). Last segment of thorax with unique pair of dorsal ridges enclosing a hump and pit that are used to close off opening to burrow.
taxon_text_2_47:
Most easily identified by its unique habit of occupying the empty burrows of dead acrothoracian barnacles, which are most commonly excavated into the shells of mollusks, but can also occur in sheets of coralline algae.

There are three pairs of eyes, and as with other members of the family Ampeliscidae (but very unusually among other amphipods) each bears a rounded corneal lens. Antennae 1 and 2 are red, short (about one-third body length), equal, thick and setose. Last three pairs of walking legs are short, with expanded bases and are spinose, the basal segment (article 2) of last pair being strongly excavate behind (hence species name). Last segment of thorax with unique pair of dorsal ridges enclosing a hump and pit that are used to close off opening to burrow.
taxon_text_3_48:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known from Algoa Bay to Cape Peninsula on shallow reefs up to about 36 m depth.
taxon_text_4_49: Has very unusual habits, the females exclusively occupying empty burrows excavated into calcareous substrata, mainly mollusk shells but also thick coralline algae, by acrothoracean barnacles. Particularly common in shells of the abalone Haliotis midae, the Turban shells Turbo sarmaticus and T. cidaris, as well as in the coralline alga Heydrichia woelkerlingii. The body form appears to have become modified to this unique habitat. The antennae have become adapted to filter-feeding, the limbs have become short, stout and spinose (reminiscent of those of hermit crabs) to grip the walls of the burrow and a plug–like structure on the dorsal surface appears to be use to close off the opening to the burrow when disturbed. Males are unknown and may look very different, since they are likely mobile and move between females, which remain captive within their burrows.
taxon_text_5_50: When feeding the antennae are projected out of the burrow opening and used to filter organic particles from the water passing overhead. When disturbed the animal rolls over and blocks the aperture with the ‘plug-like’ swelling on its back.
taxon_text_6_51: All amphipods broods their eggs in a marsupial chamber between the legs, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles which are then released into the water. In this case females are trapped within their burrows, so males are suspected to be free swimming and to move between females for fertilization. This has never been observed though and indeed males remain completely unknown.
taxon_text_7_52: There are over 200 species in the genus Ampelisca, of which 14 are found in South Africa. However, most of these construct fragile sandy tubes in soft sediments. This species in unique in its specialised hermit-like habit, taking over the empty burrows of another species.
taxon_text_8_53:
Original description: Barnard, KH (1925). Contributions to the Crustacean Fauna of South Africa no 8. Further Additions to the List of Amphipoda. Annals of the South African Museum, 20 (5): 319-380.

Botha, TPA & Griffiths, CL (2021). South African Acrothoracica (Crustacea: Cirripedia). Zootaxa, 4949(1), 45-78.

Gray, WS & Barnard, JL (1970). South African Ampelisca excavata KH Barnard (Amphipoda, Gammaridea), a redescription with notes on the domicile. Crustaceana, 19 (1): 67-83.
taxon_text_1_55: Antennae not strongly sotose, antenna 1 considerably shorter than antenna 2. Second pair of legs (gnathopod 2) with strong nippers, especially in males; palm of hand oblique, about as long as hindmargin. Last pair of walking legs not expanded. Last pair of abdominal appendages (uropod 3) very short and with single branch (ramus). Green to brown with row of white spots along side.
taxon_text_3_57:
Global: Widespread across Indian and Pacific Oceans, including southern Africa, Chile, New Zealand, Japan etc, also Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Mozambique to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_58: One of most common species amongst seaweeds on intertidal rocky shores and can survive high on the shore by nestling among algae.
taxon_text_6_60: Eggs are brooded on a marsupial chamber between walking leg of females until they have developed into fully formed juveniles which are then released
taxon_text_7_61: There are 24 species in this genus, but only one of these, A. diastoma, occurs in the region and can be distinguished by the strongly curved and basally excavated finger (dactly) of male gnathopod 2.
taxon_text_8_62: Branch G, Griffiths CL, Branch M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 96).
taxon_text_1_64: Laterally flattened, smooth-bodied, shrimp-like amphipod, best recognized by its obligate association with limpets. Colour pale translucent green with red eyes. Antennae equal and about 20% body length; nippers small and more of less equal, with elongate, rectangular hand. Last 3 pairs of abdominal appendages (uropods) with two equal branches, almost devoid of spines. End of telson rounded or slightly notched.
taxon_text_3_66:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_67: Well known for its apparent obligate association with large limpets, particularly being found under shells of Cymbula oculus, C. granatina, C. miniata and C. compressa, as well as Scutellastra tabularis. Usually occur in male/female pairs within the mantle (gill) cavity of the limpet. The sizes of the amphipods is correlated with that of the host limpet. Thought to be territorial and to defend their host habitat (the limpet) against other individuals of its own species.
taxon_text_5_68: Feed on faeces of the limpet host and probably also on algal fragments scraped from the rocks by the limpet’s radula.
taxon_text_6_69: Males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_70: The only regional species in the genus and best identified by its unusual habitat. Another amphipod, Apohyale grandicornis, is also sometimes found under limpets exposed during low tide, but this is a casual relationship, and the amphipods leave their host during high tide (see that species entry for a description of Apohyale). In Apohyale the second nipper is also greatly enlarged in males and the last pair of uropods has only one short branch.
taxon_text_8_71:
Barnard, JL (1978). Redescription of the amphipod, Calliopiella michaelseni Schellenberg from South Africa, with comparison to a new genus from the Pacific Ocean. Annals of the South African Museum 75: 33–40.

Branch, G (1975). The ecology of Patella from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 5. Commensalism. Zoologica Africana, 10, 133–162.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 40).
taxon_text_1_73: Off-white, eyes dark, first antennae much shorter than second. First pair of nippers small, second pair greatly enlarged in males, palm of the hand cut into a deep, semicircular excision. Walking legs splayed to the side to support the animal upright in air, last two pairs of legs not markedly elongated and basal segment not greatly expanded. Dorsal surface of abdomen smooth, lacking dorsal projections. Also distinguished from most other amphipods by its terrestrial, air-breathing habits and ability to leap high into the air.
taxon_text_3_75:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Port St Johns.
taxon_text_4_76: Found on sandy beaches, particularly those where large amounts of wrack or kelp are washed ashore, where they can become extremely abundant, numbering thousands per linear meter of beach. Normally remain buried in the sand by day to avoid heat and desiccation and emerge at night, or during cool-moist weather, to feed in the open on drift algae. When disturbed can lead high into the air, landing clumsily and staggering back into an upright position. At some sites populations may extend well above high watermark and into the dunes. There have been numerous reports of beach hoppers invading coastal properties in large numbers and dying in drifts inside homes. Some home-owners even erect barricades to keep them out!
taxon_text_5_77: Feed on drift algae under which they shelter and can be remarkably effective in consuming drift kelp when present in large numbers.
taxon_text_6_78: Like in all amphipods eggs are deposited into a brood pouch between the legs of the females, where they are fertilised by males and develop into fully formed juveniles before being released. Ovigerous females of this species are found throughout the year, although there are two peaks of abundance in summer and in winter.
taxon_text_7_79: Co-occurs with other beach-hopper of the genus Africorchestia, which are characterized by having pairs of dorsal projections on the abdominal segments and greatly expanded basal joint in the elongated 6th pair of legs in adult males. From the Cape Peninsula westwards the species present is A. quadrispinosa, which has one pair of dorsal projects on each of abdominal segments 1, 2 and sometimes 3. East of Cape Agulhas another similar species, A. meridionalis occurs, but this has two pairs of dorsal spines of the second abdominal segment and one pair each on segments 1 and 3.
taxon_text_8_80:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Lowry, JK & Baldanzi, S (2016). New talitrids form South Africa (Amphipoda, Senticaudata, Talitroidea, Talitridae) with notes on their ecology. Zootaxa 4144(2), 151-174.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_82: As with all members of this family, the body has become greatly elongated and cylindrical. The first two pairs of legs bear nippers, the second pair being much the larger, the next two pairs of legs are entirely absent and the last three pairs are strongly clawed and splayed to grip the substratum. This species is characterized by having a rounded forehead and a ventral spine between the bases of the second pair of legs (gnathopod 2), which also has a short, flanged basal segment. The first two body segments are characteristically greatly elongated in males.
taxon_text_3_84:
Global: Very widespread species, which may have been distributed to some current sites via shipping. Found across Europe, N and S America, Asia, also New Zealand, Africa and Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Mozambique to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_85: Caprellid amphipods all cling to hydroids, bryozoans seaweeds and the like using the specially-adapted hind limbs and extend their elongate bodies out into the water , where they snatch any passing food item passing by. They may remain immobile for long periods waiting for prey but when disturbed they move rapidly along like inchworms. They can be extremely abundant on floating structures, such as buoys, ships hulls.
taxon_text_5_86: Caprellids are though to be omnivorous, feeding on any small invertebrates, larvae, or other items float within reach.  Some species also filter-feed using the antennae.
taxon_text_6_87: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_88: There are over 200 species in the genus Caprella of which 8 occur in South Africa. Several of the local species have a spike on the head, others can be distinguished by size and shape of the nippers (gnathopod 2).
taxon_text_8_89: Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_91: As with all members of this family, the body has become greatly elongated and cylindrical. The first two pairs of legs bear nippers, the second pair being much the larger, the next two pairs of legs are entirely absent and the last three pairs are strongly clawed and splayed to grip the substratum. This species is characterized by having a forward-pointed spike on the top of the head and an elongate second pair of legs (gnathopod 2), with a long basal segment and elongate distally-widening hatchet-shaped hand.  There is no ventral spine between the bases of the legs.
taxon_text_3_93:
Global: Very widespread species, which has been spread to some current sites via shipping. Found across Europe,  S, America, Caribbean, Asia, Australia, New Zealand and southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Mozambique to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_94: Caprellid amphipods all cling to hydroids, bryozoans seaweeds and the like using the specially-adapted hind limbs and extend their elongate bodies out into the water, where they snatch any passing food item passing by. They may remain immobile for long periods waiting for prey, but when disturbed they canmove rapidly along like inchworms. They can be extremely abundant on floating structures, such as buoys, ships hulls. This species is sometimes also found in large numbers on the  surgace of the reticulated starfish  Henricia ornata, but the nature of this association is unknown.
taxon_text_5_95: Caprellids are though to be omnivorous, feeding on any small invertebrates, larvae, or other items that float within reach.  Some species also filter-feed using their antennae.
taxon_text_6_96: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_97: There are over 200 species in the genus Caprella of which 8 occur in South Africa. Local species can mostly be recognized by presence of absence of a spike on the head, and by size and shape of the nippers (gnathopod 2).
taxon_text_8_98:
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.

Krapp, T, Lang, C, Libertini, A, & Melzer, RR (2006). Caprella scaura Templeton, 1836 sensu lato (Amphipoda: Caprellidae) in the Mediterranean. Organisms Diversity & Evolution, 6(2), 77-81.
taxon_text_1_100: Laterally flattened and shrimp-like with distinctive transverse red and white stipes. Eyes pale. Antenna 1 considerably longer than antenna 2. First two pairs of legs (gnathopods) with distinct nippers, those of second pair much larger, especially in males. Posterior margins of first three abdominal segments (and third abdominal side plate) cut into characteristic series of flat, sharp serrations. Last pair of abdominal appendages (uropod 3) with two long equal-sized branches.
taxon_text_3_102:
Global: Widespread in Indo-Pacific, including Australia and New Zealand, Fiji etc, extending around South Africa into Namibia

Local/Regional: Namibia to KZN.
taxon_text_4_103: Usually found under boulders intertidally and on shallow reefs. Habits unknown.
taxon_text_6_105: Males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_106: There are 53 species in this genus, but only one other occurs in South Africa, C. natalensis. This also has similar serrations on the abdominal segments, but has a greatly enlarged second gnathopod with a transverse palm and occurs only in KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_8_107:
Barnard JL (1972). Gammaridean amphipoda of Australia, Part 1. Smithsonain Contributions to Zoology, 103, 1-333 (see p. 220 and Fig,129).

Branch G, Griffiths CL, Branch M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_109: Like all skeleton shrimps the body segments are greatly elongated and cylindrical and the side plates absent. Legs 3 and 4 are absent in most skeleton shrimps, but in this species they remain fully developed. Leg 5 is also characteristically reduced to three segments, so that only the last two pairs of legs remain robust and are used to grip onto the substratum.
taxon_text_4_112: Like other skeleton shrimps assumed to cling to algae, hydroids, bryozoans etc with the last two pairs of legs, with the elongate body extending out into the water, reaching out periodically with the nippers to intercept prey.
taxon_text_5_113: Members of this group are mostly though to be omnivorous, catching small crustaceans, worms, diatoms. etc.
taxon_text_6_114: Adult females can easily be recognized by the presence of ventral brood plates on body segments 3 and 4. The eggs are laid into the brood chamber where they are fertilized by the male and brooded until they develop into fully-formed young.
taxon_text_7_115: This is the only species in this unusual  and endemic genus. The fully developed legs 3-4 are highly unusual among regional skeleton shrimps, the only other regional species with this character being Phtisica marina.  However leg 5 in P. marina is also fully developed, where as in C. leoni it is reduced to just 3 segments.
taxon_text_8_116:
Griffiths, CL (1974). The Amphipoda of Southern Africa. 3. The Gammaridea and Caprellidea of Natal. Annals of the South African Museum. 62(7), 209-264, figs: 1-8.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_127:
Cyamids are very unusual parasitic amphipods with strongly flattened, oval bodies. The first pair of legs (gnathopod 1) bears large, powerful nippers and the second pair much smaller ones. The third and fourth pairs of legs are entirely missing and only gills are present on those body segments. Legs 5-7 are powerful, extended laterally and end in large grasping claws for clinging to the skin of their cetacean hosts.

Several species occur in the region, each distinguished largely by the form of the gills, as well as by associated with particular hosts. In this species the gills each consist of a single elongate ‘sausage’ with a short crescent-shaped accessory gill at its base. This is also the only whale louse association with Humpback whales.
taxon_text_3_129:
Global: Widespread across North and South Atlantic Ocean, Southern Ocean and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_130:
One of several cyamid amphipods that have parasitic relationships with cetaceans, most species being associated with only one, or a small groups of closely-related hosts.

Whale lice tend to favour areas where they obtain some shelter from water currents, for example around the blow-holes, genital or other body opening, in wounds, around the callosities of right whales and in areas previously infested with whale barnacles (Coronula diadema). The entire life-cycle occurs on the host, with juveniles simply moving from the brood pouch of females directly onto the adjacent skin of the host. Transfer between individual hosts presumably only occurs when they against touch one another.
taxon_text_5_131: Hyperiids are though feed on algae that settle on the body of the host, but also ingest skin flakes and tissue around wounds. They are not though to cause significant damage to the hosts.
taxon_text_6_132: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_133: This group is very easily recognised by their compact, flattened bodies, absence of third and fourth pair of legs and grasping posterior limbs, as well of course by their unique associations with cetaceans. Several species of Cyamus and related genera have been reported from the region, each with different form of the gills and associated with different cetacean species. This is the only species found on Humpback whales, whereas, for example, three other species all occur on Southern right whales.
taxon_text_8_134:
Branch G, Griffiths CL, Branch M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 94).

Iwasa-Arai, T, Freire, AS, Colosio, AC, & Serejo, CS (2017). Ontogenetic development and redescription of the whale louse Cyamus boopis Lütken, 1870 (Crustacea: Amphipoda: Cyamidae), ectoparasite of humpback whale Megaptera novaeangliae (Mammalia: Cetacea: Balaenopteridae). Marine Biodiversity, 47(3): 929-939.

Leung, YM (1967). An illustrated key to the species of whale-lice (Amphipoda, Cyamidae), ectoparasites of Cetacea, with a guide to the literature. Crustaceana, 12(3), 279-291.
taxon_text_1_118:
Bizarre and unique-looking amphipod and the only representative of the wood-boring family Cheluridae found in South Africa. Body cylindrical with rounded head and thickened second antennae that lack a flagellum. Third abdominal segment with a large dorsal projection. Last three abdominal segments fused and with enlarged and very unusual-shaped appendages (uropods). Third pair of uropods massively enlarged and forming an oval lobe that extends well beyond posterior end of body. 

Also easily-recognised by its wood boring habits.
taxon_text_3_120:
Global: Thought to have originated in Europe, but now dispersed widely by shipping and found on both Atlantic and Pacific coasts of North America, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_121: Associated with submerged wood, especially in harbours but also wooden wrecks and sunken timber. Often associated with the wood boring isopods Limnoria spp. (‘gribbles’) and appear to expand and enlarge gribble burrows, rather than creating their own tunnels.
taxon_text_5_122: Presumed to feed on decaying wood and the micro-organisms associated with it, also consume the faecal pellets of gribbles.
taxon_text_6_123: Eggs are brooded on a marsupial chamber between walking leg of females until they have developed into fully formed juveniles which are then released.
taxon_text_7_124: The only representative of this family in South Africa and easily identified by its unusual morphological features and unique habits.
taxon_text_8_125:
Charles, F, Riera, P, Sauriau, PG, Lantoine, F, Lebreton, B, Agogué, H & Hourdez, S (2020). Trophic niche partitioning in marine wood-borers revealed by stable isotope analysis. Aquatic Biology, 29, 33-43.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 28).

Picker, M & Griffiths, CL (2011). Alien and Invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 164).
taxon_text_1_136:
Cyamids are very unusual parasitic amphipods with strongly flattened, usually oval bodies. The first pair of legs (gnathopod 1) bears small nippers and the second pair much larger and more powerful ones. The third and fourth pairs of legs are entirely missing and only gills are present on those body segments. Legs 5-7 are powerful, extended laterally and end in large grasping claws for clinging to the skin of their cetacean hosts. 

Several species occur in the region, each distinguished by body shape, form of the gills, and by associated with particular cetacean hosts. This species has an unusually slender, almost parallel-sided body and the gills each consist of a single short ‘sausage’ only about as long as two body segments. It is one of three species of whale louse associated with Southern right whales.
taxon_text_3_138:
Global: Widespread only on Southern right whales across South Atlantic Ocean, Southern Ocean and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_139:
One of several cyamid amphipods that have parasitic relationships with cetaceans, most species being associated with only one, or a small groups of closely-related hosts.

Whale lice tend to favour areas where they obtain some shelter from water currents, for example around the blow-holes, genital or other body opening, in wounds, around the callosities of right whales and in areas previously infested with whale barnacles (Coronula diadema). The entire life-cycle occurs on the host, with juveniles simply moving from the brood pouch of females directly onto the adjacent skin of the host. Transfer between individual hosts presumably only occurs when they against touch one another.
taxon_text_5_140: Cyamids are thought to feed on algae that settle on the body of the host, but also ingest skin flakes and tissue around wounds. They are not thought to cause significant damage to the hosts.
taxon_text_6_141: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_142:
This group is very easily recognised by their compact, flattened bodies, absence of third and fourth pair of legs and grasping posterior limbs, as well of course by their unique associations with cetaceans. Several species of Cyamus and related genera have been reported from the region, each with different form of the gills and associated with different cetacean species.

This is one of three species found on Southern right whales and can be distinguished by its slender body and short, simple gills. Of the other two species on this host C. erraticus has much longer gills (as long as 4 body segments) and C. ovalis has a much broader body and the gills each consist of two elongate ‘sausages’ with a pair of shorter crescent-shaped accessory gills at their bases.
taxon_text_8_143:
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 87).

Leung, YM (1967). An illustrated key to the species of whale-lice (Amphipoda, Cyamidae), ectoparasites of Cetacea, with a guide to the literature. Crustaceana, 12(3), 279-291.
taxon_text_1_145:
Cyamids are very unusual parasitic amphipods with strongly flattened, usually oval bodies. The first pair of legs (gnathopod 1) bears large, powerful nippers and the second pair much smaller ones. The third and fourth pairs of legs are entirely missing and only gills are present on those body segments. Legs 5-7 are powerful, extended laterally and end in large grasping claws for clinging to the skin of their cetacean hosts.

Several species occur in the region, each distinguished largely by the form of the gills, as well as by association with particular hosts. In this species the gills each consist of two elongate ‘sausages’ with a pair of shorter crescent-shaped accessory gills at their bases. This is one of three whale louse species associated with Southern right whales.
taxon_text_3_147:
Global: Widespread across North and South Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean and Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_148:
One of several local cyamid amphipods that have parasitic relationships with different cetaceans, most species being associated with only one, or a small group of closely-related hosts.

 Whale lice tend to favour areas where they obtain some shelter from water currents, for example around the blow-holes, genital or other body opening, in wounds and especially around the callosities of right whales. Also in areas previously infested with whale barnacles (Coronula diadema). The entire life-cycle occurs on the host, with juveniles simply moving from the brood pouch of adult females directly onto the adjacent skin. Transfer between individual hosts presumably only occurs when hosts touch one another.

Genetic relationships between parasites collected from different whale populations can be used to infer how connected these populations are and suggest that Northern and Southern hemisphere populations have exchanged parasites within the past 1-2 million years.
taxon_text_5_149: Cyamids are thought feed on algae that settle on the body of the host, but also ingest skin flakes and tissue around wounds. They are not though to cause significant damage to their hosts.
taxon_text_6_150: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_151:
This group is very easily recognised by their compact, flattened bodies, absence of third and fourth pair of legs and grasping posterior limbs, as well of course by their unique associations with cetaceans.

Three species of whale lice are found associated with Southern right whales, but of these this is the only species with two equal primary gill lobes. The other species have only one primary gill lobe (plus small crescentic lobes at base of each). They are C. gracilis, which has a narrow, almost parallel-sided body and short gills (each as long as only 2 body segments) and C. erraticus, which has much longer gills (as long as 4 body segments).
taxon_text_8_152:
Kaliszewska, ZA, Seger, JON, Rowntree, VJ, Barco, SG, Benegas, R, Best, PB, et al. (2005). Population histories of right whales (Cetacea: Eubalaena) inferred from mitochondrial sequence diversities and divergences of their whale lice (Amphipoda: Cyamus). Molecular Ecology, 14(11), 3439-3456.

Leung, YM (1967). An illustrated key to the species of whale-lice (Amphipoda, Cyamidae), ectoparasites of Cetacea, with a guide to the literature. Crustaceana, 12(3), 279-291.
taxon_text_1_154:
Relatively large, laterally-flattened, smooth-bodied, shrimp-like amphipod. Colour palepinkish, densely speckled with brown spots. Eyes white with red centres. Antennae similar in length, but second pair densely hairy in males, which also have dense fringes of hairs along ventral margins of side plates. Claws moderate in size, first pair slightly smaller than the second. First two pairs of legs contain cloud-like silk glands. Last pair of abdominal appendages (uropod 3) with characteristic short, paddle-like branches, the outer branch armed with two large, terminal, hook-like spines. 

Best recognized by its habit of constructing cylindrical nests woven from algal debris and incorporated into seagrass or algal beds in estuaries and on sheltered sandbanks.
taxon_text_2_155: Large for an amphipod, body length up to about 20 mm, excluding antennae.
taxon_text_3_156:
Global: Supposedly widespread across north Atlantic, Mediterranean, Red Sea, Gulf of Mexico, South Atlantic and round southern Africa, but in reality this is a European name and specimens from other regions probably belong to undescribed regional species.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_157:
Global:  Supposedly widespread across north Atlantic, Mediterranean, Red Sea, Gulf of Mexico, South Atlantic and round southern Africa, but in reality this is a European name and specimens from other regions probably belong to undescribed regional species.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to Mozambique.
taxon_text_5_158: Not known, but assumed to feed on algae.
taxon_text_6_159: Males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released. There seems to be an element of parental care in this species, as quite large juveniles are often found sharing nests with adults.
taxon_text_7_160: Only one named species of Cymadusa is found in the region and this is currently known as C. filosa. Recent research has, however, suggested that the true C. filosa is a European species and that specimens reported from various locations in the southern hemisphere, including Australia, Madagascar and South Africa, in fact each belong to a variety of other regional species. Two such as yet un-named species are thought to occur in South Africa, the one described here and another larger darker brown species found under boulders only on the west coast of the Cape Peninsula.  Work is currently under way to describe and name these species.
taxon_text_8_161:
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 25).

Peart, RA (2004). A revision of the Cymadusa filosa complex (Crustacea: Amphipoda: Corophioidea: Ampithoidae). Journal of Natural History, 38(3), 301-336.
taxon_text_1_163: Small, but very conspicuous and much photographed species with characteristic rounded, almost bean–like body shape, red eyes, short antennae and greatly enlarged side plates 3-4, which together form a shield covering sides of the body. Colour pattern unmistakable, banded in brilliant yellow and black. Abdomen tucked under the body when alive, enhancing the spherical shape.
taxon_text_3_165:
Global: Widespread  across Indo-Pacific extending to Namibia.

Local/Regional: KwaZulu-Natal to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_166: A common species on shallow reefs, where it moves around brazenly in the open, clearly defended by its bright warning colouration, which presumably warns predators that it is distasteful.
taxon_text_5_167: Appear to feed on the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum, which occurs only on the shells of the whelk Burnupena papyracea. Often seen gathered in large numbers on these whelks. Exactly what chemical are sequestered from the bryozoan and how these are involved in protecting the amphipod are unknown, but would make for a fascinating study.
taxon_text_6_168: As with all amphipods the eggs are released into a brood pouch between the legs of the female, where they are fertilized by males and develop into fully-formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_169: The only local species in the genus and unmistakable. Many of the images of this species from the Pacific show very different colouration, suggesting that more than one species may be subsumed under this one name.
taxon_text_8_170:
Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_172:
Squat, rotund amphipod with truncated head bearing very large, vertically- elongated eyes; antennae very short in females, much longer in males. First two pairs of legs without nippers and remaining legs held splayed and more or less all similar in length. Colour fairly transparent with brown or orange speckles, eyes sometimes green.

Perhaps most easily identified by its association with large jellyfish.
taxon_text_3_174:
Global: Widespread in North and South Atlantic Ocean.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_175:
One of several hyperiid amphipods that have parasitic relationships with large jellyfish (as well as with salps and ctenophores) and commonly found in the bells of compass jellyfish (Chrysaora species). The amphipods are facultative parasites when adult (in other words they also live outside of jellyfish), but the relationship is obligate in juveniles. There is a tendency for the amphipods to move to the gonads of the host as it becomes larger, the reason being that the gonad tissue provides higher carbon and protein concentrations than other tissues.

 In the North Sea the relationship is strongly seasonal with jellyfish being much more heavily parasitised in late summer and autumn, when they are larger and sexually mature. In Namibia, infection rates were low (4%) in summer, but much higher (38%) in winter, suggesting that the jellyfish may breed at that time, which correlates with their generally larger sizes in winter.
taxon_text_5_176: Hyperiids may feed on prey caught by the jellyfish and are sometimes found on their feeding arms, but also feed on the host tissue, particularly the gonads.
taxon_text_6_177: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_178: This group is fairly easily recognised by the compact, humped body form, very large eyes and association with jellyfish. However, several species of Hyperia and related genera have been reported from the region, so not all specimens found associated with jellyfish may belong to this particular species.
taxon_text_8_179: Buecher, E, Sparks, C, Brierley, A, Boyer, H, & Gibbons, M (2001). Biometry and size distribution of Chrysaora hysoscella (Cnidaria, Scyphozoa) and Aequorea aequorea (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa) off Namibia with some notes on their parasite Hyperia medusarum. Journal of Plankton Research, 23(10), 1073-1080.
taxon_text_1_181: Fairly-large and robust pink amphipod with rather short, equal antennae. Best identified by the unusual form of the nippers (gnathopods). The first pair of nippers has a unique form in which the ‘finger’ is formed by both of the last two segments, which close against a ‘palm’ formed by an extension of the third-last segment. Second pair of nippers are unusually powerful, but conventional in form (subchelate), palm without teeth. Third abdominal side-plate with square corner.
taxon_text_3_183:
Global: Widespread across Atlantic, Southern and Indian Oceans.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_184: Commensal in the cavities within sponges and tunicates.
taxon_text_5_185: Assumed to scavenger on food particles pumped thought he internal cavities of sponges and tunicates, within which the amphipods dwell.
taxon_text_6_186: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release.
taxon_text_7_187: In South Africa this family is represented by only the one genus Leucothoe, with five fairly-similar species that are distinguished by the length of the antennae, shape and numbers of teeth on the palm of the second pair of nippers and shape of third abdominal side plate. This species is identified by its relatively short antennae, lack of teeth on the second nipper and square corner to third side plate.
taxon_text_8_188:
Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 96).

Griffiths, C. L. (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 52).
taxon_text_1_190: Colour variable, but usually off-white with brown dorsal saddles. Sturdy and hard-bodied with elongate, protective side plates. Antennae both short, the first pair with particularly short, thick basal segments. Eyes dark and vertically elongated. First pair of legs (gnathopod 1) lacking nippers. Side plate of third abdominal segment rounded. Telson rounded, without medial notch or slit.
taxon_text_3_192:
Global: Widespread in Europe, South Africa and Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_193: Common under intertidal boulders, in sand and gravel and among seaweeds, etc.
taxon_text_5_194: Assumed to be a scavenger of seaweeds.
taxon_text_6_195: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release.
taxon_text_7_196: One of many easily-confused compact and hard-bodied species within this diverse family, indeed it is unlikely that South African and European forms bearing this name are really the same species. In the closely related L. variegata the third abdominal side plate is extended into an upturned tooth and the telson is apically notched.
taxon_text_8_197:
Branch G, Griffiths CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 94).

Griffiths, C. L. (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 59).
taxon_text_1_199: Body uniform orange in colour. Antenna 1 longer than 2, base of antenna 2 strongly setose. First two pairs of legs (gnathopods 1 and 2) with small elongate nippers. Last pair of legs enormously fat, with broad, flattened segments. Last pair of abdominal appendages with two short branches, the outer one ending two large upturned spines.
taxon_text_3_201:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution from Gqeberha to Cape Town.
taxon_text_4_202: Appears to occur mainly on Hanging Wrack (Brassicophycus brassicaeformis) where it makes small woven nests between the branches of the fronds.  Like in other amphithoids, there are spinning glands in the anterior walking legs which can spin silky threads used to construct the nests. The function of the highly unusual and greatly widened last pair of legs is unknown.
taxon_text_5_203: Probably feeds on the living tissue of the host alga Brassicophycus brassicaeformis.
taxon_text_6_204: Like all amphipods the eggs are released in to a brood-pouch  situated ventrally between the legs, where they are fertilized by the male and retained until they have developed into fully-formed young.
taxon_text_7_205: This is the only species in the genus, but it has been suggested that it should be incorporated into the genus Sunamphitoe, where it would still be distinguished by the uniquely enlarged last pair of legs.
taxon_text_8_206:
Griffiths CL (1979). A redescription of the kelp curler Amphitoe humeralis (Crustacea, Amphipoda) from South Africa and its relationship to Macropisthopus. Annals of the South African Museum 79 (5), 131-138.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_208: Most easily identified by its unusual ‘mobile home’ constructed of shells and gravel particles and shaped like a Y, with the two lateral branches each formed of a single flat piece. The animal itself is cylindrical and elongated in shape, with short legs and a reduced abdomen, the last few segments of which are bent forwards beneath the body. The last two pairs of abdominal appendages (uropods) are greatly reduced. The second pair of antennae is long and thickened and is used for locomotion (see below).
taxon_text_2_209: Up to about 6 mm, excluding elongate antennae.
taxon_text_3_210:
Global: South Africa, Red Sea.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana.
taxon_text_4_211: A very interesting and charismatic species only recently discovered in the region. The tubular body is concealed within the main stem of the characteristic Y-shaped tube. This is made of a variety of found items, including shell and stone particles, pieces of barnacle or polychaete tube, etc. The animal either moves slowly along by reaching out and pulling itself forward with the enlarged antennae, or by flicking the antennae downwards against the sand and flipping the tube backwards (hence the common name ‘jumping sand’).
taxon_text_5_212: Unknown; probably a detritus feeder consuming dead organic material on the sand surface.
taxon_text_6_213: Like all amphipods the eggs are held in a ventral marsupium between the walking legs, where they develop into fully formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_214: There is another regional species in the genus, but this make soft tubes out of fine particles glued together with secretions make by silk-glands in the legs and does not show the flipping behaviour so characteristic of jumping sand.
taxon_text_8_215:
Milne, R, & Griffiths, CL (2013). Additions to and revisions of the amphipod (Crustacea: Amphipoda) fauna of South Africa, with a list of currently known species from the region. African Natural History, 9(1), 61–90.

Just, J (1988). Siphonoecetinae (Corophiidae) 6: a survey of phylogeny, distribution, and biology. Crustaceana. Supplement 13: 193–208.

Jones, G. (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group (p.94).
taxon_text_1_217: Laterally flattened with distinctive flat-lying dorsal tooth projecting from posterior margins of pleon (abdomen) segments 1 and 2, after which the species is named. Colour in life an unusual pale blue with wine-red stripes on antennae, anterior appendages and across first thoracic segment, Antennae more of less equal and about 2/3 body length, first two legs (gnathopods) with small claws. Uropods (appendages of last three abdominal segments) elongate and pointed.
taxon_text_3_219:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Still Bay to Lüderitz (Namibia).
taxon_text_4_220: Usually found under boulders, especially in sand-inundated areas. Nothing more known about habits.
taxon_text_6_222: As with all amphipods, the eggs are help in a ventral marsupium between the walking legs, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_223: One other much more common species in the region, P. capensis, but this lacks the two dorsal teeth on pleon and is pale to red and not blue.
taxon_text_8_224:
Barnard, KH (1932). Amphipoda. Discovery Reports, 5, 1-326.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_226: Laterally flattened, shrimp-like species, lacking any dorsal teeth on body. Colour variable, but typically pale, often with red bands across the back and sides on each segment. Antennae more or less equal and about 2/3 body length. Eyes distinctive, large, elongated vertically and red to black, almost meeting on top of head. Gnathopods (claws) on tips of legs 1 and 2 small. Uropods (appendages of last three body segments) elongate and pointed. Telson (tail – flap) medially slit, end of each lobe cut into several distinct teeth.
taxon_text_3_228:
Global: Atlantic and Indo-Pacific.

Local/Regional:  Found along entire coastline of southern Africa.
taxon_text_4_229: One of the most common of all regional amphipod species, occurring in large numbers among seaweeds and also swimming in open water, especially at night. Given the great variability in colour and diversity of habitat apparently occupied, it is possible that more than one species is actually represented under this one name.
taxon_text_5_230: Unknown; probably either a herbivore or detritus feeder consuming dead algae.
taxon_text_6_231: Like all amphipods the eggs are held in a ventral marsupium between the walking legs, where they develop into fully formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_232: One of over 50 species globally in this genus, but only one of these, P. bidentata occurs in the region. That species can be distinguished by having a flat-lying dorsal tooth on the posterior margin of pleon (abdominal) segments 1 and 2 and by its unusual blue colour when alive.
taxon_text_8_233:
Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum.
taxon_text_1_235:
Delicate, laterally-flattened and shrimp-like with large black eyes and elongate, setose antennae. Nippers of legs 1 and 2 small, remaining legs unusual in that they each end in a minute claw (used to grip the sides of the burrow).

Perhaps best recognized in the field by the unusual habit of occupying semicircular burrows excavated into the surfaces of compound ascidians.
taxon_text_3_237:
Global: Tropical Indian Ocean through to Namibia.

Local/Regional: Mozambique to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_238: Excavate shallow burrows into the surfaces of compound ascidians, within which they lie upside down, with the legs pointing upwards. The pleopods are then beaten to create a water current from which food particles are filtered. The small claws on the walking legs are used to grip the sides of the burrows and to close these when disturbed. Can be very common, with several individuals per square centimeter of host surface.
taxon_text_5_239: Presumed to pump water through the burrow by constant beating of the abdominal appendages (pleopods) and to filter food particles from the water stream using the setose antennae.
taxon_text_6_240: As with all amphipods, the eggs are extruded into a marsupial chamber beneath the legs of females, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_241: There are some 25 species in this genus, all with similar habits, but this is the only one found in the region. No other regional amphipod species occupy this unusual habitat.
taxon_text_8_242:
Foster, JM & Thoma, BP (2016). Polycheria josephensis, a new species of symbiotic amphipod (Crustacea, Amphipoda, Dexaminidae) from the Northern Gulf of Mexico, with notes on its ecology. Zoosystematics and Evolution, 92(1), 23-31.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 38).
taxon_text_1_244: Extraordinary, transparent, cylindrical planktonic amphipod in which the head has become enormously extended to about half the length of the entire body! The elongate main part of the head has a medial swelling which bears very large eyes and beyond this projects a very long, spike-like rostrum. The walking legs are short and held folded close to the body, but the branched abdominal appendages (uropods) are again extremely elongate and trail behind the body.
taxon_text_3_246:
Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Entire region.
taxon_text_4_247: One of the most bizarre of all amphipods and found swimming in the plankton. The large eyes presumably allow the animal to have a wide field of vision and avoid predators and/or spot prey, while the very thin, elongate body would be very streamlined for swimming. The long rostrum may be a mechanism to make the amphipod more difficult for predators to swallow. Very little else is known about the biology.
taxon_text_6_249: Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_250: This group is easily recognised by the extremely elongate cylindrical body and enormously enlarged pointed rostrum. There are three similar species in the region though. Of these R. whitei has a much shorter short rostral spike but even more elongate uropods.
taxon_text_8_251: Stebbing, TRR (1888). Report on the Amphipoda collected by H.M.S. Challenger during the years 1873-1876. Report on the Scientific Results of the Voyage of H.M.S. Challenger during the years 1873–76. Zoology. 29 (part 67): i-xxiv, 1-1737, pl. 1-212.
taxon_text_9_252: This species has a complicated history as far as names are concerned. It was first reported in South Africa by Griffiths (1979), who identified it as Amphithoe humeralis, a species previously known only from the Pacific coast of North America. However, Milne and Griffiths (2013) concluded that it merited separation from that northern hemisphere species, which had in the interim been moved to the genus Peramphithoe, and thus re-named the South African form as P. africana. To further complicate matters Peart (2017) amalgamated Peramphithoe into the genus Sunamphitoe, so the species now becomes S. africana!
taxon_text_1_253:
Relatively large, laterally-flattened, smooth-bodied, pale amphipod. Claws moderate in size, first pair slightly smaller than the second. Tips of posterior pairs legs bearing strongly-curved claws (presumably to grip kelp fronds for nest-making). Last pair of abdominal appendages (uropod 3) with characteristic short, paddle-like branches, the outer branch armed with two large, terminal, hook-like spines. 

Best recognized by its habit of constructing nests by folding over the tips of the secondary fronds of the kelp Ecklonia maxima and sealing these together with silk to form tubular nests.
taxon_text_2_254: Large for an amphipod, body length up to 15 mm, excluding antennae.
taxon_text_3_255:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_256:
Originally discovered in 1978 and described in 1979 from samples collected at Oudekraal, on the Cape Peninsula, and fairly common at that time (136 specimens collected!). Surprisingly, the species has hardly ever been seen since, despite considerable research being undertaken on kelps and their associated fauna in the region.

 The biology is very distinctive, adults folding over the tips of kelp fronds and gluing these together some 20 mm above the fold, thus make a tubular home, which they then consume from the inside, progressively moving the occupied chamber backwards along the frond as they consume its tip. Chambers contained up to 121 individuals, comprising usually 2-3 adults and their developing young.
taxon_text_5_257: Feeds on fronds of kelp that form the walls of the chamber.
taxon_text_6_258: Males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released. There seems to be an element of parental care in this species, as quite large juveniles are often found sharing nests with adults.
taxon_text_8_260:
Griffiths, CL (1979). A redescription of the kelp curler Ampithoe humeralis (Crustacea, Amphipoda) from South Africa and its relationship to Macropisthopous. Annals of the South African Museum, 79, 131-138.

Milne, R & Griffiths, CL (2013). Additions to and revisions of the amphipod (Crustacea: Amphipoda) fauna of South Africa, with a list of currently known species from the region. African Natural History, 9, 61-90.

Peart, RA (2017). Analysis of the genus Sunamphitoe Spence Bate, 1857 (Amphipoda: Ampithoidae) with descriptions of eight new species. Zootaxa, 4269(3), 301.
taxon_text_1_271: Highly unusual amphipods with flattened body shape, making them easily to mistake as being isopods (but have unmistakably amphipod limb structures). Antennae very short, walking limbs lack nippers and spayed out sideways to grip substratum. Abdominal appendages greatly reduced. Colour characteristic – red-brown with rows of flourescent bright blue dots along the back.
taxon_text_4_274: Found in small groups clinging to the underside of boulders or to rock surfaces intertidally and on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_5_275: Biology unknown, but are slow moving and sedentary, walking slowly away when disturbed or exposed. Food unknown, but probably consists of benthic invertebrates such as hydroids, bryozoans or colonial ascidians, on which they are found.
taxon_text_6_276: Like in all amphipods, the eggs are held in a marsupium between the walking legs of females and grow there into fully-developed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_277: There are only two species in this genus, both of which are endemic to South Africa. The other species, T. hystrix, has a series of strong upright dorsal projections along the centre of the back.
taxon_text_8_278:
Barnard, KH (1916). Contributions to the Crustacean Fauna of South Africa n° 5. The Amphipoda. Annals of the South African Museum, 15(3), 105-302

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Griffiths, CL (1975). The Amphipoda of South Africa, Part 5. The Gammaridea and Caprellidea of the Cape Province west of Cape Agulhas. Annals of the South African Museum, 67 (5), 91-181 (see p. 172, Fig. 21)
taxon_text_1_280: Unusually short, stout-bodied amphipod with wide, hairy legs that curve around to form a cavity beneath the body. Antennae short and eyes small in females, but antenna 2 much longer and eyes much larger in males. The 5th pair of legs particularly broad and last segment bearing about 7 sharp spines along anterior margin. Abdominal appendages strong and used to propel a stream of water beneath body and thus drive the animal forwards though the sediment.
taxon_text_3_282:
Global: Europe, Mediterranean and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_283: Burrows through sand on beaches and sheltered lagoons much like a mole. The short, wide body and wide legs enclose a tunnel-like ventral space beneath the body and beating of the strong abdominal appendages within this chamber creates a strong water current which drives the animal forward within the sand.
taxon_text_5_284: Assumed to scavenger on food particles attached to sand grains that are pumped thought the ventral body cavity by beating of the abdominal appendages.
taxon_text_6_285: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release. Reproduction has not been studied in South African populations, but in European species the number of eggs is low at about 15 per brood, maturity is reached in about five months and longevity seldom exceeds one year.
taxon_text_7_286: The group is fairly easily identified by the unusually short, squat body and wide legs highly adapted for the burrowing lifestyle. In South Africa this genus is represented by at least 8 similar species that differ mainly in the width and shape of the segments on the 5th (and sometimes 6th and 7th) walking legs. This species is unusual in having a row of about 7 anterior spines along the last segment of leg 5. For a full key to species see Griffiths reference below.
taxon_text_8_287:
Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 46).
taxon_text_1_298:
Spiders as a group can be easily identified by the fact that the body is divided into just two sections – an anterior prosoma (equivalent to a fused head and thorax) and an opisthosoma or abdomen. The prosoma bears a pair of poison fangs, a pair of leg-like feelers called pedipalps and four pairs of jointed legs. Another characteristic feature is the presence of silk glands in the abdomen.

This species can be identified by its huge fangs, which make up about a third of the body length, by the shiny brown prosoma and furry grey abdomen and by it unusual intertidal habits.
taxon_text_3_300:
Global: South Africa and Namibia.

Local/Regional: Approximately East London to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_301: Common in the mid to upper intertidal, especially on boulder shores, where they construct silken nests in crevices and particularly under the empty shells of mussels and limpets. Air is trapped in these nests and the spiders shelter there during high tide. When the tide is low and especially at night they emerge to hunt for prey, particularly small crustaceans.
taxon_text_5_302: Feed on small crustaceans, particularly isopods and amphipods.
taxon_text_6_303: Eggs are laid in the nests, which are constructed by a single female. Each nest consists of a series of wedge-shaped egg sacs that fit together within a crevice or empty shell.  Not all the egg sacs contain eggs and it is thought that the extras sacs act as ‘red-herrings’ to reduce the likely-hood of egg parasitism by the parasitic wasp Echthrodesis lamorali, which appears to be unique to this host and highly specialised habitat.  The number of eggs per nest averages 41, but can be as high as 226. The pale eggs hatch directly into tiny white spiderlings and where eggs go brown this is indicative they have been parasitized.
taxon_text_7_304: Occurs together with and could be confused with the other common intertidal spider in the region, Amourobiodes africana, but that species is darker brown, has much smaller jaws and has chevron pattern on the abdomen.
taxon_text_8_305:
Lamoral, BH (1968). On the ecology and habitat adaptations of two intertidal spiders, Desis formidabilis (OP Cambridge) and Amaurobioides africanus Hewitt, at" The Island"(Kommetjie, Cape Peninsula), with notes on the occurrence of two other spiders. Annals of the Natal Museum, 20(1), 151-193.

Owen, CA, van Noort, S, Compton, SG, & Coetzee, JA (2019). Nest site choice by the intertidal spider Desis formidabilis (Araneae: Desidae) and nest utilisation by its hymenopteran egg parasitoid. Ecological Entomology, 44(1), 62-70.
taxon_text_1_307:
Beetles of the family Staphylinidae (‘rove beetles’) are fairly easily recognized as a group, in that most have elongate, narrow bodies and very short wing-covers, leaving the long abdomen largely exposed. However, many species are small and the family is very diverse, so species level identification can be challenging.

This species is larger than most, uniformly black, and fairly easily recognised by the very strongly punctate (dimpled) texture of the wing covers (elytra) and to a lesser extent of the abdomen, which also ends of an unusually long tuft of setae.
taxon_text_3_309:
Global: Atlantic coasts of Europe and Africa, including Mediterranean and Baltic Sea.

Local/Regional: Not well known, but fairly common along west coast.
taxon_text_4_310: Little known about this species in South Africa other than that it restricted to the seashore and is regularly recorded among drift kelp. In Europe known to be a predator of kelp flies and of their larvae and abundance is correlated to that of the prey.
taxon_text_5_311: Feeds on kelp flies and their larvae.
taxon_text_6_312: The South African species has not been studied, but most staphylinids lay their eggs attached to objects in their habitat, such as kelp in this case. Their larvae are grub-like and also predatory.
taxon_text_7_313: Staphylinid beetles are extremely common in intertidal habitats and hundreds of coastal species are known globally. The South African fauna is poorly described and many species probably remain un-named. Although several other staphylinid species are found associated with rotting algae in the region this one is fairly easily recognized by its punctate elytra.
taxon_text_8_314:
Frank, JH, & Ahn, KJ (2011). Coastal Staphylinidae (Coleoptera): A worldwide checklist, biogeography and natural history. ZooKeys, 107, 1-98.

Hodge, S & Williams, A (2007). Coleoptera found in wrack beds and strandlines around the Kent coast. British Journal of Entomology and Natural History, 20, 61-70.

Stenton-Dozey, JME, & Griffiths, CL (1983). The fauna associated with kelp stranded on a sandy beach. In Sandy beaches as ecosystems (pp. 557-568). Springer, Dordrecht.
taxon_text_1_316: Tiny, plump, wingless, slate-blue animal covered with short hydrophobic hairs which allow it to float on the water surface. The head has small eyes and short antennae, the thorax three pairs of short, stumpy legs and the abdomen six plump segments. The ventral furca, which is the most distinctive feature of most collembolans, is vestigial in this species, which thus is unable to jump.
taxon_text_3_318:
Global: Cosmopolitan.

Local/Regional: Throughout the region, mostly on intertidal rocks.
taxon_text_4_319: Common in the upper intertidal zone on both rocky shores and saltmarshes, boulder beaches, etc. Shelters in cavities such as rock crevices and dead barnacle shells when the tide is in and emerges at low tide to scavenge dead animals. Often see floating in rafts of many individuals together on the surfaces of high-shore rock pools.
taxon_text_5_320: Feed on dead or dying animal material, such as barnacles, drowning beach-hoppers, etc.
taxon_text_6_321: Males deposit a spermatophore on the substratum and the females move over this and pick it up to fertilise their eggs. Eggs are laid in shelters and hatch directly into the adult form.
taxon_text_7_322: Although there are many other collembolans in the region, including some found on the surface of freshwater, this is the only species so far reported from rocky shores. The fact that it does not leap, which is so characteristic of most other springtails, also is a useful aid to identification.
taxon_text_8_323:
McMeechan, FK, Manica, A, & Foster, WA (2000). Rhythms of activity and foraging in the intertidal insect Anurida maritima: coping with the tide. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 80(1), 189-190.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 74).
taxon_text_1_325: Cumaceans are a fairly common group of small crustaceans, but are seldom noticed because of their small size. As a group, they can be readily identified by their distinctive body shape, which consists  of an enlarged, often markedly-swollen and ornamented carapace, followed by a long, slender body that ends in a single pair of elongate ‘tails’ or uropods. This species can be distinguished by its smooth carapace and body and by a distinct antennal notch in the front margin of the carapace.
taxon_text_3_327:
Global: Tropical west Africa to about False Bay.

Local/Regional: False Bay westwards and northwards.
