taxon_text_4_328: Habits not well known, but assumed to burrow in sand and to either filter-feed or scrape organic matter from sand grains. Many cumaceans emerge from the sediments at night to swim in the water column, but it is not know if this species does so.
taxon_text_5_329: Feeds on fine organic matter in the sediments.
taxon_text_6_330: All cumaceans retain the eggs in a marsupial chamber between the legs of females until they are almost fully developed and are missing only their last pair of adult legs.
taxon_text_7_331: There are over 80 described species of cumaceans in South Africa, 45 of which were presented as new in the only significant review of this group by J. Day in the 1978. This is indicative of how little is know about the regional fauna. As a result only this one image is available and only one entry is provided here.
taxon_text_8_332:
Day, JA (1975). South African Cumacea 1. Family Bodotriidae, subfamily Vaunthompsoniinae. Annals of the South African Museum, 66 (9), 177–220.

Day, JA (1978). South African Cumacea. PhD thesis, Zoology Department, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_334: Dark, flattened flies with a plain black thorax, clear grey wings and hairy legs. Best identified by their habitat, which is restricted to beaches, especially those where large amounts of kelp are washed ashore. Can attain very high densities when food is abundant. Distinguished from the other common kelp fly in the region (Fucellia capensis) by the lack of longitudinal stripes on the thorax.
taxon_text_3_336:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Western Cape, restricted to the upper shore.
taxon_text_4_337: Associated with draft seaweeds on the coastline. Reluctant to fly and when disturbed typically remain close to the sand, moving only a few metres before settling again. Can swarm in large numbers when conditions are favourable and become a nuisance to beach users. Larvae found in large numbers in moist piles of rotting kelp.
taxon_text_5_338: Adults probably feed on the mucus exuded by rotting kelps. Larva consume decomposing kelps and may be important agents in their decay and disappearance from beaches.
taxon_text_6_339: Eggs are laid singly on the surfaces of kelps cast up on the driftline. The decomposition of the kelp keeps temperatures elevated and may speed up larval development.  Pupae are often washed out on the next set off high spring tides and may be found in large numbers along the driftline. Larval and pupal stages each about two weeks in duration.
taxon_text_7_340: Often occur at the same sites as another kelp fly Fucellia capensis, which has very similar habits, but can be distinguished by having four pale longitudinal stripes along the thorax.
taxon_text_8_341:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.(p. 78).

Picker, MD, Griffiths, CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 346).
taxon_text_1_343: Rather non-descript dark-grey fly with four indistinct longitudinal stripes along thorax. Wings light brown. Best identified by its close association with kelps washed up on sandy beaches and distinguished from the other common kelp fly in the region (Coelopa africana) by the longitudinal stripes on its thorax.
taxon_text_3_345:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: shoreline of Western Cape northwards to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_346: Closely associated with kelp wrack, where it breeds in large numbers, sometimes reaching nuisance levels. Prefer deep drifts of wrack, where moisture levels remain high. Larvae are often washed out of the kelp at high spring tides and are much sought after as food by gulls, ibises and other coastal birds.
taxon_text_5_347: Adults probably fed on mucus exuded by kelps and larvae feed on piles of rotting kelp.
taxon_text_6_348: Eggs are laid single on drift kelp and hatch within 24-32 hours. There are three larval stages, which together take about 14 days to complete. Larvae eat about 1.5 times their body weight in kelp each day. The papal stage then lasts another 9 -14 days, so the new generation of adults emerge almost exactly one month after the eggs were laid. The pupae are buoyant and may be washed up along the driftline in large numbers.
taxon_text_7_349: Easily confused with and occur together with another kelp fly Coelopa africana, but that species has a plain black thorax without longitudinal stripes.
taxon_text_8_350:
Picker, MD, Griffiths, CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 350).

Stenton-Dozey, J & Griffiths, CL (1980). Growth, consumption and respiration by larvae of the kelp-fly Fucellia capensis. South African Journal of Zoology, 15, 280-283.
taxon_text_1_352: Tiny, flattened, red, elongate-oval benthic copepods with very short antennae. Best identified in the field by their habit of scuttling around in large numbers on the fronds of tongue-weed Gigartina polycarpa and other similar flat-bladed algae. Barely at the limit of visibility with the naked eye, so often overlooked, but extremely common once noticed.
taxon_text_3_354:
Global: Thought to be endemic (but very poorly studied).

Local/Regional: Algoa Bay to at least Cape Peninsula, probably extending up west coast.
taxon_text_4_355: Development typically takes 3-4 weeks and the adults live a few months.  This species is extremely abundant on the frond of intertidal seaweeds and migrates out along the fronds when underwater, then moved back to the bases when in the air.
taxon_text_5_356: Thought to feed on fine organic matter, probably including bacteria, protozoa, mucus, etc.
taxon_text_6_357: Sexes are separate and copulating pairs are commonly seen. The male deposits sperm in a spermatophore that is cemented to the genital opening of the female and the eggs are fertilized as they are laid. They are then held in a single ventral sac while they develop.
taxon_text_7_358: Benthic copepods are very poorly studied in the region, but are commonly seen on the undersides of rocks, on shells and algae etc, so there are likely many other species that remain un-described.
taxon_text_8_359:
Gibbons, MJ (1989). Tidal migration of Porcellidium (Copepoda: Harpacticoida) on fronds of the rocky shore alga Gigartina radula (Esper) J. Agardh (Gigartinales: Rhodophyta). South African Journal of Marine Science, 8(1), 3-7.

Hicks, GRF (1982). Porcellidiidae and Peltidiidae (Copepoda: Harpacticoida) from the marine algae of St Croix Island, Algoa Bay, South Africa. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, London, 75(1), 49-90.
taxon_text_1_370: Very diverse genus of relatively large, off-white isopods characterized by having five free abdominal segments and a distinct ‘tail-fan’ formed of a rounded to triangular pleotelson (ornamented in the various species with a variety of knobs, pustules, ridges or setae) and a sturdy pair of uropods with more-or-less equal branches. This species can be identified by its coarsely pitted body and triangular pleotelson with its single, small, central tubercle.
taxon_text_3_372:
Global: South Africa and St Paul and Amsterdam Islands.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_373: Poorly known, but one of several species of this genus common on rocky shores and on shallow subtidal reefs, all of which are thought to be scavengers.
taxon_text_5_374: Presumed to be either a predator and/or to scavenge on dead animal matter.
taxon_text_6_375: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_376: A very diverse genus including many common and easily confused species, including over 20 reported from South Africa. The single central tubercle on the pleotelson is unique to this species though.
taxon_text_8_377: Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 70).
taxon_text_1_379:
Very diverse genus of relatively large, off-white isopods characterized by having five free abdominal segments and a distinct ‘’tail-fan’ formed of a rounded to triangular pleotelson (ornamented with a variety of knobs, pustules, ridges or setae that distinguish the various species) and a sturdy pair of uropods with more-or-less equal length branches.

This species has finely crimped posterior margins to each thoracic segment. These become larger in each segment, becoming distinct teeth along each of the free abdominal segments. The pleotelson is long and pointed and had a pair of dorsal longitudinal ridges along it centre and fine crimp marking along its edges. The uropods have unusually broad and scoop-like outer branches.
taxon_text_3_381:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to East London.
taxon_text_4_382: Poorly known, but one of several species of this genus common on rocky shores and on shallow subtidal reefs, all of which are thought to be scavengers.
taxon_text_5_383: Presumed to be either a predator and/or to scavenge on dead animal matter.
taxon_text_6_384: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_385: A very diverse genus including many common and easily confused species, including over 20 reported from South Africa. The combination of crimped or toothed posterior margin of the last thoracic and all abdominal segments and pair of longitudinal ridges along pointed pleotelson are unique to this species though.
taxon_text_8_386:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa: additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum 10: 325–442.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 71).
taxon_text_1_388:
Very diverse genus of relatively large, off-white isopods characterized by having five free abdominal segments and a distinct ‘tail-fan’ formed of a rounded to triangular pleotelson (ornamented with a variety of knobs, pustules, ridges or setae that distinguish the various species) and a sturdy pair of uropods with more-or-less equal length branches.

This species is readily recognized by the saw-tooth like lines of dorsal tubercles along the posterior margins of the last thoracic segment and each of the free abdominal segments. The pleotelson also has a triangular tooth in its centre and the uropods have unusually broad and scoop-like outer branches. The specimen depicted belongs to the variety simplex, which has rather fewer teeth and a smoother pleotelson that the original form described by Stebbing.
taxon_text_3_390:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_391: Poorly known, but one of several species of this genus common on rocky shores and on shallow subtidal reefs, all of which are thought to be scavengers.
taxon_text_5_392: Presumed to be either a predator and/or to scavenge on dead animal matter.
taxon_text_6_393: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_394:
A very diverse genus including many common and easily confused species, including over 20 reported from South Africa. The combination of toothed posterior margin of the last thoracic and all abdominal segments and triangular central tooth on the pleotelson are unique to this species though.  

The variety simplex described by Barnard (1914) may eventually prove to represent a distinct species, but this needs to be tested by genetic analyses.
taxon_text_8_395:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa: additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum, 10, 325–442.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 71).
taxon_text_1_397: Unmistakable air-breathing isopod found abundantly on the upper intertidal levels of rocky shores and distinguished by the elongate paired ‘horns’ arising from the dorsal surface of each thoracic segment. The horns are typically much longer in adults and in males relative to females. Abdomen clearly segmented and uropods each with a single short ramus (as opposed to the pair of elongate rami in Ligia species, which share the same habitat).
taxon_text_3_399:
Global: Southern Africa and St Paul and Amsterdam Islands (those outlying populations probably represent a distinct species).

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Knysna.
taxon_text_4_400: Very common around the drift line of rocky shores wherever drift kelp is cast ashore, where they co-occur with the even more abundant Ligia species. Feed on drift kelp and other algae, and may also scavenge on dead animals. Most active at night, but also on cloudy days, moving down to the shore to feed and back above the high water mark to shelter during heat of the day. May migrate in formidable numbers.
taxon_text_5_401: Mainly kelp, but also other drift algae and organic debris.
taxon_text_6_402: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_403: The only member of the family Detonidae in South Africa and unlikely to be confused with other species due to the unusual dorsal ‘horns’. The populations on St Paul and Amsterdam Islands have dorsal spikes on the abdominal segments as well and thus are almost certainly a different species. Often found together with other air-breathing isopods of the genus Ligia, which lack horns and have long uropods with two elongate branches. Recent but still unpublished genetic data suggest that Deto populations from the west and south coasts in fact represent two separate species.
taxon_text_8_404:
Chilton, C (1915). Deto, a Subantarctic genus of terrestrial Isopoda. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 32(219), 435–456.

Glazier, DS, Clusella-Trullas, S, & Terblanche, JS (2016). Sexual dimorphism and physiological correlates of horn length in a South African isopod crustacean. Journal of Zoology, 300(2), 99–110.
taxon_text_1_406: Common and relatively large, smooth-bodied isopod that readily rolls into a ball when disturbed. Abdominal segments fused. Colouration variable, but usually mottled in browns and yellows. Most characteristic features are the unusually flatted body, rows of short longitudinal ridges on each thoracic segment; broadly triangular and bluntly–pointed pleotelson and truncated tips to the inner branches of the uropods.
taxon_text_3_408:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_409: Common under boulders on rocky shores and shallow reefs.
taxon_text_5_410: Not specifically known, but thought to feed on algae and possibly other organic debris.
taxon_text_6_411: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_412: There are 14 regional species in this common genus, all of which have an entire pleotelson (not distally rolled or notched). The various species are distinguished mainly by ornamentation and shape of the pleotelson and shape of the uropods. This species is particularly flat and has very broad uropods, but could easily be confused with several others, such as E. varicolor (which has two small dorsal ridges near base of pleotelson and rounded tips to uropods) and E. laeviusculum (semi-circle of small tubercles on pleotelson).
taxon_text_8_413:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 92).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 106).
taxon_text_1_415: Extremely common small, smooth-bodied isopod that readily rolls into a ball when disturbed. Abdominal segments fused with telson to form a ‘pleotelson’. Colouration vary variable, but usually fairly uniform yellows, browns or pinks, sometimes with broad white patch dorsally. Most characteristic features are the broadly-rounded, slightly truncated pleotelson (after which the species is named) and pointed tips to the uropods, which extend to at least tip of pleotelson.
taxon_text_2_416: Up to 8 mm excluding antennae, but mostly smaller.
taxon_text_3_417:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_418: An extremely common, but small species that occurs in enormous densities, especially under boulders on rocky shores and also in sand near to rocks. Particularly common far up into the intertidal, where it is one of few dominant species.
taxon_text_5_419: Feeds on drift kelp and other algae and organic debris that accumulate in rockpools, gullies and under boulders.
taxon_text_6_420: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_421: There are 14 regional species in this common genus, all of which have an entire pleotelson (not distally rolled or notched). The various species are distinguished mainly by ornamentation and shape of the pleotelson and shape of the uropods. This is the only species with a smooth, broadly-rounded pleotelson and pointed uropods.
taxon_text_8_422:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 92).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 106)
taxon_text_1_424:
Common, medium-sized, mostly smooth-bodied isopod that readily rolls into a ball when disturbed. Abdominal segments fused. Colouration very variable (hence the species name!), but usually banded, the front half of thorax and of abdomen usually brown and the central section of body and tips of uropods and pleotelson cream or yellow.

Best identified by form of pleotelson, which is triangular with a pair of small longitudinal dorsal ridges at its base. Uropods not reaching beyond tip of pleotelson.
taxon_text_3_426:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_427: Common under boulders and among seaweeds on rocky shores and shallow reefs.
taxon_text_5_428: Not specifically known, but thought to feed on algae and possibly other organic debris.
taxon_text_6_429: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_430: There are 14 regional species in this common genus, all of which have an entire pleotelson (not distally rolled or notched). The various species are distinguished mainly by ornamentation and shape of the pleotelson and shape of the uropods. This species is identified by the triangular pleotelson and its pair of small basal dorsal ridges.
taxon_text_8_431:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa: Additions to the marine isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum, 10, 325-442.

Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 92).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 107).
taxon_text_1_433: Body elongate, flattened and parallel-sided with a strong keel along the back that ends in a forward-directed spike (rostrum) on the head. Abdominal segments fused with telson to form a ‘pleotelson’. Pleotelson elongate, slightly tapering, with three partial crimp-like ‘sutures’ near base of either side (representing fused abdominal segments), distal margin slightly concave. Colouration strongly blotched in purples, pinks and browns.
taxon_text_3_435:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to Transkei coast.
taxon_text_4_436: Very common under intertidal boulders, usually singly or in small groups. Details of biology unknown.
taxon_text_5_437: Presumed to be herbivorous, like most other members of this family.
taxon_text_6_438: As with all isopods, the eggs are retained in a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_439: The only representative of this genus and unlikely to be confused with any other regional isopods due to unusual keeled body.
taxon_text_8_440:
Branch, G, Griffiths, C L, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 86).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 37).
taxon_text_1_28: Laterally flattened and shrimp-like, with distinctive gaudy colour pattern. Body vertically banded in purple and white, eyes white with black spots, bases of antennae and distal parts of legs orange-red. Second pair of nippers with enlarged hand, palm of hand oblique, finely serrated and with 2 sharp triangular teeth, one near base of finger and one at junction with hind margin. Abdominal segment 4 with a single dorsal tooth and segment 5 with a pair of small teeth. Third uropods elongate and with one very short, oval branch and one much longer one.
taxon_text_3_30:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Plettenberg Bay.
taxon_text_4_31: Poorly known, but the specimen depicted here was found in the shells of hermit crabs and may be a commensal in that habitat.
taxon_text_5_32: Unknown, probably herbivorous and/or detritus feeder, perhaps even feeding on faeces of hermit crabs, but this needs confirmation.
taxon_text_6_33: As in all amphipods males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_34: There are about a dozen regional species in the family Melitidae, these being characterized by the unusual form of the third uropod (one long branch and the other very short). Each species has teeth on the dorsal margin of some abdominal segments and they can be identified based on which segments bear teeth and numbers of teeth on each segment. This is the only regional species with one tooth on segment 4 and 2 teeth on segment 5. The colour pattern of live animals is also a useful identification feature and the bright colours of this species are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_35:
Barnard, KH (1955). Additions to the fauna-list of South African Crustacea and Pycnogonida. Annals of the South African Museum. 43: 1–107 (p. 91).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 54).
taxon_text_1_289:
Spiders as a group can be easily identified by having the body divided into just two sections – an anterior prosoma (equivalent to a fused head and thorax) and a posterior opisthosoma or abdomen. The prosoma bears a pair of poison fangs, a pair of leg-like feelers called pedipalps and four pairs of jointed legs. Another characteristic feature is the presence of silk glands in the abdomen.

This species can be identified by its unusual habitat, relatively small fangs, dark brown prosoma and by the distinctive chevron pattern on the dorsal surface of the pale abdomen, from which the common name is derived.
taxon_text_3_291:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_292: Confined to the upper parts of the intertidal zone, especially on boulder shores. Make silken nests in crevices or under boulders. The nests often incorporate the shells of limpets or mussels, which are stuck to the rocks with silk. The opening of the nest always faces downwards so that it traps air when submerged at high tide. The spiders shelter in their nests during high tide and emerge to hunt for prey during low tide and particularly at night.
taxon_text_5_293: Feeds mainly at night, either by sitting at the nest entrance and pouncing on passing prey, or by moving about in search of prey animals. Feeds mostly on small crustaceans, such as amphipods and isopods, but also intertidal midges and other smaller spiders.
taxon_text_6_294: Eggs are laid in the silken nests and hatch directly into tiny spiderlings.
taxon_text_7_295: Could be confused with the Formidable Shore Spider Desis formidabilis, which occurs in the same habitat and has similar nesting and feeding habits, but is smaller with much smaller fangs and is also distinguished by the distinctive chevron pattern on the abdomen.
taxon_text_8_296:
Lamoral, BH (1968). On the ecology and habitat adaptations of two intertidal spiders, Desis formidabilis (OP Cambridge) and Amaurobioides africanus Hewitt, at "The Island"(Kommetjie, Cape Peninsula), with notes on the occurrence of two other spiders. Annals of the Natal Museum, 20(1), 151-193.

Moloney, CL, & Nicolson, SW (1984). Water relations and haemolymph composition of two intertidal spiders (Order Araneae). Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 83(3), 275-284.
taxon_text_1_361: Head triangular with short antennae; body smooth, grey and flattened, legs ending in powerful hooked claws to grip on host. Abdomen clearly divided into five segments, ending on large rounded telson and pair of elongate lateral pleopods that extend well beyond end of body.
taxon_text_3_363:
Global: Regional endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to East London.
taxon_text_4_364:
Parasitic on seabreams (fishes of Family Sparidae), attaching to the head, usually above and behind the eye. The rasping mouthparts are used to gouge a hole in the skin allowing the parasite to feed on the host blood and tissue. The isopods change sex as they grow, starting life as males, then transitioning to become females as they become larger.

In a study of Cape seabreams (Pachymetopon blochii) in False Bay it was found that 5.2% of fish were infected with isopods. Of infected hosts, 33% had one parasite, 66% had two parasites and less than 2% had more than two parasites. Parasite size was correlated with host size and infected fish were in slightly lower body condition than unparasitised fish.
taxon_text_5_365: Feed on the living tissues of host fish.
taxon_text_6_366: Usually occur in pairs, comprising a larger female and much smaller male, both attached to the same host. The female has a large brood pouch into which she extrudes the eggs and the male then fertilizes these. The eggs are incubated on the brood pouch until the fully developed juveniles are released to seek out new hosts.
taxon_text_7_367: The most common and one of the largest of many parasitic isopods found externally on various fishes. Each parasite tends to only occur on specific host fish or families of fish.
taxon_text_8_368:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 86).

Wright, RV, Lechanteur, YARG, Prochazka, K & Griffiths, CL (2001). Infestation of the Cape Hottentot Pachymetopon blockii by the fish louse Anilocra capensis (Crustacea, Isopoda) in False Bay, South Africa. African Zoology, 36, 177–183.
taxon_text_1_442: Very unusual and strongly sexually dimorphic small isopods with only five pairs of legs. Males have large heads with huge forward-directed mandibles. Females have small heads and mid-section of body (formed of fused segments 2–5) is greatly inflated. Abdomen narrow with distinct segments. Larvae are parasitic on fishes, but adults are free living.
taxon_text_3_444:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Approximately Lambert’s Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_445: Larvae are temporary parasites of klipfish species, feeding on their blood. They go through several larval stages and need to take a blood meal to complete each stage, detaching from the fish after each meal and having to find a new host to complete the next larval stage. Adults are found in sponges in the intertidal as well as on tunicates and the tubes of serpulid worms. Larvae may also act as vectors for blood parasites that infect the fish.
taxon_text_5_446: Larvae are blood-feeders. Adults do not feed, despite their formidable looking jaws.
taxon_text_6_447: Eggs are retained within the swollen bodies of females rather than in a marsupium, as in most isopods. There are six larval stages and the entire lifecycle takes about 62 days at a temperature of 20–25°C.
taxon_text_7_448: The most common of several regional Gnathia species. Unlikely to be confused with any other isopods due to unusual, but different, body shapes of both sexes.
taxon_text_8_449:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa. 1. Additions to the marine Isopoda. Annals of the South African Museum. 10 (7): 197–230.

Smit, NJ, Van As, JG, & Basson, L (1999). A redescription of the adult male and praniza of Gnathia africana Barnard, 1914 (Crustacea, Isopoda, Gnathiidae) from southern Africa. Folia parasitologica, 46(3), 229-240.

Smit, NJ, Basson, L, & Van As, JG (2003). Life cycle of the temporary fish parasite, Gnathia africana (Crustacea: Isopoda: Gnathiidae). Folia parasitologica, 50(2), 135¬–142.
taxon_text_1_451: Tiny, parallel-sided isopod with reduced eyes and rectangular thoracic segments, the sides of the last few being bent backwards. Abdomen of one short free segment, remaining segments fused with telson to form a ‘pleotelson’. Pleotelson rounded. Body covered in fine pile of tiny hairs. Best identified by its unusual habitat within the brood pouches of larger isopods.
taxon_text_3_453:
Global: Widespread in Southern Hemisphere, including South America, South Africa, New Zealand, Tasmania and various subantarctic islands.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_454: May be found free-living, but usually recorded from within the brood pouches of larger sphaeromid isopods, such as Exosphaeroma, Parisocladus, Sphaeroma, Dymanenella and Sphaeromene. Up to 25 commensals may be found within the brood pouch of a single host, but these do not appear to detract from the development of host eggs.
taxon_text_5_455: Not known, but do not appear to damage the eggs of the host.
taxon_text_6_456: As with all isopods the eggs are retained in a brood pouch beneath the walking legs of females. Due to the small adult size, egg numbers are unusually low, with a maximum of only 14 eggs produced per female. Breeding is thought to be continuous throughout the year and lifespan is only about 7 months.
taxon_text_7_457: The unusual habitat and pubescent texture of the body mean that this species is unlikely to be confused with any other.
taxon_text_8_458:
Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isodods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 135).

Marsden, ID (1982). Population biology of the commensal asellotan Iais pubescens (Dana) and its sphaeromatid host Exosphaeroma obtusum (Dana)(Isopoda). Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 58(2–3), 233–257.
taxon_text_1_460:
Diverse genus of flatted, rounded isopods that quickly roll into a ball when disturbed. First five abdominal segments fused together, sixth segment fused to telson to form a ‘pleotelson’ the tips of which are characteristically rolled downwards in this genus to form a ‘gutter’. 

This species is identified by its smooth body, which lacks any tubercles or granules, and by its convex, domed pleotelson and the broadly rounded tips to the uropods. Colour can range from cream to pink or red.
taxon_text_2_461: Reported in literature to grow up to 18 mm (excluding antennae) but all examples we have seen are smaller than 10 mm.
taxon_text_3_462:
Global: Southern Africa, New Zealand and sub-Antarctic Islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_463: Poorly known, but found common amongst seaweeds and under boulders in intertidal and on shallow subtidal reefs.
taxon_text_6_465: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_466: There are 10 regional species in this genus, many of them common among intertidal algae. They are separated by body shape, dorsal ornamentation (smooth or with dorsal tubercles) and by pleotelson shape, ornamentation and type of terminal notch. The smooth body separates this species from all other regional representatives of the genus.
taxon_text_8_467:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 92).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 92).
taxon_text_1_469: Diverse genus of flatted, rounded isopods that roll into a ball when disturbed. First five abdominal segments fused together, sixth segment fused to telson to form a ‘pleotelson’ the tips of which are rolled downwards to form a ‘gutter’. This species is identified by its broad head (hence the species name), which is longer than the first thoracic segment, and by the pair of pronounced dorsal tubercles on the pleotelson. Colour generally mottled pink.
taxon_text_3_471:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_472: Poorly known, but found under boulders in intertidal and on shallow subtidal reefs.
taxon_text_6_474: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_475: There are 10 regional species in this genus, many of them common among intertidal algae. They are separated by body shape, dorsal ornamentation (smooth or with dorsal tubercles) and by pleotelson shape, ornamentation and type of terminal notch.
taxon_text_8_476: Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 92).
taxon_text_9_477: Genus and family incorrectly spelt as Jaeropsis and Jaeropsidae by Kensley and other authors.
taxon_text_1_478: Small, elongate and parallel-sided, flattened, off-white isopod. Antennae very short and kinked to the sides. A distinctive dark band extends across top of the head between the eyes. Lateral margins of body segments separated. Pleotelson broadly rounded. Very short uropods do not extend beyond tip of pleotelson.
taxon_text_3_480:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about False Bay.
taxon_text_4_481: Biology poorly known, but common under intertidal boulders.
taxon_text_5_482: Unknown, but given the under boulder habitat may feed on sponges, bryozoans, hydroids or other encrusting species.
taxon_text_6_483: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_484: There are 5 very similar regional species in this genus that can be distinguished by shape of the pleotelson, length of the uropods and other microscopic details. The brown ‘mask’ between the eyes is also a useful identification feature for this species and is shared only by J. beuroisi, but that species has a narrower, more pointed pleotelson and longer uropods that extend beyond its tip.
taxon_text_8_485:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 88).

Kensley, B. (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 132).
taxon_text_1_487: Very common air-breathing isopod found abundantly on the upper intertidal levels of rocky shores. Head with large eyes and elongate antennae. Body broad, especially in males, dorsally smooth and strongly flattened. Abdomen narrower than thorax, with free segments. Uropods elongate, projecting well beyond end of body and with two equal branches.
taxon_text_3_489:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Reported in literature from Lüderitz in Namibia to about Hermanus, but dominant from about Cape Peninsula to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_490: Very common around the drift line of rocky shores, wherever drift kelp is cast ashore. May co-occur in mixed populations with both the horned isopod Deto echinata and with the similar L. glabrata. Feed on drift kelp and other algae, and may also scavenge on dead animals. Most active at night, but also on cloudy days, moving down to the shore well into the intertidal to feed and back above the high water mark to shelter during high tide and in heat of the day. May migrate in formidable numbers, swarming over the rocks and kelp wrack.
taxon_text_5_491: Mainly kelp but also other drift algae and organic debris.
taxon_text_6_492: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully developed juveniles. In this species recruitment occurs from spring to autumn and females become reproductive active at an age of 12 months. Life expectancy is about 2 years.
taxon_text_7_493: Often in mixed populations with Deto echinata, but that species is easily recognised by the unusual dorsal ‘horns’ on each thoracic segment. Also found together with L. glabrata, but that species has a narrower body and also tends to be dominant along the west coast, whereas L. dilatata is dominant from about Kommetjie on the Cape Peninsula eastwards. Another species, L. natalensis, occurs even further east and into KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_8_494:
Greenan, TM, Griffiths, CL, & Santamaria, CA (2018). Molecular approaches uncover cryptic diversity in intertidal Ligia isopods (Crustacea, Isopoda, Ligiidae) across the southern Africa coastline. PeerJ, 6, e4658.

Koop, K, & Field, JG (1980). The influence of food availability on population dynamics of a supralittoral isopod, Ligia dilatata Brandt. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 48(1), 61-72.

Koop, K, & Field, JG (1981). Energy transformation by the supralittoral isopod Ligia dilatata Brandt. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 53(2-3), 221-233.
taxon_text_1_496: Tiny white isopod most easily recognised by its unusual habit of boring into wood. Antennae very short, abdominal segments not fused, segment 5 with a V-shaped dorsal ridge. Pleotelson large and rounded, with 3 small dorsal knobs arranged to form a triangle; uropods tiny, outer branch bent outwards.
taxon_text_3_498:
Global: Cosmopolitan. Has been very widely distributed in warmer waters around the world by wooden ships, such that its area of origin is now obscure.

Local/Regional: Only recently (2008) detected in Table Bay and known only from that site, although must certainly have been present there for many decades and almost certainly also occurs in other harbours and marinas in the region.
taxon_text_4_499: Bores into the wood of wooden vessels and particularly pier pilings etc. Heavily infected pilings have a characteristic hourglass shape in which the lower intertidal section has been severely eroded away. A single pair normally occupy each tunnel, the female occurring close to the opening. Burrows tend to follow the grain of the wood and are initially confined to the surface layers, but as these crumble away damage extends deeper.
taxon_text_6_501: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released. Due to the small size of adults brood size is unusually small at 5–15 eggs per female.
taxon_text_7_502: A second cosmopolitan and introduced species, L. quadripunctata, also occurs in harbours from Cape Town to Port Elizabeth, as well as in natural habitats such as kelp holdfasts. As the name suggests it has 4 rather than 3 small knobs on the pleotelson, these being arranged in a square.
taxon_text_8_503:
Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 83, L. quadripunctata).

Picker, M & Griffiths, CL (2011). Alien and invasive animals – a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 165).
taxon_text_1_505: Common air-breathing isopod related to terrestrial woodlice and found just above the drift line on rocky shores. Body broadly oval, flattened and dorsally smooth. Colour dark brown with fine white lines.  Head with distinctive spade-like projection between the antennae (after which species in named); antennae only about half of length of thorax. Abdomen short with separate broad segments. Uropods short, each with single club–shaped ramus.
taxon_text_3_507:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Restricted to Southwestern Cape, between about Saldanha and Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_508: Until recently rarely reported, but now known to be common around and above the drift line of rocky shores in the SW Cape where drift kelp is cast ashore. May co-occur in mixed populations with both the horned isopod Deto echinata and with the sea slater L. glabrata, but tends to extend higher on the shore that either of those species. Feeds on drift kelp and other algae, and may also scavenge on dead animals. Most active at night.
taxon_text_5_509: Mainly kelp but also other drift algae and organic debris.
taxon_text_6_510: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_511: Often in mixed populations with Deto echinata, but that species is easily recognised by the unusual dorsal ‘horns’ on each thoracic segment. Also found together with Ligia species, but these have a narrower body and elongate, branched uropods.
taxon_text_8_512:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 88).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 160).
taxon_text_1_514: Members of this unusual isopod family are characterized by having a very elongate, slender thorax, short antennae and a short abdomen, the segments of which are often fused. This species is easily recognized by its striking colour pattern. The body is cream with a broad dark border around each thoracic segment.
taxon_text_3_516:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_517: Very little is known about the biology of this unusual species, other than that it is usually found under boulders in the intertidal and on shallow rocky reefs.
taxon_text_6_519: As in other isopods the eggs are brooded in a marsupium between the walking legs of females and releases as fully-formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_520: There are over 25 species of Anthuridae reported from South African waters, but this species is instantly recognized by its colour pattern. Nothing else is known about the biology of any of the regional species.
taxon_text_8_521:
Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isodods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p 52).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p 88).
taxon_text_1_523: Very large, robust, elongated and parallel-sided isopod with reticulated markings on a green to brown background. Abdominal segments fused and joined to telson to form a ‘pleotelson’. The pleotelson is elongate and more or less parallel–sided with a median dorsal keel and three partial crimp-like ‘sutures’ near base of either side. The lateral margins of the pleotelson are also characteristically thick and grooved and the corners projected into sharp, raised and curved points.
taxon_text_3_525:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Luderitz in Namibia to Cape Point.
taxon_text_4_526: Commonly found on kelps and other seaweeds along the west coast of southern Africa, upon which it grazes. The gut contains surfactants and a chitinous lining to protect against polyphenolic chemicals secreted by the kelps as anti-herbivore defences. Can become a pest on Gracilaria farms.
taxon_text_5_527: Herbivorous, feeding mostly on kelps and on agar-weed. Also reported to scavenge on fish caught in gill nets.
taxon_text_6_528: As with all isopods the eggs are retained in a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_529: There are several smaller representative of this genus in the region, but this is the only one in which the tips of the pleotelson are extended into keeled points.
taxon_text_8_530:
Anderson, BC, Smit, AJ, & Bolton, JJ (1998). Differential grazing effects by isopods on Gracilaria gracilis and epiphytic Ceramium diaphanum in suspended raft culture. Aquaculture, 169(1–2), 99–109.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 86)

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isodods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 40).
taxon_text_1_532: Large, robust, elongated and parallel-sided plain green isopod. Abdominal segments fused and joined to telson to form a ‘pleotelson’. The pleotelson is elongate and more or less parallel–sided, lacks a central keel and has two partial crimp-like ‘sutures’ near base of either side, representing fused segments. The lateral corners project into short, sharp points.
taxon_text_3_534:
Global: Widespread across Southern Hemisphere including South America, southern Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Namibia to approximately East London.
taxon_text_4_535: Common under boulders and among seaweeds on rocky shores and also in lagoonal areas, where it can be abundant along green seaweeds such as Ulva.
taxon_text_6_537: As with all isopods the eggs are retained in a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_538: There are several other members of this genus in the region, but this is the only one in which the pleotelson is not keeled, but its lateral tips are extended into short points.
taxon_text_8_539:
Branch, G, Griffiths, C L, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 86).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 40).
taxon_text_1_541: Broad, flattened isopod with abdominal segments fused and joined to telson to form a ‘pleotelson’. Able to roll into a ball when disturbed. Pleotelson large with broad uropods. The most distinctive feature is the very large backward-sloping dorsal spike emerging from the centre of the last thoracic segment in males. The pleotelson of males also has a distinctive wide keyhole-shaped notch at its tip. Females lack the dorsal spike and keyhole on the pleotelson, which instead has two small humps.
taxon_text_3_543:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_544: Poorly known, but fairly common on rocky shores, particularly under boulders and in kelp holdfasts. The role of the rather awkward-looking dorsal spike is unknown, but it might make males more difficult for predators to swallow.
taxon_text_6_546: As in all isopods the eggs are retained in a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_547: One of only two species in this endemic genus. The male of the other species, P. stimpsoni, has a very short double-tipped horn on the last thoracic segment, a much smaller ‘keyhole’ and a ring of small tubercles on the pleotelson. Females also have the short horn, but no keyhole.
taxon_text_8_548:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 90).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 110).
taxon_text_1_550: Broad, flattened isopod with abdominal segments fused and joined to telson to create a ‘pleotelson’. Able to roll into a ball when disturbed. Pleotelson large and uropods broad. The most distinctive feature is the short double-layered dorsal spike emerging from the centre of the last thoracic segment in males. The pleotelson of males also has a narrow keyhole-shaped notch at its tip. Females share the dorsal spike, but lack the keyhole on the pleotelson.
taxon_text_3_552:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_553: Poorly known, but fairly common on rocky shores, particularly under boulders and in kelp holdfasts.
taxon_text_6_555: As in all isopods the eggs are retained in a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_556: One of only two species in this endemic genus. The male of the other species, P. perforatus, has a much longer backward-sloping horn on the last thoracic segment, and a broader ‘keyhole’. Females lack both horn and keyhole and have two humps on the pleotelson.
taxon_text_8_557:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 90).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 110).
taxon_text_1_577: The leaf-shrimps are a fairly distinctive group of small crustaceans in which the thorax and front part of the abdomen are enclosed in a bivalve-like carapace, which also has a hinged visor-like rostrum projecting above the eyes. The slender hind part of the abdomen projects backwards, ending in a pair of elongate, pointed projections (furcae). There are only about 35 described species worldwide, and only one in South Africa, although another two are described from Namibia. In the local species the eyes are red and body plain cream.
taxon_text_4_580: Uncommon and generally found under boulders on rocky and boulder shores, usually in small groups.
taxon_text_5_581: Thought to be filter feeders and opportunistic scavengers on dead organic material, such as drift algae.
taxon_text_6_582: The eggs are carried in a brood chamber beneath the carapace of females and hatch as free-swimming post-larvae.
taxon_text_7_583: This is the only species of leaf-shrimp reported from South Africa, although two others are known from Namibia (see references below).
taxon_text_8_584:
Bochert, R & Zettler, ML (2012). Nebalia deborahae, a new species of Leptostraca (Phyllocarida) from South West Africa. Crustaceana, 85(2), 205-218.

Kensley, BF (1976). The genus Nebalia in South and South West Africa (Crustacea Leptostraca). Cimbebasia, 4, 155 -162.
taxon_text_1_586: Mysids are small, often transparent shrimps in which the legs lack nippers. The abdomen ends in a tail fan formed of an elongate central telson and a single pair of large, branched uropods. A characteristic small round statocyst or balancing organ is found at the base of the inner ranch of the uropod. In this species the apex of the telson is notched, the notch being lines by small spines. The lateral margins of the telson also bear a row of 6-7 evenly-spaced spines, the last and largest one being at the tip.
taxon_text_3_588:
Global: Mozambique to Namibia.

Local/Regional: Across region on sandy beaches.
taxon_text_4_589:
Mysids can be either benthic or free-swimming and this species characteristically forms swarms in the surf zone of exposed sandy beaches.

Occur in the surf zone of exposed sandy beaches, sometimes burrowing into the sand by day and emerging into the water column at night. Brooding females often occur inshore and males and juveniles in deeper water more offshore.
taxon_text_5_590: Mysids are mostly filter feeders, creating a feeding current by beating the abdominal appendages and feeding on algae, detritus and zooplankton in the water column. This species appears to feed largely on the surf-zone diatom Anaulus birostratus.
taxon_text_6_591: Females have a conspicuous ventral brood pouch in which the eggs are brooded until they have developed fully into the adult form.
taxon_text_7_592: There are numerous species in this and related genera in the region and these are distinguished mostly by details of the shape and spination of the uropods and telson. The habitat of this particular species also helps to identify it.
taxon_text_8_593:
Tattersall, OS (1958). Further notes on Mysidacea from South African waters. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 4, 373-385.

Webb, P, Perissinotto, R, & Wooldridge, TH (1988). Diet and feeding of Gastrosaccus psammodytes (Crustacea, Mysidacea) with special reference to the surf diatom Anaulus birostratus. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 45(3), 255-261.

Wooldridge, T (1981). Zonation and distribution of the beach mysid, Gastrosaccus psammodytes (Crustacea: Mysidacea). Journal of Zoology, 193(2).
taxon_text_1_595:
Mysids are small, often transparent shrimps in which the legs lack nippers. The abdomen ends in a tail fan formed of an elongate central telson and a single pair of large, branched uropods. A characteristic small round statocyst or balancing organ, is found at the base of the inner ranch of the uropod. In this species the apex of the telson is broadly rounded and lines by series of marginal spines which become longer towards the apex.

Mysids can be either benthic or free-swimming and this species characteristically forms large swarms in shallow water, particularly associated with kelp beds.
taxon_text_3_597:
Global: South Africa and Namibia.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_598: Occur in dense swarms in and around kelp-beds where they create an important food resource for fish and other predators.
taxon_text_5_599: Mysids are mostly filter feeders, creating a feeding current by beating the abdominal appendages and feeding on algae, detritus and zooplankton in the water column.
taxon_text_6_600: Females have a conspicuous ventral brood pouch in which the eggs are brooded until they have developed fully into the adult form.
taxon_text_7_601: There are numerous species in this and related genera in the region and these are distinguished mostly by details of the shape and spination of the uropods and telson. The habits of this particular species are unusual though and help identify it.
taxon_text_8_602: Wooldridge, TH (1988). A new species of Mysidopsis (Mysidacea) from coastal waters of Southern Africa and a key to the known species from the subcontinent. Annals of the South African Museum, 98 (4), 93-103.
taxon_text_1_613:
Pycnogonids are bizarre animals sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have four pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, they are not closely-related to true spiders, so we prefer the term pycnogonids. The body consists of a head with a tubular proboscis, usually a pair of grasping chelicerae and a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming and, in the males, to carry the eggs. Behind the head is a usually elongate trunk consisting of four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes to which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical, abdomen.

This unusual species has a comparatively compact body with a raised spiky ocular (eye) tubercle on the first segment, and a transverse spined ridge running across each body segment, this being armed by a central and a pair of lateral spiny knobs. The proboscis is a large tubular structure with a narrow base and is folded back under the body. There is a pair of small, clawed chelifers that extend forward from the front of the head, but the longer segmented palps typical of most pycnogonids are absent. The limbs are spinose and in live animals often coated with fine debris. The abdomen is an elongate spiked club-like spiny structure. Colour is plain cream, sometimes tinged pink. Males are often seen carrying a large oval egg mass.

The taxonomic position if this genus is uncertain so the family placement is debatable.
taxon_text_3_615:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to about Durban.
taxon_text_4_616: Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, but this species is relatively commonly on rocky shores in the Cape Town region. Normally occur singly or in pairs moving slowly and ponderously around.
taxon_text_5_617: The food of this species is not known with certainly, but the specimens depicted here were found amongst colonies of the bryozoan Bowerbankia under boulders in Sea Point, so this may be the diet.
taxon_text_6_618: Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits.  The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
taxon_text_7_619: Fairly easily distinguished from other regional pycnogonids when examined microscopically, due to the spiky transverse ridges across each body segment, the forward pointing chelifers, and the lack of palps.
taxon_text_8_620: Barnard, KH (1954). South African Pycnogonida. Annals of the South African Museum, 39, 81-159.
taxon_text_1_622:
Bizarre animals sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, as they are not closely-related to true spiders, we prefer the term pycnogonids. The body consists of a head with a tubular proboscis, usually a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming, as well as used by males to carry the eggs. Behind the head is an elongate trunk consisting of approximately four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes to which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical, abdomen.

This species is easily distinguished from other local species by its bright red colour. It is relatively large and has long spindly legs. The head possesses both palps; chelifers and ovigerous legs are present in both sexes.
taxon_text_3_624:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape coast to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_625: Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, but this species is relatively commonly seen under boulders and on rocky shores. Normally occur singly or in pairs moving slowly and ponderously around.
taxon_text_5_626: Thought to feed on hydroids, probably by nipping these off with the chelifers.
taxon_text_6_627: Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits.  The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
taxon_text_7_628: Easily distinguished from other local species by the unusual dark red colour. One of over 330 species in this very diverse genus which includes representatives from around the world.
taxon_text_8_629: Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 78).
taxon_text_1_631:
Bizarre animals sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, as they are not closely-related to true spiders, we prefer the term pycnogonids. The body consists of a head with a tubular proboscis, usually a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming, as well as used by males to carry the eggs. Behind the head is an elongate trunk consisting of approximately four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes to which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical, abdomen.

This species is easily identified as the head lacks chelicerae and because it has a compact, almost circular trunk, a very large forward-directed proboscis and relatively short legs.
taxon_text_3_633:
Global: West coast of Southern Africa to KwaZulu-Natal and St Paul Island.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_634: Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, but this species is relatively commonly seen under boulders and  on rocky shores. Normally occur singly or in pairs moving slowly and ponderously around. Sometimes seen with the enlarged proboscis plunged into the column of a sea-anemone.
taxon_text_5_635: The very large proboscis and lack of chelicerae in this species suggest an unusual sectorial mode of feeding and they have been seen with the proboscis plunged into the columns of sea anemones. However, it is not known whether this is the only mode of feeding.
taxon_text_6_636: Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits.  The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
taxon_text_7_637: There are several other small white pycnogonids in the intertidal in this region, but the lack of chelicerae, large proboscis and short body of this species make it unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_638: Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 78).
taxon_text_1_640: Small parasitic copepods found on the external surfaces of coastal fish. Body length about 2 mm, thorax broadly rounded with short antennae and short one-segmented abdomen bearing pair of short branched appendages (rami). Females larger than males and distinguished by long egg strings projecting from the hind end of the body.
taxon_text_2_641: Up to 2 mm, excluding antennae and egg strands.
taxon_text_4_643: Found on the external surfaces of various coastal fish species including blennies, klipfish and suckerfish. The round, flattened thorax acts like a suction cap helping the mouthparts to grip onto the fish. Usually only a few parasites are found on each fish in the wild, where they probably cause little damage, but they can become serious pests in fish-farms, where large numbers of hosts occur in close proximity, facilitating transmission. Adults can move around on the host.
taxon_text_5_644: Feed on mucus, epidermal tissue and blood of host fishes, causing open wounds when in high density.
taxon_text_6_645: Eggs from the eggs strings of females hatch into non-feeding planktonic larvae, which later seek out hosts using chemosensory and mechanosensory cues, Once attached to the host they go though several other stages before becoming adults.
taxon_text_7_646: There are over 300 described species in this genus of which 39 have been reported in South Africa. In reality it is difficult to identify these to species based only on photographic evidence (as here) and detailed microscopic examination is required. However, as many species are restricted to specific hosts, of group of hosts, and C. mortis is the only species commonly found on klipfish of the genus Clinus, we assume that is the species in our images of these fish.
taxon_text_8_647: Grobler, NJ, Van As, JG, & Olivier, PA (2002). Description of the previously unknown male of Caligus mortis Kensley, 1970 (Copepoda: Caligidae), parasite of intertidal fish from South Africa. Folia parasitologica, 49(2), 131-136.
taxon_text_1_649: Best identified by its unusual habitat as a parasite attached to ventral surface of arms of the brittle star Amphiura capensis. The body is broadly oval, with short antennae. Females often bear conspicuous paired egg sacks on either side of the abdomen.
taxon_text_3_651:
Global: South Africa and Namibia.

Local/Regional: Cape Town to Lüderitz.
taxon_text_4_652: Attach by their antenna to the basal arm segments of the host, always with the head facing towards the mouth and central disc of the host. About 10 % of hosts examined had parasitic copepods, with between one and three parasites being present on each host. Impacts on the host are unknown.
taxon_text_5_653: Probably steals food particles being transported along the legs of the host towards its mouth.
taxon_text_6_654: The eggs are born on conspicuous paired egg-masses.
taxon_text_7_655: There are seven species in this genus, all of which are parasites of brittle stars, but only one other is known from the region – C. durbanensis ­­– which is confined to deeper waters of KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_8_656: MacKinnon, RB, Landschoff, J, & Griffiths, CL (2016). Rediscovery and first South African records of the parasitic copepod Cancerilla oblonga Bartsch, 1975 (Crustacea, Cancerillidae). African Invertebrates, 57(2), 105-109.
taxon_text_1_658: Small parasitic copepods found attached to the gills of fishes. The thorax is oval and the trunk elongated and oval, with no distinct separation between trunk and abdomen, the trunk just ending in a pair of small uropods. Two elongate eggs strings may also be present in females.
taxon_text_2_659: Body about 2-5 mm with egg strings another 3 mm.
taxon_text_3_660:
Global: Reported from Japan, Chile, South Africa, Western Indian Ocean and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Around entire South African coast.
taxon_text_4_661: All members of this diverse genus are gill parasites on a variety of fish. This species occurs on snoek and on angelfish.
taxon_text_5_662: Thought to feed on mucus as well as on gill tissue of host fish.
taxon_text_6_663: The eggs are produced in long strings hanging from the abdomen of females. These hatch into swimming larvae which seek out new host fish.
taxon_text_7_664: One of more than 70 species in this genus but the only one found in South Africa.
taxon_text_8_665:
Cressey, RF (1968). A redescription of Hatschekia conifera, Yamaguti 1939, (Copepoda, Caligoida), including the first description of the male. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 81, 173–178.

Jones, JB (1985). A revision of Hatschekia Poche, 1902 (Copepoda: Hatschekiidae), parasitic on marine fishes. New Zealand Journal of Zoology, 12(2), 213-271.

Oldewage, WH (1993). Morphological variation in Hatschekia conifera Yamaguti, 1939 (Copepoda, Siphonostomatoida) from the Southern Atlantic ocean. Crustaceana, 65 (1), 41-45.
taxon_text_1_667: Best identified by its unusual habitat of occupying the discarded shells of small gastropods, much like a hermit crab. Like all taniads the first of the seven pairs of walking legs bear a conspicuous pair of chelate nippers. The second walking leg is elongate and used for walking, but the remaining ones are short and bearing sucker-like structures that are presumably used to grip the inside of the host shell.
taxon_text_3_669:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Known only from False Bay, but almost certainly more widely distributed in the region.
taxon_text_4_670: Best known for its unusual habits of living in small mollusc shells, much like a hermit crab, and almost certainly mistaken for juvenile hermit crabs by most observers. The species was only known from a single specimen described in the 1950 until recently rediscovered by the Sea Change Project researchers living in large numbers under intertidal boulders in False Bay, where it co-occurs with two species if small hermit crabs. Occupy at least 19 different of small gastropod shells and appendages adapted to grip the inside of the host shell, much as in hermits.
taxon_text_5_671: Not well known, but presumed to feed on detritus and small organisms grasped by the sturdy chelae.
taxon_text_6_672: As in all tanaids the eggs are brooded in a marsupial chamber ventrally between the legs of the female and released as manca larvae.
taxon_text_7_673: The only known species of shell-inhabiting tanaid from the region, although as this group is so poorly researched others may well remain undetected.
taxon_text_8_674: Brokensha, R, Landschoff, J, du Plessis, A & Griffiths CL (2020). Redescription and notes on the ecology of Pagurapseudes dentatus (Brown, 1956) (Peracarida: Tanaidacea), a shell-inhabiting tanaid from South Africa, Journal of Crustacean Biology, 40(6), 715–724
taxon_text_1_694: An uncommon, but very distinctive species. Column cream to peach coloured with longitudinal rows of round purple spots (which are in fact batteries of stinging cells). Oral disc marked with vivid scarlet lines that radiate from the mouth to surround bases of the 48 short, stubby, white tentacles. Violet spot at each end of mouth.
taxon_text_2_695: Column diameter up to about 30 mm. When open can reach 50 mm across, including tentacles.
taxon_text_3_696:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine on west coast to about St Lucia in KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_697: Easily recognized by virtue of its unique and distinctive colour pattern. Uncommon and usually found singly in sandy sites at or below low tide level. Has been observed greatly extending column and reaching over to consume food items on adjacent rock surface. Nothing further known about biology.
taxon_text_5_698: Prey unknown, but almost all anemones are unselective predators feeding on a wide variety of invertebrate taxa.
taxon_text_6_699: No details known, but most anemones can both reproduce sexually by releasing sperm and eggs into the water to merge and form plankton larvae, and by division of the adult.
taxon_text_7_700: Unlikely to be confused with any other regional anemones especially due to bright radiating red stripes on oral disc. Most similar to Dwarf spotted anemone (Anthostella sp.), which is also cream and has purple spots on column, but that species is much smaller, has purple-tipped tentacles and a plain oral disc.
taxon_text_8_701:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_9_702: There is some confusion about the correct name of this species, which has been referred to by some authors as Anthothoe chilensis. Here we follow WoRMS (World Register of Marine Species) and consider A. chilensis to be a South American species, but see also notes below regarding possible unresolved taxonomy.
taxon_text_1_703: Small but common species with a smooth column that can vary from short and squat to elongate and slender. Column smooth and almost always with distinct vertical stripes, colour of stripes ranges from pinks to greens and browns; some specimens can also be very pale and almost white, others very transparent, such that internal organs can be seen through column wall. Tentacles vary widely in number from 130–370. One of most distinctive features is its habit of readily releasing sticky white acontia threads though the body wall whenever disturbed.
taxon_text_2_704: Column typically about 20 mm in diameter, but varies widely with individuals from deeper water often being larger.
taxon_text_3_705:
Global distribution: Namibia, South Africa and Tristan da Cunha Island.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban.
taxon_text_4_706: Usually found in groups in rock pools and shallow reefs, also under boulders in the intertidal and up to depths of 28 m. Common fouling species on harbour walls, jetties and various floating structures. Photosynthetic symbiotic algae live in the tissues and add to food supply. Preyed upon by the indica nudibranch Anteaeolidiella cacaotica.
taxon_text_5_707: Polyphagous opportunistic feeder that also contains photosynthetic algal cells that contribute to its nutrition. Diet in False Bay dominated by isopods, which contributed 62% to numbers of prey in gut. Copepods, polychaetes and spiders each contributed 8% of diet, followed by mites and small gastropods (6% each).
taxon_text_6_708: Like most anemones can reproduce both sexually or by fission. In fission the two sides of the foot essentially move apart and the body gradually divides (tears itself) into two genetically identical halves. In sexual reproduction mature gametes are released into the internal cavity (coelenteron) and then spawned through the mouth. The zygotes then develops into planktonic larvae which disperse in the water column, then settle at a new site and develop into new juvenile anemones.
taxon_text_7_709: Unlikely to be confused with any other local species due to vertical stripes on smooth column and habit of releasing acontia threads when disturbed. Body shape and size, colour and habitat are, however, extremely variable and it appears likely from recent genetic evidence (Spana et al., 2018) that several distinct but still undescribed species may be present in the region but are included under this one name. These still await formal resolution though.
taxon_text_8_710:
Branch, G, Griffiths, C, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. Cape Town, Struik Nature. (p. 24)

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Cape Town, SURG.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Spana C, Haussermann V, Acuna F H, Griffiths CL, Sebb LW & Gomez-Uchida D (2018). Hierarchical biogeographical processes largely explain the genomic divergence patterns in a species complex of sea anemones. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution 127: 217–228.
taxon_text_1_712:
Abundant, large and conspicuous species often occurring in large, close-packed colonies that completely coat sand-filled gullies, or cover flat rocks subject to sand inundation. Occurs in a wide range of colours, including browns, pinks, reds and blues. Column wide and bearing numerous sticky knobs to which sand grains and pieces of shell strongly adhere. Closes up tightly when exposed at low tide, concealing the tentacles so that the colonies resemble sheets of small sandy hummocks. Tentacles short and closely packed, up to 384 in number, often with opaque white spots.

Juveniles often attached to mussels.
taxon_text_2_713: Column diameter typically up to 80 mm, tentacles only about 10 mm long.
taxon_text_3_714:
Global: Endemic to Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to St Lucia in northern KwaZulu-Natal, but most abundant along west coast.
taxon_text_4_715: A very common, large and well-known species that can be extremely abundant on the west coast, where it carpets sandy gullies and low-lying rocks. Colonies include adjacent individuals of a wide range of bright colours, forming an attractive mosaic when open.
taxon_text_5_716: A classic wait-and-see predator that occupies low-lying rocks beneath densely colonized reefs and feeds almost entirely on tumbled prey dislodged from adjacent rocks or swept in by the waves. The diet is diverse with the most frequently consumed items being barnacles, mussels, gastropods and polychaete worms. Almost any organic item will be eaten though and it is quite common to see individuals trying to consume large urchins, rock-lobster or crab moults, discarded fishing bait, etc.
taxon_text_6_717: Anemones can reproduce sexually, by releasing sperm and eggs into the water, and this species can be seen undertaking mass spawning events in which sperm and eggs are pouring from the apertures of each colony member. They can also divide by fission, so where similarly-coloured individuals are found in close proximity these are probably derived by division of a single founding individual.
taxon_text_7_718: Sometimes confused with the knobbly anemone Bunodosoma capense, which not only has a similar generic name, but also occurs in a wide range of colours and is found on the same shores. However, the knobs on the column of the knobbly anemone are not sticky and sand grains do not adhere to them. That species also tends to occur singly or in small groups in clean sand-free sites.
taxon_text_8_719:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_721: Common and conspicuous species fairly easily identified by the fact that the broad column is patterned with horizontal rows of small, non-adhesive knobs. These are always darker than the background colour of the column, which can vary widely from cream to yellow, red, orange, blue or purple. Up to 192 short, usually paler tentacles and a row of small spherules beneath these.
taxon_text_3_723:
Global: Recorded from Chile, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Durban in KwaZulu-Natal.
