taxon_text_4_724: A common and well-known species found usually singly or in small groups in sand-free rock-pools and shallow reefs, often attached to other species, such as mussels or large ascidians. Notable for its extremely variable colouration, but since anemones cannot see and are rarely consumed by predators, colour is probably of little significance and is not selected for or against. The small knobs on the column contain stinging cells and are probably defensive in function.
taxon_text_5_725: Feeds on a wide variety of invertebrate groups, with no one prey category dominating the diet.
taxon_text_6_726: Anemones can reproduce sexually, but releasing sperm and eggs into the water, but can also divide by fission, so where similarly-coloured individuals are found in close proximity the group is probably derived by division of a single founding individual.
taxon_text_7_727: Sometimes confused with the Sandy anemone Bunodactis reynaudi, which not only has a similar generic name, but also occurs in a wide range of colours and is found on the same shores. However, the Sandy anemone has sticky knobs on its column to which sand grains adhere. It also tends to occur in large groups and to be confined to sandy habitats, which are avoided by the more solitary B. capense.
taxon_text_8_728:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_730: Easily recognized by the long, wormlike body and habit of living freely in a long mucous tube buried in soft sediment, into which the animal quickly withdraws if disturbed. The tentacles are comprised of two distinct groups, an inner circle of shorter tentacles and an outer one of much more elongate, slender and tapering ones. Colour varies from white to yellow, orange, blue or purple.
taxon_text_2_731: Up to about 15 cm in body length. Tubes may extend up to 1m into the sediment.
taxon_text_3_732:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Known only from the Cape Peninsula, but almost certainly more widespread. Specimens collected from Knysna almost certainly represent a different and undescribed species.
taxon_text_4_733: Not strictly anemones, but belong to another related class, Ceriantharia. Lack an adhesive foot and live freely in long mucous tubes deeply buried in soft sediments. Withdraw instantly if disturbed and hence seldom collected using conventional trawls, dredges of grabs. Thus probably much more common and diverse than reported to date. The few samples that exist were extracted by divers manually digging up specimens – an extremely taxing process, as they can withdraw up to 1m down into the sediment!
taxon_text_5_734: No specific information available, but certainly predatory.
taxon_text_6_735: No details known, but assumed to reproduce sexually. Fission has not been observed to our knowledge.
taxon_text_7_736: Unmistakable in appearance and habits and unlikely to be confused with any other regional species. To date the only described cerianthid in the region, although it is highly likely that there are other undescribed species present. Photographic observations span a wide range of depths and habitats unlikely to all be occupied by just this one described species.
taxon_text_8_737:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 24)

Molodtsova, T, Griffiths, CF & Acuña FH (2011). A new species of shallow-water cerianthid (Cnidaria: Anthozoa) from the South Africa with remarks on the genus Ceriantheopsis. African Natural History, 7, 1-8.
taxon_text_1_739: Technically not a true anemone but more related to corals but included here since, as the common name suggests, it is almost always treated as an anemone. Forms dense colonies comprised of small beautifully-coloured transparent pink polyps that have a smooth column and about 90 pale finely-wrinkled tentacles that each end is a distinctive white knob. Tentacles in the inner rings are shorter than those on outer rings.
taxon_text_3_741:
Global: Endemic to Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_742: Found from low intertidal to depth of about 100m, forming often extensive colonies on shallow reefs, particularly on vertical surfaces and under overhangs.
taxon_text_5_743: Not known for this species, but probably feed on small planktonic organisms that come into contact with extended tentacles.
taxon_text_6_744: Reproduce both sexually and asexually. Sperm and eggs may be released into the water column join to form planktonic larvae that float away and establish new colonies. Existing individuals may also divide to expand existing colonies. Individuals in the colony are closely packed, but not joined to one another at the base (unlike in zoanthids or corals for example).
taxon_text_7_745: Unlikely to be confused with any other species due to the unusual transparent pink colour and knobbed tentacles.
taxon_text_8_746:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 24).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_748: Body divided into distinct vertical sections and lives buried in sand, the disc level with sand surface. Only 12 elongate, evenly-tapering, equal tentacles that are held spread flat against the substratum, like the arms of a clock. Body colourless to cream, tentacles pale with yellow-brown Y shaped markings at base and bands of white spots along upper surfaces.
taxon_text_2_749: Column about 10 mm wide and 50 mm in height.
taxon_text_3_750:
Global: Endemic to South Africa (a record from India unlikely this species).

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution between St Helena Bay and False Bay.
taxon_text_4_751: Rarely reported species originally found in False Bay with a few subsequent reports up to St Helena Bay. Sits buried in course sand with the tentacles spread out on sand surface. No other information on biology.
taxon_text_5_752: Diet has not been examined, by assumed to feed on a variety of smaller invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_753: Not specifically known for this species, but most anemones can reproduce both sexually, but releasing sperm and eggs into the water, and can also divide by fission.
taxon_text_7_754: Low tentacle number, colour pattern on disc and habitat fairly distinctive and one of few regional anemones with so few tentacles. Holoclava capensis has similar habits, colour, and a confusingly similar name, but has 20 very short tentacles.
taxon_text_8_755:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_757: Small and inconspicuous, but quite common in preferred habitat.  Column cream to pale pink, transparent and divided by a constriction into upper and lower sections, the lower section being covered by a thin cuticle. Only 24 fairly elongate, tapering and transparent tentacles. Tentacles may be marked by transverse cream bars, or pale chevron patterns.
taxon_text_2_758: Column up to 9 mm wide and 22 mm in height.
taxon_text_3_759:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  Saldanha Bay to Richards Bay.
taxon_text_4_760: Prefers sheltered areas, such as under boulders or in kelp holdfast. Primarily reported from intertidal, but records extends down to 79 m depth.  Very little studies other than distribution records.
taxon_text_5_761: Diet has not been examined, by assumed to feed on a variety of smaller invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_762: Young are brooded in a pouch half way up the column and emerge as fully-formed juvenile anemones.
taxon_text_7_763: Often found in the same under boulder-habitat as the similarly small and pale Ring-tentacle anemone Isanthus capensis, but that species has 48 shorter tentacles and does not brood its young.
taxon_text_8_764:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_766: Small and inconspicuous, but quite common. Column smooth with vague longitudinal furrows (marking locations of internal mesenteries); white basally, becoming darker just below the 48 shortish tentacles. Oral disc marked with radiating brown bands and traversed by an orange band running between two longer orange catch tentacles positioned inside the main circle. Outer tentacles each with two brown dots at base, cream basally, outer section crossed by 2–3 brown bands.
taxon_text_2_767: Column about 15 mm wide and 20 mm in height.
taxon_text_3_768:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast between about Hondeklip Bay and False Bay.
taxon_text_4_769: Primarily reported from intertidal, but records extends down to over 150 m depth. Most commonly found under rock and in sand and gravel in sheltered intertidal sites.
taxon_text_5_770: Diet has not been examined but assumed to feed on a variety of smaller invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_771: Not specifically known for this species, but most anemones can reproduce both sexually by releasing sperm and eggs into the water, and can also divide by fission.
taxon_text_7_772: Colour pattern on disc and habitat fairly distinctive. Often found in the same under boulder-habitat as the similarly small and pale Brooding anemone Helianthella annularis, but that species has only 24 longer tentacles.
taxon_text_8_773:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 28).

Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_786: Rare but large, unusual and highly distinctive species that lives unattached to substratum. Column red or red-striped and can be squat or become narrow and elongated. Oral disc and foot inflated and marked with distinctive red and white radiating stripes, after which the common name is derived. Tentacles about 50, fat and with red and white longitudinal bands.
taxon_text_2_787: Up to about 10 cm in length when fully extended.
taxon_text_3_788:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about Durban.
taxon_text_4_789: A spectacular species and one of few anemones that are not permanently attached to the substratum, but crawl or float around in search of prey. Originally described from Durban, but more recent records all from the Cape, where it appears to be most often encountered (a reminder of the danger of naming species after their original place of discovery!). Usually seen with the foot greatly expanded onto a ‘umbrella’ that probably aids in dispersal by waves and currents. When a sea fan is encountered the stomach is everted thought the mouth and the sea fan externally digested, leaving only a dead skeleton. The few specimens reported have been found on shallow reefs of 1–15 m depth.
taxon_text_5_790: Appears to feed only on gorgonians which are engulfed in situ and the soft tissues digested from the skeleton which is left bare as the anemone moves on.
taxon_text_6_791: No details known but assumed to reproduce sexually. Fission has not been observed to our knowledge.
taxon_text_7_792: Unmistakable in appearance and habits and unlikely to be confused with any other regional species.
taxon_text_8_793:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Riemann-Zürneck, K & Griffiths, CL (1999). Korsaranthus natalensis (Carlgren, 1938) nov. comb. (Cnidaria: Actiniaria) a mobile sea anemone attacking octocorals. African Zoology, 34(4), 190–196.
taxon_text_1_796:
Zoanthids resemble small anemones and similarly have a columnar body topped by a ring of tentacles surrounding a central mouth. Unlike anemones though, they are colonial and colony members remain united by a basal sheet of tissue. Most species carpet tropical shores, this one is thus unusual both in it temperate distribution and because it lives in sponges.

Colonies infiltrate sponges on shallow reefs, with the individual polyps emerging through the surface of the sponge. The delicate polyps are about 5 mm tall, white to pale yellow, not covered in sand and have fairly long slender tentacles (for a zoanthid). Often seen in the Tree sponge Echinoclathria, which may host so many zoanthid polyps that infected sponges are sometimes mistaken for seafans.
taxon_text_2_797: Polyps about 5 mm tall, colonies may infiltrate sponges at least 20 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_798:
Global: Endemic

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_799: Very little is known about this species, other than that it is seen emerging from sponges. Given its white colour and subtidal distribution the polyps probably lack symbiotic algae (zooxanthellae), which are common in intertidal species. It thus probably relies entirely on capturing food with the tentacles.
taxon_text_5_800: Small planktonic prey are captured with the tentacles, which are armed with stinging calls, and transferred to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_801: Zoanthids can reproduce both sexually and asexually. Now colonies are founded via the release of sperm and eggs into the water. After fertilization eggs develop into planktonic larvae, which are transported to new sites, where they settle and transform into the adult form. Once established, colonies develop by budding off the original founding individual and all members of the colony are thus genetically identical and remain connected to one another via a basal carpet of tissue.
taxon_text_7_802: Several other zoanthid species are common on subtropical shores to the east of South Africa, but this is one of few to occur in temperate parts of the county. It is unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to its white colour and unusual habitat of living within sponges.
taxon_text_8_803:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 30).

Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.
taxon_text_1_806: Highly unusual anemone, sometimes also known as the creeping or sock anemone. Soft and floppy, with the entire surface of the column covered in sticky pink papillae, while the oral and pedal discs are smooth and marked with about 24 radiating red stripes.
taxon_text_2_807: Up to about 9 cm diameter and 20–30 cm in length when fully extended.
taxon_text_3_808:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Restricted range in and around the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_809: Not attached but moves around using peristaltic waves of contractions of the body and by ‘walking’; with the papillae in search of sea fans on which it feeds. Often seen engulfing these prey, leaving behind only their horn-like internal skeletons.
taxon_text_5_810: Appears to feed only on gorgonians which are engulfed in situ and the soft tissues digested from the skeleton which is left bare as the anemone moves on.
taxon_text_6_811: No details known but assumed to reproduce sexually. Fission has not been observed to our knowledge.
taxon_text_7_812: Unmistakable in appearance and habits and the only representative of this family in the region.
taxon_text_8_813:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_816: Large, conspicuous and well-known anemone. Body fairly wide and squat, base with undulating edges. Column smooth and uniform yellow, orange or red. Tentacles paler orange to yellow, fairly long, numbering up to 230, usually with purple tips and generally held extended perpendicular to column. Unusual in that it has a weak sphincter and is thus unable to fully close up when disturbed. Three to five rows of globular vesicles immediately beneath the tentacles are used for combat.
taxon_text_2_817: Column reaches a diameter of at least 75 mm, so tentacles can have a span of over 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_818:
Global: Widespread, with records from Brazil, Norway and Azores, as well as common in Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about St Lucia in KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_819:
A large and conspicuous species, particularly common in low intertidal pools and on shallow reefs, but recorded down to at least 46 m depth. Unusual in that the sphincter is weak and so the tentacles cannot be completely withdrawn, so is permanently ‘open’. Well known for its territorial behaviour, individuals inflating their vesicles and using them to attack and sometimes kill unrelated individuals. Where several similarly-coloured individuals occur in close proximity these are thus almost certainly genetically-identical and derived from fission of a founding individual.

The venom of the stinging cells is particularly potent and captive animals in the marine aquarium have been observed to capture juvenile catsharks on several occasions. The catsharks, which settles on an expanded anemone, were instantly paralysed and offered no resistance as they were slowly dragged into the mouth by the tentacles and swallowed. If one touches these anemones with a finger the stinging cells fire and the tentacles stick into the skin, but the venom is unable to penetrate the dead epidermis, so the sting is not painful (in case of allergic reaction, it is unrecommended trying this though!).
taxon_text_5_820: Feeds on a variety of larger invertebrates and also the only regional species to routinely take fish. An analysis of gut contents on the Cape Peninsula revealed the diet to consists of 43% gastropods, 18% bivalves, 18% isopods and 12% echinoderms; but as echinoderms were larger they accounted for 51% of the diet by mass.
taxon_text_6_821: Anemones can reproduce sexually, but releasing sperm and eggs into the water, but can also divide by fission, so where similarly-coloured individuals are found in close proximity the group is probably derived by division of a single founding individual.
taxon_text_7_822: Easily confused with the closely-related Pseudactinia varia which is also found in much the same habitat. That species, however, smaller, and is usually paler pink in colour with fewer, lighter-coloured tentacles, which also lack purple tips. There are also only 1–2 rows of vesicles beneath the tentacles.
taxon_text_8_823:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_826: Fairly wide, squat anemone, uniform but variable in colour (as the name suggests). Usually red to pink to pale orange, column smooth, tentacles fairly long, numbering between 72 and 174. Tentacles same colour as column, but often paler, particularly towards tips; generally held extended perpendicular to column. Two rows of globular vesicles immediately beneath the tentacles (vs 3-5 rows in the similar P. flagellifera). Unusual in that it has a weak sphincter and is unable to fully close up when disturbed.
taxon_text_2_827: Column about 30 mm wide and similar in height, tentacles about 15 mm long.
taxon_text_3_828:
Global: South Africa and St Helena Island.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine to Durban.
taxon_text_4_829: Primarily intertidal and usually found on the underside of boulders of in shady crevices, but also found at depths up to 47 m. Probably shows the same territorial behaviour as the closely related P. flagellifera (see that entry) but not documented.
taxon_text_5_830: Feeds on a variety of larger invertebrates, which may be captured live or tumble into the tentacles after being displaced by waves or having died of other causes. An analysis of gut contents revealed the diet to consists of 42% gastropods, 23% bivalves, 17% isopods and 12% echinoderms; but as echinoderms were larger they accounted for 56% of the diet by mass.
taxon_text_6_831: Anemones can reproduce sexually, but releasing sperm and eggs into the water, but can also divide by fission, so where similarly-coloured individuals are found in close proximity the group is probably derived by division of a single founding individual.
taxon_text_7_832: Easily confused with the closely-related Pseudactinia flagellifera which is also found in much the same habitat. That species, however, grows to a larger size of up to 75 mm diameter, and is usually dirty orange in colour with up to 230 lighter-coloured tentacles, which often end in purple tips. There are also usually 3–5 rows of vesicles beneath the tentacles.
taxon_text_8_833:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_836: Shell elongate-rectangular, wider at posterior end, giving an oblique outline (hence species and common name), lower margin concave. Outer surface brown, sculptured with fine radiating ridges and covered with velvety black ‘fur’ that is often eroded away except along margins. Eroded areas of shell become white.
taxon_text_3_838:
Global: Widespread across tropical Indian and Pacific Oceans, southwards to South Africa.

Local/Regional: KwaZulu-Natal westwards to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_839: Usually found in small groups attached to underside of boulders in sandy pools, rock crevices, or among sponges. One of only a few species of this mainly tropical group that extend into cooler waters of the Western Cape. Details of biology unknown. The blood of Arc shells is unusual among bivalves in that it is red, due the presence of haemoglobin (possibly an adaptation to living in lower oxygen habitats under rocks?).
taxon_text_5_840: All bivalves feed by drawing water in then filtering it thought the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_841: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_842: Only two species of this characteristic and mostly tropical genus are found in the Western Cape, the other being the Sculptured ark shell B. sculpturata, which is smaller (up to 30 mm) and has less elongate, pink shell (central portion sometimes eroded to white) with a straight lower margin and yellow marginal fibers.
taxon_text_8_843:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 148).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 157).
taxon_text_1_846: Shell fat and more of less square in outline, ventral edge not concave. Shell valves pale pink, central section becoming white; ornamented with fine radiating ridges (these are paired when examined closely). Margins of shell with fringe of pale, yellowish threads. Usually attached to undersides of boulders in sandy sites.
taxon_text_3_848:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_849: Usually found in small groups attached to underside of boulders in sandy pools, rock crevices or among sponges. One of only a few species of this mainly tropical group to extend into cooler waters of the Western Cape. Details of biology unknown. The blood of Arc shells is unusual among bivalves in that it is red due the presence of haemoglobin (possibly an adaptation to living in lower oxygen habitats under rocks?).
taxon_text_5_850: All bivalves feed by drawing water in, then filtering it through the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_851: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_852: Only two species of this characteristic genus found in the Western Cape, the other being the oblique ark shell B. obliquata, which is larger (up to 58 mm) and has more elongate, darker shell (central portion sometimes eroded to white) with a concave lower margin. The shell of that species is also covered with a dense coating and fringe of black fibers, not yellow ones as here.
taxon_text_8_853: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 157).
taxon_text_1_856:
Shell large and fairly heavy with posterior end broader and squared-off, resulting in characteristic wedge-shaped appearance, after which common name is derived. External surface white to yellowish-brown, sometimes purple-tinged; mostly smooth except for faint concentric growth lines, but posterior end ornamented with course wavy concentric ridges. Internal colour white, suffused with violet which can be bright when alive but fades over time, margins of shells with faint crenulations. When alive, the elongate siphons extend into water column, inhalant siphon shorter and fatter with branched tentacles surrounding aperture, exhalent siphon long and slender, with smooth opening.

Commonly referred to as ‘white mussel’ but we prefer the term wedge clam as this is not technically a mussel (these being non-burrowing bivalves that attach themselves to solid substrata by secreting byssal threads) but a clam (infaunal bivalves that use their enlarged foot to burrow into soft sediments).
taxon_text_3_858:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_859:
One of the most abundant and iconic intertidal species on sandy beaches in the region, occurring in high densities at suitable sites, which tend to be those with clean, medium to course sand and moderate to high wave exposure. Interestingly the vertical distribution differs on west and south coasts. On the west coast, adults occur at extreme low water and below, while juveniles are found higher in the intertidal. On the south coast, this is reversed and adults are intertidal, with juveniles at lower levels. The reasons for this are not well understood.

Wedge clams do not migrate up and down the shore with the daily tides (as some other Donax species do), but can burrow rapidly back into the sand if displaced. They normally remain shallowly submerged beneath the sand surface and, when underwater, extend their elongate siphons up into the water overhead in order to filter-feed on fine food particles in the water. The siphons are often nipped of by predatory fish, but can be quicky regrown. Students studying diets of fish are often perplexed when trying to identify the siphons in the fish stomachs, as they resemble strange white tubular organisms!

Most of the considerable research that has been undertaken on this species has been done in the Eastern Cape, where populations are particularly dense. Here young spat settle subtidally and move up the shore as they grow. Growth is quite rapid, reaching 32 mm in the first year and 48 mm after two years, after which it slows.

Wedge clams are sought after for both bait and human consumption. A permit is required for recreational exploitation and a daily bag limit is used to manage the fishery. The stock could sustain a small commercial fishery, but there is considerable resistance from recreational users against this.
taxon_text_5_860: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_861: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. There is a small summer spawning and larger winter spawning each year.
taxon_text_7_862: Can be confused with the butterfly wedge-shell D. sordidus, which occurs in the same beaches. However, that species grows to a much smaller size, lacks the course wavy ridges running across the truncated posterior end of the shell, and lacks the purple interior.
taxon_text_8_863:
Brown, AC, Stenton-Dozey, JME & Trueman, ER (1989). Sandy-beach bivalves and gastropods: a comparison between Donax serra and Bullia digitalis. Advances in Marine Biology, 25, 179-247.

Laudien, J, Brey, T & Arntz, WE (2003). Population structure, growth and production of the surf clam Donax serra (Bivalvia, Donacidae) on two Namibian sandy beaches. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 58, 105-115.

McLachlan, A & Hanekom, N (1979). Aspects of the biology, ecology and seasonal fluctuations in biochemical composition of Donax serra in the East Cape. African Zoology, 14(4), 183-193.
taxon_text_1_866: Shell triangular but with extended anterior end and truncated posterior end. Surface smooth other than concentric growth lines and fine oblique ridges at posterior end. Colour white to very pale pinkish internally and externally, externally often with yellowish coating, especially near margin.
taxon_text_3_868:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_869: Burrows in clean sand on wave-exposed sandy beaches and unlike the related D. serra, which occurs on the same beaches, migrates up and down with the tide, popping out of the sand and allowing the swash to move it to a new location before rapidly re-burying itself using its large, mobile foot. Becomes more common towards eastern part of range. Fast growing and short lived, few individuals surviving more than about 17 months.
taxon_text_5_870: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_871: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Spawns twice a year in early summer and early winter and grows rapidly reaching 20 mm within one year.
taxon_text_7_872: Easily confused with juveniles of the wedge clam (or ‘white mussel’) D. serra which occurs in the same beaches. However, that species grows to a much larger size, has course wavy ridges running across the truncated posterior end of the shell and is tinged (often brightly) with purple internally.
taxon_text_8_873:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 156).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 189).

McLachlan, A (1979). Growth and production of Donax sordidus Hanley on an open sandy beach in Algoa Bay. African Zoology, 14(2): 61-66.
taxon_text_1_876: Medium-sized and slender with delicate, thin shell valves that are broadly rounded at the anterior end and longer and more tapering posteriorly, but are not bent to the side (as in Pallidea). Shell smooth, other than fine concentric growth lines. Colour glossy white.
taxon_text_3_878:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_879: Burrows in fine sediments from low water to about 8 m depth. Common on sandy beaches in the Western Cape. As in other tellins, essentially a deposit feeder, bending over the elongate siphons and moving them around on, or close to, the sediment surface to vacuum up food particles lying there.
taxon_text_5_880: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water through an exhalent siphon. Because of their deposit-feeding habits, tellins tend to suck in large amounts of sand along with their food material and thus have large labial palps, which are used to sort the incoming particle stream.
taxon_text_6_881: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle of this species in South Africa have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_882: Best distinguished from other regional tellins by colour pattern. At some sites occurs adjacent to the smaller Moerella tulipa, which is similar in shell shape but marked with pink concentric and transverse rays.
taxon_text_8_883:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 154, as Tellina trilatera).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 182, as Tellina trilatera).
taxon_text_9_885: Previously known as Tellina tulipa and Tellina gilchristi and given the common name Gilchrist’s tellin. Given the new scientific name, however, that now seems inappropriate, so we have changed the common name to a more descriptive ‘Tulip tellin’, also to match the new species name.
taxon_text_1_886: Fairy small and slender, with delicate, thin shell valves that are slightly extended posteriorly, but not bent to the side (as in Pallidea). Shell smooth, other than fine concentric growth lines. Colour off-white with both concentric and radiating pink lines that best distinguish it from other local tellines.
taxon_text_2_887: Relatively small, at up to 28 mm shell length.
taxon_text_3_888:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  St Helena Bay to Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_889: Burrows in fine sediments from low water to about 100 m depth. Fairly common in False Bay and other similar, sheltered sites but scarce elsewhere. As in other tellins, this species is essentially a deposit feeder, bending over the elongate siphons and moving them around to vacuum up food particles lying on, or close to, the sediment surface.
taxon_text_5_890: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalent siphon, filtering out fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water through an exhalent siphon.  Because of their feeding habits, tellins tend to suck in large amounts of sand along with their food material and thus have large labial palps, which are used to sort the incoming particle stream.
taxon_text_6_891: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle of this species in South Africa have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_892: Best distinguished from other regional tellins by colour pattern. At some sites occurs adjacent to the larger Homalina trilatera, which is similar in shell shape, but pure white in colour.
taxon_text_8_893:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 154).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 181).
taxon_text_9_895: Tellina alfredensis and hence also given the common name ‘Port Alfred tellin’. That no longer seems appropriate though, so we have also changed the common name to a more descriptive one based on the species name. Also previously named Tellina palliderosea.
taxon_text_1_896: Large for a tellin and with smooth (other than faint concentric growth lines), laterally-compressed shells that are distinctively extended and curved to the right at the posterior end.  Colour a striking pale pink, often with paler and darker growth bands; colouration more vivid on inner surface of shells.
taxon_text_2_897: Relatively large, at up to 85 mm shell length.
taxon_text_3_898:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_899: Burrows in sediments from low water to about 3 m depth. Lies horizontally with the left valve downwards and the elongate inhalant siphon projecting above the sediment surface and held horizontally to vacuum–up fine particulate material lying on, or close to, the sediment surface. Shells commonly washed-up after storms.
taxon_text_5_900: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water through an exhalent siphon.  Because of their feeding habits, tellins tend to suck in large amounts of sand along with their food material and thus have large labial palps, which are used to sort the incoming particle stream.
taxon_text_6_901: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle of this species in South Africa have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_902: One of the best know local bivalves and unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to the large size and striking colour.
taxon_text_8_903:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 154).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 181).
taxon_text_1_906: Small, almost perfectly round, fat, glossy-white clam. When seen alive the foot is elongate and mobile. This group is poorly studied and taxonomy needs revision (may be incorrectly named and also may be more than one local species represented!).
taxon_text_3_908:
Global: Originally described from Bass Strait, Australia and subsequently reported from South Africa, but unlikely these represent the same species. The local form is thus probably endemic to South Africa and would then need to be re-described under a new name.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_909: A nestling species, usually found singly or in small groups on the underside of boulders, in dead barnacle shells, or in crevices in intertidal rocks.
taxon_text_5_910: Very little is known about the feeding biology of this species, but almost all bivalves are filter-feeders, sucking in seawater and removing fine particulate material from it by passing the water though their enlarged sieve-like gills.
taxon_text_6_911: Has not been investigated for this species, but all members of this family are protandrous hermaphrodites - starting life as males and later changing to become females. Eggs are brooded within the mantle cavity, usually around the gills. In some species these are released as late-stage larvae, while in other species they are released only at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_912: Can be confused with another small roundish species Lasaea turtoni, which also occurs in similar habitats. However, that species is smaller (up to 5 mm), usually found in groups and is more oval with a pink to red tinged shell.
taxon_text_8_913:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 154).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 175).
taxon_text_9_915: Previously misidentified as Kellia rubra (a Europen species now re-named Lasaea adansoni).  Later reported as Lasaea adansoni turtoni, but as stated above the true L. adansoni is a Northern Hemisphere species and the South African subspecies is now recognized as its own separate species.
taxon_text_1_916: Tiny, fat bivalve with an oval outline and a distinct bulge behind hinge. Valves smooth, other than faint growth lines. Colour pale pink, usually with red-brown margins. Found among byssal threads of mussels or between barnacles or vermetid gastropod tubes on rocky shores.
taxon_text_2_917: Very small, shell length less than 5 mm.
taxon_text_3_918:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_919: A nestling species, often missed because of its small size, but in fact common on rocky shores, especially among byssal threads of mussels, or in crevices. Most members of this family are similarly associated with other larger invertebrates, especially filter-feeders, which may benefit the clams by generating water currents around them.
taxon_text_5_920: Very little is known about the feeding biology of this species, but almost all bivalves are filter-feeders, sucking in seawater and removing fine particulate material from it by passing the water though their enlarged sieve-like gills.
taxon_text_6_921: Has not been investigated for this species, but all members of this family are protandrous hermaphrodites - starting life as males and later changing to become females. Eggs are brooded with the mantle cavity, usually around the gills. In some species these are released as late-stage larvae, and in other species only at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_922: Can be confused with another small round species, Kellya rotunda, which also occurs in similar habitats. However, that species is larger (up to 11 mm), is usually found singly and is glossy white with an almost perfectly round shell.
taxon_text_8_923:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 154, as Lasaea adamsoni turtoni).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 175, as Lasaea adamsoni turtoni).
taxon_text_9_925: Previously misidentified as Limaria rotundata (which remains a valid species). Previous name Ostrea tuberculata.
taxon_text_1_926: Shell valves equal, delicate translucent white and ornamented with fine radiating ridges. A small lateral ‘ear’ next to the straight hinge. Live animal bright red and edged with numerous long, conspicuous, mobile tentacles. Foot has a bright purple tip.
taxon_text_3_928:
Global: Mediterranean, West Africa, southwards to Angola and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_929: A striking species that lives singly and unattached under boulders, in rock crevices or kelp holdfasts or similarly sheltered habitats, such as between tunicates or other sedentary organisms. At first sight the elongated tentacles could be confused with those of a sea anemone. Can swim clumsily by clapping the shell valves together, much like a scallop. The brightly-coloured marginal tentacles aid in defence by secreting acrid, sticky mucus and can be shed at will. Loose tentacles wriggle like discarded lizard tails, and this distracts predators. New tentacles develop rapidly to replace lost ones.
taxon_text_5_930: All bivalves feed by drawing water in then filtering it thought the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the edge of the gill and then to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_931: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_932: Several similar species occur in the more tropical waters of KwaZulu-Natal, but this is the only common coastal species in the Western Cape although L. loscombii also occurs in deeper offshore waters on the Agulhas Bank.
taxon_text_8_933:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 150).

Kilburn, RN (1998). The Limidae of South Africa and Mozambique (Mollusca: Bivalvia): genera Limaria, Limatula, Divarilima, Ctenoides and Fukama. Annals of the Natal Museum, 39, 203-247.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 169, as L. rotundata).
taxon_text_1_5815: Unusual species in which the head is retracted between the anterior body segments and is concealed by a prominent circular ‘cage’ of long, forward-projecting, stiff, annulated setae. The body is stiff and covered with rings of tiny wart-like papillae. The posterior end is strongly tapered and usually bent, or reflexed forward.
taxon_text_3_5817:
Global: There are over 40 species globally in this genus including several from South Africa and these are difficult to distinguish, so we can only identify images to genus level.

Local/Regional: Unknown, as species not identified.
taxon_text_4_5818: Thought to live in rock crevices and holes and to hold the body in a U-shape, so as to eject faeces from the opening of the hole. Feed using a pair of frilly palps in the head to sweep detritus from the setal cage.
taxon_text_5_5819: Detritus feeders, picking up organic material with frilly palps on the head.
taxon_text_6_5820: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_5821: The stiff cages of elongate setae around the head are characteristic. The Flabby bristleworm Flabelligera affinis belongs to the same family and has a similar, but much smaller, anteriorsetal cage, but that species in much softer and more mobile and is also covered in a sheath of green mucus.
taxon_text_8_5822:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 743).

Seitz, RD & Schaffer, LC (1995). Population ecology and secondary production of the polychaete Loimia medusa (Terebellidae). Marine Biology, 121, 701-711.
taxon_text_1_776:
Zoanthids resemble small anemones and similarly have a columnar body topped by a ring of tentacles surrounding a central mouth. Unlike anemones though, they are colonial and colony members are united by a basal sheet of tissue. Most species carpet tropical shores, this one is thus unusual both in its temperate distribution and because it occurs in overhangs and under boulders, rather than in the open.

Colonies are generally small and formed of a few dozen individuals, each of which is orange to pink, has a column covered on course sand and is topped by about 30 relatively long (for a zoanthid) tentacles.
taxon_text_2_777: Polyps about 12 mm tall, colonies up to 10 cm across.
taxon_text_3_778:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_779: Found rather in caves and overhangs and beneath boulders. Unlike many other regional zoanthids lack symbiotic algae (zooxanthellae) so relies entirely on capturing food with the tentacles.
taxon_text_5_780: Small planktonic prey are captured with the tentacles, which are armed with stinging calls, and are transferred to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_781: Zoanthids can reproduce both sexually and asexually. New colonies are founded via the release of sperm and eggs into the water. After fertilization eggs develop into planktonic larvae which are transported to new sites, where they settle and transform into the adult form. Once established colonies develop by budding of the original founding individual and all members of the colony are genetically identical and remain connected to one another via a basal carpet of tissue.
taxon_text_7_782: Several other zoanthid species are common on subtropical shores to the east of South Africa, but this is one of few to occur in temperate parts of the country. It is unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to its pink colour and cryptic habitat.
taxon_text_8_783:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 30)

Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.
taxon_text_9_675: Previously incorrectly thought to be Actinia equina (a valid but European species); at one point also invalidly named A. mandelae.
taxon_text_1_676:
Column short, squat and smooth, glossy dark red, tentacles about 90 in number, relatively short and lighter red to brown than column. A characteristic row of round, bright blue spherules found underneath the outer ring of tentacles.

Also readily recognized by its habitat, as it is one of very few anemones found high in the intertidal and able to survive in air for extended periods.
taxon_text_2_677: Column diameter usually about 20 mm. When open can reach 60 mm across, including tentacles.
taxon_text_3_678:
Global: Currently recorded as endemic to South Africa, although samples reported under the name E. equina from West Africa may turn out to represent this, rather than the European, species.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to about East London. A green form also found around Durban.
taxon_text_4_679:
Easily recognized by virtue of both its appearance (uniform glossy dark-red colour and blue spherule) and its unusual habitats, being the only regional anemone to survive out of water for extended periods.

 Usually occurs singly or in small spread-out groups in shaded gullies or rocky overhangs in the mid- to low- intertidal. When exposed to air closes up tightly, trapping water in the body cavity and hanging like plump, ripe fruit from the rock surface. Water is gradually released from the mouth to keep the animal moist and to reduce body temperature via evaporative cooling.

South African specimens were originally thought to represent the widespread European species A. equina and were only recognized and described as a local endemic species in 2011.
taxon_text_5_680: The prey spectrum of this species differs from that of most other regional intertidal anemones and it is the only species to feature insects as a significant component of the diet. The most common group found in the guts of specimens from the Cape Peninsula were small bivalves (28%), particularly the tiny Nucula nucleus; followed by insects (26%) and then isopods (24%).
taxon_text_6_681: Members of this genus are unusual in that larvae are brooded within the gut cavity and released as tiny, fully-formed tiny anemones 1–3 mm in diameter. These settle on adjacent rocks close to the adults (see photo below). Single adults of the European species have been recorded brooding up to 100 embryos.
taxon_text_7_682: Unlikely to be confused with any other regional anemones due to the uniform dark rusty-red colour, row of blue spherules outside the tentacles and ability to survive in air. Similar in colour to the Natal anemone Anemonia natalensis, which is common in KwaZulu-Natal, but that species normally occurs in rock pools and has radiating lines across the oral disc from the mouth to the bases of the tentacles.
taxon_text_8_683:
Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Schama, R, Mitchell, M, & Solé-Cava, AM (2012). Actinia ebhayiensis sp. nov., a new species of sea anemone (Anthozoa: Actiniaria: Actiniidae) from South Africa. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 92(5), 885–894.
taxon_text_1_568: Large, heavily-built, off-white, air-breathing isopod resembling a very large, stout woodlouse. Eyes prominent and black, first antennae minute, second antennae held laterally; pleotelson short and rounded; dorsal surface of body granuate. Found at and above the driftline of exposed sandy beaches along west coast. Rolls up tightly into a ball when disturbed.
taxon_text_3_570:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to Cape Point.
taxon_text_4_571:
An iconic and well-studied species typical of exposed sandy beaches wherever drift kelp is washed ashore. Strictly nocturnal. Adults spend the day buried in deep burrows excavated up to 40 cm below the sand surface and above the high water mark. Emerge before nocturnal low tides and trundle down the beach in search of drift algae. After feeding, return above the high water mark to rebury themselves. Burrowing is achieved by scraping the sand backwards, while at the same time turning the body, thus create a pit-shaped hollow. Once the head is directed downwards the animal continues to burrow down vertically until it reached cool moist sand, where it remains quiescent until the next low tide. Incoming burrows are thus marked by a molehill-like mound, whereas emergent ones are plain round holes flush with the sand surface.

 Since low tide occurs about 50 minutes later each night, the time of emergence is correspondingly delayed on successive nights. Eventually the time of emergence would start to occur after dawn, and then the isopods switch back to emerging in the evening, shortly after dark!

Tylos can reach impressive densities in suitable sites and watching them emerge and feed at night is a dramatic regional wildlife experience. Unfortunately, though, numbers have declined dramatically at some sites and they are no longer found in the vicinity of Cape Town, where much of the early research was undertaken. The causes of these declines are not certain but possible reasons may include disturbance, pollution events, removal of kelp from the beaches or disorientation due to light pollution from land-based sources.
taxon_text_5_572: Feed principally on decaying kelp washed up along the drift line but have also been seen taking animal material such as dead insects.
taxon_text_6_573: As in all isopods the eggs are incubated in a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of females and emerge as fully-formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_574: A second smaller and smooth bodied species T. capensis, if found from Cape Point Eastwards to about Port Elizabeth but the ranges of the two species do not overlap. Unlikely to be confused with any other regional isopods due to its large size and unusual habits.
taxon_text_8_575:
Kensley, BF (1974). Aspects of the biology and ecology of the genus Tylos Latreille. Annals of the South African Museum 65 (11): 401-471.

Marsh, BA, & Branch, GM (1979). Circadian and circatidal rhythms of oxygen consumption in the sandy-beach isopod Tylos granulatus Krauss. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 37(1), 77-89.

Odendaal, FJ, Eekhout, S, Brown, AC, & Branch, GM (1999). Aggregations of the sandy-beach isopod, Tylos granulatus: adaptation or incidental-effect? African Zoology, 34(4): 180-189.
taxon_text_1_559: Relatively large, heavily-built, off-white, air-breathing isopod resembling a large woodlouse, but considerably smaller than the closely-related west coast T. granulatus (from which it is anatomically distinguished by the fact that the ventral processes of pleonite 5 do not meet in the midline). Eyes black, first antennae minute, second antennae held laterally; dorsal surface of body smooth. Found at and above the drift line of exposed sandy beaches along the south coast and rolls up tightly into a ball when disturbed.
taxon_text_3_561:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Port Elizabeth.
taxon_text_4_562:
Found on exposed sandy beaches wherever drift kelp or other algae is washed ashore. Strictly nocturnal, adults spending the day buried in deep burrows excavated below the sand surface above the high-water mark. Emerge before nocturnal low tides and trundle down the beach in search of drift algae. After feeding, return above the high-water mark to rebury themselves.

Habits probably similar to those of the much more intensively studied west coast species T. granulatus, but have not been so studied and are not nearly as common, normally being found only in small numbers.
taxon_text_5_563: Feed principally on decaying kelp washed up along the drift line but have also been seen climbing into and feeding on Bietou bushes above the beach.
taxon_text_6_564: As in all isopods the eggs are incubated in a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of females and emerge as fully-formed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_565: A second much larger-bodied and granular species T. granulatus, is found from Cape Point westwards to Namibia, but the ranges of the two species do not overlap. Unlikely to be confused with any other regional isopods due to its large size and unusual air breathing habits.
taxon_text_8_566:
Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 88).

Brown, AC, & Odendaal, FJ (1994). The biology of oniscid Isopoda of the genus Tylos. Advances in Marine Biology, 30, 89-153.

Kensley, BF (1974). Aspects of the biology and ecology of the genus Tylos Latreille. Annals of the South African Museum, 65 (11), 401-471.
taxon_text_9_935: The South African material was described as Pholas jordani by van Hoepen (1941), but that species was subsequently merged with P. dactylus, which is a European species, by Barnard (1964). Recent research by the Sea Change group has shown that the South African form is genetically distinct from the European one and hence the original name needs to be re-erected for local material. This has not yet been formally done though, so at the time of writing the official name remains P. dactylus.
taxon_text_1_936: Highly distinctive and iconic species with elongate, pure white shell that gapes widely at anterior end. There are a pair of unique accessory shell plates covering the hinge, and a row of exterior partitions above the hinge, which allow even fragments of dead shell to be positively identified. The exterior of the shell is ornamented with concentric rows of sharp pricky ridges, which are used to file away the rock and form the burrow. Also readily identified by its unusual habit of excavating deep, tapering burrows onto soft sandstone and limestone.
taxon_text_3_938:
Global: Jordani form endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_939:
Excavate elongate, linear, tapering burrows deep into soft rocks. The burrow is created by rocking the shells against the walls of the burrow such that the sharp, rasp-like prickles on the exterior of the shell erode away the rock. As the animal grows, the burrow is extended deeper into the rock and becomes progressively wider, reaching to at least 20 cm depth in large individuals. The large siphons project from the gaping anterior end of the shell and reach our through the small aperture into the overlying water.

 Apart from their unusual rock-burrowing habits, piddocks are also well known for their ability to produce  a luminous mucus. The European species has been extensively exploited for human consumption since Roman times and as extracting and collecting piddocks involves destruction of their habitat, the species is now endangered and strictly protected in Europe. As only a small number of live colonies are known to exist in South Africa, these should probably also be protected against similar over-exploitation.
taxon_text_5_940: As with most bivalves filter-feed by sucking water in through an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine food particles by passing the water though the enlarged sieve-like gills and then ejecting waste water though a exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_941: Broadcast spawners, ejecting sperm and eggs into the water column, where they merge to form pelagic larvae to drift in the plankton and settle in other suitable sites.
taxon_text_7_942: Unlikely to be confused with other species due to the unusual rock-boring habits and unusual shell structure. Burrows are sometimes confused with those created by another rock boring species Petricola bicolar, but piddock burrows are much deeper, linear and tapering, while those of Petricola are shallow and cup shaped.
taxon_text_8_943:
Barnard, KH (1964). Contributions to the knowledge of South African marine Mollusca V. Lamellibranchiata. Annals of the South African Museum, 47, 361-593.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 201).
taxon_text_9_945: Referred to as Mytilus crenatus in older literature. Frequently misspelt as Aulacomya ater.
taxon_text_1_946: Unmistakable due to the strong wavy ridges that run the length of the shells, which are light brown in juveniles, becoming darker and almost black in larger adults. Eroded sections of the shells, which have lost their outer coating, appear white. Interior of shells white.
taxon_text_2_947: Reaches 95 mm in deeper water, but intertidal specimens seldom exceed 70 mm shell length.
taxon_text_3_948:
Global: Widespread on both Pacific and Atlantic coasts of South America and in southern Africa, also found in New Zealand. An introduced population has established in Scotland.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to about Port Alfred in the Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_949:
A primarily subtidal species that can be abundant in kelp beds and on shallow reefs up to depth of 40 m, especially along the west coast, where it is reported to be an important food source for rock lobsters. Intertidal populations have now been largely replaced by the faster-growing and introduced Mediterranean mussel, Mytilus galloprovincialis, which is more tolerant of aerial exposure. However A. atra persist within the Mytilus beds, which may in fact may protect them and allow them to persist higher up on the shore than before.

 Compared with other regional mussel species, growth is slow and maximum size is only reached after about 10 years. The ridges on the shell increase its strength and resistance to predation, such that large specimens are immune to most predators.
taxon_text_5_950:
All mussels feed by drawing water in through a distal and ventral inhalent siphon, which is surrounded by branched lobes to keep out particles too large to be consumed. The water is then filtered thought the enlarged sieve-like gills and ejected though a dorsal, smooth-edged exhalent siphon. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth at the anterior (pointed) end, where they are sorted by the labial palps and lighter particles ingested. Inedible particles are rejected by the palps and ejected as ‘pseudofaeces’ which has not passed thought the digestive tract.

They feed on suspended organic matter, bacteria, phytoplankton, microalgae and detritus. This interaction with the water column means they are instrumental in pelagic-benthic coupling and nutrient cycling.
taxon_text_6_951:
Mussels are unusual in that the gonad permeates throughout the body and when ripe can make up more than 50% of the total body weight. Spawning is usually synchronised via hormones released with the sperm and eggs and after spawning ‘spent’ individuals are thin and flaccid. Spawning is triggered by temperature changes and in temperate areas spawning occurs predictably in spring and autumn. However, in South Africa sea temperatures show much more seasonal stability and spawning tends to be more irregular and is probably triggered by short-term upwelling events. The numbers of eggs produced is enormous, running to the millions per mussel and hence billions per square meter of mussel bed! Larval development takes about 30 days and juvenile mussels (spat) sometimes settle in densities of hundreds of thousands per square meter.

In this species males make up 66% of the population and females only 34%. Spawning seems to take place three times a year although the timing and intensity of spawning events differs considerably between years.
taxon_text_7_952: The only regional member of the genus and unlikely to be confused with other mussel species due to the unusual longitudinal ridges on the shells.
taxon_text_8_953:
Avendaño, M & Cantillánez, M (2014). Reproductive cycle of Aulacomya ater [Bivalvia: Mytilidae (Molina 1782)] in Punta Arenas Cove (Antofagasta Region, Chile). Aquaculture International, 22(4), 1229–1244.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 146).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 158).

Van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths, CL (1990). Marine mussels of southern Africa: Their distribution patterns, standing stocks, exploitation and culture. Journal of Shellfish Research, 9, 75-85.

van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths, CL (1991). A comparison of reproductive cycles and reproductive output in four southern African mussel species. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 76, 123-134.
taxon_text_1_956: Large, smooth-shelled, shiny black mussel, narrow in cross-section. Eroded areas of the shell become blue. Internally the shell is blueish–white.  The gonads (which permeate most of the body) colour the flesh of males a distinctive dark chocolate brown, while females are light yellow. Prefers sand-inundated sites.
taxon_text_3_958:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to about Algoa Bay in the Eastern Cape, but most common west of Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_959: Prefers areas which are partially inundated by sand and often found attached to rocks that are partially buried in sediment, such that only the broad posterior end of the shell is visible (see image below). Very common on flat subtidal reefs and sand-inundated areas in the intertidal. Tend to be quite weakly attached and often wash up in vast numbers after storms. Juveniles often settle along the margins of the shells of adults and later migrate down between them, attaching to the rocks and ultimately displacing the adults by forcing them upwards and replacing them. Growth is rapid and can reach 70 mm after the first year when permanently submerged, but is slower in intertidal populations, which have reduced opportunity to feed, which of course they can only do when submerged.
taxon_text_5_960: All mussels feed by drawing water in though a distal and ventral inhalant siphon, which is surrounded by branched lobes to keep out particles too large to be consumed. The water is then filtered thought the enlarged sieve-like gills and ejected though a dorsal, smooth-edged exhalent siphon. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth at the anterior (pointed) end, where they are sorted by the labial palps and lighter particles ingested. Inedible particles are rejected by the palps and ejected as ‘pseudofaeces’ which has not passed thought the digestive tract. Not surprisingly, given its sandy habitat, this species is particularly adept at separating sand from food and can feed even in very turbid water conditions.
taxon_text_6_961:
Mussels are unusual in that the gonad permeates throughout the body and when ripe can make up more than 50% of the total body weight. Spawning is usually synchronised via hormones released with the sperm and eggs and after spawning ‘spent’ individuals are thin and flaccid. Spawning is triggered by temperature changes and in temperate areas spawning occurs predictably in spring and autumn. However, in South Africa sea temperatures show much more seasonal stability and spawning tends to be more irregular and is probably triggered by short-term upwelling events. The numbers of eggs produced is enormous, running to the millions per mussel and hence billions per square meter of mussel bed! Larval development takes about 30 days and juvenile mussels (spat) sometimes settle in densities of hundreds of thousands per square meter.

In this species about 60 % of adults are males and 40 % females. There are normally two protracted breeding seasons a year, but the timing of these is quite variable
taxon_text_7_962:
Easily confused with the introduced Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis and even experts can find it difficult to separate juveniles. Large individuals can be separated by both shell shape and shell colour. Mytilus are broader in cross-section and have a flattened base, while Choromytilus are more slender, with the widest point mid-way up the shell. Thus large Mytilus can stand upright on a flat surface, whereas Choromytilus always fall over onto their sides. Large Mytilus are also usually strongly eroded with rough light blue sides, whereas most Chromytilus remain black and shiny into adulthood.

Internally, females can also be separated by gonad colour (orange in Mytilus and chocolate brown in Choromytilus). If all else fails it is necessary to examine the resilial ridge (the white band alongside the hinge ligament) under the microscope. This is pitted In Mytilus and smooth in Choromytilus and can be used to identify even small, immature individuals.
taxon_text_8_963:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 146).

Griffiths, RJ (1981). Population dynamics and growth of the bivalve Choromytilus meridionalis (Kr.) at different tidal levels. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 12(1), 101-118.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 158).

van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths, CL (1991). A comparison of reproductive cycles and reproductive output in four southern African mussel species. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 76, 123-134.
taxon_text_1_966: Large, smooth-shelled, black or blue-grey mussel (rarely yellowish when grown in low light conditions). Adults broad in cross-section, especially towards base. Lateral areas of shell often eroded and appear pitted and light blue. One of the dominant species in the low to mid intertidal on exposed rocky shores, where they form dense, often multi-layered beds on sediment-free sites. Rarely found sub tidally, despite thriving on permanently-submerged ropes under culture conditions.
taxon_text_2_967: Can reach 140 mm shell length when permanently submerged, but seldom exceed 85 mm intertidally.
taxon_text_3_968:
Global: Extremely widespread. Native to Europe and Mediterranean region, but has been widely dispersed by shipping and now also found in Asia, Pacific coast of USA, New Zealand, Australia, South America and southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to Eastern Cape, but most common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_969:
Accidentally introduced to South Africa in about 1979 and quickly spread northwards from SW Cape to Namibia and eastwards to Eastern Cape. Now a dominant species on rocky shores all along the west coast, but less abundant on the south coast. Physiological research suggests that the species is unlikely to expand further east into the warmer waters of KwaZulu-Natal. More tolerant of arial exposure than other regional mussel species, thus extending mussel beds higher up into the intertidal than before.

Certainly the most significant marine invasive species in the region to date and has multiple ecological and economic impacts. Many invaded shores were previously dominated by large grazing limpets, which kept the rocks fairly open and clear. These sites are now carpeted by dense mussel beds and thus support a much larger biomass and a greater diversity of species, especially small forms which now find shelter between the mussels. Some limpet species have been displaced, while others have managed to survive among the mussels by becoming dwarfed and living and feeding on their curved shell valves. Food availability for predators has also increased and this has been to the advantage of species such as the Black African Oystercatcher, which now has access to more food, which is also available for more hours in the day. Also used for human consumption and a significant culture industry based on this species is centred in Saldanha Bay. Surprisingly the mussels settle and thrive in the permanently-submerged culture ropes, but do not appear to occur in significant numbers on other submerged habits, but remain mostly restricted to the intertidal.
taxon_text_5_970: All mussels feed by drawing water in though a distal and ventral inhalant siphon, which is surrounded by branched lobes to keep out particles too large to be consumed. The water is then filtered thought the enlarged sieve-like gills and ejected though a dorsal, smooth-edged exhalent siphon. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth at the anterior (pointed) end, where they are sorted by the labial palps and lighter particles ingested. Inedible particles are rejected by the palps and ejected as ‘pseudo faeces’ which has not passed thought the digestive tract.
taxon_text_6_971:
Mussels are unusual in that the gonad permeates throughout the body and when ripe can make up more than 50% of the total body weight. Spawning is usually synchronised via hormones released with the sperm and eggs and after spawning ‘spent’ individuals are thin and flaccid. Spawning is triggered by temperature changes and in temperate areas spawning occurs predictably in spring and autumn. However, in South Africa sea temperatures show much more seasonal stability and spawning tends to be more irregular and is probably triggered by short-term upwelling events. The numbers of eggs produced is enormous, running to the millions per mussel and hence billions per square meter of mussel bed! Larval development takes about 30 days and juvenile mussels (spat) sometimes settle in densities of hundreds of thousands per square meter.

This species has and equal sex ratio (48% male, 52% female) and usually breeds twice a year, once in summer and once in winter.
taxon_text_7_972:
Easily confused with the Black mussel Choromytilus meridionalis and even experts can find it difficult to separate juveniles. Large individuals can be separated by both shell shape and shell colour. Mytilus are broader in cross-section and have a flattened base, while Choromytilus are more slender with the widest point mid-way up the shell. Thus large Mytilus can stand upright on a flat surface, whereas Choromytilus always fall over onto their sides. Large Mytilus are also usually strongly eroded with rough, light-blue sides, whereas most Chromytilus remain black and shiny into adulthood.

Internally, females can also be separated by gonad colour (orange in Mytilus and chocolate brown in Choromytilus). If all else fails it is necessary to examine the resilial ridge (the white band alongside the hinge ligament on the inside of the shell) under the microscope. This is pitted In Mytilus and smooth in Choromytilus and can be used to identify even small, immature individuals.
taxon_text_8_973:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 146)

Robinson, TB, Branch, GM, Griffiths, CL, Govender, A & Hockey, PAR (2007). Changes in South African rocky intertidal invertebrate community structure associated with the invasion of the mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 340, 163-171.

Van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths, CL (1990). Marine mussels of southern Africa: Their distribution patterns, standing stocks, exploitation and culture. Journal of Shellfish Research, 9, 75-85.

van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths, CL (1991). A comparison of reproductive cycles and reproductive output in four southern African mussel species. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 76, 123-134.
taxon_text_1_976: Large, smooth-shelled brown mussel, sometimes tinged with green or (in juveniles) with a chevron pattern. Eroded areas of the shell white or silvery. May form dense beds in lower intertidal zone and then become elongated, almost square in cross-section, and dented where rub against neighbours. Internally, gonads of females orange and those of males off-white. Resilial ridge (narrow white band alongside the hinge ligament on inner surface of shell) finely pitted.
taxon_text_2_977: Reaches 125 mm in deeper water, but intertidal specimens seldom exceed 90 mm shell length.
taxon_text_3_978:
Global: Widespread across the western Indian Ocean and Atlantic coast of South America, as well as Namibia. Introduced to Gulf coast of USA.

Local/Regional: Namibia and south and east coasts of South Africa, but absent from west coast.
taxon_text_4_979:
Primarily a warmer-water species that forms dense intertidal beds on rocky shores from False Bay eastwards along the south and especially east coasts of South Africa, where it is commonly collected for human consumption. Absent from the west coast but then, surprisingly, reappears again in Namibia.

Along the south coast occurs in mixed beds with the Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, but there is some separation between the species as Perna has a stronger byssal attachment to the rocks, so is more tolerant of wave-exposed sites, whereas Mytilus can tolerate longer periods of aerial exposure, so dominates at higher tidal levels. Was once abundant in False Bay, but is now rare there and restricted to a few shallow, warmer sites because of declining sea temperatures occurring in this area over the past few decades.
taxon_text_5_980: All mussels feed by drawing water in though a distal and ventral inhalant siphon, which is surrounded by branched lobes to keep out particles too large to be consumed. The water is then filtered thought the enlarged sieve-like gills and ejected though a dorsal smooth-edged exhalent siphon. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth at the anterior (pointed) end, where they are sorted by the labial palps and lighter particles ingested. Inedible particles are rejected by the palps and ejected as ‘pseudo faeces’ which has not passed thought the digestive tract.
