taxon_text_6_981:
Mussels are unusual in that the gonad permeates throughout the body and when ripe can make up more than 50% of the total body weight. Spawning is usually synchronised via hormones released with the sperm and eggs and after spawning ‘spent’ individuals are thin and flaccid. Spawning is triggered by temperature changes and in temperate areas occurs predictably in spring and sometimes also autumn. However, in South Africa sea temperatures show much more seasonal stability and spawning tends to be more irregular and is probably triggered by short-term upwelling events. The numbers of eggs produced is enormous, running to the millions per mussel and hence billions per square meter of mussel bed! Larval development takes about 30 days and juvenile mussels (spat) sometimes settle in densities of hundreds of thousands per square meter.

In this species males are more common (64%) and females (36%). The breeding season has been documented in several different areas and differs between sites (and/or years). There is usually either one extended breeding season, or two discreet events.
taxon_text_7_982: The brown colour is fairly distinctive and a reliable identification feature, but could be confused with the introduced Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, as they often occur in mixed beds. The shells of Perna are more elongate and shorter in the vertical dimension. There are also differences in the adductor muscle scars on the inside of the shells (Perna has one anterior scar and a divided posterior scar and Mytilus two anterior scars and an undivided posterior one - see Van Erkom Schurink paper listed below for diagrams showing differences.
taxon_text_8_983:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 146)

Bownes, SJ & McQuaid, CD (2006). Will the invasive mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis Lamarck replace the indigenous Perna perna L. on the south coast of South Africa? Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 338(1), 140-151.

Van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths CL (1990). Marine mussels of southern Africa: Their distribution patterns, standing stocks, exploitation and culture. Journal of Shellfish Research, 9, 75-85.

Van Erkom Schurink, C & Griffiths, CL (1991). A comparison of reproductive cycles and reproductive output in four southern African mussel species. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 76, 123-134.
taxon_text_1_986: Small, relatively delicate, smooth-shelled mussel with a brown to black shell, often tinged with green. The anterior (pointed) end is markedly swollen relative to other regional species. Internally most individuals are hermaphrodite, with male gonad on the one side and female on the other, but a small proportion of individuals in the native Chile have been shown to be entirely male or entirely female.
taxon_text_2_987: Most common in low intertidal, where specimens seldom exceed 50 mm, but deeper water specimens can attain almost double that size.
taxon_text_3_988:
Global: Native to Chile, but accidentally introduced to both Namibia and west coast of South Africa.

Local/Regional: South African population ranges from Groenrivier on west coast to about Hermanus, but is still spreading eastwards.
taxon_text_4_989:
First detected in South Africa in 2009, but as the population was already widespread and well-established when discovered, certainly present for some time previously. Most abundant in the lower intertidal, where it often occurs adjacent to and below the Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, another invasive species which dominates the mid-intertidal zone across much the same range. The two species are often separated by a distinct boundary, with the paler and larger Mytilus above and smaller, darker Semimytilus below!

Usually occurs in extremely dense beds, newly-settled spat carpeting the rocks in densities exceeding 100 000 per meter squared. As growth proceeds self-thinning occurs, smaller individuals often physically undermining and forcing larger ones off the rocks (see image below). Since the mussels are small and tightly-packed, they offer less habitat for infaunal species than the larger Mytilus, so the beds are relatively devoid of other organisms. Small limpets, for example, are absent here, but common living on Mytilus shells. Being small, abundant and relatively thin-shelled this species probably forms a new and plentiful food source for various local predators, such as rock-lobsters, drilling whelks and kelp gulls and may thus benefit those populations, while displacing and outcompeting other sessile animals, such as limpets.

Recent studies show that the species is still expanding eastwards and has extended its eastward limit from Blauberg in 2010 to Hermanus in 2022.
taxon_text_5_990: All mussels feed by drawing water in though a distal and ventral inhalant siphon, which is surrounded by branched lobes to keep out particles too large to be consumed. The water is then filtered thought the enlarged sieve-like gills and ejected though a dorsal, smooth-edged exhalent siphon. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth at the anterior (pointed) end, where they are sorted by the labial palps and lighter particles ingested. Inedible particles are rejected by the palps and ejected as ‘pseudo faeces’ which has not passed thought the digestive tract.
taxon_text_6_991: Mussels are unusual in that the gonad permeates throughout the body and when ripe can make up more than 50% of the total body weight. Spawning is usually synchronised via hormones released with the sperm and eggs and after spawning ‘spent’ individuals are thin and flaccid. Spawning is triggered by temperature changes and in temperate areas spawning occurs predictably in spring and autumn. However, in South Africa sea temperatures show much more seasonal stability and spawning tends to be more irregular and is probably triggered by short-term upwelling events. The numbers of eggs produced is enormous, running to the millions per mussel and hence billions per square meter of mussel bed!  Larval development takes about 30 days and juvenile mussels (spat) sometimes settle in densities of hundreds of thousands per square meter. The way hermaphroditic gonads of this species affect reproduction (for example whether individuals can self-fertilise) is not known.
taxon_text_7_992:
Easily confused with the Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, which occurs on the same sites and often adjacently on the rocks. The species can, however, be separated by both shell shape and shell colour. Mytilus are narrow and ‘pointed’ at the anterior end, whereas Semimytilus are notable swollen. Mytilus are also usually strongly eroded with rough, light blue sides, whereas most Semumytilis are brown especially ventrally (sometimes with black margin) and have green tinges.

If all else fails it is necessary to examine the resilial ridge (the white band alongside the hinge ligament on the inside of the shell) under the microscope. This is pitted in Mytilus and smooth in Semimytilus and can be used to differentiate even small, immature individuals.
taxon_text_8_993:
De Greef K, Zeeman, Z & Griffiths, CL (2013). Déjà vu? A second mytilid mussel, Semimytilus algosus, invades South Africa’s west coast. African Journal of Marine Science, 35, 307-313.

Skein, L, Alexander, M, & Robinson, T (2018). Contrasting invasion patterns in intertidal and subtidal mussel communities. African Zoology, 53(1), 47-52.
taxon_text_1_996: Very large, fragile, pale-brown bivalve with marked longitudinal rows of external scale-like cusps that run the length of each shell. Shells gape widely at the posterior (upper) end, which projects from the substratum. An elongate hinge ligament joins the shells along dorsal margin and a dense bunch of long byssal threads projects from the ventral margin anchoring the shell to pebbles and other nearly objects.
taxon_text_3_998:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_999: Lives partially buried in the sand in sheltered sites at depth of up to about 35 m with the posterior (broad and gaping) end of the shell projecting into the water. Often densely overgrown with fouling organisms, such that each mussel acts as a small ‘island’ supporting a community of smaller hard-substratum organisms. The commensal crab Pinnotheres dolfeini is commonly found on the gills and steals food from the mussel. The elongate byssal threads of similar horse mussels in the Mediterranean were once woven into a strong and highly prized cloth thought, for example, to have been used to weave Jason’s Golden Fleece of Greek mythology. Dead shells, or pieces of shell, are often washed ashore after storms and have a beautiful shiny internal nacreous layer. Pearls are also sometimes produced.
taxon_text_5_1000: All bivalves feed by drawing water in then filtering it through the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_1001: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_1002: Unlikely to be confused with any other regional species due to its large size and marked external scales. Replaced on more tropical eastern parts of South Africa by the furrowed horse-mussel Pinna muricata, which has smaller external cusps and a distinct furrow running down the inner surface in the centre of each valve. Early records of A. squamifera from the east coast are misidentifications of P. muricata.
taxon_text_8_1003:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 148).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 167).
taxon_text_1_1006: Shell irregularly-shaped and flattened, with the left valve cemented to the substratum and the right valve lying above it. The lower valve is only shallowly cupped and lacks any recess beneath the hinge. Colour white internally, often with a pink margin. Upper valve red or purplish-brown externally and textured by course overlapping growth layers, which may be eroded away in central area. Live animals are often densely overgrown by fouling organisms and can be very difficult to spot, especially when valves closed.
taxon_text_3_1008:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1009: Fossil beds of dead shells abundant in Langebaan Lagoon, where they were once dredged to make agricultural lime, but live animals no longer found there. Mostly occur singly or in small groups on shallow reefs, where they mostly go unnoticed due to dense overgrowth of fouling organisms. Edible, but not commonly exploited as uncommon and hard to find.
taxon_text_5_1010: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1011: As with other members of this genus, individual are hermaphrodite and eggs are incubated before release as late stage larvae with spend about two weeks in the plankton before settling.
taxon_text_7_1012: May be confused with the cape rock oyster Striostrea margaritacea, which has an overlapping distribution and similar habitat preferences. However, that species has the lower valve much deeper and has a hollowed-out recess internally beneath the hinge.
taxon_text_8_1013:
Compton, JS (2001). Holocene sea-level fluctuations inferred from the evolution of depositional environments of the southern Langebaan Lagoon salt marsh, South Africa. The Holocene, 11(4), 395-405.

Haupt, TM, Griffiths, CL, Robinson, TB, Tonin, AF & De Bruyn, PA (2010). The history and status of oyster exploitation and culture in South Africa. Journal of Shellfish Research, 29(1), 151-159.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 170).
taxon_text_1_1016: Typical of this family, the shell is irregularly-shaped and flattened, with the deeper left valve cemented to the substratum and the smaller, flatter right valve lying above it. In this species the lower valve is deep, heavy and thick and made up of multiple layers of shell. There is a distinct cup-like recess beneath the hinge, such that older shells may be quite elongate and extended into a ‘beak’ beneath and behind the hinge. The lower valve is white internally, sometimes with pink or purplish markings, and the upper valve flat and often externally marked by radiating lines.
taxon_text_3_1018:
Global: South Africa eastwards to Madagascar and Tanzania

Local/Regional: False Bay eastwards to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1019:
Uncommon west of Cape Agulhas, where it is usually found individually in low intertidal pools, but a common and well-known species on the south and east coast of South Africa, where it  forms scattered beds at extreme low tide and on shallow reefs.

Regularly exploited for human consumption and the most economically important indigenous oyster in the region. Marketable size is reached after about 33 months and oysters are harvested both commercially and recreationally. In KwaZulu-Natal the coastline is divided into 10 management zones with commercial fishing allowed in two years out of five in each zones. Recreational collection is allowed in the years preceding commercial harvesting in each zone. Annual commercial catches in the early 2000s were about 200 000 oysters per year. On the Cape coast effort is controlled by licencing pickers and by a short closed season over the peak holiday season. Annual commercial catch in this region over the early 2000s was around 400 000 oysters per year, but this is based on catch returns and excludes the take by subsistence and recreational fishers, which may be considerable.
taxon_text_5_1020: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1021: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Spawning takes place in summer and the larvae have a planktonic life of about three weeks before settling.
taxon_text_7_1022: May be confused with the brooding oyster Ostrea atherstonei, which has an overlapping distribution and similar habitat preferences. However, that species has the lower valve much flatter and not hollowed-out beneath the hinge. Most commercially marketed oysters are introduced Pacific oysters (Crassostea gigas), which are farm-cultured. Some wild populations of that species have escaped and established in Southern Cape estuaries, but they are not found on the open coast.
taxon_text_8_1023:
De Bruyn, PA, Moloney, CL, & Schleyer, MH (2009). Application of age-structured production models to assess oyster Striostrea margaritacea populations managed by rotational harvesting in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. ICES Journal of Marine Science, 66(2), 408-419.

Haupt, TM, Griffiths, CL, Robinson, TB, Tonin, AF & De Bruyn, PA (2010). The history and status of oyster exploitation and culture in South Africa. Journal of Shellfish Research, 29(1), 151-159.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 169).
taxon_text_1_1026: Large, unattached scallop with lower (right) valve strongly convex and upper (left) one flat, 12-15 strong radiating ridges on each shell. Distinct ‘ear’ on both sides of straight hinge. Colour mottled cream and pink, often paler in older individuals.
taxon_text_3_1028:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_1029:
Lies on clean sandy substrata at depths of about 22-84 m with the curved right valve always downwards. When disturbed capable of sustained swimming by clapping the shell valves together and expelling jets of water. Swimming direction can be controlled by opening and closing different parts of the mantle edge.  The curved shape of the lower shell ensures that the scallop always settles right way up after a bout of swimming. Edge of the mantle decorated with a series of conspicuous shiny simple eyes, each borne at the base of a sensory tentacle. These are used to sense the presence of predators.

Large scallops are highly sought after as seafood and this species is certainly big enough to be eaten, but the wild stocks are too small to sustain a commercial fishery. There has, however, been recent interest in culturing this species for human consumption and growth rates attained in culture are comparable to those found in other famed species.
taxon_text_5_1030: All bivalves feed by drawing water in, then filtering it thought the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the edge of the gill and then to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_1031: Like almost all bivalves scallops are broadcast spawners. The spawning season in this species is from June to September each year.
taxon_text_7_1032: This is the only common large scallop likely to be encountered on Western Cape, but several other similar species occur in the warmer waters off KwaZulu-Natal and at deeper depths (for details see references below).
taxon_text_8_1033:
Arendse, DC, Andersen, S, Blake, NJ & Pitcher, GC (2008). The reproductive cycle of the scallop Pecten sulcicostatus from the southern Benguela upwelling system. Journal of Shellfish Research, 27(2), 281-287.

Arendse, DCZ & Pitcher, CG (2012). Growth and survival of the South African scallop Pecten sulcicostatus in suspended culture. African Journal of Marine Science, 34, 181-186.

Dijkstra, HH & Kilburn, RN (2001). The family Pectinidae in South Africa and Mozambique (Mollusca: Bivalvia: Pectinoidea). African Invertebrates, 42, 263-321.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 17).
taxon_text_1_1036: Shell valves equal in size and both domed, oval in outline and longer (hinge to opening) than wide. An ‘ear’ next to the hinge on the one side only. Shell valves each with about 50-70 fine, radiating and prickly ribs. Colour very variable, ranging from white to yellow, but most often orange or violet. A row of distinct simple eyes are visible along the edge of the mantle, each situated on a short sensory tentacle.
taxon_text_3_1038:
Global: Mediterranean, Azores, Angola, Namibia and southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1039: Found attached by their delicate byssus to the undersides of rocks or more commonly in crevices or among larger organisms, such as the ascidian Pyura stolonifera or nestled in the holdfasts of kelps. Usually occur singly. The brightly-coloured marginal eyes, for which this group is well known, are thought to aid scallops to sense the presence of predators.
taxon_text_5_1040: All bivalves feed by drawing water in, then filtering it thought the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the edge of the gill and then to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_1041: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_1042: This is the most common small scallop found on Western Cape shores, but several other similar species occur in the warmer waters of KwaZulu-Natal and at deeper depths (for details see reference below).
taxon_text_8_1043:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 150).

Dijkstra, HH & Kilburn, RN (2001). The family Pectinidae in South Africa and Mozambique (Mollusca: Bivalvia: Pectinoidea). African Invertebrates, 42, 263-321.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 171, as Chlamys tincta).
taxon_text_9_1045: Previously named Dosinia lupinus orbigny and considered to be a subspecies of the European D. lupinus, but now recognized as being a distinct species. Also previously named Artemis orbignyi.
taxon_text_1_1046: Shell very heavy, almost perfectly circular apart from a dorsal depression just behind the hinge. Externally surface smooth except for finely-sculptured concentric growth lines. Colour uniform white to cream.
taxon_text_3_1048:
Global: From Senegal down Africa’s west coast to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Found all along the west and south coasts of southern African to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1049: Burrows in clean sand and gravel sediments from low water to about 160 m depth. Popularly collected for human consumption in Angola, where it is known as 'ameijoinha'.
taxon_text_5_1050: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1051: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle in this species have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1052: Adults unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to the almost perfectly round, heavy and smooth shells. The Lesser heart clam D. hepatica is similar in shape, but much smaller (25 mm) and found only in estuaries from Gqeberha eastwards.
taxon_text_8_1053:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 158).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 193).
taxon_text_1_1056: Very large and oblong with relatively thin shell valves. Shell gapes widely at both ends when alive. Hinge displaced towards anterior end and has a very prominent spoon-shaped ligamental pit. Exterior surface white, often stained a dirty yellow. The live animal has a very large, fleshy foot that protrudes from the shell and massive siphons that are fused along their length and can be extended to 2-3 times the length of the shells.
taxon_text_3_1058:
Global: Widespread in Europe and Mediterranean and also Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional:  Namibia to about Port Alfred
taxon_text_4_1059: Burrows deeply in fine sediments from low water to about 100 m depth. Seldom seen alive, as it lives so deeply buries below the sand surface, but shells commonly washed up after storms.
taxon_text_5_1060: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water through an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1061: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle of this species in South Africa have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1062: Adults unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to their very large size and unusual elongated and open-ended shell. Other species of Lutraria occur on the east coast, but do not extend into the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_1063:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 152).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 179).

Signorelli, JH (2021). The Family Mactridae Lamarck, 1809 (Bivalvia: Cardiida) in South African Waters. Malacologia, 63(2), 195-223.
taxon_text_1_1066: Large, fat, oval clam with smooth, glossy-white shell often tinged with yellow to brown around growing margin. Swollen around hinge area and often with fine concentric growth lines visible. Young specimens may be marked with pale-brown radiating lines. When live, the ends of the siphons can be seen to be fused. Internally, the hinges of all Mactra species bear a distinctive socket- shaped ligamental pit, from which the common name ‘trough shells’ is derived.
taxon_text_3_1068:
Global: Around Africa, from Senegal in the west to Tanzania in the east.

Local/Regional: Found all around southern African coastline.
taxon_text_4_1069: Burrows in fine muddy sediments from low water to about 38 m depth and can attain high population densities in suitable sites. Once very abundant in Langebaan Lagoon, but now scarce there. Often washed up in considerable numbers after storms, but can speedily rebury when exposed. Sought after for human consumption.
taxon_text_5_1070: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon. In Mactra the siphons are lined internally with branched, interlocking tentacles to keep large particles out.
taxon_text_6_1071: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle in this species have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1072: Adults unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to their large size and smooth, oval shells. Juveniles may be confused with the streaked sand-clam Tivela compressa, as the two species occur in the same sites and often wash up together. The shells of T. compressa are, however, densely marked with concentric brown bands, in addition to the radiating streaks found in juvenile M. glabrata. A second species of Mactra, M. auquisulcata is found along the east coast, but does not extend into the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_1073:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 152).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 178).

Signorelli, JH (2021). The Family Mactridae Lamarck, 1809 (Bivalvia: Cardiida) in South African Waters. Malacologia, 63(2), 195-223.
taxon_text_1_1076: Oval, but almost always deformed and with a distinctly irregular margin. Hinge displaces well towards anterior end. Shell valves dirty-white or grey and sculptured with course radiating ridges and finer concentric growth lines. Interior often with a reddish-brown posterior patch. Best identified by its unusual habit of excavating shallow, rounded burrows onto soft sandstone and limestone.
taxon_text_3_1078:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1079:
Excavates shallow, rounded burrows into soft limestone or sandstone, smaller individuals also sometimes found burrowing into shells of large gastropods. Burrows bored by abrading away the rock with the rough sculpturing on anterior surfaces of the shells, as these are rocked against one another. Opening to the burrow closed with a plug of sand and mucus, the long siphons reaching though this plug into the water above. Inconspicuous and mostly found dead, but still in their burrows, after host rocks are washed ashore in storms. Can be abundant and rocks densely pitted with the characteristic burrows are common.

Specimens from the east coast are more regular in shape, darker in colour and more strongly sculptured than those from the west coast and may prove to represent another undescribed species.
taxon_text_5_1080: As with most bivalves filter-feed by sucking water in through an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine food particles by passing the water though the enlarged sieve-like gills and then ejecting waste water though a exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1081: Broadcast spawners, ejecting sperm and eggs into the water column, where they merge to form pelagic larvae to drift in the plankton and settle in other suitable sites.
taxon_text_7_1082: Unlikely to be confused with other species due to the unusual rock-boring habits and irregular shell shape. Burrows are sometimes confused with those created by piddocks (Pholas dactylus), but piddock burrows are much deeper, linear and tapering, while those of Petricola are shallow and cup shaped.
taxon_text_8_1083: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 201).
taxon_text_1_1086: Large, almost triangular clam with a distinctive, almost-flat posterior end that is sharply delimited from the lateral section of the shell by an angular ridge. Outer surface with fine growth lines, off-white with broad darker brown zone around growing margins. Internally the ligamental pit at the hinge is deep and conspicuous. Siphons fused.
taxon_text_3_1088:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_1089: Burrows in fine sediments from low water to about 8 m depth. Very common in False Bay, where it is often washed up in considerable numbers after storms, but uncommon elsewhere.
taxon_text_5_1090: Like almost all bivalves feeds by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering out fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water through an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1091: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle of this species have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1092: Adults unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to their large size and unusual squared-off posterior surface of the shell. Often found together with Mactra glabrata, but that species is fatter with a rounded, not squatted off, posterior end.
taxon_text_8_1093:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 152).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 179).

Signorelli, JH (2021). The Family Mactridae Lamarck, 1809 (Bivalvia: Cardiida) in South African Waters. Malacologia, 63(2), 195-223.
taxon_text_1_1096: Medium to large, flat, rounded-triangular clam with smooth, shiny shells. Colour cream, strongly patterned with both concentric brown bands and radiating brown bands and lines. Interior white.
taxon_text_3_1098:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to about Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_1099: Burrows in clean sand and gravel sediments from just below low water to about 54 m depth. Particularly common in False Bay, where dead shells frequently wash up after storms.
taxon_text_5_1100: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1101: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle in this species have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1102: Could be confused with juveniles of the smooth trough shell Mactra glabrata, particularly as the two species are often found together, but that species grows much larger and lacks the brown patterning.  Internally the hinge structure is also quite different (see diagrams in Kilburn and Rippey).
taxon_text_8_1103:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 158).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 193).
taxon_text_1_1106: Shells elongate-oval with the hinge displaced towards anterior end. Surface with many wrinkled concentric ridges (hence name). Colour very variable – juveniles often attractively marked with brown blotches or zig-zag patterns, but adults plain dirty-cream. Interior white with purple patches at anterior end. Siphons short, separate, mottled with brown and with rows of tentacles around openings.
taxon_text_3_1108:
Global: Europe down west coast of Africa to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Durban.
taxon_text_4_1109: Burrows in sand and gravel sediments from low water to about 27 m depth, often found nestling among mussels, especially Choromytilus meridionalis, in sandy areas; also burrows in shallow sandbanks. Common in Holocene middens along the west coast and still intensively harvested for human consumption in European countries. Also cultivated as a seafood in Spain, Portugal, France and Italy.
taxon_text_5_1110: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon. In this species a clam of 1g dry weight filtered about 1-3 litres of water per hour.
taxon_text_6_1111: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle in this species in South Africa have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1112: Adults unlikely to be confused with other species found in Western Cape due to the distinctive wrinkled concentric ridges on the shells.
taxon_text_8_1113:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 158).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 200).

Stenton-Dozey, JME, & Brown, AC (1992). Clearance and retention efficiency of natural suspended particles by the rock-pool bivalve Venerupis corrugatus in relation to tidal availability. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 82(2), 175-186.
taxon_text_1_1116: Distinctive species with very heavy, oval shells that are externally sculptured by about 20 strong concentric ridges, each broken up into rows of rounded knobs. There is a distinct dorsal depression just posterior to the hinge. Colour white to cream, sometimes tinged with pink.
taxon_text_3_1118:
Global: From Europe around west and South Africa to southern Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Found all around South African coastline.
taxon_text_4_1119: Burrows in clean sand and gravel sediments from low water to about 155 m depth, often resting with the posterior end exposed.
taxon_text_5_1120: Like almost all bivalves feed by pumping water in via an inhalant siphon, filtering our fine particles though the enlarged gills and then ejecting the filtered water though an exhalent siphon.
taxon_text_6_1121: Like almost all bivalves is a broadcast spawner. Details of reproductive cycle in this species have not been investigated.
taxon_text_7_1122: Adults unlikely to be confused with other regional species due to the very unusual knobbed concentric ridges on the shells. The Greater heart clam Dosinia lupinus orbignyi has a similarly-shaped, equally heavy shell, but has a smooth external surface.
taxon_text_8_1123:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 158).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 193).
taxon_text_1_1126: Tough, yellowish–brown, unsegmented worm pointed at the posterior end. An elongate, tubular process (the introvert) can be extended from the anterior end via muscular contractions of the body and, when fully extended, ends in a single ring of short regularly-spaced tentacles.
taxon_text_2_1127: Typically 20-40 mm body length when contracted, can double in length when the anterior process (introvert) is fully extended.
taxon_text_3_1128:
Global: Southern Namibia to tropical western Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1129:
Until recently sipunculids were regarded as a separate phylum, but as a result of molecular work they are now included as a Class of Annelida.

 This species is found singly or in small groups under boulders, especially those partially buried in course sand or gravel.
taxon_text_5_1130: Almost all sipunculids are deposit feeders, extending the introvert and gathering and sorting organic particles with the tentacles around the mouth.
taxon_text_6_1131: The reproductive biology of this species has not been studied, but in related species sexes are separate and sperm and egg are released into the water, where fertilization takes place. Fertilised eggs develop into pelagic larvae which settle and change into the adult form after about 20 days.
taxon_text_7_1132: Body form unmistakable. This is the only commonly-found sipunculid in local seaforest systems.
taxon_text_8_1133:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 62)

Stephen, AC & Cutler, EB (1969). On a collection of Sipuncula, Echiura, and Priapulida from south african waters. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 38(2), 111-121.
taxon_text_1_1136: Nematodes are an extremely diverse phylum of mostly small, slender and elongate worms. The body tapers at both ends and is covered by a tough cuticle, but is otherwise fairly featureless unless examined under a high-powered microscope. Although nematodes are abundant across all habitats and include a wide diversity of both free-living and parasitic forms, identification is difficult and the group remains un-noticed by most people.
taxon_text_3_1138:
Global: North Atlantic Ocean, Australia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Knysna.
taxon_text_4_1139:
Found free-living in the body cavity of snoek and present in almost every individual examined. Numbers of nematodes per fish was highest in Summer and Autumn and increased rapidly with snoek length, averaging over 100 per host and exceeding 1000 in some larger fish.

Some anisakid nematodes that establish in the muscle tissue of host fish can cause strong allergic reactions in humans who eat raw or undercooked fish and this is the case for the species that parasitizes snoek in New Zealand, for example. In South Africa though, the parasites are confined to the body cavity, so are not normally eaten. Workers in the fishing and seafood industries still remain at risk though, since prolonged and repeated contact exposure to the parasites can cause allergic reactions.
taxon_text_6_1141: Anisakid nematodes have complex life cycles including a variety of hosts. Eggs hatch in seawater and the larvae are eaten by planktonic crustaceans, such as euphausids. The infected crustaceans are then eaten by fish, such as snoek, where they burrow through the gut wall and establish in the body cavity or flesh. The fish in turn are eaten by marine mammals, such as seals, or by sharks, where the adult worms mate in the intestine and release eggs that pass back into the sea along with the host’s faeces.
taxon_text_7_1142: Parasitic nematode worms have few external features that can be used for morphological identification and are best identified by the host in which they occur. This is the main nematode parasitic on snoek.
taxon_text_8_1143:
Nieuwenhuizen, N, Lopata, AL, Jeebhay, MF, De'Broski, RH, Robins, TG & Brombacher, F (2006). Exposure to the fish parasite Anisakis causes allergic airway hyper-reactivity and dermatitis. Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, 117(5), 1098-11.

Nunkoo, MAI, Reed, CC & Kerwath, SE (2016). Community ecology of the metazoan parasites of snoek Thyrsites atun (Euphrasen, 1791)(Perciformes: Gempylidae) off South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 38(3), 363-371.
taxon_text_1_1146:
Nemertines are soft-bodied, flattened, unsegmented worms that are best known for the ability of species to vary enormously in length. When observed alive they can become extremely elongated, but when collected or disturbed they contract and adopt a much shorter and thicker shape. The South African fauna is poorly studied and many species doubtless remain undescribed.

Nemertines occur both on rocky habitats and burrowing into soft sediments. This species is the only common nemertine found on exposed sandy beaches in the region and is plain yellowish-white with a pointed head and no other body markings. Unlike many rocky shore species it does not change its body shape much and is typically 2-3 mm in width and 20-40 mm long.
taxon_text_3_1148:
Global: Widely distributed in Europe and North America, as well as in Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Distributed across whole region.
taxon_text_4_1149: Found burrowing in the sand of exposed sandy beaches across the region. There are no gills or other respiratory organs and gas exchange takes place across the extensive body surface. There are very few other distinctive features and the supposed broad global distribution is suspicious. Genetic studies may eventually reveal that the Southern African form is taxonomically distinct from that found in the northern hemisphere.
taxon_text_5_1150: All nemertines are predatory and shoot out an elongate proboscis from a special cavity just above the mouth to capture prey, which consists of other small invertebrates, such as polychaetes, bivalves or crustaceans. The specific feeding preferences of this and indeed most other South African species are not known.
taxon_text_6_1151: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are shed into the water. Some species guard the eggs, but reproductive behaviour is not known for South African species. Can also regenerate broken pieces. In some species body fragmentation is routine and even broken sections from near the tail can re-grow full bodies.
taxon_text_7_1152: Best recognized by its habitat and is the only species reported from exposed sandy beaches in the region.
taxon_text_8_1153:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 62)

Wheeler, JFG (1940). Some nemerteans from South Africa and a note on Lineus corrugatus M'Intosh. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 41(276), 20-49.
taxon_text_1_1156:
Nemertines are soft-bodied, flattened, unsegmented worms that are best known for their ability to vary enormously in length. When observed alive they can become extremely elongated, but when collected or disturbed they contract and adopt a much shorter and thicker shape. The South African fauna is poorly studied and many species remain undescribed.

This species is best identified by its purplish to bright-red body colour and completely white head.
taxon_text_2_1157: About 50 mm when contracted, but can extend to 20-30 cm or more when alive.
taxon_text_3_1158:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About False Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_1159: Found under rocks and insinuated among sedentary animals on rocky shores. Moves around by gliding along on a bed of cilia, or by stretching out and extending the body through small gaps. Can be very hard to untangle and examine and often breaks if handled. There are no gills or other respiratory organs and gas exchange takes place across the extensive body surface.
taxon_text_5_1160: All nemertines are predatory and shoot out an elongate proboscis from a special cavity just above the mouth to capture prey, which consists of other small invertebrates, such as polychaetes, bivalves or crustaceans. The specific feeding preferences of most South African species are not known.
taxon_text_6_1161: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are shed into the water. Some species guard the eggs, but reproductive behaviour is not known for South African species. Can also regenerate broken pieces. In some species body fragmentation is routine and even broken sections from near the tail can re-grow full bodies.
taxon_text_7_1162: Best recognized by colour pattern. A second member of the genus, Lineus ornatus, occurs in much the same region and has similar habits, but is dark blue-grey and has a white collar rather than an entirely white head.
taxon_text_8_1163:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 62)

Wheeler, JFG (1940). Some nemerteans from South Africa and a note on Lineus corrugatus M'Intosh. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 41(276), 20-49.
taxon_text_1_1166:
Nemerteans are soft-bodied, flattened, unsegmented worms that are best known for their ability to vary enormously in length. When observed alive they can become extremely elongated, but when collected or disturbed they contract and adopt a much shorter and thicker shape. The South African fauna is poorly studied and many species certainly remain undescribed.

This species is best identified by its blue-grey body colour and the transverse white band just behind the head; the ‘lips’ around the mouth are also white.
taxon_text_2_1167: About 50 mm when contracted, but can extend to 20 cm or more when alive.
taxon_text_3_1168:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About Lambert’s Bay on west coast to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_1169: Found under rocks and insinuated among sedentary animals on rocky shores. Moves around by gliding along on a bed of cilia, or by stretching out and extending the body through small gaps. Can be very hard to untangle and examine and often breaks if handled. There are no gills or other respiratory organs and gas exchange takes place across the extensive body surface.
taxon_text_5_1170: All nemertines are predatory and shoot out an elongate proboscis from a special cavity just above the mouth to capture prey, which consists of other small invertebrates, such as polychaetes, bivalves and crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_1171: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are shed into the water. Some species guard the eggs, but reproductive behaviour is not known for South African species. Can also regenerate from broken pieces. In some species body fragmentation is routine and even broken sections from near the tail can re-grow full bodies.
taxon_text_7_1172: Best recognized by colour pattern. A second member of the genus Lineus lacticapitatus occurs in much the same region and has similar habits, but is purple-brown to bright red and had an entirely white head.
taxon_text_8_1173:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 62)

Wheeler, JFG (1940). Some nemerteans from South Africa and a note on Lineus corrugatus M'Intosh. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 41(276), 20-49.
taxon_text_1_1176:
Phoronids are a small phylum containing only two genera and about 12 species worldwide. They are un-segmented, worm-like animals with a cylindrical body that lacks appendages, other than a characteristic anterior, horseshoe-shaped ring of filter-feeding tentacles called the lophophore and a bulbous ampulla at the posterior end. The gut is U-shaped and the anus is situated at the anterior end, just outside the ring of tentacles.

This species lives single in a tube made of sand grains and shells attached to the surface of a rock, from which it extends a single circular crown consisting of a row of longer outer and another of shorter inner tentacles. The body is yellowish and the tentacles transparent but each decorated at intervals with elongated white spots.
taxon_text_2_1177: About 20 mm body length, span of tentacles 8 mm.
taxon_text_3_1178:
Global: Rare but widespread, having been reported from South Africa, Ivory Coast, Madagascar, Hawaii, Australia, Costa Rica and Panama.

Local/Regional: Known only from Gilchrist’s original record from False Bay and has never been found or photographed again in South African waters.
taxon_text_4_1179:
Phoronids live in chitinous tubes in either sediments or in cavities in hard substrata, such as rocks or shells. They are anchored into the tube by the swollen bulb at the posterior end of the body (the ampulla). Other than being able to retract rapidly when disturbed, they are slow moving. The lophophore can be jettisoned and regenerated, so specimens lacking lophophores are common in benthic samples.

Some smaller species form extensive colonies, but larger species (such as this one) are normally solitary. The South African specimens were found emerging from holes in limestone rocks that had been collected to decorate an aquarium.
taxon_text_5_1180: All phoronids are suspension feeders, using the ciliated lophophore to gather fine particles from the water and propel these back to the central mouth.
taxon_text_6_1181: Most phoronids can reproduce both sexually and asexually, by either budding or fission. Different species show a diversity of modes of sexual reproduction – some are hermaphrodite and others have separate sexes; some brood the young around the lophophore and other have planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1182:
This is one of only two phoronids known from South Africa, the other being Phoronis hippocrepia, which has a colourless lophophore with all tentacles the same length. The tiny Phoronis ovalis has also been reported burrowing into the shells of mussels and other molluscs in Namibia.

In the field could easily be confused with fanworms, which are much more common and have superficially similar crowns of feeding tentacles. However, fanworms are segmented and have lateral appendages (parapodia) on each body segment. Their anus is also at the hind end whereas in phoronids it is at the anterior end.
taxon_text_8_1183:
Dean, HK, Sibaja-Cordero, JA & Cortés, J (2010). Occurrence of the Phoronid Phoronopsis albomaculata in Cocos Island, Costa Rica. Pacific Science, 64(3), 459-462.

Gilchrist, JDF (1907). New forms of the Hemichordata from South Africa. Transactions of the South African Philosophical Society, 17(1), 151-176.
taxon_text_9_1185: Ochetosoma capense (also previously classified as Phylum Echiura)
taxon_text_1_1186: Body soft, sausage-shaped and unsegmented. Body wall brown and partially transparent, such that internal organs and muscle bands are visible beneath. A large cupped and tongue-shaped non –retractable proboscis extends from anterior end.
taxon_text_3_1188:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About Saldanha Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1189: Echiurans were until recently classified as belonging to their own Phylum, the Echiura, but are now recognized to be annelids that have secondarily lost their segmentation. They burrow in soft sediments and are deposit feeders. They have a long, coiled intestine and no specific respiratory organs, gaining oxygen by diffusion though the body wall.
taxon_text_5_1190: Echiurans are deposit feeders, extending the proboscis to gather light organic food particles from the sediment surface that are then transported to the mouth by cilia.
taxon_text_6_1191: The sexes are separate and they are broadcast spawners, the fertilized eggs developing into trochophore larvae, some of which go through a segmented stage, supporting the theory that echiurans are descended from more typical segmented annelids.
taxon_text_7_1192: The unsegmented body and permanently extended scoop-like proboscis fairy easily identify the group. This is the most common genus but includes several other regional species that can be quite difficult to differentiate.
taxon_text_8_1193:
Biseswar, R (2019). The echiuran fauna of southern Africa (Class: Echiura, Phylum: Annelida). African Zoology, 54(2), 73–90.

Biseswar, R & Moodley, LG (1989). The proposed transfer of the echiuran Ochetostoma capense to the genus Listriolobus. South African Journal of Zoology, 24(4), 337–339.

Jones, CM & Stephen, AC (1954). A new species of echiuroid worm (Ochetostoma capensis) from the Cape Province, South Africa. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 34(2), 273–278.
taxon_text_1_1196:
As the name implies flatworms have wide, flat, leaf-like bodies and either glide around on a bed of cilia or, in larger species, by using ripples of muscular contraction that pass along the body.  Many tropical species are very brightly-coloured, but those found in the temperate parts of South Africa tend to be more cryptic.

This species is flat and oval without a frilled margin or any dorsal projections. It is light brown in background colour and marked with a dense network of darker brown spots and patches. It is best identified by its obligate association with large limpets.
taxon_text_2_1197: Typically about 10 mm body length, but can be up to 20 mm.
taxon_text_3_1198:
Global: The previous Notoplana patellarum was endemic to South Africa, but now that it and several other regional species have been amalgamated under the name Notocomplana erythrotaenia  it has become difficult to trace the wider global distribution.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1199: Associated with large limpets, particularly the Goat’s-eye limpet Cymbula oculus. Live in the gill cavity between the foot of the limpet and the shell. There may be several flatworms associated with each individual limpet.
taxon_text_5_1200: The feeding organ of flatworms is a tubular proboscis on the underside and this leads into a blind-ending gut with no anus. This species is thought to feel on small crustaceans including commensal copepods that are also associated with the host limpets.
taxon_text_6_1201: Flatworms are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilise one another by hypodermic impregnation – a process whereby the penis of one individual is stabbed into the partner and sperm injected into the body cavity. The spermatozoa then make their way to the ovaries of the receiving partner. Eggs are laid in gelatinous strings that are often deposited in spiral coils and hatch into free-swimming larvae. These float for a few days in the plankton before settling at new hosts.
taxon_text_7_1202: Fairly easily recognized by its flat speckled-brown body and lack of dorsal tentacles, also by the fact that is found only under limpets.
taxon_text_8_1203:
Branch, G (1975). The ecology of Patella from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 5. Commensalism. Zoologica Africana, 10, 133-162.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 60)
taxon_text_1_1206:
As the name implies flatworms have wide, flat, leaflike bodies and either glide around on a bed of cilia or, in larger species, by using ripples of muscular contraction that pass along the body.  Many tropical species are very brightly coloured, but those found in the temperate parts of South Africa tend to be more cryptic.

This species has a wide body with a frilly margin. There are no projections on the upper surface, other than two short, pointed tentacles near the front end. Colour is pale brown on the upper side, speckled with variable mix of black, white and brown spots and white on the underside. (It may eventually emerge that the different colour morphs represent separate species).
taxon_text_2_1207: Typically 20-30 mm body length, but can be up to 70 mm.
taxon_text_3_1208:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1209: Normally found creeping on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal zone, or on shallow reefs. Usually solitary. Can swim if disturbed using undulations of the body.
taxon_text_5_1210: The feeding organ of flatworms is a tubular proboscis on the underside and this leads into a blind-ending gut with no anus. This species feeds on small worms, crustaceans and molluscs. Under experimental conditions it fed readily on winkles of the genus Oxystele, even picking up and carrying around prey individuals for later consumption.
taxon_text_6_1211: Flatworms are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilise one another by hypodermic impregnation – a process whereby the penis of one individual is stabbed into the partner and sperm injected into the body cavity. The spermatozoa then make their way to the ovaries of the receiving partner. Eggs are laid in gelatinous strings that are often deposited in spiral coils and hatch into free-swimming larvae. These float for a few days in the plankton before settling at new sites.
taxon_text_7_1212: Fairy easily recognized by the speckled brown body and pair of dorsal tentacles. The Limpet flatworm Notoplana patellarum has a similar distribution and colour, but lacks dorsal tentacles and is found only under limpets.
taxon_text_8_1213:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 60).

Jacubowa, L (1907). A new species of Planocera (P. gilchristi) from South Africa. Transactions of the South African Philosophical Society, 17(1), 145-149.

Koopowitz, H (1970). Feeding behaviour and the role of the brain in the polyclad flatworm, Planocera gilchristi. Animal Behaviour, 18, 31-35.
taxon_text_1_1216:
As the name implies flatworms have wide, flat, leaflike bodies and either glide around on a bed of cilia or, in larger species, by using ripples of muscular contraction that pass along the body.  Many tropical species are very brightly-coloured, but those found in the temperate parts of South Africa are more cryptic.

This is a large species with a frilly margin, the upper surface light pink and the underside white. It is easily recognised by the numerous dark-tipped finger-like processes covering the upper surface. These are shorter laterally and longer centrally, and the lateral projections are mostly pink to orange, while those in the centre of the body are darker blueish-black. The projections certainly serve to greatly the surface area for respiration, but may also serve as camouflage.
taxon_text_3_1218:
Global: As currently accepted, this species has a wide global distribution including North and South America, Mediterranean, New Zealand, Persian Gulf, India and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1219: Normally found creeping on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal zone, or on shallow reefs, where they can be quite common. Usually solitary. Can swim if disturbed using undulations of the body.
taxon_text_5_1220: The feeding organ of flatworms is a tubular proboscis on the underside and this leads into a blind-ending gut with no anus. Most species feed on smaller slow-moving invertebrates, but the feeding preferences of most South African species remain un-studied.
taxon_text_6_1221: Flatworms are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilise one another by hypodermic impregnation – a process whereby the penis of one individual is stabbed into the partner and sperm injected directly into the body cavity. The spermatozoa then make their way to the ovaries of the receiving partner. Eggs are laid in gelatinous strings that are often deposited in spiral coils and hatch into free-swimming larvae. These float for a few days in the plankton before settling at new sites.
taxon_text_7_1222: An easily recognized genus of which this is the most common species. Several colour forms occur in the region and may represent other related species, but species identifications remains difficult.  This is largely because most earlier species were described from preserved material, so lacked live-colour descriptions, whereas today most photographers do not collect the specimens they photograph, so their internal anatomy cannot be compared with and matched to the original descriptions!  Many earlier species have also subsequently been synonymised under this name.
taxon_text_8_1223:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 60)

Pitale, R & Apte, D (2017). First record of Thysanozoon brocchii (Platyhelminthes: Polycladida) from Indian waters. Marine Biodiversity Records, 10(1), 1-11.
taxon_text_1_1226:
Brachiopods are sessile animals enclosed within bivalve shells that superficially resemble those of bivalve molluscs. However, the shells enclose the animal dorsally and ventrally, rather than laterally, as in bivalves. The ventral shell is usually larger and is cupped, while the dorsal one is flatter. A stalk or pedicel emerging from the rear of the shell attaches the animal firmly to the substratum. Internally, the dominant organ is a large feathery, horse-shoe shaped filter-feeding organ (the lophophore), which is supported by a delicate internal skeleton.

This species has pink shells with 20-30 prominent radiating ribs. The internal skeleton is shaped like a pair of delicate horns.
taxon_text_3_1228:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_1229: Brachiopods were once a dominant component of the marine fauna and thousands of fossil species have been described. However, they are relatively rare today and only a few shallow-water species occur in the region. Most of these are found attached in small groups to the undersides of rocks.
taxon_text_5_1230: Brachiopods are filter-feeders, sieving water by passing it though the branches of the lophophore, which are lined with cilia, and transporting captured particles along ciliated tracts to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_1231: Sexes are separate and the vast majority of species are broadcast spawners, shedding eggs and sperm into the water, where fertilisation takes place and planktonic larvae develop and disperse to new sites.
taxon_text_7_1232: The Thick-ribbed lamp shell C. crassicostata is similar in appearance and habits but has only about 10-12 relatively course ribs on the shells.
taxon_text_1_1236:
Brachiopods are sessile animals enclosed within a bivalve shell that superficially resembles that of bivalve molluscs. However, the shells enclose the animal dorsally and ventrally, rather than laterally, as in bivalves. The ventral shell is usually larger and is cupped, while the dorsal one is flatter. A stalk or pedicel emerging from the rear of the shell attaches the animal to the substratum. Internally the dominant organ is a large feathery, horse-shoe shaped filter-feeding organ (the lophophore), which is supported by a delicate internal skeleton.

This species has a delicate oval and transparent-white shell marked with only very faint ribs. The internal skeleton is in the form of a closed circle.
taxon_text_3_1238:
Global: South Africa and Madagascar.

Local/Regional: West coast to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1239: Brachiopods were once a dominant component of the marine fauna and thousands of fossil species have been described. However, they are relatively rare today and only a few shallow-water species occur in the region. Most of these are found attached in small groups to the undersides of rocks.
taxon_text_5_1240: Brachiopods are filter-feeders, sieving water by passing it though the branches of the lophophore, which are lined with cilia, and transporting captured particles along ciliated tracts to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_1241: Sexes are separate and the vast majority of species are broadcast spawners, shedding eggs and sperm into the water, where fertilisation takes place and planktonic larvae develop and disperse to new sites.
taxon_text_7_1242: Replaced along the south and east coast by the very similar but more elongate and pear-shaped and mostly deeper water T. abyssicola.
taxon_text_9_1245: Previously known as Cucumaria insolens,Trachythyone insolens and Pseudocnella insolens.
taxon_text_1_1246: Small species reaching only about 40 mm lenght, andquite variable in colour. Most common on shallow subtidal reefs, where body uniform bright red with yellowish tentacles, but intertidal specimens often black dorsally and red below (hence the common name), the darker colour perhaps being an adaptation to bright light. Pale, almost white, or yellow specimens sometimes also found. Tubefeet scattered dorsally, but form three distinct bands on the underside. Tentacles 10 in number, yellow, quite short and irregularly branched.
taxon_text_2_1247: Body length only up to about 40 mm, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_1248:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1249: A common and well known species that can occur in very large numbers in suitable habitats, sometimes forming extensive beds covering shallow subtidal reefs, but also in intertidal pools, overhangs and gullies. Clings to the rock surface in the open (unlike the similarly-coloured Thyone aurea which lies with body buried in sediment) with the front end elevated and the tentacles extended upwards.
taxon_text_5_1250: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_1251: Reproduction unusual in that the eggs are incubated in pouches in the skin and emerge as fully formed juveniles, which are often seen clinging to the surfaces of their parents. Brooding is known in at least 30 species of holothurians, but the mechanisms differ between species and details of the mode of reproduction in this species have not yet been studied.
taxon_text_7_1252: The red colour distinguishes this species from most other regional cucumbers, but could be confused with the Golden sea cucumber Thyone aurea, which is similar in colour and is also abundant on shallow reefs. However, that species is orange rather than red, is softer in texture and much larger at up to about 130 mm body length. It also occurs buried in sediment or between other organisms and not exposed in the open.
taxon_text_8_1253:
Barkai, A (1991). The effect of water movement on the distribution and interaction of three holothurian species on the South African west coast. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 153(2), 241-254.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 117).
<p>in mixed beds with the Cask sea cucum: in mixed beds with the Cask sea cucumber
taxon_text_1_1256: Body very firm and tough, more or less quadrangular in cross-section. Colour dorsally mauve to almost black, becoming pale and almost grey on underside. Tubefeet arranged in five distinct double rows, strongly adhesive and also highly retractile. Tentacles 10, each with fairly short tree-like (dentritic) branching.
taxon_text_2_1257: Body length typically about 70 mm, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_1258:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to Eastern Cape (a record from Southern Mozambique is considered suspect).
taxon_text_4_1259: A common and well known species that can occur in very large numbers in suitable habitats, sometimes forming extensive beds covering shallow subtidal reefs, particularly in kelp beds. Clings to the rock surface in the open with the front end elevated and the tentacles reaching upwards.
taxon_text_5_1260: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_1261: Not studied in this species, but in most cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_1262: The tough purplish body and rather quadrangular cross section distinguish this species from most other regional cucumbers.
taxon_text_8_1263:
Barkai, A (1991). The effect of water movement on the distribution and interaction of three holothurian species on the South African west coast. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 153(2), 241-254.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 117).
<p>in mixed beds with the Red-chested se: in mixed beds with the Red-chested sea cucumber
taxon_text_1_1266: Fairly small, soft-bodied, cylindrical and dark olive-green to jet-black. Dorsally the tube feet are mostly confined to distinct bands, although a few are also scattered between these bands. Ventrally the tube feet are confined to distinct bands, each with no more than four rows. There are 10 equal-sized dendritic tentacles. Often insinuated into crevices in the rocks or between other sedentary organisms. Juveniles mainly under rocks, but adults in the open.
taxon_text_2_1267: Body length typically about 60 mm, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_1268:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1269: Usually found singly or on small groups, attached in crevices or under boulders on rocky shores. Juveniles often under rocks, but adults usually exposed in the open.
taxon_text_5_1270: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_1271: Not studied in this species, but in most cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_1272: Easily confused in the field with the very similar Stephenson’s sea cucumber Roweia stephensoni, which is similar in both colour and habits. However, when closely examined that species has the tube feet on the dorsal surface not grouped into distinct bands and there are 6 rows of tube in each of the ventral bands, rather than 4.
taxon_text_8_1273:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (1991). The Cucumariid holothurians of southern Africa with the erection of a new genus. South African Journal of Zoology, 26(3): 115 – 139.

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 117).
taxon_text_1_1276: Fairly soft-bodied, cylindrical and jet-black. Ventrally the tube feet are confined to distinct bands, each with about 6 rows, but dorsally the tube feet are scattered and interspersed with sucker–like papillae (to which particles of sand and shell adhere). There are 10 equal-sized dendritic tentacles. The body normally lies horizontal and adheres strongly to the substratum along its whole length.
taxon_text_2_1277: Body length up to about 130 mm, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_1278:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1279: Usually found in closely-packed groups adhering strongly to rocks by the ventral tube feet and with the bodies largely concealed by sand and pieces of shell, weed or gravel that adhere to the upper surface. The black tentacles are held aloft when feeding and are much more conspicuous than the body.
taxon_text_5_1280: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_1281: Not studied in this species, but in most cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_1282: Easily confused with the Black sea cucumber Pseudocnella sykion, which is similar in size, colour and habits, but has distinct bands of tubefeet on dorsal surface and only 4 rows of tubefeet in each of the ventral bands.
taxon_text_8_1283:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 163).
taxon_text_1_1286: Large, soft, pale cucumber with cylindrical body that tapers towards slender posterior end, body wall bearing brown spots and blothes and with scattered tube-feet that are not arranged into distinct rows. Lives buried in course sediments with the head and tail ends elevated to the surface and the body curved downwards into the sand in a U-shape. There are 10 long, strongly-branching, tree-like (dendritic) tentacles arranged into inner and outer cycles of 10 tentacles-each. Females possess a series of paired transverse slits in the body wall whose function has not been established (but may be used to brood young).
taxon_text_2_1287: Body up to 270 mm long, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_1288:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Recorded only from False Bay and two sites in KZN, but likely continuous in suitable sites between these locations.
taxon_text_4_1289: A large and striking species, which remarkably was only first described in 1989. This is probably due to both its cryptic habits and the fact that it lives buried deeply in the sediments, so that conventional benthic sampling equipment, such as dredges and trawls, would be unlikely to capture samples. All existing samples are also from <20 m depth, where ships would be unable to operate. Lives buries in course sand with only the anterior end and long tentacles projecting upwards from the surface, while the body is buried in a U-shape, such that the anus again reaches to the sand surface. The large white and speckled tentacles are held upright into the water column to intercept floating particles passing in the current.
taxon_text_5_1290: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_1291: Details unknown, but the presence of slits in the body wall of only females suggest young may be brooded.
taxon_text_7_1292: The large size and unusual habits of this species make it unlikely that it would be confused with other local holothurians. There is one other regional species in the genus, M. maculosum, but this is known only from far northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_8_1293:
Thandar, AS (1989). A new species of a phyllophorid holothurian from southern Africa. Journal of Zoology, 219(4): 637-644.

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 76)
taxon_text_9_1295: Holothuria aurea, Thyone proceracorona, Thyone serratus, Thyone turrissolida
taxon_text_1_1296: Soft, floppy, golden-orange sea cucumber with weak tube-feet scattered randomly over body surface and not arranged into distinct rows. There are 10 branching, tree-like (dendritic) tentacles that are held aloft to gather food particles from the water column. Live buried in sediments or in spaces between other sedentary organisms, such as mussels and redbait, with only the tentacles visible.
taxon_text_2_1297: Body up to 130 mm long, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_1298:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1299: A common and well known species that can occur in large numbers in suitable habitats, particularly on shallow reefs (but records extend to 70 m depth). The body is normally concealed beneath the sand, or between other benthic invertebrates, particularly mussels and large ascidians, and only the crowns of tentacles are visible, sometimes forming carpets of orange plumes. Has poor powers of adhesion and is often washed up in large numbers after storms. Readily disgorges the gut if disturbed, but is able to quickly re-generate this and recover.
taxon_text_5_1300: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_1301: Details unknown for this species but sexes separate and most holothurians are broadcast spawners that discharge eggs and sperm into the water column where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_1302: The soft texture and orange colour are sufficient to distinguish this species from most other regional cucumbers, but can be confuses with the Red-chested sea cucumber Hemiocnus insolens which is similar in colour and also abundant on shallow reefs. However, that species is red rather than orange, is firmer in texture and much smaller at only about 40 mm body length. It also occurs in the open rather than buried in sediment.
taxon_text_8_1303:
Barkai, A (1991). The effect of water movement on the distribution and interaction of three holothurian species on the South African west coast. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 153(2), 241-254.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 88).
taxon_text_1_1306: Test large, oval and semi-transparent, often with purplish vein-like markings and light purplish or pinkish colouring, intensifying along siphons. Siphons fairly elongate and widely-separated, with exhalent siphon well down on one side. Siphons not adhering to substratum (as in A. caudata) and grooved towards tip, apertures distinctly lobed and without distinct oral tentacles. Typically found in groups under boulders.
taxon_text_2_1307: Up to about 100 mm long, including siphons.
taxon_text_3_1308:
Global: Atlantic Ocean, South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1309:
Lives in narrow crevices or in cavities beneath boulders in shallow water.

The structure of the outer test of solitary ascidians such as this is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1310: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1311:
