Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary one reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1312:
The taxonomic position of this species is uncertain and it is closely related to and often confused with A. sydneiensis. Monniot et al. (see refs below) recognise the Atlantic, South African and Mozambique forms under this name and those from Australia, Sri Lanka  and Mauritius as A. sydneiensis.

There are also several other Ascidia species in the region and these can be difficult to distinguish, but A. canaliculata is best separated from related species by the fact that the siphons are not glued to the rock and their tips are lobed (unlike A. caudata), and they do not have red spots between the lobes (as found in A. incrassata).
taxon_text_8_1313:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 63)
taxon_text_1_1336: Tall, solitary, upright ascidian with a transparent creamy test, though which the internal organs are clearly visible. The large inhalant siphon projects upwards and the smaller exhalent one is displaced to the side. An introduced, fouling species that forms dense colonies coating ships’ hulls, wharfs, mussel farms, buoys and lines and other artificial structures.
taxon_text_3_1338:
Global: Originally described from Japan, but recent molecular studies have shown that  populations from the Mediterranean, east and west coasts of North America and South Africa, that were all previously identified as C. intestinalis, in fact belong to this species.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Durban, mostly in harbours.
taxon_text_4_1339:
Introduced to South Africa some time before 1955 (date of first local records) and now common in and around harbours from Namibia to Durban. Forms dense beds, especially on floating structures, particularly in shaded areas, such as beneath boat’s hulls, underside of floating jetties and on ropes hanging into the water.

A significant pest as a fouling organism that needs to be scrapped of the hulls of ships and that that coats mussels being cultured on mussel farms, where they both impede the feeding activities and hence growth of the mussels and incur additional costs, as large volumes of ascidians need to be removed and disposed of when the mussels are harvested.

The structure of the outer test of this and other ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1340: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1341:
A hermaphrodititic broadcast spawner. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop. These have a duration of about 10 days before settling.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1342: The tall transparent test is unusual, making it unlikely that this species will be confused with other regional ascidians. The habitat preferences of this species are also characteristic.
taxon_text_8_1343:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Morphological evidence that the molecularly determined Ciona intestinalis type A and type B are different species: Ciona robusta and Ciona intestinalis. Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research, 53 (3), 186–193.

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (as C. intestinalis, p. 60).

Picker, M & Grififths, C (2011). Alien and invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 72)
taxon_text_9_1345: Ascidia lepadiformis, Clavelina pumillo, Clavelina rissoana, Clavelina savigniana
taxon_text_1_1346: An unmistakable species that forms dense clumps of small zooids that are joined at their bases. Each individual is about 3 cm long and the transparent test is marked by bright white lines around the visceral organs and up the test and circular white rings around the top of the pharynx and the siphons. The sieve-like pharynx and orange visceral organs are both clearly visible though the test.  An introduced, fouling species largely confined to harbour areas.
taxon_text_2_1347: Individual zooids typically about 30 mm in height, colonies typically 50-100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_1348:
Global: Native to Europe, but introduced to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Durban, mostly in harbours.
taxon_text_4_1349:
Fairly recently introduced to South Africa, where it was first reported in 2001, but now common in and around harbours from Saldanha to Durban. Forms dense colonies on floating structures, boat’s hulls, floating jetties and on ropes hanging into the water. Due to its relatively small size probably not a significant pest.

The structure of the outer test of this and other ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1350: All ascidians are filter feeder, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1351: A hermaphroditic broadcast spawner. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop. These have a duration of about 10 days before settling.
taxon_text_7_1352: The transparent test and striking white-striped colour pattern make it unlikely that this species would be confused with other regional ascidians.
taxon_text_8_1353:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 248).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 198).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 38).

Picker, M & Griffiths, C (2011). Alien and invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 71).
taxon_text_1_1356:
Very distinctive colonial species, with clusters of independent upright zooids all joined at the base. The zooids are usually blue but sometimes yellow or colourless and almost completely transparent, such that the organs can be seen within. There is a darker blue band between the two siphons.

Some of the supposed colour variants may in fact represent undescribed species and genetic work would be needed to confirm this.
taxon_text_3_1358:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to probably KwaZulu-Natal ( tropical forms may be genetically distinct species).
taxon_text_4_1359: Found attached to shallow reefs in areas of rapid water flow. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1360: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1361: Colonies expand and grow via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1362: The bright blue or yellow zooids are distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other temperate species. Several other similar transparent blue ascidians occur in more tropical parts of South Africa though.
taxon_text_8_1363:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 196.)

Kott, P (2005). Pycnoclavella (Tunicata: Ascidiacea) species from the West Indian Ocean. African Zoology, 40(2), 205-212.
taxon_text_1_1366: An extremely soft and fragile species forming flat semi-transparent gelatinous sheet that overgrow seaweeds, rocks and other sedentary invertebrates. The small pale round zooids are evenly spaced in the matrix and each has its own inhalant opening. Larger raised exhalant openings are spread unevenly across the surface and white pigment cells are scattered thought the matrix. Breaks up very easily when handled and is hence often overlooked, also frequently misidentified as a sponge due to the turret-like exhalant openings.
taxon_text_2_1367: Zooids only about 2-3 mm, but colonies 100 mm or more across.
taxon_text_3_1368:
Global: An introduced species originally from Europe but now widely dispersed across the globe by shipping.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal, mostly in harbours, but also sheltered reefs.
taxon_text_4_1369: A common but often overlooked fouling species abundant in harbours and other sheltered sites, but also in rocky reefs, kelps beds, etc. Impact probably minimal due to its fragile nature.
taxon_text_5_1370: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus. In this species waste-water is then expelled though common exhalent apertures shared by numerous zooids.
taxon_text_6_1371: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1372: The evenly-spaced zooids and fragile nature of the colony distinguish this species from most other regional colonial ascidians. Often misidentified as a sponge though!
taxon_text_8_1373:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M. (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 60).

Picker, M & Griffiths, C (2011). Alien and invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 72).
taxon_text_1_1376:
A very common colonial species forming thin, opaque encrustations on rocks, shells and other surfaces. The surface layer of the colony is densely packed with microscopic, star-shaped and protective spicules, such that the zooids beneath cannot be seen without dissection. As a result this and other didemnids are frequently mis-identified as sponges.

Colonies may be flat, or thrown into folds that fancifully represent those on the surface of the brain (hence name). The small, star-shaped inhalant siphons are evenly distributed and protrude slightly. The exhalent siphons of individual zooids pump into a common internal cavity, the water from this then existing the colony though much larger, more widely-spaced, smooth-edged and elevated openings (which can be confused with the oscula of sponges). Colour usually white, but may be grey or pinkish.
taxon_text_2_1377: Individual zooids minute (1 mm), but colonies up to about 100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_1378:
Global: Widely distributed across Pacific and Indian Oceans.

Local/Regional: About Saldanha Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1379: Little is known about the biology of this species other than that it is common, widely distributed and protected from predation by the internal spicules.
taxon_text_5_1380: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1381: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1382: The detailed taxonomy of this group is very confused (see Monniot reference below) and although the species was first described from South Africa, specimens from other regions may in fact represent other similar species. This is the most common of a number of very similar species in this and the closely-related genus Didemnum and which are extremely difficult to distinguish without microscopic examination.
taxon_text_8_1383:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 39).
taxon_text_1_1386: Colonies form soft, irregular, fairly transparent white or pale pink or brown masses, usually in shaded areas, such as overhangs, or attached to under-surfaces of boulders. The zooids are separate and evenly spaced, without any grouping into shared systems. Each zooid is fairly elongate (much more so than Botyllus species for example) and sits vertically in the matrix with both siphons opening separately. When examined closely the inhalant siphon has 6 lobes.
taxon_text_2_1387: Zooids up to 6 mm long, colonies up to 100 mm or more across.
taxon_text_3_1388:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to about Knysna.
taxon_text_4_1389: Common intertidally, especially under overhangs and boulders. Colonies are very often colonized by the burrowing amphipod Polycheria atolli, which lies upside-down and filter-feeds within a slit-like burrow excavated into the colony surface.
taxon_text_5_1390: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1391: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1392: Could be confused with a number of other white lobed or hemi-spherical colonial species, such as Distaplia skoogi and Aplidium circulatum, but in those species the zooids are grouped around common exhalant siphons.
taxon_text_8_1393:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 248).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 37).
taxon_text_1_1396: Very distinctive colonial species, the heads being laterally-flattened plates attached by a stalk to a common base, resulting in a branched colony. The elongated zooids are arranged in double rows vertically down both sides of each head and the common exhalent apertures form a line along the upper surface of each lobe. Colour variable, may be red, white or brown; commonly the upper edges of the lobes white and the sides grey or brown.
taxon_text_2_1397: Zooids about 5 mm long, colonies up to 100 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_1398:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to about Knysna.
taxon_text_4_1399: Found attached to shallow reefs in areas of rapid water flow. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1400: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1401: Colonies expand and grow via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1402: The fan-shaped heads and stalked structure of the colonies of this species is very distinctive. Although only this one species is currently described from the region, the large diversity of shapes and colours seen among photographed specimens suggest that other, currently un-described species are also present.
taxon_text_8_1403:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 248).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 196).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 36).
taxon_text_1_1406: Very distinctive colonial species, the head being hemispherical and attached to the top of a thick stalk that narrows towards the base, the whole colony resembles a white mushroom in both shape and colour. The tunic may be encrusted with sand and the elongated zooids are arranged in circles around common exhalent siphons.
taxon_text_2_1407: Zooids up to 15 mm long, colonies up to 100 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_1408:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to Jeffrey's Bay.
taxon_text_4_1409: Found attached to shallow reefs in 8-12 m depth, usually in small groups of colonies. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1410: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1411: Colonies expand and grow via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1412: The mushroom like shape of the colony is distinctive. Otherwise structure and arrangement of the zooids is similar to that in the closely-related A. flavolineatum. The two species also differ in colour (white here and pink in A. flavolineatum).
taxon_text_8_1413:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 196).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 3).
taxon_text_1_1416: Forms thick rounded cushions that harbour elongate zooids up to 30 mm long. Each oral aperture is circled with a white line that often extends down the side of the elongate thorax, within which the filter-feeding pharynx can be seen in section (left side of image). Zooids arranges in often indistinct groups around communal exhalent openings. Colony colour usually pink, but can be cream or red.
taxon_text_2_1417: Zooids up to 30 mm, colonies up to 100 mm or more across.
taxon_text_3_1418:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Sodwana Bay.
taxon_text_4_1419: Common intertidally, especially along the whole south coast.
taxon_text_5_1420: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1421: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1422: The cushions are much deeper and the zooids much longer that those of Botryllus species, which form similarly-coloured colonies. Can be distinguished from the related A. circulatum by shape, as in that species the colony is raised on a mushroom-like stalk.
taxon_text_8_1423:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 196).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 6).
taxon_text_1_1426:
Large and conspicuous solitary ascidian found mostly in sheltered sites and sometimes rooted in sand. The test (outer covering) is distinctively raised into pointed papillae around the siphons (distinguishing it from the otherwise similar and much more common P. stolonifera). Live specimens often heavily encrusted with fouling organisms.

When cut it has a rigid whitish inner layer covered with a thin red to brown ‘skin’. The prominent inhalant siphon points upwards and the exhalent one projects laterally on the ‘shoulder’. The flesh is pink to bright red (hence the common name ‘red bait’).
taxon_text_3_1428:
Global: Namibia, South Africa and Morocco.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1429:
Less common than the closely related P. stolonifera and mostly found in sheltered sites. Although primarily on rocks or jetties etc., they can occur on soft substrata (see photo below) and then the test is extended downward into the sediment in the form of long tapering ‘roots’ that anchor the animal into the substratum.

The structure of the outer test of this and related ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coating, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1430: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1431:
Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary ones reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1432: Pyura species are easy to distinguish from other regional ascidians due to their large size and thick, red to brown-skinned tests. This species can easily be confused with P. stolonifera though, which is very similar in size and habits, but lacks the lobed papillae around the siphons.
taxon_text_8_1433:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 114).
taxon_text_1_1436: Very large and conspicuous solitary ascidian that forms extensive beds in the low intertidal and on shallow reefs around virtually the whole South African coast. The test (outer covering) is thick and relatively smooth, although it may be heavily encrusted with fouling organisms. When cut it has a rigid whitish inner layer covered with a thin brown ‘skin’. The prominent inhalant siphon points upwards and the exhalent one projects laterally on the ‘shoulder’. The flesh is pink to bright red (hence the common name ‘red bait’).
taxon_text_2_1437: The largest ascidian in the region with a typical size of about 150 mm height, but can reach at least 300 mm and be as fat as a rugby ball.
taxon_text_3_1438:
Global: Namibia to Mozambique. Many earlier references also report this species from Australia, but those populations are now recognised as comprising several other separate species (P. praeputialis, P. dalbyi and P. sp. See reference below)

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1439:
A very important species ecologically, dominating the lowest parts of the intertidal and rocky reefs down to a depth of about 10 m, especially in the Cape. Also occurs as loose boulder-like masses on soft substrate in sheltered sites and these are often washed up in large quantities after storms. Red bait beds create habitat for a large number of other species, including commensal copepods, amphipods and crabs that live inside the body cavity. Pyura are also extensively exploited as bait (hence the common name) and are also eaten in some regions.

The structure of the outer test of ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1440: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the  pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1441:
Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary one reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the subratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1442: Pyura species are easy to distinguish from other regional ascidians due to their large size and thick, brown-skinned tests. This species can easily be confused with P. herdmani though, which is very similar in size and habits, but has lobed papillae on the test, especially around the siphons.
taxon_text_8_1443:
Fielding, PJ, Weerts, KA & Forbes, AT (1994). Macroinvertebrate communities associated with intertidal and subtidal beds of Pyura stolonifera (Heller)(Tunicata: Ascidiacea) on the Natal coast. African Zoology, 29(1), 46-53.

Klumpp, DW (1984). Nutritional ecology of the ascidian Pyura stolonifera: Influence of body size, food quantity and quality on filter-feeding, respiration, assimilation efficiency and energy balance. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 19(3), 269-284.

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 113).

Rius, M & Teske, PR (2011). A revision of the Pyura stolonifera species complex (Tunicata, Ascidiacea), with a description of a new species from Australia. Zootaxa, 2754, 27-40.
taxon_text_1_1446: Common colonial species that forms thickish undulating cushions on rock and many other hard substrata. When hanging from kelps, jetties or harbour walls etc., may extend into large, flat, fleshy hanging sheets that are double-sided, with zooids present on both surfaces. The zooids are arranged in rows, or irregular circular groups (but not usually in a regular, consistent circular pattern) along a network of channels and exhalent openings and the inhalant (or oral) aperture of each zooid is circled with a ring a white pigment. Apart from this distinctive feature, colour is very variable although tunic is most commonly pink, purple or red.
taxon_text_2_1447: Zooids about 2 mm, but colonies up to about 200 mm across.
taxon_text_3_1448:
Global: Only known with certainty from South Africa and reports from New Zealand, Australia, Japan and Europe probably represent other, related species.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1449: A common fouling species abundant in harbours and other sheltered sites, but also in rocky reefs, kelps beds, etc. Little else is known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1450: All ascidians are filter feeder, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1451: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooida), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1452: The white ring around the oral apertures of zooids is probably the best identification character, but very variable in colour and still easily confuses with various Botryllus species. The detailed taxonomy of the group is confused (see Monniot reference below) and is it seems likely that samples reported from other regions represent other species.
taxon_text_8_1453:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 77).
taxon_text_1_1326: Test inflated (‘incrassate’ – hence name) fairly thick and hard, purple to red in colour and often covered with epifauna, attached to substratum by the one side.  Siphons fairly distinct from body, devoid of epifauna, the inhalant siphon directed upwards and the exhalent one to the side. Tips of both siphons folded into 8 lobes, with red patches between each lobe.
taxon_text_2_1327: Up to about 100 mm long, including siphons.
taxon_text_3_1328:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only with certainty from Western Cape (Saldanha Bay to False Bay). Specimens identified under this name from Mozambique probably represent A. canaliculata. Those reported from the Eastern Cape differ somewhat in colour pattern and may represent an undescribed species.
taxon_text_4_1329:
Attached to rocks or the undersides of boulders on shallow reefs.

The structure of the outer test of solitary ascidians such as this is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coating, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1330: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1331:
Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary ones such as this reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1332: There are several Ascidia species in the region and these can be difficult to distinguish. However, the purple to red colour of the test and red spots on the inner edge of the siphon of this species make it fairly easy to recognise.
taxon_text_8_1333:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 67)
taxon_text_1_5665:
Entoprocta are a small and little known Phylum unfamiliar to even many marine biology students and seldom included in field guides. They were once included within the Bryozoa, but have now been moved to a separate phylum (largely because the mouth lies inside the crown of tentacles, as opposed to outside in the Bryozoa). Globally, they comprise about 150 species of small, sessile, almost exclusively marine animals with long stalks and goblet-shaped bodies topped by a ring of 8-30 solid tentacles. Some are solitary but most are colonial, with individuals arising at intervals from a creeping stolon.

This species is colonial and found attached to other invertebrates, in the case depicted the carapace of a West Coast Rock Lobster and the Rock crab.
taxon_text_3_5667:
Global: Not known as species uncertain.

Local/Regional: Throughout region.
taxon_text_4_5668: Found growing on the surfaces of algae and of other invertebrates such as sponges, bryozoans and crustaceans.
taxon_text_5_5669: All ectoprocts are filter feeders. Cilia on the tentacles generate a feeding current that draws water inwards between the tentacles and then up through the central opening. Food particles trapped by the cilia are transported downwards to the mouth. The digestive tract is U-shaped and the anus lies inside the circle of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_5670: All ectoprocts are hermaphroditic and many brood their eggs in the area between the tentacles before releasing them. After a short free-swimming existence the larvae settle and undertake a complicated metamorphosis from which new adults are derived.
taxon_text_7_5671:
Only a handful of species are know from South Africa, some of which (Loxosoma) are solitary and live on soft bodies hosts such as polychaete worms and others (Barentsia) which are colonial, but have a muscular swelling at the base of each individual and undergo a characteristic nodding motion.

Can be confused with bryozoans. Another group these animals can be confused with are horseshoe worms (phoronids), of which smaller species of the same size to entoprocs build extensive colonies with similar filterfeeding adaptations. Superficially also can be confused with hydroids but the tentacles are solid, not mobile as in hydroids.
taxon_text_8_9694: O'donoghue, CH & Day, JH (1957). Some South African Bryozoa. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 35(2), 71-95.
taxon_text_1_1456: Globular, light brown solitary species with a tough leathery tunic that has a knobbly texture and is often covered by fouling organisms. The siphons are short and prominent with wide openings that are internally banded and spotted in white and red.
taxon_text_3_1458:
Global: Widely distributed across the globe by shipping, including in Europe South America, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: West coast, from Alexander Bay to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_1459: Mostly found attached to pilings, ropes and pontoons in harbours, but has spread to shallow reefs in False Bay.
taxon_text_5_1460: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1461: Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1462: The leathery texture of the test and wide red and white patterned siphons are good identification features. One of several introduced solitary ascidians common in habours in the region.
taxon_text_8_1463:
Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 98, as Cnemidocarpa humilus).

Picker, M & Grififths, C (2011). Alien and invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 74, as Cnemidocarpa humilus).
taxon_text_1_1466: One of the more distinctive species in this diverse and confusing genus, which includes a number of very variable local species. The colony is thin and encrusting and grows only on the surfaces of red-algae, particularly Rhodymenia (previously Epymenia) obtusa. Most unusual within the genus in that the zooids are not clustered into groups around common exhalent apertures, but are separate, spherical and regularly arranged within the transparent matrix, all facing in the same direction.
taxon_text_2_1467: Zooids about 2 mm, but colonies up to about 100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_1468:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western Cape only, from about Cape Peninsula to Knysna.
taxon_text_4_1469: Fairly common and only found on the blades of red algae, the reasons for this association are not known. Little else is know about biology.
taxon_text_5_1470: All ascidians are filter feeder, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1471: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids) but now colonies arise by sexual reproduction.  This species is unique among Botryllus in that the larvae are brooded in the tunic, rather than within the individual zooids.
taxon_text_7_1472: There are several easily confused Botryllus species in the region, but this one is easily recognized since the zooids are separate and regularly distributed across the tunic, rather than being arranges into groupings of various configurations, as is the case with all other species.
taxon_text_8_1473:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 200).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 77).
taxon_text_1_1476: One of the more distinctive species in this diverse and confusing genus, which includes a number of very variable local species. The colony is thin and encrusting and forms meandering ‘ladders’ of paired zooids that lie on either side of a central cloacal (exhalent) channel that has few, hardly–visible opening. The chains of zooids may branch and although variable in colour are most commonly pink or red, the colour being concentrated within the zooids, the matrix of the tunic being relatively transparent.
taxon_text_2_1477: Zooids about 2 mm, but colonies up to about 100 mm long.
taxon_text_3_1478:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western Cape only, from about Cape Peninsula to Knysna.
taxon_text_4_1479: Fairly common almost always under boulders and in similar shaded habitats. Little else is know about biology.
taxon_text_5_1480: All ascidians are filter-feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1481: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.
taxon_text_7_1482: The ladder-like arrangement of the zooids in long parallel chains on either side of the cloacal channel is fairly distinctive. Still can be confused with various other Botryllus species though and the detailed taxonomy of this and other members of the group remain confused (see Monniot reference below).
taxon_text_8_1483:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 77).
taxon_text_1_1486: One of the more distinctive species in this diverse and confusing genus, which includes a number of very variable local species. The colony is thin and encrusting and most often chocolate brown or purple in colour (more rarely grey) and the zooids are grouped in circles of about 5 -10 individuals regularly arranged around common exhalent apertures, each group creating a characteristic white or grey star-shaped pattern.
taxon_text_2_1487: Zooids 2-3 mm, but colonies typically about 100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_1488:
Global: Native to North Atlantic and Mediterranean, but has been translocated widely by shipping and is now widely found across both coasts of N. America, in Australasia, Japan, South Africa, etc

Local/Regional: First reported in South Africa in 1946, now widely distributed form Alexander Bay to Durban, mainly, but not exclusively, in harbours and adjacent bays and lagoons.
taxon_text_4_1489: Common fouling species in harbours and on floating structures. Little else is know about biology.
taxon_text_5_1490: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1491: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids) but new colonies arise by sexual reproduction.
taxon_text_7_1492: There are several easily confused Botryllus species in the region, but this one is fairly easily recognized but the radiating white ‘stars’ surrounding the rings of zooids to their common exhalent apertures.
taxon_text_8_1493:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 250).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 80).
taxon_text_1_1496: Very distinctive colonial species in which the thick, freshy, oval, pink tunic projects vertically from the rock surface and is supported on a short flexible stalk or peduncle. The small zooids are darker pink and each is enclosed is a small capsule embedded in the tunic. Each zooid is about 6 mm long and has a pair of closely-adjacent siphons. Pieces of colony are often used as cloaks by dromid crabs.
taxon_text_2_1497: Colonies up to about 200 mm in height.
taxon_text_3_1498:
Global: South Africa (and possibly Falkland Islands).

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to East London.
taxon_text_4_1499:
A fairy common and unusual species with a distinct paddle-like appearance that often causes interest when specimens are cast up in large numbers after storms. Pieces of colony are also often used a ‘cloaks’ by dromid crabs such as Pseudodromia latens (see Fig. 57.4 in Two Oceans book).

The structure of the outer test is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1500: All ascidians are filter feeder, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1501: Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop. Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults! The larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1502: Entire colonies are unmistakable. The detailed taxonomy of the group is confused though (see Monniot reference below) and is it seems likely that samples reported from Falklands and KwaZulu-Natal may represent other similar species.
taxon_text_8_1503:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 248).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 88).
taxon_text_1_1506: Tall, solitary, upright ascidian with a tough, leathery, brown test that is angular and six-sided in cross-section (hence the name). The siphons each have four lobes, with the inhalant one being on the shoulder and the exhalant one pointing upwards.  Often partly overgrown by fouling organisms.
taxon_text_3_1508:
Global: Namibia and South Africa only.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_1509:
A fairy uncommon species usually seen singly or in small scattered groups in low intertidal pools or on shallow reefs. Little else known about habits.

The structure of the outer test of these ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!
taxon_text_5_1510: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1511:
Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary one like this one reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1512: The 6-sided angular test is distinctive, although at least two other much smaller Styela species also occur in the same region.
taxon_text_8_1513:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 199).
taxon_text_1_1516: Soft, delicate, worm-like organism with an unsegmented yellowish body divided into an acorn-like proboscis, a short collar section and an elongate trunk, the anterior part of which is wrapped by lateral lobes that cover a series of gill slits, behind which are a row of small khaki-coloured hepatic lobes.
taxon_text_3_1518:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1519:
Of evolutionary interest, as represents a link between the invertebrates and vertebrates, as has gill slits and a notocord (primitive backbone).

Constructs U-shaped burrows into sheltered sandbanks or in sediments between rocks and may reveal its presence by ejecting coiled sand-castings onto the sand surface. Moves sluggishly though sediments using ciliary action and muscular contractions of the proboscis.

Extremely delicate and frequently breaks up when excavated or handled, so probably more common that sampling results indicate.
taxon_text_5_1520: Deposit feeder, consuming sediments and extracting organic matter from these.
taxon_text_6_1521: Sexes are separate and the eggs and sperm released into the water via a small pore near the gill slits. The fertilized eggs develop into elongate planktonic larvae, which in most species develop directly into the adult form. In some species there is a second intermediate larval stage called a tornaria larva. This resembles the larvae of echinoderms, suggesting an evolutionary link between these groups.
taxon_text_7_1522: Unlikely to be confused with other groups due to the unique body form. Replaced by the much larger (up to 1 m long!) B. natalensis along the east coast.
taxon_text_8_1523:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 244)

von Bonde, C (1934). The morphology of Balanoglossus capensis (Gilchrist), a species of Enteropneusta from False Bay. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 22(1), 17-33.
taxon_text_1_1526: Large, wide-bodied, heavy-set and slow-moving species with a pair of large, rounded humps on the pleotelson. Body otherwise smooth, except for 4 small tubercles on last abdominal segment of males (but not females). Tip of pleotelson truncate, with pair of small notches in male. Often attractively mottled in pinks and reds.
taxon_text_3_1528:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1529: One of the larger isopods found under boulders and among seaweeds on rocky shores and shallow reefs.  Usually encountered singly. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1530: Not specifically known, but thought to feed on algae and possibly other organic debris.
taxon_text_6_1531: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_1532:
This a diverse genus of which more than 20 species have been recorded from the region. Species level identification is thus difficult ( refer to Kensey 1978 reference below) particularly as ornamentation of the body often differs between males and females.

This species is best identified by a combination of its unusually large size and by the relative lack of dorsal ornamentation, other than the pair of large humps on the pleotelson of both sexes.
taxon_text_8_1533:
Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 102).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 92).
taxon_text_9_1535: Previously included within Eurydice longicornis, but that species has now been split into three separate species, E. longicornis, E. barnardi and E. kensleyi.
taxon_text_1_1536: Fairly small, off-white isopod with black specking dorsally. Most easily recognized from other isopod genera by the form of the first antennae, the first segment of which projects forward, while the remainder of the appendage is turning outwards at right-angles (hence common name). Separated form other local Eurydice species by length of second antennae, which in males reach back to about end of thorax, and by pleotelson having a small central depression (only visible microscopically).
taxon_text_3_1538:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Probably Southern Namibia to about Cape Peninsula, but many older records are now thrown into doubt due to subdivision of the original species into three!
taxon_text_4_1539: An active swimmer found in the intertidal zone of sandy beaches, especially fairly flat, dissipative beaches along the west coast. By contrast the closely-related but less common E. barnardi is more of a burrower, occurs mostly higher up the shore and feeds mostly on nematodes.
taxon_text_5_1540: A predator that feeds mostly on polychaete worms. Also attracted to dead animal matter, such as washed up bivalves and drowned sandhoppers.
taxon_text_6_1541: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released. Breed throughout the year, each female carrying between about 40 and 50 eggs.
taxon_text_7_1542: Originally only a single species of this genus, Eurydice longicornis, was though to occur in the region, but this has now been subdivided into three, with the original E. longicornis occurring subtidally and both E. barnardi and E. kensleyi intertidally. The two intertidal species have similar distributions, but can be separated by length of antenna 2 and presence/absence of a central depression in the pleotelson. In E. kensleyi antenna 2 of males is as long as the thorax and the pleotelon has a depression, while in E. barnardi the antennae only extend the thorax segment 3 and the pleotelson lacks a depression.
taxon_text_8_1543:
Brown, AC (1972). The ecology of the sandy beaches of the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. Part 4: Observations on two intertidal isopoda, Eurydice longicornis (Stüder) and Exosphaeroma truncatitelson Barnard. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 40(5), 381-404.

Bruce, NL & Soares, AG (1996). Taxonomy and ecology of sandy beach Eurydice (Crustacea, Isopoda, Cirolanidae) from the West coast of South Africa. Cahiers de Biologie Marine, 37, 77-98.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 72, as E. longicornis).
taxon_text_1_1546: Medium-sized, off-white isopod. Antennae short, reaching only about a third length of thorax; antenna 1 with the first few segments swollen (but not bent outwards at right-angles, as in Eurydice). Second antennae slender. Upper lip (epistome) coming to a sharp point that projects upwards between bases on antennae. Pleotelson with a pair of lateral concavities and both uropods and pleotelson fringed with fairly-long setae.
taxon_text_3_1548:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1549: Fairly common burrowing into sandy beaches and especially in sand around rocks where it scavenges on washed up debris.
taxon_text_6_1551: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_1552: The only regional representative of this genus, but found together with species of Right-angles beach louse (Eurydice species) with which it is often confused.  Eurydice are distinguished by having the first antennae initially project forward and then turn outwards at right angles after the first segment.
taxon_text_8_1553:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa. 3. Additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum, 10 (11), 359-440.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 74, as Pontogeloides latipes).
taxon_text_1_1556: Large, wide-bodied and flattened isopod with head projecting forward into a ‘nose’ and short, thickened antennae. Walking legs strongly modified and hooked to grip host. First abdominal segment notably narrower than succeeding ones. Best identified by its habitat of living exclusively in the mouth of the Carpenter seabream Argrozona argyrozona.
taxon_text_3_1558:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1559:
Tongue replacement isopods are a remarkable group of isopods that replace the tongues of living fish. The parasite enters the mouth through the gills and the female then severs the blood vessels leading to the tongue, which withers and drops off. She then attaches onto the stub of the tongue and takes over its function, while the smaller male takes up a position beneath and behind the female. This is the only known example of a group of parasites actually functionally replacing the organs of their hosts!

Perhaps surprisingly, this is a fairly common adaptation and there are numerous species of tongue-replacement isopods in this and related genera, each specialising in a single host fish, or a related group of fish. In general the parasites appear to cause relatively little harm to their hosts, although some studies have shown parasitised fish to be thinner than un-parasitised ones. In the crowded conditions of cage culture farms, however, tongue replacement parasites (and other external isopod parasites) can become very abundant and cause significant mortality among host populations.

This particular species is the largest known tongue replacement isopod and is found only on the Carpenter seabream Argrozona argyrozona.
taxon_text_5_1560: Feed on the host blood and on fish mucus.
taxon_text_6_1561: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles. Adults begin life as males and later become females and take up position as a replacement tongue for the host fish.
taxon_text_7_1562:
This a diverse genus with more than 20 species globally and five in South Africa (for identification key and list of hosts of each species see reference below).

This species is best identified by a combination of its unusually large size and by the fact that it is restricted to the Carpenter seabream.
taxon_text_8_1563: Hadfield, KA & Smit, NJ (2020). Review of the global distribution and hosts of the economically important fish parasitic isopod genus Ceratothoa (Isopoda: Cymothoidae), including the description of Ceratothoa springbok n. sp. from South Africa. International Journal for Parasitology, 50(10-11), 899-919.
taxon_text_1_1566: Small, flattened, white isopod with oval, setose body and gaps between lateral margins of thoracic segments. Antennae very long and setose. Pleotelson oval with a small bulge at tip. Uropods long and setose with the two branches diverging, outer one somewhat the shorter.
taxon_text_2_1567: Up to about 5 mm, excluding antennae, which are as long as body.
taxon_text_3_1568:
Global: Southern Africa and St Paul and Amsterdam Islands.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1569: Biology poorly known, but fairly commonly found under intertidal boulders and on rocky reefs to a depth of about 84 m.
taxon_text_5_1570: Unknown, but given the under boulder habitat may feed on sponges, bryozoans, hydroids or other encrusting species.
taxon_text_6_1571: Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_1572: The oval, setose body is fairly characteristic and so unlikely to be confused with other species.
taxon_text_8_1573:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa. 3. Additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum, 10, 325–442.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 88).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 139).
taxon_text_1_1576:
Distinctive species in that the dorsal surface of the entire body is covered in conical or tongue-shaped tubercles that are arranged in transverse rows across each body segment. Usually there are alternating larger and smaller tubercles in each row.

The pleotelson is also tuberculate, but otherwise very different in the two sexes. In males it is greatly enlarged and terminates in an unusual keyhole-shaped notch that has a raised margin. In females the margins of the pleoteson are folded downwards, so that when viewed from above it has a narrowly-rounded raised tip. In both sexes the uropods are unusual in that the inner branch, which bears a row of dorsal tubercles, is forked at its tip, whereas the outer branch is smooth and ends in an outwardly-curved and pointed tip.
taxon_text_3_1578:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1579:
Very little is know about this species, which has an unusual history. The original specimens, from which the species was described, were all females and were collected from the stomach of a cormorant! Thus when Kensley wrote his guide-book in 1978, the male was still unknown, although he appears to have been unaware of this and incorrectly depicted the female as a male (and thus incorrectly defined the species as lacking a notch in the male pleotelson).

 In compiling this guide we for the first time formally found males and were able to match them with females from the same samples.  The images and description given here is thus the first formal record of males of this species. We found this species to be abundant under high to mid-shore rocks on boulder shores at several sites.
taxon_text_5_1580: Not specifically known, but probably feeds on algae and possibly other organic debris that collects under boulders.
taxon_text_6_1581: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_1582:
There are two described species in this genus from South Africa and these were previously separated primarily by the form of the male pleotelson, but as described above, this was based on an error, as Kensley (1976) mistakenly depicted the female as a male. The species do, however, still differ in the size and form of the dorsal tubercles, which are larger and button-shaped in S. polytylotos and smaller and more conical in S. microtylotos. The distinction between these species is thus retained, although this should be confirmed by genetic analysis, as there is a good deal of variation on dorsal ornamentation between individuals.

Note that males of Parisocladus also show this unusual keyhole-shaped opening in the pleotelson, the function of which remains unknown. Parisocladus lack dorsal tubercles though.
taxon_text_8_1583:
Barnard, KH (1955). Additions to the fauna-list of South African Crustacea and Pycnogonida. Annals of the South African Museum, 43, 1-107 (p. 66).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 112)
taxon_text_1_1586:
Distinctive species, in that the dorsal surface of the entire body is covered in large, flat-topped, almost button-like tubercles arranged in transverse rows across each body segment.

The pleotelson is also tuberculate, but different in the two sexes. In males it is enlarged and terminates in an unusual keyhole-shaped notch, but in females the margins are entire. In both sexes the uropods are unusual in that the inner branch, which bears a row of dorsal tubercles, is slightly forked at its tip, whereas the outer branch is smooth and ends in an outwardly-curved point.
taxon_text_3_1588:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to Plettenerg Bay.
taxon_text_4_1589: Found among mussels and barnacles on rocky shores, but also common among reefs of the Cape reef worm, Gunnarea gaimardi.
taxon_text_5_1590: Thought to feed on filamentous and green algae and possibly other organic debris that collects in the habitat.
taxon_text_6_1591: As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_1592:
There are two described species in this genus from South Africa and these were separated by Kensley (1976) primarily by the form of the male pleotelson, but this was based on an error, as he mistakenly depicted the female of S. microtylotos as a male and thus stated that species to lack the keyhole-like notch at the end of the pleotelson. Now that we have found males (see that entry) we find that the male pleotelsons of both species are similar.

The species do still differ in the size and form of dorsal tubercles, which are much larger and more flat-topped in S. polytylotos and smaller and more conical in S. microtylotos. The distinction between these species is thus retained, although this should be confirmed by genetic analysis, as there is considerable variation on dorsal ornamentation between individuals.

Note that males of Parisocladus also show keyhole-shaped openings in the pleotelson, the function of which remains unknown. Parisocladus lack rows of dorsal tubercles on the thorax though.
taxon_text_8_1593:
Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa. 3. Additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum, 10, 325–442.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 92).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 112).
taxon_text_1_1596:
Pyrosomes are free-swimming colonial organisms related to ascidians, but in which the individual zooids are arranged into a transparent tubular colony that is closed at the one end and open at the other. The colony thus resembles the finger of a glove. The individuals look much like those of colonial ascidians (sea squirts), except that the inhalant and exhalent openings are now at opposite ends of the body. The individuals all face outwards, so that water is sucked in from outside and pumped into the central chamber and out though the open end of the colony, thus propelling it forwards.

There is a pair of luminescent organs on either side of the inhalant aperture of each zooid and these contain bioluminescent bacteria that produce a bright light when the colony is disturbed (hence the group name pyro = fire, soma = body).

Most of the previously recognized species have now been amalgamated under this one name and this is now the only valid species reported from South Africa.
taxon_text_3_1598:
Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate seas globally.

Local/Regional: Across whole region.
taxon_text_4_1599: Planktonic and not often seen, but at times can become very common  and sometimes washed ashore in large numbers. Well know for their ability to bioluminesce when disturbed.
taxon_text_5_1600: Filter-feeders drawing in water though the inhalant siphon and passing it though a mucous net that lines the pharynx. Capable of extracting minute particulate from the water.
taxon_text_6_1601: Colonies grow by budding off new zooids, so can vary greatly in size and number of component individuals. New colonies are formed by sexual reproduction in which the single egg within each zooid is fertilised internally. This then grows into a zooid that buds off 4 other arranged around it. The original zooid then degenerates, except for its tunic, which is retained to form the basic body of the new colony.
taxon_text_7_1602: Unlikely to be confused with other species, except perhaps comb jellies (ctenophores) some of which have a similar transparent and sausage–shaped body, but are formed of a single individual.
taxon_text_8_1603:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 244).

Gibbons, MJ (1997). An introduction to the Zooplankton of the Benguela Current Region. NBD Goodwood, Western Cape.
taxon_text_1_1606: Strange, semi-transparent, blind, eel-like organisms that represent a link between invertebrates and true vertebrates. Body pointed at both ends and with a short fin extending all the way along the back and around the tail. There is a well-developed notochord (primitive backbone), an anterior mouth encircled by short cirri, a series of gill slits and the body is divided into obviously visible muscle blocks.
taxon_text_3_1608:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1609:
Of evolutionary interest, as represent a link between the invertebrates and vertebrates, as have well-developed gill-slits and notocord (primitive backbone), but lack a true head, brain or skull and the gill slits are used primarily for feeding, rather than for respiration. Also lack red blood cells and haemoglobin typical of vertebrates.

When alive lancelets are very active and swim a short distance before quickly burrowing into the sediment when disturbed. When settled they sit with the body buried and just head projecting upwards into the water column.  Not found intertidally, but common in benthic sediments, especially in False Bay.
taxon_text_5_1610: Filter water into the mouth and capture fine food particles on a mucous sheet is continually produced and flows over the gill slits before being directed into the digestive tract.
taxon_text_6_1611: Sexes are separate and spawn synchronously, releasing the eggs and sperm into the water. These develop into larvae which ultimately settle onto the bottom and transform into young lancelets.
taxon_text_7_1612: Unlikely to be confused with other groups due to the unique body form.
taxon_text_8_1613: Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 244).
taxon_text_1_1626: Small, usually six-armed species, the most distinctive feature of which is that it frequently reproduces by splitting in half (‘fissipary’), such that three of the arms are typically much shorter than the other three. Five armed specimens also sometimes encountered and may have 2 or 3 longer arms. Body colour fairly uniform pink or orange, evenly covered in shortish, blunt spines. Always has 2 madreporites, presumably in preparation for division!
taxon_text_3_1628:
Global: Fairly widespread across South Atlantic, including Argentina, Southern Chile, South Atlantic islands, Angola, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1629: Uncommonly seen on shallow reefs along the west coast, but very distinctive due to the 6-armed body design and unequal arms.
taxon_text_5_1630: Thought to feed on a variety of invertebrates by extruding the stomach though the mouth and plastering it over the prey. The diet of this species has not been studied though.
taxon_text_6_1631: Sexes are separate and there are probably six gonads in each individual (one in each arm) although these may only be mature in the larger arms! Although sexual reproduction certainly occurs, with sperm and eggs being released to form planktonic larvae, this species appear to reproduce mainly by division. Argentinian specimens divide once a year by spring by splitting across the disc and development of the new series of arms takes about 5 months.
taxon_text_7_1632: Unlikely to be mistaken for any other species, but the Many-armed starfish Concinasterias calamaria, which is also much larger and darker and usually has 8-10 arms, also has some arms much shorter than the others.
taxon_text_8_1633:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 226).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 91).

Rubilar, T, Pastor de Ward, CT & Díaz de Vivar, ME (2005). Sexual and asexual reproduction of Allostichaster capensis (Echinodermata: Asteroidea) in Golfo Nuevo. Marine Biology, 146(6), 1083-1090.
taxon_text_1_1636: One of only a few local starfish that lives on soft substrata, not on rocky reefs, and mostly buried in sand by day, emerging to feed at night. Body flattened, off-white to apricot, with purple strip along top of arms, becoming brighter towards tip. Arms fairly long and triangular, evenly tapering and each bordered with a double row of small, tile-like plates, those in upper row each with a single spine and those on lower row each bearing 3-4 longer spines. Unlike most other starfish, members of this family have pointed tubefeet that lack suckers and are used to burrow, rather than to adhere to hard surfaces.
taxon_text_3_1638:
Global: Species widespread in Europe and Mediterranean, but the local subspecies pontoporaeus found only in Angola, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1639: Lives buried in soft sediments, which it shuffles aside with the tube feed in order to bury itself. When buried a conical structure in the centre of the  upper surface, through which water is sucked in for operation of hydraulic system (the aboral cone) may still be visible. Emerges to feed at night.
taxon_text_5_1640: Carnivorous, feeding on small molluscs and crustaceans buried in the sediment.
taxon_text_6_1641: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1642: Members of this group are easily distinguished from most other starfish by the tile-like plates along the margins of the arms, the pointed tubefeet and habit of living buried in sediments. This species is replaced by A. granulatus in KwaZulu-Natal, that species being recognised by its grey colour and strong  white spines that project from the lower row of arm–plates. Several other species also occur in deeper waters.
taxon_text_8_1643:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 222).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 81).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 176)
taxon_text_1_1646: Distinctive brown or orange species with central area covered in course spiny granules, while margins of body and sides of arms are lined with large square tiles. These may be smooth, or have spines or granules projecting from them.
taxon_text_3_1648:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to Algoa Bay, 9-23 m depth.
taxon_text_4_1649: Uncommon, but fairly often seen by divers on shallow reefs in False Bay and Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_5_1650: Not specifically known for this species, but presumably carnivorous like most other similar species, feeding on a variety of reef invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_1651: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Eggs and sperm are presumed to be released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1652: Given the wide variety of colour forms and sizes and numbers of knobs and spines on the marginal plates of photographed specimens it seems likely that more than one local species may be represented.
