taxon_text_8_1653:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 222).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 81).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 176)
taxon_text_1_1656: Arms tapering from a fairly-broad base, each semicircular in cross-section, the upper surface convex and the lower surface flat. Surface texture granular. Colour variable and may be yellow, orange, red or purple, but almost always with round yellow or orange spots, which become larger and denser towards ends of arms.
taxon_text_2_1657: Diameter typically about 80 mm, but up to 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_1658:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Almost entirely confined to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1659: Fairly common species in this location extending from about 15 - 55 m depth. Despite being commonly photographed, little else is known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1660: No specific information for this species but thought to feed on detritus and on a variety of benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_1661: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Sperm and eggs are released into the water column and develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1662: The closely-related Red-tiled starfish C. granifera is similar in size and shape and found in much the same habitat, but differs in colour, always being plain orange or red.
taxon_text_8_1663: Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 78).
taxon_text_1_1686: Disc fairly small and arms long, quite stout and rounded in cross-section. Each arm swells slightly just beyond its base before evenly tapering to a quite sharply pointed tip. Texture granular (raised into small humps) and base colour orange with the granules yellow. Tips of arms distinctly yellow.
taxon_text_3_1688:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay, 0-16 m.
taxon_text_4_1689: Uncommon species sometimes seen by divers on shallow reefs. Little else known about its biology.
taxon_text_5_1690: No information, but other Fromia species are reputed to feed on microscopic algae.
taxon_text_6_1691: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Sperm and eggs are released into the water column and develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1692: One of several red starfish in the region, but can be distinguished by mottled red and yellow colour and the fact that the arms broaden slightly beyond the bases and then taper again to fairly narrow yellow tips. The Reticulated starfish Henricia ornata has narrower, cylindrical arms and a reticulated surface texture. The Red starfish Callopatiria granifera has broader arms that taper evenly towards their tips and has a tiled texture.
taxon_text_8_1693:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 226).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 69).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 176)
taxon_text_1_1696: Orange to dark red starfish, rarely with white blotching centrally. Arms elongate and cylindrical and only gradually tapering towards blunt tips. Entire dorsal surface covered in a characteristic, irregularly honeycombed texture, after which the common name is derived.
taxon_text_3_1698:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1699: Common intertidal species extending to depths of about 90 m. Despite being commonly observed, little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1700: Thought to feed on sponges, but also probably on detritus. The tiny skeleton shrimp Caprella scaura is sometimes found clinging to the body surface in some numbers and perfectly matches its host in colour. The nature of this relationship is not known though.
taxon_text_6_1701: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Sperm and eggs are released into the water column and develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1702: One of several red starfish in the region, but can be distinguished by the narrow, cylindrical arms and reticulated surface texture. The Red starfish Callopatiria granifera has broader arms that taper evenly towards their tips and has a tiled texture, whereas the Granular starfish Fromia schultzei is mottled red and yellow and has arms broader slightly beyond the bases and then tapering again to fairly narrow, yellow tips.
taxon_text_8_1703:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 226).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 89).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 177)
<p>juveniles like to hide in Smokey feat: juveniles like to hide in Smokey feather hydroid
taxon_text_1_1716:
Small, flattened, almost perfectly pentagonal species with poorly developed arms (almost always five, but specimens with four or six arms may be found). Surface texture evenly granular. Gonopores situated on the dorsal side. 

Colour variable, but usually dominantly pink with patches of purple or white.
taxon_text_3_1718:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1719: Found in the open in low intertidal pools or on shallow reefs, usually in low numbers and often together with the much more abundant and smaller P. exigua, with which it is easily confused (see below).
taxon_text_5_1720: Herbivorous and feed by extruding the stomach though the mouth and plastering it onto the surfaces of algae, or onto rock surfaces, such that any microscopic algae present are digested and absorbed by the stomach. Pale, flower-like scars are sometimes visible on smooth rocks (or algae-coated glass of fish tanks) where specimens have recently fed!
taxon_text_6_1721: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1722: Easily confused with the Dwarf cushion star P. exigua which occurs in the same sites and is more common and notably smaller (20 mm). That species also extends higher on the shore, reaching at least midshore rockpools. The two species also differ in colour, surface texture and reproductive mode, P. exigua is mostly plain green or brown on the west coast, but brightly coloured in a mosaic of blue, red, purple, brown and white
taxon_text_8_1723:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 224).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 80).

Payne, RP, Griffiths, CL, Von der Heyden, S & Koch, E (2015). The cushion–star Parvulastra exigua in South Africa: one species or more? ZooKeys, 524, 1-16.
<p>madreporite of a washed-up and dried: madreporite of a washed-up and dried specimen
taxon_text_1_1726:
Tiny, flattened and pentagonal species with poorly developed arms (usually five, but specimens with four or six arms may be found). Surface texture a series of small tile-like plates, each bearing a cluster of tiny knob-like spines. Gonopores situated on the ventral side. Common on algae, especially encrusting corallines, in rock pools and often seen laying groups of orange eggs on the undersides of rocks.

Colour very variable and differs regionally. Specimens from the west coast are usually uniform green or (more rarely) brown, while those east of Cape Point are variegated and mottled in a wide variety of patterns and in colours including blue, brown, red, purple and white. Underside uniformly blue-green.
taxon_text_3_1728:
Global: Angola, Namibia, South Africa, Mozambique, Mauritius and southern Australia.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1729: By far the most common starfish in the intertidal zone, especially in rock pools, where often with several present on each square meter of rock, but easily missed by virtue of their small size and extremely cryptic colouration.
taxon_text_5_1730: Herbivorous and feed by extruding the stomach though the mouth and plastering it onto the surfaces of algae, or onto rock surfaces, such that any microscopic algae present are digested and absorbed by the stomach. Pale, flower-like scars are sometimes visible on smooth rocks (or algae-coated glass of fish tanks) where specimens have recently fed!
taxon_text_6_1731: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! This species in unusual among starfish in that its lays its eggs in groups on the undersides of rocks, where they develop directly into tiny starfish, without any planktonic larval stage. Development to hatching takes about 20 days in Australia, but is strongly dependent on water temperature.
taxon_text_7_1732: Easily confused with the Granular cushion star P. dyscrita which occurs in the same sites, but is less common, slightly larger (40 mm) and is usually found lower on the shore, or sub-tidally. The two species also differ in colour, surface texture and reproductive mode, P. dyscrita usually being mottled in pink and purple, having a more uniform granular surface texture and having dorsal gonopores, its sperm and eggs being released into the water column, where they develop into pelagic larvae.
taxon_text_8_1733:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 224).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 81).

Payne, RP, Griffiths, CL, Von der Heyden, S & Koch, E (2015). The cushion–star Parvulastra exigua in South Africa: one species or more? ZooKeys, 524, 1-16.
<p>typical False Bay, South Coast, colou: typical False Bay, South Coast, colour morphs
taxon_text_1_1736:
Fairly large, very fat, cushion-like species with poorly developed arms and a central dorsal opening. Colour yellow to orange, often with brown spots or blotches.

The dorsal surface (as in all members of this family) consists of a unique double layer, the normal lower layer bearing long, branched spines which support a second thin outer membrane, thus creating a cavity which is used as a brood chamber. The dorsal chamber is ventilated through a central round opening and specimens can be observed ’breathing’ in and out of this hole.
taxon_text_3_1738:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1739: Absent intertidally, but occurs from a few metres depth to about 370 m on both rock and sand. Uncommon and usually seen singly. Secretes copious toxic mucus when disturbed to deter predators.
taxon_text_5_1740: Thought to feed on a variety of invertebrates by extruding the stomach though the mouth and plastering it over the prey. The diet of this species has not been studied, but related species in the Northern Hemisphere feed on sponges, molluscs and ascidians.
taxon_text_6_1741: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Like many other members of this family this species broods it young in the dorsal chamber. The details of this process have not been studied, but in related North American species the young are considerably larger than the eggs from which they develop, suggesting that developing juveniles must obtain nutrition directly from the mother (or by eating one another!).
taxon_text_7_1742: The large size, fat cushion-like form and respiratory aperture in the centre of the dorsal surface make it unlikely that Pteraster species would be confused with other regional starfish. There are three other deep water species in the region though (P. affinis, P. flabellifera and P. fornicatus), but these all occur below about 300 m water depth.
taxon_text_8_1743:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 224).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 84).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 178)
taxon_text_1_1776:
Test oval, white, very thin and fragile and with a marked anterior notch that extends into a distinct trough that runs to centre of upper side (hence the heart shape). Dorsal ‘petals’ wide and distinctly sunken. Mouth displaced towards anterior end and with a scoop-like posterior lip. Underside bears patches of large tubercles (to which spines attach) separated by smooth channels (where tubefeet emerge). Anus high on posterior end, which is raised and truncated

Living animal brownish with white spines of more or less uniform length, those on ventral surface with distinctly flattened spoon-like tips (spatulate).
taxon_text_3_1778:
Global: Widespread from northern Norway along European coast to  Mediterranean and Morocco, South Africa, Japan, New Zealand and Southern Australia.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Sodwana Bay.
taxon_text_4_1779: Found buried in clean sand at a depth of about 10-15 cm below the sand surface. Creates a mucus-lined respiratory channel down to the anterior end and this leaves a conical depression at the surface within which detrital material collects, thus revealing the location of the urchin. In Europe lifespan is thought to be about 10 years.
taxon_text_5_1780: Feeds on organic debris in the sand, which it sorts from the sand particles using elongated tubefeet at the anterior end.
taxon_text_6_1781: Sexes are separate and sperm and eggs are released into the water where they merge and form pelagic larvae. In European populations larvae have a duration of about 39 days.
taxon_text_7_1782: Replaced in deeper waters by the similar but smaller (50 mm) E. capense, which also has shorter spines and is deep purple when alive.
taxon_text_8_1783:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 236).

Filander, Z & Griffiths, C (2017). Illustrated guide to the echinoid (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) fauna of South Africa. Zootaxa, 4296(1), 1-72. (p. 60)

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 251).

Schultz, H (2010). Sea Urchins 1: A guide to worldwide shallow water species. Heinke and Peter Schultz Partner Scientific Publications. Hemdingen, Germany (p. 411).
taxon_text_1_1786: Test large and unusually thick and heavy, round when viewed from above, low hemispherical with a very flat bottom when viewed from the side. Mouth in center of underside and anus at hind margin. Entire test covered is uniformly short yellowish spines. The ampulacral grooves form five equal and symmetrical ‘petals’ extending from the four gonopores at the apex to the equator and then round to the mouth.
taxon_text_3_1788:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1789: Found in areas of course gravel, where it ploughs along just below the surface, leaving a distinct track, much like a golden mole. Common at certain sites, especially in False Bay.
taxon_text_5_1790: Feeds on organic debris in the sand, which it ingests along with copious amounts of sand.
taxon_text_6_1791: Details of reproductive cycle not known for this species, but in all echinoids sexes are separate and there are five gonads in each individual. Like almost all urchins this species is almost certainly a broadcast spawner with planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1792: The very heavy, flat-bottomed and circular test is unique among regional urchins and hence unlikely to be mistaken for any other species.
taxon_text_8_1793:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 236).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 244).

Filander, Z & Griffiths, C (2017). Illustrated guide to the echinoid (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) fauna of South Africa. Zootaxa, 4296(1), 1-72. (p. 49).
taxon_text_1_1796: Test hemispherical to fairly conical (taller than most regional species), pale grey to cream with paler radial bands where the tube feet occur (ambulacra). Areas between the bands of tube feet (interambulacra) with sparsely-distributed large tubercles (to which primary spines attach) and many more much smaller ones. Live animal with sparse white primary spines, each about 25% test diameter and dense mats of much smaller, darker secondary spines between.
taxon_text_3_1798:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1799: Not found intertidally and rarely extends inshore to depths as shallow as 10 m, where it is sometimes seen by divers. Becomes much more common in deeper waters, where it is frequently recorded in trawled samples.
taxon_text_5_1800: Not known and most commonly found in depths devoid of algae, so probably feeds on organic debris.
taxon_text_6_1801: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Like almost all urchins a broadcast spawner with planktonic larvae, but details of reproductive cycle not known for this species.
taxon_text_7_1802: Can co-occur and be confused with the Cape urchin, which occurs over much the same range, but mostly in shallower waters. However that species has a green test and live animals are usually bright red or purple (but sometimes pale) and have much more dense cover of more equal-length spines.
taxon_text_8_1803:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 236).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 236).

Filander, Z & Griffiths, C (2017). Illustrated guide to the echinoid (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) fauna of South Africa. Zootaxa, 4296(1), 1-72. (p. 40)

Schultz, H (2010). Sea Urchins 1: A guide to worldwide shallow water species. Heinke and Peter Schultz Partner Scientific Publications. Hemdingen, Germany (p. 188).
taxon_text_1_1806:
By far the most common urchin in shallow waters all along the Northern, Western and Eastern Cape coastline, where it is a dominant and iconic species. Dead test hemispherical, slightly pentagonal when viewed from above and usually a characteristic light-green in colour, sometimes with radial bands of darker grey-green or brown. Marked with regular rows of closely spaced tubercles.

Live animal very variable in colour, most commonly purple, red or orange, but sometimes green or pale grey. Spines short, dense fairly slender and pointed, mixed in length, but none of spines exceeding about 20% of disc diameter. When alive the five double bands of thick, elongate red tube feet are prominent and project beyond tips of spines.
taxon_text_3_1808:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KZN.
taxon_text_4_1809:
Very common from the intertidal to depths of about 100 m and often occurs in dense beds in intertidal pools and on shallow reefs. Known for their habit of covering themselves with dead shells or other pieces of debris as sunshades, probably to protect themselves from ultraviolet radiation.

Play various important role in the structure of the entire community. Firstly, they are important grazers, controlling the survival and hence density of kelps and other algae.  Secondly, juvenile abalone often shelter under to spines of these urchins, where they gain protection from predators. Thus, removal of urchins greatly increases the mortality rate of young abalone and has a negative effect on recruitment and ultimately on the fishery. Thirdly, urchins form an important component of the diets of rock-lobsters, reef fish and various invertebrate predators, such as helmet shells.

In other parts of the world urchins are commonly harvested as food, the roe or eggs being the only part consumed. Perhaps fortunately for this species, females do not grow  large enough to produce gonads of marketable size and a fishery based on this species has been deemed not economically viable!
taxon_text_5_1810: Feeds largely on algal debris which they grip with the tubefeet, but also on live seaweeds, including kelp sporelings. Thus play an important role in controlling the distribution and abundance of kelps and other algae.
taxon_text_6_1811: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Spawning takes place in spring and autumn with sperm and eggs being released into the water column, where fertilized eggs develop to planktonic larvae. When raised under laboratory conditions at 15 degrees Celsius these had a mean larval development time of 56 days, before settling onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_1812: Over much of the western part of its range this is the only common coastal urchin, so there are no other species for it to be confused with! The bright and variable colours and green test are also unusual features. In deeper waters largely replaced by Gilchrist’s urchin Echinus gilchristi, which has a taller, more conical test and two distinct spine types - sparse pale primary spines, between which are beds of much shorter secondary spines.
taxon_text_8_1813:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 234).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 237).

Filander, Z & Griffiths, C (2017). Illustrated guide to the echinoid (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) fauna of South Africa. Zootaxa, 4296(1), 1-72. (p. 42)

Schultz, H (2010). Sea Urchins 1: A guide to worldwide shallow water species. Heinke and Peter Schultz Partner Scientific Publications. Hemdingen, Germany (p. 196).
taxon_text_1_1826:
Large, well-known and iconic species frequently photographed by divers. Disc cream to grey and decorated with radiating rows of tubercles, each surrounded by a black ring (hence common name). The 10 elongate, slender, flexible arms are each banded in black and cream and bear regular lateral branches, which in turn are divided into ever-finer branches.

Specimens usually seen clinging to reef pinnacles, seafans or similar prominent perches, arms widely outstretched to intercept passing food particles.
taxon_text_3_1828:
Global: Endemic to South Africa (records from other regions considered unreliable).

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1829: A relatively uncommon species, but very large, striking and conspicuous and thus one of the best-known of all regional invertebrates. Depth range 11- 555 m and usually found with arms widely extended and perched prominently on reef pinnacles, or among other sedentary organism, especially seafans, with the arms facing into the current. When not feeding the arms are retracted and coiled.
taxon_text_5_1830: Arms held up into the water column and orientated towards the current to form a parabolid ‘basket’ to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Food may include relatively large organisms, such as jellyfish, crustaceans and polychaetes. Prey are grasped by the slender end branches of the arms and periodically each arm is coiled towards the mouth and the food particles removed by passing the arm through the comb-like oral papillae. The tube feet do not play a role in food transport, as in other brittle-stars.
taxon_text_6_1831: Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and basket stars are normally broadcast spawners that discharge eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Juveniles are sometimes found clinging to the adults, but this is simply because they form suitable substrata and is not an indication of brooding.
taxon_text_7_1832: Basket stars are unmistakable due to their branched arms and this species is by far the most common one seen by divers and is easily recognized by the white, black-ringed tubercles on the disc. There are, however, several other regional basket–star species, including the plain-coloured A. hirtus, which is confined to northern KwaZulu-Natal, and the pinkish brown to red Gorgonocephalus pustulatum, which occurs in deeper waters of 75-860 m.
taxon_text_8_1833:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 230).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 131).

Olbers, JM, Griffiths, CL, O'Hara, TD & Samyn, Y (2019). Field guide to the brittle and basket stars (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) of South Africa ABC Taxa, 19, 1–346 (p. 61).
taxon_text_1_1836:
Disc round and covered with granules, the radial shields large and oval. Arms fairly smooth, with only very short lateral spines. Most easily identified by its striking and attractive colour patterns, which make it a favorite with photographers!

Colour fairly variable, but disc cream to purplish-pink with irregular white blotches which may be diffuse or formed into clear bands. Arms strongly banded in broad white to pale-purple and red sections, these often being separated by thinner white or dark-brown rings.
taxon_text_3_1838:
Global: South Africa and Vema Seamount.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Kosi Bay.
taxon_text_4_1839: Usually found singly under boulders or on gravel or sand adjacent to rock.
taxon_text_5_1840: Presumed to feed on detrital particles on the sediment surface as arms are not held up into the water column. In most deposit feeding brittle stars the tube feet grasp prey items and compact them into balls, which are then transported along cilial tract on the underside of the arms to the central mouth.
taxon_text_6_1841: Not specifically know for this species. Some other local members of this family, such as Ophioderma wahlbergii, are brooders, but brooding has not been reported in this species, which is thus probably a broadcast spawner.
taxon_text_7_1842: The distinctive colour pattern and relatively smooth arms easily distinguish this species from others in the region, although there are other species with similarly banded arms occur in the more tropical waters of KwaZulu-Natal, such as O. gorgonia and Ophiodyscrita acosmeta.
taxon_text_8_1843:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 230).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 183).

Landschoff, J & Griffiths, CL (2015). Brooding behavior in the shallow‐water brittle star Ophioderma wahlbergii. Invertebrate biology, 134(2), 168-179.

Olbers, JM, Griffiths, CL, O'Hara, TD & Samyn, Y (2019). Field guide to the brittle and basket stars (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) of South Africa ABC Taxa, 19 1–346 (p. 145).
taxon_text_1_1846: Fairly large species with smooth, round body densely and uniformly covered with flat, round granules (radial shields not obvious). Arms thick and appear smooth, as arm spines are short and closely pressed to sides of arm. Colour normally uniformly black or dark brown, lighter ventrally, sometimes with lighter bars on arms.
taxon_text_3_1848:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Danger Point (Western Cape).
taxon_text_4_1849: Usually found under boulders or on gravel or sand adjacent to rock, where it can occur in large numbers, either in the open or partially hidden under rocky ledges, with some arms projecting into the open. Well known for its habit of brooding large young, the arms of which can sometimes be seen projecting from the genital slits on the ventral surface, on either side of the bases of the arms of females.
taxon_text_5_1850: Presumed to feed on detrital particles on the sediment surface as arms are not held up into the water column. In most deposit feeding brittle stars the tube feet grasp prey items and compact them into balls which are then transported along cilial tract on the underside of the arms to the central mouth.
taxon_text_6_1851: This species is well known for its brooding behaviour. Females become mature at a disc diameter of about 17 mm and reproductive activity occurs year-round, with about 50% of individuals sampled in each month brooding young. Brooding individuals contained an average of 7 and up to 33 developing young, early stage juveniles being more common than later stage ones, suggesting that mortality occurs during development. The young within the each brood pouch are of the same age, but clutches within different brood pouches within the same individual can hold young of different ages. The large size of brooded young and their orientation within the brood pouch suggest they obtain nutrition direct from the mother and are thus truly viviparous.
taxon_text_7_1852: The large size, black colour and smooth arms distinguish this species form most others in the region.
taxon_text_8_1853:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 230).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 182).

Olbers, JM, Griffiths, CL, O'Hara, TD & Samyn, Y (2019). Field guide to the brittle and basket stars (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) of South Africa.1 ABC Taxa, 19, 1–346 (p. 137).
<p>microCT image of adult female broodin: microCT image of adult female brooding 13 young in its brood pouches
<p>SEM image of brooded embryo extracted: SEM image of brooded embryo extracted from the broodpouch, total size 3-4 mm
taxon_text_1_1856:
Disc more of less pentagonal, dorsal surface covered in spines, smaller spinelets and stumps (often intermixed, but separately in var. triglochis), radial shields large and triangular, may be naked but covered in stumps (only in var. triglochis). Arms relatively short and fringed with long spines that project at right-angles and become progressively shorter towards tips of arms.

Colour extremely variable and often strikingly attractive. Common colours include combinations of greens, browns, purples, pinks, oranges and reds. The arms are often banded, have a central band of bright colour, or rows of dorsal spots.
taxon_text_3_1858:
Global: Widespread in European waters, Mediterranean, North Sea, North-East Atlantic, down the west coast of Africa and around South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Kosi Bay.
taxon_text_4_1859: Common from the intertidal to depths of about 350 m. Coastal specimens usually concealed under rocks,in kelp holdfasts, in gravel or other cryptic habitats. In deeper water may form large aggregations on reefs or soft substrata, all holding their arms up into the water current to intercept passing detritus.
taxon_text_5_1860: Solitary individuals normally act as scavengers picking up detrital particles on the sediment surface. In deeper waters the arms are held up into the water column to intercept passing particles in the water column. In most detritus feeding brittle stars the tube feet grasp prey items and compact them into balls, which are then transported along cilial tract on the underside of the arms to the central mouth, but this species is also reported to pass the food to the mouth by curling the arms.
taxon_text_6_1861: In Europe spawn once a year, the fertilized eggs developing into planktonic larvae that take about 3 weeks to develop before settling onto suitable habitats. Newly settled juveniles have a disc diameter of just 2 mm and only 2 segments per arm.
taxon_text_7_1862: The most common of several local species in this diverse genus. Differ from most other regional brittle stars by having very spinose dorsal surface to the disc. Most of the other regional species occur in the warmer waters of the east coast, but O. aristulata is also common in the Western Cape, although usually in deeper waters than O. fragilis.
taxon_text_8_1863:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 230).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 144).

Olbers, JM, Griffiths, CL, O'Hara, TD & Samyn, Y (2019). Field guide to the brittle and basket stars (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) of South Africa. ABC Taxa, 19, 1–346 (p. 284).
taxon_text_1_1866: Unmistakable. Very plump, short, bright-orange worm that tapers at both ends. Whole dorsal surface brush-like and covered with transverse rows of short, erect spines interspersed with short gills.
taxon_text_3_1868:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Inhaca Island in Southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1869: Common, but usually seen only singly, crawling sluggishly across the rock surface under boulders and on the shore. Scarcely moves when disturbed, other than to slightly curl the body. Often associated with sponges and the bright colour may reflect that of the sponges on which it feeds. Little else is known about the biology.
taxon_text_6_1871: Details unknown, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1872: Unlikely to be confused with any other regional species due to the unusual short, plump body and dense rows of spines covering the dorsal surface. Related to the fireworms of more tropical regions, but those are much larger, more elongate and active and are pale with marked lateral tufts of setae which are strongly irritant if touched (hence the common name).
taxon_text_8_1873:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 Errantia (p. 127).
taxon_text_1_1876: Large, robust, dark worm with a more or less quadrangular body of 25-40 segments. Dorsal surface smooth and shiny black, while parapodia bear tufts of strong white setae and bushy gills. Best recognized by their occurrence on floating objects and unique obligate association with goose barnacles.
taxon_text_3_1878:
Global: Widespread across N. Atlantic, Pacific, Indian Ocean, including Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Throughout region.
taxon_text_4_1879: A very unusual species that is found only associated with  floating objects that are heavily colonised by goose barnacles. May be found within the branchial chamber of the barnacles, but large individuals are observed crawling around among the barnacles, on which they are presumed to feed.
taxon_text_5_1880: Carnivorous, assumed to feed on the goose barnacles among which they live.
taxon_text_6_1881: This species is a hermaphrodite and is assumed to show direct development, since larvae have been found living in the intersegmental grooves of adults.
taxon_text_7_1882: Unlikely to be confused with any other species both because of its large size and unusual dark appearance, but mainly because of its unique habitat among goose barnacles on floating objects.
taxon_text_8_1883:
Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 Errantia (p. 122).

Moazzam, M & Moazzam, N (2019). Occurrence and abundance of commensal polychaete Hipponoe gaudichaudi Audouin and Milne Edwards, 1830 (family: Amphinomidae): an associate of goose barnacle Lepas (natifa) anserifera along Pakistan coast. International Journal of Biological Biotechnology, 16, 755-759.
taxon_text_1_1886: Well-known and extremely common species that builds large boulder-like reefs of coarse sandy tubes, each tube with a flared opening. Especially common in intertidal sites on the west coast, where the reefs form dominant features on the shore. The head bears a crown of short, dark-blue, un-branched feeding tentacles and a conspicuous double row of stiff, flat golden setae that are used to close off the entrance to the tube. The back half of the body is extremely thin and folded back under the anterior section, so that feces can be voided from the entrance to the tube!
taxon_text_2_1887: Body typically about 90 mm, and reach 110 mm; reefs can be 1 m or more across.
taxon_text_3_1888:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal (but recent genetic work shows specimens from the east coast probably need to be described as another new species).
taxon_text_4_1889: Use sand particles collected from the water column and mucus to construct large reefs of strong, sandy tubes. Each tube is blind-ended and has a flanged opening that concentrates food at the entrance. The reefs form important habitats that are colonised by a wide variety of other species. Predated upon by the Pustular triton Argobuccinum pustulosum, which secretes an acid saliva to dissolve the protective crown of bristles. Sometimes also gathered by fishers as bait. Considering its importance surprisingly little research has been conducted on this species.
taxon_text_5_1890: Suspension feeder, gathering fine organic materials from the water column.
taxon_text_6_1891: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1892: Replaced by the similar Idanthyrsus pennatus in northern KwaZulu-Natal. The extensive sandy reefs and golden bristles on the heads are distinctive. Icecream-cone worms Amphictece capensis have similar bristles, but are solitary and live in perfectly conical tubes buried vertically in sand.
taxon_text_8_1893:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2 (p. 673).

Day, JA (1969). Feeding of the cymatiid gastropod, Argobuccinum argus, in relation to the structure of the proboscis and secretions of the proboscis gland. American Zoologist, 9(3), 909-916.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_1896: Largish worm normally found singly or in loose groups. Lives within a hard, rough-textured calcareous tube firmly cemented to the rock face by its one side. The tube is usually oval in cross-section and often curved (but not coiled, as in some related species). The head bears two eyes and two flattish, semicircular crowns of feathery feeding appendages. These are usually red, orange, purple or pink, with white banding. There is also a distinctive funnel-shaped operculum, which closes off the opening when the worm withdraws. The operculum has distinctive crimped ridges all around its margin.
taxon_text_2_1897: Body length can reach 200 mm, but typically 60-80 mm.
taxon_text_3_1898:
Global: Widespread across European seaboard of Atlantic Ocean and  the Indo-Pacific including Australia and New Zealand, as well as South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1899:
Fairly large and spectacular species usually seen singly or in small groups extending from rockfaces on shallow reefs, to which the tube is firmly cemented. Also sometimes under boulders. The fan of tentacles functions both as a feeding and respiratory organ. The tube is secreted by glands on the thoracic segments and shaped by a collar just behind the head.

Where common the tubes can act as substratum for a variety of other smaller invertebrates and significantly alter community structure.
taxon_text_5_1900: Filter feeder, removing fine particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_1901: Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. In the UK spawning takes place in Summer (June to September) and the larvae spend about two months in the plankton before settling. The worms mature after about 10 months and live for several years.
taxon_text_7_1902: Many other serpulid worms are found in the region and all construct calcareous tubes and have crowns of feeding tentacles. The Red fanworm Protula bispiralis is similar in size and occurs in the same habitat, but lacks an operculum. It also has elongate, spiral, rather than flat, fans and these are uniformly red.
taxon_text_8_1903:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Chapman, ND, Moore, CG, Harries, DB & Lyndon, AR (2012). The community associated with biogenic reefs formed by the polychaete, Serpula vermicularis. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 92(4), 679-685.

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2 (p. 809).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 78).
taxon_text_1_1906: Very large, well-known, firm-bodied and active worm with an iridescent blue-brown sheen and often a white bar across the 5th body segment. Head with rounded palps and five finger-like antennae. Next two segments lack lateral appendages (parapodia), but possess a pair of short dorsal tentacular cirri. Feathery gills start to arise from lateral appendages from about segment 8 backwards.
taxon_text_2_1907: Body length typically about 200 mm, but can be much larger.
taxon_text_3_1908:
Global: Widespread across North Atlantic, Caribbean, Indian Ocean, Red Sea, New Zealand, South Africa, etc.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1909: The largest regional polychaete and indeed the largest in the world (if it is believed that all worms bearing this name belong to the same species), the longest recorded specimen being neatly 3 m in length! Live in mucus-lined tubes excavated in sand and gravel between boulders. Sought after as bait and excavation by bait collectors causes considerable damage to the restricted habitats where these worms live. Possess formidable jaws and can inflict a painful bite.
taxon_text_5_1910: Voracious carnivores, pouncing on passing prey from within the burrow and dragging the victims back underground. Documented feeding on fish in other regions, but this not observed locally to our knowledge.
taxon_text_6_1911: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate. Eggs have been observed lining the burrows, but it is assumed these develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1912:
The extremely large size, distinctive colour pattern and habits of this species are fairly distinctive, but it is very unlikely that the populations around the world that carry this name all indeed represent the same species. There are also several regional species in the genus.

Marphya species are similar, but smaller and they lack the tentacular cirri on segments 2-3.
taxon_text_8_1913:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part1 Errantia (p. 389).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 76).

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_1916: Fairly large, firm-bodied, cylindrical worm with a smoothly-rounded head that lacks eyes or any appendages. Body segments have only very short, stubby appendages and lack gills. Under microscopic examination the setae on the first few limbs end in a distinct hooded hook (see refs below for illustrations). Body colour reddish-brown, with a distinct iridescent sheen.
taxon_text_3_1918:
Global: Appears to be widely distributed across North Atlantic, Mediterranean, Caribbean, Red Sea, Southern Africa, etc., but in reality there may be several species subsumed under this one name.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1919: Usually found on rocky shores creeping among seaweeds, burrowing in course sand or under boulders.
taxon_text_5_1920: Very little known about biology of this family, with some species being described as carnivorous on small invertebrates and others as selective deposit feeders.
taxon_text_6_1921: Little is known about reproduction in this species or indeed family. Probably spawn eggs and sperm into the water where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1922:
There are several similar brown, smooth-bodied, earthworm-like species in this genus which are easily confused, but the rounded head is a good generic identification feature. The Pudding worms Arabella iricolor and Scoletoma cf. tetraura (previously Lumbrineris tetraura) have a similar body shape and colour, but have pointed conical heads, that in Arabella also bearing four tiny eyes at its base.

Also recent studies by Simon et al. (2021) suggest that the species up till now known as Scoletoma tetraura may in fact represent more than one species, neither of which are the true S. tetraura!
taxon_text_8_1923:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part1 Errantia (p. 436).

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_1926: Fairly large, firm-bodied, cylindrical worm. The head is distinctive, as it has a pair of small black eyes and a pair of broadly-rounded semicircular palps, above which are three fairly short, finger-like antennae. The first two segments lack limbs and the remaining segments do not bear gills. Body colour reddish-brown, often with pale spot-like markings.
taxon_text_3_1928:
Global: Previously thought to be endemic to southern Africa, but recently reported from Phillipines and Pakistan. Also apparently accidentally introduced to western Mediterranean (assuming these identifications are correct!).

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1929: Usually found on rocky shores among seaweeds or Redbait (Pyura stolonifera), but also burrowing in course sand or among coral or limestone debris.
taxon_text_6_1931: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate. Assumed to spawn eggs and sperm into the water where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1932: One of a number of similar large, round worms with groups of antennae projecting forwards from the head, but can be distinguished by the combination of having three antennae (unlike the five in Marphysa and Eunice spp.) and by the absence of gills on the body segments (these being large and conspicuous in most other related genera).
taxon_text_8_1933:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part1 Errantia (p. 402).

Díaz, A & López, E (2020). Four New Records of Eunicidae (Annelida: Polychaeta) from the Western Philippines Islands. Thalassas: An International Journal of Marine Sciences, 36(2), 321-332.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_1946: Very large, well-known worm that digs deep U-shaped burrows in estuaries, lagoons and sheltered sandy beaches. Body tough and cylindrical, dark brown to black with a rough, round, balloon-like proboscis that can be inflated or withdrawn. Anterior section of the body with tufts of setae and branched red gills on each segment. Thinner tail section lacking gills or obvious setae.
taxon_text_2_1947: Body length typically about 200 mm, but can exceed 500 mm long.
taxon_text_3_1948:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_1949: Digs deep U-shaped burrows in fine sediments in sheltered sites. The head end of the burrow is visible as a funnel-like depression and the tail end as a small cone. Water is drawn though the burrow by peristaltic movements of the worm’s body and this action both oxygenates the sediment and pulls in detrital particles, which accumulate in a feeding zone around the head of the animal. Here the water movement and bacterial action help decomposes the detritus, making it more digestible.
taxon_text_6_1951: Eggs and sperm are released into the water and develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1952: A second smaller species, Gilchrist’s bloodworm Abarenicola gilchristi also occurs in the same region and the ridges on each segment are more widely separated ventrally.
taxon_text_8_1953:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Simon, CA, Kara, J, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2020). Genetic structure of bloodworm, Arenicola loveni (Annelida; Arenicolidae) suggests risk of local extinction in the face of overexploitation is lower than expected. African Zoology, 55(2), 175-183.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_1956: Members of this genus are very spectacular and unusual worms, easily identified to genus level by their triangular body segments, very long and coiled dorsal cirri and the elongate, thin, and coiled pharynx, which is thought to be used to pierce pieces of food. Local specimens are usually pink to yellow with distinctive groups of small black lines on the dorsal surfaces of each segment.
taxon_text_3_1958:
Global: North East Atlantic, Mediterranean, South Africa, Madagascar, Australia, Japan.

Local/Regional: About Saldanha to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_1959: Very distinctive and attractive, but rarely seen, species that is always a thrill to find and photograph. Usually found singly, crawling actively and rapidly under boulders, or on surfaces of rocks on pools. Also found in kelp holdfasts. The elongate dorsal cirri and extremely mobile and are alternately rolled up tightly and then extended, particularly when the worm is disturbed.
taxon_text_5_1960: Some species in the genus have been observed feeding on sponges.
taxon_text_6_1961: Not known locally, but in North American species sexes are separate and specialised reproductive individuals develop that have large eyes and posterior segments filled with gametes. Eggs are laid in gelatinous masses, which are brooded by the females and develop into crawling juveniles without any free-living larval stages.
taxon_text_7_1962: Unmistakable to genus level, but species within the genus are poorly defined. The World Register of Marine Species currently recognises 10 species, but several of these are widespread and probably represent species complexes. Recent studies (see reference below) have shown considerable morphological and genetic differences between specimens from different sites, but unfortunately no South African material was included in these studies. Pending further work, we thus use the currently-applied name but this may change in the future.
taxon_text_8_1963:
Aguado, MT, Capa, M, Lago-Barcia, D, Gil, J, Pleijel, F & Nygren, A (2019). Species delimitation in Amblyosyllis (Annelida, Syllidae).PloS one, 14(4), e0214211.

Branch, G & Branch M (1981). The Living shores of southern Africa. C. Struik Publishers Cape Town (p. 169, pl. 50).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London Part 1 (p. 259).

Pernet, B (1998). Benthic egg masses and larval development of Amblyosyllis speciosa (Polychaeta: Syllidae). Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 78(4), 1369-1372.
taxon_text_1_1966:
Fairly broad-bodied, elongate-oval worm with the dorsal surface completely covered by 15 pairs of large, off-white, overlapping scales, each of which bears a gray centre and a broad, grey, crescent-shaped marginal marking.

Also easily recognized by its habit of living commensally in the burrows of Sand prawns Kraussillichirus kraussi.
taxon_text_3_1968:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1969: A locally endemic species found only at a few sites in the southwestern Cape and associated mostly with the burrows of sand prawns, within which it lives commensally. Most commonly seen when accidentally discarded on the sand surface by anglers who are collecting sand prawns using a prawn–pump. Little else is known about its biology.
taxon_text_5_1970: Carnivorous, feeding on small invertebrates buried in the sediment.
taxon_text_6_1971: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1972: Scaleworms are easily recognized as a group due to the flat dorsal scales that cover all, or much, of the body. This species is unusual in that the scales are white and the worm is found on sandy substrata and is associated with sand-prawn burrows (most scaleworms are free-living and the majority live on hard substrata).
taxon_text_8_1973:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1953). The polychaet fauna of South Africa. Part 2. Errant species from Cape shores and estuaries. Annals of the Natal Museum, 12(3), 397-441.

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History) , London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 58).
taxon_text_1_1666: Uniformly bright orange-red above and paler orange below. Arms tapering from a fairly-broad base, each semicircular in cross-section, the upper surface convex and the lower surface flat. Surface texture resembles small overlapping tiles.
taxon_text_3_1668:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_1669: Fairly common intertidal species extending to depths of about 80 m. Despite being commonly observed, little else is known about biology.
taxon_text_5_1670: Feeds both on detritus and on a variety of benthic invertebrates including sea-fans, bryozoans and corals. Frequently observed feeding on colonial sea squirts.
taxon_text_6_1671: Sexes are separate and (being echinoderms) there are five gonads in each individual! Sperm and eggs are released into the water column and develop into planktonic larvae. Spawning is temperature induced, and we have repeatedly observed males starting to spawn when water temperatures reach >20°C. This probably induces spawning in females.
taxon_text_7_1672: The closely-related Beautiful starfish C. formosa is similar in size and shape and found in much the same habitat, but differs in colour, the base colour varying from yellow to purple or grey and this is ornamented with orange or yellow spots, which tend to increase in size towards the tips of the arms. Sometimes also confused with the Reticulated starfish Henricia ornata, which is the same colour and occupies the same habitats, but has much more slender, cylindrical arms that barely taper and also has a characteristic  irregular honeycombed texture.
taxon_text_8_1673:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 226).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 79).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 176)
taxon_text_1_1616: Tiny, inconspicuous, plain white to pale grey species that is easily missed, or assumed to be a juvenile, but is in fact extremely common. Disc round, its upper surface covered in overlapping rings of scales. Radial shields D-shaped and abut one another along their full length. Arms relatively short, thin and fragile with obvious but fairly-short laterally projecting spines. Despite the tiny size broods live young.
taxon_text_3_1618:
Global: Extremely widespread across Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans, Mediterranean, Red Sea, etc. (in fact represents a species complex with separate forms in various different regions).

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1619: Very common from the intertidal to depths of about 2000 m. Coastal specimens usually among gravel or course sand, or under rocks. Known to be luminescent but the function of this is not well understood.
taxon_text_5_1620: Feeds on small detrital particles picked up from the sediment surface and passed to the mouth by the tube feet.
taxon_text_6_1621: Hermaphroditic and despite its small body size broods the young. Analysis of scanned specimens from South Africa showed an A. squamata to contain 6 developing embryos, which together made up about 24% of the disc volume.  This was much more than in a specimen of the other, much larger, brooding species - Ophioderma wahlbergii, where 13 brooded young together made up only 14% of disc volume. The young lie with the mouth upwards and pressed against the body wall of the mother and their large size can only be explained by the fact that they obtain nutrition directly from the mother.
taxon_text_7_1622: The small adult size, plain colour and appressed radial shields distinguish this species from other common coastal brittlestars in the region. A second similar species A. strata is also found in deeper waters but microscopic examination is needed to distinguish these species (see Olbers reference below for details of how to do this).
taxon_text_8_1623:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 232).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 151).

Landschoff, J & Griffiths, CL (2015). Three-dimensional visualisation of brooding behaviour in two distantly related brittle stars from South African waters. African Journal of Marine Science, 37(4), 533-541.

Olbers, JM, Griffiths, CL, O'Hara, TD & Samyn, Y (2019). Field guide to the brittle and basket stars (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) of South Africa. ABC Taxa, 19, 1–346 (p. 217).
<p>microCT scan - brooding adult virtual: microCT scan - brooding adult virtually opened from the oral side, brooded juveniles in brood pouches
<p>microCT scan - brooding adult with su: microCT scan - brooding adult with surface set to transparent, brooded juveniles visualized in colour
<p>microCT scan - brooded juveniles insi: microCT scan - brooded juveniles inside the adult
taxon_text_9_1935: Previously incorrectly identified as Marphysa sanguinea  (which remains a valid, but not South African species) and then described as a new, local species M. elityeni, but this has now been combined with M. haemasoma on the basis of genetic evidence.
taxon_text_1_1936: Large, dark-red worm with distinctly flattened body. Head with two swollen semicircular palps and five pale finger-like antennae with darker tips. Mouthparts, if everted, with large strongly-toothed jaws. Anterior limbs without gills, but those on most of body with large red gills, each with six long finger-like branches (first gill and last 13 have only one branch).
taxon_text_2_1937: Body length about 300 mm, can reach 470 mm.
taxon_text_3_1938:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Probably Namibia to about East London, but Namibian samples were not included in the recent genetic studies and may turn out to represent yet another species. Confirmed distribution Saldanha to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1939: A large species typically found burrowing in gravel in boulder fields in the low intertidal, where they can be quite common. Sought after as bait.
taxon_text_6_1941: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate. Some other Marphysa species lay eggs in gelatinous egg sacs. Larval development is almost certainly planktonic.
taxon_text_7_1942: Several other Marphysa species are found in the region and are distinguished mostly by microscopic details of the setae and gill filaments. All are described in detail in the paper by Kara et al. cited below. Can also be confused with the Giant wonderworm Eunice aphroditois which occurs in the same habitat, but Eunice have a pair of tentacular cirri on the first body segment that are absent in Marphysa.
taxon_text_8_1943:
Branch G, Griffiths CL, Branch M, Beckley L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, part1 Errantia (p. 396).

Lewis, C & Karageorgopoulos, P (2008). A new species of Marphysa (Eunicidae) from the western Cape of South Africa. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 88(2), 277-287.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_1746: This species has only 10 rather slender arms that are held curved over the body. On the upper surface of the body the ambulacral grooves converge on the mouth, which is situated centrally, whereas the anus (situated on a conical process) occupies an off-centre position. On the underside there 35-40 fairly-slender attachment cirri. Colour is extremely variable, but most commonly brownish-yellow, sometimes with striped pinnules.
taxon_text_3_1748:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_1749: Found in low intertidal pools and under rocks and overhangs, but most abundant on shallow reefs to a depth af about 26 m, where it can occur in the open in dense and extensive beds, often mixed with the similar-looking Common feather-star Comanthus wahlbergii, with which it is often confused (see below). Like most feather stars capable of swimming using a slow, graceful up and down movement of the arms if displaced from the reef. As the group name suggests, the arms are brittle and easily broken, but are quickly regenerated. Individuals with some shorter arms, or a reduced number of arms, are thus regularly encountered.
taxon_text_5_1750: The arms are extended upwards into the water column to intercept floating plankton of other organic particles. Each pinnule is lined with tubefeet, which are held erect to form a mesh.  The tubefeet grasp passing particles and pass them to an ambulacral groove running along the length of the arm, along which cilia propel a string of mucus and food particles to the mouth, which is situated on the upper surface of the central disc. A fairly simple U-shaped gut fills most of the small body and ends in an anus that is raised on a cone close to the mouth and also on the upper surface.
taxon_text_6_1751: Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and the gonads are located in the swollen basal pinnules, rather than in the small body itself. When the gametes are mature the pinnules rupture and release the eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Newly settled larvae are stalked (like many fossil crinoids), but the stalk is lost as they enter the adult stage.
taxon_text_7_1752: Easily confused with the Common feather-star Comanthus wahlbergii but usually has fewer arms (10 vs 10-22 but usually 16-20). That species has the mouth off-centre and the anal cone in the centre of the upper body surface. The two species are most easily distinguished by the markedly different number of ventral cirri, which number 12-25 in C. wahlbertii, but 35-40 in A. occidentalis. In practice though, very few photographers turn specimens over and count their cirri, so the identity of species in many published images is suspect! It would be a valuable study to compare the distribution patterns of these two species and to determine their relative abundances, size ranges and habitat preferences (and to record the range and proportions of various arm numbers and colour forms in each species).
taxon_text_8_1753:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 228).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 20).
taxon_text_1_1816:
Test large, white and smoothly oval (without frontal notch) with slightly-extended posterior end, upper surface with five regularly-arranges petals that are encircled within a distinct smooth oval ring. Underside slightly convex, mouth slightly forward of centre, anus on underside but on slightly-extended posterior bulge.

Live animal covered on very short, more or less uniform spines, those within dorsal ring darker.
taxon_text_3_1818:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz to about Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_1819:
Found buried in clean sand at a depth of about 10-15 cm below the sand surface. Creates a mucus-lined respiratory channel down to the anterior end and this leaves a conical depression at the surface within which detrital material collects, thus revealing the location of the urchin.

Sea Change Project researchers have recently discovered several symbiotic species that appear to live only in association with these urchins, these including a small bivalve now newly described as Brachiomya ducentiunus, as well as a scale-worm Malmgreniella sp. and a lysiannasid amphipod, which also both appear to be undescribed species!
taxon_text_5_1820: Feeds on organic debris in the sand, which it sorts from the sand particles using its tube feet.
taxon_text_6_1821: Sexes are separate and sperm and eggs are released into the water where they merge and form pelagic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1822: Could be confused with Spatangus capensis, which is another large heart urchin that is common in the same region. That species however is restricted to deeper waters of about 37-500 m depth and has a distinct anterior notch in the test.
taxon_text_8_1823:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 236).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 250).

Filander, Z & Griffiths, C (2017). Illustrated guide to the echinoid (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) fauna of South Africa. Zootaxa, 4296(1), 1-72. (p. 62)

Schultz, H (2010). Sea Urchins 1: A guide to worldwide shallow water species. Heinke and Peter Schultz Partner Scientific Publications. Hemdingen, Germany (p. 403).
taxon_text_1_1676: Fairly large and normally has between 8 and 10 arms, but as it often reproduces by division (‘fissipary’), only some of these are fully developed, while others remain greatly reduced. Colour mottled mauve and purple, body and arms covered in pointed spines.
taxon_text_2_1677: Diameter typically about up to about 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_1678:
Global: Mostly known from Australia and New Zealand and not reported in earlier books on South African echinoderms, but is now quite common in False Bay, to which it might have been accidentally introduced in recent decades.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_1679: Quite commonly seen intertidally and on shallow reefs in the southwestern Cape and very distinctive due to its many-armed body and the unequal length of the arms.
taxon_text_5_1680: Thought to feed on a variety of invertebrates, particularly mussels, by extruding the stomach though the mouth and plastering it over the prey. The diet of this species has not been studied in South Africa though and we have repeatedly seen and documented it taking other echinoderms.
taxon_text_6_1681: Sexes are separate and although sexual reproduction certainly occurs, with sperm and eggs being released to form planktonic larvae, this species appear to reproduce mainly by division (‘fissipary’). Adults tear themselves into two and then each half regenerates a set of replacement arms, but overall arm number can still vary considerably. Australian populations have between 7 and 14 arms and intertidal specimens and those with more food available tended to divide more often, while deeper water ones and those with less food tended to opt for sexual reproduction.
taxon_text_7_1682: Unlikely to be mistaken for any other species, but is similar in colour and texture to the larger five-armed Spiny starfish Marthasterias africana.
taxon_text_8_1683:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 226).

Crump, RG & Barker, MF (1985). Sexual and asexual reproduction in geographically separated populations of the fissiparous asteroid Coscinasterias calamaria (Gray). Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 88(2), 109-127.

Waters, J & Roy, M (2003). Global phylogeography of the fissiparous sea-star genus Coscinasterias. Marine Biology, 142(1), 185-191.
taxon_text_1_1976: Fairly large, firm-bodied, cylindrical worm with a bluntly-pointed head that has four small black eyes at its base; head otherwise without any appendages. Body segments have only very short, stubby limbs with few setae and lacking gills. Body colour bronze, with a distinct iridescent sheen.
taxon_text_3_1978:
Global: Appears to be widely distributed across North Atlantic, Mediterranean, Caribbean, Indian Ocean, Southern Africa, Philippines, New Zealand, etc., but in reality there may be several species subsumed under this one name.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1979: Usually found on rocky shores inundates with gravel and shell debris, into which it burrows.
taxon_text_5_1980: Very little known about biology of this family, with some species being described as carnivorous on small invertebrates and others as selective deposit feeders.
taxon_text_6_1981: Little is know about reproduction in this species or indeed family. Probably spawn eggs and sperm into the water, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_1982: There are several similar brown, smooth-bodied, earthworm-like species with which this could easily be confused, but the pointed head and four dark eyes are good identification features. The Pudding worm Scoletoma tetraura (previously Lumbrineris tetraura) has a similar body shape and colour, but lacks eyes, while Lumbreneris coccinea has a smoothly rounded, ball-like head, also without eyes.
taxon_text_8_1983:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 446).
taxon_text_1_1986: Probably the most unique and remarkable of all regional worms. Lives permanently in a papery tube that is open at both ends and is either embedded in a crevice between rocks, or in soft substrata. The body is divided into several very distinct sections – the first 9 segments are flattened and have lateral appendages; there follows a ring–like structure with long terminal horns and then three segments that each bear large semicircular paddles. Behind this the posterior segments each have large, branched, white parapodia that serve as gills.
taxon_text_2_1987: Body length typically about 80 mm, but can be much larger.
taxon_text_3_1988:
Global: Supposedly cosmopolitan, but recent molecular work suggests that several distinct regional species are in fact subsumed under this one name.

Local/Regional: Angola to about East London.
taxon_text_4_1989:
An extraordinary and unmistakable species with a remarkable method of filter-feeding. The wing-like appendages on segment 10 secrete a mucous net that is extended backwards into a bag by the pumping action of the three paddle-like appendages behind it. As water passes through this net fine organic particles are trapped by it. Sections of the mucous bag are then cut off and passed forwards to the mouth to be eaten!

Apart from this amazing feeding mechanism, Chaetopterus worms also frequently host commensal species within their tubes. On a global basis these include a number of scaleworm species, many species of crab and even a nudibranch that is reputed to feed on the mucous net. This species is also well known for exhibiting strong bioluminescence. The function of this is unknown, since the worms do not posses light-detecting organs and spend their entire lives buried inside their tubes!
taxon_text_5_1990: Filter feeder, collecting fine particulate material from the water pumped though the tube by filtering it though a mucous net.
taxon_text_6_1991: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. The larvae are renowned for the long periods they spend in the plankton (up to a year in some genera in the family).
taxon_text_7_1992:
Unlikely to be confused with any other species, although the single name currently applied to specimens from around the globe is almost certainly incorrect and several distinct regional species probably exist.

Other much smaller (<20 mm), more slender members of this family also occur commonly along the subtropical east coast, where they live in groups of small sandy tubes, often among zoanthids.
taxon_text_8_1993:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2 (p. 529).

Mirza, JD, Migotto, AE, Yampolsky, IV, de Moraes, GV, Tsarkova, AS & Oliveira, AG (2020).Chaetopterus variopedatus bioluminescence: a review of light emission within a species complex. Photochemistry and photobiology, 96(4), 768-778.
taxon_text_1_1996: Distinctive, long, slender, cylindrical, bright-green worm with a small, rounded head bearing obvious circular eyes and five short antennae – a median one and two on each side. Easily identified by the unique large, oval, leaf-like dorsal lobes projecting from each segmental limb. If extended the proboscis is large, conical and covered externally in small papillae.
taxon_text_3_1998:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa (a published record from New Zealand is considered unlikely to represent the same species).

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to about Plettenberg Bay.
taxon_text_4_1999: Uncommon, but easily recognised. Typically found crawling around under rocks in the intertidal. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_6_2001: Little is know about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and production of a mucous bag of eggs has been reported in other species in this genus.
taxon_text_7_2002: Easily recognised to genus level by the large lobes on the segmental limbs and to species by body colour and leaf-like shape of these lobes. There are, however, several other species in this genus in the region that differ in body colour and shape of the lobes on the limbs.
taxon_text_8_2003:
Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 Errantia (p. 154).

Olive, PJW (1975). Reproductive biology of Eulalia viridis (Müller) (Polychaeta: Phyllodocidae) in the north eastern UK. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 55(2), 313-326.
taxon_text_1_2006: Elongate, cylindrical worm strongly tapering at both ends and with particularly narrow tail. The head is very distinctive and consists of a narrow, elongated, annulated cone made up of successively smaller rings and tipped by two pairs of tiny tentacles. When disturbed (or when attacking prey) an enormous cylindrical proboscis is shot out of the mouth and this ends in four formidable, sharply-pointed jaws. The segmental limbs (parapodia) are smallish, but distinct and each has a single tubular gill on its dorsal surface. Body colour transparent white, suffused with pink.
taxon_text_2_2007: Body length typically about 60 mm, but up to 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_2008:
Global: Widespread across Europe, including Mediterranean, Caribbean, Red Sea and Southern Africa, also across Indo-Pacific.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2009: Fairly large, active worm that burrows in sandbanks and feed on benthic invertebrates. Lashes about vigorously when disturbed and may also extend and retract the enormous proboscis. The jaws of glycerids are associated with venom glands and some larger species can inflict painful bites!
