taxon_text_5_2010: Carnivorous, feeding on other worms and smaller crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_2011: Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2012: The small, elongated, conical head and enormous toothed proboscis and very characteristic making it unlikely that this species would be confused with any other regional polychaete. Along the east coast a second similar species G. subaenea also occurs and this has a tuft of five, rather than one, gill filament dorsally on each lateral limb. There are also several other less common regional species.
taxon_text_8_2013:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 (p. 360).

von Reumont, BM, Campbell, LI, Richter, S, Hering, L, Sykes, D, Hetmank, J., et al. & Bleidorn, C (2014). A polychaete’s powerful punch: venom gland transcriptomics of Glycera reveals a complex cocktail of toxin homologs. Genome Biology and Evolution, 6(9), 2406-2423.
taxon_text_1_2016: Fairly short, broad-bodied and parallel-sided worm with the dorsal surface completely covered by 12 pairs of large, brown, overlapping scales, the posterior section of each of which is covered in blunt, conical tubercles.
taxon_text_3_2018:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to about Durban.
taxon_text_4_2019: Common species, found usually singly under boulders or amongst other invertebrates, kelp holdfasts and the like. Occurs from the mid intertidal  downwards.
taxon_text_6_2021: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2022: Scaleworms are easily recognised as a group due to the flat dorsal scales that cover all or much of the body, but there are more than 50 species in the region and many of these are hard to distinguish from each other. Useful clues to species identification include number of pairs of scales, and whether these cover the whole, or only the front half of the body, as well as scale colour and ornamentation.  A second very similar species, L. durbanensis is found along the east coast, but this has spherical rather than conical tubercles on the scales.
taxon_text_8_2023:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 85).
taxon_text_9_2025: Platynereis dumerilii (which is a valid species, but occurs in the Mediterranean).
taxon_text_1_2026:
Firm, cylindrical worm with a tapering body that is typically light green or brown with a luminescent chain-like pattern of white markings along the back. Typical of this group, the head has dark eye-spots, a pair of small frontal antennae, a pair of swollen palps with tiny, nipple-like tips and four pairs of elongate tentacular cirri. The everted proboscis ends in a pair of strong jaws and has characteristic comb like rows of small teeth, after which the common name is derived.

Its habit of secreting a transparent tube that binds together fronds of seaweed is also fairly characteristic and a useful clue to identification.
taxon_text_3_2028:
Global: Angola, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to about Kidds Beach in Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2029: Very common worm in intertidal algal beds, where it secretes soft, flexible, transparent tubes of mucus and sand that are used to bind together the fronds of various seaweeds. Previously misidentified as P. dumerilii, which is a European species, and only described as a native Southern African species in 2020.
taxon_text_6_2031:
Sexes are separate. The northern hemisphere species (and probably also the local species) show mass spawning events tied to the phases of the moon. In preparation for this, the bodies of the worms become transformed into a specialised reproductive form that has enlarged eyes and large paddle-like parapodia. These individuals then leave their tubes on specific nights and swim up into the water column, where they perform a nuptial dance, their bodies burst to release the sperm and eggs and then they die.

After fertilization the eggs develop into planktonic larvae which do not feed but subsist on maternal yolk provided in the eggs. Larval life is short at about 3 days (in the European species) and the worms then settle as tiny 3-segmented forms that progressively develop new segments at their posterior ends.
taxon_text_7_2032: There are many similar species in the region and positive identification of these requires microscopic examination of the everted pharynx and of the gills and setae on the parapodia. However, the white band along the back and habit of cementing algal fronds together are fairly reliable field identification features for this species.
taxon_text_8_2033:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Kara, J, Santos, CS, Macdonald, AH & Simon, CA (2020). Resolving the taxonomic identities and genetic structure of two cryptic Platynereis Kinberg species from South Africa. Invertebrate Systematics, 34(6), 618-636.

Özpolat, BD, Randel, N, Williams, EA, Bezares-Calderón, LA, Andreatta, G, Balavoine, G, et al. & Handberg-Thorsager, M (2021). The Nereid on the rise: Platynereis as a model system. EvoDevo, 12(1), 1-22.
taxon_text_1_2036: Elongate, slender scaleworm in which only the front half of the body bears scales, while the segments of the back half are naked and brown. The scales are characteristically each half chocolate-brown and half pale pink.
taxon_text_3_2038:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2039: Uncommon species usually seen singly, crawling under boulders or amongst other invertebrates, kelp holdfasts and the like.
taxon_text_6_2041: Little is know about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2042:
Scaleworms are easily recognised as a group, due to the flat dorsal scales that cover all or much of the body, but there are more than 50 species in the region and many of these are hard to distinguish at species level. Useful clues to species identification include number of pairs of scales, and whether these cover the whole, or only the front half of the body, as well as scale colour and ornamentation.

This genus is unusual in that the body is very elongate and only the front half of the segments bear scales. A second similar species P. scolopendrina occurs in the same region, but in that species the scales are rough and speckled with grey.
taxon_text_8_2043:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 55).
taxon_text_1_2046: Elongate, slender scaleworm in which only the segments of the front half of the body bears scales, while the segments of the back half are naked and brown. The scales are characteristically each speckled with grey.
taxon_text_3_2048:
Global: Widespread across Europe, North Atlantic, Adriatic and Red Sea. Also Southern Africa (intuitively it seems doubtful S. African specimens truly represent the northern hemisphere species).

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2049: Uncommon species usually seen singly, crawling under boulders or amongst other invertebrates, kelp holdfasts and the like.
taxon_text_6_2051: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2052:
Scaleworms are easily recognised as a group, due to the flat dorsal scales that cover all or much of the body, but there are more than 50 species in the region and many of these are hard to distinguish at species level. Useful clues to species identification include number of pairs of scales, and whether these cover the whole, or only the front half of the body, as well as scale colour and ornamentation.

This genus is unusual in that the body is very elongate and only the front half of the segments bear scales. A second similar species P. erythrotaenia occurs in the same region, but in that species the scales are each half pale and half chocolate-brown.
taxon_text_8_2053:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 55).
taxon_text_9_2055: Previously incorrectly identified as P. variegata (which is a valid species, but occurs in Chile).
taxon_text_1_2056:
Robust, firm, cylindrical worm that is typically iridescent brown or dark green in colour. Typical of members of this family the head has two pairs of small, dark eyes, two short tentacles, a pair of swollen palps each topped by a tiny nipple-like segment, and behind these 4 pairs of tentacle-like cirri. The segmental limbs (parapodia) are lobed and armed with two tufts of firm bristles.

There are numerous regional species in the group that can only really be definitively identified by everting the pharynx and examining the patterns of teeth on its surface (see cited references below as to how to do this), and by detailed examination of the setae and gills on the parapodia. This species is fairly distinctive though, due to its unusually large size and the fact that it is so abundant in mussel beds and Cape reefworm (Gunnarea gaimardi) colonies.
taxon_text_3_2058:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2059:
Large, active worm that is very common among mussels, reefworm colonies, kelp holdfasts and similar habitats, where it can reach considerable densities. When the pharynx is everted this bears a pair of formidable jaws terminally.

Commonly exploited as bait by fishers.
taxon_text_5_2060: Omnivorous, feeding on other worms and smaller crustaceans, but also consuming seaweeds.
taxon_text_6_2061: Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2062: There are many similar species in the region and accurate identification of these requires microscopic examination of the everted pharynx and of the gills and setae on the parapodia. However, most related species are much smaller and more slender and hence large, robust worms (>50 mm), especially those found among mussels and reef-worm colonise, can fairly reliably be assigned to this species.
taxon_text_8_2063:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1. (p. 331).

Kara, J, Macdonald, AH & Simon CA (2018). Integrative taxonomic methods reveal an incorrect synonymisation of the South African Pseudonereis podocirra (Schmarda) as the widespread Pseudonereis variegata (Grube) from Chile. Invertebrate Systematics, 32(6), 1282-1297.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
taxon_text_1_2066:
As a group syllid species are fairly easy to recognise, as mostly they are long, thin worms with unusual elongate, annulated cirri projecting from each segment.

In this species the head bears a single median and a pair of lateral annulated antennae. Each of the body segment also has a pair of long cirri that emerge from the dorsal sides of the parapodia, each with about 30 annulations. It also has a fairly characteristic colour pattern with broken brown bars dorsally across each of the anterior body segments. Note though that photographs from other regions show different colour patterns, suggesting that there are in fact different species in different regions, all bearing this same name!
taxon_text_3_2068:
Global: Widespread across Europe, Mediterranean, North Atlantic, Caribbean, and Indo-Pacific, including New Zealand and Australia (probably several species subsumed under this one name).

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2069: Found on weed covered rocky shores from mid-shore downwards; also under boulders. Relatively uncommon and usually seen individually or in small groups sheltering in crevices.
taxon_text_5_2070: Details unknown for this species, but other syllids are reported to feed on either algae of sedentary invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_2071: Members of this family are famous for their diversity of reproductive strategies. Some species have a specialised pelagic phase in the lifecycle which swims off the bottom and release the eggs and sperm into the plankton. Others bud-off baby individuals (stolons) which detach from the parent and swim away to establish themselves at another site. Another variation is to develop a single reproductive stolon, which has enlarged appendages and swims off in to the plankton, where is bursts and dies.
taxon_text_7_2072: The family contains about 60 regional species and many of these are difficult to distinguish without microscopic examination of the setae on the parapodia and shape and number of annulations of the cirri.
taxon_text_8_2073:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 (p. 248 ).

Simon, C, San Martín, G & Robinson, G (2014). Two new species of Syllis (Polychaeta: Syllidae) from South Africa, one of them viviparous, with remarks on larval development and vivipary. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 94(4), 729-746.
taxon_text_1_2076: Very small, delicate species that forms aggregations of long, thin, white calcareous tubes in sheltered sites, such as the undersides of boulders or in sheltered gullies or caves. The masses of tubes sometimes radiate outwards into a circular pattern, but may also intertwine and grow upwards into lacy reefs. There is usually no operculum present and the head bears two lobes each with four feather-like tentacles. These may be orange to bright red and are rapidly withdrawn at the slightest disturbance.
taxon_text_2_2077: Body length typically about 5 mm, tubes 1mm or less in diameter.
taxon_text_3_2078:
Global: Widespread in Europe, also Mediterranean, Gulf of Mexico, Red Sea, India, New Zealand, Australia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: About Port Nolloth to East London.
taxon_text_4_2079: Small but attractive species forming delicate lace-like masses and with red tentacles that contrast markedly with the white tubes. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_2080: Filter feeder, removing fine particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_2081: Sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are also released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. The species is also known to reproduce by transverse fission as well as by bud forming.
taxon_text_7_2082: Many other serpulid worms are found in the region and all construct calcareous tubes and have crowns of feeding tentacles. The very thin and delicate intertwined colonies formed by this species are fairly characteristic though.
taxon_text_8_2083:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 817).

Faulkner, GH (1930) The anatomy and the histology of bud-formation in the Serpulid Filograna implexa, together with some cytological observations on the nuclei of the neoblasts. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 37(251), 109-190.
taxon_text_1_2106: Forms tough, transparent tubes and lives in colonial masses among kelps holdfasts, redbait or similar sedentary reef organisms. When extended, the crown forms two cup-like arcs of feathery appendages. Unusually, there are distinct rows of small eyes along the outer surfaces of these appendages. Colour generally uniform dull yellow, brown or green.
taxon_text_2_2107: Crown about 10 mm across, colonies may be 100 mm or more in diameter.
taxon_text_3_2108:
Global: Previously though to be widespread across Europe, Mediterranean, Canada, Caribbean, Arctic, North Pacific and Southern Africa, but several of these populations have now been described as separate species. The South Africa population is also probably incorrectly named and the true P. reniformis is likely a European species. Until this is resolved we retain the current name though.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2109: A distinctive species and one of the only regional fanworms to live in large colonial masses. The openings of the flexible tubes roll up when the animals retract, probably as a mechanism to protect from predators. The eyes are an unusual feature and also aid in predator evasion.
taxon_text_5_2110: Filter feeder, removing particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_2111: A variety of modes of reproduction occur in this group and most species can reproduce both asexually by ‘budding’ off smaller individuals, and sexually. In this species asexual reproduction is common and thought to be an important factor in the formation of the colonies. The posterior part of the animal breaks into 2-4 fragments and these generate either both posterior and anterior, or just anterior, ends - depending on their original position. Sexual reproduction certainly also occurs with eggs and sperm being released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2112: There are several other related fanworms in the region, but this species is easily recognised by its colonial habits, by the flexible plastic-like texture of the tubes, the spoon-like shape of the branchial crown and the characteristic eyes on the external surface of the feeding appendages.
taxon_text_8_2113:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 764).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 76).

Knight-Jones, P, Darbyshire, T, Petersen, ME & Tovar-Hernández, MA (2017). What is Pseudopotamilla reniformis (Sabellidae)? Comparisons of populations from Britain, Iceland and Canada with comments on Eudistylia and Schizobranchia. Zootaxa, 4254(2), 201-220.
taxon_text_1_2116: Long, slender worm that lives within a smooth, stiff tube that projects vertically upwards out of the sand. When feeding, the head is extended from the tube and opens to reveal a single circular, daisy-like crown of long, feathery tentacles. Body usually dull orange or purple with inconspicuous parapodia. Tentacles pale and attractively banded in concentric rings of reds, brown, or purple spots.
taxon_text_2_2117: Tubes projects up to about 100 mm from sand, worm up to 200 mm long, crown up to 30 mm across.
taxon_text_3_2118:
Global: Widespread across Europe including Mediterranean, as well as in temperate South Africa (this population may eventually turn out to be a genetically distinct species though).

Local/Regional: About Saldanha Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_2119: A large and conspicuous worm found singly or in small groups in sandy areas, often close to or among rocks. The conspicuous tubes project vertically from the sand and the worms retract rapidly into their tubes at the slightest disturbance.
taxon_text_5_2120: Filter feeder, removing particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles. The particles are sorted by the mouthparts and fine ones are eaten, medium ones used for constructing the tube and larger ones are rejected. Filtration rate in this species has been measured at 73 ml per hour.
taxon_text_6_2121: A variety of modes of reproduction occur in this group and most species can reproduce both asexually by ‘budding’ off smaller individuals, and sexually. Sexes are usually separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2122: Members of this family characteristically have soft parchment tubes and circular crowns of tentacles and several species are common in the region. This species is fairly easily recognised by its long size, thin, vertical tubes and single, flat circle of tentacles. The Feather-duster worm Pseudobranchiomma longa is also common in the region, but is a much fatter worm usually found projecting from crevices in rock and not sand and has two uniformly-coloured spiral crowns of tentacles.
taxon_text_8_2123:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 763).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 78).

Murray, JM, Watson, GJ, Giangrande, A, Bentley, MG & Farrell, P (2011). Reproductive biology and population ecology of the marine fan worm Sabella pavonina (Savigny)(Polychaeta: Sabellidae). Invertebrate Reproduction and Development, 55(3), 183-196.
taxon_text_1_2126: Very common and well-known species that builds large, flattish reefs of interwoven blue tubes and extends upwards into the mid-intertidal of rocky shores. The opening to each tube usually has a characteristic overhanging lip and the head bears two curved heads of feathery feeding appendages (the ‘radiolar crown’), which are usually attractively mottled in whites, blues and browns. An operculum is also present and is used to plug the opening of the tube when the worm withdraws. In this species the operculum is round and cup-shaped and bears a characteristic pair of wing–like projections.
taxon_text_2_2127: Body length typically about 15 mm and tube diameter about 2 mm.
taxon_text_3_2128:
Global: As currently defined this is a very widespread species found across the North Atlantic and Indo-Pacific, but recent studies have shown that it is in fact a species complex and several genetically-distinct species are involved. The original description was from South Africa though, so the local form is correctly named, although it will likely emerge that it is restricted to the region and forms found elsewhere in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific will need to be renamed.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2129: A very common and characteristic species of the mid to low intertidal of exposed rocky shores, where it constructs extensive flat reefs of hard bluish calcareous tubes. When underwater the mottled crowns of tentacles are extended to filter-feed and when disturbed these are rapidly withdrawn and the openings closed by the operculum. The reefs created by this worm provide habitat for a variety of other species.
taxon_text_5_2130: Filter feeder, removing fine particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_2131: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2132: Although many other serpulid worms are found in the region and all construct calcareous tubes and have crowns of feeding tentacles, the large blue reefs formed by this species and its typically mid intertidal and exposed habitat make it fairly easy to identify in the field.
taxon_text_8_2133:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 800).

Simon, CA, van Niekerk, HH, Burghardt, I, ten Hove, HA & Kupriyanova, EK (2019) Not out of Africa: Spirobranchus kraussii (Baird, 1865) is not a global fouling and invasive serpulid of Indo-Pacific origin. Aquatic Invasions, 14(2): 221–249.
taxon_text_1_2136: Slender worm with a sharply pointed, conical head that lacks any appendages. The body is divided into two distinct sections. The front 18-24 segments are firm and flattened and the limbs take the form of low, setose ridges running down the sides of each segment. The posterior segments are softer and more fragile and are cylindrical. The limbs are also longer and project dorsally, giving the worm the ‘wooly’ appearance referred to in the common name. If the mouthparts are everted they take the form of a fleshy cone.
taxon_text_3_2138:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_2139: Do not construct tubes, but burrow in sheltered beaches and sandbanks, especially in lagoons and estuaries, where they are often one of the dominant organisms, reaching densities of thousands per square meter.
taxon_text_5_2140: Presumed to be deposit feeders consuming organic matter from the sediments.
taxon_text_6_2141: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2142: There are several very similar regional species in this genus, but this is by far the most common. The pointed, conical head and division of the body into two regions with different types of limbs are fairly diagnostic identification features.
taxon_text_8_2143:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 543).
taxon_text_1_2146:
Members of the family Spionidae are fairy easily recognized, as they have a characteristic pair of elongated, grooved palps extending from the otherwise fairly featureless pointed or rounded head. Otherwise most are small and slender.

This species has a pointed head that lacks any other appendages other than the elongated palps. The fifth segment is not swollen or otherwise modified and there are simple strap-like gills on the parapodia from segment 2 backwards. It is the most abundant worm on sandy beaches in sandy pools and in lagoonal areas, where it can attain very high densities.
taxon_text_3_2148:
Global: Widely distributed on both sides of the Atlantic, including  the Mediteranean and Caribbean and around South Africa to Mozambique and Madagascar.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2149: Live in mucus-reinforced sandy vertical burrows excavated in sand. Sometimes these tubes are so abundant that the surface layer of sand is fused into a crust perforated by numerous holes. The palps are extended from the opening of the tube and can be used to gather food from the water column, or from the sediment surface.
taxon_text_5_2150: Feed on either suspended particles or those on the sediment surface. Examination of gut contents (in Northern hemisphere populations) showed the food to include organic and inorganic sediment particles, faecal pellets of other animals and a variety or larvae and small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_2151: In the UK breeds from March to July, releasing sperm and eggs into the water column. These develop into planktonic larval with a duration of about five weeks. Growth is rapid and the worm has a short lifespan of about a year.
taxon_text_7_2152: Fairly easily recognised to group because of the long, grooved palps (although similar palps do also occur in a few other families). There are over 40 regional species in the family though and these require detailed microscopic examination to identify to species level. However, this species is by far the most common member of the group to be found on regional sandy beaches and mixed shores.
taxon_text_8_2153:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Dauer, DM (1983). Functional morphology and feeding behavior of Scolelepis squamata (Polychaeta: Spionidae). Marine Biology, 77(3), 279-285.

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 485).
taxon_text_1_2156: Unmistakable species that builds a perfect, elongate cone-shaped tube composed of neatly-arranged brick-like sections of sponge spicule. The worm itself is soft, tapering and fairly transparent and its most distinctive feature is an arc of stiff golden bristles on the head that can be used to close-off the wide, open end of the tube.
taxon_text_3_2158:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2159: Lives buried in soft sediments, with the head and wider end of the tube pointing vertically downwards and the narrow posterior end sometimes projecting from the sediment surface. The stiff bristles on the head are used for burrowing. Sediment is gathered by tentacles on the head and sorted, material unsuitable for ingestion being passed between the body and the tube and out through the narrow upper opening in the form of pseudofaeces.
taxon_text_5_2160: Deposit feeders. Ingesting fine organic materials from the sediments.
taxon_text_6_2161: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. These develop a larval tube while still in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2162: The unusual tapering tube and golden bristles on the heads of members of this family are distinctive. A second related species, Lagis neopolitana, also occurs in the same region, but makes its tube out of larger irregular sand grains. Cape Reefworms Gunnarea gaimardi have similar bristles on their heads, but live colonially in large reef-like colonies of course sandy tubes.
taxon_text_8_2163:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 663).

Hutchings, P & Peart, R (2002). A review of the genera of Pectinariidae (Polychaeta) together with a description of the Australian fauna. Records-Australian Museum, 54(1), 99-127.
taxon_text_1_2166: Fairly large orange worm with a bluntly-rounded head. Numerous soft, red, grooved feeding tentacles arise from body segments 3-4 and then elongate orange gills (easily confused with the tentacles) emerge all along the body from each of the remaining segments.
taxon_text_3_2168:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa

Local/Regional: Angola to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2169: Large and spectacular species, easily recognised to genus level by the trailing orange gills and red tentacles that emerge from the sides of the body. Lives buried in sediments, or in the spaces between mussels or other sedentary invertebrates, with only the gills and cirri showing as a tangle of threads on the surface.
taxon_text_5_2170: Detritus feeder, collecting fine particulate material from the sediment surface with the sticky feeding tentacles and pulling these back to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_2171: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2172: Several other related species found in the region, of which the most common is C. tentaculata. This differs from C. capensis by having a pointed head, tentacles on segments 5-7 rather than 3-4 and by having red rather than orange gills.
taxon_text_8_2173:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 517).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 76).
taxon_text_1_2176: Small, jet-black worm that characteristically burrows into encrusting coralline algae, forming colonies of regularly–spaced individuals. Only the first few segments of each worm project and are visible. The head is bluntly rounded and bears a pair of elongate, grooved palps and behind this each of the first 4 body segments bears a pair of long, thin, thread-like, black gills.
taxon_text_3_2178:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_2179: Very characteristic species both in terms of the unusual jet black colour and the specialised habitat of burrowing into plates of thick coralline algae. Very common in this habitat, both intertidally and on shallow reefs. The palps are extended to gather food particles from the passing water and the gills project from the burrow for gas exchange.
taxon_text_6_2181:
Most species in this group can reproduce both asexually and sexually.

This species is well known to expand its colonies by fragmenting asexually into anterior and posterior halves, each of which then regenerates its missing portions. All individuals appear to fragment before later undergoing sexual reproduction as adults. At that point eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. They take about two years to reach sexual maturity.
taxon_text_7_2182: Unlikely to be confused with other local species, although a second introduced species D. fewkesi has been found in Cape Town harbour. That species is also black, but constructs its own characteristic hemispherical masses of coralline tubes, rather than burrowing into coralline algae.
taxon_text_8_2183:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 502).

Gibson, PH (1977). Reproduction in the cirratulid polychaetes Dodecaceria concharum and D. pulchra. Journal of Zoology, 182(1), 89-102.
taxon_text_1_2186: Unusual species in which the soft, flabby body is enclosed in a pale green mucus sheath. The parapodia (segmental limbs) are poorly developed, but long, simple bristles project from each segment. The head is retracted between the anterior segments and is enclosed within a forward-projecting ‘cage’ of elongate bristles.
taxon_text_3_2188:
Global: Currently thought to be widespread across both coasts of North Atlantic, Arctic, Mediterranean, North Pacific, New Zealand and South Africa. In reality though, there are probably distinct species in various regions and indeed 5 new species previously thought to be F. affinis have recently been recognised from Japan and described under new names.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2189: Has a characteristic caterpillar-like crawling motion, keeping the body more less linear as it creeps forward. Commonly found crawling around under boulders and in silty areas, where it feeds on detritus.
taxon_text_5_2190: Detritus feeders, picking up organic material with frilly palps on the head.
taxon_text_6_2191: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2192: Unlikely to be confused with any other species due to the unusual mucus sheath surrounding the body and creeping mode of locomotion. Some other regional forms, such as Pherusa spp. have even more marked cages of elongate setae around the head, but they are stiffer in texture and more sedentary and have a strongly-tapering body covered in wart-like papillae.
taxon_text_8_2193:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 655).

Jimi, N, Hasegawa, N, Taru, M, Oya, Y, Kohtsuka, H, Tsuchida, S, et al. & Woo, SP (2022). Five New Species of Flabelligera (Flabelligeridae: Annelida) from Japan. Species Diversity, 27(1): 101-111.
taxon_text_1_2196: Longish, soft, flesh-coloured worm better known for its unusual branching tube than for the appearance of the worm itself. The head bears a tuft of long, thin tentacles and segments 2-4 bear branching red gills. The remainder of the worm is soft and flesh-coloured (often red patch ventrally) with short pad-like appendages on the thoracic segments. The tube is long and straight and made of course sand grains and shell fragments cemented together with mucous. It can project several centimeters above the sediment and terminates in an expanded tree-like crown of stiff branches that support the feeding appendages.
taxon_text_3_2198:
Global: Widespread across Europe including Mediterranean, as well as Gulf of Mexico, Mauritius, Red Sea, Mozambique and South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_2199: Lives buried in soft sediments with the top of the tube protruding into the water column. The branched, tree-like extensions around the opening of the tube support the feeding tentacles as these reach out to grasp food particles on the water column, or on the sediment surface. Can occur in dense aggregations, in which case they can change the structure of the surrounding sediments and create habitat for a variety of other species. The distinctively branched tubes are often cast ashore after storms.
taxon_text_5_2200: Filter or deposit feeder, removing particulate material from the water column passing overhead, or from the sediment surface.
taxon_text_6_2201: In this family sexes are usually separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. Larvae in European populations of this species spend about two months in the plankton before settling.
taxon_text_7_2202: Many similar species of terebellid worms, most of which have soft bodies, long tentacles and red gills, occur in the region. This species is best recognised by its unique tube.
taxon_text_8_2203:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 743).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 78).

Rabaut, M, Guilini, K, Van Hoey, G, Vincx, M & Degraer, S (2007). A bio-engineered soft-bottom environment: the impact of Lanice conchilega on the benthic species-specific densities and community structure. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 75(4), 525-536.
taxon_text_1_2206:
Tangle worms, or spaghetti worms, as they are sometimes also known, of this family are easy to recognize as a group, as the head bears a tangle of multiple, elongate, sticky, grooved tentacles (correctly termed palps) that are extended from the burrow to gather food. Behind the palps are tufts of gills, which are usually bright red, but may be unbranched, or branched in tree-like fashion (dendritic). The body is soft, floppy and tapering and generally enclosed within a fragile, sandy tube. The segmental appendages (parapodia) are normally short ridges and are devoid of gills.

The group is very diverse, with over 40 regional species and these are hard to identify to species level, especially as the gills and tentacles have a tendency to break off if the worm is handled! This species is characterised by having three pairs of branched, red, tree-like gills and by the fact that the body and tube are coiled like a cork-screw.
taxon_text_3_2208:
Global: Widespread across Indo-Pacific, also USA, Caribbean and Mediterranean (several species may be included under this one name).

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2209: Construct fragile, coiled mucus tubes of sand and shell particles, usually attached to the sides of boulders buried in sand, on the undersides of rocks in sandy pools. The worm remains in the tube and extends the feeding palps (tentacles) in all directions to collect organic particles. These are not transported back to the mouth along ciliated grooves (as in fanworms for example), but rather the tentacles themselves are periodically withdrawn and food particles licked off them by the mouth.
taxon_text_5_2210: Detritus feeder, extending the tentacles to gather fine organic material from of the sediment surface, or from the water passing overhead.
taxon_text_6_2211: Not known for local populations, but in the USA spawn in summer in response to lunar rhythms. Eggs and sperm are released into the water column and larvae have a planktonic duration of about one month, then reach maturity after only two months from settling. Lifespan is about one year indicating that this is an opportunistic, fast-reproducing species.
taxon_text_7_2212:
Easy to identify to group, but there are many genera and species that can only be distinguished by microscopic examination.

This species is best recognised by the twisted, corkscrew-like body and presence of three pairs of branched gills. Species of the genera Nicolea and Terebella are also common, but there are only two pairs of gills present in these genera.
taxon_text_8_2213:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 658 onwards).

Salazar-Vallejo, SI (2014). Revision of Pherusa Oken, 1807 (Polychaeta: Flabelligeridae). Zootaxa, 3886(1), 1-61.
taxon_text_1_2216:
Very elongated with many whorls (hence the common name screw-shell), each whorl bearing a pair of ridges running up its centre (sometimes 3-5 ridges in lower whorls). Aperture small, operculum horny and with concentric rings. Colour usually brownish-grey, sometimes purplish, with paler flames.

Also readily recognized by its unusual habit of burying head-down in sandbanks, often occurring in large numbers in sheltered sites.
taxon_text_3_2218:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape border to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2219: Very common in sheltered sandbanks, particularly in sites such as in Langebaan Lagoon, Saldanha Bay, False Bay and Knysna Estuary, where it can occur in many hundreds per square meter. Lives completely buried head-down into the sediment. Two channels through the sand communicate with the surface and water is drawn down one of these to the gills, which filter out fine particles and transport these in a string of mucus to the mouth, where the mucus string is raked in by the delicate radula. Wastewater is then expelled up the other channel back to the surface.
taxon_text_5_2220: Filter feeder, filtering water though the gills and transporting captured particles to the mouth along with a string of mucus.
taxon_text_6_2221: In this family sexes are separate and fertilisation is internal. Females generally lay clusters of egg capsules attached to small stones, each capsule containing 6-20 eggs. These usually hatch within one week and develop as pelagic larvae, although in some species eggs only emerge as crawling larvae. Details of reproductive mode are not know for local species.
taxon_text_7_2222: One of several screw-shells on the region, which can be distinguished by habitat, as well as shell structure. The Threaded screw-shell T. carinifera grows to a larger size (48mm), has a single spiral ridge running up each whorl and occurs singly among encrusting organisms attached to rocks. The Mottled screw-shell T. sanguinea has rounded whorls with many fine parallel ridges and is marked with reddish-brown streaks. It is much larger, up to 106 mm and buries in sand in deeper areas. The Zebra screw-shell T. declivis can be abundant in deeper sediments, reaches 100 mm and has dark brown bands around each whorl.
taxon_text_8_2223:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 52).
taxon_text_1_2226:
Very elongated with many whorls (hence the common name screw-shell), each whorl bearing a single sharp central keel up its centre. Colour white of pale brown.

Also unusual among turritellids in that is occurs on rocks shores, rather than burrowing in sand and is usually found embedded within encrusting sponges, ascidians and bryozoans under rocks.
taxon_text_2_2227: Up to 110 mm in length, but usually about 70 mm.
taxon_text_3_2228:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Western Cape to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2229: Usually found among encrusting organisms on the undersides of boulders or in crevices in the rocks and often completely fused into position. Sometimes the shells are distorted, and two or more individuals may become fused together as ‘Siamese twins’ (see image below).
taxon_text_5_2230: Filter-feeder, filtering water though the gills and transporting captured particles to the mouth along with a string of mucus.
taxon_text_6_2231: In this family sexes are separate and fertilisation is internal. Females generally lay clusters of egg capsules attached to small stones, each capsule containing 6-20 eggs. These usually hatch within one week and develop as pelagic larvae, although in some species eggs only emerge as crawling larvae. Details of reproductive mode are not known for local species.
taxon_text_7_2232: One of several screw-shells on the region, which can be distinguished by habitat, as well as shell structure. In this species the single sharp spiral ridge running round the centre of each whorl is diagnostic. Also other screw shell live buried in sand, whereas this species is associated with rocks.
taxon_text_8_2233:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 53).
taxon_text_1_2236: Very elongated with many whorls (hence the common name screw-shell). The whorls are flat-sided, such that the shell forms a smoothly-tapering cylinder coming to a sharp point. Aperture small, operculum horny and with concentric rings. Colour white with a distinctive wide, brown band running up the centre of each whorl.
taxon_text_2_2237: Large, reaching up to 120 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2238:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2239: A large and attractive species found buried in sediments in somewhat deeper waters, where it can reach great densities. Particularly common on the Agulhas Bank, where sometimes a dominant part of benthic biomass. Like other screw shells probably lives completely buried head-down into the sediment. Two channels through the sand communicate with the surface and water is drawn down one of these to the gills, which filter out fine particles and transport these in a string of mucus to the mouth, where the mucus string is raked in by the delicate radula. Wastewater is then expelled up the other channel back to the surface.
taxon_text_5_2240: Filter feeder, filtering water though the gills and transporting captured particles to the mouth along with a string of mucus.
taxon_text_6_2241: In this family sexes are separate and fertilisation is internal. Females generally lay clusters of egg capsules attached to small stones, each capsule containing 6-20 eggs. These usually hatch within one week and develop as pelagic larvae, although in some species eggs only emerge as crawling larvae. Details of reproductive mode are not known for local species.
taxon_text_7_2242:
One of several screw-shells on the region, which can be distinguished by habitat, as well as shell structure. The Waxy screw shell T. capensis is much smaller (33 mm), has two spiral ridges running around each whorl and occurs in sheltered sandy from the intertidal downwards. The Threaded screw-shell T. carinifera grows to a larger size (48 mm), has a single spiral ridge running up each whorl and occurs singly among encrusting organisms attached to rocks. The Mottled screw-shell T. sanguinea has rounded whorls with many fine parallel ridges and is marked with reddish-brown streaks. It is much larger, up to 106 mm and buries in sand in deeper areas.

Australian specimens referred to in earlier papers under this name have now been removed to another separate species (T. capiva).
taxon_text_8_2243:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182)

Herbert, DG (2013). Turritella declivis Adams & Reeve, in Reeve, 1849 (Mollusca: Gastropoda)–a South African not an Australian species, and a characteristic component of the Agulhas Bank benthos. African Zoology, 48(2), 412-417.

Herbert, DG & Jones, GJ (2018). Phylum Mollusca In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Offshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 249-320 (p. 274 as Fucinus ocelliferus).
taxon_text_1_2246:
Shell much smaller than body, robust and limpet-like and with an oval hole at its apex, through which the exhalant siphon projects. Shell saddle-shaped when viewed from the side (such that it rocks from end to end when placed on a flat surface) and with fine radiating riblets and concentric growth lines. Colour usually red.

Animal much larger than shell, which simply perches on its back. Head is not projected into an elongate narrow snout (as in the similar Dentrofissurella), but is rounded. Numerous large frilly branching projections around margin of shell. A pair of long red tentacles extend forward. Body colour generally yellow to orange or red.
taxon_text_2_2247: Shell up to 30 mm in length, expanded animal up to 60 mm.
taxon_text_3_2248:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_2249: Uncommon species, usually seen singly under boulders, particularly in sandy areas. Little is known about its biology, as previously confused with Dendrofissurella scutellum.
taxon_text_6_2251: Reproduction in this species has not been studied, but members of this family normally have separate sexes (some change sex from male to female with age). Eggs may be laid within thin gelatinous masses or in spherical gelatinous capsules. The young then hatch as late-stage planktonic larvae, or in some species at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2252:
Long confused with the Saddled keyhole limpet Dentrofissurella scutellum and has a similar laterally curved shell, but the soft parts are quite different and lack the elongated trunk-like head of that species. Also has far more, and larger, frilly papillae around the margins of the shell and foot.

Since the species was described in a somewhat obscure American museum journal and the live animal was not depicted in that paper, the correct identification of this species has eluded regional researchers for decades and, although quite often seen, it is has not been featured in any of the regional field guides. Indeed we believe this to be the first identified image of a live specimen to be published. Hopefully now that the live animal is known and can be recognized, more information about the distribution and biology of this species can be gathered.

Could also be confused with the smaller keyhole limpet Fissurella mutabilis, but in that species the shell is flat and not saddle-shaped and almost completely covers the animal.
taxon_text_8_2253: McLean, JH & Kilburn, RN (1986). Propodial elaboration in Southern African and Indian Ocean Fissurellidae (Mollusca: Prosobranchia) with descriptions of two new genera and one new species. Contributions in Science, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 379: 1-12.
taxon_text_1_2256:
Shell much smaller than body, robust and limpet-like and with an oval hole at its apex, through which the exhalant siphon projects. Shell saddle-shaped when viewed from the side (such that it rocks from end to end when placed on a flat surface) and with fine radiating riblets and concentric growth lines. Colour variable, including cream, pink or brown, may be plain or with radiating rays of darker colour, sometimes attractively marbled.

Animal much larger than shell, which simply perches on its back. Head projects into an elongate narrow snout with side branches and bears a pair of elongate tentacles at base. A few frilly, branching projections around margin of shell but these modest in number and size. Colour variable, often plain black or dark brown, but can be cream or pale pink (larger, darker, west coast and smaller, more mottled, south coast forms are recognized as separate subspecies).
taxon_text_2_2257: Shell up to 40 mm in length, expanded animal up to 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_2258:
Global: Angola to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to central KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2259: Common species, seldom seen in the open, but abundant under boulders, particularly in sandy areas. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_2260: Herbivorous, feeding on algae, notably the commercially important Gracilaria.
taxon_text_6_2261: Reproduction in this species has not been studied, but members of this family normally have separate sexes (some change sex from male to female with age). Eggs may be laid within thin gelatinous masses or in spherical gelatinous capsules. The young then hatch as late stage planktonic larvae, or in some species at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2262:
Genetic studies may well show that the two recognized subspecies on the west and south coasts, which show various morphological differences, are in fact distinct species. Often confused with the similar Amblychilepas platyactis, which is similar in overall size and body form and also has a saddle-shaped shell, but that species lacks the elongated forward-directed head and has many more and longer papillae around the margins of the shell. It is also usually red or pink in colour.

Can also be confused with the smaller keyhole limpet Fissurella mutabilis, but in that species the shell is flat and not saddle-shaped and almost completely covers the animal.
taxon_text_8_2263:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 172)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 35).

McLean, JH & Kilburn, RN (1986). Propodial elaboration in Southern African and Indian Ocean Fissurellidae (Mollusca: Prosobranchia) with descriptions of two new genera and one new species. Contributions in Science, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 379, 1-12.
taxon_text_1_2266: Shell flattened and limpet-like with an elongated ‘keyhole-shaped’ (with slight lateral notches midway) apical aperture. Outer surface ornamented with radiating threads and very variable in colour, usually pinkish, reddish-brown or brown, sometimes blue with red to purple margin, can be uniformly coloured or ornamented with radiating rays or concentric zig-zag patterns. Interior white. Shell almost completely covers the animal.
taxon_text_3_2268:
Global: Namibia and South Africa (records in older papers from Mozambique and Madagascar considered suspect).

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2269: Common species, seldom seen in the open, but often extremely abundant under boulders, extending upwards into the mid-intertidal.
taxon_text_6_2271: Reproduction in this species has not been studied, but members of this family normally have separate sexes (some change sex from male to female with age). Eggs may be laid within thin gelatinous masses or in spherical gelatinous capsules. The young then hatch as late-stage planktonic larvae, or in some species at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2272: Replaced in KwaZulu-Natal by the larger, thicker-shelled F. natalensis which usually has a light to dark brown shell with well-marked radiating ribs and darker rays. Could be confused with Saddled keyhole-limpet Dendrofissurella scutellum, but in that species the body is much larger than the shell and extends well beyond its margins.
taxon_text_8_2273:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 172)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 36).
taxon_text_1_2276: Very large and well-known abalone species with heavy, oval, depressed shell, enormous aperture and row of about 8-11 small respiratory openings. Exterior surface usually mottled brick-red, bearing marked rows of strong, irregular corrugations that are orientated parallel to the growing edge, which is markedly convex (distinguishing it from the smaller, smoother H. spadicea). Interior of shell shiny mother–of-pearl. In live animals the sides of the foot are densely covered by distinctive branched, fleshy tentacles.
taxon_text_2_2277: Up to 190 mm shell length and 3 kg in mass.
taxon_text_3_2278:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to southern Kwazulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2279:
Very well-known species which is an iconic feature of shallow reefs in the region and is of great economic significance, previously as a wild fishery and now as an aquaculture crop.

Juveniles occur mostly under boulders in the intertidal and move down-shore as they grow. Small individuals lack the shell corrugation typical of adults and instead show fine spiral ridges. They often also develop attractive colour banding in the shell due to changes in the diet over time. Growth is slow, with sexual maturity being reached only after 8-10 years and the minimum legal collections size (when fishing of the wild stock was still permitted) of 114 mm only after about 13 years. The shell becomes thicker and more elevated with age and old animals can attain a wet weight of up to 3 kg and probably survive in excess of 30 years.

In former times abalone occurred in vast numbers on rocky reefs from about low tide to 20 m depth and formed the basis of a large and profitable fishery that reached a peak in 1965, when 2800 tonnes were harvested. Overexploitation and ‘mining’ of the stock, which had accumulated over many decades, plus uncontrolled illegal harvesting, have subsequently led to a collapse of the wild fishery, which was closed in 2008.

The wild fishery has now been replaced by a flourishing aquaculture industry, which propagates abalone from selected brood stock under controlled culture conditions in land-based tank facilities, where they are fed on either wild-harvested or cultured seaweeds, or on artificial pellet feeds. The animals grow faster and are sold at much smaller sizes than wild caught abalone, marked size being at a length of about 100 mm, which is attained after 5 years. Almost the entire production is exported to the Far-East and South Africa is now a leading global producer of abalone outside of Asia.

Apart from their economic value, abalone play, or at least used to play, various ecological roles kelp bed systems in the region. Despite their enormous abundance prior to human exploitation they were less important as grazers than might be thought, since they feed largely on drift rather than live algae. Juveniles also form prey for a variety of natural predators, including large reef fish (although these too are now greatly depleted) and octopus. The surfaces of their shells also provide habitat for numerous algae, as well as many sedentary and burrowing invertebrates.
taxon_text_5_2280: Herbivorous, unselective feeders consuming a variety of living algae, which are rasped off the rocks with the powerful radula, but also largely on drift algae, which are captured by raising the head and clapping it down on passing food items.
taxon_text_6_2281: Abalone have separate sexes and are broadcast spawners. Eggs and sperm are released through the holes in the shell and develop into planktonic larvae that have a larval duration of 5-7 days and settle preferentially on coralline algae. Growth under wild conditions is slow and sexual maturity is only reached at a length of about 85 mm, which equates to an age of 8-10 years.
taxon_text_7_2282: Could be confused with the smaller and less common Siffie H. spadicea, but this lacks the raised corrugations on the shell and has a concave, not convex, growing edge to the shell; the live animal also shows its bright green mantle visible thought the respiratory apertures and has pronounced lobes, rather than branched tentacles, on the sides of the foot.
taxon_text_8_2283:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 164)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 35).

Muller, S (1986). Taxonomy of the genus Haliotis in South Africa. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 46(1), 69-77.

Sales, J & Britz, PJ (2001). Research on abalone (Haliotis midae L.) cultivation in South Africa. Aquaculture Research, 32(11), 863-874.
taxon_text_1_2286:
Small, light, broad abalone species with characteristics typical of this group, which include a flat, oval, depressed shell, enormous aperture and row of six small respiratory openings.

Exterior surface usually mottled brick-red with white patches, sometimes plain red, lacking corrugations, but bearing fine spiral thread. Interior of shell shiny mother-of-pearl. The most distinctive identifying feature is a conspicuous spiral ridge running around the centre of the last whorl of the shell, which is matched by a furrow on the inner surface. The foot of the live animal is grey and white and bears a scattering a small marginal knobs and tentacles.
taxon_text_3_2288:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2289: Rarely found alive in the shallows but common at diving depth. Beached shells wash up regularly. Not of commercial value, nor exploited as food by humans, but eaten by various fish and seabirds. Otherwise little studied.
taxon_text_6_2291: Reproduction in this uncommon species has not been studied, but all abalone have separate sexes and are broadcast spawners. Release of sperm into the water by males stimulates females to spawn and the eggs are ejected singly though the holes along the lip. After fertilization the eggs develop into swimming larva, which take from a few days to several weeks to grow in the plankton before settling.
taxon_text_7_2292: Replaced in the far Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal by the similar and uncommon H. quecketti, which has one well-marked and several weaker spiral ridges and the holes in the shell, which are also raised on prominent turrets.
taxon_text_8_2293:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 164)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 34).

Muller, S (1986). Taxonomy of the genus Haliotis in South Africa. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 46(1), 69-77.
taxon_text_1_2296:
Medium-sized, fairly narrow-shelled abalone species with characteristics typical of this group, which include a flat, oval, depressed shell, enormous aperture and row of about six small respiratory openings.

Exterior surface usually mottled brick-red or brown with white patches, bearing a few minor rounded corrugations and spiral ridges (but not sharp upright ridges, as in H. midae). Outer lip concave. Interior of shell shiny mother-of-pearl.

The live animal is also easily recognized by the fluorescent bright green mantle visible though the respiratory apertures and the sides of the foot, which bear distinctive leaf-like lobes.
taxon_text_3_2298:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to northern Kwazulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2299: Common, but somewhat cryptic with specific habitat requirements, so live animals often go un-noticed, while dead shells are frequently seen. Live animals congregate in rock crevices and among redbait close to low water mark where they can be difficult to spot. Were commonly exploited as both bait and for human consumption, but recreational collection of all abalone species is no longer permitted in South Africa.
taxon_text_6_2301: Like all abalone have separate sexes and are broadcast spawners. Release of sperm into the water stimulates females to spawn and the eggs are ejected singly though the holes along the lip, are fertilized and develop into swimming larva which take from a few days to several weeks to develop in the plankton before settling. In this species spawning occurs from October to February.
taxon_text_7_2302: Fairly easily distinguished from the larger and more common Abalone H. midae by the lack of raised corrugations and concave growing edge of the shell and by the bright green mantle and lobed sides of the foot in living specimens. Also from the smaller and less common H. parva by lack of a conspicuous spiral ridge across centre of last whorl of shell.
taxon_text_8_2303:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 164)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 35).

Muller, S (1986). Taxonomy of the genus Haliotis in South Africa. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 46(1), 69-77.
taxon_text_1_2306:
Large and distinctive species. Shell thick, limpet- shaped and smoothly oval, with a double rim in which a white inner layer projects beyond the coloured outer layer. Apical aperture very large and oval, about 30% length of shell. Shell colour pale grey to brown with darker brown rays, white internally.

Live animal tough and very variable in colour, mottled or striped yellow, orange, brown, blue to black, completely enveloping and concealing the shell, so that only the apical shell aperture is visible. Underside of foot a distinctive orange.
taxon_text_2_2307: Shell up to 35 mm in length. Body up to 80 mm.
taxon_text_3_2308:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2309: Highly distinctive species that is usually found singly on shallow reefs. Has been observed to feed on sponges. Very little else known about its biology.
taxon_text_6_2311: Reproduction in this species has not been studied, but members of this family normally have separate sexes (some change sex from male to female with age). Eggs may be laid within thin gelatinous masses or in spherical gelatinous capsules. The young then hatch as late stage planktonic larvae, or in some species at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2312: Unmistakable, but as it is so unlike other keyhole-limpets it could be confused at first sight with a large sea-slug.
taxon_text_8_2313:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 172)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 36 as Fissurellidea aperta).
taxon_text_1_2326: Fairly large, heavy, somewhat flattened whelk with very short siphonal canal and shortish spire. Each whorl bears about 7–8 flat spiral ridges, each punctuated with regular pustules (hence the common name). In live animals outer surface covered with a thick velvety outer layer (periostracum). Outer lip with about nine teeth, but lacking the obvious dark brown stripes found in several related species. Foot of live animals pinkish.
taxon_text_2_2327: Shell up to 115 mm in length, but usually less than 60 mm.
taxon_text_3_2328:
Global: Southern Africa, plus Chile, Australia and New Zealand (uncertain that these are truly the same species).

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2329: Fairly common intertidally on the west coast, where it occurs in sandy pools and feeds mainly on the Cape reef worm Gunnarea gaimardi. A toxic saliva is injected into the worm tube to paralyze the worm and partially digest its tissues, which are then sucked up through the proboscis as a ’soup’.
taxon_text_6_2331: The elongate-oval stalkless egg cases are laid in groups. In Chile these are 9–12 mm long and 47–149 capsules are laid in each mass over a period of 3–9 days. There are 2 500–5 400 eggs per capsule and up to 650 000 eggs per spawning. Development takes 54–56 days and it is thought that there is a long planktonic larval life, which may account for the wide distribution of the species.
taxon_text_7_2332: The fairly large size, pustulate ridges around the final whorls of the shell, velvety outer surface in live shells and lack of colouring on the outer lip are good identification features.
taxon_text_8_2333:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 190).

Day, JA (1969). Feeding of the cymatiid gastropod, Argobuccinum argus, in relation to the structure of the proboscis and secretions of the proboscis gland. American Zoologist, 9(3), 909-916.

Gallardo, CS, Haro, D, Wagner, C, Garrido, O & Cañete, JI (2012). Egg-laying behaviour and intracapsular development of Argobuccinum pustulosum (Gastropoda: Ranellidae) in temperate waters at the South coast of Chile. Marine Biology Research, 8(9), 815-828.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 75).
taxon_text_1_2336: Shell cap-shaped, flat and with apex slightly coiled, but last whorl greatly enlarged and flattened. Internally a flat shelf protects the visceral organs. Exterior of shell off-white, sculptured with rows of short scale-like spines. Found on underside of rocks (not on other shells, as in Crepidula porcellana) and does not form stacks.
taxon_text_2_2337: Shell up to about 26 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2338:
Global: Brazil, Argentina and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2339: Usually found singly or in small groups on the undersides of boulders, or in other sheltered habitats. Little else known about biology. The species was previously known as Crepidula aculeata and only fairly recently transferred to the newly-created genus Bostrycapulus.
taxon_text_5_2340: Filter-feeder, removing small particles from the surrounding sea water by passing this though the enlarged, sieve-like gills.
taxon_text_6_2341: Eggs fairly large and laid in egg-capsules which also contain nurse cells. The developing embryos consume the nurse calls as they develop and hatch into crawling juveniles without a free-swimming larval stage.
taxon_text_7_2342: The obvious rows of scale–like spines on the outer surface of the shell clearly distinguish this species from other regional slipper limpets.
taxon_text_8_2343:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 172).

Collin, R (2005). Development, phylogeny, and taxonomy of Bostrycapulus (Caenogastropoda: Calyptraeidae), an ancient cryptic radiation. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 144(1), 75-101.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 57 as Crepidula aculeata).
taxon_text_1_2346: Distinctive species with an almost perfectly round, conical shell rising to a central sharp point. Last whorl greatly enlarged and flattened with an internal flat shelf that protects the visceral organs. Margin of shelf distinctly convex and lobed. Exterior of shell white, usually smooth but may be sculpted with small knobs.
taxon_text_2_2347: Shell up to about 15 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2348:
Global: Europe and Mediterranean down West Africa to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2349: Usually found singly or in small groups on other shells or the undersides of boulders or in other sheltered habitats.
taxon_text_5_2350: Filter-feeder, removing small particles from the surrounding sea water by passing this though the enlarged, sieve-like gills.
taxon_text_6_2351: Protandrous hermaphrodite, changing from male to female as growth proceeds. Eggs are laid in capsules that are sheltered under females and these hatch into crawling young without a free-swimming larval stage.
taxon_text_7_2352: The shell shape is distinctive. Progressively replaced by the larger (up to 45 mm) C. helicoidea from Algoa Bay eastwards. That species has a similar shell shape, but has radial ribs on outer surface that are tinged with orange-brown.
taxon_text_8_2353:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 172).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 57 ).

Wyatt, HV (1961). The reproduction, growth and distribution of Calyptraea chinensis (L.). The Journal of Animal Ecology, 30, 283-302.
taxon_text_1_2356: The largest whelk in the region, reaching an impressive 290 mm. Shell heavy, with moderately long spire, but short siphonal canal. Each whorl with flattened spiral ridges and a row of low nodules. Positions of previous apertures marked by transverse ridges spaced more than a half-turn apart. Aperture with thick outer lip marked with a series of brown transverse bars, inner lip pinkish with wrinkles. External colour pale brown with darker flames. In live animal foot mottled red-brown and tentacles orange with transverse black bars. Operculum elongate-oval, thick and horny.
taxon_text_3_2358:
Global: Very widely distributed including Europe, west coast of Africa, South Africa, Madagascar, Indian Ocean, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2359:
Fairly common from low intertidal to a depth of at least 100 m and usually found singly. Predatory, feeding on holothurians, sea urchins and starfish.

The wide global distribution of the species and regional differences in shape, ornamentation, colour and adult size suggest that several species may be currently included under this one name.
taxon_text_5_2360: Feeds on echinoderms, including holothurians, urchins and starfish. A toxin is used to anaesthetize the prey.
taxon_text_6_2361: Egg cases are more or less cylindrical with a ridge up each side and are reddish in colour. They are laid in groups of 90-120. Each egg capsule contains 300-2000 eggs, which hatch after 1-4 months, emerging through an exit pore at the top of the case as planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2362: The large size and ornamentation of the aperture are distinctive. Could be confused with the similarly-shaped Ranella gemmifera, but that species only reaches 110 mm.
taxon_text_8_2363:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 190).

Herbert, DG & Jones, GJ (2018). Phylum Mollusca In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Offshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 249-320 (p. 265).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 73).
taxon_text_1_2366:
Distinctive group in which the shell is teardrop-shaped with a slightly coiled apex, but the last whorl enormously enlarged and flattened, and with a thin internal ‘shelf’ protecting the body organs.

In this species the margin of the internal shelf is concave and the exterior of the shell brown and smooth or slightly ridged. Habitat also distinctive, as usually found attached to other large shells, such as whelks or turban shells, and often arranged in stacks, one above the other (see Biology).
taxon_text_2_2367: Shell up to about 25 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2368:
Global: West Africa to northern KwaZulu-Natal.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2369: Common, but often missed, as immobile and tightly attached to the shells of other large mollusks, which it often resembles in colour.
taxon_text_5_2370: Filter-feeder, removing small particles from the surrounding sea water by passing this though the enlarged, sieve-like gills.
taxon_text_6_2371:
Protandric hermaphrodite, changing sex from male to female with age. Solitary individuals pass rapidly though the male phase and quickly become female. Juveniles then settle on these larger, established females and initially mature into males. Further individuals often settle on this group, forming a stack. Position in the stack determines sex, those on the top acting as males, intermediate ones being transitional and lower ones females.
