Females lay large yellow eggs, which are attached to the host and protected beneath the shell aperture. In most Crepidula species the eggs hatch into planktonic larvae, but in some species, they are retained until they hatch into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2372: The related Crepipatella capensis has the lip of the internal shelf convex, rather than concave, and is usually found attached to rocks, rather than to other shells. The Spiny slipper-limpet Bostrycapulus odites also has a similar shell shape, but the exterior of the shell bears obvious rows of scale–like spines.
taxon_text_8_2373:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 172).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 57).
taxon_text_1_2376:
Cowries are among the best known and most easily identified of all molluscs and are characterized by their glossy, egg-like shells, and the narrow, parallel-sided aperture that runs the full length of the flattened ventral surface of the shell and which is usually toothed on one or both margins. In live animals the mantle, which itself can be dramatically coloured and textured, completely covers the shell, so it can be difficult to match images of live animals with those of dead shells (indeed some species are known only from dead shells). Although often thought of as a primarily tropical group, a wide diversity of endemic cowries are found in the cooler waters off South Africa.

The shell of this species is globular and the dorsal surface is sparsely to densely covered with dark brown spots against a pale apricot background. The density of these spots is so variable that the dorsal surface can vary from being almost white to almost completely dark brown! The ventral surface is always milky white though. The aperture is slightly curved posteriorly and is weekly toothed on the inner lip, the teeth not extending onto the ventral surface. The outer lip bears 14-21 stronger un-pigmented teeth that do extend across most of its width. In live animals the mantle is also extremely variable, ranging from a more usual salmon pink to black in some cases and may bear a few small papillae. The siphon is short, upturned and white and the tentacles are yellow.
taxon_text_3_2378:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_2379: Found from 8-200 m depth, but occurs in shallow waters only in the western part of its range, moving to deeper depths in warmer waters of the Eastern Cape. Associated with sponges and the mantle colour usually matches that of the sponges on which specimens are seen.
taxon_text_5_2380: Feeds on sponges. but also observed to supplement its diet by consuming crinoids.
taxon_text_6_2381: Females deposit about 30 egg capsules among bryozoans, in crevices or on the underside or rocks. Each capsule contained one fertilized egg, along with many nurse cells, which the embryo consumes during its development into a shelled juvenile.
taxon_text_7_2382: Identification of local species in the genus is difficult due to extreme variation in shell size, colour and ornamentation within species, as well as of the colour of the mantle in live animals. This species can be fairly reliably identified by the white ventral surface of the shell and the un-pigmented teeth that do not extend across the basal surface. Readers are referred to the excellent accounts in Liltvelt (see reference below) for more details, as that account contains numerous images showing variation in both the live animal and its shell.
taxon_text_8_2383:
Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (discussed p. 62 under C. edentula).

Liltved, WR (2000). Cowries and their Relatives of Southern Africa. (second edition). Gordon Verhoef, Seacomber Publications (p. 50, as Cypraea algoensis).
taxon_text_1_2386:
Cowries are among the best known and most easily identified of all molluscs and are characterized by their glossy, egg-like shells, and the narrow, parallel-sided aperture that runs the full length of the flattened ventral surface of the shell and which is usually toothed on one or both margins. In live animals the mantle, which itself can be dramatically coloured and textured, completely covers the shell, so it can be difficult to match images of live animals with those of dead shells (indeed some species are known only from dead shells). Although often thought of as a primarily tropical group, a wide diversity of endemic cowries are found in the cooler waters off South Africa.

The shell of this species is globular, with a pale pink ground-colour overlaid with chestnut-brown patches. The underside is off-white with an unusually wide and slightly curved aperture. The outer lip has19-25 fine, widely-spaced light orange or brown teeth, while the inner lip has 19-22 weak denticles which only extend onto the lower surface at the extreme anterior end of the aperture, The live animal is fairly distinctive as the mantle is pale pink with numerous black spots and has many large finger-like papillae, which lack the spotted pattern. The broad siphon has a lobed margin, and the tentacles are yellow to pink.
taxon_text_3_2388:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2389: Uncommon and poorly known, but live animals fairly easily recognised by the enlarged papillae extending from the mantle. Misidentified previously as C. verhoefi.
taxon_text_6_2391: Not known for this species, but related species lay egg capsules among sedentary invertebrates, such as sponges or bryozoans, on the reef. Each capsule contained one fertilized egg along with many nurse cells, which the embryo consumes during its development into a shelled juvenile.
taxon_text_7_2392: Identification of local species in the genus is difficult due to extreme variation in shell size, colour and ornamentation within species, as well as of the colour of the mantle in live animals. When alive this species can be fairly reliably identified though by the enlarged papillae on the mantle. The shell is best identified by the wide, curved aperture and pattern of teeth (see Liltved book for images and details).
taxon_text_8_2393: Liltved, WR (2000). Cowries and their Relatives of Southern Africa. (second edition). Gordon Verhoef, Seacomber Publications (p. 50 , as Cypraea verhoefi, see also p. 222 for more details).
taxon_text_1_2396:
Cowries are among the best known and most easily identified of all molluscs and are characterized by their glossy, egg-like shells, and the narrow, parallel-sided aperture that runs the full length of the flattened ventral surface of the shell and is usually strongly toothed on both margins. In live animals the mantle, which itself can be dramatically coloured and textured, completely covers the shell, so it can be difficult to match images of live animals with those of dead shells (indeed some species are known only from dead shells). Although often thought of as a primarily tropical group, a wide diversity of endemic cowries are found in the cooler waters off South Africa.

The shell of this species if fairly easily identified, especially by the 15-20 dark brown ridges (‘teeth’) that run across the ventral surface and after which it is named. The dorsal surface of the shell is densely patterned with fused brown spots and dashes and the margins are usually purple (all colours fade in dead museum specimens and many guides depict such old, faded shells). The mantle of live animals is very variable in colour (as in many other local species), but is typically brown with black spots and often bears small finger-like papillae. The short siphon has a white band at its top and the tentacles are usually yellow to apricot.
taxon_text_3_2398:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Point to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_2399: Found on reefs at depth of 6-130 m, especially in areas densely colonised by the black sponges on which this species feeds.
taxon_text_6_2401: Egg capsules are deposited in the folds of sponges on which the adults feed. Liltved reports egg capsules in this species to be spherical and to measure 3.9 mm with 52 capsules laid by a female. Each capsule contained one fertilized egg along with many nurse cells, which the embryo consumes during its development into a shelled juvenile.
taxon_text_7_2402: Shells are fairly easily identified by the strong ridges running across the ventral surface and by the purple margins. Since the mantle of live animals shows such a range of colours and textures, live images can easily be confused with those of a number of other local species (such as C. capensis, C. fuscorubra, etc), so identifications not confirmed by examination of (or not showing) the shell should be treated with caution.
taxon_text_8_2403:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 184)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 62 as Cypraea fuscodentata).

Liltved, WR (2000). Cowries and their Relatives of Southern Africa. (second edition). Gordon Verhoef, Seacomber Publications (p. 64).
taxon_text_1_2406:
Worm shells are an unusual group in that the whorls of the shell have become largely uncoiled and irregular and are attached permanently to the substratum (or one another) by one side. They are often mistaken for tube-dwelling polychaetes.

This species is relatively small and gregarious, forming large, flat, intertwining masses or ‘reefs’ of tubes on the upper surfaces of rocks in the low intertidal. The off-white tubes themselves are often covered by coralline algae, leaving only the apertures visible, each of which is closed by a dark red-brown horny operculum.
taxon_text_2_2407: Individuals only about 10 mm in length, but colonies may be 30 cm or more across.
taxon_text_3_2408:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_2409: Very common in the low intertidal, where it forms extensive flat reefs coating the upper surfaces of rocks in areas of strong water flow. Often overgrown with encrusting algae, so that the intertwining white tubes are concealed and only the openings are visible, each closed by a dark, reddish-brown, horny operculum, often with a yellow centre. The intertwined structure and transverse growth ridges of the bluish-white shells is in fact best seen on eroded pieces of colony that have been washed ashore!
taxon_text_5_2410: Filter-feeder, forming a net of mucous strands that are used to capture floating food particles. After some time the net is gathered in by the radula and the captured food items consumed.
taxon_text_6_2411: Broods up to 11 egg-capsules in a single row within the mantle cavity, each capsule containing a single embryo. The free-swimming larvae can settle within 24 h, but can also delay metamorphosis for 4–5 days if suitable substrata are not found. The larvae prefer to settle on encrusting coralline algae and use the radula to dig a groove, into which they can firmly attach themselves. Young are released from July-December.
taxon_text_7_2412: Replaced from the Eastern Cape northwards by the almost identical D. tholia. The Solitary worm-shell Thylacodes natalensis occurs in the same region, but is much larger, pinky-white in colour, is solitary and lacks an operculum.
taxon_text_8_2413:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182).

Hughes, RN (2008). The biology of Dendropoma corallinaceum and Serpulorbis natalensis, two South African vermetid gastropods. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 64(2), 111–127.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 52)
taxon_text_1_2416: Tiny plain black gastropod with a short, pointed spire and a calcareous operculum. Extremely abundant among intertidal algae, but often overlooked due to its small size.
taxon_text_3_2418:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_2419: Very little is known about this tiny species, which is found in large numbers amongst intertidal seaweed, especially those in shallow rockpools. Known as ‘tooth-crunchers’ by those that like to eat seaweeds!
taxon_text_5_2420: Probably browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_2421: Reproduction in this species has not been studied.
taxon_text_7_2422: Often confused with juvenile Southern periwinkles Afrolittorina knysnaensis but that species occurs higher on the shore and has a horny and not calcareous operculum.
taxon_text_8_2423:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 180)

Ponder, WF & Worsfold, TM (1994). Review of the Rissoiform Gastropods of Southwestern South America (Mollusca, Gastropoda). Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 445, 1-63.
taxon_text_1_2426: A large and heavy whelk with short siphonal canal.  Outer surface with several spiral ridges and rows of low knobs; outer surface of shell often covered with a thick fibrous later of spiky bristles (hence common name). Outer lip marked with six pairs of course teeth and inner lip with numerous transverse ridges. In live animal the foot and antennae are attractively marked with numerous black leopard-like spots on a yellow background.
taxon_text_2_2427: Shell up to 150 mm in length, but usually less than 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_2428:
Global: Very widely distributed including Europe, west coast of Africa, South Africa, Indian Ocean, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Cape Point to Durban.
taxon_text_4_2429: Relatively uncommon and often buried in the sand, but may be washed up after storms. Thought to feed on bivalves and other molluscs.
taxon_text_5_2430: Feeds on echinoderms including holothurians, urchins and starfish. A toxin is used to anaesthetize the prey.
taxon_text_6_2431: Egg cases triangular and laid inside a cup shaped structure and are guarded by the female until they hatch (1-3 month). Each egg case contains many eggs, which hatch into free-swimming veliger larvae, which in many related species have an unusually long larval life, allowing for wide dispersal.
taxon_text_7_2432: The large size, hairy external surface and ornamentation of the aperture, plus the unusual body colour are distinctive. Ranella gemmifera is similar, but has a smooth inner lip and conspicuous brown bars crossing the outer lip (these are also visible on ridges from earlier apertures).
taxon_text_8_2433:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 190).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 74).
taxon_text_1_2446:
Necklace shells are fat and almost spherical with a short spire and large, semicircular aperture with a thin outer lip and horny operculum. In live animals the foot is very large and used to plough though the sand in search of prey.

This species is yellowish to brown, sometimes fairly plain, but usually attractively patterned with darker spots and zig-zag streaks. It is the only common necklace shell found intertidally in the South-Western Cape. The umbilicus is closed and the operculum is smooth.
taxon_text_3_2448:
Global: Southern Africa (and possibly also Madagascar).

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape with possible records also from Mozambique and Madagascar.
taxon_text_4_2449:
Lives in clean sand, both in estuaries and lagoons and in sandy pools on the open coast, especially sites adjacent to rocks and colonised by the sand-tolerant Black mussel Choromytilus meridionalis, which is a favoured prey.

Crawls rapidly though the sediment just below the surface, often leaving a characteristic mole-like trail to mark its passage. When a prey item, usually a mussel or other bivalve, is encountered, it is enveloped by the large foot and a characteristic bevelled hole drilled through the shell by alternately applying a special boring gland, then rasping away the softened shell material with the radula. The position of the borehole is very consistent within a particular prey species (but differs between prey species).
taxon_text_5_2450: On the open coast feed mainly on mussels, but in sheltered sites and estuaries also on a range of other burrowing bivalves. Prey size is related to predator size, larger necklace shells taking correspondingly larger mussels. The size of the borehole is also closely correlated to the size of the predator that made it, thus by measuring the borehole one can calculate the size of the predator that made it.
taxon_text_6_2451:
The egg cases are unusual and take the form of a flattened, parallel-sided blade enclosed in sand and attached to the rocks surface by a short stalk at the one end. Most other species in this family lay egg cases that are in the form of a flattened, sometimes crimped ribbon coiled into a characteristic collar (hence the term necklace shells) and that are left unattached on the sand surface.

The detailed of embryonic development are not known in this species, but in related species several thousand eggs capsules are found within each eggs strand. Each capsule may contain 1-7 eggs, sometimes also accompanied by nurse cells used as nourishment for the developing embryos. In some species the eggs hatch as planktonic larvae and in others as crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2452: The only common necklace shell in the region and the only one with a closed umbilicus.
taxon_text_8_2453:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 188).

Griffiths, RJ (1981). Predation on the bivalve Chromytilus meridionalis (Kr) by the gastropod Natica (Tectomatica) tecta Anton. Journal of Molluscan Studies, 47, 112-120.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 70).
taxon_text_1_2456:
Worm snails are an unusual group in that the whorls of the shell have become largely uncoiled and irregular and the shell is attached permanently to the substratum (or one another) by one side. They are often mistaken for tube-dwelling polychaete worms.

This species is relatively large and solitary with a loosely-coiled pinkish-white shell that is attached by its side to the underside of rocks. Shell is sculptured by weak longitudinal ridges and often crossed by transverse growth ridges. There is no operculum and the foot is pink-orange to red.
taxon_text_3_2458:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2459: Fairly common on the undersides of boulders or in low-shore pools. Occurs single or in dispersed groups (not intertwined together). A filter-feeder that gathers food particles using a mucous net. Adjacent individuals have synchronized feeding rhythms, probably to prevent net-robbing!
taxon_text_5_2460: Filter-feeder, forming a net of mucous strands that are used to capture floating food particles. After some time the net is gathered in by the radula and the captured food items consumed.
taxon_text_6_2461: Young are released from July-December. Incubates up to 30 egg-capsules, which hang on short stalks in staggered rows from the roof of the shell. Each capsule contains 20-40 embryos, plus nurse cells that are used to nourish them as they develop. After a short larval life they settle and secrete a sticky mucus trail that helps then adhere to the substratum as they select a site to permanently attach.
taxon_text_7_2462: Replaced from the Eastern Cape northwards by the very similar T. aureus. The Colonial worm-snail Dendropoma corrallinaceum occurs in the same region, but is much smaller, occurs in dense intertwined colonies and has a round, dark operculum.
taxon_text_8_2463:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182).

Hughes, RN (2008). The biology of Dendropoma corallinaceum and Serpulorbis natalensis, two South African vermetid gastropods. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society. 64 (2): 111–127.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 52).
taxon_text_9_2465: Given as a variety of Tonna variegata in Kilburn and Rippey, 1982
taxon_text_1_2466:
Tun shells have a large, thin, globular shell with a very short spire and greatly enlarged last whorl. The outer lip is slightly thickened, the siphonal canal very short and the operculum absent. The foot is very large and often cannot be fully retracted into the shell.

This species is ornamented with 16-19 flat spiral ridges separated by deep grooves and is light brown with regular darker flecks. Foot large and thick, mottled with light and dark brown streaks.
taxon_text_3_2468:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2469: A large and easily recognised species found on inshore reefs and sometimes extending into intertidal gullies. Uncommon in the Western Cape becoming more common eastwards. Typically buries in sand and emerges to hunt for sea cucumbers, which are paralysed using a salivary secretion containing sulphuric acid. This may also be squirted though the proboscis as a defense measure.
taxon_text_6_2471: Sexes separate and fertilization internal. Tun shells lay their eggs in a long, wide gelatinous ribbon containing large numbers of egg-capsules arranged in transverse rows. Each capsule contains 20-100 eggs.  A single ribbon of spawn may thus contain up to 660 000 eggs! The eggs hatch into large veliger larvae, which can have a very long development time of up to several month in same species. This probably allowing for very wide dispersal.
taxon_text_7_2472: Unlikely to be confused with any other regional species and the only ton shells with a distribution extending to the cooler waters of the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_2473:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 188)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 71 as a variety of T. variegata).
taxon_text_1_2476:
Shell cowrie-like, pink and with a smooth glossy external texture and inflated oval shape. Spire very short and more or less parallel-sided; aperture running the length of the underside. Both inner and outer lips of aperture bearing a series of transverse teeth, which do not extend across ventral surface.

In life the shell is usually completely obscured by the mantle, which is very variable in colour pattern. The most common form is greyish-white covered in black dots that are each encircled by an opaque white ring. However, in some specimens the mantle is yellow or pink and the black markings are elongate and worm-like or stippled.
taxon_text_3_2478:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2479:
Found on rocky reefs from about 3 m depth down to at least 50 m. Normally associated with compound ascidians, on which they feed.

Colour pattern thought to mimic toxic dorid nudibranchs.
taxon_text_5_2480: Feed on compound ascidians, biting of the tough test with the jaws to get to the soft tissues inside.
taxon_text_6_2481: Not specifically studied in this species, but other species in the genus embed vase-shaped egg capsules inside the host ascidian. Each capsule contains numerous eggs and in British species the larvae are planktonic. However, the large size of the embryos in this species suggest it might show direct development.
taxon_text_7_2482:
This species is largely defined by the pink, smooth shell and mantle colour. The closely related T. millardi normally has a white shell and pink to orange mantle. Many other species in the genus have transverse ridges that extend across the ventral surface or right  around to the dorsal surface of the shell.

Species level identifications within this genus are complicated though, as there are some 30 similar endemic species in the region. Also, these species are largely defined by features of the shell, which is usually concealed by the mantle in live images. To complicate matters further, mantle colour can be highly variable within species! Readers are referred to the detailed accounts in Liltved (2000- see refs below) for more information and multiple images showing variations within these species.
taxon_text_8_2483:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 186)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 59).

Liltved, WR (2000). Cowries and their Relatives of Southern Africa (second edition). Gordon Verhoef, Seacomber Publications (p. 162).
taxon_text_1_2486:
Fairly large shell, easily recognized by the fairly long spire and elongated siphonal canal, which is about 30% total length of the shell. Also by the fact that the foot is bright orange-red with white spots. The whorls of the shell are decorated with flattened spiral ridges and sometimes with small knobs. External colour pale with brown markings and spots, interior white.

There are several regional varieties which may represent genetically distinct species.
taxon_text_3_2488:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2489: Fairly common and distinctive species found both intertidally and on deeper reefs. Little else is known about its biology.
taxon_text_5_2490: Thought to feed on polychaete worms as evidenced by the presence of their setae in its faeces, but no other details known.
taxon_text_6_2491: The egg cases are vase-shaped with a short thick stalk and are deposited in groups under rocks.
taxon_text_7_2492: Fairly easily recognized by its long siphonal canal and bright red foot. Can be confused with the Fine-ribbed whelk Lugubrilaria lugubris but that species occurs only on the west coast, has more numerous and more delicate ridges on the shell, a shorter siphonal canal and two pleats on the inner lip near the siphonal canal.
taxon_text_8_2493:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Herbert, DG & Jones, GJ (2018). Phylum Mollusca In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Offshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 249-320 (p. 274 as Fucinus ocelliferus).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 102).
taxon_text_1_2496: Fairly small whelk-like shell with a smooth conical spire, without steps between whorls. Aperture wide and flared with thin outer lip and short, wide siphonal canal. Outer surface of last whorl with numerous shallow spiral grooves. Colour light brown with wavy dark longitudinal bands. Colour pattern fades in beach-cast or museum specimens, which are then depicted in some guides as plain brown or reddish. Interior reddish-brown.
taxon_text_3_2498:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal south coast.
taxon_text_4_2499: Very little is known about this small species, which is fairly commonly cast ashore, but uncommonly found alive. Usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders in low-shore pools and gullies. More common towards eastern parts of range.
taxon_text_5_2500: Unknown, but other members of this family are unusual in that they appear to be omnivorous, feeding both on dead animal matter and on algae, hydroids and other sessile animals.
taxon_text_6_2501: Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other species in the family, however, lay horny egg capsules singly or in group and attach these to the substratum. In some species eggs hatch into planktonic larvae, but in others the young emerge at the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2502: There are over 50 small species from this relatively obscure family found in the region, but most of these have much heavier shells and more marked external sculpturing that this delicate species.
taxon_text_8_2503: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_2096: Often-seen, large, conspicuous worm common in rock pools and on rocky reefs from the mid-intertidal downwards. Body fat and sausage-like, enclosed in a soft, muddy, parchment-like tube. Head with two prominent spiral crowns of feeding appendages that are of uniform colour, but can be white, yellow, red or purple.
taxon_text_2_2097: Body up to 120 mm long, crown about 50 mm across.
taxon_text_3_2098:
Global: Regional endemic.

Local/Regional: South Africa, Mozambique and Madagascar.
taxon_text_4_2099: A distinctive and well-known species commonly found in intertidal pools and gullies and on shallow reefs. The tube usually extends into a crack or under a boulder and the spectacular crown of feeding tentacles is extended into the water to intercept food particles. Snaps back into its tube rapidly at the slightest disturbance. Rejected food particles are used to construct the tube.
taxon_text_5_2100: Filter-feeder, removing and consuming particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_2101:
A variety of modes of reproduction occur in this group and most species can reproduce both asexually by ‘budding’ off smaller individuals, and sexually. 

In this species asexual reproduction is known to occur, the posterior part of the animal breaking off and generating a new body. Sexual reproduction also occurs with eggs and sperm being released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2102: There are several other related fanworms in the region, but this species is easily recognised by its large size, plus the uniform colour and spiral shape of the tentacular crown.
taxon_text_8_2103:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 771).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 76).
taxon_text_9_2435: Phalium labiatum zeylanicum, Phalium zeylanicum, Semicassis labiata
taxon_text_1_2436: Well known and easily recognized species and the only helmet shell to extend into the cooler waters of the Western Cape. Shell fairly large and globular with a short spire, deep siphonal notch and thickened outer lip. Last whorl of shell with row of rounded knobs, otherwise smooth and glossy. Knobs undeveloped in False Bay specimens. Colour pinkish with rows of pale spots, outer lip crossed by five pairs of dark bars. Foot large and pink with a narrow yellow margin and yellow and black striped tentacles. Large tubular siphon usually held erect. Extremely variable species that has caused taxonomic confusion, as several different growth forms occur along the coast and offshore, but which are all regarded the same species.
taxon_text_3_2438:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2439: Attractive and conspicuous species. Dead shells often washed ashore, but live animals subtidal and less frequently seen. Often buried in sand emerging to feed on sea urchins and pansy shells.
taxon_text_5_2440: Predatory, Western Cape specimens feeding almost entirely on the common Cape urchin Parechinus angulosus, which are first paralysed using a toxic mucous and then attached by either drilling a hole though the test, or by penetrating the peristome (the membrane surrounding the mouth). Feeding rates in captivity have been measure at one urchin every 7,5 days, although there are sometimes long gaps between feeding events.
taxon_text_6_2441: The egg cases are laid in large communal cylindrical masses contributed to by numerous females. Each female lays 2000-3000 egg capsules each containing a mean of 133 eggs. Eggs hatched as veliger larvae after 23 days and settled after a further 7 days.
taxon_text_7_2442: Unlikely to be confused with any other regional species but this species is extremely variable with two main forms.
taxon_text_8_2443:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 18).

Herbert, DG & Jones, GJ (2018). Phylum Mollusca In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Offshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 249-320 (p 262).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 72 , as P. labiatum zeylanicum).

Mazomba, T (2017). Feeding and reproduction behaviour in Semicassis labiata zeylanica (Gastropoda: Cassidae). Honours project, Department of Biological Sciences, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_2506:
Plough shells of the genus Bullia are a characteristic feature of wave-exposed sandy beaches and shallow benthic sands and are fairly easy to identify to group. They have elongated, generally smooth, conical shells that are mostly plain peach-coloured. The foot is extremely large with two tiny ‘tails’ at the posterior end and the operculum is much smaller than the aperture. The siphonal canal is very short and there is often a large shiny area (callus) extending from the inner lip of the aperture.

Some regional species are hard to distinguish from one another, but this one is easy to identify by virtue of the distinct steps separating the whorls of the shell and the fine spiral ridges around each whorl. There are often slight bumps and reddish-brown marks on the shoulders of the whorls. The callus is small and the operculum small and un-serrated.
taxon_text_3_2508:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_2509:
Shells are often washed up on beaches, but the live animals occur mostly subtidally and down to a depth of about 100 m, especially in large sheltered bays, such as False Bay.

Does not emerge from the water or surf into the intertidal, as do many other species in the genus.
taxon_text_5_2510: A scavenger gathering rapidly around fish guts, dead invertebrates or other offal.
taxon_text_6_2511: Not known specifically for this species, but other related species lay eggs in large membranous capsules that are buried in the sand. Each capsule contains several hundred eggs, but most of these are nurse cells consumed by the developing embryos and in the end only a few crawling young emerge from each egg case. In some species the female guards the egg cases and carries them around in a fold in her foot.
taxon_text_7_2512: There are several related species of Bullia that occur on the same shores and some of these can be difficult to distinguish at species level. This species is easily recognized though, due to the distinctive  ‘steps’ between the whorls of the shell and spiral ridges on the shell. Similar steps occur in the Calloused plough shell B. callosa, but that species occurs further east (east of Still Bay) has a much larger callus and weaker ridges and has reddish-brown marking, especially on the callus and along the sutures between whorls.
taxon_text_8_2513:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 198).

Brown, AC (1982). The biology of sandy-beach whelks of the genus Bullia (Nassariidae). Oceanography and Marine Biology: an Annual Review, 20, 833.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 96).
taxon_text_1_2516:
Plough shells of the genus Bullia are a characteristic feature of wave-exposed sandy beaches and shallow benthic sands and are fairly easy to identify to group. They have elongated, generally smooth, conical shells that are mostly plain peach-coloured. The foot is extremely large with two tiny ‘tails’ at the posterior end and the operculum is much smaller than the aperture. The siphonal canal is very short and there is often a large shiny area (callus) extending from the inner lip of the aperture.

Some regional species are hard to distinguish from one another and this species is easily confused with several others, so named images on websites etc. cannot be relied upon as being accurately identified. The key identification features are the long, pointed spire, lack of steps and of crimping between whorls and that the operculum has a strongly-serrated margin. Shell colour is also often characteristically tinged with purple, often with a purple line around the aperture. The surface of the shell is often coated in green algae.
taxon_text_3_2518:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2519:
Very common and well known species and the dominant plough shell on Atlantic shores, but also common along south coast. Lives shallowly buried in the sand low on the beach, or in the shallow subtidal, smelling the water using the siphon to detect carrion washed up on the beach. When prey is detected, numerous plough shells quickly emerge from the sand, roll over onto their backs and raise the enlarged foot like a sail in order to catch an incoming wave and surf up the shore towards the prey item. They then roll over and, using a rowing action of the sides of the enlarged foot, crawl up the odour trail towards the food item, leaving a characteristic track in the sand as they do.

Feeding is very rapid and involves plunging the proboscis into the prey, commonly a bluebottle or a jellyfish, rasping the food with the radula and sucking the pieces up the large tubular proboscis. As soon as the sand becomes too dry, the plough shells abandon the prey and re-bury themselves until another waves wets the sand.
taxon_text_5_2520: Scavengers, gathering rapidly around animal matter washed up on the beach. Feed mainly on jellyfish and colonial hydroids such as bluebottles, but will attack any smelly organ matter, such as redbait or dead fish – even paddling with smelly feet may cause them to emerge and gather!
taxon_text_6_2521: Lay eggs in large membranous capsules that are buried in the sand. Each capsule contains several hundred eggs, but most of these are nurse cells consumed by the developing embryos and in the end only a few crawling young emerge from each egg case.
taxon_text_7_2522: Easily confused with at least two very similar species that occur on the same shores. The Smooth plough shell Bullia rhodostoma is slightly broader, the interior of the aperture is orange and the operculum is not toothed (it is also absent from the west coast). The similar Pure plough shell B. pura is smaller (only up to 34 mm), almost white and has a more distinct callus on the base of the body whorl and an un-toothed operculum. It is also absent from the west coast and is known to brood its young.
taxon_text_8_2523:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 198).

Brown, AC (1961). Physiological-ecological studies on two sandy-beach Gastropoda from South Africa: Bullia digitalis Meuschen and Bullia laevissima (Gmelin). Zeitschrift für Morphologie und Ökologie der Tiere, 49, 629-657.

Brown, AC (1982). The biology of sandy-beach whelks of the genus Bullia (Nassariidae). Oceanography and Marine Biology: an Annual Review, 20, 833.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 96).
taxon_text_1_2526:
Plough shells of the genus Bullia are a characteristic feature of wave-exposed sandy beaches and shallow sands and are fairly easy to identify to group. They have elongated, generally smooth, conical shells that are mostly plain and peach-coloured. The foot is extremely large with two tiny ‘tails’ at the posterior end and the operculum is much smaller than the aperture. The siphonal canal is very short and there is often a large shiny area (callus) extending from the inner lip of the aperture.

This is one of the more distinctive species, as it is very heavy and squat with an exceptionally large aperture, a short, smooth spire (shorter than length of aperture) and a large callus on the underside. The operculum is tiny, oval and un-serrated.
taxon_text_3_2528:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2529:
A mostly subtidal species found to depths of at least 75 m, and can be extremely common, to the extent that it was once investigated as a potential target for a small-scale commercial fishery. Extends into shallow waters, or even into the intertidal, in sheltered areas, such a lagoons. Mostly found shallowly buried in the sand, emerging to gather around carrion.

Does not emerge from the water or surf into the intertidal, as do many other species in the genus.
taxon_text_5_2530: A scavenger gathering rapidly around fish guts, dead invertebrates or other offal.
taxon_text_6_2531: Eggs are laid in large membranous capsules that are buried in the sand. Each capsule contains several hundred eggs, but most of these are nurse calls consumed by the developing embryos and in the end only a few crawling young emerge from each egg case. In some species the female guards the egg cases and carries them around in a fold in her foot.
taxon_text_7_2532: There are several related species of Bullia that occur on the same shores and some of these can be difficult to distinguish at species level. However, this species is easily recognized by its very broad shell with its extremely large aperture and broad callus.
taxon_text_8_2533:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 198).

Brown, AC (1982). The biology of sandy-beach whelks of the genus Bullia (Nassariidae). Oceanography and Marine Biology: an Annual Review, 20, 833.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 96).
taxon_text_1_2536:
Whelks of the genus Burnupena can be difficult to identify, as several species may be common on the same shores, there is considerable variation in shell shape and colour within some species and external features may become concealed by encrusting algae or bryozoans.

This species is common in rock pools along the west coast and has a moderately elongate shell (length twice width) that is fairly smooth, but marked by numerous fine spiral ridges. The most obvious distinguishing feature is the characteristic colour-pattern consisting of alternating light and dark flames crossing each whorl. Internal colour dark purple.
taxon_text_2_2537: Shell up to 50 mm long, typically 30 mm.
taxon_text_3_2538:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_2539: A common, but relatively small Burnupena species that occurs relatively high on the shore. Mostly found concealed in crevices or under rocks and sometimes partially buried in sand. Becomes active and gathers quickly around dead or damaged animals or other food materials on which it scavenges.
taxon_text_5_2540: A scavenger, feeding on a wide range of dead or dying organisms, abandoned bait, fish guts and the like.
taxon_text_6_2541: The egg cases are compressed, with a leaf-like flap at the apex and are laid in a hemispherical mass attached in the open directly on the rock or to the shells of other molluscs. The eggs hatch directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2542: Several related species of Burnupena occur on the same shores and can be difficult to separate. This species is best recognized by the fine spiral ridges on the otherwise fairly smooth shell, the flame-like colour markings and deep purple interior. Can be confused with the Variable burnupena B. lagenaria, but that species has a shorter, broader shell that lacks flame-like markings. The Ridged burnupena B. cincta is larger and heavier with pronounced ridges on the shell and has a paler purplish interior. Also co-occurs with the Papery burnupena B. papyracea, which is easily recognized as the shells are usually all coated by the purple to orange knobbly bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum.
taxon_text_8_2543:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 94).
taxon_text_1_2546:
Whelks of the genus Burnupena can be difficult to identify, as several species may be common on the same shores. There is considerable variation in shell shape and colour within some species and external features may be concealed by encrusting algae or bryozoans covering the shells.

This species has a thick, heavy shell with a fairly elongate spire (about as long as aperture) and each whorl is ornamented with strong spiral ridges. The posterior end of the outer lip is strongly kinked inwards. The outer surface is dull brown, but often tinged green by algae, or covered by encrusting red algae. The interior of the shell is usually pale violet.
taxon_text_3_2548:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2549: Very common, usually found nestled in crevices or under rocks, from mid-tide level downwards, sometimes partially buried in sand. Becomes active and gathers quickly around dead of damaged animals or other food materials on which it scavenges.
taxon_text_5_2550: A scavenger, feeding on a wide range of dead or dying organisms, abandoned bait and fish guts and the like.
taxon_text_6_2551: The egg cases are presumed to resemble those of other Burnupena species and to be compressed, with a leaf-like flap at the apex and to be laid on a hemispherical mass attached directly to the rock or to the shells of other molluscs. The eggs hatch directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2552: Several related species of Burnupena occur on the same shores and can be difficult to separate. This species is best recognized by its large size, heavy ridged shell and pale purplish interior. Other common species in the same region include the Variable burnupena, B. lagenaria, which is smaller (<45mm) with a shorter spire, less marked ridges (except in some south-east coast specimens) and has a deep purple interior. Also the Papery burnupena B. papyracea, live individuals of which are easily recognized as the shells are coated by the purple to orange knobbly bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum. Dead shells are yellow with fine spiral ridges.
taxon_text_8_2553:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_2556:
Whelks of the genus Burnupena can be difficult to identify, as several species may be common on the same shores, there is considerable variation in shell shape and colour within some species and external features may be concealed by encrusting algae or bryozoans.

This species is probably the most common Burnupena in the intertidal and has a relatively thin shell with a short spire (spire much shorter than aperture) that has only traces of spiral ridges in Western Cape specimens (those in Eastern Cape may have more obvious ridges). The interior of the aperture is deep purple.
taxon_text_2_2557: Shell up to 45 mm long, typically 35 mm.
taxon_text_3_2558:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2559: This is probably the most common of the Burnupena species and occurs relatively high in the shore. Mostly found concealed in crevices or under rocks and sometimes partially buried in sand. Becomes active and gathers quickly around dead of damaged animals or other food materials on which it scavenges.
taxon_text_5_2560: A scavenger, feeding on a wide range of dead or dying organisms, abandoned bait and fish guts and the like.
taxon_text_6_2561: The egg cases are compressed, with a leaf-like flap at the apex and are laid in a hemispherical mass attached in the open directly on the rock or to the shells of other molluscs. The eggs hatch directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2562: Several related species of Burnupena occur on the same shores and can be difficult to separate. This species is best recognized by its short spire, lack of external ridges and deep purple interior. Can be confused with the Ridged burnupena B. cincta, but that species is larger and heavier with pronounced ridges on the shell and a paler purplish interior. Also occurs along with the Papery burnupena B. papyracea, but in that species live individuals are easily recognized as the shells are coated by the purple to orange knobbly bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum. Dead shells are yellow with fine spiral ridges.
taxon_text_8_2563:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_2566:
Whelks of the genus Burnupena can be difficult to identify, as several species may be common on the same shores, there is considerable variation in shell shape and colour within some species and external features may be concealed by encrusting algae or bryozoans.

This is one of the easiest species to identify though, since when alive the shell is nearly always completely covered with the purple to orange nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum. The dead and without the bryozoan cover the shell is also distinctive and is yellowish–brown with a fairly long spire and is ornamented with fine spiral ridges. The interior of the shell is white.
taxon_text_3_2568:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: A west coast species found from Namibia to about Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_2569:
Common and easily recognised by the external coating of orange nodular bryozoan, which is known to protect the species against predators such as rock-lobsters. Indeed these whelks have been observed ganging up against rock lobsters and attacking them - an unusual case of reversed predation!

The brightly coloured ridgeback amphipod Ochlesis lenticulosus and Hunchback amphipod Iphimedia gibba are often seen congregating on the backs of the whelks and feeding on the bryozoan, thus ingesting the toxins it contains, and thus also presumably gaining protection against predators (a fascinating subject for future research!).
taxon_text_5_2570: A scavenger, feeding on a wide range of dead or dying organisms, abandoned bait and fish guts and the like. Can also overcome and eat rock-lobsters when abundant.
taxon_text_6_2571: The egg cases resemble those of other Burnupena species and are compressed, with a leaf-like flap at the apex and are laid in a hemispherical mass attached directly to the rock or to the shells of other molluscs. The eggs hatch directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2572: Several related species of Burnupena occur on the same shores and can be difficult to separate. When alive this species can be distinguished from most others by its coating of orange bryozoan, and when dead by the fine spiral ridges and white internal colour of the shell. There is, however, a second very similar species, the Pubescent burnupena B. pubescens, which is also covered by the same bryozoan. However, that species is smaller (30 mm) and the shell has longitudinal ridges crossing the spiral ridges, giving it a chequered texture.
taxon_text_8_2573:
Barkai, A & McQuaid, C (1988). Predator-prey role reversal in a marine benthic ecosystem.Science, 242(4875), 62-64.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Gray, CA, McQuaid, CD & Davies-Coleman, MT (2005). A symbiotic shell-encrusting bryozoan provides subtidal whelks with chemical defence against rock lobsters. African Journal of Marine Science, 27(3), 549-556.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_2576: Shell large and heavy with long spire and sharp apex. Whorls slightly swollen and covered with a thin, black periostracum that readily flakes off, revealing pinky-white shell beneath. Aperture wide and very characteristic in shape in that the outer lip is cut back into a very deep sinus, matching the similarly deep sinus leading onto the suture. Operculum horny. Specimens from the west are larger and smoother then those from the east of the range.
taxon_text_3_2578:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_2579: Rarely found and not featured in most regional field guides. Most specimens trawled in deeper water off the Agulhas Bank, but has been found by SCUBA divers active at night in False Bay.
taxon_text_6_2581: Details unknown, but related species lay purse-shaped eggs capsules with a short stalk and from which crawling young emerge.
taxon_text_7_2582: The large size and unusual notches in the aperture readily identify this species. The only species with a similar structure is the much smaller (51 mm) C. tripartita, which is only found east of Jeffreys Bay.
taxon_text_8_2583:
Kilburn, RN (1985). Turridae (Mollusca: Gastropoda) of southern Africa and Mozambique. Part 2. Subfamily Clavatulinae. Annals of the Natal Museum, 26(2), 417-470.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 116 as Clionella taxea).

Steyn, DG & Lussi, M (2005). Offshore Shells of Southern Africa: A pictorial guide to more than 750 Gastropods. Published by the authors (p. 204).
taxon_text_1_2586: Shell with fairly long spire and short anterior canal. Each whorl crossed by marked transverse ribs, these numbering 16-18 on last whorl. Colour dark brown to black, usually strongly eroded, especially at apex. Posterior margin of outer lip crimped inwards. Operculum horny.
taxon_text_3_2588:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2589: Common under loose rocks lying on sand, usually found half buried in sand and gravel.
taxon_text_5_2590: Poorly known, but from our own observations specimens aggregating on sandy substrates gang up to prey on small sand reef-forming polychaetes.
taxon_text_6_2591: Lays very compressed, purse-shaped eggs capsules with a short stalk attaching them to rocks of shells; 5-6 crawling young emerge from each capsule.
taxon_text_7_2592: The numerous axial ribs on the shells whorls and black, heavily-eroded shell are fairly distinctive, although there are in fact several other rarer species in this genus in the region.
taxon_text_8_2593:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 53).
taxon_text_1_2596:
Cone shells are a diverse and very distinctive group, easily recognized by the smooth, strongly conical shape of the shell, with its short spire, elongate, narrow aperture and thin, smooth outer lip. The outer lip is never toothed or pleated, as in other more-or less-conical groups, such as olive shells and marginellas. Although cones are most diverse in tropical seas, a few species extend into the cooler waters of the Western Cape.

This species has a moderately extended spire with slight steps between the whorls. The cleaned shell (as depicted in most guides) is generally off-white with chocolate flame-like markings, but in life this is covered with a yellow-brown semi-transparent outer layer (periostracum). Body dark brown with white eyestalks. There are several regional colour variants.
taxon_text_3_2598:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_2599:
Has a limited distribution, but nevertheless exhibits local variation within this narrow range, resulting in the recognition of three sub-species which may or may not be genetically distinct.

Fairly commonly found in sandy pools or under boulders in the intertidal and occurs down to over 50 m depth, usually singly.
taxon_text_5_2600: All cones are predators, feeding on worms, mollusks or, in the case of some larger species, even on fish. They have a specialised feeding method in which a powerful nerve toxin is secreted by a poison gland and is fed into a hollow harpoon-like radula tooth, which is stabbed into the prey. Some larger fish-eating species can inflict a painful of even dangerous sting and should not be handled, but smaller worm – eating forms are not considered dangerous. This species feeds on small polychaete worms.
taxon_text_6_2601: The egg cases are purse-shaped with a wide unstalked base. One to three crawling young emerge form each egg case.
taxon_text_7_2602: Few other cone shells occur in the cooler waters of the south Western Cape, of which the most common is the Elongate Cone C. mozambicus (which confusingly does not occur in Mozambique). That species has a much narrower, more elongate shell with a more pointed spire and is usually pale yellowish-brown with darker (or lighter) flames or spots. The Variable cone C. tinianus takes over as the most common species east of Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_8_2603:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 202)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 122).
taxon_text_1_2606:
Cone shells are a diverse and very distinctive group, easily recognized by the smooth, strongly conical shape of the shell, with its short spire, elongate, narrow aperture and thin, smooth outer lip. The outer lip is never toothed or pleated, as in other more-or less-conical groups, such as olive shells and marginellas. Although cones are most diverse in tropical seas, a few species extend into the cooler waters of the Western Cape.

This species is fairly large with an unusually elongate and slender shell (hence common name) with a fairly pointed and extended spire and is normally pale yellow to brown in colour with brown spots or flames. The body is mottled brown.
taxon_text_3_2608:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London (but not Mozambique, despite its name!).
taxon_text_4_2609: The only common cold-water cone to be found along the West Coast. Usually seen singly under rocks and in crevices, often partially buried in sand.
taxon_text_5_2610: All cones are predators, feeding on worms, mollusks or, in the case of some larger species, even on fish. They have a specialised feeding method in which a powerful nerve toxin is secreted by a poison gland and is fed into a hollow, harpoon-like radula tooth, which is stabbed into the prey. Some larger fish eating species can inflict a painful of even dangerous sting and should not be handled, but smaller worm – eating forms are not considered dangerous. This species feeds on polychaete worms.
taxon_text_6_2611: The egg cases are more or less cylindrical with a thick stalk. Each contains 19-23 eggs, which emerge as crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2612: Few other cone shells occur in the cooler waters of the south Western Cape, of which the most common is the Algoa cone C. algoensis. That species is broader with a shorter spire in which there is a step between the whorls and is usually brown with white markings. The Variable cone C. tinianus takes over as the most common species east of Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_8_2613:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 202).

Kilburn, RN (1971). A revision of the littoral Conidae (Mollusca: Gastropoda) of the Cape Province. Annals of the Natal Museum, 21(1), 37–54.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 122).
taxon_text_1_2616:
Distinctive species with a heavy, globular shell, the outer surface of which is sculptured with flattened, spiral ridges, but covered with a thick, fibrous brown periostracum in life. Aperture with a short but deep siphonal canal, outer lip thickened, with obvious ridges-like teeth along its inner margin. Inner lip with a broad, shield-like callus that bears granules anteriorly and has 5-6 obvious transverse ridges across its face. Operculum oval and horny.

External colour brown when alive, due to thick periostracum and associated fouling. Cleaned or washed-up shells white, flecked or mottled with light brown. Interior white.
taxon_text_3_2618:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2619: A mostly subtidal species trawled at up to 85 m depth, but also found at night by divers on shallow sandy substrata. No further details known.
taxon_text_5_2620: Details unknown, but thought to be scavenger gathering around fish guts, dead invertebrates or other offal.
taxon_text_6_2621: The egg capsules are flattened, leaf-like and born on a long thin stalk attached to the substratum, resembling transparent lollipops on a stick!
taxon_text_7_2622: The heavy, oval, spirally-ridged shell and distinctive sculpturing on the aperture make this species easy to identify. A second member of the genus, D. ventricosa, does occur in the region, but is much smaller (27 mm), lighter, lacks the conspicuous ridges across the inner lip and is usually pink in colour.
taxon_text_8_2623:
Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 99).

Steyn, DG & Lussi, M (2005). Offshore Shells of Southern Africa: A pictorial guide to more than 750 Gastropods. Published by the authors (p. 130).
taxon_text_1_2636: Fairly large shell, with longish spire and extended, but not elongate, siphonal canal. The whorls of the shell are decorated with numerous fine spiral ridges. External colour light brown, interior of shell white; foot bright orange-red with white spots.
taxon_text_3_2638:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2639: Fairly common and distinctive species found both intertidally and on deeper reefs. Little else is know about its biology.
taxon_text_5_2640: Predatory, has been seen feeding on other gastropods, such as the Smooth turban-shell Turbo cidaris.
taxon_text_6_2641: The egg cases are unusually large and club shaped, consisting of a fat oval bulb borne on an elongate slender stalk. Despite their large size, only 4-7 unusually large crawling young emerge from each egg case.
taxon_text_7_2642: Fairly easily recognized by the fine spiral ridges of the shell combined with bright red foot. The more knobbed south and easy coast variety identified by Kilburn and Rippey is now recognised as being a separate species Kilburnia heymenanni. Could also be confused with the Long-siphoned whelk Africofusus ocelliferus which has a somewhat similar shape and also a red body, but that species has a much longer siphonal canal and fewer, courser ridges on the shell.
taxon_text_8_2643:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 102).
taxon_text_1_2646:
As a group marginellids are fairly distinctive. They have a smooth, glossy shell with an elongate, narrow aperture and a correspondingly short spire. The outer lip is thickened (unlike in cones for example) and the inner lip bears a series of distinctive ridges or pleats. There is no operculum and in live specimens the broad foot is often brightly patterned. Species identification is much more complicated, as there are a large number of often localized species (over 60 in South Africa), many with similar colour patterns. Only a few of the more distinctive and common species are treated in this guide.

This species is one of the largest found in the region and can be recognized by its size, the wavy grey and white ‘cloudy’ pattern on the heavy shell, the grey areas often edged with black lines; the dark spots on the strongly thickened outer lip and the fact that there are four pleats on the inner lip. In the living animal the foot is off-white with opaque white to almost bright green patches and red spots.
taxon_text_3_2648:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to  East London.
taxon_text_4_2649: Not usually found intertidally, but fairly often seen by divers on shallow reefs, and to a depth of about 74 m. Usually found shallowly buried in sand in the vicinity of rocks, or crawling rapidly across the sand surface in search of prey.
taxon_text_5_2650: Predatory, feeding on other gastropods. Details unknown for this species, but related species immobilize their prey with a poison gland, envelop the victim in the foot and drag it beneath the sand surface for consumption.
taxon_text_6_2651: Members of the group lay domed or lens-shaped egg capsules that are attached to rocks or shells. Each capsule contains a single embryo.
taxon_text_7_2652: There are many similar species in this group, but this one is fairly easily recognized by its exceptionally large size and clouded markings.
taxon_text_8_2653:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 200)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 114).

Veldsman, SG (2019). Taxonomic review of the genus Marginella: dividing the African coast into marine provinces and Sub-Provinces. PhD Thesis. University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa.
taxon_text_1_2656:
As a group marginellids are fairly distinctive. They have a smooth, glossy shell with an elongate, narrow aperture and a correspondingly short spire. The outer lip is thickened (unlike in cone shells for example) and the inner lip bears a series of distinctive ridges or pleats. There is no operculum and in live specimens the broad foot is often brightly patterned. Species identification in much more complicated, as there are a large number of often localized species (over 60 in South Africa), many with similar colour patterns. Only a few of the more distinctive and common species are treated in this guide.

This species is one of the most common on the Cape Peninsula and is best recognized by a distinctive concavity in the inner margin of the outer lip near ‘shoulder’ level, but this is unfortunately never visible in images of live animals! Otherwise, it is identified by the attractive pink and brown (‘rosy’) flares that run longitudinally and spirally around the shell. The foot is off-white with bright white patches and red spots.
taxon_text_3_2658:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution between Saldanha Bay and Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_2659: Quite common low in the intertidal and in shallow water, usually under boulders or in sandy pools. Crawls rapidly along with the siphon held upright and the enlarged and beautifully patterned foot extended.
taxon_text_5_2660: Predatory, feeding on other gastropods. Details unknown for this species, but related species immobilize their prey with a poison gland, envelop the victim in the foot and drag it beneath the sand surface for consumption.
taxon_text_6_2661: Members of the group lay domed or lens-shaped egg capsules that are attached to rocks of shells. Each capsule contains a single embryo.
taxon_text_7_2662: There are many similar species in this group, and this one is best recognized by the distinctive notch in the outer lip, after which the common name is derived. There are several other similarly-coloured species in the region though and thus identifications made without examining the shell should be treated with caution. Distinguished from the larger M. nebulosa by pinker and more intricate colour pattern, smaller size and occurrence in the intertidal.
taxon_text_8_2663:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 200)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 114).

Veldsman, SG (2019). Taxonomic review of the genus Marginella: dividing the African coast into marine provinces and Sub-Provinces. PhD Thesis. University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa.
taxon_text_1_2666:
As a group marginellids are fairly distinctive. They have a smooth, glossy shell with an elongate, narrow aperture and a correspondingly short spire. The outer lip is thickened (unlike in cones for example) and the inner lip bears a series of distinctive ridges or pleats. There is no operculum and in live specimens the broad foot is often brightly patterned. Species identification is much more complicated, as there are large numbers of often localized species (over 60 in South Africa), many with similar colour patterns. Only a few of the more distinctive and common species are treated in this guide.

This relatively small species has an almost cylindrical, semi-transparent, white to pale fawn shell with a short spire and four very oblique pleats on the inner lip. In live specimens the mottled body colours show through the shell. The broad, triangular foot is light grey with numerous white spots and blotches.
taxon_text_3_2668:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Cape Hangklip.
taxon_text_4_2669: Typically found in sheltered sandy sites and particularly common in Langebaan Lagoon. Crawls actively around partially buried just under the sand surface in search of bivalves. Sometimes gathers in large numbers around carrion.
taxon_text_5_2670: Predatory, feeding mostly on bivalves. Behaviour unknown for this species, but related species immobilize their prey with a poison gland, envelop the victim in the foot and drag it beneath the sand surface to be consumed.
taxon_text_6_2671: Lays domed egg capsules about 3 mm in diameter that are typically attached to the shells of other molluscs. Each capsule contains a single embryo that emerges as a fully-developed crawling juvenile.
taxon_text_7_2672: The transparent, almost colourless shell and white-spotted foot distinguish this from most other regional species in this complicated and diverse group.
taxon_text_8_2673:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 200)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 114, as Volverina capensis).

Veldsman, SG (2019). Taxonomic review of the genus Marginella: dividing the African coast into marine provinces and Sub-Provinces. PhD Thesis. University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa.
taxon_text_1_2676: Fairly small, delicate whelk with an elongate, pointed spire and small aperture with a small callus (smooth area on inner lip of aperture). Each whorl of the shell is ornamented with axial (longitudinal) ribs, these numbering 12-14 on the largest whorl. Each rib crossed by transverse furrows that break it into a series of about five transverse ridges. Shell colour white, often with a dark band running across the lower part of each whorl.  Body transparent with white speckles, siphon usually held upright and extended.
taxon_text_3_2678:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2679: Fairly common in clean sand in intertidal pools, sheltered sands and to depths of about 30 m. Usually seen ploughing along the sand surface with the elongate siphon extended in search of prey.
taxon_text_5_2680: Details unknown, but members of this genus are normally scavengers, gathering quickly around dead animals or carrion such as fish bait.
taxon_text_6_2681: No details are available on the reproductive biology of this species.
taxon_text_7_2682: There are several Nassarius species in the region of which this is the smallest and most delicate. Other related species have much broader shells with a larger aperture bearing a more marked callus on inner lip.
taxon_text_8_2683:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 196).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 100).
taxon_text_1_2686: Medium-sized, fairly broad whelk with shortish, tapering spire that shows distinct shoulders between whorls. Last whorl with about 11 low axial ribs that show only as low rounded knobs. These are crossed by numerous fine spiral ridges, that provide the dominant surface pattern. Shell colour brown with distinctive purple patch at tip of aperture. Callus extends about halfway across underside. Body white with brown and yellow spots, base of siphon purple.
taxon_text_3_2688:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2689: Common in sand in sheltered areas such as lagoons and down to a depth of 95 m. Shells of this species are commonly occupied by small hermit crabs.
taxon_text_5_2690: Details unknown, but members of this genus are normally scavengers, gathering quickly around dead animals or carrion such as fish bait.
taxon_text_6_2691: No details are available on the reproductive biology of this species. Individuals are often seen with egg capsules attached to their shells and these may have been deposited there by other members of the same species.
taxon_text_7_2692: There are several Nassarius species in the region but this one is easily recognized by the purple mark at the tip of the aperture.
taxon_text_8_2693:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 196).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 101).
taxon_text_1_2696:
Shell conical and whelk-shaped with a large aperture and relatively short spire, each whorl of the shell with a series of weak, flattened spiral ridges. The ridges are sometimes patterned with alternating bands of brown and white marks, but colouration is extremely variable (hence the species name ‘dubia’!) and ranges from plain brown or grey to bearing marked dark flames on a pale background. Internal colour usually dark purple to brown, often with paler bands.

The fact that this species extends far higher into the intertidal than other whelks is also a useful identification feature in the field.
taxon_text_3_2698:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2699:
Very common, but relatively small species found remarkably high into the intertidal and the only whelk to occur up into the Littorina Zone, where it nestles in crevices, emerging to feed on periwinkles, barnacles and small limpets, which it attacks by drilling, or though the opercular opening.

As they can occur in high densities (86 per square m) the whelks are responsible for predating about 12 % of the periwinkle population each year, and as many as 45% of the population of the barnacle Tetraclita serrata, hence probably maintaining free spaces within the barnacle beds.
taxon_text_5_2700: The egg cases are purse-shaped with a pair of short ear-like lobes at the top and are borne on a very short stalk. Each capsule contains many hundreds of eggs, but only about 12-47 of these develop into crawling young, which emerge through an ‘escape hatch’ in the egg case, the remaining eggs are nurse-cells that are eaten during development.
taxon_text_6_2701: The egg cases are purse-shaped with a pair of short ear-like lobes at the top and are borne on a very short stalk. Each capsule contains many hundreds of eggs, but only about 12-47 of these develop into crawling young, which emerge through an ‘escape hatch’ in the egg case, the remaining eggs are nurse-cells that are eaten during development.
taxon_text_7_2702: There are several related species that occur on the same shores. The Girdled dogwhelk Trochia cingulata is bluish-grey to white, often has a series of pronounced spiral ridges on each whorl and is found lower on the shore and only on the west coast. The Scaly dogwhelk N. squamosa is larger with a grid of numerous intersecting fine ridges on the shell, which is almost always covered by the hydroid Hydractinia altispina. The banded dogwhelk N. wahlbergi is larger (34 mm) with a longer spire and is white with fine spiral grooves and usually a marked brown band around the last whorl.
taxon_text_8_2703:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 192).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 90).

McQuaid, CD (1985). Differential effects of predation by the intertidal whelk Nucella dubia (Kr.) on Littorina africana knysnaensis (Phillipi) and the barnacle Tetraclita serrata Darwin. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 89(2-3), 97-107.
taxon_text_1_2706: Shell moderately large, fairly plump and whelk-shaped, outer surface ornamented with intersecting transverse and spiral ridges that form a rectangular network with scale–like granules where the ridges intersect (hence common name). External colour light brown, internal colour off-white. Live animals are almost always completely covered by the prickly orange hydroid Hydractinia altispira, which is unknown other than on the shells of this whelk and thus appears to be an obligate commensal.
taxon_text_3_2708:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2709:
