Fairly common and usually found in low shore pools and gullies and in kelp holdfasts. Occurs to a depth of about 50 m. Easily recognised by the intersecting grid of ridges and external coating or orange hydroids, the stinging cells of which are thought to repel a variety of predators.

Mussels are known to entangle and trap these whelks using their byssal threads and this is thought to be a defense mechanism against these predators although it is hard to argue that this is intentional. Little else is known about the biology of this species, although it is assumed to be a drilling predator, like other members of the genus.
taxon_text_5_2710: A predator, feeding on mussels and other sedentary invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_2711: The egg cases are about 10 mm tall, elongate and upright with a flattered concave tip. It is thought that crawling young emerge, as in other related species.
taxon_text_7_2712: There are several related species that occur on the same shores. The Common dogwhelk Nucella dubia is smaller, has weak rounded ridges and is usually plain brown or grey, or has flames of rows of darker brown colour, and occurs high in the intertidal. The Girdled dogwhelk Trochia cingulata is bluish-grey to white, often has a series of pronounced spiral ridges on each whorl and is found lower on the shore and only on the west coast. The banded dogwhelk N. wahlbergi is larger (34 mm) with a longer spire and is white with fine spiral grooves and usually a marked brown band around the last whorl.
taxon_text_8_2713:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 192).

Day, RW, Barkai, A & Wickens, PA (1991). Trapping of three drilling whelks by two species of mussel. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 149(1), 109-122.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 91).
taxon_text_1_2716: Shell conical and whelk-shaped with a relatively small aperture, slightly extended siphonal canal and long, sharp spire. Surface of each whorl sculpted with a series of narrow, flattened spiral ridges.  Colour white with last whorl of the shell usually bearing a distinctive broad, chocolate-brown band.
taxon_text_3_2718:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2719: Relatively uncommon and range-restricted species found under intertidal boulders and in lowshore pools to a depth of several meters. No specific information about biology, but presumed to be a drilling predator like others species in the genus.
taxon_text_5_2720: Presumed to be a predator, but prey unknown.
taxon_text_6_2721: Not documented, but presumed to lay egg cases within which the eggs develop into crawling young, as in other members of the genus.
taxon_text_7_2722: This species is fairly easily recognized by the flat ridges on the shell and by its colour pattern (off white with a wide brown band on last whorl). There are, however, several related species that occur on the same shores. The Common dogwhelk Nucella dubia is smaller, has weak rounded ridges and is usually plan brown or grey, or has flames of rows of darker brown colour, and occurs high in the intertidal. The Girdled dogwhelk Trochia cingulata is bluish-grey to white, often has a series of pronounced spiral ridges on each whorl and is found lower on the shore and only on the west coast. The scaly dogwhelk N. squamosa is larger with a grid of numerous intersecting fine ridges on the shell, which is almost always covered by the hydroid Hydractinia altispina.
taxon_text_8_2723:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 192).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 90).
taxon_text_1_2726: Shell conical and whelk-shaped with a relatively small aperture and relatively short spire. Shell ornamentation very variable. The ‘typical’ form usually illustrated in guides is easy to recognize and has 1-4 very prominent, white, flat-topped ridges running around each whorl. These ridges are often absent though and in these cases the shell is smoothly blue-grey. Internal colour usually brownish with white bands corresponding to external ridges (where present).
taxon_text_3_2728:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2729:
A characteristic and well-known west-coast species and one of the earliest shells to be described from South Africa. The typical banded form is very characteristic and easily recognised, but smooth forms are common and less easy to distinguish.

Often aggregates around clumps of mussels in the mid to low intertidal and is responsible for considerable mortality amongst smaller mussels – indeed  the whelks can be seen creating clearings in the mussel beds as they feed (first photo)!

Most drilled mussels are small (<30 mm). Predation rates are quite slow at less than 0.1 mussels per whelk per day, but as the whelks can reach densities of more than 500 individuals per square meter they are a significant cause of mussel mortality (500 whelks x 0.1 mussels per day x 365 days per year = 18 250 mussels killed per square meter per year!). The mussels are able to retaliate by tying down the whelks with byssal threads, preventing them from moving to new feeding locations!
taxon_text_5_2730: Prey mainly on mussels, but also on slipper limpets, barnacles, etc., drilling through the shell by alternately scraping away shell material with the radula and applying an acid gland to soften the shell.
taxon_text_6_2731: Lays characteristic egg cases that are about 4-5 mm tall with a fairly long stalk and wedge-shaped body with a flat top, protected by a distinct overhanging ‘canopy’. Each eggs case contains a few eggs that develop into crawling young, plus numerous nurse cells that are consumed by the embryos during development.
taxon_text_7_2732: Easily recognized by the broad flat ridges on the shell where these are present, but smooth individuals easily confused with the Common dogwhelk N. dubia. However, that species occurs higher in the intertidal, has weak, rounded ridges on each whorl of the shell, and is usually either plain brown or grey or has flames of rows of darker brown colour. The scaly dogwhelk N. squamosa is larger with a grid of numerous intersecting fine ridges on the shell, which is almost always covered by the hydroid Hydractinia altispina, while the Banded dogwhelk N. wahlbergi is also larger with a longer spire, and is white with a broad brown band around the last whorl.
taxon_text_8_2733:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 192).

Day, RW, Barkai, A & Wickens, PA (1991). Trapping of three drilling whelks by two species of mussel. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 149(1), 109-122.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 90).

Wickens, PA & Griffiths, CL (1985). Predation by Nucella cingulata (Linnaeus, 1771) on mussels, particularly Aulacomya ater (Molina, 1782). The Veliger, 27(4), 366-374.
taxon_text_1_2736: Small whelk heavily and attractively ornamented with both bold spiral ridges and transverse ribs, the two intersecting to form a grid-like pattern of raised ridges, the points of intersection being raised as nodules. Siphonal canal short, external colour mottled white and brown, interior colour white to pale purple.
taxon_text_3_2738:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2739: Fairly common and small species usually found on the underside of rocks in the low intertidal, but extends down to at least 37 m. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_2740: Diet unknown, but members of this family are predatory on various other invertebrates including molluscs, barnacles and worms.
taxon_text_6_2741: Not known for this species, but most related species lay egg cases from which the young emerge as crawling juveniles.
taxon_text_7_2742: Can be confused with O. purpuriodes, which has similar external sculpturing, but is distinguished by the purple external stripes and internal colour that gives the species its name.
taxon_text_8_2743:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 192).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 82 as Ocenebra fenestrata).
taxon_text_1_2746: Small whelk heavily and attractively ornamented with both bold spiral ridges and transverse ribs, the two intersecting to form a grid-like pattern, the points of intersection being raised as scale-like nodules. Internal surface of outer lip strongly ridged. External colour off-white with two faint purple bands, internal colour white around margin, becoming purple deeper inside.
taxon_text_3_2748:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_2749: Little known and small, but fairly common species with a limited distribution. Found on the underside of rocks from mid tide to about 40 m depth.
taxon_text_5_2750: A predator, reported to feed on small tube-worms.
taxon_text_6_2751: The egg cases about 3-4 mm long, vase-shaped with a short, narrow stalk. About 10 crawling young emerge from each egg case.
taxon_text_7_2752: Two other regional species in the genus also have similar strong external sculpture, but lack the purple colour that gives this species its name.
taxon_text_8_2753: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 89 as Ocenebra purpuroides).
taxon_text_1_2756:
As a group marginellids are fairly distinctive. They have a smooth, glossy shell with an elongate, narrow aperture and a correspondingly short spire. The outer lip is thickened (unlike in cones for example) and the inner lip bears a series of distinctive ridges or pleats. There is no operculum and in live specimens the broad foot is often brightly patterned. Species identification in much more complicated, as there are a large number of often localized species (over 60 in South Africa), many with similar or variable colour patterns. Only a few of the more distinctive and common species are treated in this guide.

This small species has a cylindrical shell that has a short spire and four strongly oblique pleats on the inner lip. The colour pattern is distinctive and unusual, as there are two very different colour forms. The one form has a white shell with a single very wide central brown band and the other form has two narrow bands where the ends of the broader band would be located. The foot is pale and transparent with a few opaque white spots.
taxon_text_3_2758:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2759: Very common intertidally and numerous specimens can be found under intertidal rocks, or on shallow reefs. The reason for the two distinctive colour forms is not known, but both occur at the same sites and intermediate forms seem not to occur!
taxon_text_5_2760: A micro-predator though to feed on minute gastropods and on polychaete worms.
taxon_text_6_2761: Not known, but related species lay domed egg capsules about 3 mm in diameter that are typically attached to the shells of other molluscs. Each capsule contains a single embryo that emerges as a fully developed crawling juvenile.
taxon_text_7_2762: The unusual colour patterns of this species are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_2763:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 200).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 114).

Veldsman, SG (2019). Taxonomic review of the genus Marginella: dividing the African coast into marine provinces and Sub-Provinces. PhD Thesis. University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa.
taxon_text_1_2766:
Shell cap-shaped, tall, and unusually light, characteristic in shape, being far more elongate and laterally compressed than in other regional species. The opening is also concave, when viewed end-on, such that the shell can fit tightly against the curved surface of a narrow kelp stipe (stem).

External surface dull brown, sculpted by faint radiating ridges. Interior surface pearly light brown. The fact that this species is only found living on kelps is also a useful identification character.
taxon_text_2_2767: Shell up to about 90 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2768:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_2769:
An unusual species both in terms of its elongate, boat-shaped shell and because of its unique habitat, which is restricted to the fronds and stipes of the Bamboo kelp Ecklonia maxima.

Juveniles are found on the primary and secondary fronds of the kelp and are flat, having not yet adopted the characteristic curved opening of adults, since they live on flat surfaces. At a length of approximately 40 mm surviving juveniles move onto the stem or stipe of the kelp and progressively adopt the characteristic elongated, curved shape to allow themselves to remain tightly attached to the narrow, rounded shape of the stipe.

Many kelps host numerous juveniles on the head and fronds (up to 46), but usually only one or two adults are found on the stipes of each individual kelp, suggestive of a high juvenile mortality rate. Their grazing activity probably helps maintain the stipes free of epiphytic algae and thus reduces drag, in turn reducing the likelihood of the kelp being uprooted during storms.

Kelp limpets are a favoured food item of octopuses, which climb up into the kelp canopy and drill into their fairly thin shells.

Growth rates have not been measured in this species.
taxon_text_5_2770: Herbivorous, feeding on algae growing on the stipes of the host kelps.
taxon_text_6_2771: Sexes are separate, but a detailed analysis of reproductive cycles and fecundity has not been undertaken for this species. Spawning probably occurs in May, however, (as in many other local species) since animals sampled in April had mature gonads and those sampled in June and August were mostly spent. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2772: The unique shell shape and habits of this species mean it is unlikely to be confused with other regional limpets.
taxon_text_8_2773:
Arendse, A (2021). ‘Distribution and morphology of the Kelp limpet Cymbula compressa (Linnaeus, 1758) in False Bay, South Africa’. Bachelor’s Dissertation. University of Cape Town, Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).
taxon_text_1_2776: Shell cap-shaped, large, moderately tall and heavy. Outer surface grayish, usually marked with distinctive granite-like chevron or zig-zag patterns and with about 15 major radiating ribs that project moderately beyond the margin, the posterior 5 ribs being stronger than the others. Outer surface often heavily eroded though and colour pattern then lost. Inner surface of shell with narrow black margin and chocolate-brown to black centre, separated by a broad white or brown/yellow mottled band. Juveniles much flatter and attractively flecked with radiating rows of iridescent green spots.
taxon_text_2_2777: Shell large, up to 80 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2778:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to about Danger Point.
taxon_text_4_2779:
A large and often common species that is a characteristic resident of the mid to low intertidal zone. Most abundant along the west coast, where it attains spectacular densities, especially in sheltered bays. Occupies a home scar when the tide is out and when wetted ranges up to about 75 cm away from the home scar to graze on algae and diatoms.

Grows more slowly and lives longer than the similar and co-occurring C. oculus, attaining 35 mm in the first year and reaching maximum size after about 7-8 years, which is also the calculated life-expectancy.
taxon_text_5_2780: Herbivorous, feeding on a variety of algae, as well as on diatoms. The vast congregations often found in sheltered bays along the west coast appear to subsist mostly on drift algae that accumulate in these sites.
taxon_text_6_2781: Sexes are separate and has an exceptionally large gonad that can account for 50% of the flesh weight when mature. The sex ratio is 82 females per 100 males. Spawning takes place once a year, gonads reaching peak maturity in May, with spawning taking place in June. Fecundity is the greatest of all regional species examined at 4-5.5 million eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2782: Most easily confused with the Goat’s eye limpet C. oculus which has a similar shell shape and habitat. However, C. oculus is most common on the south coast, has more even and fewer ribs and lacks the zig-zag exterior patterning. The interior of the shell also has a broad black margin and a white/cream centre.
taxon_text_8_2783:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).
taxon_text_1_2786: Shell cap-shaped, very flat, almost perfectly oval, outer surface with about 80 fine ribs that alternate in size, are slightly prickly and do not project beyond the smooth margin of the shell. External colour pale, shot with numerous attractive pink rays. Internal shell colour with a pale oval centre, surrounded by radiating rays of blue against a white background.
taxon_text_2_2787: Shell moderately large, up to 80 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2788:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2789: Relatively uncommon and found low in the intertidal, but more commonly on shallow reefs down to a depth of about 11 m. Feeds exclusively on encrusting coralline algae. Mostly does not form a home scar and ranges widely, feeding both by day and by night and independent of the tide, often not returning to the original position after feeding excursions.
taxon_text_6_2791: Sexes are separate and a broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton. Sex ratio, breeding seasons and fecundity have not been documented for this species.
taxon_text_7_2792: The flat profile, smooth oval outline, numerous fine ribs on the shell and pinkish colour pattern make this species fairly easy to distinguish from other regional limpets.
taxon_text_8_2793:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 38).
taxon_text_1_2796: Shell cap-shaped, large, moderately tall and heavy. Outer surface pale grey or greenish-brown, marked with about 10 broad radiating ribs that project moderately beyond the margin. Outer surface often heavily eroded and/or encrusted with coralline or foliose algae, the latter often completely concealing the shell. Inner surface of shell with wide black margin and light brown centre. Juveniles are much flatter and with yellow and black markings, often flecked with iridescent green.
taxon_text_2_2797: Shell large, up to 100 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2798:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2799:
A large and common species that is a characteristic resident of the mid-intertidal zone, especially along the south coast. Occupies a home scar when the tide is out and when wetted ranges up to about 1.5 m away from the home scar to graze on algae and lichens (acting much like cattle in a meadow), playing an important role in controlling algal growth. Indeed where they are abundant most algal clumps on this level on the shore are in fact growing on the shells of the limpets themselves – the only surfaces they cannot graze!

Growth is very rapid relative to other limpets, a length of 56 mm being attained in the first year of life and 70 mm by the end of the second year. Few individuals survive beyond 3 years in age.

The commensal flatworn Notocomplana erythrotaenia is commonly found under the shell between the foot and the mantle.
taxon_text_5_2800: Herbivorous, feeding on a wide range of algal types, as well as on lichens and diatoms, indicating that this species in an unselective feeder.
taxon_text_6_2801: Unusual amongst local limpets as changes sex, small individual initially maturing as males and then becoming female in their second or third year. The population consists largely of smaller males and relatively fewer larger females. The sex ratio is 43 females for each 100 males. Spawning takes place in about September each year and fecundity ranges between about 850 000 and 1 million eggs per female. Broadcast spawners, larvae developing in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2802:
Most often confused with the Granite limpet C. granatina, which occupies the same habitat, but is more common on the west coast. That species is taller and has about 15 major ribs and a granite-like chevron pattern on the upper surface (although this is often eroded). The colour of the inner surface of the shell is also quite different in C. granatina, which has a narrow black margin and a black centre.

The Granular limpet C. granularis has about 50 much finer, granular ribs and interior of the shell has a narrow black border and brown centre.
taxon_text_8_2803:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974a). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, GM (1974b). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa, 3. Growth-rates. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 161-193.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).
taxon_text_1_2806: Shell thin, elongate-oval and fairly flat, ‘cap-shaped’ with the aperture covering the full surface area. Apex displaced about two-thirds way towards anterior end. Outer surface of shell with fine, but distinct radial striations. Colour variable, west coast specimen usually pale with broad dark brown to black rays, south coast specimens brown with darker rays and sometimes a few green flecks.
taxon_text_3_2808:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_2809: Found from mid to low intertidal on rocky shores and under boulders, emerging at night to feed using its powerful radula to scrape algae off exposed rocks.
taxon_text_6_2811: No species-specific information, but other regional Helcion species spawn mainly in summer, the larvae developing in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2812: Easy to confuse with the very similar Broad rayed-limpet H. pruinosus, but that species has a broader shell profile and lacks radial ribs on the shell. Colour also differs, with H. pruinosus usually being brown with distinctive radiating rows of iridescent green to blue spots.
taxon_text_8_2813:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 37).
taxon_text_1_2816: Shell tall and conical (‘cap-shaped’), oval in outline, the aperture covering the full surface area. Apex recurved and strongly displaced to the anterior end. Outer surface of shell sculptured by about 26 distinctive radiating ribs, each bearing numerous small, sharp prickles (can be partially eroded in older specimens). Shell colour brown with black ribs and black interior.
taxon_text_3_2818:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal south coast.
taxon_text_4_2819:
Occupies a distinct habitat concealed in rock crevices or under rocks in mid- to high intertidal zone, but can be abundant in such sites.

Grazers, scraping algae and lichens off the rocks with a powerful radula.

Growth rate about 5-6 mm per year and maximum age about 5-6 years.
taxon_text_6_2821: A protandrous hermaphrodite, males becoming mature at an age of about one year and size of about 10-12 mm shell length and then changing sex into females at an age of two years and shell length of about 16 mm. The resulting sex ratio in the population is about two males to one female. Spawning takes place mostly in summer (Nov/Dec) with a second smaller spawning in Autumn (April) and the larvae develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2822: The prickly ribs in the shell are very distinctive and make it unlikely that this species will be confused with others, although two other smooth-shelled species of Helcion co-occur on rocky shores in the region.
taxon_text_8_2823:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170).

Gray, DR & Hodgson, AN (2003). Growth and reproduction in the high-shore South African limpet Helcion pectunculus (Mollusca: Patellogastropoda). African Zoology, 38(2), 371-386.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 37).
taxon_text_1_2826: Shell thin, broad elongate-oval and fairly flat, ‘cap-shaped’ with the aperture covering the full surface area. Apex displaced about 75% way towards anterior end. Outer surface of shell smooth, with only faint radial striations. Colour brown, often shot with numerous distinctive and beautiful iridescent green spots and lines.
taxon_text_3_2828:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern west coast to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2829: Common from mid to low intertidal on rocky shores and under boulders, emerging at night, particularly at spring tides, to feed using its powerful radula to scrape algae off exposed rocks.
taxon_text_6_2831: Sex ratio 1:1 in the west, but with significantly more males in the eastern populations. Spawn mainly in summer, the larvae developing in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2832:
Easy to confuse with the similar Slim rayed-limpet H. dunkeri. but that species has a more slender profile and fine radial ribs on the shell. Colour in H. dunkeri also differs, usually being white to yellow or brown, often with darker rays or entire segments; although iridescent spots can occur, these are also far less conspicuous than in H. pruinosus.

Can also be confused with juveniles of Cymbula oculus and C. granatina, both of which are also flat and flecked with iridescent green. However in these species the outline is broken by distinct projecting ribs, whereas the margin of H. pruinosus is smooth.
taxon_text_8_2833:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170).

Henninger, TO & Hodgson, AN (2001). The reproductive cycle of Helcion pruinosus (Patellogastropoda) on two South African boulder shores. Journal of Molluscan Studies, 67(3), 385-394.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 37).
taxon_text_1_2836:
Shell cap-shaped, very large, tall, heavy and almost perfectly oval in outline. Outer surface pale brown, marked with numerous pale, fine, radiating ribs that barely project beyond the margin. Outer surface often heavily eroded and/or encrusted with coralline algae. Larger shells often also marked by the oval scars formed by smaller individuals settling on the adults. Inner surface of shell white, with a light brown centre.

The characteristic habitat, on the extreme low shore adjacent to stands of kelp, is also a useful identification feature.
taxon_text_2_2837: Shell large, up to 90 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2838:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2839:
A large and iconic species that is most abundant on the west coast, where it reaches high densities low on the shore on moderately exposed sites. South coast individuals are both rarer and smaller. Usually found on encrusting coralline algae, within which each individual creates a distinct home-scar. Large individuals often have juveniles living on their backs.  Move off the home scar when immersed, but seldom range more then 60 cm from their scar. Feed on both coralline algae and diatoms, but also show a characteristic behaviour of trapping kelp fronds, the animal lifting the margin of its shell and snapping this down to capture and then graze on kelp fronds that drift beneath the shell in the waves.

Threatened by the invasive Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis that has moved into its characteristic habitat and now forms almost monospecific beds there, displacing the limpets from many sites where they were once common.
taxon_text_5_2840: Herbivorous, feeding on algae, particularly the fronds of kelps.
taxon_text_6_2841: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio is 87 females per 100 males. Spawning takes place once a year, gonads reaching peak maturity in May, with spawning taking place in June and to a lesser extent July. Fecundity averages about 3 million eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2842: The tall, heavy shell and its lack of projecting ribs, along with the characteristic habitat, make this one of the easier limpet species to identify.
taxon_text_8_2843:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 166).
taxon_text_1_2846: Shell cap-shaped, large, relatively tall and heavy. Exterior surface white or pale brown, very frequently encrusted with coralline or other algae; marked with ca 20 strong angular ribs that project fairly evenly beyond the margin. Extent of ribs varies with habitat and age, and may often be heavily eroded. Sides of foot distinctively white, speckled with grey. Inner surface of shell white, sometimes with light-brown centre.
taxon_text_2_2847: Shell large, up to 80 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2848:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2849: A large and common species found in the lower intertidal, in rock pools and down to a depth of about 6 m. On the Southern and Eastern coast defends gardens of filamentous red algae, but on the west coast does not form gardens and moves around on the shore grazing on encrusting algae and associated micro-organisms. Growth rate not documented.
taxon_text_5_2850: Herbivorous, feeding on a wide range of algae. The gut also contains copious quantities of sand, as well as diatoms, forams, sponge-spicules, etc., suggesting unselective rasping of the substratum.
taxon_text_6_2851: Sexes are separate, and the sex ratio is 118 females per 100 males. Spawning takes place once a year, gonads reaching peak maturity in April with spawning taking place in May and June. Fecundity averages about 1.3 million eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2852: Could be confused with the Giant limpet S. tabularis, but that species grows much larger, maintains an algal garden, lacks the speckles on the foot and has a distinctive pink inner margin to the shell. Also occurs together with the somewhat similarly shaped Goat’s eye limpet Cymbula oculus but that species tends to be flatter with fewer, broader ribs and has a distinctive wide black inner margin to the shell.
taxon_text_8_2853:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 166).
taxon_text_1_2856:
Shell very flat, outer surface with broad, flat ribs which hardly project beyond outline. Shell shape very distinctive, the anterior end extended into a spout-like lobe, such that the shape resembles a pear. Outer surface almost always heavily eroded, encrusted with coralline algae and often marked by scars of juveniles that frequently live on the backs of larger individuals. Inner surface of shell white with blue tinges and with a U- shaped, blue-black muscle scar.

The characteristic habitat, in which dense populations and their gardens create a virtual monoculture on the extreme low shore, is also a very useful identification feature.
taxon_text_3_2858:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to southern border of KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2859:
A very distinctive species both in terms of its unusually flat and distinctively pear-shaped shell, but also its distribution pattern and gardening habits.

Dense populations can monopolize the extreme low intertidal zone of exposed rocky shores, which is termed the ‘cochlear zone’. Populations can achieve massive densities of up to 1700 individuals per square meter. Associated with the paint-like pink coralline algae Chaimberlainium spp. Larger individuals also maintain narrow gardens of fast-growing, fine red algae, which they defend and on which they feed. Juveniles start life on the backs of adults and initially feed on coralline algae, before establishing their own gardens (sometimes on the shells of larger individuals). When an adult dies it is quickly replaced by a juvenile, which moves down off an adjacent adult and occupies its territory, hence maintaining a consistent population density.

Growth is initially fairly rapid with shell length of about 25-40 mm being attained in the first five years of life (depending on site), but growth then slows to about 1 mm per year, suggesting that large individuals may attain ages of at least 15-25 years, far older that any other regional species of limpet.
taxon_text_5_2860: Herbivorous, feeding on algae, initially coralline algae but later also those from their gardens, which they defend, weed and fertilise with their waste products.
taxon_text_6_2861: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio varied in different sites from 50 to 97 females per 100 males. Spawning takes place once a year, gonads reaching peak maturity in May with spawning taking place in June at some sites and over a more protracted period from June to September in others. Fecundity is low compared to other limpet species at between 120 000 and 212 000 eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2862: Unlikely to be confused with other limpets due to the very distinctive flat, pear-shaped shell.
taxon_text_8_2863:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974a). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, GM (1974b). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa, 3. Growth-rates. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 161-193.

Branch, GM (1975). Intraspecific Competition in Patella cochlear Born. Journal of Animal Ecology, 44(1). 263–281.
taxon_text_1_2866:
Shell cap-shaped, medium in size, fairly tall and relatively light. External surface with about 50 fine alternately weaker and stronger ribs that hardly break the smooth, oval outline. Ribs patterned with white scales when in good condition, but frequently shell very eroded, smoothing the ribs and exposing a brown cap. Interior of shell with a dark border and a brown centre, separated by a white band.

The fact that this species occurs higher on the shore than other limpets is also a useful identification feature.
taxon_text_2_2867: Shell up to about 60 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2868:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2869:
An extremely common species that is restricted to the intertidal and most abundant high on the shore, extending well up into the barnacle zone. Maintains a home scar, where the profile of the shell exactly matches that of the rock. Undertakes feeding excursions both at high tide and when the weather is cool, rainy or misty, and is very effective at maintaining the rock surfaces free of algae. This can be demonstrated by placing exclusion cages, or painting closed circles or squares of anti-fouling paint onto the rock, which the limpets will not cross. Within a few weeks excluded areas become completely coated with algae!

Much of the habitat originally occupied by this species has become monopolized by the invasive Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis and there was initially concern that the limpets would be severely impacted, but research has demonstrated that they in fact not only survive but attain a higher density and reproductive output in mussel beds than on un-invaded rocks. They do this by living on the shell valves of individual mussels, which cumulatively provide a much larger surface area than the smooth rock. Although growth is much slower on these restricted territories, the limpets still reach sexual maturity and breed there. Thus mussel beds support a larger number of smaller ‘bonsai’ limpets than were present before invasive mussels established and altered the upper shore.

Growth rates are highly variable between sites, generally being faster on the west coast. The size at one year of age varies from about 20-40 mm and longevity has been estimated at about 6-7 years.
taxon_text_5_2870: Herbivorous, diet depending largely on height on the shore. High-shore individuals feed largely on black lichens and those at lower levels also on a wide range of algal species.
taxon_text_6_2871: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio has been measured at between 66 and 72 females per 100 males. Gonads reached maximum size in May with spawning taking place in June and July. Fecundity varies widely at between 400 000 and 1.7 million eggs per female. Broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2872: The granular external texture and ability to survive higher on the shore than other similar limpets make this species fairly easy to identify. Replaced in KwaZulu-Natal by the very similar S. natalensis, which has black granules on the ribs.
taxon_text_8_2873:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974a). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, GM (1974b). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa, 3. Growth-rates. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 161-193.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).
taxon_text_1_2876:
Shell cap-shaped, fairly flat, outer surface bearing about 11 prominent ribs which project well beyond the margin, giving the shell a characteristic star-shaped of ‘duck’s foot’ outline. Shell externally brown, internally white or blue-white with a narrow black border.

The conspicuous garden of encrusting brown algae surrounding each adult is also a useful identification feature.
taxon_text_2_2877: Shell fairly large, up to 70 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2878:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2879:
Common  in the mid- to lower intertidal, often mixed with Bearded limpets S. barbara and Goat’s Eye limpets Cymbula oculus and at lower levels among more numerous Pear limpets (S. cochlear).

Juveniles are found on the shells of other mollusks, then as they grow these migrate onto the rock surface, initially feeding on coralline algae until they are able to establish their own gardens, which they subsequently defend against other grazers. The limpets cut distinct paths though the garden as they feed, creating edges into which the alga rapidly regrows. This regular cropping system has been shown to both stimulate productivity and reduce the amount of anti-herbivore chemicals produced by the algae!

Growth rates are quite hard to measure accurately in this species as shell shape changes during life and lengths of the ribs on the shell differ greatly between individuals (and are subject to erosion). Grown seems to be slow though, reaching a shell length of 60 mm after only 10-15 years.
taxon_text_5_2880: Herbivorous, juveniles feed on encrusting algae growing on other shells, or on the rock surface, but adults establish their own gardens of the encrusting brown alga Pseudoralfsia verrucosa (referred to as Ralfsia in earlier publications).
taxon_text_6_2881: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio is 77 females per 100 males. Spawning takes place once a year, gonads increasing in size from January to September and spawning taking place sporadically from September to December. Fecundity averages about 500-800 thousand eggs per female. A broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2882: The elongate ribs and resultant star-shaped outline of the shell are characteristic, as is the large, brown algal garden. Could be confused with S. Barbara, which also had fairly distinct ribs, but these are less pronounced and more numerous; also no garden is maintained and the shell is white internally without a dark margin.
taxon_text_8_2883:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, GM (1974a). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 2. Reproductive cycles. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 111-160.

Branch, GM (1974b). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa, 3. Growth-rates. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 41(2), 161-193.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).
taxon_text_1_2886:
Shell very large and heavy, cap-shaped, fairly tall, exterior surface brownish-red but very often encrusted with pink coralline or other algae, with about 30 roughly equal-sized ribs that project slightly from the margin. Interior pure white, with a distinct pink marginal band.

Habitat at or below the low water mark and association with large gardens of the smooth, encrusting brown alga Zeacarpa leiomorpha also useful aids to identification.
taxon_text_2_2887: Shell very large, up to 180 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_2888:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2889:
The largest limpet in South Africa and one of the largest in the world. Less common than other species and usually seen singly, or in small colonies, in the extreme low intertidal or on shallow reefs down to about 4 m depth. Adults are associated with large gardens of the flat brown alga Zeacarpa leiomorpha (incorrectly referred to as Ralfsia expansa in earlier publications), which they defend by thrusting against intruding grazers.

Adults maintain a distinct home scar within their gardens and move about 50 cm from the scar while feeding. Smaller individuals cover greater distances and can range up to 3 m from their home scar, but still feed on the same species of alga.

Growth rates have not been measured in this species.
taxon_text_5_2890: Herbivorous, adults feeding almost exclusively on gardens of the encrusting brown alga Zeacarpa leiomorpha which they culture and guard.
taxon_text_6_2891: Sexes are separate but sex ratios, reproductive cycles and fecundity have not been determined for this species. A broadcast spawner, fertilization and larval development taking place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_2892: The very large size of adult individuals means they cannot be confused with any other regional limpet. Smaller individuals could be confused with various other moderately-ribbed species, such as S. barbara, Cymbula oculus or C. granatina, but the pink interior margin of the shell is diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_2893:
Branch, GM (1971). The ecology of Patella Linnaeus from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa I. Zonation, movements and feeding. African Zoology, 6(1), 1-38.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 168).
taxon_text_1_2896: Shells pure white, small and slender with a sharp apex and elongate, tapering spire of many flat whorls. Each whorl marked by oblique flattened axial ribs that extend right across the whorl from suture to suture. Ribs stop abruptly at the anterior margin of the body whorl. Operculum horny, body transparent white with black eye.
taxon_text_3_2898:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to KwaZulu-Natal north coast.
taxon_text_4_2899: Very little is known about the biology of this small but common species, which lives mostly in crevices on the undersides of rocks in low-shore pools and on shallow reefs. All members of this diverse family are thought to be parasitic, sucking the blood or body fluids of various invertebrate hosts, including other molluscs, polychaete worms and tunicates. Most species are host-specific. During feeding the very long proboscis is extended and attached to the host using a terminal sucker. The mouth lacks a radula, but the jaws are modified into a spike-like stylet that penetrates the skin of the prey. The body fluids are then pumped up the proboscis using the muscular pharynx.
taxon_text_5_2900: Parasitic on other invertebrates, but the host of this species has not been identified.
taxon_text_6_2901: Members of this family are hermaphroditic. The spawn consists of a lump of clear jelly often attached to the host. In some species the eggs hatch into free-swimming larvae, but in others they remain in the jelly until they reach the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2902: One of more than 100 species of this diverse family found in Southern Africa. Many of these are known only from dead shells and very little is known about the biology of the living animals. This species can be distinguished from most others in the family by the very elongate shell and marked axial ribs.
taxon_text_8_2903: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 129).
taxon_text_1_2906:
Shell cap-shaped, right side slightly bulging to accommodate the breathing siphon. Exterior surface brown with about 40-50 low, flat, paler and more-or-less equal radiating ribs that do not project beyond the fairly smoothly-oval outline of the shell. Apical part of shell often strongly eroded and ribs then only obvious around margin.

Interior of shell shiny brown with pale margin crossed by dark-brown rays.
taxon_text_4_2909:
Often found in dense clusters, especially in shallow pools, but also on open rocks in the upper-mid to low intertidal of rocky shores. Occupy a distinct home scar, leaving this to undertake feeding excursions and to rasp a variety of algae and black lichens off the rock with the powerful radula. Attachment to the rocks is relatively weak.

Unusually (relative to other limpets) feeds during low tide to prevent being displaced by wave action. Rock-pool populations feed both by day and by night, but those on the open rock feed only during nocturnal low tides to avoid desiccation.

The respiratory system in this group is unusual in that they posses a lung-like pulmonary chamber that opens on the right side via a tubular siphon. The inner surface of this chamber is highly vascularised and also contains a secondary gill, allowing the animals to breath both in air and in water. If one turns the animal upside down the siphon can been seen opening and closing, much like the opening to the lung of a land snail.

The tissues of this species are laden with milky toxic mucus that deters predators.
taxon_text_5_2910: Herbivorous, feed on a variety of larger algae and on encrusting lichens.
taxon_text_6_2911: Hermaphrodite with the male gonads developing in advance of the female ones. Eggs are laid in an irregular ribbon attached to the rock adjacent to the colony. In this species each egg mass contains about 20 000 eggs, which take 4-5 days to develop and which then hatch into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2912: False-limpets can be difficult to identify to species level, and this species is easily confused with a number of others that occur in the same region. The Serrate false-limpet Siphonaria serrata has 30-40 external ribs that are prickly (serrate) and project beyond the margin of the shell; the interior is pale brown with a narrow darker margin crossed by radiating white rays. The Eyed false-limpet S. oculus is similar, but the ribs are alternating small and large and the interior is dark with a distinctive white bar across the apex. The Ribbed false–limpet S. concinna has fewer (20-25), stronger ribs that often extend well beyond the shell margin; interior has a wide black margin with narrow white rays and a white centre.
taxon_text_8_2913:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170)

Branch, GM & Cherry, MI (1985). Activity rhythms of the pulmonate limpet Siphonaria capensis Q. & G. as an adaptation to osmotic stress, predation and wave action. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 87(2), 153-168.

Chambers, RJ & McQuaid, CD (1994). Notes on the taxonomy, spawn and larval development of South African species of the intertidal limpet Siphonaria (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 60(3), 263-275.

McQuaid, CD, Cretchley, R & Rayner, JL (1999). Chemical defence of the intertidal pulmonate limpet Siphonaria capensis (Quoy & Gaimard) against natural predators. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 237(1), 141-154.
taxon_text_1_2916:
Shell cap-shaped, unusually elongate and very small, with elevated apex offset to the right. Outer surface smooth, lacking the distinct radiating ribs typical of most other regional species. Colour dark brown, often with pale radiating rays around margin.

Also easily identified by its unique habitat, as it is restricted to the blades of the seagrass Zostera capensis.
taxon_text_3_2918:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted to Langebaan Lagoon, with another genetically distinct population only in Knysna Estuary that probably needs to be described as a distinct species.
taxon_text_4_2919: Habitat extremely distinctive, as found only grazing on the fronds of the seagrass Zostera capensis at a single site, Langebaan Lagoon, and then also confined to the lower levels of these seagrass beds. As the range is so restricted, and the population has undergone considerable annual fluctuations over the past decades, this species is considered vulnerable to extinction. Seagrass beds in the region are also in decline.
taxon_text_5_2920: Herbivorous, thought to feed on microscopic algae growing on the fronds of seagrass blades.
taxon_text_6_2921: Eggs are laid in protective capsules on the seagrass blades. Each capsule contains only about 20-50 eggs (far fewer that other species) and hatch after 13 days 25 °C or 18 days at 17 °C as completely metamorphosed juveniles.
taxon_text_7_2922: Easily identified by its small adult size, elongate shape and lack of radiating ribs on the exterior of the shell. Also by and specialised habitat.
taxon_text_8_2923:
Allanson, BR (1958). On the systematics and distribution of the molluscan genus Siphonaria in South Africa. Hydrobiologia, 12, 149-180.

Allanson, BR & Msizi, SC (2010). Reproduction and growth of the endangered siphonariid limpet Siphonaria compressa (Pulmonata: Basommatophora). Invertebrate Reproduction & Development, 54(3), 151-161.

Angel, A, Branch, GM, Wanless, RM & Siebert, T (2006). Causes of rarity and range restriction of an endangered, endemic limpet, Siphonaria compressa. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 330(1), 245-260.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170).

Chambers, RJ & McQuaid, CD (1994). Notes on the taxonomy, spawn and larval development of South African species of the intertidal limpet Siphonaria (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 60(3), 263-275.
taxon_text_1_2936:
Shell cap-shaped, right side slightly bulging to accommodate the breathing siphon. External surface dark brown, with about 25 paler, radiating ridges or ribs; apex often eroded and white. Relative sizes of ribs extremely variable. Some specimens have a few very dominant ribs that project well beyond the margins, giving the shell an almost star-like shape and making it easy to identify. In other samples though, there are 20-25 more or less prominent ribs, alternating with smaller ones, and these specimens are more difficult to distinguish from other species in the genus. Shells of juveniles may be flecked with distinctive iridescent blue-green spots.

Interior of shell with broad black margin crossed by narrow white rays and with central white patch. Sides of foot with fine white spots.
taxon_text_3_2938:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2939:
Found in clusters on open rocks in the upper-mid to low intertidal of rocky shores. Occupy a distinct home scar, leaving this to undertake feeding excursions when wetted by the incoming tide. Rasp lichens and algae off the rock with a powerful radula.

The respiratory system in this group is unusual in that they posses a lung-like pulmonary chamber that opens on the right side via a tubular siphon. The inner surface of this chamber is highly vascularised and also contains a secondary gill, allowing the animals to breath both in air and in water. If one turns the animal upside down the siphon can been seen opening and closing much like the opening to the lung of a land snail.
taxon_text_5_2940: Herbivorous, thought to feed primarily on lichens and on encrusting algae.
taxon_text_6_2941: Hermaphrodite with the male gonads developing in advance of the female ones. Eggs are laid in a neatly coiled gelatinous mass of several concentric cycles and attached to the rock adjacent to the colony. In this species each egg mass contains about 30 000 eggs, which take about 5 days to develop, and which then hatch into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2942: False-limpets can be difficult to identify to species level, but this is one of the more distinctive species. Especially those individuals with very large projecting ribs and juveniles with iridescent spots are easily identified.
taxon_text_8_2943:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 135).

Chambers, RJ & McQuaid, CD (1994). Notes on the taxonomy, spawn and larval development of South African species of the intertidal limpet Siphonaria (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 60(3), 263-275.
taxon_text_1_2946:
Shell cap-shaped, fairly tall, right side bulging to accommodate the breathing siphon. External surface brown with 30-40 paler alternating larger and smaller ribs. Ribs characteristically saw-toothed or serrate and projecting distinctly beyond margin of shell. Inner surface brown with distinct white rays radiating though the dark margin.

In living animal dark flecks on side of foot.
taxon_text_3_2948:
Global: Endemic to South Africa (reported record from Madagascar considered unlikely).

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2949:
Common on exposed rocks in the mid to upper intertidal, where probably grazes largely on lichens. Does not form a home scar.

The respiratory system in this group is unusual in that they posses a lung-like pulmonary chamber that opens on the right side via a tubular siphon. The inner surface of this chamber is highly vascularised and also contains a secondary gill, allowing the animals to breath both in air and in water. If one turns the animal upside down the siphon can been seen opening and closing much like the opening to the lung of a land snail.
taxon_text_5_2950: Herbivorous, thought to feed largely on encrusting lichens.
taxon_text_6_2951: Eggs are laid in a collar attached to the rock adjacent to the colony. In this species each egg mass contains about 1000-2500 eggs, which take 20-28 days to develop and hatch directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_2952: False-limpets can be difficult to identify to species level, but this is one of the more distinctive species due to the serrate ribs that extend beyond the margin. It can be confused with the Ribbed false-limpet S. concinna, but that species has fewer (20-25) external ribs which are never serrate. The interior also has a wide black margin but a white or pale centre and the sides of the foot have white not dark spots.
taxon_text_8_2953:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 170)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 135, as S. aspera).

Chambers, RJ & McQuaid, CD (1994). Notes on the taxonomy, spawn and larval development of South African species of the intertidal limpet Siphonaria (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 60(3), 263-275.
taxon_text_1_2956: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, exterior usually rough chalky white, sculpted into about 8 well-developed spiral ridges around each whorl. South coast specimens are often mottled or flecked with dark brown. Umbilicus open in juveniles, but closed in adults. Operculum round and horny, with spiral rows of minute calcareous beads. Body white.
taxon_text_3_2958:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_2959: Very little is known about this small species, which is usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders. Given regional differences in colour and shell form, the west and south coast populations may well represent distinct species.
taxon_text_6_2961: Reproduction in this species has not been studied.
taxon_text_7_2962: White specimens are very distinctive and unlikely to be confused with other regional species, but darker patterned shells could be confused with Gibbula species, such as G. zonata, which also has spiral ridges around the shell. In that species though the colour bands also run spirally, whereas in patterned C. dunkeri the colour bands run across the whorls.
taxon_text_8_2963:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 48, as C. granulosa).
taxon_text_1_2966: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, whorls smoothly rounded (not with distinct angle between base and upper surface, as in some other species). Each whorl sculptured into several low spiral ridges; typically 2-3 more pronounced ridges, with finer ones between. Colour dark grey with oblique pale ‘flames’ crossing each whorl. Interior pale, operculum flat and horny.
taxon_text_2_2967: Shell up to 9 mm in width, but typically less than 5 mm.
taxon_text_3_2968:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Cape Point.
taxon_text_4_2969: Little is known about this small species, which is usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders and in low-shore pools and gullies.
taxon_text_5_2970: Unknown, but other members of this family generally browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_2971: Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other Northern hemisphere species in the genus, however, lay eggs in a jelly mass, the eggs frequently hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2972: There are several other small, common Gibbula species in the region, and some of these are hard to identify to species in the field and require close examination of shell shape and/or colour pattern via a good quality close-up image, or examination under a microscope. This species is most similar to G. cicur in shell shape and colour pattern, but in that species narrow black and pale dashes follow the coils of the shell, whereas in G. beckeri larger pale ‘flames’ cross the whorls in an oblique manner.
taxon_text_8_2973:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 40).
taxon_text_1_2976: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, with a fairly flat shape and a distinct angle demarcating the upper from the lower surfaces. External colour usually pink to red, crossed by oblique white stripes. There is usually a band of particularly obvious red/purple/pink and white around the widest perimeter of the shell. Umbilicus open, operculum round and horny. Tentacles strikingly banded in black and white.
taxon_text_3_2978:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_2979: Very little is known about this small species, which is usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders and in low-shore pools and gullies.
taxon_text_5_2980: Unknown, but other members of this family generally browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_2981: Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other Northern hemisphere species in the genus, however, lay eggs in a jelly mass, the eggs frequently hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2982: There are several other similar small Gibbula species in the region, but the sharp angle between the upper and lower surfaces in this species distinguishes it from most others in the genus, which tend to be deeper and have more rounded ‘shoulders’.
taxon_text_8_2983:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 41).
taxon_text_1_2986: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, whorls smoothly rounded (not with an angle between base and upper surface, as in some other species). Each whorl sculptured into several more or less equal spiral ridges; each ridge coloured with alternating dashes of black and grey. Interior pale, operculum flat and horny.
taxon_text_3_2988:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_2989: Little is known about this small species, which is usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders and in low-shore pools and gullies.
taxon_text_5_2990: Unknown, but other members of this family generally browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_2991: Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other Northern hemisphere species in the genus, however, lay eggs in a jelly mass, the eggs frequently hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_2992: There are several other small and common Gibbula species in the region, but these can be distinguished by close examination of shell shape and/or colour pattern (a good quality closeup image or examination under a microscope is sometimes needed!). This spiral ridges and their ‘dashed’ colour pattern in this species are fairly diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_2993:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 40).
taxon_text_1_2996: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, with a fairly flat profile and with 2-3 spiral ridges running around each whorl. Aperture round, lacking teeth, umbilicus open in the eastern parts of range, closed in the Western Cape; operculum round and horny. External colour variable, but usually bright and multicoloured, with red, blue and white banded stripes. Often a particularly boldly-banded stripe around the widest margin of the shell. Antennae white, dark eyes visible at their bases.
taxon_text_3_2998:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_2999: Very little is known about this small species, which is usually found in small groups in lowshore pools and gullies and on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_5_3000: Unknown, but other members of this family generally browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_3001: Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other Northern hemisphere species in the genus, however, lay eggs in a jelly mass, the eggs frequently hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_3002: Easily confused with other similar small Gibbula species in the region, but the 2-3 distinct ridges on the shoulder are a good identification feature, as is the brightly-coloured shell. The very similar G. capensis differs by having a strongly angular shoulder between upper and lower surfaces and by having striped (rather then white) tentacles.
taxon_text_8_3003:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 41).
taxon_text_1_3006: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, external ground colour pinkish grey, each whorl marked with several distinctive dark purplish spiral lines. The bands in centre of whorl are thicker than those at edges; there are sometimes faint pink ‘shadow lines’ between the darker ones. Umbilicus closed in adults, operculum round and horny. Tentacles white to grey, sometimes with a longitudinal pink stripe.
taxon_text_3_3008:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_3009: Very little is known about this small species which is usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders in low-shore pools and gullies.
taxon_text_5_3010: Unknown, but other members of this family generally browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_3011: Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other Northern hemisphere species in the genus, however, lay eggs in a jelly mass, the eggs frequently hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_3012: There are several other similar small Gibbula species in the region, but the strong spiral dark bands on the shells of this species easily distinguish it from related forms.
taxon_text_8_3013:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 41).
taxon_text_9_3015: Oxystele variegata (now split into O. antoni and O. impervia)
taxon_text_1_3016: Shell medium-sized, globular and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short, blunt spire. External colour extremely variable, but typically tabby patterned, with oblique dotted bands running across a yellowish or greenish background. There is often a band of larger, more distinct alternating black and pale markings around the top of the last whorl. Inner surface pearly; umbilicus closed, operculum round and horny.
taxon_text_3_3018:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3019:
Very common species in the mid to low intertidal of rocky shores, where it is an important grazer. Previously known as O. variegata, but that species has recently been shown to comprise a mixture of two very similar species, O. antoni and O. impervia. Since research on the biology precedes the split, it is assumed here that both the new species share the same biological characteristics.

Juveniles occur mostly in the lower intertidal and are restricted to that zone because they are unable to survive the hotter, dryer condition further upshore. As they grow, they tend to migrate further upshore to avoid predation by whelks, which is most intense at lower levels. They do this despite the fact that food is more readily available at lower levels. Growth is initially quite rapid, a size of 14 mm being attained in the first year, but this only increases to 18 mm after the second year (growth rates also vary with tidal level, becoming slower at upper levels). Commonly fed on by various predators including starfish, whelks and intertidal fish.
taxon_text_5_3020: Feeds on encrusting algae and microalgae on intertidal and shallow subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_3021: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio does not differ significantly from 1:1. Spawning appears to take place throughout the year. The eggs are released into the water column and larval development takes place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3022: Several common species of Oxystele co-exist on the same Cape shores. The Beaded topshells (O. impervia) is extremely similar and difficult to distinguish (although genetic work has shown it to be distinct), but it has bead-like rows of dots that spiral around the whorls. The Tiger topshell (O. tigrina) and Pink lipped topshell (O. sinensis) are both much larger with a plain black exterior and, in the latter case, a pink interior.
taxon_text_8_3023:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 176).

Heller, J & Dempster, Y (1991). Detection of two coexisting species of Oxystele (Gastropoda: Trochidae) by morphological and electrophoretic analyses. Journal of Zoology, 223(3), 395-418.

Lasiak, T (1987). The reproductive cycles of three trochid gastropods from the Transkei coast, Southern Africa. Journal of Molluscan Studies, 53(1), 24-32.

McQuaid, CD (1982). The influence of desiccation and predation on vertical size gradients in populations of the gastropod Oxystele variegata (Anton) on an exposed rocky shore. Oecologia, 53, 123-127.

McQuaid, CD (1983). Population dynamics and growth of the gastropod Oxystele variegata (Anton) on an exposed rocky shore. African Zoology, 18(2), 56-61.
taxon_text_9_3025: Oxystele variegata (now split into O. antoni and O. impervia)
taxon_text_1_3026: Shell small to medium, globular and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short, blunt spire. External colour variable, but typically with bands of alternating brown and white dots running horizontally around a yellowish or greenish, sometimes pink, background. Often there is a band of larger, more distinct alternating black and pale markings around the top of the last whorl.  Inner surface pearly; umbilicus closed, operculum round and horny. Chemosensory tentacles around the margin are often extended when the animal is active.
taxon_text_3_3028:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3029:
Very common species in the mid to upper intertidal of rocky shores, where it is an important grazer. Previously known as O. variegata, but that species has been shown to comprise a mixture of two very similar species, O. antoni and O. impervia. Since research on the biology precedes the split, it is assumed here that both the new species share the same biological characteristics.

Juveniles occur mostly in the lower intertidal and are restricted to that zone because they are unable to survive the hotter, dryer condition further upshore. As they grow, they tend to migrate further upshore to avoid predation by whelks, which is most intense at lower levels. They do this despite the fact that food is more readily available at lower levels. Growth is initially quite rapid, a size of 14 mm being attained in the first year, but this only increases to 18 mm after the second year (growth rates also vary with tidal level, becoming slower at upper levels). Commonly fed on by various predators including starfish, whelks and intertidal fish.
taxon_text_5_3030: Feeds on encrusting algae and microalgae on intertidal and shallow subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_3031: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio does not differ significantly from 1:1. Spawning appears to take place throughout the year. The eggs are released into the water column and larval development takes place in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3032: Several common species of Oxystele co-exist on the same Cape shores. The Variegated topshell (O. antoni) is extremely similar and difficult to distinguish (although genetic work has shown it to be distinct), but it has a tabby-like pattern of irregular oblique bands running around the whorls. The Tiger topshell (O. tigrina) and Pink lipped topshell (O. sinensis) are both much larger with a plain black exterior and, in the latter case, a pink interior.
taxon_text_8_3033:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 176).

Heller, J & Dempster, Y (1991). Detection of two coexisting species of Oxystele (Gastropoda: Trochidae) by morphological and electrophoretic analyses. Journal of Zoology, 223(3), 395-418.

Lasiak, T (1987). The reproductive cycles of three trochid gastropods from the Transkei coast, Southern Africa. Journal of Molluscan Studies, 53(1), 24-32.

McQuaid, CD (1982). The influence of desiccation and predation on vertical size gradients in populations of the gastropod Oxystele variegata (Anton) on an exposed rocky shore. Oecologia, 53, 123-127.

McQuaid, CD (1983). Population dynamics and growth of the gastropod Oxystele variegata (Anton) on an exposed rocky shore. African Zoology, 18(2), 56-61.
taxon_text_1_2926: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating on its dorsal side, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide, covered with small spicules and greenish bristles interspaced with larger ones. Nine tufts of long, glassy spines are characteristic. Middle plates subtriangular to rhomboid-shaped. Texture of shell with small oval granules and fine striae. Colour dark grey or brown with white central line or a pair of lines. Articulamentum dark brown, grey or green with large anterior shell extensions.
taxon_text_2_2927: Medium, typically around 10-20 mm total body length, but large specimens reach 45mm.
taxon_text_3_2928:
Global: Mauritius, Reunion and South Africa. Reports from WoRMS and other articles from Fiji and Venezuela cannot be confirmed.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2929: On exposed rocks and crevices from the inter- to mid tidal zone. Unusual among chitons in that occurs in the open, rather than concealed under boulders. The spines can cause skin irritation, so animals should be handled with caution.
taxon_text_5_2930: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_2931: External fertilization releasing eggs and sperm into the water. Eggs develop into planktonic trochophore larvae that metamorphose and then settle as juvenile chitons. The egg hull is formed by microapocrine secretions instead of exocytosis of Golgi vesicles. When fertilization occurs, the sperm digests a pore in the egg hull and releases its DNA.
taxon_text_7_2932: The related A. variegata occurs from False Bay to Bhanga Nek but has lower and less dense granules. These are more prominent on younger individuals while valves can be heavily eroded in adults. A. variegata is a more cryptic species than A. garnoti.
taxon_text_8_2933:
Blainville, HMD de (1825). Oscabrion, Chiton, pp. 519-555, in: Dictionnaire des Sciences Naturelles (F. Cuvier, ed.), vol. 36. Levrault, Strasbourg & Paris, & Le Normant, Paris.

Kilburn, RN & Rippey, E (1982) Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg, xi + 249 pp. (p. 137).
taxon_text_1_3036: Shell medium-sized, globular and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short, blunt spire. External colour black, apex often eroded and pearly white. Shell also often covered by the pink coralline alga Spongoides discoidea. Internal colour pearly white, the inner lip and spire distinctively coloured with a wide red to pink band. Umbilicus closed, operculum round and horny.
taxon_text_2_3037: Shell up to 62 mm in width, but usually <45 mm.
taxon_text_3_3038:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to far Eastern Cape.
