taxon_text_4_3039:
Very common species in the mid to low intertidal, yet surprisingly little is little is known about its basic biology, such as growth rate, longevity, breeding season, etc.

Commonly preyed on by rock-lobsters and sometimes gathered as a source of food by both recreational and subsistence collectors.

The shells are very often covered by the pale pink coralline alga Spongoides discoidea and it was suspected that this might help keep the winkles cool during low tide, but research has shown that the alga offers no advantage, other than perhaps some camouflage.
taxon_text_5_3040: Feeds on encrusting algae and microalgae on intertidal and shallow subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_3041: Reproduction in this species has not been studied.
taxon_text_7_3042: Several common species of Oxystele co-exist on the same Cape shores. The Variegated and Beaded topshells (O. antoni and O. impervia) are much smaller and have obvious striped and spotted ‘tabby’ patterned shells. The Tiger topshell O. tigrina is similar in size, but lacks the distinctive pink inner lip and tends to occur slightly higher on the shore and ranges up the west coast.
taxon_text_8_3043:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 176)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 42).

Eager, R, Puckree-Padua, C & Maneveldt, GW (2015). Understanding the association between the non-geniculate coralline red alga Spongites discoidea and the mollusc Oxystele sinensis. African Journal of Marine Science, 37(3), 335-344.

Van Zyl, RF, Mayfield, S, Pulfrich, A & Griffiths, CL (1998). Predation by West Coast rock lobsters (Jasus lalandii) on two species of winkle (Oxystele sinensis and Turbo cidaris). African Zoology, 33(4), 203-209.
taxon_text_1_3046: Shell medium-sized, globular and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short spire. External colour black, sometimes with a few scattered white spots, apex often eroded and pearly white. Internal colour pearly white or silver, lacking any trace of red (as in O. sinensis) and with a narrow black border to outer lip. Umbilicus closed, operculum round and horny.
taxon_text_3_3048:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3049: Very common species in the mid to low intertidal, yet surprisingly little is little is known about its basic biology, such as growth rate, longevity, breeding season, etc.
taxon_text_5_3050: Feeds on encrusting algae and microalgae on intertidal and shallow subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_3051: Reproduction in this species has not been studied.
taxon_text_7_3052: Several common species of Oxystele co-exist on the same Cape shores. The Variegated and Beaded topshells (O. antoni and O. impervia) are much smaller and have obvious striped and spotted ‘tabby’ patterned shells. The Pink-lipped topshell O. sinensis is similar in size, but has a distinctive pink inner lip and tends to occur slightly lower on the shore and in pools.
taxon_text_8_3053:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 41).
taxon_text_1_3056:
Shell small, smooth, glossy and fairly high-spired (but spire not excelling aperture in length). External colour greyish-black with a few white flame-like markings. Operculum white and calcareous.

Extremely abundant among intertidal algae (also a useful identification feature!).
taxon_text_3_3058:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Hermanus (note earlier papers include the “africana“ form so cite a much wider distribution).
taxon_text_4_3059:
Small but extremely common species found crawling over rock surfaces and intertidal algae in rock pools. Very active and crawl speedily along, frantically waving the three pairs of sensory tentacles along the sides of the foot. The foot is divided longitudinally into two muscle bands that can operate alternately (like tank tracks) giving added maneuverability.

Little else is known about the biology of this small but very common species.
taxon_text_5_3060: Feeds on surface tissues of algae and on diatoms and detritus found on algal and rock surfaces.
taxon_text_6_3061: Sexes are separate in this family and eggs are shed singly into the water, each enclosed in a gelatinous capsule. They hatch into pelagic larvae which settle within a few days.
taxon_text_7_3062: Southern Africa hosts more phasianellid species than anywhere else in the world, with 10 endemic species reported, plus 3 other Indo–Pacific species extending into KwaZulu-Natal. Tricolia capensis is by far the most common species along the west coast and in the South-Western Cape though. It is replaced to the east (from Struis Bay) by T. africana, which is smaller, more elongate, has a smaller aperture and is generally more brightly coloured. The two species also differ in habitat, T. capensis occurring among seaweeds, and T. africana on or under rocks in midshore pools.
taxon_text_8_3063:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 180).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 42 includes ‘africana’ form under capensis).

Nangammbi, TC, Herbert, DG & Teske, PR (2016). Molecular insights into species recognition within southern Africa's endemic Tricolia radiation (Vetigastropoda: Phasianellidae). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 82(1), 97-103.
taxon_text_1_3066: Shell small, smooth, glossy and very short-spired, with a large aperture. Colour pattern distinctive, comprising numerous thin spiral lines over a paler background and with a few white or yellow spots just below the suture. In live specimens shell colour is cream with dark purple to black lines, but these lines fade to become red or pink in dead shells (which are what is depicted in most guides!). Interior of shell pearly white, foot decorated with narrow dark lines. Operculum white and calcareous.
taxon_text_3_3068:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_3069: Small but fairly common among seaweeds or under boulders. Little else is know about the biology of this species.
taxon_text_5_3070: Feeds on surface tissues of algae and on diatoms and detritus found on algal and rock surfaces.
taxon_text_6_3071: Sexes are separate in this family and eggs are shed singly into the water, each enclosed in a gelatinous capsule. They hatch into pelagic larvae which settle within a few days.
taxon_text_7_3072: Fairly distinctive species by virtue of its very short spire, enlarged aperture and dense pattern of spiral stripes. Most guides depict the dead shell, which has bright pink stripes, and this can cause confusion when observing live animals, which have much darker purple to black stipes on the shell!
taxon_text_8_3073:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 180).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 47).

Nangammbi, TC, Herbert, DG & Teske, PR (2016). Molecular insights into species recognition within southern Africa's endemic Tricolia radiation (Vetigastropoda: Phasianellidae). Journal of Molluscan Studies, 82(1), 97-103.
taxon_text_1_3076:
Shell large, globular, smooth and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short, blunt spire. External colour variable, but usually black or brown with paler bluish or white flames, in juveniles with darker spiral bands of white and brown bars. Mature specimens often strongly eroded and pitted with polychaete and burrowing barnacle holes. Internal colour pearly white. Umbilicus closed, operculum round, very thick and calcareous, external surface granular and with a groove that spirals towards a distinctive central pit.

There are two subspecies, the Cape T. cidaris cidaris (described above) and the eastern T. cidaris natalensis that has 6-11 well defined spiral ridges on each whorl of the shell and no central pit in the operculum. It seems very likely that these should be recognized as separate species, but we are not aware of genetic or morphological research that is needed to support (or negate) this change.
taxon_text_3_3078:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to far Eastern Cape (T. cidaris cidaris).
taxon_text_4_3079:
Very common and well-known species. Juveniles are common in the mid to low intertidal, especially under boulders and in crevices. Adults usually found subtidally down to about 11 m depth, but most common in the depth range 0-2 m.

Often seen climbing up kelp stipes, presumably to graze on epiphytic algae growing there. Commonly preyed upon by a variety of predators including rock lobsters, octopus, African Black Oystercatchers and Kelp gulls. The latter drop large individuals onto flat rocks or ‘anvils’ to break the tough shell and access the meat. Are sometimes also collected for human consumption but should be surprisingly, little is known about growth rate, longevity of other biological characteristics.
taxon_text_5_3080: Feeds on algae and microalgae on intertidal and shallow subtidal rocks and on kelp stipes.
taxon_text_6_3081: Surprisingly, the reproduction in this species appears not to have been studied.
taxon_text_7_3082: Progressively replaced by the Ridged turban shell Turbo cidaris natalensis from about Algoa Bay northwards. Co-occurs in the Western Cape with the Giant turban or Alikreukel, T. sarmarticus, which grows to a much larger size, has rows of low nodules round each whorl and has an operculum covered by densely-packed rough nodules and with no central pit.
taxon_text_8_3083:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 178).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 47).

Pulfrich, A & Branch, TA (2002). Population dynamics and potential yield of three species of giant winkles in the Western Cape, South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 24, 161-183.
taxon_text_1_3086: Shell very large, globular, and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short, blunt spire. External colour orange, becoming black with age, with about three rows of low knobs that spiral around each whorl. Older individuals often heavily-eroded, becoming firstly more black and finally pearly as the outer shell layers become eroded away. Internal colour pearly white. Umbilicus closed, aperture with a black internal marginal band, sometimes blue tinged, operculum round, very thick, hemispherical and calcareous, external surface granular and densely covered in course white nodules (and with no central pit).
taxon_text_3_3088:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to far Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3089:
One of the largest gastropods in the region. Very common and very well-known species along the South Coast, where it has long been sought after for human consumption, to the extend that large individuals have become hard to find in the intertidal across much of the range. Substantial populations still persist in deeper waters though, as evidenced by the fact that large shells are still commonly cast up along the driftline at most locations and also seen by divers.

Juveniles are commonly found under rocks in pools in the mid- to low- intertidal, but adults tend to occur at lower intertidal levels and on shallow reefs down to about 8 m, usually concealed in gullies and crevices.

Growth is relatively slow, reaching sexual maturity at an age of 1.5-2 years and the legal minimum collection size of 64 mm after 3-4 years. Longevity can extend to an age of about 12 years.
taxon_text_5_3090: A generalist grazer feeding on a wide variety of green, red and brown algae. Consumption rates (in Eastern Cape) have been measured at 1.5-9.5% of body weight per day for juveniles and 1-6% of body weight per day for adults, with the higher rates occurring at warmer temperatures.
taxon_text_6_3091: Sexes are separate and the sex ratio (in the Eastern Cape) has been reported to be slightly biased in favour of males with 120 males per 100 females. The gonads of males are creamy yellow and those of females olive green. Sexual maturity is attained at a mean size of 52.5 mm and spawning takes place from December to March, eggs and sperm being released into the water column and the larvae developing in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3092: The large size of adults distinguished this from other regional turban shells. Smaller individuals could be confused with the Smooth turban shell T. cidaris, but as the name suggests that species lacks the rows of low nodules round each whorl. It also has an operculum covered by rough nodules, but bearing a distinctive spiral groove that leads to a marked central pit.
taxon_text_8_3093:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 178).

Foster GG (1997). Growth, reproduction and feeding biology of Turbo sarmarticus (Mullusca, Vetigastropoda) along the coast of the Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. PhD thesis, Rhodes University.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 47).

Pulfrich, A & Branch, TA (2002). Population dynamics and potential yield of three species of giant winkles in the Western Cape, South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 24, 161-183.
taxon_text_1_3096: Small, slender shark with two dorsal fins that are set far back, behind pelvic fin, second dorsal slightly smaller, both lack anterior spines. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Head with depressed snout that has a distinct upturned knob at its tip. Nostrils separate from mouth and not connected by a groove. Colour pattern distinctive, body pale pinkish-brown with about 10 strongly-defined dorsal saddles, each saddle with darker edges and a lighter middle; often thinner, less-distinct ‘shadow’ saddles between these main ones. No spots, underside creamy.
taxon_text_3_3098:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3099:
Benthic species found from the shoreline to a depth of 172 m, often on the edges of reefs, most common in Eastern Cape. Fairly often caught by both trawlers and shore anglers.

Males mature at a length of 29–35 cm and females at about 30–44 cm.
taxon_text_5_3100: Fairly sluggish predator feeding on a diversity of benthic organisms, including both bony fish and other small sharks and rays, as well as crustaceans, molluscs and worms.
taxon_text_6_3101: Lay eggs in which young develop (oviparous), females carrying about 12-22 egg cases at a time. Unusually among catsharks, these are retained internally until the embryos reach about 4.5 cm length, presumably thus reducing the time the eggs are exposed to predation. Egg cases are about 4 x 1.5 cm in size, excluding the long tendrils extending from each corner. They are laid attached by these tendrils to sessile organism on the reef and hatch after only about 2 months.
taxon_text_7_3102: Can be confused with other small catsharks of the genus Haploblepharus, which are similar in size and also have dark saddles. Those species have a blunter snout though; also the saddles are less distinct against a darker background and the nostrils are joined to the mouth by a groove.
taxon_text_8_3103:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Heemstra P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 66).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 479).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) 2003. Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 91).
taxon_text_1_3116:
Small, elongate shark with two small, triangular and equal-sized dorsal fins that lack anterior spines and are set far back, both behind pelvic fin. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Deep grooves connect nostrils to mouth, nasal barbels absent.

Colour pattern distinctive: ground colour dark brown to almost black with 6–8 faint dorsal saddles that may have their centres dark orange-brown to almost black. Whole dorsal surface marked with indistinct white spots. Underside abruptly white to cream.
taxon_text_3_3118:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3119:
A common benthic species found on shallow reefs to a depth of about 35 m, particularly in kelp beds and sometimes extending into intertidal pools. Curls into a tight ball when disturbed, wrapping the tail over the head – hence the common name shyshark.

 

Males mature at about 40 cm length and females from 36 cm. Matures at an age of about 15 years and longevity estimated as at least 25 years.
taxon_text_5_3120: Has a broad diet, feeding on small bony fish, worms, crustaceans, molluscs, echinoderms and occasionally also algae, which may be accidentally ingested along with other prey.
taxon_text_6_3121: Oviparous, females laying pairs of rectangular dark brown egg cases with long tendrils at each corner. Egg cases about 5.5 cm long by 2.5 cm wide and laid at shallow depths averaging only 3 m and sometimes even in intertidal pools. Eggs most frequently attached to the Hanging wrack alga Brassicophycus sisymbrioides (previously Bifurcaria brassicaeformis). Incubation time dependent on temperature and in captivity varies from 8 months at 14 degrees Celsius to about 6 months at 17 degrees Celsius. Young hatch at a length of 10–12 cm.
taxon_text_7_3122:
Several easily confused species in this genus and many records and images incorrectly assigned. Detailed colour pattern are distinctive but general background colour should be treated carefully as individuals of all easily confused species can adapt this to match habitat.

The Puffadder shyshark H. edwardsii has a similar range and habits but a less depressed and more pointed head and is more brightly pigmented, with distinct light brown saddles with dark-edges. Both H. fuscus, which is plain brown, and H. kirtnamsamyi, which has dark saddles, but white spots only on the saddles, are only found further east, beyond the distribution range of sea forests. Can further be confused especially with juveniles of the otherwise larger Yellowspotted catshark Scyliorhinus capensis which can have a similar deep dark appearance but has larger and more pronounced white to yellow spots.
taxon_text_8_3123:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 479).

Pretorius, C & Griffiths, CL (2013). Patterns of egg deposition and egg development in the catsharks Poroderma pantherinum and Haploblepharus pictus. African Zoology, 48(1), 115-124.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 92).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 13).
taxon_text_1_3126: Medium-sized shark with five gill slits and two large dorsal fins that lack anterior spines (as found in Spiny dogfish). Body cylindrical, but distinctly flatted anteriorly. Teeth inconspicuous, low and bluntly rounded (hence alternative common name ‘gummy shark’). Colour grey with a few large scattered black blotches dorsally. Underside white.
taxon_text_2_3127: Up to 170 cm length with a mass of up to 25 kg.
taxon_text_3_3128:
Global: Widespread from Europe and Mediterranean down the west coast of Africa to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Durban.
taxon_text_4_3129:
Found from the shore to depth of about 350 m over sandy bottoms.

Females mature at 125–140 cm and an age of about 12–15 years and males at 95–130 cm at an age of about 6–9 years. Maximum lifespan at least 24 years.
taxon_text_5_3130: Feed on benthic species, especially crabs, lobsters, prawns, mantis shrimps, cephalopods and bony fish.
taxon_text_6_3131: Viviparous, pups being initially nourished by yolk, but in later stages by a placental connection with the mother. From 4–23 pups are born per litter, their size at birth being 35–42 cm. Gestation period 10–11 months. Larger mothers tend to have more pups.
taxon_text_7_3132: Can be confused with Spotted gullyshark Triakis megalopterus, which is similar in size and also has black spots. However, that species has many more smaller spots, a less flattened body and the second dorsal fin is almost as large as the first.
taxon_text_8_3133:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 258).

Heemstra P & Heemstra E. (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 64).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 501).

Smale, MJ, & Compagno, LJV (1997). Life history and diet of two southern African smoothhound sharks, Mustelus mustelus (Linnaeus, 1758) and Mustelus palumbes Smith, 1957 (Pisces: Triakidae). South African Journal of Marine Science, 18(1), 229-248.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 82).
taxon_text_1_3136: Small to medium, fairly stocky shark with two small, rounded dorsal fins, the first being the larger. These lack anterior spines and are set far back, both behind pelvic fin. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Free part of nasal barbel short and not reaching mouth. Colour pattern distinctive, head and body marked by 2–3 thick black horizontal bands on each side, set against a dark grey background. Underside paler.
taxon_text_2_3137: Up to 109 cm length and a mass of 8 kg.
taxon_text_3_3138:
Global: Endemic to South Africa (records from Madagascar, Mauritius and Seychelles are errors).

Local/Regional: About Saldanha Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_3139:
Benthic species found from the shoreline to a depth of about 100 m, often on the edges of reefs. Mostly nocturnal and spend the days hiding in cracks and crevices in the reef, often in groups. Individuals thought to remain within a confined home range.

Males mature at a length of 58–76 cm at ages of about 11 years and females at about 65–72 cm. Thought to live for at least 22 years.
taxon_text_5_3140: Opportunistic predator feeding on a wide variety of both vertebrate and invertebrate prey. Takes a variety of small fish, including other small sharks and their egg cases; also cephalopods, crustaceans, mollusks and worms. Has also been observed capturing Chokka squid as they come in to lay eggs on their spawning grounds and ripping the arms off octopus with a twisting roll.
taxon_text_6_3141: Oviparous, females laying dark brown rectangular egg cases about 9 cm long by 4.5 cm wide and with long tendrils at each corner. These are wound around seafans, or large algae, to keep them secure during development. Development (in captivity) takes about 5.5 months and young are born at a length of about 14–15 cm.
taxon_text_7_3142: Similar in shape and habits to the Leopard catshark P. pantherinum but the colour patterns are distinctive, the Leopard catshark having spots, rings or rosettes of black on the sides, rather than continuous horizontal black stripes.
taxon_text_8_3143:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town.

Compagno, LJV (1984). FAO Species Catalogue. Vol. 4. Sharks of the world. An annotated and illustrated catalogue of shark species known to date. Part 2 - Carcharhiniformes. FAO Fish. Synop. 125(4/2), 251-655. Rome: FAO.
taxon_text_1_3146: Smallish, fairly stout shark with two small, rounded dorsal fins that lack anterior spines and are set far back, both behind pelvic fin, first dorsal fin the larger. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Longish nasal barbels conspicuous and reach back to mouth. Colour pattern distinctive but variable, and formed of horizontal bands of numerous dark spots, rings or rosettes against a grey background. Spot numbers and pattern differs greatly between individuals, leading to taxonomic confusion and many synonyms, but all forms now shown to belong to the same species.
taxon_text_2_3147: Up to 70 cm length and a mass of 3 kg.
taxon_text_3_3148:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About Saldanha Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_3149:
Benthic species found from the shoreline to a depth of 250 m, often on the edges of reefs. Mostly nocturnal and spend the days hiding in cracks and crevices, often together with the more common Pajama catshark.

Males mature at a length of 54–58 cm and females at about 58–61 cm, both at age of about 10 years. Longevity estimated at 15–19 years.
taxon_text_5_3150: Feeds mostly on crustaceans, small fish and octopus. Has also been observed capturing Chokka squid as they come in to lay eggs on their spawning grounds.
taxon_text_6_3151: Oviparous, females laying light brown rectangular egg cases about 7 cm long by 3 cm wide and with long tendrils at each corner. These are laid at depths of around 7–27 m and wound mostly around seafans or other benthic structures to keep them secure during development. Development time (in captivity) is strongly dependent on temperature, taking between 10 months at 14 degrees Celsius degrees to only 4 months at 17 degrees Celsius and young are born at a length of about 11 cm.
taxon_text_7_3152: Similar in shape and habits to the Pyjama catchark P. africanum, but the colour patterns are distinctive, the Pyjama catshark having bold continuous horizontal black stripes along the body.
taxon_text_8_3153:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 67).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 491).

Pretorius, C & Griffiths, CL (2013). Patterns of egg deposition and egg development in the catsharks Poroderma pantherinum and Haploblepharus pictus. African Zoology, 48(1), 115-124.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 95).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 14).
taxon_text_1_3156: Medium-sized shark with five gill slits, large dorsal fins without anterior spines, second dorsal fin almost as large as first. Snout bluntly rounded and mouth wide. Teeth small with a narrow erect cusps. Colour grey, usually with numerous small black spots (sometimes sparse or even absent, especially in juveniles).
taxon_text_2_3157: Up to 208 cm length with a mass up to 50 kg.
taxon_text_3_3158:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Angola to Eastern Cape, rarely reported in southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3159:
Shallow waters over both rocky reefs and sand to a depth of about 50 m. Generally remains close to the bottom and may shelter in crevices, but mainly active at night. Usually solitary or in small groups, but can form larger aggregations in summer, probably associated with reproduction.

Fairly slow-growing species, females maturing at about 145 cm and an age of about 15 years and males at 125–135 cm at an age of about 11–13 years. Maximum lifespan at least 25 years.
taxon_text_5_3160: Feeds on larger benthic invertebrates, such as crabs, lobsters and cephalopods, as well as on bony fish. The main prey item of smaller individuals is the Cape rock crab Guinusia chabrus. Larger individuals take a wider variety of prey, mostly bony fish but including guitarfish and catsharks.
taxon_text_6_3161: Ovoviviparous, females giving birth from May to August and producing 5–15 pup per litter, larger females generally producing more young per litter. Young are born at a length 30–31 cm. Due to the long gestation time females only reproduce once every 2–3 years.
taxon_text_7_3162: Can be confused with Smooth-hound shark Musteus mustelus, which is similar in size and can also have black spots. These are fewer and larger though, and in that species the second dorsal fin is much smaller than the first.
taxon_text_8_3163:
Booth, AJ, Foulis, AJ & Smale, MJ (2011). Age validation, growth, mortality, and demographic modeling of spotted gully shark (Triakis megalopterus) from the southeast coast of South Africa. Fishery Bulletin, 109, 101-112.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 258).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 64).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 504).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 86).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 12).
taxon_text_9_3165: Goes by a confusing number of alternative common names, including Broadnose sevengill shark, Broadnose sevengill cowshark, Spotted sevengill shark, Spotted sevengill cowshark, Spotted sevengill shark, Sevengill shark. All refer to this same species!
taxon_text_1_3166: Easily recognized by the presence of seven pairs of large gill slits (most sharks have only five, rarely six) and by the fact that there is only one (not the usual two) dorsal fin and this is set far back, behind the pelvic fins. Head broad and snout blunt. Mouth wide and lower jaw teeth comb-like, with 4–5 inclined cusps; upper jaw teeth with 1–2 cusps. Colour silvery-grey, usually with numerous black and white spots.
taxon_text_2_3167: Up to 300 cm length with a mass up to 182 kg.
taxon_text_3_3168:
Global:  Widespread in temperate oceans across the world, including west coast of North America, both coasts of South America, Southern Africa, China and Japan, Australia and New Zealand (but absent from North Atlantic) .

Local/Regional: Namibia to East London.
taxon_text_4_3169:
Benthic species found from the coast to a depth of 136 m. Generally seen cruising slowly around shallow reefs and can be very inquisitive, approaching divers without fear or aggression, but is potentially dangerous, so should be approached with caution. Most active at night and in low light conditions (dawn, cloudy weather), tending to retreat into deeper waters when light levels high.

Females mature at a length of about 220 cm and mass of 54 kg, at age 11–21 years, while males mature at 150–180 cm and 17 kg at age 4–5 years. Thought to live for at least 30 years.
taxon_text_5_3170: Opportunistic predators feeding on a wide variety of prey including invertebrates and carrion, but mostly take bony fish, other sharks and rays (and their egg cases) and mammals, sometimes forming packs to hunt seals.
taxon_text_6_3171: Ovoviviparous, females giving birth to a remarkably large number of pups per litter, typically 60–82, but up to 100! Pups are born at a length of 34–45 cm and gestation period thought to be about one year, followed by a resting period during which next batch of eggs mature.
taxon_text_7_3172: Unlikely to be confused with other sharks and the only coastal sevengill shark in the region.
taxon_text_8_3173:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 64).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 415).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 47).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 11).
taxon_text_1_3176: One of the largest and best known of all shark species and the subject of intense public interest and research. Body very large (up to ca 6 m), powerfully built and spindle-shaped with bluntly-conical snout and triangular serrated teeth, those on upper jaw being broader. Eyes very black. First dorsal fin large and triangular, second dorsal very much smaller. Pectoral fins long and narrow. Tail powerful and crescent-shaped. Colour uniformly bluish-grey above, abruptly becoming white on underside.
taxon_text_2_3177: Up to about 600 cm length with a mass up to about 2000 kg (maximum recorded size is a source of contention!), females growing considerably larger than males.
taxon_text_3_3178:
Global: Worldwide in temperate and tropical oceans .

Local/Regional: Whole region, but scarce on west coast.
taxon_text_4_3179:
Open water species usually found near the surface and fairly close inshore, but has been recorded to depths of at least 130 m. Usually seen patrolling areas that might offer suitable food, such as vicinity of seal colonies. Capable of impressive speeds and can capture fast-swimming prey such as mako sharks, dolphins and seals, sometimes breaching clear of the water when attacking seals from below.

Undertakes long migratory movements to take advantage of seasonal food resources, one tagged individual having been recorded moving between South Africa and Australia! In False Bay large numbers of individuals move into the area in winter to feed on seal pups, which begin to forage away from the colony at that time. The same individuals return year after year to take advantage of this seasonal food source, moving off up the east coast in summer. Pattern has been interrupted by the presence of orcas that specialized on hunting and killing sharks causing White sharks to avoid the South Coast and move further east.

All members of this family are essentially warm-blooded, maintaining a body temperature above that of the surrounding ambient water, and this accounts for their highly active, predatory habits and makes them among the fastest-swimming of all fish.

Females mature at a length of about 400-500 cm and age 12-14 years, while males mature at 350-400 cm at age 9-10 years. Life expectancy contentious with some studies giving this as about 27 years and others estimating longevity of as long as 70 years.

The species is protected in South Africa and the killing of Great white sharks has been prohibited since 1991. As top predators the total population size is very limited and the total population in South Africa is estimated to be only about 500 individuals. Individuals can be photographically recognised by the profiles and markings on their dorsal fins.
taxon_text_5_3180: Juveniles feed on fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. Adults take mostly larger bony fish, other elasmobranchs and marine mammals, such as seals and dolphins. They are highly opportunistic though and known to take turtles, sea birds and to feed on whale carcasses, as well as to ingest various inedible objects.
taxon_text_6_3181: Viviparous, females giving birth to 2-13 pups per litter, these being born at a remarkably large size of 120-160 cm after a gestation period of about a year.
taxon_text_7_3182: Unlikely to be confused with other sharks due to its very large size, slender snout, triangular teeth and distinctive colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_3183:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 70).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 473).

Peschak, T P, Scholl MC 2006. South Africa’a Great White Shark. Struik Publishers, Cape Town.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 98).
taxon_text_1_3186: Head and body form an enormous, flattened, angular disc. Dorsal fins absent. Tail unusually short (less than length of body) relative to other regional stingrays and bears a large, venomous stinging spine projecting from its dorsal surface and scattered small denticles (densest towards tip). Upper surface plain brown, with row of small, white pores along bases of pectoral fins. Underside white with conspicuous gill slits.
taxon_text_2_3187: Up to 300 cm disc width and 430 cm total length (including tail) and with a mass of up to 300 kg.
taxon_text_3_3188:
Global: Southern Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Maputo.
taxon_text_4_3189: Thought to be the largest of all stingrays and can be distinguished from other local species by its enormous size and shorter tail. Found over soft substrata from shallow water to a depth of at least 480 m. Although curious and not aggressive should be approached with caution, as the sting can be over 30 cm long and can inflict a dangerous wound.
taxon_text_5_3190: Feeds on both benthic invertebrates, such as mollusks and crustaceans, as well as fish. Can use suction to extract buried prey, the excess water then being expelled though the gill slits. Has been observed patrolling beds of chokka squid eggs during mass spawnings, feeding on squid that come to the bottom to lay.
taxon_text_6_3191: Undertakes courtship behaviour in mid-water, males following females and attempting to grip and bite her disc. When she agrees to mate the male rolls upside down and inserts his clasper into her vent. Captive females have been observed mating with up to three males in succession. Give birth to 6-10 live pups with disc widths of 32-36 cm.
taxon_text_7_3192: The very large size, relative lack of patterning and short tail distinguish this species from other regional stingrays
taxon_text_8_3193:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 82).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 600).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 136).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 21).
taxon_text_1_3196: Head and body form a flattened angular disc with a slightly extended triangular snout. Dorsal fins absent. Whip-like tail bears a large venomous stinging spine projecting from its dorsal surface. Upper surface brown with finger-like blue markings. Underside white with conspicuous gill slits.
taxon_text_2_3197: Up to 75 cm disc width and a mass of about 25 kg.
taxon_text_3_3198:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Angola to about Mozambique border. Possibly also Madagascar.
taxon_text_4_3199: Found from the surf zone to depths of at least 110 m, also on sandflats and in coastal lagoons, as well as estuary mouths. Tends to move offshore in winter. Females mature at a disc width of about 51 cm and age of 7 years, males at a disc width of 39 cm and an age of 4 years. Longevity about 14 years, females tending to live longer than males.
taxon_text_5_3200: While in shallow water feed mostly on sand prawns, bivalves, and worms. When in deeper water take mostly small bottom-dwelling fish and prawns.
taxon_text_6_3201: Give birth to live young after a gestation time of about 9 months. Typically 1–7 pups are born per brood in the early summer in inshore habitats, females typically producing about 20 young in their lifetimes. Young born at a disc-width of 15–20 cm. Juveniles move further offshore as they grow.
taxon_text_7_3202: Colour pattern fairly distinctive. The Honeycomb stingray Himantura uarmak has a much longer tail and an intricate honeycomb pattern on the upper surface, but also occurs further east and does not extend into the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_3203:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 262).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 82).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 602).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 21).
taxon_text_1_3206: Body flattened and diamond-shaped, broader than long (disc width almost twice length), the thin, wing-like pectoral fins distinct from the more bulbous body. Fleshy snout and eyes project in front of leading edge of pectoral fins. Whip-like tail long and thin, up to twice body length, with one small dorsal fin at base, followed by venomous serrate spines. Colour plain dark brown to black above (rarely with irregular black spots), underside white.
taxon_text_2_3207: Up to 150 cm disc width and mass up to 21 kg.
taxon_text_3_3208:
Global: Widespread across western Atlantic from Europe and Mediterranean down the west coast of Africa and around South Africa to Southern Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Bazaruto in Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3209: On soft substrata from the intertidal to depths of about 95 m, readily entering shallow lagoons and lower reaches of estuaries. Females reach sexual maturity at a disc width of 60 cm and males at 54 cm. Fast swimming and able to jump out of the water.
taxon_text_5_3210: Feeds on a variety of benthic invertebrates including bivalves, gastropods, crustaceans, worms and ascidians, as well as bony fish.
taxon_text_6_3211: Viviparous (live bearing), internally developing embryos initially feeding on yolk then later receiving additional nutrition from secretions produced by the mother. Gestation period 6–8 months and typically give birth to 3–7 pups in shallow water. Size at birth 20–23 cm disc width.
taxon_text_7_3212: Unmistakable and the only common Eagle ray in the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_3213:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 264).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 82).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 623).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 133).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 86).
taxon_text_1_3216: Head and body form a flattened disc with a stiff, pointed snout supported by a stout cartilage and wide, wing-like pectoral fins. Tail narrow with two small rounded dorsal fins near tip. Single row of thorn-like structures along mid-dorsal line of snout, disc and tail. Colour dorsally light brown with numerous small black spots and a larger eye-spot at base of each pectoral fin. Underside white with small mouth and short gill slits.
taxon_text_2_3217: Up to 68 cm disc width and a mass of about 1.4 kg, females growing larger than males.
taxon_text_3_3218:
Global: Western Sahara down west coast of Africa to South Africa, possibly also Mozambique, Mauritius and Madagascar.

Local/Regional: Namibia to East London.
taxon_text_4_3219: Occurs on sand from the surf zone to a depth of 690 m. Generally found singly lying on, or shallowly covered by, sand where well camouflaged. Males reach sexual maturity at about 56–68 cm total length and females at 55–71 cm.
taxon_text_5_3220: Feeds mainly on bony fish, as well as on crustaceans and squid.
taxon_text_6_3221: Oviparous, egg cases laid two at a time. The tough, brown, rectangular cases with a pointed horn at each corner and are about 8 cm long (excluding horns). Egg cases lie freely on the substratum during development, which takes several months. Size at hatching about 16 cm total length.
taxon_text_7_3222: The Spearnosed skate Rostroraja alba has a similar body shape and snout, but is usually grey in colour, sometimes with white spots and has three (not one) rows of large thorns along the tail.
taxon_text_8_3223:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 262).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 81).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 587).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 126).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 18).
taxon_text_1_3226: Head and body form a very large, flattened, angular disc with a stiff, pointed snout. Tail narrow and about as long as disc, with two small, rounded dorsal fins near tip and three rows of prominent thorn-like structures along centre and either side. Colour variable, juveniles dorsally light brown, adults plain grey to brown with or without white spots. Underside white, with conspicuous gill slits.
taxon_text_2_3227: Very large, reaching 160 cm disc width, 240 cm total length. Females grow larger than males.
taxon_text_3_3228:
Global: Eastern Atlantic from the UK down west coast of Europe (including Mediterranean) and Africa, around South Africa to central Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3229:
Occurs on sand from the surf zone to a depth of 600 m. Generally found singly lying on, or shallowly covered by, sand where well camouflaged. Length at sexual maturity 120 cm total length in males and 130 cm total length in females, with a longevity of about 10 years.

The rectangular egg cases are often washed ashore, where they attract considerable attention, not only due to their enormous size (up to 18 cm long, 14 cm wide, excluding long horns!), but because of their distinctive reticulated texture. Young are born at about 40 cm total length, hatchlings reddish brown with blue spots.
taxon_text_5_3230: Bottom-feeding predator, feeding mainly on bony fish, as well as on various crustaceans, octopus and squid.
taxon_text_6_3231: Oviparous, the tough, brown, rectangular egg cases are laid a pair at a time and lie freely on the substratum during development, which takes up to 18 months.
taxon_text_7_3232: The Biscuit skate Raja straeleni has a similar body shape and snout, but is much smaller (up to 68 cm disc width) brown in colour, with small black spots plus a larger eye spot at base of pectoral fins and has one (not three) rows of large thorns along the tail.
taxon_text_8_3233:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 262).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 81).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 119).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 18).
taxon_text_9_5430: Rhinobatos annulatus. Alternative common name of Lesser guitarfish but neither the term ‘-shark’ nor ‘-fish’ reflect the much closer biological relationship to the rays.
taxon_text_1_5431: Distinctive flattened, wedge-shaped head with translucent, pointed snout; rest of body narrower and triangular in cross section. Pectoral fins broad and merged with head. Two upright dorsal fins set well back towards tail. Five pairs on gill slits on underside. Teeth blunt and pavement-like. Colour tan with numerous brown spots and white rings. Underside white.
taxon_text_2_5432: Up to 140 cm total length and a mass of up to 27 kg.
taxon_text_3_5433:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Angola to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5434: Distinctively shaped species found on sand from the intertidal zone to 130 m depth. Very common in sheltered areas such as Langebaan Lagoon, but also around deeper reefs. Often conceals itself with sand in extremely shallow water and erupts to escape only when about to be trodden on! Females reach sexual maturity at a length of 68–89 cm and males more quickly at a length of 59 cm. Longevity only about 7 years.
taxon_text_5_5435: Feed on burrowing crustaceans, bivalves, worms and smaller fish.
taxon_text_6_5436: Ovoviviparous – the eggs developing within the female feeding initially on egg yolk but at advanced stages of development receive additional nutrients through liquid produced by the uterus. Female then gives birth to fully-developed pups. Mating occurs from April to June and gestation takes about 10 months. There are usually 3–10 pups per litter and these are born at a length of about 23 cm.
taxon_text_7_5437: The unusual body shape is characteristic of the group and this is by far the most common guitarfish in the Western Cape. The much rarer Bluntnose guitarfish, A. blochii occurs from Namibia to Cape Point and can be recognised by its broader rounded snout and the plain brown dorsal colour of adults (juveniles may have a few white spots).
taxon_text_8_5438:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 262).

Harris, SA, Bennett, BA & Branch, GM (1988). An assessment of the role of the sand shark Rhinobatos annulatus as a predator in Langebaan Lagoon. South African Journal of Marine Science, 7(1), 153-159.

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 81).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 591).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 119).
taxon_text_1_3236: Head, body and pectoral fins together form a rounded flattened disc with the large, kidney-shaped electric organs clearly visible as swellings alongside the head. Eyes small, the raised spiracles directly behind them with raised rims. Tail short and sturdy with a rounded tail fin and a single rounded dorsal fin. Underside with five small gill slits and small mouth armed with tiny pointed teeth. Colour grey to brown above, underside white to yellow.
taxon_text_3_3238:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa (records from Mozambique and Madagascar unconfirmed).

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3239:
Occurs on sand, usually in shallow water, although has been recorded to a depth of 183 m. Bottom dwelling and often buries itself with just the eyes and spiracles exposed. Propels itself with the tail rather than the pectoral fins (as in most rays). Can deliver a potent electric shock to protect itself from predators and so best not handled!

Males reach sexual maturity at a length of 17–23 cm and females at about 16 cm.
taxon_text_6_3241: Details not studies in this species, but assumed to be viviparous, as with other electric rays (other related species typically produce 2–32 pups after about a 10-month gestation).
taxon_text_7_3242: The only coastal electric ray in the region. Several other species occur along the east coast (or in much deep water), but all those other South African species have two dorsal fins on the tail.
taxon_text_8_3243:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 591).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 214).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 119).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 18).
taxon_text_1_3246: Bizarre and instantly recognizable species with a silvery, scaleless skin, gill openings hidden by a soft operculum, long, pointed upper lobe to tail and a strange fleshy hoe-shaped proboscis extending from the snout. Front of first dorsal fin with a large, mildly-toxic, serrate spine. Males have intromittent organs (claspers) extending behind the pelvic fins, a small claw-like appendage (tentaculum) on the top of the head and an additional retractile clasper in a pouch in front of the pelvic fin.
taxon_text_2_3247: Up to 122 cm total length and a mass of about 5 kg.
taxon_text_3_3248:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to (rarely) KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3249: Found on soft substrata from the surf zone to a depth of over 300 m and most common in the SW Cape, where it supports a small fishery. The proboscis is used to detect prey buried in the sediments. Females reach sexual maturity at a length of 46- 50 cm and age of 4 years and males at about 43 cm after 3 years. Longevity about 10 years.
taxon_text_5_3250: Feeds on a variety of bottom-dwelling invertebrates including bivalves, crustaceans, sea-urchins, gastropods and worms, as well as on fish, particularly gobies and lightfish.
taxon_text_6_3251: Males grasp the females during copulation and insert small spermatophores with their claspers. Females lay distinctive large, spindle-shaped eggs (up to 23 cm long) that are surrounded a broad, flattened flange and somewhat resemble mango-pips. The eggs are laid two at a time and are left unattached on the sea floor until they hatch. Up to 22 eggs are laid per female each year. Incubation time is 9-12 months and size at birth about 13 cm. Hatched egg cases are often washed ashore where they generate much interest due to their peculiar appearance.
taxon_text_7_3252: Unmistakable and the only common chimera in the region.
taxon_text_8_3253:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 147).
taxon_text_1_3256: Elongate eel-like species with a smooth, flexible body lacking scales or paired fins, but tail surrounded by an extensive, rounded fin. Head lacks true (lensed) eyes, but has primitive eyespots and bears six short, tapering barbels around the oval mouth, four pointing forwards and two pointing backwards. Mouth has two extensible rows of horny, comb-like teeth borne on cartilaginous plates that can be everted and retracted to grasp food. Two rows of slime pores and six pairs of gill openings on underside of body. Colour uniform dark grey.
taxon_text_3_3258:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Walvis Bay in Namibia to Durban.
taxon_text_4_3259:
Hagfish are a very primitive group of vertebrates and have a cartilaginous skull and only rudimentary vertebrae. The group has remained virtually unchanged for over 300 million years.

This species is found from the intertidal to depths of up to 400 m and can occur both in crevices on rocky reefs or buried in sediments. It is a scavenger that rapidly gathers around dead or disabled fish, or other organisms, which are torn apart with the teeth, additional traction being created by knotting the body and pulling the head back against the knot. Secretes copious amounts of mucus when handled. Often caught in lobster traps and regarded as a pest by fishers.
taxon_text_5_3260: Scavenger, feeding on dead or disabled fish, crustaceans, bait or other animal material.
taxon_text_6_3261: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but other hagfish lay 1–30 large yolky eggs that are sticky and deposited in crevices in the rocks, or beneath the sand. Eggs can take up to 11 months to develop. There is no larval stage.
taxon_text_7_3262: Unmistakable and the only shallow water hagfish species found in the region.
taxon_text_8_3263:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Mincarone, MM (2017). Redescription of the hagfishes (Myxinidae: Eptatretus) from southern Africa. Marine Biology Research, 13(7), 797-810.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 147).
taxon_text_1_3266: Body flattened and disc-shaped with small, projecting mouth, as typical of this diverse tropical family. Colour silvery-white with narrow, dark vertical bar though eye and two wider brown vertical bands across body. Fins yellowish, dorsal fin with 1-2 black spots above posterior bar and caudal fin with yellow vertical bar. Adults have yellow spots in centre of each lateral scale.
taxon_text_3_3268:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay on west coast to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3269: The only southern African butterflyfish to extend into temperate waters. Usually seen singly or in pairs on shallow reefs, but extends to depth of 120 m. Juveniles sometimes in rock-pools.
taxon_text_6_3271: Matures at about 11 cm length, attained at an age of probably 2 years. Spawns between May and November, females releasing multiple batches of pelagic eggs.
taxon_text_7_3272: Many species of butterflyfish occur along the more tropical East Coast, but this is the only species found in the cooler waters of the South-western Cape. Barred colour pattern also diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_3273:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 308).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 228).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 629).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 45).
taxon_text_1_3276: Very long, slender eel, anterior part cylindrical, posterior part laterally compressed; light brown to silvery in colour, paler on underside, with a sharply pointed head and largish eyes. Jaws slender, the upper being longer than the lower. Jaws bear sharp, fang-like teeth and incapable of closing completely. Dorsal fin inconspicuous. Tail ends in a sharp, finless point.
taxon_text_2_3277: Recorded as growing up to 2.5 m, but most specimens found  along coast about 50 cm.
taxon_text_3_3278:
Global: Widespread across eastern Atlantic, Mediterranean, around South Africa to Mozambique and Comoros. The Indo-Pacific species currently known as O. macrorhynchos from China and Japan may be conspecific.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3279:
Found from the intertidal to a depth of at least 300 m in sandy and muddy areas. Often buried in the sediment with only the head visible, striking upwards to grasp prey. Probably mostly nocturnal and can bury itself in seconds, burrowing either tail first or headfirst.

Sometimes swallowed alive by predators and has been observed to burrow though the intestinal wall tail-first, but then become trapped in the abdominal cavity, as cannot penetrate the thicker abdominal wall!
taxon_text_5_3280: An ambush predator feeding mostly on small fish and crustaceans.
taxon_text_7_3282: Although numerous eel species occur in South Africa, most of these are restricted to the more tropical waters of the Indian Ocean and this is one of very few species found on the west coast. The very slender body and plain colour are also fairly distinctive, but members of this family are diverse (about 70 species in Western Indian Ocean) and difficult to identify to species level.
taxon_text_8_3283:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 266).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 106).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 126).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 184).
taxon_text_1_3286: Small, flattened, benthic fish with a broad head and wide mouth fringed with fleshy tentacles. Skin loose and body scaleless. Pectoral fin large and spread laterally. Colour pattern distinctive, light brown with dark brown patches and transverse bars, the banding extending onto pectoral and dorsal fins.
taxon_text_3_3288:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3289: Bottom-dwelling and reluctant to swim, usually just moving a short distance if disturbed. Fairly common in rock pools and under boulders and seldom found deeper than 10 m depth. Makes a grunting noise when handled.
taxon_text_5_3290: Details unknown, but assumed to be a predator of invertebrates.
taxon_text_7_3292: Easily recognised to group, but a second similar species, the Pleated toadfish Chatrabus felinus (formerly Batrichthys felinus), also occurs in the same region. That species grow considerably larger though (to 19 cm), has larger, bulging eyes, a loose, wrinkled skin and a fat-lipped mouth fringed with small tentacles. Colour dark brown with yellow barring.
taxon_text_8_3293:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 272).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 275).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 218).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 359).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 25).
taxon_text_1_3296:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, somewhat compressed species has a very short, blunt head with large eyes and no cirri above the eyes. The dorsal fin has 26–30 spines and 8–11 rays, the first few spines being slightly elevated and bearing small terminal cirri and with a slight notch between these and later spines. There is a more distinct notch between the last dorsal spine and the rays (distinguishing this genus from Clinus), the rays are also longer than the spines and hence raised to form a rounded crest. The pelvic fin has 3 rays.

Colour is variable, but often very attractively mottled in reds, pinks, greens and browns. There are generally a series of darker broken vertical bars along the sides and a large, round ocellus above the pectoral fin, this usually being green or blue centrally with a red ring. The eyes are red. Fins also brightly coloured, the pelvic fin especially with bright red bars and the anal fin with striking red and blue patches.
taxon_text_3_3298:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3299: Found in shallow waters generally less than 10 m depth. Usually associated with areas densely covered with algae, amongst which it is well camouflaged. Relies on concealment and readily approached underwater.
taxon_text_5_3300: Feeds mainly on amphipods, followed by polychaete worms, isopods and tanaids.
taxon_text_6_3301: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3302: Very attractive and brightly coloured species best identified by the combination of the short, blunt head, large ocellus above the pelvic fin, deep notch between the spines and rays on the dorsal fin and brightly coloured pelvic and anal fins. There is one other species in the genus B. stella, but this only occurs from Algoa Bay eastwards.
taxon_text_8_3303:
Bennett, B, Griffiths, CL & Penrith, ML (1983). The diets of littoral fish from the Cape Peninsula. African Zoology, 18(4), 343-352.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 385).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 759).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56).
taxon_text_1_3306:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This rather slender species has a laterally flattened, elongate body, with a somewhat depressed, wedge-shaped head bearing large eyes. The dorsal fin lacks any crest or notch between the spines and has 40–45 spines and 2–4 rays. The colour pattern in diagnostic and comprised a series of red longitudinal stripes against a pale background. There is often a broad white longitudinal band across the top of the head and an indistinct darker ocellus on the shoulder.
taxon_text_3_3308:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_3309: Rare and seldom photographed, but found in low shore tidepools or hiding on shallow reefs. Nothing else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_3310: Unknown for this species, but other members of genus feed on a wide range of benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3311: All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom. Details unknown for this species.
taxon_text_7_3312: Rare species, but easily recognised by the unique longitudinal stripes. Could be confused for an unusual colour morph of the Nosestripe klipfish Muraenoclinus dorsalis, which has a similar elongate shape, large eyes and white stripe along snout, but that species has only one dorsal ray and is normally plain green or brown.
taxon_text_8_3313:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 387).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 759).
taxon_text_1_3316:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This very elongated, slender, sand-dwelling species has eyes on top of the head and the lower jaw distinctly projecting. The dorsal fin has its origin above the vent and had 38–43 spines and 11–15 slightly longer rays. Pelvic fin consisting of 3 upturned rays connected by a membrane, like a frog-foot. Body colour cream, with a row of grey, darker-edged saddles dorsally and smaller spots along the flanks.
taxon_text_3_3318:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of South Africa to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_3319: Found on clean sand and gravel substrata from low water mark to a depth of about  20 m, especially where the bottom is thrown into distinct ripples. Surprisingly-well camouflaged against pink coralline algae that cover many of the shells and pebbles. Usually found buried in the sediment with only top of the head and eyes protruding. Able to insinuate itself quickly into the sand by wiggling the body side to side.
taxon_text_5_3320: Details not studied, but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and other small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3321: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3322: There are three species in this genus, all with similar habits. The Slender platana klipfish C. burrelli is semi-transparent and cream with 12 small dark blotches along the back, while the Whiteblotched klipfish is white with fine purple blotching and two broad purple-brown bands across the body, the posterior one extending onto the tail.

taxon_text_1_3326:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

Although uncommon, this species is one of the largest and most distinctive klipfishes and is easily recognized by the unique barbels around the mouth - three on the top lip and eight on the chin. The mouth is strongly extended forwards and has thick lips. Dorsal fin low, even in height and without anterior crest, many of the spines with small cirri at their tips. Colour variable, usually pale to dark reddish-brown with faint vertical bars and usually a distinct round blotch on shoulder. Juveniles very different in colour, with black and white longitudinal stripes and red fins, but still have the characteristic barbels.
taxon_text_3_3328:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_3329: Uncommon, usually found singly in low-shore rockpools and on shallow rocky reefs. Often seen in crevices or caves with only the head projecting.
taxon_text_5_3330: Unknown, but most clinids feed on small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3331: All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3332: The only regional clinid with barbels, making it unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_3333:

taxon_text_1_3336:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This relatively small, slender and stocky species has a large head and wide mouth. The dorsal fin has 30–34 spines, the first few with 2–3 small cirri at their tips; followed by 5–7 rays. The dorsal fin is relatively even in height with a slightly raised section over the posterior rays, but with no anterior crest or notch. Body colour variable, but usually pale green or yellow with darker head and a few wide vertical dark bars along the body (less obvious in larger individuals). Indistinct ocellus on shoulder and body often with scattering of numerous small white of yellow spots. Tips of pectoral fins reddish.
taxon_text_3_3338:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_3339: A common species in intertidal rock pools on the west coast, but tends to occur below the low tide mark on the south coast.
taxon_text_5_3340: Feeds on a wide range of diverse invertebrates. Juveniles take mostly amphipods, isopods and polychaete worms; but in larger individuals molluscs and decapod crustaceans become increasingly important.
taxon_text_6_3341:
All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

In this species females mature at about 80 mm and males between about 60-70 mm and gonad mass peaks in spring. Average number of mature embryos was found to be 91 with a maximum of 468 (much more than in other clinids where this has been measured), but young were born at a correspondingly relatively small size of only 13 mm.
taxon_text_7_3342: Probably most similar to West coast klipfish, C. heterodon but that species has a shorter, more rounded head and a prominent, blue-edged spot (ocellus) on the shoulder.
taxon_text_8_3343:

taxon_text_1_3346:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This relatively slender species has a low dorsal fin with 32-38 spines, followed by only 2-4 rays (the lowest number of any Clinus species). The first few spines are not raised into a crest, but there is a distinct notch between spines 3 and 4. There are small, simple cirri at the tips of the first 15 or so spines, but these are not obvious. Pigmentation extends onto the dorsal fin membranes except between the last few rays, where there is a distinct clear window. The tail membrane is also clear. There is a small cirrus above the eye that resembles a raised hand with the fingers extended.

Body colour is variable, as with most clinids, but most commonly speckled white or pale green or brown, with about 7 darker vertical bars, these often alternately darker and lighter. Eye colour divided into segments of white and dark and often marked oblique white lines from eye across cheek.
taxon_text_3_3348:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay, but primarily a west coast species.
taxon_text_4_3349: A common species in intertidal rock pools on the west coast, also in estuaries.
taxon_text_5_3350: Has a more restricted diet than many other clinids, with only three groups of prey – amphipods, isopods and polychaetes (in that order) – making up significant components of the diet.
taxon_text_6_3351:
All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

In this species females mature at the unusually small size of about 45–60 mm and males at an even smaller 40–50 mm and gonad mass peaks in spring and early summer (Aug - Nov). Average number of mature embryos was found to be 31 with a maximum of 192 and young were born at average size of 15 mm.
taxon_text_7_3352: One of the most common klipfish on the west coast and best identified by the low dorsal fin, which both lacks a crest and has an unusually low number of fin rays.
