taxon_text_9_3355: Although originally recognized as being a distinct variety within the C. superciliosus complex, this form was long subsumed under that name, and has only recently been recognized as an independent species. It is thus important to note that any biological information (on diet, reproduction, etc) published prior to 2012 refers to the whole group and not to any one of the six component species now recognized.
taxon_text_1_3356:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are smallish, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

Clinus arborescens is fairly slender and reaches quite a large size. The dorsal fin has 36-41 spines and 4-7 rays with the first 3 spines raised into a tall crest, which is followed by a deep notch extending almost to the body. This notch is visually enhanced by the upper membrane after the third spine being predominantly see-through, and this is the most useful identification character in the field. The anterior spines are all tipped by obvious clusters of cirri. The orbital cirrus is a short, flat, branching tree-like stalk (hence presumably the scientific name).

Body colour extremely variable with shades of pink or red with about 8 dark vertical half-bars running up the dorsal half of the body and onto the dorsal fin. There are usually scatterings of numerous small white and/or blue dots and a strong oblique band running from the eye across the operculum. The iris of the eye has about 6 equally-spaced brown spokes.
taxon_text_3_3358:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_3359: In rock pools and on shallow reefs. Appears to be associated with red understory algal growth and prefers to stay close to these hide-outs.
taxon_text_5_3360: Diet (assessed before splitting species) consists mostly of crustaceans, polychaetes and mollusks. Smaller prey items, such a copepods, amphipods, isopods and polychaetes declined in importance in larger fish, whereas larger prey, such as decapods and mollusks, plus the occasional fish, became more important in large specimens.
taxon_text_6_3361: Females reach sexual maturity between about 110–120 mm and males between 50–60 mm, although males eventually grow much larger than females and there appears to be a dominance hierarchy based on male size (so large males probably  monopolise females). Between 20–144 live young are born per brood at an average length of 20 mm (as assessed before splitting species).
taxon_text_7_3362: There are six species in the supercilious-Group. This one is reasonably easily recognised by the combination of largely colourful and often red colouration, strongly elevated crest on the dorsal fin, deep excavation following the third spine and bunches of cirri on the anterior dorsal spines. The “window” in the membrane behind the dorsal crest is diagnostic and separates this species from the similar Super klipfish C. superciliosus, Mosaic klipfish C. musaicus and Shy klipfish C. exasperatus. These are all common and occur next to each other in the same area although they segregate by microhabitat and show different behaviours, which gives useful identification clues in the field. This was observed by Tess Attwood during her UCT B.Sc. (Hons) project on different colour morphs in the clinids: Clinus aborescens prefers semi-open habitats that give “shrub”-like cover to hide at slightly deeper depth than the Super klipfish. Often hides in low algae such as upright wrack, red algae but also invertebrate overgrowths or feather stars. Can be approached at very close distance without swimming away.

taxon_text_1_3366:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This species has a large, blunt head with a steep profile, wide mouth and large, dark, bulging eyes. Above each eye is a bony ridge and a tentacle consisting of a flat stalk, tipped by numerous filaments. The low, even dorsal fin has 31–36 spines and 4–6 rays and neither a raised crest nor notch behind the first few spines.

Body colour mottled cream and brown with indistinct vertical dark bars, a characteristic large brown spot on the operculum and two oblique brown bars below the eye. Pectoral fins large and transparent.
taxon_text_3_3368:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Olifants River on west coast to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3369: Common in intertidal rock pools, especially under boulders, less common subtidally. Often the most abundant fish species found in intertidal pools east of Cape Point. Particularly active at night.
taxon_text_5_3370: Feeds on a wide range of invertebrates. Isopods and amphipods are the most important components of the diet, followed by decapod crustaceans, polychaete worms and barnacle cirri.
taxon_text_6_3371:
All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

In this species females reach sexual maturity between about 65–80 mm and males at a smaller size of 60–65 mm. The average number of embryos per female is 15 (one of lowest number among species examined) and the size at birth is about 15 mm.
taxon_text_7_3372: Fairly easily recognised by the blunt head, large eyes and characteristic large, round, black spot on the operculum.

taxon_text_1_3376:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This rather plain-looking species is of average body shape and eye size and the dorsal fin lacks both an anterior crest and notch in the membrane. Dorsal fin has 33–36 spines and 8–9 rays, these being about 1.5 times longer than the spines, thus raised into a slight posterior hump. The cirrus above the eye is the most unique identification feature and is a flat stalk with a fringe of fine, elongate filaments. Body colour is fairly uniform light pink or yellow brown with irregular mottling and indistinct vertical bars which extend onto the dorsal fin.
taxon_text_3_3378:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Has a restricted distribution only from Saldanha Bay to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_3379: Rare and seldom photographed, but usually found subtidally on sandy substrata. Nothing else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_3380: Unknown for this species, but other members of genus feed on a wide range of benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3381: All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom. Details unknown for this species.
taxon_text_7_3382: Fairly inconspicuous and rare species, but easily recognised by the unusual form of cirri above the eye.
taxon_text_8_3383:

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 763).
taxon_text_9_3385: Only recognized as a distinct species (within the C. superciliosus complex) in 2012, so any biological information on diet, reproduction, etc. published prior to 2012 incorporated under the wider definition.
taxon_text_1_3386:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are smallish, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

Clinus musaicus appears to be a range-restricted form within the broader C. superciliosus complex and has a dorsal fin with 38-40 spines and 7-8 rays, the first 3 spines forming a low crest with a shallow notch between the 3rd and 4th spines. The orbital cirrus is a flat stalk with several short, simple branches.

The species is defined largely by colour and more boldly marked than most other clinids. Ground colour is very variable, including pink, grey, brown or black, but the upper half of the body usually has a series of bold lozenge-shaped darker marks with another offset series around the midline, while the lower part of the body is generally white, often broken into reticulated pattern by darker lines (hence illusion to ‘mosiac’ ), or speckled with small white spots. Fin membranes usually transparent and can end in pastel colours.
taxon_text_3_3388:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of Cape Peninsula to Betty’s Bay.
taxon_text_4_3389: Found on shallow reefs and pebble beds to a depth of about 10 m.
taxon_text_5_3390: Diet (assessed before splitting species) consists mostly of crustaceans, polychaetes and mollusks. Smaller prey items, such a copepods, amphipods, isopods and polychaetes decline in importance in larger fish, whereas larger prey, such as decapods and molluscs, plus the occasional fish, became more important in large specimens.
taxon_text_6_3391: Females reach sexual maturity between about 110–120 mm and males between 50–60 mm, although males eventually grow much larger than females. Between 20–144 live young are born per brood at an average length of 20 mm (as assessed before splitting species) .
taxon_text_7_3392: There are several closely-related species within the C. superciliosus complex, but this one is reasonably easily recognised by its bold mozaic- like colour patterns. The specimen 33.14 depicted as C. superciliosus by Zlilavecz belongs to this species.

Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 166(4), 827-853.
taxon_text_1_3396:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This species is one of the most distinctive of all klipfishes and is easily recognized by the form of the dorsal fin, in which the first 8 spines are separated from one another by deep notches in the membrane and are each tipped by a bunch of prominent filaments. The body is stocky with large eyes and there is a conspicuous cirrus above each eye, composed of a flat base leading to a hand of long, thin filaments. The dorsal fin has 31–34 spines and 5–7 rays.

Colour variable pale brown to red with several (usually 4) darker vertical bars.
taxon_text_3_3398:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_3399: Uncommon species found on deeper reefs from about 13–50 m depth, usually concealed within dense growths of seaweeds, bryozoans, soft corals or crinoids and brittlestars, within which they are well camouflaged. Little studied and few details available on biology. The name derives from the fact that the species was originally described as coming from the South China Sea. However, this was later found to be an error, and the original specimen probably came from False Bay!
taxon_text_5_3400: Details unknown, but most other clinids feed on small benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3401:
All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

No specific details available on this species.
taxon_text_7_3402: Easily recognised by the unique form of the dorsal fin in which the first 8 spines are well separated by deep notches in the membrane and each is tipped by a conspicuous bunch of cirri.
taxon_text_8_3403:

taxon_text_1_3406:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This unusually large species has a very stocky, compressed body and blunt, rounded head bearing a large mouth and thin lips with vertical corrugations. The dorsal fin has 32–34 spines and 9–14 rays, the first 3 spines being raised into a slight crest, followed by a shallow notch before the 4th spine. Colour mottled brown or reddish with broken darker bars that extend onto the dorsal and pectoral fins. Usually cheek bars radiating form below eyes. Eyes with a circle of radiating lines around the iris.
taxon_text_2_3407: Unusually large, reaching at least 37 (some report 50) cm total length.
taxon_text_3_3408:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3409: A rare species usually associated with algae, uncommon in intertidal. Stagnant and well camouflaged. No other details known.
taxon_text_5_3410: Diet of this species has not been studied, but the large mouth and sluggish habits suggest that it is probably an ambush predator capable of taking larger prey.
taxon_text_6_3411: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3412: The large size, blunt head, wide mouth with its corrugated lips and notch after third spine on the dorsal fin identify this species.
taxon_text_8_3413:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 396).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 764).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 62).
taxon_text_9_3425: It was recently recognized that several closely-related species were being confused under this one name and thus the previous ‘species’ long known as C. superciliosus has now been split to create six species. These are C. superciliosus itself, which remains valid and indeed is the most common or at least most conspicuous of the ‘daughter’ species, and the new (or resurrected) C. arborescens, C. exasperatus, C. ornatus, C. musaicus and C. spatulatus. It is thus important to note that any biological information (on diet, reproduction, etc) published prior to 2012 refers to the whole group and not just the form now known as C. superciliosus.
taxon_text_1_3426:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are smallish, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

Clinus superciliosus is one of the larger species in the genus and is the most common clinid at many intertidal and shallow water sites. The head is large and the dorsal fin has 32–38 spines and 8–9 rays, the first three spines being strongly elevated into a conspicuous triangular crest, which is most pronounced in adult males, where it can be 2.5 times the height of the rest of the fin. There is a deep notch after the third spine and the crest spines lack conspicuous cirri but have a single filament at tip. The cirrus above the eye has a short stalk with a flattened end bearing short branches – these being longer and more filamentous in males.

Body colour is extremely variable and can be plain or mottled green, grey, red or brown, but there are usually about 6 vertical half-bars on the dorsal side of the body and often radiating lines from the eyes across the cheeks. Often a dark comma-shaped spot is present on the operculum and a black spot at base of second dorsal spine.
taxon_text_3_3428:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3429: A very common species in rock pools and on shallow reefs. Very inquisitive and will often approach snorklers. The body colour changes with habitat, paler individuals often occurring in sandy areas, green ones among seagrasses, red ones among red algae etc. Males grow larger than females.
taxon_text_5_3430: Diet (assessed before splitting species) consists mostly of crustaceans, polychaetes and mollusks. Smaller prey items, such a copepods, amphipods, isopods and polychaetes declined in importance in larger fish, whereas larger prey such as decapods and mollusks, plus the occasional fish, became more important in large specimens.
taxon_text_6_3431: Females reach sexual maturity between about 110–120mm and males between 50–60 mm, although males eventually grow much larger than females and there appears to be a dominance hierarchy based on male size (so large males probably  monopolise females). Between 20–144 live young are born per brood at an average length of 20 mm (as assessed before splitting species).
taxon_text_7_3432: Colour very variable and there are several closely-related species. The best identification features are the large size, robust shape, tall crest on the dorsal fin and lack of cirri on those spines.
taxon_text_8_3433:

Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 166(4), 827-853.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 765).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 63).
taxon_text_1_3436:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This relatively small, slender and compressed species has an even dorsal fin of 35–41 spines and 2–3 rays, lacking either an anterior crest or notch (although the second spine may be slightly longer than the others). The cirri above the eyes are elongate and spoon-shaped, with lateral branches. Colour highly variable and often very attractive, commonly with broken brown or red vertical bars, and often with two large, dark spots on dorsal fin. There is generally a distinctive yellowish, dark-edged flare across the cheek and the eyes have a characteristic radiating pattern of alternating orange and green ‘spokes’.
taxon_text_3_3438:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3439: A fairly common species usually found on rocky reefs below the intertidal and to a depth of about 30 m. The attractive and variable colour patterns and striking eye colour make this a photographer’s favourite, although the enormous variation in colour can make identification tricky.
taxon_text_5_3440: Unusual in that the most common component of the diet is brittle stars, with amphipods, isopods, and other small crustaceans making up most of the remainder.
taxon_text_6_3441: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3442: Colour variable, but most specimens can be recognised by the unusual green and orange spoked colour of the eyes, the flash across the cheek and the two large spots on the dorsal fin. The spoon-like cirri above the eyes with their marginal branches also a good identification feature.
taxon_text_8_3443:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 328).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 399).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 765).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 64).
taxon_text_1_3456:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This slender, strongly laterally-compressed species has a small head and mouth and a long, slender peduncle to the tail. The dorsal fin has 25–28 spines and 3–4 rays, with the first three spines distinctly raised into a crest separated by a deep notch from following spines. There is no tentacle above the eye.

The colour is extremely variable, but is usually fairly plain green, yellow, red or brown, often with paler horizontal bars. The body colour extends onto the dorsal fin, which has a series of pale windows after ever 2–3 spines. Pale windows also present in tail and anal fin. Eyes usually with three darker spokes forming a Y.
taxon_text_3_3458:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3459: Sluggish, slow-moving species, associated with dense algae, among which it is well camouflaged. Colour varies with host algae. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_3460: Small-mouthed species that feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and copepods. In larger fish copepods become less important and polychaetes, isopods and mollusks make up more of the diet.
taxon_text_6_3461: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3462: The only member of this endemic genus, but several similar and easily confused species occur in the related genus Pavoclinus, which have similarly slender bodies and elongated caudal peduncles and are very variable in colour. The windows in the dorsal fin are a good distinguishing feature.
taxon_text_8_3463:
Bennett, B, Griffiths, CL & Penrith, ML (1983). The diets of littoral fish from the Cape Peninsula. African Zoology, 18(4), 343-352.

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 390).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 766).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 65).
taxon_text_1_3466:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, elongate and eel-like species has a narrow, pointed head marked with a conspicuous white dorsal stripe running forward from the dorsal fin (and after which it is named). The dorsal fin is low and even, with no anterior crest. Colour variable, but usually plain greenish brown to almost black.
taxon_text_3_3468:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3469: A very common species in intertidal pools on rocky shores. Has the unusual capability of surviving for long periods out of water and frequently found under exposed boulders at low tide where the tide would only return after several hours.
taxon_text_5_3470: Small-mouthed species that feeds mainly on amphipods and isopods, as well as some polychaete worms.
taxon_text_6_3471:
All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.  

In this species females reach sexual maturity at about 4.5 cm and males at about 5 cm. Several broods of eggs and embryos at different stages of development are present within a single female at any one time, with an average of about 14 juveniles in the most developed brood. Gestation is thought to take 4-6 months and young are born at a length of about 20 mm (surprising large, relative to other larger clinid species which has smaller babies).
taxon_text_7_3472: Easily recognised by the slender body shape, plan colour and especially the white nose stripe.
taxon_text_8_3473:
Bennett, B, Griffiths, CL & Penrith, ML (1983). The diets of littoral fish from the Cape Peninsula. African Zoology, 18(4), 343-352.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 328).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 766).
taxon_text_1_3486:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This slender, laterally compressed species has an elongate head, a small mouth and a long, slender peduncle to the small tail. The dorsal fin has 30–36 spines and 2–4 rays and first three of the spines are distinctly raised above the fourth and following ones. The colour is extremely variable and can change depending on the algal species on which the specimen is living (see very variable images in references below). The body can have longitudinal brown or white bands, may be mottled in pinks and brown or can be fairly plain green, brown (as depicted here) or red. There consistently tends to be a series of wavy blue-green lines radiating from the eye back to the operculum (and forwards to the mouth) and this is perhaps the best way to identify the species.
taxon_text_3_3488:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3489: Found on shallow rocky reefs from intertidal to about 15 m depth and strongly associated with algae, in which they nestle. Well camouflaged and colour varies, depending on that of the host algae. Placid and tends to remain still and rely on concealment to escape predators.
taxon_text_5_3490: Small-mouthed species that feeds mainly on amphipods and isopods, as well as some polychaete worms and small molluscs.
taxon_text_6_3491: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3492: There are several similar and very easily confused species within this genus, although some can be distinguished by habitat (for example P. smalei occurs only on gravel bottoms), or are not found in the Western Cape (P. myae, P. mentalis, P laurentii).  The Bluespot klipfish C. caeruleopunctatus is particularly similar in both appearance and habitat, but has a notch between dorsal spines 3 and 4 and has characteristic round blue spots on the cheeks (after which the name is derived).
taxon_text_8_3493:
Bennett, B, Griffiths, CL & Penrith, ML (1983). The diets of littoral fish from the Cape Peninsula. African Zoology, 18(4), 343-352.

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 391).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 403).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 768).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 76).
taxon_text_1_3496:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, fairly-elongated species has a pointed head and small mouth, while the dorsal fin is not elevated anteriorly and has 36–38 spines and 2–3 rays. The colour pattern is distinctive, comprising a pale cream ground-colour with three irregular dark-purple/brown dorsal saddles and paler purplish patches and scribbles between. The gravel habitat is also a useful aid to identification, as most related species occur on reefs.
taxon_text_3_3498:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3499: Found on clean gravel substrata, especially where the bottom is thrown into distinct ripples. Surprisingly-well camouflaged against pink coralline algae that cover many of the shells and pebbles. Usually seen sitting on the sediment surface, but can dive into the sand if disturbed.
taxon_text_5_3500: Details not studied, but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and other small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3501: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3502: Both the colour pattern and habitat distinguish this from other members of the genus, which are also larger and found on rocks or among algae. Can be confused with the Platana klipfish Xenopoclinus kochi, which occurs in the same habitat, and has a similar colour pattern, but that species is much more elongate, has the eyes set more towards the top of the head and differs in details of colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_3503:
Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 769).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 69).
taxon_text_1_3506:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This species has a characteristic body shape, being very laterally compressed with a short, steeply inclined head. The tall dorsal fin originates far forwards, almost above the eyes, and is expanded anteriorly into a large, rounded crest formed by the first five spines, but with no notch in the membrane behind this crest. The dorsal fine has 28–31 spines and 4–6 rays. Body colour fairly uniform green, yellow or dark brown, often pale patches on fins and a white patch beneath base of pectoral fin.
taxon_text_2_3507: Up to at least 20 cm total length, some sources report 30 cm.
taxon_text_3_3508:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3509: A rare species usually associated with kelps and other algae. No other details known.
taxon_text_5_3510: Diet of this species has not been studied, but the cryptic colouration and apparent sluggish habits suggest it is an ambush predator of invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3511: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3512: The laterally compressed body, blunt steeply-sloping head, and large crest on the dorsal fin readily identify this species.
taxon_text_8_3513:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 404).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 768).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 68).
taxon_text_1_3516:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, slender klipfish has a flattened head and eyes set well-forward and high on top of the head. Dorsal fin low, with 33–37 spines and 7–11 rays, anterior spines not raised into a crest. Pelvic fin unusual in that it has 3 not 2 uncurled rays that are joined by a membrane along most of their length (giving ‘web-footed’ appearance and hence common name ‘platana’ klipfish). Colour pattern distinctive and off-white with about 8 transverse pink to purple bars, each with a darker outline, sides of body with bright white spots.
taxon_text_3_3518:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_3519: Found on clean gravel substrata from the low intertidal to depths of at least 15 m, especially where the bottom is thrown into distinct ripples. Surprisingly-well camouflaged against pink coralline algae that cover many of the shells and pebbles. Usually found shallowly buried in the sediment with just the eyes showing above the sediment surface. If disturbed swims a short distance before diving back into the sand like an eel. Difficult to detect and probably much more common that existing observations suggest.
taxon_text_5_3520: Details not studied, but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and other small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3521: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. This species has an unusually large, cylindrical penis. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3522: Distinctive colour pattern and unusual gravel habitat makes this slender species fairly easy to identify. A second member of the genus, the Leprous platana klipfish X. leprosus occurs in the same habitat, but has more laterally placed eyes and is different in colour - being black with 3–5 broad white saddles across the back. The Deep-reef klipfish Pavoclinus smalei is similar in colour but has a much different shorter body and is not elongated.
taxon_text_8_3523:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 406).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 769).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 68).
taxon_text_1_3526:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, slender klipfish has a somewhat flattened head and eyes set high on the sides of the head. Dorsal fin low, with 31–36 spines and 7–12 rays, anterior spines not raised into a crest. Pelvic fin unusual in that it has 3 not 2 uncurled rays that are joined by a membrane along most of their length (giving ‘web-footed’ appearance and hence common name Leprous ‘platana’ klipfish). Colour pattern distinctive and essentially black with 3-5 broad white saddles across the back.
taxon_text_3_3528:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of South Africa to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_3529: Found on clean gravel substrata at depths of at least 20 m, especially where the bottom is thrown into distinct ripples. Surprisingly-well camouflaged against pink coralline algae that cover many of the shells and pebbles. Usually seen sitting on the sediment surface, but can dive into the sand if disturbed.
taxon_text_5_3530: Details not studied, but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds mainly on amphipods, isopods, and other small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3531: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3532: Distinctive colour pattern and unusual gravel habitat makes this slender species fairly easy to identify. A second member of the genus, the Platana klipfish X. kochi occurs in the same habitat, but has more dorsally placed eyes and is different in colour - being cream with a series of about 8 narrow pinkish-purple vertical bars, each with a darker purplish margin.
taxon_text_8_3533:
Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 769).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 69).
taxon_text_1_3446:
Triplefins are a minor group of small, cryptic, benthic fish best characterized by the fact that the dorsal fin is divided into three separate parts. The pelvic fins are elongate and formed of only two rays and one hidden spine. Only one species is found in the Western Cape region of South Africa.

The Cape triplefin has a short, blunt face with thick lips and large eyes. There is a short, bushy, branched cirrus above the eye and another smaller one on the nostril. Colour normally blotchy cream and brown, but breeding males become brightly coloured with broad orange or yellow mottled vertical bands and blue dots.
taxon_text_3_3448:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3449: Cryptic although quite common. Usually found hiding amongst dense growth of invertebrates or algae on the rock-faces of shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_3451: The reproductive behaviour of this species has not been documented, other than that the breeding males become brightly coloured. In other species in the family males have been reported to defend territories on the vertical walls of reefs. Females visit the males and release adhesive eggs in areas of dense algal cover. The males then guard the eggs as they develop.
taxon_text_7_3452: The only triplefin species in the Western Cape. Could superficially be confused with klipfish (Famly Clinidae), but those have a single dorsal fin.
taxon_text_8_3453:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 326).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 230).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 756).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 53).
taxon_text_1_3106:
Small, elongate shark with two small, triangular and equal-sized dorsal fins that lack anterior spines and are set far back, both behind pelvic fin. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Deep grooves connect nostrils to mouth, nasal barbels absent.

Colour pattern distinctive: ground colour pale yellow–brown with 8–10 prominent dorsal saddles that have orange central areas and dark brown to almost black margins. Whole of upper side covered in small pale spots. Underside pale.
taxon_text_3_3108:
Global:  Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_3109:
Benthic species found on shallow reefs and in kelp beds, sometimes extending into intertidal pools, also over sandy bottoms in eastern part of the range. May form groups when resting and curls into a tight ball when disturbed, wrapping the tail over the head – hence the common name shyshark.

This species (like many other shysharks) have a special green fluorescent protein in their skin that makes them glow in the dark! This biofluorescence is possible due to the absorption of the ocean’s blue light which is then emitted by the protein as a greenish glow. It is thought this ability is useful in communication and finding a mate, which is backed up by the fact that these sharks have special eyes that can see this glow.

Mature at a length of about 40–50 cm at an age of about 7 years. Longevity estimated as at least 22 years. These sharks are caught as bycatch during demersal trawls and have seen their population decline in the last few decades, hence giving them an Endangered status on the IUCN Red List.
taxon_text_5_3110: Feeds on small bony fish, worms, crustaceans and cephalopods. Interestingly, male and female shysharks prefer different food. Males have an affinity for polychaete worms, while females tend to prefer crustaceans. The different sexes even have different tooth shapes, with males having three-pointed teeth, while females have five-pointed teeth, likely driving their dietary preferences.
taxon_text_6_3111: Oviparous, females laying pairs of rectangular egg cases with long tendrils at each corner. Egg cases about 3–5 cm long by 1.5–3 cm wide and distinctively coloured light brown with about 4 wide transverse paler bands. Incubation time about 3 months and young born at a length of about 10 cm.
taxon_text_7_3112: Can be confused with the closely-related Dark shyshark, H. pictus, which also occurs in the same habitats. However, that species has a broader, more depressed head and is much darker in colour, with less distinct saddles that are dark brown to almost black and has fewer, less obvious spots.
taxon_text_8_3113:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 260).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 479).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 91).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 13).
taxon_text_1_5865: Small to medium elongate shark with two small, triangular dorsal fins that lack anterior spines and are set far back, both behind pelvic fin, first dorsal fin slightly the larger. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Pelvic fins completely fused to form a ‘pelvic curtain’. Colour light brown above with about 7–9 darker dorsal saddles, some with darker margins, and numerous white to light-yellow spots (no black spots). Underside cream.
taxon_text_3_5867:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal, more common in the west. Record from India is an error.
taxon_text_4_5868:
A benthic species found mostly around deeper rocky reefs with literature records of 26–695 m depth. Fairly rarely photographed by divers although sometimes seen in shallow kelp forests. More common and occurs in shallower waters in the Western Cape; rarer and deeper in the warmer waters to the east. Curls up when disturbed.

Males mature at a length of about 84 cm and females at about 75 cm and males grow larger than females. Little else known about behaviour.
taxon_text_5_5869: Feed on bony fish and various invertebrates, especially crustaceans and worms, also cephalopods.
taxon_text_6_5870: Oviparous, females laying pairs of rectangular egg cases with long tendrils at each corner. Young are born at a length of about 25–27 cm.
taxon_text_7_5871: Despite the name, spots can be white rather than yellow (at least in available live images, which may be of juveniles). Easily confused with Shysharks of the genus Haploblepharus, but these are smaller in size (<60 cm), occur in shallower waters and differ in details of colour pattern. Similar to the Puffadder shyshark H. edwardsii, but that species has much more pronounced tan saddles and more numerous, smaller white spots. The Dark shyshark H. pictus is much darker with almost black saddles and much less distinct spots.
taxon_text_8_9547:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 492). 

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_3416: This species has a stocky, compressed body and blunt, rounded head with a large mouth. The dorsal fin has 30–32 spines and 8–9 rays, the anterior portion being raised into a distinctive low, rounded crest with no notch separating this  from rest of the fin. Colour usually pale pink, green, yellow or brown with upright bars of darker pigmentation. Head may be coloured strikingly differently from body. Eyes with a dark pupil and distinctive circle of spoke-like bars around the iris. Juveniles often have bright red head.
taxon_text_3_3418:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_3419: An uncommon species usually associated with kelps and other algae. Sluggish and well camouflaged. No other details known.
taxon_text_5_3420: Diet of this species has not been studied, but the large mouth and sluggish habits suggest that it is probably an ambush predator taking larger invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3421: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_3422: The large, blunt head, wide mouth and low crest on the dorsal fin readily identify this species.
taxon_text_8_3423:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 397). 

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 765).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 62).
taxon_text_1_3536:
This diverse family includes a wide variety of mostly larger, powerful, predatory species including various regional species of kingfish, queenfish, trevallies, pompanos, etc., many of which are of commercial importance. However, the family is much more diverse in more tropical waters, with only a few representatives in the Western Cape.

The Leerfish can be recognized by its powerful, strongly laterally compressed, silvery-green body, pointed head, large mouth, and elongate forked tail. The anterior sections of both the dorsal and anal fins project into matching pointed lobes. The dark lateral line is characteristic, curving upwards over the pectoral fin and then down again behind it.  

Juveniles are yellow with 6–7 black vertical stripes across the hind portion of the body.
taxon_text_2_3537: Up to 150 cm total length and a mass of up to 32 kg.
taxon_text_3_3538:
Global: Widely distributed from Europe and the Mediterranean and along the west coast of Africa, around Southern Africa to Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Whole region from Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3539:
Adults found close to the shore in clear water, both in estuaries and in the open sea; juveniles mostly in estuaries. Voracious predators of shoaling fish. Adults may migrate considerable distances, some moving up the east coast along with the sardine run.

Fast growing and reach sexual maturity at about 75–80 cm (at age only 3–4 years), reaching 90–150 cm by age 5–9 years.
taxon_text_5_3540: Small juveniles feed on mysids, shrimps and small fish and can swallow prey up to 70% of their own length! Large juveniles feed mostly on estuarine fish such as sardines and mullet. Adults exclusively piscivorous and feed on shoaling fish, sometimes hunting in packs and causing prey to jump wildly out of the water.
taxon_text_6_3541: Most adults spawn along the KwaZulu-Natal coast from September to November.
taxon_text_7_3542: One of only a few large inshore carangids in the region and can be recognised by the very compressed body and unusual shape of the lateral line.
taxon_text_8_3543:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 312).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 308).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 54).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 652).
taxon_text_1_3546: Large, graceful and sought after fishery species that shoals in mid-water. Body spindle-shaped with powerful forked tail and short pectoral and dorsal fins. Colour blue above and white below with a yellow to bronze line along the side. Fins a characteristic yellow, hence the name.
taxon_text_2_3547: Large, attaining 190 cm total length and a mass of 58 kg (but typically half this size).
taxon_text_3_3548:
Global: Widespread across southern hemisphere, sometimes extending into north Pacific. Goes by a variety of regional common names including Yellowtail (South Africa), Yellowtail amberjack (USA) and Yellowtail kingfish (Australia).

Local/Regional: Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3549:
Large, predatory shoaling species and a prized angling and eating fish that is subject of a substantial fishery. Fast growing and reaches maturity after 2–3 years and at a length of 61–72 cm. Longevity up to 10 years.

Usually found in large shoals, especially off Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula, but portions of the population follow the pilchard migration (Sardine run) up the east coast each winter.
taxon_text_5_3550: Predatory, feeding mainly on fish, squid and crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_3551: Spawns mainly from October to March. Spawning takes place following high-speed courtship behavior between a single female and pursuing male. The eggs are buoyant and develop in surface waters.
taxon_text_7_3552: Unlikely to be confused with other regional species, due to the distinctive colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_3553:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 312).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 311).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 61).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 228).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 657).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 49).
taxon_text_1_3556: Laterally flattened and elongate-oval with thick lips, single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail fin. Pectoral fin red with the lower few rays elongated and free (hence name) - these being used as support the body when resting on the bottom. Body yellowish, densely marked with irregular dark red and brown spots and with staggered brown vertical bars but these are broken at the lateral line. Colouring extends onto dorsal and tail fin.
taxon_text_3_3558:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3559: Usually found singly and common in tide pools and shallow reefs to a depth of about 25 m. Often sits on the bottom using the thickened free lower pectoral rays as support. When disturbed usually swims lazily a few meters then settles again.
taxon_text_5_3560: A predator, feeding mostly on benthic invertebrates such as worms, crustaceans and gastropods.
taxon_text_6_3561: Details unknown, but eggs probably develop in plankton, as the extremely compressed postlarvae (‘paperfish’) are found offshore, sheltering under floating objects.
taxon_text_7_3562: Similar in body shape and habits to the Barred fingerfin C. pixi, but that species tends to occur in deeper waters and has five broad and vertical bars that continue through the lateral line. Also similar in body shape and habits to the Twotone fingerfin Chirodactylus brachydactylus (note the confusingly similar but different genus name), but that species has a quite different colour pattern, being brown with a large silvery patch across the side of the head and shoulder and five white dots along the lateral line.
taxon_text_8_3563:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 316).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 323).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 83).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 228).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 667).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 49).
taxon_text_1_3566: Laterally flattened and elongate-oval with thickish lips, single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail fin. Pectoral fin pale, with the lower few rays markedly elongated and free (hence common name) - these being used as support when resting on the bottom. Body colour pale with small red and brown spots, plus five broad unbroken brown vertical bars. Tail fin transparent and not striped.
taxon_text_3_3568:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3569: Smallish fish usually found singly and more commonly on deeper reefs of 10-30 m (but has been recorded from 5 m to at least 100 m). Often sits on the bottom using the thickened free lower pectoral rays as support and when disturbed swims lazily a few meters, then settles again.
taxon_text_6_3571: Details unknown, but eggs probably develop in plankton.
taxon_text_7_3572: Similar in body shape and habits to the Redfingers C. fasciatus, but that species tends to occur in more shallow waters, has a darker mottled body, a striped tail, and the vertical bars on the sides are broken and staggered at the level of the lateral line. The Twotone fingerfin Chirodactylus brachydactylus (note the confusingly similar but different genus name) is also similar in shape and habits, has a quite different colour pattern, being uniform brown with a large silvery patch across the side of the head and shoulder and five white dots along the lateral line.
taxon_text_8_3573:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 316).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 83).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 228).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 667).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 49).
taxon_text_1_3576:
Laterally flattened and elongate-oval with thick lips, single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail fin. Pectoral fin with lower rays free and extended into finger–like appendages used to support the fish when resting on the bottom. Body colour plain brown with a large silvery patch on side of head and over gills and row of four silvery spots along lateral line.

Juveniles quite different in appearance being plump and silvery-blue with about 6 black transverse bars across the back.
taxon_text_3_3578:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3579: Usually found singly on rocky shores and shallow reefs but extends to a depth of 240 m. Juveniles common in rock pools in the Western Cape. Often sits on the bottom using the thickened free lower pectoral rays as support.
taxon_text_5_3580: Feeds on benthic invertebrates, such as crustaceans and bivalves. Ingests mouthfuls of sand, sifting out prey with the gill-rakers before ejecting the sand though the gill openings.
taxon_text_6_3581: Matures as a length of 25 cm and spawns in summer. Juveniles initially silvery and acquire adult colouration when about 5 cm in length.
taxon_text_7_3582: Similar in body shape and habits to the Redfingers Cheilodactylus fasciatus (note the confusingly similar but different genus name), but that species has a quite different colour pattern, being speckled with irregular brown spots and with staggered lateral brown bars. The Bank steenbras Chirodactylus grandis in the same genus also occurs in the region but that species rarely visits shallow waters and is also uniformly pale or dark grey.
taxon_text_8_3583:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 316).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 323).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 84).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 230).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 667).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 50).
taxon_text_1_3586:
Large species (largest in the family) with laterally flattened and elongate-oval body, large head and very thick, fleshy lips. The single continuous dorsal fin has 17–18 even spines and 22–24 slightly longer rays. Tailfin large and forked. Pectoral fin with lower 6 rays extended into finger-like projections.

Body colour plain silvery-grey with slightly darker head and fins. A characteristic red stripe runs from below eye forwards across the forehead.
taxon_text_2_3587: Typically 80 cm but can reach up to 180 cm total length.
taxon_text_3_3588:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3589: Usually found singly on deeper rocky reefs, from about 20–150 m depth. Sought after eating fish caught by trawl, as well as by ski-boat fishers and spearfishers.
taxon_text_5_3590: Feeds during the day on benthic invertebrates, mainly polychaete worms, amphipods and other crustaceans, but also sometimes on small fish and squid.
taxon_text_6_3591: Reproductive biology of this species has not been studied but other species in this family juveniles are laterally flattened and shelter under floating objects.
taxon_text_7_3592: Thick lips and red stripe in front of the eye are characteristic distinguishing features. The smaller Twotone fingerfin C. brachydactylus is similar in body shape and also has thickened lips, but has a distinctive two-tone brown and white colour pattern after which the name is derived.
taxon_text_8_3593:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 316).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 323).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 84).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 667).
taxon_text_1_3596: Oblong, laterally compressed, fairly plain dark-grey fish with small scales, a continuous dorsal fin and a mask-like black patch around eyes. Head somewhat pointed and teeth fused to form a parrot-like beak. Juveniles quite different in colour, being yellow with a black vertical bar though eye, another in front of tail and a black patch around base of pectoral fin.
taxon_text_2_3597: Up to 90 cm total length and a mass of 7 kg.
taxon_text_3_3598:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3599: Juveniles sometimes found under floating objects at sea and have been seen cleaning other fish. Adults on inshore reefs from depths of about 5–100 m, often found in crevices and caves.
taxon_text_5_3600: Generalist feeder, consuming a wide range of sedentary or slow-moving benthic invertebrates including sponges, tunicates, barnacles, bryozoans, sea urchins and holothurians, as well as some algae.
taxon_text_6_3601: Reaches sexual maturity at a length of about 40 cm and an age of about 5.7 years. Has a protracted breeding season with a peak in spring. Grows fairly slowly and has a longevity of about 14 years.
taxon_text_7_3602: Fairly unmistakable and the only species in this family found in the Western Cape. A second darker species, the Natal knifejaw O. robinsoni, occurs from about Algoa Bay eastwards.
taxon_text_8_3603:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 300).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 18).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 229).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 632).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46).
taxon_text_1_3606: Laterally flattened, dull brown fish with a deeply forked tail and flat forehead. Best identified by distinctive large mouth with strongly projecting lower jaw (hence common name). Interior of mouth white. Juveniles yellow with vertical black stripes and enlarged pelvic fins.
taxon_text_2_3607: Up to 60 cm total length and reaching a mass of 5.4 kg.
taxon_text_3_3608:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3609: Swims over reefs at depths of 15–200 m. The weak dentition and large gill-rakers indicate this is a filter feeder. Grows to over 5 kg, but since does not take bait seldom caught by anglers and known mostly to divers.
taxon_text_5_3610: Most references report this species to filter water thought the enlarged gill rackers and consume zooplankton, especially small crustaceans, such as mysids. It has, however, also been observed taking larger prey, such as squid, by sucking them from the water column using the large, extensible mouth. Also often seen swimming after fish larva.
taxon_text_6_3611: Details unknown and the only representative of the family.
taxon_text_7_3612: Head shape and projecting lower jaw distinctive and unlikely to be confused with other species.
taxon_text_8_3613:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 299).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 249).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 341).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 229).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 632).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46).
taxon_text_1_3616: Smallish, cylindrical fish with a single triangular dorsal fin that lacks spines, a forked tail and no lateral line. Mouth terminal with few to no teeth, but internally with up to 120 large gill rakers for filter feeding. Colour silvery blue with a distinctive row of 10–15 black spots along side.
taxon_text_2_3617: Up to 32 cm length but typically about 20 cm.
taxon_text_3_3618:
Global: Widespread from Southern Africa across the Indo-Pacific, with distinct genetic lineages in Southern Africa, Australia, Chile, California and Japan.

Local/Regional: Southern Angola to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3619:
Form huge pelagic schools and the target of a major purse seine fishery. The fishery landed up to 400 000 t in South Africa and 1.4 million t in Namibia at its peak in the 1960’s, but these catches were unsustainable and have since declined markedly. Also major source of food for numerous predatory species, including piscivorous fish such as snoek, tuna, yellowtail and kob, seabirds such as penguins and gannets, as well as sharks, dolphins and seals.

Undertakes complex migrations. Some spawn on the Agulhas Bank and their eggs drift westwards, juveniles congregating off the west coast in autumn and winter, then gradually working their way southwards back to the spawning grounds. Some also migrate inshore up the east coast in winter, following pockets of cooler water and resulting in the well-know sardine-run, in which dense schools are attacked by congregations of birds, fish, whales and dolphins, as well as by humans.
taxon_text_5_3620: The fish swim forward with the mouth widely gaping and gather microscopic phytoplankton, copepods and fish eggs on the enlarged gill rakers, which serve as an efficient filter-feeding apparatus.
taxon_text_6_3621: Most of the stock spawns in spring and summer over the Agulhas Bank, with some also migrating to KZN where they spawn in winter and spring. The eggs and larvae are planktonic.
taxon_text_7_3622: Can be confused with various other small silvery schooling fish such as Redeye roundherring, but these lack the lateral spots and have the anal fin placed further back, behind the base of the dorsal fin. Anchovy are smaller (up to only 13 cm), lack the lateral spots, but have a silvery stripe along the flank and the snout projects forwards in front of the mouth.
taxon_text_8_3623:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 268).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 108).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 151).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 204 as S. ocellatus).
taxon_text_1_3626: Fairly deep-bodied, robust, laterally compressed species with a smallish mouth. Dorsal fin with 10 short, strong spines, separated by notch from rayed part, which has 18–19 taller rays. Body scales extend onto fins. Colour uniform dark grey to almost black, sometimes with poorly-defined darker vertical bars. Can rapidly change colour when moving over different substrata. Juveniles with pale vertical bars. Front margins of pelvic and anal fin whitish-grey.
taxon_text_2_3627: Up to 80 cm total length and a mass of 6.5 kg.
taxon_text_3_3628:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Angola to north coast of KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3629: Well-known angling species and South Africa’s national fish. Found in shallow waters with strong wave action and often resident on the same reef for long periods, although some tagged individuals have been recorded making extensive migrations. Uses its strong curved teeth to tear attached invertebrates from reefs.
taxon_text_5_3630: Omnivorous, feeding mostly on a variety of benthic invertebrates, mainly mussels, gastropods, ascidians, worms and crustaceans, but also algae.
taxon_text_6_3631: Females mature at 34 cm, which is attained at an age of about 6 years and males mature at 31 cm. Longevity about 13 years. Spawning takes place from October to March. The eggs and larvae are planktonic.
taxon_text_7_3632: There are only two species in this family, which is restricted to Southern Africa (including Madagascar). The other species, the Banded galjoen D. multifasciatus is similar in body shape, but has about 14 alternating broad and narrow dark vertical bands along its sides. It is found mostly along the east coast, but can extend as far west as False Bay.
taxon_text_8_3633:

taxon_text_9_3635: Previously incorrectly known as Argyrosomus hololepidotus, which remains a valid species, but occurs only off Madagascar.
taxon_text_1_3636: Large, fairly elongated, silvery fish with a bronzy sheen, large scales, a wide fleshy-lipped mouth and a square tail. Black spot at base of pectoral fin and a row of silver spots along the lateral line.
taxon_text_2_3637: Up to 180 cm total length and a mass of up to 75 kg.
taxon_text_3_3638:
Global: Has a widespread Indo-Pacific distribution in coastal waters from South Africa, up the east coast of Africa to Oman, Pakistan, India, China, Korea, Japan and Australia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3639:
Small juveniles strongly associated with estuaries, larger ones also common in the surf zone. Adults occur mostly over soft substrata, but also in the vicinity of reefs or wrecks, ranges from the surf zone to a depth of 120 m. Reaches an age of at least 42 years.

Can produce loud sounds using muscles to vibrate the gas-filled swim bladder (hence the alternative common group name of drums or croakers) – these sound probably associated with spawning behaviour.

A very important recreational and commercial fishery species, not only in South Africa, but also in Australia, where known as mulloway. Both stocks overfished.
taxon_text_5_3640: Juveniles feed on small crustaceans, such as copepods and mysids. Adults feed on fish, shrimp and squid.
taxon_text_6_3641: Females mature only at a length of about 110 cm at an age of 6 years and males at 92-100 cm and an age of 5 years. Spawn on inshore reefs at night. In the western Cape the spawning season is October to January, but the bulk of the population spawn in KZN in August to November.
taxon_text_7_3642: Easily confused with the very similar Silver kob A. inodorus (indeed that species was only recognised and described in 1995). The main distinguishing factors are that the Silver kob has a longer, narrower peduncle to the tail and a longer pectoral fin. Also similar to Squaretail kob A. thorpei, but that species only occurs from Algoa Bay eastwards.
taxon_text_8_3643:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 300).
