Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 394).
taxon_text_1_3646:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This species has a relatively elongate body for a sparid (body depth = head length) and a slightly protruding lower jaw with 4 large anterior canine teeth. The body is silvery-red, the red extending onto to pectoral and tail fins. The lateral line is conspicuous and the sides bear about 7 horizontal bands of blue spots alternating with silvery bands. The eyes are red.
taxon_text_2_3647: Up to 80 cm total length and a mass of up to 5 kg, but most fish seen in shallower water much smaller than this.
taxon_text_3_3648:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3649: Adults common on deeper reefs of 50-200 m, where form the basis of a significant fishery. Juveniles on shallower reefs from 10-40 m. A schooling species and has been recorded migrating over distances of at least 300 km.
taxon_text_5_3650: Juveniles feed on small crustaceans and worms, while adults feed mostly on squid and small schooling fish, such as anchovy and pilchard.
taxon_text_6_3651: Do not change sex. Females reach sexual maturity as a length of about 25-27 cm and males at 26-28 cm. Spawn throughout their range in December to April. Eggs develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3652: Colour pattern similar to that of Panga Pterogymnus laniarius, which is also pink and has horizontal bands of blue spots. However, Panga have a deeper body, flaring canine teeth and a blue line across the cheek.
taxon_text_8_3653:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 288).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 392).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 582).
taxon_text_1_3656:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

Adults of this species are deep-bodied with a steep, projecting forehead (slightly concave in adults) and fairly large mouth. Head and body orange, becoming paler on underside. Blue line between the eyes and small dark marks along rear of operculum and at base of pectoral fin. A larger and distinctive black patch at rear of dorsal fin. Juveniles pink with a faint horizontal band along side, two darker blotches beneath dorsal fin and distinct spot at rear of dorsal fin (as in adults).
taxon_text_2_3657: Up to 75 cm length and 9 kg in mass.
taxon_text_3_3658:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3659:
A schooling species found on low profile reefs. Adults occur in deeper waters at a depth of 25-100 m. Juveniles found more inshore and even in rock pools. Change sex from females to male as they grow. Females reach sexual maturity at 37-38 cm and an age of 9-10 years. They then become male at 42-46 cm at an age of about 11 years. Longevity at least 23 years.

Heavily exploited by both recreational and commercial fishers and stocks depleted and classified as Critically Endangered. Size at maturity and of sex change become reduced in heavily exploited populations.
taxon_text_5_3660: Generalist predators feeding on a range of prey including crabs, worms, squid, fish, and echinoderms.
taxon_text_6_3661: Spawn mostly in summer (October to January) in the Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_7_3662: Can be confused with a number of other red seabreams in the same genus, such as Red stumpnose C. gibbiceps, Roman C. latipes (and in the eastern part of its range with Slinger C. puniceus), but the black spot at the rear of the dorsal fine is a reliable identification feature.
taxon_text_8_3663:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 290).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 217).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 583).
taxon_text_1_3666:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

Adult males of this species are easily recognized by the conspicuous hump that develops on the forehead, after which the common name is derived. Large adults of this overexploited species, which anyway inhabit deeper waters, are now mainly seen in captivity though, while juveniles are more commonly seen on shallower reefs. Younger fish have distinct reddish vertical bars of varying widths, the bulbous forehead starting to become evident at a length of about 25 cm. In larger individuals the barring becomes less distinct and ‘messy’ and the body develops numerous black spots.
taxon_text_3_3668:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3669: Adults occur in deeper waters at a depth of 30-150 m and are solitary. Juveniles can be seen on shallow reefs singly or in small groups. Reach sexual maturity at about 30 cm and may change sex with age. IUCN status Endangered.
taxon_text_5_3670: Generalist predator feeding on a range of invertebrates including gastropods, mussels, ascidians, sea urchins, cephalopods, crabs, worms and fish but particularly brittle stars.
taxon_text_6_3671: Poorly known, but spawns in summer and eggs probably develop on plankton.
taxon_text_7_3672: The bulbous forehead of large males is unmistakable. Smaller fish can be confused with other vertically red-striped sparids such as the Englishman C. anglicus, and False englishman C. lophus but these only occur further up the east coast.
taxon_text_8_3673:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 290).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 296).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 224).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 584).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 35).
taxon_text_1_3676:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, but some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow and this change may be in either direction – having larger females resulting in production of more eggs, but having larger more powerful males allowing them to better defend their territories!

This iconic fish is one of the most attractive in the region and is sought after by underwater photographers, but also by anglers and spearfishers! It is easily identified by its bright red body colour with a large triangular white patch behind the head and vertical white bar below the dorsal fin. There is a blue line between the eyes. Juveniles are initially pale reddish-brown with a dark brown horizontal line extending forward from the tail and they develop their red colour from about 5 cm length.
taxon_text_2_3677: Up to 50 cm length and 5 kg in mass.
taxon_text_3_3678:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3679: Adults found on rocky reefs from 5–100 m depth, females occurring in small groups, but males are solitary and territorial, remaining in the proximity of a home cave or crevice for extended periods. Juveniles often in small groups and occur closer inshore, usually in caves or crevices. Change sex from female to male, females reaching maturity at a length of 17–20 cm and then changing to male at a length of 30-33 cm. Heavily exploited populations reach maturity and change sex at a smaller size. Longevity at least 17 years.
taxon_text_5_3680: Ambush predators feeding on a range of prey including crustaceans, echinoderms, molluscs and worms.
taxon_text_6_3681: Spawn in summer. Eggs and larvae develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3682: Although there are several other red seabreams in this same genus, the white patches behind the head and white vertical bar below the dorsal fin are diagnostic for this species.
taxon_text_8_3683:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 290).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 219).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 296).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 224).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 584).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 36).
taxon_text_1_3686:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, but some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is very distinctive as an adult, due to its very large size, black body (with white belly), thick lips, stout conical teeth and unusual bulbous, fleshy nose. Large adults are seldom seen in the wild though and juveniles, which lack the prominent nose, are dark (initially greenish or yellowish) brown with 2 broad black vertical areas and irregular white patches.
taxon_text_2_3687: Up to 150 cm total length and a mass of up to 34 kg.
taxon_text_3_3688:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Town to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3689: Adults found on rocky reefs from 2–100 m and are solitary and stagnant, defending a small home range. They have long been targeted by both anglers and spearfishers though and are thus now rarely seen. Juveniles occur on shallower reefs and in algal beds. Slow-growing and long-lived,  reaching an age of 45 years.
taxon_text_5_3690: Juveniles feed mostly on crustaceans. Adults take a wide variety of larger prey, including echinoderms, crustaceans, cephalopods, chitons, gastropods and fish.
taxon_text_6_3691: Change sex from female to male as they grow. Females reach sexual maturity at a length of about 43 cm (age about 10 years) and then change to become males at about 70 cm or 18 years. Spawns in winter.
taxon_text_7_3692: Adult males very easily recognised by their huge size and unusual faces, and are star attractions in regional aquaria. Juveniles more conventional in shape, but still have distinctive colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_3693:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 290).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 298).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 585).
taxon_text_1_3696:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This silvery species is deep-bodied and easily recognized by the distinctive black blotch on the top and sides of the tail peduncle, after which the common name is derived. Juveniles also have 8–10 faint black bars dorsally, while adults may also show such bars during the night.
taxon_text_3_3698:
Global: Southwest Atlantic and Indian Oceans.

Local/Regional: Angola to Mozambique, Madagascar, Oman and Pakistan.
taxon_text_4_3699:
A common species across the region. Juveniles often found in rockpools and also in estuaries and over shallow reefs. Adults on shallow reefs and in kelp beds from the intertidal to a depth of about 40 m.

Reaches maturity at a length of 22 cm, equivalent to age of about 3–4 years. Can attain an age of at least 21 years. Some but not all males later change sex to become females.
taxon_text_5_3700: Juveniles feed mainly on small crustaceans and worms (and in the case of estuarine populations on insects), whereas adults take a wide range of prey including algae, sea urchins, anemones, sponges, bivalves and tunicates.
taxon_text_6_3701: Spawn July to September in KZN, and October to December in Eastern Cape. Eggs develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_8_3703:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 292).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 586).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 36).
taxon_text_1_3706:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is easily recognized by its diagnostic colour pattern of 6 dark vertical bars against a silvery background. The first dark bar runs though the eye and the last across the peduncle of the tail. Adults also have short, thin black bars across the belly in the interspaces between the main bars. Barring fades at night. Juveniles are yellowish between the bars.
taxon_text_3_3708:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3709:
Found on rocky shores from low water to a depth of about 120 m. Juveniles tend to occur inshore, even in rock pools, and are common in estuaries. They stay close to cover, often occurring in caves and crevices in the reef. Adults occur singly or in small groups and swim in open water round reefs.

Reaches maturity at a length of 29 cm, equivalent to age of about 6 years. Can attain an age of at least 33 years.
taxon_text_5_3710: Juveniles feed mostly on small crustaceans and worms (also insects in the case of estuarine populations), adults mostly consume amphipods and worms.
taxon_text_6_3711: Do not change sex. Spawn from September to January. Eggs develop on the plankton.
taxon_text_8_3713:

taxon_text_1_3716:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This fairly plump species can be rather easily recognized by its dark coppery-brown body colour (becoming blue-grey on the head), startling bright blue eyes and prominent, outwardly-curving teeth.
taxon_text_3_3718:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3719: Usually solitary and found on rocky reefs from shore to a depth of 80 m. Often shelters in overhangs and caves. Life history and longevity poorly known.
taxon_text_5_3720: Omnivorous, feeding on tunicates, algae, bryozoans, worms and crustaceans torn from the rock with the protruding teeth.
taxon_text_6_3721: Details unknown. Eggs presumed to develop in the plankton, as with other members of this family.
taxon_text_7_3722: The blue eyes are unmistakable. Otherwise similar in body shape to Hottentot (Pachymetopon species), but these differ in colour pattern and also lack the protruding teeth.
taxon_text_8_3723:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 292).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 586).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 37).
taxon_text_1_3726:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This well-known species grows to a larger size and is more elongate that most others in the family. It has a long, sloping forehead, thick lips and a strongly protrusible mouth. Colour silver with 7 faint dark vertical bars that become less prominent in large adults.
taxon_text_2_3727: Up to 200 cm total length and a mass of up to 30 kg.
taxon_text_3_3728:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Orange River mouth to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3729:
Unlike the most species in this family, found over sand rather than rocky reefs. Juveniles spend the first year of life in estuaries, larger juveniles in the surf zone of beaches. Adults from the Western Cape undertake a breeding migration to spawn in the Eastern Cape from June to August, returning to the Western Cape in summer, where they many get caught in numbers off the beaches by trek net fishers.

Adults have an unusual method of feeding, adopting a vertical posture and probing into the sediment with the strongly extended mouth in search of burrowing prey. When feeding in shallow water the tail can sometimes be seen waving above the water surface.

Reach sexual maturity at the unusually large size of 54–65 cm (at age 5–6 years) and can reach an age of 25–30 years. Highly sought after commercial and recreational angling fish and currently overexploited. IUCN conservation status Endangered.
taxon_text_5_3730: Juveniles feed on small crustaceans, worms and insects in estuaries. Adults feed on burrowing crabs and prawns, bivalves and worms off beaches.
taxon_text_6_3731: Do not change sex. Spawn in July-August close inshore in the Eastern Cape, the larvae drifting southwards and after metamorphosis entering estuaries.
taxon_text_7_3732: The elongate body shape distinguishes this species from most other sparids. The closely related Sand steenbras L. mormyrus is much smaller (up to only 55 cm), has a convex snout and 10–14 narrow dark vertical bars on the body.
taxon_text_8_3733:

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 302).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 224).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 587).
taxon_text_1_3736:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

The Sand steenbras is relatively small for a sparid, reaching only about 50 cm. It has a fairly elongate body, convex forehead (distinguishing it from the larger, but closely-related white steenbras), a protrusible mouth and small teeth. Colour silvery with a yellowish sheen and with 12–14 vertical dark bands.
taxon_text_2_3737: Up to 55 cm total length and a mass of up to 1 kg.
taxon_text_3_3738:
Global: Widely distributed from western Europe and Mediterranean down the west coast of Africa and around the coast of South Africa to Mozambique. Also reported from the Red Sea and Oman.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3739: Unlike most species in this family, and as the name suggests, found over sand, rather than rocky reefs. Juveniles in bays and estuaries and in the surf zones of beaches. Adults over sandy bottoms at depth of 10–50 m. Sometimes form large shoals.
taxon_text_6_3741: In the Mediterranean males mature at a length of about 14 cm and age of 2 years, changing sex to become females at 21–28 cm, when they are aged 4–7 years. Spawns in summer all along the South African coast. Larvae planktonic.
taxon_text_7_3742: The elongate body shape distinguishes steenbras from most other sparids. The closely-related White steenbras L. lithognathus is much larger (up to 200 cm), has a straight or slightly concave snout and only 7 and larger dark vertical bars on the body.
taxon_text_8_3743:

taxon_text_1_3746:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is fairly plump with a largish eye and pectoral fin longer than the head. Adult males have a slightly concave snout profile and bulge between the eyes. Mouth is small and lacks molars; front part of operculum scaly (distinguishing it from similar Bronze bream). Colour silvery-bronze on body, streaked with blue, head distinctly blue-tinged. Dorsal fin spines blue. Fin membranes distinctly yellow.
taxon_text_2_3747: Up to 50 cm total length and a mass of up to 5 kg.
taxon_text_3_3748:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana Bay.
taxon_text_4_3749: Found on rocky reefs to a depth of about 75 m, juveniles usually more inshore at 10–20 m.
taxon_text_5_3750: Feeds on a wide range of benthic invertebrates, particularly hydroids, tunicates and octocorals.
taxon_text_6_3751: First matures as female at a length of 20–25 cm and then changes sex to become male at a length of 20–30 cm (age of 4–9 years). Spawns from September to March, eggs developing in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3752: Easily confused with the two other Pachymetopon species in the region. The Hottentot P. blochii (which is much the most common of the species) has a smaller eye and is fairly plain bronzy-brown. The Bronze bream P. grande is plumper with a smaller head and is bronze brown with a blue tinge on head. The anterior part of the operculum lacks scales.
taxon_text_8_3753:

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 588).
taxon_text_1_3756:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is plain and unremarkable in shape and colour. The eye is not enlarged, the mouth fairly small and the colour uniform dark bronze-grey to brown in with a paler underside and dusky fins.
taxon_text_2_3757: Up to 54 cm total length and a mass of up to 3 kg.
taxon_text_3_3758:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa

Local/Regional: Angola to Eastern Cape, but uncommon east of Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_3759: Probably the most common fish found over inshore reefs along the west coast and often seen in small shoals milling about in kelp beds and over shallow reefs to a depth of about 55 m. Lend to be resident at a particular site.
taxon_text_5_3760: Omnivorous, feeding on algae and on wide range of benthic invertebrates, including various crustaceans, worms, hydroids, mollusks, ascidians and sometimes other fish. Larger individuals feed mostly on algae.
taxon_text_6_3761: Reach sexual maturity at about 22 cm, which equates to an age of 5 years. Spawn year-round but with peaks in late autumn and summer.
taxon_text_7_3762: Easily confused with the two other Pachymetopon species in the region. The Blue hottentot is plumper, has a larger eye and the body is streaked with blue, especially on the head. The Bronze bream P. grande is also plumper with a smaller head and is bronze brown with a blue tinge on head. The anterior part of the operculum also lacks scales.
taxon_text_8_3763:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 294).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 229).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 588).
taxon_text_1_3766:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is fairly plump and oval, with a small head and pectoral fin longer than the head. Adult males have a slightly concave snout profile and bulge between the eyes. The mouth is small with 5 rows of incisors and no molars. Preoperculum (front part of operculum) without scales (distinguishing it from similar Blue hottentot). Colour bronze on body, head iridescent blue.
taxon_text_2_3767: Up to 74 cm total length and a mass of up to 6 kg.
taxon_text_3_3768:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Maputo.
taxon_text_4_3769: Found singly or in small groups on rocky reefs to a depth of about 25 m, usually in rough water and often near caves. Juveniles usually more inshore and among algae. Tend to be resident, sometimes remaining in the same area for years. Slow growing, reaching an age of at least 40 years. Sought after by anglers and spearfishers.
taxon_text_5_3770: Feeds primarily on red and green algae and associated fauna.
taxon_text_6_3771: Does not change sex and matures at a length of about 30 cm (age of 5 years). Spawns from January to June, eggs developing in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3772: Easily confused with the two other Pachymetopon species in the region. The Hottentot P. blochii (which is much the most common of the species) has a smaller eye and is fairly plain bronzy-brown. The Blue Hottentot P. aeneum is more elongate with a larger head and is grey-bronze streaked with blue and with a cobalt blue front to head. The anterior part of the operculum in the latter species is scaled.
taxon_text_8_3773:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 294).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 588).
taxon_text_1_3776:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, although some mostly larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This powerful, robust species has a large mouth equipped with projecting canine teeth. Adult colour fairly plain reddish-bronze; juveniles reddish-orange with a black spot on the back behind the dorsal fin and near base of tail. In small juveniles the belly and peduncle of the tail are also bright yellow.
taxon_text_2_3777: Up to 200 cm total length and a mass of 70 kg.
taxon_text_3_3778:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3779: Adults found over rocky reefs in 20–160 m of water, juveniles occur more inshore in 10–30 m. A legendary angling fish that once formed an important component of both recreational and commercial line fisheries, but now severely overexploited and adults thus seldom seen. Usually solitary.  Only reaches sexual maturity at the large size of 58–75 cm and age of 7–9 years (making the species particularly vulnerable to overexploitation) and reaches an age of 55 years. IUCN Red List status Endangered.
taxon_text_5_3780: Adults are voracious predators feeding on large prey such as cephalopods and other fish.
taxon_text_6_3781: Spawning aggregations form in July-October off the Eastern Cape and the fish are particularly vulnerable to fishing exploitation at this time. Larvae pelagic and drift in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3782: Large size and colour pattern fairly distinctive but does vary considerably with age.
taxon_text_8_3783:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 294).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 589).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 39).
taxon_text_1_3786: Common, attractive and well-known species popular with anglers. Head elongate and projecting, with long, sloping forehead and protrusible terminal mouth. Silvery in colour with numerous black spots on body (but not on head) and a black patch on hind edge of operculum. Juveniles without spots but retain the dark patch on operculum.
taxon_text_2_3787: Up to 90 cm length and 10 kg in mass.
taxon_text_3_3788:
Global: Widespread in tropical and warm-temperate Indian Ocean from South Africa to India, including Madagascar and Seychelles.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3789: Found over sandy bottoms in shallow coastal waters and in estuaries. Sensitive to cold waters and extend into False Bay mainly only in summer. Feed by adopting an upright posture and plunging the jaws into the sediments, taking in mouthfuls of sand, sifting out burrowing invertebrates and expelling the waste sediment from the gill openings. Juveniles found mostly in estuaries.
taxon_text_5_3790: Feeds on burrowing crustaceans such as sand and mud-prawns and on bivalves.
taxon_text_6_3791: Matures at length of 36 cm in females and 30 cm in males (both at 3 years of age). Usually spawns at sea from August to December in the eastern part of the range, but also recorded spawning in estuaries. Juveniles enter estuaries in spring and summer and remain there for about a year before returning to the sea at 17–20 cm length.
taxon_text_7_3792: Easily identified by the elongate head and distinctive spots on the body. The Cock grunter P. multimaculatus is also spotted, but the dots also extend onto the head and the species is found only from Algoa Bay eastwards.
taxon_text_8_3793:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 284).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 190).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 279).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 568).
taxon_text_1_3796: Fairly small, plain, oblong species with a uniform greenish-silver colour, yellowish fins and a dark blotch at rear of operculum, just above base of pectoral fin.
taxon_text_3_3798:
Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate Indian Ocean from South Africa to Somalia, Oman, Madagascar, India, Indonesia and Malaysia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3799: Common in inshore waters of 10–90 m depth, where it can form large shoals. Juveniles found in lower reaches of estuaries. Can be an important component of the diets of inshore predators like sharks and dolphins. Common name derived from the fact that it can make a grunting sound. Lives for up to 10 years.
taxon_text_6_3801: Matures at about 14 cm length. Spawning occurs throughout the year.
taxon_text_7_3802: Lacking in distinctive features (other than the black blotch on the operculum) and can thus be confused with various other unrelated silvery fish, such as juvenile kobs.
taxon_text_8_3803:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 284).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 281).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 568).
taxon_text_1_3806:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This species has a moderately deep body (body depth greater then head length) and the jaw has 4–6 enlarged canine teeth, the outer pair on each jaw curved outwards. The body is pink, becoming silvery below, the pink extending onto the fins and tail. The body has faint longitudinal lines of blue spots, with some blue spots extending onto the operculum.
taxon_text_2_3807: Up to 45 cm length and a mass of up to 1.5 kg.
taxon_text_3_3808:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3809: Found on deepish reefs from 20–230 m depth and seldom closer inshore, so infrequently encountered by divers. Can, however, form large shoals in deeper water, where it is an important target of trawl and line fisheries. Thought to be the most abundant of all regional sparid species. Longevity estimated at 16 years.
taxon_text_5_3810: Feeds mainly on crustaceans, worms, brittlestars and small fish.
taxon_text_6_3811: Does not change sex. Reaches sexual maturity as a length of about 20–28 cm at age 4–5 years. Spawns all year round. Eggs develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3812: Can be confused with Carpenter, Argyrozona argyrozona which has a similar colour pattern, but a less deep body (body depth = head length), attain a much larger size (80 cm, 5 kg) and lack blue spots on the operculum.
taxon_text_8_3813:
Booth, AJ & Buxton, CD (1997). The biology of the panga, Pterogymnus laniarius (Teleostei: Sparidae), on the Agulhas Bank, South Africa. Environmental Biology of Fishes, 49, 207-226.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 310).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 39).
taxon_text_1_3816:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This well-known species has a deep body with the blunt rounded head typical of all stumpnose and after which the common name is derived. It can be distinguished from other regional stumpnose by its silvery body marked by 6–7 faint dark vertical bars.
taxon_text_2_3817: Up to 65 cm total length and a mass of up to 3 kg.
taxon_text_3_3818:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3819: Adults found in shoals both in sandy and rocky areas from the low water mark to a depth of 120 m. Juveniles common in estuaries and in the surf zone of beaches and may occur in mixed shoals with the closely-related Cape stumpnose. Tend to move offshore in winter and concentrate inshore in summer. Can reach an age of about 21 years.
taxon_text_5_3820: Small juveniles feed mostly on zooplankton and later on filamentous algae and small crustaceans. After their molars develop at about 4 cm they start to take shelled mollusks, larger crustaceans and worms. Adults feed on bivalves, worms and a variety of crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_3821: Do not change sex. Reach sexual maturity as a length of about 17–23 cm (2-4 years of age). Spawn inshore in spring and summer (August to February). Eggs develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3822: Body shape and habits similar to Cape stumpnose R. holubi, but that species lacks the dark vertical bars and instead has a horizontal golden band running along the side from head to tail. Could at first glance be confused with the White steenbras Lithognathus lithognathus and perhaps Sand steenbras L. mormyrus as both species also have vertical bars but long and tapering mouths instead of a blunt rounded head.
taxon_text_8_3823:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 235).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 310).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 226).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 592).
taxon_text_1_3826:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This species has a deep, silvery body and the blunt, rounded head typical of all stumpnose (and after which the common name is derived). It can be distinguished from other regional stumpnose by the single golden horizontal bar running along the side of adults from head to tail. In juveniles there are 5–6 fainter bars. There is also a small back spot at the base of the pectoral fin.
taxon_text_2_3827: Up to 40 cm total length and a mass of up to 3.5 kg.
taxon_text_3_3828:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3829: Juveniles use sheltered bays, estuaries and lagoons as nursery areas and are common around seagrass beds. They reach a length of about 10 cm after their first year, after which most return to the open sea. Adults occur in shoals over both rocky reefs and sandy bottoms from the shore to a depth of 50 m.
taxon_text_5_3830: Juveniles graze on algae and seagrasses, but mostly only digest the epiphytic diatoms and encrusting invertebrates associated with these. Adults take a wide variety of invertebrates including echinoderms, crustaceans, molluscs, bryozoans and worms.
taxon_text_6_3831: Do not change sex. Reach sexual maturity as a length of about 19–20 cm. Spawn inshore from July to February in the Cape (but in winter in KZN). Eggs develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3832: Body shape and habits similar to White stumpnose R. globiceps, but that species has dark vertical bars and lacks a horizontal golden band running along the side. Also similar to Tropical stumpnose R. sarba, but that species only occurs from Wilderness eastwards and has a golden spot in the centre of each scale, rather than a golden line along the side of the body.
taxon_text_8_3833:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 237).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 311).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 592).
taxon_text_1_3836:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs (although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This relatively elongate but plump, smaller species is often seen forming dense shoals on shallow reefs and is fairly easily recognized by the silvery ground colour and 8–10 prominent yellow horizontal stripes running the length of the body. The fins are also tinged with yellow and there is a small black spot at the base of the pectoral fin.
taxon_text_2_3837: Up to 45 cm total length, but mostly much smaller.
taxon_text_3_3838:
Global: Widespread from western Europe and Mediterranean, down the west coast of Africa and around Southern Africa to Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3839:
A common species across the region and found in tightly-shoaling groups of similar-sized individuals across a variety of habitats, including in estuaries, the surf zones of sandy beaches and on shallow reefs and into gullies and rock pools. 

Most, but not all, individuals change sex, first maturing as males at a length of about 14–15 cm (2 years) and then after one year as a male changing to become female at a length of 18–22 cm. A few individuals, however, do not follow this pattern and either remain male for one or two extra years, or skip the male phase entirely and mature directly into females.
taxon_text_5_3840: Small juveniles feed mainly on small crustaceans, particularly copepods. Adults are herbivorous, mainly on red algae and seagrasses.
taxon_text_6_3841: Spawns April to September in large groups. Larvae develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3842: Colour pattern fairly unmistakable. Some stumpnose species also have horizontal yellow stripes, but these are fewer and less distinct and stumpnose are much deeper in body shape than strepies.
taxon_text_8_3843:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 239).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 313).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 226).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 593).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 39).
taxon_text_1_3846:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, but some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This well-known angling species is easily recognized as an adult due to its plain silvery colour and its unusually enlarged, blunt head with its rounded snout and powerful jaws, which are equipped with 4 prominent incisors and rows of crushing molars.

Juveniles are more commonly seen and lack the much-enlarged head, but still have a blunt, rounded snout. They also have small horizontal rows of darker spots along the body. In smaller individuals the fins are distinctively orange.
taxon_text_2_3847: Up to 120 cm total length and a mass of up to 30 kg.
taxon_text_3_3848:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Angola to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3849: Juveniles are found close inshore on shallow rocky reefs and even in tide pools, but adults occur in deeper water to about 30 m depth. Usually solitary, but sometimes seen in groups during spawning season. Juveniles are resident on particular reefs, but adults appear to undertake an annual winter spawning migration up the east coast, returning to the Cape in summer.
taxon_text_5_3850: Juveniles feed on small crustaceans, algae, the tube feet of sea urchins and worms. Adults eat larger crustaceans, molluscs, tunicates, echinoderms and worms.
taxon_text_6_3851: Mature at a length of about 35 cm and age of bout 5 years. Spawn for August to January. Probably spawn in groups and eggs develop in the plankton. Longevity at least 31 years.
taxon_text_7_3852: The enlarged, very blunt head of adults is characteristic. Larger juveniles can be confused with various stumpnose species, but smaller juveniles can be readily distinguished by their orange fins.
taxon_text_8_3853:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 240).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 585).
taxon_text_1_3856:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

The Steentjie is one of the smaller species in the group and has a forward-projecting snout, unusually large eye, and jaws armed with 4–6 rows of slender, pointed incisors. The body is silvery-blue with several faint horizontal golden stripes and often a blue band between the eyes. Breeding males change colour to become dark anteriorly, with 3–5 large bluish-black vertical patches posteriorly, some becoming almost black. Breeding females are paler with white marks on the flanks.
taxon_text_2_3857: Up to 45 cm total length and a mass of up to 1 kg.
taxon_text_3_3858:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_3859: Occurs in large shoals and found on rocky reefs at depths of 2–60 m, as well as in estuaries. Does not change sex and is unique among regional sparids in that does not have pelagic eggs and larvae, but rather lay its eggs in nests excavated in sand (see details under reproduction below). Attains a maximum age of about 8 years.
taxon_text_6_3861: Matures at a length of 20–22 cm and spawns off the Western Cape from September to January. The spawning behaviour is unique among regional sparids in that males excavate saucer-shaped nests about 50–100 cm across and up to 20 cm deep in communal nesting sites adjacent to rocks. The eggs are laid as a yellow mass and cover most of the area of the nest, where they are guarded by the male against both predators and other males. Both males and females also change colour quite dramatically during the breeding season.
taxon_text_7_3862: Can be confused with Fransmadam Boopsoidea inornata, but that species has an even larger eye and lacks yellow lines on its sides. Cape stumpnose Rhabdosargus holubi have similar yellow stripes, but a much blunter head. Strepie Salpa salpa have much more pronounced yellow stripes.
taxon_text_8_3863:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 315).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 594).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 40).
taxon_text_1_3866: Relatively deep-bodied species with an arching back and small, downward-facing mouth with a single short thick barbel under chin. Front (spinose) portion of the dorsal fin tall and triangular and separated from the lower (rayed) posterior section by a deep notch. Juveniles more commonly seen and are light brown with a broad dark-brown vertical band and narrower horizontal band along flank. Adults develop longitudinal wavy dark bands along back and sides.
taxon_text_3_3868:
Global: Widespread in Mediterranean, eastern Atlantic and western Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to East London, rarely off KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3869: Adults mainly found offshore and are caught by the trawl fisheries down to a depth of at least 300 m. Juveniles can be found close inshore over sand or in caves. Usually seen singly or in small groups.
taxon_text_5_3870: Predatory, feeding mostly on shrimps, worms and other invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3871: Matures at a length of 20–25 cm and spawns August to February. The transparent, buoyant eggs are releases into the water column and develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_3872: Easily confused with Slender baardman U. robinsoni, which occurs from Cape Point eastwards and has similar habits. However, that species grows to a much larger size of 99 cm and is usually dark brown with wavy oblique white lines along sides of body (but can change colour to silvery within a few seconds!).
taxon_text_8_3873:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 300).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 412).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 619).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 44).
taxon_text_1_3876: Characteristic and unmistakable species. Body very elongate and slender with long tubular snout and tapering tail, middle rays of the forked tail fin extended into a long, tapering filament. Eyes large. Swims horizontally in water column with body horizonal and linear. Colour uniformly green or brown with rows of blue dots dorsally.
taxon_text_2_3877: Up to 120 cm total length, but specimens seen in this region smaller.
taxon_text_3_3878:
Global: Widespread across the Indo-Pacific from South Africa up the east coast of Africa and right across to Mexico and South America, Australia and New Zealand. Recently also reported from Mediterranean, where it has rapidly spread and become abundant and is considered an invasive species that may threaten local fish species, after having migrated into the system through the Suez Canal.

Local/Regional: Normally about Mossel Bay eastwards, only recently observed in False Bay.
taxon_text_4_3879: Usually seen singly or in small groups over shallow reefs or sea-grass beds (or here kelp beds). Mostly swims with a slow undulating movement, but when approaching prey advances stealthily and draws the body into an S shape, then lunges forward like a striking snake. May use other larger fish as cover when stalking prey.
taxon_text_5_3880: Feeds mostly on small fish, but also squid and shrimps.
taxon_text_6_3881: Sexual maturity is reached at a length of about 65 cm and the eggs are large, hatching into larvae that are about 6–7 cm at birth.
taxon_text_7_3882: Unmistakable and the only flutemouth in the region, although there are other rarer species in the eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_8_3883:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 138).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 497).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 444).
taxon_text_1_3886: Small suckerfish with a broad, flat head, pointed ‘nose’ and double (divided) suction disc. Typically sits with the tail curled around to one side in a J-shaped posture. Common, but seldom noticed due to its small size and cryptic habits. Often found hiding inside dead mussel shells, or in similar habitats. Colour variable, but mostly pink to orange with transverse bands, especially one between eyes.
taxon_text_3_3888:
Global: Madeira and Canary Islands, Senegal to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_3889: Common in rock pools and on shallow reefs to a depth of about 20 m. Usually found singly in dead bivalve shells or similar concealed habitats. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_3890: Not studied, but probably feed on smaller crustaceans and other invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3891: Females lay eggs on the insides of dead mollusk shells. The eggs are guarded by the female until they hatch into fully-formed miniature suckerfish.
taxon_text_7_3892: Could be confused with juvenile Rocksuckers Chorisochismus dentex, but attain much smaller adult size, has a double sucker, smaller teeth and a different posture, with curled-around tail.
taxon_text_8_3893:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 123).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 437).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 218).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 379).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 27).
taxon_text_1_3896:
Gobies are a diverse family of small, bottom-dwelling fish, most with a broad, depressed head, dorsal fin separated into anterior spiny and posterior soft-rayed sections and pelvic fins united to form a cup-like disc on which the fish rests when sitting on the bottom. The eyes are usually placed close together on top of the head. Some tropical species are brightly coloured, but temperate ones are generally pale and well camouflaged.

Although there are over 100 species in southern Africa, few extend to the Western Cape, of which this is the most common and conspicuous. The body is mottled brown and white, with a pale bar across base of pectoral fin and the mouth is large and thick-lipped.
taxon_text_3_3898:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_3899: Usually found singly in sandy pools or on shallow sand to a depth of about 25 m. May dig a burrow in open sand, but more commonly found sheltering under overhangs on the sand-rock interface. Sits on the bottom, supported by the pelvic fin and with pectoral fins extended for support.
taxon_text_6_3901: Breeds year-round. Eggs are attached to stones.
taxon_text_7_3902: Relatively few gobies extend to the south Western Cape, but there are several other similar species in the region. The Commafin goby C. saldanha is pale with numerous black spots and a larger black patch at rear of first dorsal fin. The Banded goby C. caffer has about 10 marked vertical bars along the sides the body and the Prison goby C. gilchristi  has similar but thinner bars and these are arranged in about 8 pairs.
taxon_text_8_3903:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 330).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 395).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 236).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 784).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 70).
taxon_text_1_3906: A well-known, easily recognized and iconic species common in rock pools and on shallow reefs. Body depressed, with a broad head bearing conspicuous eyes and a very wide mouth armed with large conical teeth. The pectoral and pelvic fins are modified to form a fused large, powerful sucker under the thorax. Colour variable, but typically mottled green, brown and white dorsally and white on the underside.
taxon_text_3_3908:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Durban.
taxon_text_4_3909:
Common in rock pools and on shallow reefs to a depth of about 10 m. Usually found firmly attached to flat rocks or seaweeds and sometimes even seen clinging to the rockface out of the water as the swells recede on wave-swept shores.

Has a characteristic method of capturing limpet prey, waiting for a limpet to raise its shell off the substratum and move before attacking. The rocksucker then makes a characteristic wriggle of its body, before launching itself into the water and coming down on its prey from directly above, with its mouth wide open, such that the large teeth grasp beneath the limpet shell on both sides. The fish then pivots it body 180 degrees, twisting the limpet free from the rock, and swallows it shell and all! Shells of consumed limpets can sometimes be seen in the stomach in X-rays, stacked like dinner plates, and are finally either regurgitated or passed out though a specially adapted wide, distensible anus!
taxon_text_5_3910: Juveniles feed mainly on smaller crustaceans, but adults are specialist predators of limpets, although they also take other large prey, including sea urchins, chitons and gastropods.
taxon_text_6_3911: Females lay up to 500 eggs attached to the underside of rocks. The eggs are guarded by the female until they hatch into suckerfish larvae.
taxon_text_7_3912: By far the largest suckerfish in the region. Juveniles can be confused with the Chubby clingfish Apletodon peregrini, but that species only attains about 5 cm. It also has a divided (paired) ventral sucker and smaller teeth. Although variable in colour there are usually transverse bars across the body.
taxon_text_8_3913:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 268).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 179).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 218).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 209).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 23).
taxon_text_1_3916: A very small fish with a very big name (which indicates its association with the kelp Ecklonia)! Very slender with a triangular, pointed head bearing prominent, shining eyes, a ventral thoracic sucker and a long, narrow, tapering abdomen. Colour variable, but usually cryptic green or brown, sometimes red, usually closely-matching the background.
taxon_text_3_3918:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_3919: Common on the fronds of kelps, more rarely also other large algae, but extremely small, cryptic and difficult to spot. Usually firmly attached to the kelp frond by the sucker, but quick to release and relocate to underside of frond when disturbed.
taxon_text_5_3920: Feeds on smaller benthic crustaceans found on kelp surfaces, particularly benthic copepods.
taxon_text_6_3921: Fertilization is internal and females then lay batches of 120–150 eggs on the surfaces of the kelp fronds. Reproduction is thought to take place throughout the year. Development details unknown.
taxon_text_7_3922: The specialised habitat and slender body shape make this species easy to identify and there are no other species in the genus.
taxon_text_8_3923:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 330).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 440).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 229).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 379).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 29).
taxon_text_1_3926:
Gobies are a diverse family of small, bottom-dwelling fish, most with a broad, depressed head, dorsal fin separated into anterior spiny and posterior soft-rayed sections and pelvic fins united to form a cup-like disc on which the fish rests when sitting on the bottom. The eyes are usually placed close together on top of the head. Some tropical species are brightly coloured, but temperate ones are generally pale and well camouflaged.

Although there are over 100 species in southern Africa, few extend to the Western Cape. This species is much smaller than other similar gobies in the region and is relatively slender. It is characterized by the fact that the gill openings on the two sides are united beneath the throat by a free fold of skin. Colour mottled grey with pale underside.
taxon_text_3_3928:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3929: Very common in estuaries, but also in sheltered marine sand banks. Abundant in Langebaan Lagoon, where it is one of the most common fish species. Typically found in shallow pools at low tide, retreating into the burrows or sand and mud-prawns when disturbed.
taxon_text_6_3931: Breeds year round. Eggs are attached to undersides of stones on the sandbanks.
taxon_text_7_3932: Relatively few gobies extend to the South Western Cape, and this species is best recognised by its small size, light build and preference for sheltered sandbanks. There are several other larger more robust species in the region. The Commafin goby C. saldanha is pale with numerous black spots and a larger black patch at rear of first dorsal fin. The Banded goby C. caffer has about 10 marked vertical bars along the sides the body and the Prison goby C. gilchristi  similar but thinner bars and these are arranged in about 8 pairs. The Bareheaded goby is mottled brown with a vertical bar at base of pectoral fin.
taxon_text_8_3933:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 330).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 801).
taxon_text_1_3936: Unusual, very elongate, cylindrical fish with large eyes, a pointed snout bearing a small barbel and a small, toothless downward-facing mouth. The single small dorsal and anal fins are set far back along the tapering body; tail shallowly forked. Colour pale pink or cream with a greenish shiny tinge.
taxon_text_2_3937: Supposedly attains 60 cm, but mostly 30 cm or less.
taxon_text_3_3938:
Global: Namibia and St Helena Island, around South Africa to Mozambique and Madagascar.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3939: Nocturnal species found on sandy bottoms from the shoreline to a depth of about 200 m. Usually found buried in the sand or mud by day, emerging at night to feed. If disturbed can dart straight into the sand, leaving only the top of the head and eyes exposed.
taxon_text_7_3942: Fairly unmistakable and the only representative of the family in South Africa.
taxon_text_8_3943:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 268).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 179).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 218).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 209).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 23).
taxon_text_1_3946:
Mullet have cylindrical, torpedo-shaped, plain silvery bodies (usually slight depressed at the head and laterally compressed at tail end), a small terminal mouth with minute teeth, two well-separated dorsal fins and a forked tail. They form tight schools close to the surface over soft substrata. About 16 difficult-to-separate species occur in South Africa.

This species has a relatively pointed snout and a distinctive yellow spot on the operculum and is very common in the Western Cape, where it is commonly caught by beach seine fishers.
taxon_text_3_3948:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Angolan border to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3949: Very tolerant of changing salinities and common from the upper reaches of estuaries to the open sea. Usually forms dense shoals over soft substrata, juveniles also commonly trapped in rock pools. A common prey species of both predatory birds and larger piscivorous fish, including sharks. An important fishery species captured in large numbers by both trek-net and gill net fisheries and commonly sold dried as bokkoms.
taxon_text_5_3950: Early juveniles feed mostly on small planktonic crustaceans, but larger juveniles and adults eat detritus, benthic diatoms, foraminifera, filamentous algae and seagrass.
taxon_text_6_3951: Matures at about 21 cm and in the Western Cape appears to breed close inshore throughout the year.
taxon_text_7_3952: Can be confused with various other small silvery schooling fish such as pilchard (but these have only one dorsal fin) or maasbanker (but these have a much more slender peduncle to the tail and scute-like scales along a conspicuous lateral line). Separation from other mullet species is quite difficult and based mostly on head shape and number of scales along the lateral line (44-50 in this species). For details see Heemstra references below.
taxon_text_8_3953:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 324).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 366).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 315).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 717).
taxon_text_1_3956: Small, elongate, cryptic fish with a large, rounded head, tiny eyes, two pairs of nostrils and an elongate, tapering body. Pelvic fin consisting of a single elongate ray. Dorsal and anal fins elongate, delicate and not joined to the tail (as in many other brotulas), they are also used for locomotion using a fluid, undulating action. Whole body light yellow in colour, belly paler.
taxon_text_3_3958:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_3959: Cryptic, benthic species. Found under rocks on shallow reefs or burrowing freely in sand. Rarely seen, but probably much more common than  thought, due to its very cryptic habits. Very little is known about the habits of either this, or any other members of this family, most of which are known from only a handful of specimens and some of which remain undescribed.
taxon_text_6_3961: No details known, but males of this family possess hardened pseudoclaspers, indicating that fertilization is internal and that they give birth to live young (viviparous).
taxon_text_7_3962: Can be distinguished from the Lesser orange brotula Dermatopsoides talboti, which has similar habits and occurs in the same sites, by the yellow not orange colour and much larger head and mouth. However, all members of this family are very poorly known and there may well be more undescribed species in the region. Any observations should be recorded.
taxon_text_8_3963:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 267).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 354).
taxon_text_1_3966: Small, elongate, cryptic fish with a rounded head, tiny eyes, two pairs of nostrils and an elongate, tapering body. Pelvic fin consisting of a single elongate ray. Dorsal and anal fins elongate, delicate and not joined to the tail (as in some other brotulas), also used for locomotion using a fluid, undulating action. Whole body a striking orange colour.
taxon_text_3_3968:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_3969: Cryptic, benthic species. Found under rocks on shallow reefs or burrowing freely in sand. Rarely seen and probably much more common than  thought, due to it being very cryptic. Very little is known about the habits of either this, or any other members of this family, most of which are known from only a handful of specimens.
taxon_text_6_3971: No details known, but males of this family possess hardened pseudoclaspers, indicating that fertilization is internal and that females give birth to live young (viviparous).
taxon_text_7_3972: Body shape and colour distinctive, but all members of this family are very poorly known and there may well be undescribed species in the region. Any observations should be recorded. The Freetail brotula Bidenichthys capensis occurs in the same region, but has a more massive head and is yellow rather than orange.
taxon_text_8_3973:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 267).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 356).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 24).
taxon_text_1_3976: Easily recognized, but cryptic species with extremely elongate, eel-like body, small mouth and elongate dorsal and anal fins. Colour light brown with broken dusky crossbars. Distinctive dark circular spot surrounded by pale ring above operculum. Tail fin separated from dorsal and anal fins (unlike in tropical species in the genus, where they are joined). Unusual in having three lateral lines along the body.
taxon_text_3_3978:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_3979: Fairly common, but seldom seen due to its very cryptic habits. Usually found under boulders, or burrowing in course gravel, but agile and evasive and quickly wriggles away and buries itself again when disturbed.
taxon_text_5_3980: Feeds on small crustaceans, such as amphipods and isopods.
taxon_text_6_3981: No published information on reproduction in this species, but others in this family lay clumps of eggs which are guarded by the male.
taxon_text_7_3982: The only member of the family in the Western Cape and unlikely to be confused with any other local species.
taxon_text_8_3983:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 326).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 119).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 230).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 729).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 52).
taxon_text_1_3986:
Gurnards are bottom-dwelling fish characterised by having a large bony head and tapering body. The first few rays of the pectoral fins are separated into ‘feelers’ that are used to ‘walk’ along the bottom and feel for food, and the rest of the pectoral fin can be spread out laterally into a large, often strikingly-coloured ‘wing’.

This species is silvery with broken red horizontal stripes and fins and has a striking brown, but blue-edged, pectoral fin with a black-and-white speckled patch near its base.
taxon_text_3_3988:
Global: Widespread across western Indian and Pacific Oceans and common around Australia and New Zealand (although recent genetic research suggests this might turn out to be a different species).

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_3989:
Found in sandy habitats from shallow water to a depth of about 150 m. Usually found on the seafloor, walking slowly along the bottom and feeling for prey using the three free pectoral rays under the head.

Most active at night and often found buried in the sand with only the top of the head emerging from the sediment. The large brightly-coloured pectoral fins may be used to startle predators.
taxon_text_5_3990: A predator feeding mostly on crustaceans, but also on small fish and polychaete worms and other small invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_3991: Sexual maturity is reached at an age of 2–3 years and eggs and sperm are released into the water column, larval development taking place in surface waters. Smaller individuals usually found in coastal waters, adults moving deeper as they grow. Longevity estimated to be about 12 years.
taxon_text_7_3992: The Cape Gurnard C. capensis is common in deeper waters up to 390 m depth and is often caught in the trawl fishery and commercially traded. It is more uniform red in colour and the lacks the blue edge to the pectoral fin.
taxon_text_8_3993:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 274).
