Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 33).
taxon_text_1_3996:
Easily recognized to genus (and indeed the only local genus in the family) by virtue of the tapering, laterally compressed body, concave forehead, extended ‘horse-like’ snout and prominent ‘mane-like’ dorsal fin, which can be raised vertically or laid flat along the back.

There are two easily-confused local species though, this one being distinguished by having spines on the snout above the mouth and a shorter dorsal fin, which has less pronounced notches between the spines.

Colouration typically mottled brown with white spots. There are usually broad darker bands along the dorsal fin and along the flank, often with a row of white dots along the lateral line.
taxon_text_3_3998:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3999: Fairly rarely seen, but distinctive, species found on rocky reefs usually deeper than 20 m. Also fairly commonly captured by trawlers on soft sediments down to a depth of about 150 m. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_4000: Not studied in this species, but other members of family feed on small crustaceans, mollusks, echinoderms and worms.
taxon_text_7_4002: Distinctive at genus and family level, but the two local species easily confused. The closely related Smooth horsefish C. torvus grows to a much larger size of 76 cm, lacks the spines above the mouth and has a taller dorsal fin, which is cut into deep notches between the spines.
taxon_text_8_4003:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 279).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 480).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 32).
taxon_text_1_4006:
Soles (and the related flounders) are easily recognized as a group, as they have become extremely flattened and lie on their left sides, often partially buried in sediment. The eye from the lower, unpigmented, side of the body has migrated to the upper side, which is typically cryptically patterned. Identification to species level is difficult, as there are about 50 regional species and colour patterns are both extremely variable within species and can quickly change in the same individual to match the background.

This species completely lacks a pectoral fin and has a distinctively hooked snout that curves over the mouth. The dorsal and anal fins are separated from the tail fin. Colour variable, but usually grayish-brown with distinctive small dark specks; sometimes there are also three vague larger dark spots along the lateral line.
taxon_text_3_4008:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_4009: Common in shallow waters to a depth of about 25 m. Juveniles abundant in estuaries. Lies on its side, often shallowly buried in sand, with just the eyes protruding. If disturbed swims on its side with an undulating movement, usually moving only a short distance before burying again in the sand.
taxon_text_5_4010: Details unknown, but probably an ambush predator of small benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_4011: Spawning peaks in summer. Juveniles mostly in estuaries or shallow protected sandy areas.
taxon_text_7_4012: The lack of a pectoral fin and hooked snout are useful identification features, as is the speckled colour pattern. Can be confused with the Blackhanded sole Solea turbynei which is similar in size and habits, but has a distinctive short, round, black pectoral fin. The East coast sole Austroglossus pectoralis grows much larger (60 cm) and also has a dark pectoral fin, but this is elongate and pointed.
taxon_text_8_4013:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 336).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 236).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 871).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 72).
taxon_text_1_4016:
Soles (and the related flounders) are easily recognized as a group, as they have become extremely flattened and lie on their left side, often partially buried in sediment. The eye from the lower, unpigmented, side of the body has migrated to the upper side, which is typically cryptically patterned. Identification to species level is difficult, as there are about 50 regional species and colour patterns are both extremely variable within species and can quickly change in the same individual to match the background.

This species was long known as S. bleekeri, but recent research has demonstrated that to be an invalid name and the correct name should be S. turbynei. The species is best recognized by the distinctive short, black, rounded pectoral fin on the upper side, after which the common name is derived. The bases of the dorsal and anal fins are joined to the tail fin by a membrane and the colour is usually brown with dark spots.
taxon_text_3_4018:
Global: South Africa to Tanzania.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4019: Most commonly found in estuaries, but also common in lagoons and on shallow sand banks. Lies on surface sediments on its pale left side. Able to quickly bury itself by flapping the fins, hiding with just the eyes exposed and moving  a short distance forward with an undulating vertical motion if disturbed.
taxon_text_5_4020: Feed largely on the siphons of bivalves, as well as on small crustaceans, especially amphipods and tanaids.
taxon_text_6_4021: Matures at 10 cm length and spawns in spring both in estuaries and in the open sea. Small juveniles found mostly in estuaries.
taxon_text_7_4022: The short, black, rounded pectoral fin is a distinctive character and otherwise colour can be extremely variable between individuals. Several other similar species occur in the regions, but pectoral fin shape can be a useful character to distinguish several of these. For example in the Cape sole Heteromycteris capensis the pectoral fin is entirely absent (and the snout distinctively hooked over the mouth), whereas in the East coast sole Austroglossus pectoralis the pectoral fin is dark but elongate and pointed.
taxon_text_8_4023:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 336).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 438).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 873).

Vachon, J, Desoutter, M & Chapleau, F (2005). Solea bleekeri Boulenger, 1898, a junior synonym of Pegusa nasuta (Pallas, 1814), with the recognition and redescription of Solea turbynei Gilchrist, 1904 (Pleuronectiformes: Soleidae). Cybium, 29(4), 315-319.
taxon_text_9_4025: Has a confusing variety of common names, including in South Africa where known as Elf in the Cape and as Shad in KwaZulu-Natal. Also know as Bluefish in the USA and as Tailor in Australia and New Zealand.
taxon_text_1_4026:
Robust, oblong, laterally-compressed body with large mouth, lower jaw slightly projecting and bearing very sharp teeth. Hind edge of preoperculum serrate. Two separate dorsal fins, the first small and consisting of only 7–8 short spines, the second longer, with 1 spine and 23–28 rays. Tail powerful and forked. 

Head and body bluish green dorsally, silvery below.
taxon_text_2_4027: Up to 130 cm total length and a mass of up to 15 kg.
taxon_text_3_4028:
Global: Widely distributed in subtropical and temperate waters on both sides of the North Atlantic, the Mediterranean and Black Sea, South Africa to Mozambique, Oman, Australia and New Zealand and Malay Peninsula.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4029:
Found in coastal waters especially the surf zone, also extending into estuaries as juveniles. A renowned angling fish well known for its fighting abilities (the name saltatrix meaning leaping) and can often be seen leaping from the water in pursuit of prey.

Fast growing species maturing at a length of about 25 cm, which is achieved after only one year. In winter adults undertake a seasonal migration from the South coast to KwaZulu-Natal, where they spawn. The pelagic larvae are then carried south by the Agulhas Current and spend their first year of life in estuaries or nearshore waters along the south coast. Longevity about 10 years.

Should be handled with care, as the teeth are razor sharp and the serrated edge of the preoperculum (cheek bone) can also inflict a nasty cut.
taxon_text_5_4030: Juveniles take a variety of crustaceans, fish and cephalopods. Adults are voracious predators consuming mostly (87%) fish, but also shrimp and squid. May attack shoaling prey in packs creating a ‘feeding frenzy’.
taxon_text_6_4031: Spawning occurs along the east coast from September to December and the eggs are pelagic, drifting southwards with the ocean currents.
taxon_text_7_4032: The family contains only this one genus and species, although could be superficially confused with a number of similarly-shaped silvery gamefish in other families.
taxon_text_8_4033:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 292).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 224).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 587).
taxon_text_1_4036: Slender, robust, cylindrical fish with a pointed snout and large eye and mouth. Dorsal fin separated into spine and ray portions and depressible into a groove. Row of small triangular finlets behind both dorsal and anal fins and stiff, forked tail with a pair of fleshy lateral keels at its base. Dorsal half of body greenish with numerous oblique wavy zig-zag dark bands, ventral half silvery-white.
taxon_text_2_4037: Up to 50 cm length and a mass of 2 kg, but typically about 30 cm (larger reported specimens now recognized as different species).
taxon_text_3_4038:
Global: Widespread in Pacific, but absent from Indian Ocean except for South Africa. Previous reports from the Atlantic are now recognised as S. colias and those from northern Indian Ocean as S. australasicus.

Local/Regional: Western Cape to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4039: Form pelagic schools in coastal waters, usually segregated by size but may be mixed with other species, such as Maasbanker (Atlantic horse mackerel) or Pilchard. Migrate southwards during summer and back northwards during winter. Targeted by both purse seine and beach seine fisheries and by recreational and commercial line fishers. Reach sexual maturity at a length of about 40 cm and an age of 3 years.
taxon_text_5_4040: Predatory, feeding mainly on zooplankton, squid or small fish, depending on their size.
taxon_text_6_4041: Spawn along the Western and Eastern Cape coasts in June to September and off KZN July-December. Eggs are laid in batches, with total number of eggs per female ranging from 100,000–400,000. Eggs and larvae are pelagic.
taxon_text_8_4043:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 314).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 418).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 282).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 835).
taxon_text_1_4046:
Large, elongate and cylindrical predatory fish with big eyes, large mouth and fang-like teeth. Dorsal fin comprised of longer spinose section of 18–21 spines, and shorter rayed section of 11–13 rays, and followed by 5–7 small finlets (these also present behind anal fin). Tail forked, but lacking fleshy keels on peduncle (as found in tuna, etc.). Pectoral and pelvic fins both small, of 15 rays, and of one spine and 5 rays, respectively. Lateral line initially high, bending downwards markedly midway along body.

Colour dark blue-grey dorsally becoming silvery-white ventrally, dorsal fin and tail dark grey.
taxon_text_2_4047: Up to about 180 cm length and a mass of 9 kg, but typically about 75 cm.
taxon_text_3_4048:
Global: Widespread across southern hemisphere, including South Africa, Australia, New Zealand and both Pacific and Atlantic coasts of South America, plus associated islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_4049:
Voracious and swift predators that form large pelagic schools in coastal waters. A very important target species for the commercial and recreational boat fisheries, also caught by trawlers.

Fast growing, reaching 29 cm after one year and reaching sexual maturity at a length of about 73 cm, which is attained at an age of only 3 years.
taxon_text_5_4050: Predatory, smaller individuals feed largely on lanternfish and larger ones mostly on small pelagic shoaling fish such as pilchard, anchovies and redeye roundherring, but also on crustaceans, especially euphausiids, and on cephalopods.
taxon_text_6_4051: Spawn in winter and spring in water depths of 100–400 m west of Cape Agulhas. Eggs and larvae pelagic.
taxon_text_7_4052: Fairly distinctive. Replaced along the east coast and into Mozambique by the Black snoek T. marleyi, which is dark brown and lacks the downward curve in the lateral line.
taxon_text_8_4053:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 314).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 410).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 260).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 835).
taxon_text_1_4056: Medium-sized, mid-water schooling fish with large eyes; dorsal fin with spinose anterior section taller than posterior rayed section and separated from it by deep dip. Colour pale-green above, silvery below, a small black patch on gill covers. Lateral line armed with bony scute-like scales and distinctly kinked downwards half way along body.
taxon_text_2_4057: Reach 70 cm, but in-shore schools usually of much smaller individuals.
taxon_text_3_4058:
Global: Widespread across eastern Atlantic from Norway to South Africa, including Mediterranean, and around the South African coast to Eastern Cape, where it is replaced by the African maasbanker T. delagoa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_4059: Medium-sized, midwater species that occurs in large schools. An important fishery species and also significant component of the diets of various larger predatory fish. Undergo diurnal migrations, moving closer to the surface at night. An important commercial species, exploited mostly by mid-water trawls. Juveniles sometimes school with other species.
taxon_text_5_4060: Filer feeder, straining small planktonic species from the water column using the enlarged gill rakers. The bulk of the diet comprises euphausiids.
taxon_text_6_4061: Sexual maturity is reached at a length of about 20 cm and at an age of 3 years and the sex ratio is 1:1. Spawning occurs form June to November with two spawning peaks. The eggs develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_4062: Could be confused with various other silvery schooling fish, such as pilchard or chub mackerel, but the armoured and kinked lateral line is a distinctive character.
taxon_text_8_4063:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 312).

Hecht, T (1990). On the life history of Cape horse mackerel Trachurus trachurus capensis off the south-east coast of South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 9(1), 317-326.

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 315).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 66).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 659).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 47).
taxon_text_1_4066: Distinctive scale-less species, most easily recognized by the two prominent barbels on the upper jaw and four on the lower jaw. The first dorsal and pectoral fins both bear a large serrate and venomous spine anteriorly. Tail deeply forked, with pointed tips. Colour plain greenish-brown with pure white belly.
taxon_text_3_4068:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_4069: Benthic species, mostly found inshore on sand of shallow reefs and in estuaries, but extends to at least 102 m depth. The strong, serrated spines on the pectoral and dorsal fins are venomous and can inflict painful wounds, so fish should not be handled unnecessarily. Has unusual mouth-brooding habits (see details below). Mostly nocturnal and tends to shelter in caves and crevices by day.
taxon_text_5_4070: Juveniles are primarily scavengers, using their barbels to detect prey. Adults feed on a variety of crustaceans, polychaete worms and molluscs, as well as on other fish.
taxon_text_6_4071: Females mature at 24 cm, males at 26 cm and spawning occurs mainly from September – December. As in other sea-catfish the eggs are extremely large (15–16 mm in diameter) and are mouth-brooded by the males. Each brood consists of an average of only 49 eggs and the male does not feed for the entire 3–4 month incubation period, over which times they may lose up to 24% of their total body weight.
taxon_text_7_4072: Fairly easily recognised and few related species in the region. The Black sea-catfish G. ater is darker, has a tail fin with rounded tips and a darker, speckled belly.
taxon_text_8_4073:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 112).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 192).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 218).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 212).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 47).
taxon_text_1_4076: Small to medium, slow-moving fish; the large, blunt head with prominent chin, conspicuous, bulging, luminescent green eyes with yellow or orange ring, and small upwardly-directed mouth, the teeth fused to form a parrot-like ‘beak’. Body soft and swollen with reduced scales, tapering to a narrow tail. Colouration distinctive - the upper surface brown to black with numerous white blotches or spots, fading to yellow and then white on underside.
taxon_text_3_4078:
Global: Widespread across Indo-West Pacific.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4079:
Common in lower reaches of estuaries and along the open coast from intertidal zone to depth of up to 400 m. Slow-swimming and often lies buried in sand with only the eyes showing, but more active at night. Like all pufferfish (which are so named for this reason) can inflate itself with water when disturbed, slowly returning to normal size when danger has passed.

As with many other members of this family, the flesh contains the potent toxin tetrodotoxin, so fish should be handled with care and not eaten, or allowed to interact with pets.

Specimens of this species frequently wash out and die on beaches along the South Coast, with several mass mortality events reported from False Bay. The reasons for this are speculative but include mass courtship and spawning events during which males might inflate themselves, get rolled around by waves and swell and loose manoeuvrability.
taxon_text_5_4080: Ambush predator that feeds on a wide range of prey, including crustaceans, bivalves and other small fish.
taxon_text_6_4081: Matures at 10 cm length. Little is known about reproduction in this species, but eggs are thought to develop in the plankton.
taxon_text_7_4082: Colour pattern fairly unmistakable and the only pufferfish whose range extends into the colder waters of the South-Western Cape (several other species found in warmer waters of east coast).
taxon_text_8_4083:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 338).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 450).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 236).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 895).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 74).
taxon_text_1_4086:
Sunfish are unmistakable, both by virtue of their enormous size and unusual habits of basking near the ocean surface, and because of its bizarre appearance.

Body elongate-oval, strongly laterally compressed and truncated posteriorly, giving it a ‘chopped–off’ appearance. Dorsal and anal fins large, elongate, stiff and triangular; caudal fin very short and lobed. Gill opening reduced to a small hole beneath small, round pectoral fin. Eyes large; mouth small and forward-directed, the teeth fused to form a bird-like beak. Skin thick, tough, with small denticles. Colour normally blue-grey, paler ventrally.
taxon_text_2_4087: Up to 300 cm total length and weighing up to 2 tons!
taxon_text_3_4088:
Global: Cosmopolitan in warmer seas.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4089:
One of the largest and heaviest of all bony fish and attracts attention whenever seen. Live individuals usually seen on the surface, often lying on their sides and appearing to bask in the sun; dead individuals also occasionally washed ashore.

Although they might appear very slow-moving, sunfish do in fact swim quite rapidly, as any diver who has attempted to approach one will attest. Tagged individuals have been recorded swimming up to 26 km a day and undertaking feeding dives to up to 600 m depth many times per day.
taxon_text_5_4090: Previously thought to feed almost exclusively on jellyfish and salps, but more recent research has shown them to be generalist predators that consume mostly fish, squid and crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_4091: One of the most fecund of all fish, females producing up to 300 million eggs at a time! The remarkable larvae resemble tiny pufferfish (to which they are related) and are covered in large spines.
taxon_text_7_4092: Unmistakable to group, but there are in fact two other similar but rarer sunfish in the region. Sometimes also confused with the Trunk fish, Ranzania laevis, which has a similar laterally-flattened and truncated body, but is smaller (80 cm), silvery in colour and has pectoral and pelvic fins set far back between an almost vertically truncated caudal fin.
taxon_text_8_4093: Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 482).
taxon_text_1_4096: Very distinctive small, oval fish with very large yellow scales, each armed with a central spike and outlined in black. The dorsal fin consists of 5–6 separated spines without a connecting membrane and there is a small light organ containing luminescent bacteria beneath the mouth.
taxon_text_3_4098:
Global: Widespread across Indo-West Pacific.

Local/Regional: False Bay eastwards to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4099:
Very distinctive species with unmistakable armoured appearance and colour pattern. Nocturnal and feeble swimmer. Usually found singly in caves or under overhangs. Uses the light organ to find and attract prey at night, often feeding over open bottoms, but returning to the shelter of caves by day.

Historically found only from Mossel Bay eastwards, but now routinely observed in False Bay, one of several more tropical species which have expanded their ranges as a result of global warming.
taxon_text_5_4100: Feeds on small benthic crustaceans, such as amphipods and mysids.
taxon_text_6_4101: Few details available. Lay unusually large eggs of 1.9 mm diameter.
taxon_text_7_4102: Unmistakable and the only representative of the family in the region.
taxon_text_8_4103:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 133).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 383).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 413).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 76).
taxon_text_1_4106: Distinctive oval, laterally-flattened species with large forward-directed eyes, a large, oblique, extensible mouth and elongate dorsal fin formed of well-separated spines. Spiky plates are present along bases of dorsal and anal fins and along the belly between pelvic and anal fins. Colour silvery with greenish horizontal bands and a characteristic very large black central spot surrounded by a white ring.
taxon_text_2_4107: Up to 90 cm and reaching a mass of 8 kg.
taxon_text_3_4108:
Global: Widespread, including Europe, Mediterranean, Africa, Australia, New Zealand and Asia.

Local/Regional: Entire region.
taxon_text_4_4109:
Mostly found in deeper waters of 50–400 m, but juveniles sometimes seen in shallow waters, including among kelp beds in False Bay. Usually solitary. The compressed head and body facilitate a stealthy approach to prey, which are then sucked up using a rapid extension of the jaw. 

A sought-after eating fish, normally landed as a by-catch of other fisheries.
taxon_text_5_4110: Juveniles feed on zooplankton and then progress to feed on smaller fish as they grow. Adults feed mainly on fish, squid and larger crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_4111: Mature at an age of 3–4 years. Sperm and eggs are released onto the water. Lifespan in the wild about 13 years for males and 15 years for females.
taxon_text_7_4112: The body shape and large black spot on the flank are distinctive. A second rarer endemic species, the Cape dory Z. capensis, also occurs in the region, but has a faint lateral spot and the spines of the dorsal fin are joined by a membrane.
taxon_text_8_4113:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 278).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 137).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 415).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 437).
taxon_text_1_4116:
Fairly large, stout and short-legged, with a broad, rounded head, short ears and thick, powerful tail flattened dorso-ventrally to act as a rudder. Five digits on each foot, those of the front feet characteristically clawless, those of hind feet webbed for propulsion underwater and with rudimentary nails on toes 2–4. The large flat molar teeth are adapted for crushing prey.

Fur dense with thick guard coat overlying a dense underfur. Colour brown, paler on the underside and with characteristic white throat, upper chest and sides of neck.
taxon_text_2_4117: Total length ranges from about 113–163 cm and mass about 10–36 kg making then the third largest of all otter species.
taxon_text_3_4118:
Global: Widely distributed in both freshwater and coastal habitats throughout the wetter regions of southern, central and west Africa.

Local/Regional: In both freshwaters across the wetter southern and eastern parts. Along the coast, except on the dryer parts of the west coast north of Saldanha.
taxon_text_4_4119:
Widely distributed along the vegetated banks of rivers and dams inland and also along the coast. Found singly or in small family groups, and maintain a home range that is marked by secretions of the anal glands. Densities in Tsitsikamma National Park and Betty’s Bay both estimated at about one otter per 2 km of coast. Dependent on fresh water for both drinking and to wash the fur and so tend to be found adjacent to streams or springs.   

Fairly seldom encountered, as active mostly around dawn and dusk and cryptic, especially when in the water. May also become more nocturnal in urban habitats, possibly in an attempt to minimize encounters with dogs and humans. Some individuals have become habituated to humans and there are increasing reports of animals that have taken up residence in urban areas, that approach and interact with divers, or that habitually approach boats at landing sites seeking food, etc.

The droppings (spraints) are deposited in specific toilet sites situated close to the dens and both reveal the presence of otters in the area and can be used to analyse their diet.

Excellent swimmers and forage in rough inshore waters, feeling in underwater caves and overhangs for fish, crabs and lobsters. Usually emerge onto rocks in the intertidal to consume the prey and this is when they are most commonly seen.
taxon_text_5_4120: Feed on fish, crustaceans and cuttlefish and octopus. In Betty’s Bay the most important components of the diet were fish (59 %), followed by octopus (15 %), crabs (14% crabs) and rock lobster (10%).
taxon_text_6_4121: After a brief mating and a gestation period of two months females give birth to litters of two to five pups, most being born in December and January. Young are raised solely by the female and weaning takes place at an age of 45–60 days. Maturity is attained at an age of about one year.
taxon_text_7_4122: The only other otter in the region, the Spotted-necked otter Lutra maculicollis is much smaller (100 cm total length, 4 kg mass) and more slender and is a freshwater species not found in the sea.
taxon_text_8_4123:
Arden-Clarke, CHG (1986). Population density, home range size and spatial organization of the Cape clawless otter, Aonyx capensis, in a marine habitat. Journal of Zoology, 209, 201–211.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 364).

Skinner, LD & Chimimba, CT (2005). The Mammals of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 492).

Verwoerd, DJ (1987). Observations on the food and status of the Cape clawless otter Aonyx capensis at Betty’s Bay, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology , 22, 33–39.
taxon_text_9_4125: Two subspecies are recognized and together are referred to as the Brown fur seal. The southern African subspecies A. pusillus pusillus is called the Cape fur seal, African or South African fur seal, while the Australian subspecies A. pusillus doriferus is known as the Australian fur seal.
taxon_text_1_4126:
The largest of the fur seal family (Otariidae) and distinguished from ‘true’ seals (family Phocidae) by having external ears and by their ability to turn the hind flipper forward for more efficient locomotion on land.

Head broad with small external ear flaps, long whiskers and powerful jaws bearing formidable canine teeth, posterior teeth cusped. Front flippers large and provide main propulsion underwater, hind flippers shorter and used mainly for steering underwater and for locomotion on land. Colour chocolate brown, becoming darkened when wet. Pups black.
taxon_text_2_4127: Strongly sexually dimorphic. Males (bulls) much the larger, reaching 2.3 m in length and a mass of 200–300 kg, females (cows) much smaller at about 1.8 m and average of 120 kg (Australian subspecies slightly smaller).
taxon_text_3_4128:
Global: South African subspecies restricted to Namibia and South Africa. Australian subspecies only in southern Australia.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4129:
Occupy about 24 breeding colonies distributed between Cape Cross in Northern Namibia and Black Rocks in Algoa Bay. Historically almost all these were on islands, presumably to avoid predation and disturbance by humans. Most of the largest breeding colonies now occur on the mainland though, either in conservation areas or mining areas with restricted access.

Spend much of their time at sea, but large males haul out on the breeding colonies in October and establish small territories there, the most desirable territories being those closest to the water. Cows arrive in November and the males establish harems of 10–40 females. The black pups are born shortly thereafter and remain with their mothers until they are weaned at an age of 8–10 months.

Often comes into conflict with the fishing industry, not only because the population consumes about 2 million tons of fish each year, a significant proportion of which comprises species also sought after by fisheries, but also because they may interfere with fishing operations. For example seals may take fish captured on lines or in nets, or themselves get caught in trawl nets or other fishing gear.

Historically fur seals have been extensively exploited and by the end of the 19th century populations had been greatly reduced and many colonies exterminated. Exploitation was subsequently controlled by legislation and finally banned in South Africa from 1973 (although it continues in Namibia). This has resulted in a substantial recovery and the population now stands at about 2 million individuals. One implication of this is that seals have recolonised islands which had become significant breeding sites for seabirds, resulting in another conflict between endangered bird colonies and seals!

Seals are themselves predated by Great white sharks, which gather around breeding colonies, where they attract shark-spotting tourist operations. Pups in mainland colonies are also taken by Black-backed jackals and Brown hyenas.
taxon_text_5_4130: Generalist and opportunistic carnivores with a diet comprising mostly fish (at least 28 different species), but also significant amounts of cephalopods (both octopus and squid) and crustaceans (rock lobster, mantis shrimp, crabs and even mud prawns).
taxon_text_6_4131: Fur seals have an interesting breeding strategy in that copulation occurs just after the female has given birth, but implantation of the embryo is delayed by 4 months, so that the subsequent 8-month pregnancy results in the birth of the next pup exactly a year after the previous birth and coinciding once again with haul out time! Females become sexually mature at an age of about 3–4 and usually bear their first pups at 4–5.
taxon_text_7_4132: The only resident seal in the region, although occasionally vagrant Leopard seals and Southern elephant seals may be found on the coastline.
taxon_text_8_4133:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 362).

David, JHM (1987). Diet of the South African fur seal (1974–1985) and an assessment of competition with fisheries in southern Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 5(1), 693-713.

Wickens, PA, David, JHM, Shelton, PA & Field, JG (1991). Trends in harvests and pup numbers of the South African fur seal: implications for management. South African Journal of Marine Science, 11(1), 307-326.
taxon_text_1_4136:
Small, stocky dolphin. Head conical with a long, sloping forehead and no obvious beak. Each jaw has 20–30 small peg-like teeth. Pectoral fins rounded. Distinctive dorsal fin set fairly far back and broadly triangular. Colour pattern a diagnostic mix of black, white and grey areas. Back, dorsal fin and tail black. Underside white, extending backwards as three streaks, one along the midline of the belly and the other two curving up the flanks. Sides on front half of body grey.

Sexes difficult to distinguish in the field, but differ in shape of a small white patch covering the genital area, which comes to a point in males and widens out to cover mammary slits in females.
taxon_text_2_4137: Maximum length of only 1.7 m and mass of 75 kg. Sexes similar in size and appearance.
taxon_text_3_4138:
Global: Endemic to the west coast of southern Africa.

Local/Regional: southern Angola to Cape Point, rarely in False Bay.
taxon_text_4_4139:
Restricted to west coast and generally found close inshore and in small groups of 1–10, although groups of up to 100 have been observed. Longevity estimated at about 26 years. Energetic and social and may be attracted to boats and bow-ride. Also seen surfing in coastal waves and may leap well clear of the water, re-entering vertically and with almost no splash.

South African populations have been reported to undertake diurnal movement patterns, moving offshore late in the day to feed on prey that rise to the surface at night and returning inshore to rest and socialize in the mornings. Dives are usually short in duration, often less that one and seldom more than two minutes and mostly to depths of less than 50 m (max 147 m).

Echolocation clicks occur in a narrow high-frequency band of 125–130 kHz when foraging and travelling, but at lower frequency and broader bandwidth when socialising. Do not whistle like many other dolphins.

Total population has been estimated at 6300 individuals, but there is a large error margin around this estimate. Inshore habits tend to make this species vulnerable to entanglement in fishing nets.
taxon_text_5_4140: Feed on fish and cephalopods, especially juvenile hake, kingklip and octopus, mostly foraging on the bottom in shallow waters, but also take pelagic goby, horse mackerel, squid and occasional crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_4141: Limited information is available on the reproductive biology of this species. Both sexes are thought to mature at an age of about 5–9 years and individual females produce a calf only every 2–4 years. Size at birth averages 87 cm. Reproduction occurs year-round.
taxon_text_7_4142: Unlikely to be confused with other species due to the small size, restricted distribution and diagnostic colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_4143:
Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 148).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 368).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 92).

Davis, RW, David, JHM, Meÿer, MA, Sekiguchi, K, Best, PB, Dassis, M & Rodriguez, DH (2014). Home range and diving behaviour of Heaviside's dolphins monitored by satellite off the west coast of South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 36(4), 455-466.

Elwen, SH, Thornton, M, Reeb, D & Best, PB (2010). Near-shore distribution of Heaviside’s (Cephalorhynchus heavisidii) and dusky dolphins (Lagenorhynchus obscurus) at the southern limit of their range in South Africa. African Zoology, 45(1), 78-91.
taxon_text_9_4145: Some previous accounts recognise two separate species, a more offshore ‘Short-beaked’ common dolphin D. delphis and a more inshore ‘Long-beaked’ species D. capensis, but these are no longer accepted being separate species.
taxon_text_1_4146:
Relatively slender, medium-sized dolphin with a gently sloping forehead, long two-toned beak and triangular, slightly-hooked dorsal fin. There are 46–58 small, sharp teeth in each jaw.

The unusual colour pattern is diagnostic. The back is black, the underside white and along the sides between these there is a large, elongated ‘figure of eight’-shaped patch that is buff in the front half and dark grey in its back half. There is also a dark stripe from the corner of the jaw to the flipper.
taxon_text_2_4147: Medium-sized with a maximum length of 2.5 m and mass of 175 kg. Males tend to be slightly larger and heavier than females.
taxon_text_3_4148:
Global: Widely distributed in tropical and temperate waters around the world.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4149:
The most abundant cetacean in the world, with a global population estimated at about 6 million. Found mostly in shallow coastal waters and can occur in large schools numbering thousands of individual and which are a thrilling sight to encounter and a popular tourist attraction. The schools are of mixed gender and generally travel at about 7 km/h, although the dolphins can swim much faster, at up to 35 km/h.

Well-known for their habit of following the sardine run up the east coast in winter and most of the regional research done on this species has been on south and east coast populations, rather than in the Western Cape population.

East coast populations are vulnerable to capture in bather protection nets and west coast ones are sometimes captured in purse-seine fisheries and although unfortunate, these modest losses are unlikely to impact the overall population of this abundant species.

Very vocal and produce a wide variety of different whistles.
taxon_text_5_4150: Feeds on a wide variety of both fish and cephalopods, but with a preference for pelagic schooling fish, particularly sardine.
taxon_text_6_4151: Females reach sexual maturity at an age of about nine and males somewhat earlier, at about seven years, but age at maturity differs greatly between populations. Gestation period is 10–11 months and calving takes place over a protracted season, but mostly in summer. Calves are born at a length of 70–100 cm and mass of about 10 kg.
taxon_text_7_4152: Unlikely to be confused with other species due the diagnostic colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_4153:
Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 213, 218 with both long and short beaked species being recognized).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 366).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 88).

Cockcroft, VG & Peddemors, VM (1990). Seasonal distribution and density of common dolphins Delphinus delphis off the south-east coast of southern Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 9(1), 371-377.

Davis, RW, David, JHM, Meÿer, MA, Sekiguchi, K, Best, PB, Dassis, M & Rodriguez, DH (2014). Home range and diving behaviour of Heaviside's dolphins monitored by satellite off the west coast of South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 36(4), 455-466.

Young, DD & Cockcroft, VG (1994). Diet of common dolphins (Delphinus delphis) off the south‐east coast of southern Africa: opportunism or specialization?. Journal of Zoology, 234(1), 41-53.
taxon_text_1_4156:
The only member of this family in the region and easily recognized by the large, yellowish-white, wart-like callosities on the head; the long, arching mouth that begins above the eye and the complete absence of a dorsal fin. Also lacks the throat grooves seen in other large regional baleen whales.

Colour black above, rarely with white or grey patches or streaks. A white blaze on the underside is of variable size and may extend up the sides. Some 3–4% of young are born white, but these darken with age.

Area-depending by far the most common whale seen from the shore in this region and even when seen from a distance can usually be recognised by its habits of lolling lazily at the surface and by the characteristic V-shaped blow.
taxon_text_2_4157: Maximum length of 14–15 m and mass of 47 tonnes. Males marginally larger than females.
taxon_text_3_4158:
Global: Widely distributed in Southern Hemisphere from the Antarctic to about 20°S, extending slightly further north in the cold waters of the Benguela (another closely-related species occurs in the Northern Hemisphere).

Local/Regional: Southern Angola to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4159:
Spend the summer in the Antarctic, where they fatten up on copepods and krill. Migrate to warmer waters in winter and spring to breed. In South Africa most abundant in shallow, sandy bays along the south and southeast coast between June and November, reaching maximum densities in September to October.

Usually seen fairly close inshore, singly or in small groups, the most common group being a cow-calf pair. Although females give birth to and raise their young along the coast, they feed very little feed over this period, a remarkable feat, considering that that they are suckling young at the same time.

Southern right whales were extensively exploited for centuries, as their large size, slow swimming speeds, inshore habits and good quality oil and baleen, plus the fact that they float when killed, all made them the ‘right’ whales to hunt! Over 100 000 are thought to have been killed globally between 1770–1840 and by 1920 the global population had been reduced to an estimated 300 individuals, but even then, the species was only given complete protection in 1935. Between 1979 (when census counts were started) and 1997 the South African population recovered at over 7% per year to reach 3 100. That is still, however, only 10–14 % of the estimated original population size, an indication of how common these magnificent creatures must once have been.

Feed by swimming forward with the mouth open and taking large volumes of water and prey. The mouth is then closed and the water expelled though over 200 enormous comb-like baleen plates, each over 2 m long that hang from the upper jaw and the food swallowed. The amount of food eaten is enormous and during the feeding season each whale has to eat about 1500 kg of tiny prey each day in order to survive through the non-feeding period. Even more remarkable is the fact that the prey are so small (one of the greatest size differences between predator and prey in the entire animal kingdom).

Placid whales that spend much of their time lolling at the surface. Often roll on their sides to show the broad, paddle-shaped flippers above the water. May also show the head above the surface (‘spyhopping’), slap the tail or flipper on the surface or breach, sometimes several times in succession.
taxon_text_5_4160: Feeds almost exclusively on small crustaceans, such as copepods, krill and euphasiids. One study indicates that individuals S of 40°S took mostly krill, while to the north of 40°S they fed almost entirely on copepods, those in between taking a mixture of copepods and euphasiids.
taxon_text_6_4161:
Females usually give birth to their first young when they are about 8 years old. The gestation period is about 12 months and the size at birth 4.5–6 m and 900 kg, size of calf being correlated to that of the mother. Calving takes place from June to November with a peak in late August. The calf grows at a rapid rate of about 2.5 cm per day and is ready to accompany its mother on the annual migration south after about 6 months, when it reaches a size of 8 m. Subsequent calves are born at intervals of usually 3 years.

Male Southern Right whales are among the best endowed of all mammals, having a penis up to 2.7 m long and testes with a combined volume of up to 198 litres.
taxon_text_7_4162: Unlikely to be confused with other regional whales due to the callosities on the head, lack of a dorsal fin and arched mouth.
taxon_text_8_4163:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 74).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 29).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 364).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 50).
taxon_text_1_4166:
Fairly small, but quite stout dolphin with gently sloping forehead extending almost to the jaw, giving it a very short beak. Dorsal fin relatively tall and curves backwards into a pointed tip. There are 26–32 slender, conical teeth in the upper jaw and 24–31 in the lower jaw.

Colour pattern complex and distinctive. Back black, belly white and large grey patch running from the upper beak backwards along the sides, with a second, branched patch running from in front of dorsal fin backwards towards tail. Dorsal fin two-toned, black in front, but becoming grey posteriorly. Flippers pale with dark edges.
taxon_text_2_4167: Medium-sized with maximum length of about 2 m and mass of 90 kg.
taxon_text_3_4168:
Global: Widely distributed in temperate waters of the Southern Hemisphere, including both coasts of South America, Southern Africa, Australia, New Zealand and various oceanic islands.

Local/Regional: Only on the west coast, from southern Angola to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_4169:
Found mostly in shallow waters and bays on the west coast. Mean group size observed in South African waters 35, but can occur in groups of several hundred individuals and very ‘tourist friendly’, often riding the bow waves of boats and making spectacular leaps clear of the water.

Vocal and make a variety of different clicks and whistles.
taxon_text_5_4170: Feed on a wide variety of both fish and cephalopods with lantern fish and hatchet fish making up the bulk of the diet in this region.
taxon_text_6_4171:
Little studies in South Africa, but elsewhere have a promiscuous mating system in which both males and females mate with multiple partners and mating appears to also take place for reasons other than reproduction (possible to strengthen social bonds).

Form mating groups of a single female and about 10 males. Males then pursue the female until only the strongest is left and claims the female.

Females start reproducing at an age of 6–7 years and gestation period lasts about 12 months, followed by lactation lasting another 12 months. Calving interval thought to average about 28 months. Calves born at a length of about 81–90 cm. Females with calves tend to gather in nursery areas in shallow water.
taxon_text_7_4172: Unlikely to be confused with other local dolphins due to the distinctive colour pattern. May occur with Heaviside’s dolphin, but that species has a broadly-triangular dorsal fin, not a recurved one.
taxon_text_8_4173:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 102).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 228).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 368).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 84).
taxon_text_1_4176:
Dorsal surface black with a small, low dorsal fin that has a wide base and is preceded by a distinct hump. Dorsal surface of head with three rows of rounded, raised tubercles, each bearing a single hair, other tubercles present on chin and sides of jaw. Flippers extremely long (>30% body length) with knobs along their leading edge, dark above and white below. Underside of head white, with about 30 distinct throat pleats, belly with variable amounts of white. Tail flukes with distinctly serrated trailing edge and variable white patches on underside (exact pattern of these can be used to identify and track individuals).

Blow a tall, single, bushy plume. At a distance best identified by the long flippers, which are obvious when breaching or rolling at the surface, and by the white underside to the tail when diving.
taxon_text_2_4177: Maximum length of males about 14 m and of females 15 m and mass up to about 40 t.
taxon_text_3_4178:
Global: Worldwide, migrating between summer feeding ground near the poles and winter breeding grounds in lower latitudes

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4179:
Although they occur worldwide, the populations in the N and S hemispheres mostly remain separate (as their migration patterns are displaced by six months). The Southern population spend the summer in the Antarctic, where they fatten up on copepods and krill. They then migrate to warmer waters of various regions in spring to breed. The African sub-population is thus transitory in our waters, passing through as they migrate between Antarctic feeding grounds and breeding grounds off east and west Africa. The northern migration peaks in our waters in June and July and the southern migration in September.

Undertake a variety of behaviours, including spectacular breaches and smacking of the water surface with the tail. Usually expose the tail flukes when diving, revealing their characteristic white underside and scalloped trailing edge.

Humpback whales are also well-known for their complicated songs, which are sung mostly on the wintering grounds and can last for 10–15 minutes. Almost all singers are large, single males and the songs are thought to either attract females or assert dominance between males.

Humpback whales were seriously depleted by whaling, with 24 700 individuals from just the African population alone being killed between only 1908 to 1915. The species was given full protection from 1964, but thousands were still killed illegally thereafter, at least until an International Observer System was implemented in 1972. There has been a substantial recovery since that time and the East African population was estimated at 12 000 in 2003 – which modelling suggests might be 79% of the original population.

The surfaces of humpback whiles are colonised by various other commensal species, including whale lice (Cyamus), whale barnacles (Coronula) and stalked barnacles (Conchoderma) –  see those pages for further details.
taxon_text_5_4180:
Lunge feeders, which surface horizontally or vertically with the mouth open and the throat grooves bagging, taking in a huge gulp of water and associated food organisms. The water is then sieved out though the baleen plates, which number over 300 in each upper jaw, each plate up to 100 cm long, and the food swallowed. Well known for their unusual habit of descending below fish shoals and concentrating these with a bubble-net, a group of whales then engulfing the trapped fish as they rise from directly below.

Feed on small crustaceans, such as copepods, krill and euphausiids, as well as on small shoaling fish.
taxon_text_6_4181: The age at maturity is estimated to vary from 5–10 between different populations and the length at maturity is about 12.5 m. Births take place in July to October with a peak in August and length at birth is about 4–4.5. m and lactation extends for 10–11 months. Females can fall pregnant again almost immediately after giving birth, but the usual calving interval is two years. Both sexes mate with multiple partners.
taxon_text_7_4182: Unlikely to be confused with other regional whales due to the enormous flippers, knobs on the head and white underside to the tail.
taxon_text_8_4183:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 76).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 41).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 364).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 58).
taxon_text_1_4186:
Very well-known and iconic species and the largest member of the dolphin family. Body robust with short, rounded head lacking the beak typical of most dolphins. Mouth with 10–13 large, conical teeth in each jaw. Pectoral fins large, broad and paddle-like, with rounded ends (those of males larger, as are the tail flukes). Dorsal fin large, upright and sexually dimorphic, being smaller and curved backwards in females and much larger (up to 2m) and more triangular in males.

Colour pattern diagnostic – black dorsally with white lower jaw and belly. Another small white patch behind the eye, a grey or white saddle dorsal behind dorsal fin and another white patch on underside of tail.
taxon_text_2_4187: Very large, with males reaching 8 m in length and a mass of 8 t, but females much smaller at 5–7 m and a mass of 3–4 t.
taxon_text_3_4188:
Global: Cosmopolitan, extending from the Arctic to Antarctic.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4189:
Although commonly referred to as ‘killer whales’ the name Orca is preferred, as they are very large members of the family Delphinidae.

Reputed to be the most widely dispersed of all mammals, occurring from the tropics to high latitudes of both hemispheres and from coast to oceanic waters. Most often seen on offshore fishing grounds, but can be found close to the coast where they are always a thrill to see, although unpredictable in their distribution and habits. Elsewhere can form groups (pods) of up to 200 animals, but in South Africa groups are much smaller, usually of only 3–4 individuals. Fast swimming, reaching up to 30 km/h and have excellent senses of vision, hearing and echolocation. Produce whistling sounds for communication and clicking ones for echolocation. May undertake significant migrations, but the movement patterns of South African populations not well understood. Have a complex social structure and can form groups of several types, some stable and descended from a ‘matriarch’ and other groups looser and more transient.
taxon_text_5_4190: Large apex predators that take a very wide variety of prey, including many species of bony fish and sharks, squid, seabirds, turtles and various other species of marine mammals, including seals, dolphins and even large whales. May hunt in packs and some groups specialize on specific target species, such as whales. A pair of two males in False Bay is well known for attacking Great white sharks and has had a devastating impact on the population and the associated shark spotting industry! Despite their obvious ability to consume prey as large or larger than humans, no human fatalities have been noted in the wild, although some have been attributed to captive orcas.
taxon_text_6_4191: Females mature at a length of about 5 m and age of about 10 years, reach peak fertility at about 20, and can continue to reproduce until the age of at least 40. They are one of the few mammals to experience menopause and may continue to live for decades (to at least 80, possible 100) after ceasing to reproduce. Males mature at about 15, but typically do not start reproducing until about 21 and are shorter-lived than females, reaching an age of about 60. Gestation varies from 15–18 months and young are born at about 180 kg and a length of 2.4 m. Females normally produce one calf about every five years. Although reproduction is seasonal in colder regions, in warmer waters young may be born at any time of year. The young are fed by the mother for at least one and up to two years.
taxon_text_7_4192: Unlikely to be confused with other species due to the extremely large size and characteristic colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_4193:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 108).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 263).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 366).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 70).

Williams, AJ, Petersen, SL, Goren, M & Watkins, BP (2009). Sightings of killer whales Orcinus orca from longline vessels in South African waters, and consideration of the regional conservation status. African Journal of Marine Science, 31(1), 81-86.
taxon_text_9_4195: Previously included along with what is now known as the Pacific humpback dolphin as a single species, Sousa chinensis, but the two regional forms shown to be separate species in a 2014 study.
taxon_text_1_4196:
Robust dolphin with a stocky body that tends to be flattened towards the tail. Has a longish, narrow beak and white-tipped jaw. Dorsal fin small and hooked and set onto a large, broad, distinctive fleshy hump, after which the species is named. There are 33–38 stout teeth in each upper jaw and 30–37 in each lower jaw.

Upper body plain brownish-grey, with a paler belly. Often bear prominent scars on flanks, suggestive of predation attempts by large sharks.

Can also be recognised in the field by its steeply-arching surfacing behaviour.
taxon_text_2_4197: Length of males up to 2.8 m and mass 150–200 kg. Females considerably smaller, not exceeding 2.5 m.
taxon_text_3_4198:
Global: Widely distributed across the Indian Ocean from South Africa up the east coast of Africa and the Middle East to India. Replaced in China and the western Pacific by the closely related S. chinensis and in Australia by S. sahulensis.

Local/Regional: From False Bay eastwards into Mozambique. Not on west coast.
taxon_text_4_4199:
Usually found in shallow waters close to the coast, rarely in water deeper than 15 m, but can occur several km offshore if water is shallow. Uncommon and usually found in small groups averaging about 12 individuals. Non-migratory and have a characteristic motion when surfacing, showing the beak and head first, then arching the back and diving to show the flukes as they submerge.

Often show scars inflicted by sharks suggesting that shark predation is a significant cause of mortality. Also particularly vulnerable to human induced disturbances including coastal pollution, habitat alteration, capture in shark nets, vessel strikes, noise etc. Calves tend to exhibit high rates of morality and tissues of stranded specimens often show high levels of chemical pollution. The South African population is estimated at only about 500 individuals, so the species is of conservation concern.
taxon_text_5_4200: Feeds on a wide variety of fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. May work as a group to herd fish and have been observed driving shoals of fish onto exposed sandbanks and then deliberately beaching themselves to capture the exposed fish.
taxon_text_6_4201: Females reach sexual maturity at an age of about 9–10 years and males at only 12–14 years. Gestation period is 10–12 and births take place mostly in summer. Calves are nursed for up to 24 month and may remain with the mother for at least 3–4 years. This results in an unusually long calving interval of about 5 years. Calves are born at a length of about 100 cm.
taxon_text_7_4202: Unlikely to be confused with other local species due the diagnostic hump around the dorsal fin.
taxon_text_8_4203:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 106 as S. chinensis).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 167 as S. chinensis).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 86 as S. chinensis).

Jefferson, TA & Rosenbaum, HC (2014). Taxonomic revision of the humpback dolphins (Sousa spp.), and description of a new species from Australia". Marine Mammal Science, 30 (4), 1494–1541.

Karczmarski, L (2000). Conservation and management of humpback dolphins: the South African perspective. Oryx, 34(3), 207-216.

Karczmarski, L, Cockcroft, VG & Mclachlan, A (2000). Habitat use and preferences of Indo‐Pacific humpback dolphins Sousa chinensis in Algoa Bay, South Africa. Marine Mammal Science, 16(1), 65-79.

Plön, S, Atkins, S, Cockcroft, V, Conry, D, Dines, S, Elwen, S, ... & Vermeulen, E (2021). Science alone won’t do it! South Africa’s endangered humpback dolphins Sousa plumbea face complex conservation challenges. Frontiers in Marine Science, 8, 642226.
taxon_text_1_4206:
Medium-sized dolphin with snout abruptly narrower that head (hence ‘bottlenosed’). Dorsal fin relatively large and strongly curved backwards. Teeth only 22–29 in each jaw and unusually stout and conical.

Body colour plain and shading from dark gray dorsally to white along the belly. Belly often freckled with dark spots.
taxon_text_2_4207: Medium-sized, with a maximum length of 2.4 m and mass of 230 kg. Males marginally larger than females, but differences barely detectable.
taxon_text_3_4208:
Global: Widely distributed in Indo-Pacific from south and east coasts of Africa to Red Sea, India, China and northern Australia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique. Not on west coast.
taxon_text_4_4209: Usually occur fairly close inshore in groups that vary widely in size from 1–1000 (averaging 40 in one study from the Eastern Cape and 140 in another). Mainly active in the morning and less so in the evening and commonly seen surfing in the breakers. May be predated on by sharks and are subject to mortality by capture in bather protection nets in KwaZulu-Natal.  Also accumulate chlorinated hydrocarbons in the blubber with age and these are ‘offloaded’ by females to the young in their milk, with unknown effects. Longevity has been estimated at 42–43 years in both sexes.
taxon_text_5_4210: Feeds on a wide variety of both fish and cephalopods with 72 different prey species found in a sample of 165 animals caught in the bather-protection nets off KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_6_4211: Males reach sexual maturity at an age of about 14 years and females at 9–11 years, usually producing their first calf at an age of 12–15.  Gestation period is about 12 months and along the KwaZulu-Natal coast most births take place in summer and autumn. Calves are born at a length of about 100 cm and mass of 9–21 kg and are weaned at an age of 1.5–2 years (but this may vary widely between regional populations).
taxon_text_7_4212: The taxonomy of Bottlenose dolphins has been confused and earlier accounts do not distinguish between this species and the very similar Common bottlenose dolphin Tursiops truncatus, so earlier descriptions of distribution and biology may refer to either species. The Common bottlenose dolphin is somewhat larger in size (3.3 m) and tends to occur further offshore. Anatomically it has fewer teeth on each jaw (21–24), a shorter beak and a brighter colour pattern, usually with a light grey blaze that runs from side of the head to below the dorsal fin. The sides of the belly are also not spotted, as in adult Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins.
taxon_text_8_4213:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 100).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 181).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 366).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 90 does not distinguish the 2 species).
taxon_text_9_4215: Once thought to be a form of the widespread African hamadryas baboon Papio hamadryas, but now recognized as a separate species.
taxon_text_1_4216: Adults dark brown with long, downward-sloping face. Limbs elongate and the front foot only about half as long as the back foot. Tail characteristically carried with the first third held upwards and the distal two-thirds drooping downwards. Male much larger and more robust that female with enlarged head, massive canine teeth and a mane of long hair on the back of the neck and shoulders. Female much lighter in build with smaller head and have obvious callosities on the rump. Juveniles black.
taxon_text_2_4217: Males much larger than females and attaining a mass of up to 44 kg, while females only reach 21 kg. Body length up to 115 cm and tail an additional 45–84 cm.
taxon_text_3_4218:
Global: Widespread across southern Africa, from southern Angola and Zambia southwards to the Cape Peninsula.

Local/Regional: Essentially an inland species widespread across the region except in driest areas.
taxon_text_4_4219: Mostly occur inland and live in fairly large troops across the region, except in the driest areas. Troops maintain territories across which they forage by day, sleeping at night on cliffs or in large trees, where they can escape predators. Included here because some troops in the Western Cape have taken to habitually foraging on the sea-shore.
taxon_text_5_4220:
Omnivorous, feeding mostly on fruits, leaves and invertebrates but also observed to hunt reptiles, birds and small mammals. Also frequently come into contact with humans and have learn to enter buildings or open car doors to take food and to even take items directly from humans.

Some troops on the cape Peninsula have learnt to supplement their diets by feeding on marine organisms during low tide. This food taken are protein rich ones, such as mussels and limpets, as well as the eggs of catsharks, which are often laid attached to seaweeds in intertidal pools and represent a particularly rich protein source. Marine foods only represent about 10% of the total diet even in these troops.
taxon_text_6_4221: Puberty is reached at an age of 4–6 years depending on location. On reaching adulthood males usually disperse to other troops, but females remain with their natal group. Females have an estrous cycle of an average of 36 days and the stage of the cycle is indicated by the colour of the skin around the callosities and mating is usually with the dominant male. Gestation period is 6 months and a single offspring is born at any time of the year. The mother carries the young initially on her underside, but later on her back. Larger young may sit jockey-style on the mother’s back just in front of the tail. Lactation normally lasts at least 8 months.
taxon_text_8_4223:
Carlton, JT & Hodder, J (2003). Maritime mammals: terrestrial mammals as consumers in marine intertidal communities. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 256, 271-286.

Lewis, MC & O’Riain, MJ (2017). Foraging profile, activity budget and spatial ecology of exclusively natural-foraging chacma baboons (Papio ursinus) on the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. International Journal of Primatology, 38, 751-779.

Skinner, LD & Chimimbak, CT (2005). The Mammals of the southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 218, as P. hamadryas).
taxon_text_1_4226: Unmistakable marine snake with black upper surface sharply demarcated from yellow underside. Tail laterally flattened for swimming and distinctively marked with black and yellow blotches. Head depressed and bullet-shaped with large dorsal scales, not strongly distinct from body. Nostrils set far back on head, open directly upwards and can be closed by valves.
taxon_text_2_4227: Total length up to 72 cm for males and 88 cm for females.
taxon_text_3_4228:
Global: One of the most widely distributed of all snakes and found throughout the warmer waters (>16–18°C) of the Indo-Pacific as far South as New Zealand (which is otherwise devoid of land snakes). Absent from the Atlantic, apart from a few vagrant records.

Local/Regional: Cape Point eastwards to Mozambique and beyond, with rare records on the Atlantic coastline.
taxon_text_4_4229:
Widely distributed not only in coastal waters, but far into the open ocean, where commonly found associated with floating mats of Sargassum, kelp or another flotsam. Have been observed in congregations of thousands where currents converge in the open ocean surface, where feed on pelagic fish which approach them seeking shelter. Accomplished divers and can reach 50 m depth and stay underwater for more than 3 hours, using both an enlarged lung and by gas exchange though the skin.

The most commonly beached sea snake in many regions and moves poorly when out of water due to the ventral keel. Unusual in that able to swim backwards. Contrary to previous belief requires fresh water to survive, although can go for months without drinking. The neurotoxic venom is extremely potent and potentially lethal, but the fangs are very short (about 1.5 mm) and rarely reported to bite humans. Beached specimens should not be handled though and if bitten, medical attention should be sought.
taxon_text_5_4230: Feeds entirely on small fish, stealthily approaching prey or waiting for prey to approach. Prey captured lunging downwards with the mouth open, rapidly paralysed and eaten underwater.
taxon_text_6_4231: Females reach sexual maturity at a length of about 62 cm. Ovoviviparous and after a gestation period of about 5–6 months females give birth to 2–6 young, each measuring about 25 cm. Young have been observed feeding on their first day of life.
taxon_text_7_4232: Unmistakable and the only sea snake seen regularly in the region.
taxon_text_8_4233:
Alexander, G & Marais, J (2007). A Guide to the Reptiles of Southern Africa, Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 166 as Pelamis platura).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 344).
taxon_text_1_4236:
The largest of the shelled turtles and the most commonly encountered turtle in South Africa. Upper surface of carapace made up of a row of 5 large plates (‘scutes’) down the midline, with another 5 large scutes to each side, these rimed by 11 or 12 much smaller marginal scutes. Head and neck relatively enlarged compared to other species and bill hooked. Some sexual dimorphism in adults, males having wider head, wider, less-domed carapace and longer tail and claws than females. Juveniles cannot be sexed externally.

Colour dark reddish brown with underside pale yellow.
taxon_text_2_4237: Total length of adults normally around 70–95 cm and mass of 80–200 kg.
taxon_text_3_4238:
Global: Distributed world-wide in tropical and temperate waters of the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans, as well as Mediterranean Sea.

Local/Regional: Nest in KwaZulu-Natal and Mozambique and most often encountered there, but occur throughout the region.
taxon_text_4_4239: Mostly found along the shallow seas and coastal reefs of tropical  and warm-temperate oceans, or when adult females come ashore to lay their eggs. Spend about 85% of their time underwater, duration of dives normally being 15–30 minutes, but can remain submerged for up to 4 hours. Juveniles swim using only their hind limbs, but adults swim by alternating both fore and hind limbs. Often rest on the bottom wedged under overhangs with limbs extended in the half-stroke position and sleep in this position at night.
taxon_text_5_4240: Omnivorous, feeding on a very wide range of prey, including both soft-bodied invertebrates like jellyfish, bluebottles and bubble-raft shells, benthic invertebrates, including molluscs, crustaceans, echinoderms and tunicates, and also fish. Hard-shelled prey are crushed with the large, powerful jaws.
taxon_text_6_4241:
Slow-maturing and reach sexual maturity only at an age of 17–30 years (in South Africa). Courtship and mating take place at sea, following which the females come ashore and lay batches of about 100 eggs at a time, placing these into holes about 50–80 cm deep dug above the high-water mark of sandy tropical beaches using a scooping action of the rear flippers. Several clutches of eggs are laid between October and February in one season, following which the female may not return to breed for 2–3 years. In South Africa breeding is restricted to the coast of northern KwaZulu-Natal.

Incubation lasts about 80 days and emerging juveniles are 4–5 cm long and weigh only about 20 g. As with other turtles, the sex ratio of hatchlings is determined by temperature, those incubated below 30°C being mostly male and those at higher temperatures female. Most hatchlings emerge at night to minimize predation and high surface temperatures and may be subject to intense predation by ghost crabs and seabirds during their journey to the ocean. They navigate seaward based on the brighter light created by reflection of moon and stars on the sea and so can become disorientated by the lights of buildings on the landward side. Juveniles live out in the open ocean before reaching maturity and returning to the coast to breed.
taxon_text_7_4242: Can be confused with Green turtles which occur in the same region, but these have a rounded bill, a smaller head and the carapace has only 4 lateral plates alongside the central row.
taxon_text_8_4243:
Alexander, G & Marais, J (2007). A Guide to the Reptiles of Southern Africa, Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 374).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 344).
taxon_text_1_4246:
The only species in this genus and family and the largest of all living turtles. Unmistakable due to the lack of a bony shell.

Carapace broad and streamlined, covered with a flexible, leathery skin bearing 7 very prominent longitudinal ridges that meet posteriorly. Head massive and cannot be fully withdrawn into the shell. Beak bicuspid. Front flippers massive and may have a span exceeding 3 m, hind limbs much smaller, strongly webbed and paddle-like, all limbs clawless. Colour dark-gray to black, blotched with white, underside paler.
taxon_text_2_4247: Total length normally up to 180 cm (can reach 250 cm) and mass of up to 500 kg (can reach 860 kg).
taxon_text_3_4248:
Global: Distributed world-wide in tropical and temperate seas, but many sub-populations have been severely depleted, both due to direct exploitation and as a result of accidental by-catch by commercial long-line and gill-net fisheries.

Local/Regional: Nest in KwaZulu-Natal and Mozambique and most often encountered there, but have been reported throughout the region.
taxon_text_4_4249:
