Cosmopolitan and fast-swimming, some tagged individuals covering thousands of kilometers per year. Males spend their entire lives at sea and females only come ashore to lay their eggs.

Well known for their ability to maintain body temperature up to 18°C above ambient water temperature, which allows them to range into cooler, temperate waters. This is achieved by ability to conserve metabolic body heat as a result of their large body size, small surface to volume ratio, layers of insulating fat and an efficient counter current exchange system in the flippers.

The most accomplished of reptilian divers, spending about 60 % of their time at depths of 10–250 m and diving for over 40 minutes on a single breath. Deepest recorded dives to over 1200 m.
taxon_text_5_4250: Feeds almost entirely on jellyfish and other soft-bodied organisms such as siphonophores, tunicates and cephalopods. May ingest plastic bags and similar marine debris, mistaking these for food items, and these may obstruct the digestive tract and cause death.
taxon_text_6_4251: Sexual maturity is achieved at an ago of 5–14 years. Mating takes place at sea and females return to the same beach where they were born to nest, in October to January in South Africa. Females drag themselves up the beach at night and excavate holes above the high-water mark using their hind flippers. Clutches of about 100 eggs are laid and the hole then filled in. The same female then returns to lay another batch of eggs at about 10-day intervals, laying up to 1000 eggs in a season. Eggs hatch after about 60–70 days and at a size of about 6 cm and 45 g. As in all turtles, the sex ratio of offspring is determined by incubation temperature, eggs incubated at temperatures above about 29.4°C developing mostly into females and those below this temperature into males. Newly hatched young emerge mainly at night to avoid predation, and may be heavily predated by crabs, seabirds and fish especially if they emerge by day.
taxon_text_7_4252: Unmistakable due their enormous size and lack of shell plates.
taxon_text_8_4253:
Alexander, G & Marais, J (2007). A Guide to the Reptiles of Southern Africa, Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 368).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 344).
taxon_text_1_4256:
Small, conical shell with a fairly sharp spire a little longer than aperture length and with fairly marked shoulders between whorls. Interior white, outer lip with feeble denticles and a strong oval sinus at the shoulder, columella smooth, lacking pleats.

Colour and surface texture variable. External surface usually sculptured by 9–11 strong, rounded axial ribs on each whorl (weak in some specimens). Colour typically reddish-brown with white flames, but sometimes plainer brown. Last whorl typically marked with distinctive zig-zag lines of reddish brown (best identification feature).
taxon_text_2_4257: Shell up to about 8 mm long, but most specimens about 5 mm.
taxon_text_3_4258:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4259: Very common among seaweeds and particularly corallines in intertidal pools and reefs, but often overlooked due to small size. Little else is known about biology.
taxon_text_5_4260: No species-specific details available, but other species in the family are thought to be omnivorous, consuming carrion, green algae and small sessile animals.
taxon_text_6_4261: No species-specific information, but other members of the family lay single oval or globular capsules that each contain one to many eggs and which may hatch into swimming larvae or directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_4262: Variable in colour and texture and one of several similar small conical gastropods found in the area. The flame-like markings on the last whorl and oval sinus on the outer lip are good identification features though.
taxon_text_8_4263: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 96).
<p>Millers Point - from Bamboo kelp hold: Millers Point - from Bamboo kelp holdfasts Ecklonia maxima; B.Sc. Honours sampling of Anna Roux, Stellenbosch University, Kelp Holdfast Biodiversity Project, PI Dr. Nasreen Peer, NRF-FBIP Grant FBIS22101863331
<p>juvenile, De Hoop - from Bamboo kelp: juvenile, De Hoop - from Bamboo kelp holdfasts Ecklonia maxima; PhD sampling of Chaitanya Katharoyan, Stellenbosch University, Kelp Holdfast Biodiversity Project, PI Dr. Nasreen Peer, NRF-FBIP Grant FBIS22101863331
taxon_text_1_4266:
Large, conspicuous worm with two spiral crowns of mottled cream to orange or brown tentacles that bear a row of small lobes (variously referred to as stylodes or lappets) on their outer surface. Tiny eyespots at bases of each lapel visible under the microscope.

Body fat and sausage-like, shading brown to purple anteriorly and with a wide anterior collar enclosing (and secreting) the top of a soft, muddy, parchment-like tube.
taxon_text_2_4267: Body typically 50 mm long, crown about 30 mm across.
taxon_text_3_4268:
Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Luderitz to False Bay. Despite the species name, not found in KwaZulu-Natal!
taxon_text_4_4269: Found in intertidal pools and gullies and on shallow reefs. The tube usually extends from a crack or from under a boulder and the crown of feeding tentacles is extended into the water to intercept food particles. Snaps back into its tube rapidly at the slightest disturbance. Rejected food particles are used to construct the soft, muddy tube.
taxon_text_5_4270: Filter-feeder, removing and consuming particulate material from the water passing through the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_4271: A variety of modes of reproduction occur in this group and most species can reproduce both asexually by ‘budding’ off smaller individuals, as well as sexually by producing sperm and eggs into the water column.
taxon_text_7_4272: There are several other large fan worms in the region. The closely related B. violacea has a crown of tentacles of two semicircles. The external lappets on the feeding appendages distinguish these species from the more common and better-known feather duster worm Pseudobranchiomma longa. Can be distinguished from the Red fan worm Serpula vermicuaris and all other members of the related family Serpulidae since these have hard calcareous tubes, rather than soft muddy ones found in family Sabellidae.
taxon_text_8_4273:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 767).
taxon_text_9_4275: Formerly known as Lanistina cuneata and as Musculus cuneatus.
taxon_text_1_4276: Shell small, oval and fat, with a distinct broad swelling running from the hinge across to the posterior corner. No internal hinge-teeth. External sculpturing distinctive and comprising fine concentric growth rings overlain with two well-separated groups of fine, flat-topped radiating ribs. One group of about 18–20 anteriorly and another group of 30–32 posteriorly. Colour reddish-brown, marbled with pale yellowish blotches.
taxon_text_3_4278:
Global: Widespread across Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans, including Mediterranean.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal north coast.
taxon_text_4_4279: Non-reef forming mussel found singly or in small groups nestling in rock crevices, in kelp holdfasts or in similar habitats. Sometimes found commensally in association with large solitary ascidians.
taxon_text_5_4280: All bivalves feed by drawing water in then filtering it through the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_4281: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_4282: Fairly distinctive external sculpture makes this small mussel easy to distinguish form other local species, but there is another larger (23 mm) and similar species, M. cumingianus, with fewer external ribs and found associated with ascidians on the east coast.
taxon_text_8_4283: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 160 as Musculus cuneatus).
taxon_text_9_4285: Formerly known as Cardium turtoni and as Parvicardium turtoni.
taxon_text_1_4286: Shell small, almost perfectly circular, external surface strongly marked with 25–28 radiating ribs, each rib with a series of strong, sharp triangular teeth or tubercles (may be eroded in larger specimens and are rapidly worn away on dead shells, which may appear almost smooth).
taxon_text_3_4288:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal north coast.
taxon_text_4_4289: Small cockle found among shallow benthic sediments, or in sandy intertidal pools. Very little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_4290: All bivalves feed by drawing water in, then filtering it through the enlarged sieve-like gills. Food particles filtered from the water are transported by cilia to the ventral edge of the gill and then forward to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_4291: Details unknown, but almost all bivalves are broadcast spawners.
taxon_text_7_4292: Fairly distinctive external sculpture makes this small cockle easy to distinguish when in good condition, but the distinctive sharp external teeth wear off easily in older and beach-cast samples.
taxon_text_8_4293: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 177 as Parvicardium turtoni).
taxon_text_1_4296:
As a group syllid species are fairly easily to recognise, as most are long, thin worms with unusually elongate, often annulated cirri projecting from each segment.

This long, thin and attractively coloured species has an transparent-white body bearing distinctive bright orange patches along the back. The head bears two pairs of round black eyes, three elongate antennae and two pairs of long tentacular cirri. The parapodia (lateral appendages) of the following body segments bear large sail-like dorsal cirri that curl over the back. Many individuals carry a chain of developing sexual buds from their posterior ends.
taxon_text_3_4298:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_4299: Usually solitary and found crawling rapidly on the undersides of boulders in intertidal pool. All members of this group are predatory.
taxon_text_5_4300: Details unknown for this species, but some other members of this genus are reported to feed on ascidians by piercing the zooids and sucking out the contents.
taxon_text_6_4301: Members of this family are famous for their diversity of reproductive strategies. Some species have a specialised pelagic phase in the lifecycle which swims off the bottom and release the eggs and sperm into the plankton. Others bud-off baby individuals (stolons) which detach from the parent and swim away to establish themselves at another site. Another variation is to develop a single reproductive stolon, which has enlarged appendages and swims off in to the plankton, where is bursts and dies. This species is commonly observed to bear a chain of developing buds extending from the tail end.
taxon_text_7_4302: The family contains about 60 regional species and many of these are difficult to distinguish without microscopic examination of the setae on the parapodia and shape and number of annulations of the cirri. The colour pattern of this species is immediately identifiable though.
taxon_text_8_4303:
Augener, H (1918). Polychaeta. Beitrage zur Kenntnis der Meeresfauna Westafrikas, 2(2), 67-625 (original description).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 287).

Nygren, A (2004). Revision of Autolytinae (Syllidae: Polychaeta). Zootaxa, 680, 1-314.
taxon_text_1_4306:
Small, conical shell with a sharp spire about equal to aperture length, relatively thin outer lip and 4 strong oblique white pleats on the columella (the best distinguishing feature).

Colour and surface texture extremely variable. External surface may be more or less smooth (as depicted here), or bear 15–20 low rounded pleats on each whorl. Colour may also vary from plain black or brown or bearing various black, brown or yellow to white spiral bands.
taxon_text_2_4307: Shell up to about 20 mm long, but most specimens do not exceed 10 mm.
taxon_text_3_4308:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4309: Common under rocks in intertidal, but often overlooked due to small size and very variable appearance. Little else is known about its biology, although members of this family are carnivorous.
taxon_text_5_4310: No species-specific details available, but other species in the group feed by sucking up soft tissues and body fluids of their prey rather than by consuming then entirely.
taxon_text_6_4311: No species-specific information, but other members of the family lay blister-shaped egg capsules that each contain few eggs (1–5) and which hatch directly into crawling young.
taxon_text_7_4312: Very variable in colour and texture, but common once noticed and reasonably easy to identify by virtue of small size and strong diagonal pleats on the columella.
taxon_text_8_4313:
Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 163 as Pusia patula)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 108 as Pusia patula).
taxon_text_1_4316: Body elongate and cylindrical in cross-section. Colour pale, speckled with brown, second pair of antennae greatly enlarged and thickened in males and with a curved tooth on underside of 4th segment. First pair of limbs (gnathopod 1) with a small claw, second pair very setose, but lacking claw. Last three abdominal segments (urosome segment 1–3) all fused.
taxon_text_3_4318:
Global: Originally from western North Atlantic, but has been spread by human activities to Europe, Australia, New Zealand, South America, South Africa and various other regions.

Local/Regional: Throughout region, especially in harbours, but also in natural habitats.
taxon_text_4_4319: Tube dwelling species that can occur in densities of thousands per square meter. Thought to have been distributed from its native habitat in North America on the hulls of ships, or associated with oysters shipped for culture. First recorded in South Africa in 1915. Can form burrows in mud on soft substrata, or live attached to rocks, among benthic organisms such as mussels, or on pilings, buoys, ships hulls and other artificial structures.
taxon_text_5_4320: Water is propelled through the tube by beating of the pleopods and food particles filtered out with the setose legs.
taxon_text_6_4321: As with all amphipods, sexes are separate. The eggs are extruded into a marsupial chamber beneath the legs of females, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_4322: The hugely enlarged second antennae of males with the ventral tooth on segment 4, and the fused abdominal segments 4–6, readily distinguish this species.
taxon_text_8_4323:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 344).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 32).

Picker, M & Griffiths, CL (2011). Alien and Invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 163).
taxon_text_1_4326:
Members of this family are dorso-ventrally flattened and have powerful legs held spread out laterally to grip the substratum. The second antennae are large, robust and sometimes brightly coloured. The second pair of claws (gnathopod 2) are very large and powerful. The abdomen is held curled under the body and urosome segment 1 is unusually elongated (more than twice as long as segment 2). The second pair of uropods may be reduced and the third pair either reduced or completely absent.

This species is fairly easily recognized by the strong dorsal processes running along the back from the head to the second abdominal segment.
taxon_text_3_4328:
Global: Widespread across Indo-Pacific and around southern Africa to Namibia.

Local/Regional: Mozambique to Namibia.
taxon_text_4_4329: Little is known about the biology of this species, but podocerids generally crawl around on the surfaces of hydroids, soft corals, bryozoans and similar benthic invertebrates. They attach themselves in prominent positions with their powerful grasping legs and then extend the elongated and setose second antennae to capture food items floating by in the current. Some are exquisitely camouflaged against their hosts, but others have very brightly coloured bodies, sometimes with the second antennae in another contrasting colour. Some brightly coloured species are thought to be mimicking nudibranchs.
taxon_text_5_4330: Presumed to capture food items from the water stream using the setose second antennae.
taxon_text_6_4331: As with all amphipods, sexes are separate. The eggs are extruded into a marsupial chamber beneath the legs of females, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_4332: There are about 10 described regional species in this group and probably several other undescribed ones that have been photographed, but the dorsal projections on each body segment are characteristic of this species. The species was originally described from Australia and the African form may well prove to be distinct if examined in detail.
taxon_text_8_4333:
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 68).

Hughes, LE (2012). New and little-known Podoceridae (Peracarida: Amphipoda) of southern Australia. Records of the Australian Museum, 64(1), 71-120.(redescription of Australian form)
taxon_text_9_4335: Gammaropsis atlantica, also previously placed in family Corophiidae.
taxon_text_1_4336: Smallish, laterally compressed species best identified by the very unusual, elongated eyes, which are extended onto a head-lobe projecting forwards between the antennae, are medially constricted, and pigmented red.  Antennae setose, the first pair somewhat the longer. Second pair of limbs (gnathopod 2) with fairly large claws, much larger than those of first pair. Last pair of abdominal appendages (uropod 3) with two short equal branches. Colour pale with black and red speckling. Commonly coxa of second walking leg with characteristic black spot.
taxon_text_3_4338:
Global: Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico and Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4339: Details unknown, but members of this family have silk glands in the walking legs for spinning tubes so are probably tube-dwelling filter-feeders.
taxon_text_6_4341: Like all amphipods the sexes are separate and males copulate with females while they are laying their eggs. The eggs are then held in a ventral marsupium between the walking legs, where they develop into fully formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_4342: The unusual elongated and centrally narrowed eyes are characteristic. A second very similar species L. afra is also has eye lobes extending between the antennae, but the eyes are oblong and the same width throughout. The relationships between the several species in this L. afra/atlantica complex remain confused (see Azman reference below).
taxon_text_8_4343:
Azman, BAR & Othman, BHR (2013). Shallow water marine gammaridean amphipods of Pulau Tioman, Malaysia, with the description of a new species. ZooKeys, (335), 1. (contains drawings of this species)

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 68).
taxon_text_1_4347: Very small, laterally-flattened, shrimp-like and uniformly pale pink in colour (except for red eyes). Antenna fairly short and equal in length. Second pair of legs (gnathopod 2) powerful and distinctive in shape, with large rectangular hand and transverse palm. The thick finger has a triangular tooth near base which closes into a marching notch in the palm. Most distinctive feature is that the body segments bearing the first two pairs of uropods (urosomites 1 and 2) are fused.
taxon_text_3_4349:
Global: As currently defined, occurs in Sri Lanka, South Africa, Mozambique, Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico, but taxonomy of this genus is confused and probably several regional species bear this same name.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4350: No species specific details known but members of this family have silk glands in the legs for spinning tubes and a tooth on the last segment of the walking legs for gripping, so are probably tube-dwelling and sedentary.
taxon_text_6_4352: In all amphipods, sexes are separate and males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs as they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_4353: This is the only local representative of the genus, and can fairly easily be identified by the enlarged rectangular hand of the second gnathopod and the very unusual fusion of the body segments bearing the first two pairs of uropods. The species name is suspect though, as it was originally used to describe specimens from Sri Lanka. Probably populations from different regions around the globe will eventually be shown to represent genetically distinct species.
taxon_text_8_4354:
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 31).

Myers, AA (2009). Chevaliidae. Zootaxa, 2260(1), 344-347.
taxon_text_1_4358: Stout, white amphipod with broad limbs adapted for burrowing in sand. The head bears an unusual and distinctive pointed ‘hood’ that projects forward over the eyes, much like the peak of a cap. The first two pair of limbs bear small claws and in the third pair the last joint is expanded into a distinctive spade-like lobe edged by large spines to aid in digging. The basal joints of the last pair of limbs are greatly expanded and lobed.
taxon_text_3_4360:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_4361: Burrows through sand on exposed sandy beaches, much like a mole.
taxon_text_5_4362: Assumed to scavenge on detritus and any other food particles found between the sand grains.
taxon_text_6_4363: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release.
taxon_text_7_4364: The tapering peak-like hood extending over the front of the head immediately identifies this species as a member of the family Phoxocephalidae (phoxo=tapering, cephala = head). This is the only species in the genus, which is named after the author of this entry, but it can be confused with Basuto stimpsoni, which has similar habits and overall appearance, but lacks the spade-like foot on the third pair of legs.
taxon_text_8_4365:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 27).

Jarrett, NE & Bousfield, EL (1994). The Amphipod superfamily Phoxocephaloidea on the Pacific coast of north America. Family Phoxocephalidae. Part II. Subfamilies Pontharpiniidae, Parharpiniinae, Brolginae, Phoxocephalinae, and Harpiniinae. Amphipacifica, 1(2), 71-150.
taxon_text_1_4378:
Fairly-large and robust amphipod with unusually short first antennae and very large and unusual nippers or gnathopods. The first pair of nippers has a unique (to the genus) form in which the ‘finger’ is formed by both of the last two segments, which close against a ‘palm’ formed by an extension of the third-last segment. Second pair of nippers are unusually powerful, but more conventional in form (subchelate), the palm without teeth and 5th segment extended into a lobe that protects hind margin of 6th segment (the ‘hand’) - see photograph under L. spinicarpa). Third abdominal side-plate has a hook-like, upturned tooth on hind corner.

Colour mottled orange with attractively white speckles on 5 pair of legs, which are held extended to the sides.
taxon_text_3_4380:
Global: Mediterranean, South Africa, Madagascar, India.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4381: Commensal in the cavities within sponges and tunicates.
taxon_text_5_4382: Assumed to scavenge on food particles pumped thought he internal cavities of sponges and tunicates, within which the amphipods dwell.
taxon_text_6_4383: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release.
taxon_text_7_4384: : In South Africa this family is represented by only the one genus Leucothoe, with five fairly similar species that are distinguished by the length of the antennae, shape and numbers of teeth on the palm of the second pair of nippers and shape of third abdominal side plate. This species is identified by its relatively short first antennae, lack of teeth on the palm of second nipper and distinctive upturned hook on lower corner to third side plate.
taxon_text_8_4385:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 52).
taxon_text_1_4388: Small, but very conspicuous and much photographed species with characteristic laterally flattened body with distinct ridge along the centre of the back and unusually short antennae with greatly reduced flagellum. There are triangular teeth on the back on each of the first three abdominal segments. Very distinctive bold colour pattern with wide yellow stripe along centre of back, sides of body purple to blue with red vertical stripes and orange legs!
taxon_text_3_4390:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4391: A common species on shallow reefs, where it moves around brazenly in the open, clearly defended by its bright warning colouration, which presumably warns predators that it is distasteful. Often seen gathering on whelk shells that are covered by the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum.
taxon_text_5_4392: Appear to feed on the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum, which occurs only on the shells of the whelk Burnupena papyracea. Often seen gathered in large numbers on these whelks. Exactly what chemicals are sequestered from the bryozoan and how these are involved in protecting the amphipod are unknown, but would make for a fascinating study.
taxon_text_6_4393: As with all amphipods the eggs are released into a brood pouch between the legs of the female, where they are fertilized by males and develop into fully formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_4394: Fairly unmistakable, could at first glance or superficially be confused with the Hunchback amphipod Iphimedia gibba.
taxon_text_8_4395:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 61).
taxon_text_1_4398: Laterally flattened and shrimp-like with distinctive patchy pale orange to dark red colouration. Eyes pale with red spots. Antenna 1 considerably longer than antenna 2. First two pairs of legs (gnathopods) with distinct nippers, those of second pair much the larger. Posterior margins of first 3 abdominal segments cut into characteristic single pair of sharp, flat-lying dorsal teeth. Last pair of abdominal appendages (uropod 3) with two fairly short equal-sized branches.
taxon_text_3_4400:
Global: South Africa and Red Sea (good chance these are not in reality the same species).

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_4401: Found among benthic algae and sedentary invertebrates intertidally and on shallow reefs. Habits unknown.
taxon_text_6_4403: In all amphipods sexes are separate and males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs as they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_4404: This is the only local representative of the genus, but can be confused with Red-striped amphipod Ceradocus rubromaculatus, which is similar in body form and is also red, but that species is much lighter in colour and is patterned with regular orange and white transverse stipes. It also has a row of several smaller teeth across the back margins of the first three abdominal segments.
taxon_text_8_4405: Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 41).
taxon_text_1_4408:
Members of this family are dorso-ventrally flattened and have powerful legs held spread out laterally to grip the substratum. The second antennae are large, robust and sometimes brightly-coloured. The second pair of claws (gnathopod 2) are very large and powerful. The abdomen is held curled under the body and urosome segment 1 is unusually elongated (more than twice as long as segment 2). The second pair of uropods may be reduced and the third pair either reduced or completely absent.

This species has a smooth body lacking any dorsal projections and is pale, mottled brown in colour. Distinctive combs of spines along the inner branches of the large uropods1 and 2 distinguish it from other local species. It is also easily identified by its unique habitat within the body cavities of the large ascidian Pyura spolonifera (Redbait).
taxon_text_3_4410:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from False Bay, but poorly studied and probably much more widespread, as the host occurs along most of the coast.
taxon_text_4_4411: Fairly recently discovered species that is known only from the branchial cavities of the large ascidian or redbait, Pyura stolonifera. Seldom observed but limited sampling suggests that most ascidians harbour 1-2 individual amphipods just inside the entrances to the siphons.
taxon_text_5_4412: Presumed to capture food items from the water stream pumped by the ascidian, using the setose second antennae.
taxon_text_6_4413: As with all amphipods, sexes are separate. The eggs are extruded into a marsupial chamber beneath the legs of females, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_4414: There are about 10 described regional species in this family and several other undescribed ones that have been photographed, but this species is unique in terms of its habitat within ascidians. Morphologically the strongly spinose uropods and lack of dorsal projections on the body are also useful identification features.
taxon_text_8_4415:
Griffiths, CL (1975). The Amphipoda of southern Africa: part 5. The Gammaridea and Caprellidea of the Cape Province west of Cape Agulhas. Annals of the South African Museum, 67 (5), 91-181 (p. 164)

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 41).
taxon_text_1_4418: Small, pale tanaid with a smooth, triangular carapace, cylindrical body and short, stout antennae that have a single, short flagellum. First pair of limbs robust and bearing equal-sized strongly-chelate (crab-like) claws. Abdomen consisting of six segments and ending in a fairly short pair of branched uropods.
taxon_text_2_4419: Up to 7 mm, but typically less than 5 mm.
taxon_text_3_4420:
Global: Southern Africa (specimens reported from New Zealand under this name have recently been described as separate new species).

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_4421: Regional tanaids have been very poorly studied and very little is known about the biology of this, or indeed any other regional species. They are common amongst algae and sessile invertebrates in the intertidal and on shallow reefs, where they live in mucous tubes. They are often overlooked because of their small size and slender bodies, which allow them to pass though the nets and sieves used by most collectors to wash benthic samples.
taxon_text_5_4422: Not well known, but presumed to feed on detritus and small organisms grasped by the sturdy chelae.
taxon_text_6_4423: As in all tanaids the eggs are brooded in a marsupial chamber ventrally between the legs of the female and released as manca larvae.
taxon_text_7_4424: The most common of several similar small tanaids found in the intertidal. Members of the common related genus Tanais can be distinguished by having five rather than six abdominal segments.
taxon_text_8_4425:
Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 94, as Anatanais gracilis).

Barnard, KH (1954). South African Pycnogonida. Annals of the South African Museum, 41, 81-158 (p. 152).
taxon_text_1_4428:
Pycnogonids are bizarre animals that are sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, since they are not closely-related to true spiders, we prefer to use the common name pycnogonids. The body consists of a head with a large tubular proboscis, a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming and, in the males, to carry the eggs. Behind the head is a compact to elongate trunk consisting of usually four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes onto which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical, abdomen.

This species is readily identified in the field by the rounded knob in the centre of the back on each thoracic segment. The head also has a conical ocular tubercle with distinct black eyes and the proboscis is stout, cylindrical, tapering and extends directly forwards. Thoracic segments 3 and 4 are more or less fused with the junction, which is difficult to see. The legs are stout and also ornamented with small conical processes.
taxon_text_3_4430:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_4431: Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, and this species has only been recorded a few times so nothing is known about its specific biology.
taxon_text_5_4432: Unknown, but almost all pycnogonids feed on cnidarians.
taxon_text_6_4433: Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits. The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
taxon_text_7_4434: The founded knobs on the back of each thoracic segment readily identify this species.
taxon_text_8_4435:
Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 94, as Anatanais gracilis).

Bird, GJ (2008). Untying the Gordian Knot: on Tanais novaezealandiae Thomson (Crustacea, Tanaidacea, Tanaidae) from New Zealand, with descriptions of two new Zeuxoides species. Zootaxa, 1877(1), 1-36.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 84).
taxon_text_1_4438: Elongate, slender scaleworm with the whole body covered by over 30 pairs of overlapping pairs of scales, each of which is pale grey. Colour pattern on scales differs regionally, but South African specimens have a single or double darker-grey semicircular arc of pigment on each scale. When examined microscopically the outer margins of the scales bear small tapering papillae (spikes).
taxon_text_2_4439: Body length typically about 80 mm, but can reach 200 mm.
taxon_text_3_4440:
Global: Widely distributed in Europe and North Atlantic, including Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico, also South Africa, Mozambique, Madagascar, India and Australia.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4441: Uncommon species usually seen singly, crawling on sand under boulders or amongst other invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_4443: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_4444:
This genus is easily distinguished from other common scaleworms in the region in that the body is very elongate and is entirely covered by a large number of overlapping scales. Other common regional scale worm genera mostly have much fewer scales (usually 15 or less) and/or have scales present only over the anterior half of the body.

Photographs of this species from other regions show differing colour patterns on the scales, suggesting that there may well be a flock of similar species in the different regions rather than the single very widely-distributed species currently recognised.
taxon_text_8_4445:
Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 109).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 53).
taxon_text_1_4448:
Shell fairly small and narrow with short siphonal canal and fairly sharp spire slightly longer than aperture. Surface smooth other than slight indentations between whorls and vague spiral threads near base. Inner lip without pleats, outer lip thin and smooth. Operculum horny.

Colour fairly variable, usually brown to yellowish with a network of either white spots or with brown lines or broader brown stripes. Foot and siphon pale with yellow spots.
taxon_text_3_4450:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_4451: Small species found from low water mark downwards nestling in crevices, among worm-tubes or ascidians or in kelp holdfasts.
taxon_text_5_4452: Not known for this species, but most dove-shells are omnivorous, feeding both on algae and on dead animals, as well as preying on small sedentary groups such as hydroids.
taxon_text_6_4453: Not known specifically for this species, but dove shells normally lay egg cases singly or in small groups. The form of these is very variable and may be domed, cylindrical or brick shaped with or without a collar. Each capsule may contain from one to many eggs, some of which may serve as nurse cells.
taxon_text_7_4454: There are several other regional species of Mitrella but this is the only one extending as far west as False Bay.
taxon_text_8_4455: Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 96).
taxon_text_1_4458: Small, very flat, irregularly-rounded, oyster-like bivalve which has the lower (right) valve firmly cemented onto the substratum. Lower valve thin, flat and white, with a distinctive large oval hole near the hinge, through which a calcified, plug-like byssus extends. The upper (left) valve is thicker and more convex, although still has a low profile. It is light brown or yellow with an irregular oval margin and is ornamented by weak radiating ribs and small scales.
taxon_text_3_4460:
Global: Europe, including Mediterranean and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_4461: Usually found singly or in small, dispersed groups attached on the undersides of boulders in sheltered pools. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_4462: Like almost all bivalves, feeds by filtering small particles and plankton from water drawn in through the inhalant aperture and sieved though the enlarged gills.
taxon_text_6_4463: Like almost all bivalves, feeds by filtering small particles and plankton from water drawn in through the inhalant aperture and sieved though the enlarged gills.
taxon_text_7_4464: The taxonomy of this group is still confused, and it is thought that several species occur in the region but these have yet to be properly described. Most regional guides feature Anomia achaeus, which is a similar small, often transparent species, often found on other mollusc shells or even algal fronds and which occurs form about Algoa Bay eastwards up the coast of Africa.
taxon_text_8_4465:
Holmes, AM (2017). Phylogenetics of British saddle oysters (Bivalvia: Anomiidae)-A review of the shell morphology, internal anatomy and genetics of Pododesmus in British waters. Journal of Conchology, 42(5), 317-325.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 172, group entry only).

Richards, D (1987). Shells of southern Africa: A concise guide for collectors (second Edition). Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 81).
taxon_text_1_4468: Small rounded beetle with very dark brown to black head and smooth black thorax. Antennae bear prominent terminal knobs. Elytra light brown and each marked with 9 strongly-pitted longitudinal grooves.
taxon_text_3_4470:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: Namibia to Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_4471:
Commonly found on sandy beaches along the west coast, where it most often found sheltering under decaying seaweeds along the driftline, especially kelps. Also occurs inland, where it is associated with dung.

Both adults and larvae are present throughout the year. The adults scavenge on decomposing material. Larvae are short-legged and white and are mostly predatory, but may also feed on material oozing from decaying kelp.
taxon_text_5_4472: Feed on decomposing material, especially rotting kelps.
taxon_text_6_4473: The larvae have a lifespan of about 40 days. Pupae are found on the top few cm of sand or soil and are enclosed in earthen cells constructed by the larvae. Pupation takes 9-12 days. Newly emerged adults are pale yellowish and take a few days to assume the normal darker colouration.
taxon_text_7_4474: There are at least 70 species of Hydrophilidae in South Africa, most of which are associated with water or damp habitats (as the family name suggests). Two species of Cercyon have been recorded among rotting kelps on beaches, the other species, C. gigas being dark brown with narrow longitudinal black stripes along its elytra.
taxon_text_8_4475: Prins, AJ (1984). Morphological and biological notes on some South African arthropods associated with decaying organic matter. 2. The predatory families Carabidae, Hydrophilidae, Histeridae, Staphylinidae and Silphidae (Coleoptera). Annals of the South African Museum, 92 (4), 295-356. (p. 305)
taxon_text_1_4478:
Earwigs are elongate insects easily identified by the curved forceps that extend from the tip of the 10-segmented abdomen. The short, square forewings are leathery and protect broad, fan-shaped and elaborately-folded hind wings beneath. Most species are cryptic and/or nocturnal.

This species is the largest in the region. Males have huge, curved forceps and females smaller, straighter ones. The body is pale tan with dark markings along the forewings and down the centre of the back, widening posteriorly.
taxon_text_3_4480:
Global: Cosmopolitan in tropical and temperate regions of the world.

Local/Regional: Entire region, both inland and along coast.
taxon_text_4_4481:
Common in moist habitats both inland, for example around the margins of lakes and dams or on sandy river banks, and along the coast. Usually found under logs, rocks or drift seaweed and remain concealed by day, emerging to feed at night.

The large forceps can be used to subdue prey, for defense, for courtship and mating and also to help fold the hindwings.
taxon_text_5_4482: Voracious predators that feed on a variety of insects, but also take carrion.
taxon_text_6_4483:
Males have two penises which they can use interchangeably, but they have a 90% preference for ‘right-handed penises’ that is unique among earwigs!

Nests are dug under rocks, logs or other debris on the shore and the female lays 60-100 large white eggs in a brood chamber, then continually guards and cleans these until they hatch about 10 days later. The female continues to groom and feed the young for a further 2-5 days until they leave the nest. Juveniles pass though 6 instars before reaching adulthood after which they live for only 2-3 months.
taxon_text_7_4484: Easily recognised by the large size and enormous forceps.
taxon_text_8_4485: Picker, MD, Griffiths, CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 80)
taxon_text_1_4488: Tiny, short, compact and entirely wingless wasp with black body densely covered with short silvery hairs. The species is best characterized by its unique habits as an egg-parasite of the intertidal spiders Desis formidabilis and Amaurobioides africanus.
taxon_text_3_4490:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Appears to be confined to a small area on the Cape Peninsula, making it both extremely localised in overall distribution and highly specialised in terms of its habitat requirements.
taxon_text_4_4491: Many scelionid wasps are eggs parasites of various arthropods and several genera parasites the eggs of terrestrial spiders. This species is unique though in that it is confined to the intertidal habitat, where it is a specialist parasite of the eggs of the Shore Spiders. The wasp appears to be highly adapted to this habitat in that it is both wingless and covered in short hairs that are though to trap a bubble of air over the body and allow the wasp to continue to breath underwater.
taxon_text_6_4493: Over 80 % of wasps hatching are female and male wasps fight with one another for the right to mate with these females, the winners mounting the females as soon as they emerge from their eggs. Female wasps then chew their way into other compartments within the same spider egg sac and lay one egg into each of the spider eggs found there. When a female finds a batch of spider eggs about 60 of the eggs present are parasitised. Parasitised eggs turn brown as they develop, whereas un-parasitised ones remain white.
taxon_text_7_4494: The only representative of this unusual and endemic genus and unlikely to be confused with any other species due to its unique habits.
taxon_text_8_4495:
Masner, L (1968). A new Scelionid wasp from the intertidal zone of South Africa (Hymenoptera: Scelionidae). Annals of the Natal Museum, 20(1), 195-198.

van Noort, S (2024). WaspWeb: Hymenoptera of the Afrotropical region. URL: www.waspweb.org.

van Noort, S, Masner, L, Popovici, O, Valerio, AA, Taekul, C, Johnson, NF & Austin, AD (2014). Systematics and biology of the aberrant intertidal parasitoid wasp Echthrodesis lamorali Masner (Hymenoptera: Platygastridae sl): a parasitoid of spider eggs. Invertebrate Systematics, 28(1), 1-16.

Owen, CA, Coetzee, JA & Van Noort, S (2014). Distributional range of the South African maritime spider-egg parasitoid wasp, Echthrodesis lamorali (Hymenoptera: Platygastridae: Scelioninae): Insecta: Hymenoptera. African Invertebrates, 55(2), 323-332.
taxon_text_1_4530: Forms a thin, straggly, flexible brown bush made up of narrow, wiry stems that periodically divide, the two branches diverging at a narrow angle. When viewed closely, the hydrothecae are positioned in pairs opposite one another and are well-separated along the stems, the openings project outwards and the apertures have two teeth, the one longer that the other. The reproductive gonothecae are larger than the feeding polyps and are pear or fig-shaped, with a large round opening closed by an operculum.
taxon_text_2_4531: Colonies typically 50-90 mm tall, gonothecae about 2 mm.
taxon_text_4_4533: Common from intertidal to 100 m depth on rocky reefs. Also on stipes of kelps.
taxon_text_5_4534: Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
taxon_text_6_4535: Colonies grow asexually by developing new branches.
taxon_text_7_4536: The thin, straggly appearance and sparce branching (without lateral side-branches) are fairly distinctive. A second species A. minima, has a single unbranched vertical stem, only reaches 6 mm in height and grows on surfaces of algae all around the coast.
taxon_text_8_4537:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 28).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 251).
taxon_text_1_4540: Very tall hydroid with stiff, wiry, black or brown stems that can be up to 30 cm long. Stems anchored by root-like holdfast and branch only near the base, thereafter stems extend as a clump of parallel stalks, each with short lateral extensions. Separate male and female colonies.
taxon_text_3_4542:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_4543: Easily recognizable species, due to its parallel stems and very large size. Found on submerged reefs from about 18-120 m depth, especially in False Bay and often washed ashore after storms attached to kelp holdfasts, redbait, mussels and the like. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_4544: Not studied, but presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
taxon_text_6_4545: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies. Male gonophores are elongate and have blunt ends. Female gonophores are bulbous and have flat lids.
taxon_text_7_4546: Easily identified by its large size and long, straight, black stems. There are three other species in the genus, but these form tree-like branching colonies.
taxon_text_8_4547:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 339).
taxon_text_1_4550: Conspicuous, large, branching hydroid with unusual black or smoky-grey stems. The final feather-like branches resemble a skeletonized leaf, with regularly-spaced filaments emerging on each side of the main stem, these being shorter at either end and longest in the centre, like a leaf. Side filaments each bear polyps only on the one, upper, side. The polyps emerge from cup-like hydrothecae that have a long, sharp lateral tooth when viewed microscopically. Reproductive individuals are globular and flattened.
taxon_text_2_4551: Vertical stems up to 150 mm tall. “Leaves‘ about 30 mm.
taxon_text_3_4552:
Global: Australia, Madagascar and Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, intertidal to up to 100 m depth.
taxon_text_4_4553: Usually attached to algae, especially coralline algae and very common in KwaZulu-Natal, where it is one of the most frequently seen coastal hydroids. Species in this genus can be venomous (for example the Fire hydroid, M. philippina) and although I am unaware of injuries being reported from this species, live specimens should not be handled.
taxon_text_5_4554: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4555: Colonies expand by asexual reproduction, with new vertical branches arising from the expanding network of stems. In this family the medusa stage has been suppressed and the reproductive individuals usually give rise to fully-formed planula larvae ready to settle.
taxon_text_8_4557:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 30 as Lytocarpus filamentosus).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 60 as Lytocarpus filamentosus).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 446 asLytocarpus filamentosus).
taxon_text_1_4560: Small, creeping hydroid with short upright, branched or unbranched stems emerging at intervals from root-like tubes cemented to the substratum. Stems tend to zig-zag slightly and bear a polyp at each bend, these emerging alternately on either side of main stem. Polyps each have a very short, ringed stalk and pale tentacles and lie within a rigid, cup-like hydrotheca, which has a smooth margin. Reproductive bodies seasonal and if present flask-like and born in the axes between the main stem and the lateral hydrothecae.
taxon_text_2_4561: Vertical stems typically about 10-30 mm tall, can reach 90 mm.
taxon_text_3_4562:
Global: Cosmopolitan, with some populations, including those in South Africa, though to be introduced by shipping.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, intertidal to up to 100 m depth.
taxon_text_4_4563: Very common fouling organism common on ships’ hulls, in harbours and on buoys, etc., as well as in natural habitats especially on surfaces of algae.
taxon_text_5_4564: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4565: Colonies grow by asexual reproduction, with new vertical branches arising from the expanding network of basal stems. Reproductive individuals give rise to fully-formed medusae, which are either male or female and in turn produce sperm of eggs which develop into planula larvae which settle and grow into new colonies to complete the lifecycle.
taxon_text_7_4566: One of several Obelia species in the region. The Zigzag hydroid Obelia geniculata has a markedly thickened stem below each polyp and is common on kelps. The stems are never branched.
taxon_text_8_4567:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 28).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 227).
taxon_text_1_4570: Small hydroid that lacks a branching upright stem, the individual polyps rather arising directly from a creeping ‘root’, which meanders across the surfaces of algae. Each polyp has about 25-30 tentacles and is enclosed in a cup-like hydrotheca that has fairly thick walls, a smooth margin and a single constriction just below the ‘cup’. Where present reproductive individuals also arise independently from the ‘root’ and are oval to pear-shaped, with a wide aperture.
taxon_text_2_4571: Individual polyps typically about 2 mm tall, colony may spread for at least 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_4572:
Global: Cosmopolitan.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, intertidal to 27 m depth.
taxon_text_4_4573: Very common and usually found growing on surfaces of algae (but also crabs and other sessile invertebrates), the creeping ‘roots firmly attached to the algal surface and giving rise to rows of polyps.
taxon_text_5_4574: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4575: Colonies expand by asexual reproduction, with new vertical branches arising from the expanding network of basal stems. Male gonophores have 4 band-like gonads, females have 30-40 large eggs arranges in 8 longitudinal rows. These develop into degenerate umbrella-shaped medusae which have no tentacles or mouth.
taxon_text_7_4576: Taxonomy of this group is complex and confused and there are many similar species in this genus and the closely-related genus Campanularia. Although usually reported as being cosmopolitan, recent genetic work also suggests that several regional species may in fact be included under this one name.
taxon_text_8_4577:
Cunha, AF, Collins, AG & Marques, AC (2017). Phylogenetic relationships of Proboscoida Broch, 1910 (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa): are traditional morphological diagnostic characters relevant for the delimitation of lineages at the species, genus, and family levels? Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, 106, 118-135.

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 27 as Campanularia integra).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 208 as Campanularia integra).
taxon_text_1_4580: A ‘textbook’ hydroid and the species is often depicted in general accounts of the group. Creeping filaments attached to the surfaces of algae or other hard substrata give rise to elongate, feather-like vertical stems which each bear branches alternately to the left and right. The zooids emerge from only the upper side of these branches and each is protected within a smooth, goblet-like cup (the hydrotheca) and is flanked by two tiny protective individuals (nematothecae - visible only microscopically). Reproductive individuals are borne close to the main stem and are flask-shaped with a smooth, slightly-curved neck. Colony colour cream.
taxon_text_2_4581: Vertical stems typically 30 mm tall, but can be up to 60 mm.
taxon_text_3_4582:
Global: Very widely distributed, including Europe and Mediterranean, Gulf of Mexico, both coasts of South America, Southern Africa, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, intertidal and mostly shallow water, but recorded down to 430 m depth.
taxon_text_4_4583: Extremely common fouling species on algae, other sedentary invertebrates (such as ascidians and sponges), rocks and artificial structures. Often in expansive colonies covering areas of the substratum.
taxon_text_5_4584: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4585: Colonies expand by asexual reproduction, with new vertical branches arising from the expanding network of stems. Male and female polyps occur on the same colony. There is no medusa stage and sperm enter the female polyp and fertilise the eggs. Planula larvae are subsequently released into the plankton and settle to form new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4586: Widespread and common, but in reality, there are some 12 regional species in this genus that can be difficult to separate without detailed microscopic examination. Also there are similar species in other genera, for example the very common Fine feather-hydroid Kirchenpauria pinnata is similar in overall appearance, but lacks nematothecae and the gonothecae have lateral ridges and a spiky apex.
taxon_text_8_4587:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 24, 29).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 60).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 399).
taxon_text_1_4590: Colonial hydroid with stiff, upright, bright-yellow stems, each bearing alternating lateral branches of decreasing length that all lie in a single plane. Larger side-branches may branch again. Both the main stem and side-branches bear polyps on both sides and each of these emerges from a projecting hydrotheca, which when the polyp is retracted is closed by a 4-sided, pyramid-shaped operculum. If present, reproductive individuals (gonothecae) are spindle-shaped and are born singly and often far out from the main stem.
taxon_text_2_4591: Stems typically 50 mm tall, but up to 300 mm reported, gonothecae about 2 mm.
taxon_text_3_4592:
Global: Australia, Southern Africa, Vema Seamount.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4593: Widely distributed on rocky reefs and in sheltered pools although also recorded down to 219 m depth. Always orientated at right angles to the predominant water flow.
taxon_text_5_4594: Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
taxon_text_6_4595: Colonies spread asexually by putting up new stems from the creeping ‘roots’. There are separate males and females and fertilized eggs develop within the female gonothecae to form planula larvae.
taxon_text_7_4596:
Distinctive stiff, flat appearance is unusual, but easily confused with members of the closely-related genus Thuiaria, which have similar colony form, but the side branches come off in pairs (not alternately to left and right) and the polyps are sunken into the stems.

Although all existing guides depict and name this species, in reality there are over 20 easily-confused local species in the genus and some of the images depicted on local websites appear to depict species other than S. arbuscula.
taxon_text_8_4597:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 28).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 281).
taxon_text_1_4600: Colonial hydroid with stiff, upright, orange-brown stems, each bearing paired lateral branches of decreasing length that lie in a single plane (the whole resembling a child’s drawing of a Christmas tree!). Both the main stem and side branches bear polyps of both sides and the slipper-like hydrothecae, from which these emerge, are sunken into the stem. If present, reproductive individuals (gonothecae) are urn-shaped with a wide aperture and are born in clusters near the main stem.
taxon_text_2_4601: Polyps less than 1 mm, stems typically 30 mm tall, but up to 60 mm reported, gonothecae up to 3 mm.
taxon_text_3_4602:
Global: Some sources give this species as endemic to Southern Africa (including Vema Seamount), but WORMS lists it as widespread across both north and South Atlantic Oceans. The taxonomy remains confused and northern records may in fact represent an undescribed species (see reference below)

Local/Regional: Whole region, from intertidal to 135 m.
taxon_text_4_4603: Widely distributed on rocky reefs, and in sheltered pools where it forms dense colonies, particularly in S. W. Cape.
taxon_text_5_4604: Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
taxon_text_6_4605: Colonies spread asexually by putting up new stems from the creeping ‘roots’. There are separate males and females and fertilized eggs develop within the female gonothecae to form planula larvae.
taxon_text_7_4606: Distinctive stiff, flat appearance is unusual, but easily confused with members of the closely-related genus Sertularella which have similar colony form, but the polyps are borne in hydrothecae that project from the sides of the stems, rather than being sunken into them.
taxon_text_8_4607:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 28).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 273).

Moura, CJ, Cunha, MR, Porteiro, FM & Rogers, AD (2011). The use of the DNA barcode gene 16S mRNA for the clarification of taxonomic problems within the family Sertulariidae (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa). Zoologica Scripta, 40(5), 520-537.
taxon_text_1_4610:
Strange-looking, pelagic, colonial hydrozoan formed of a float and a group of swimming bells at the one end, from which extends a long, spirally-coiled stem that bears groups of feeding individual or gastrozooids at intervals of about 5 cm. Each of these clumps consists of one to several gastrozooids and these are armed with both longer white tentacles and shorter reddish-brown ones.

The entire string can be retracted into a fairly tight spiral, or extended into a long, trailing string, such that the clumps of gastrozooids are widely separated (hence the allusion to ‘barbed wire’).
taxon_text_2_4611: Typically 20-50 mm in diameter, entire colony may be 3 m or more long when extended.
taxon_text_3_4612:
Global: Cosmopolitan in tropical and temperate waters, from surface to 1000 m depth.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4613:
Drifts in open water with the string of gastrozooids trailing behind to capture planktonic organisms that come into contact with the extended tentacles. When disturbed these can be retracted into a tight spiral. Specimens encountered in coastal waters are often broken as a result of wave action, so may consist of just a piece of the stem with a few clumps of zooids. 

The tentacles can inflict a painful sting, so contact with skin should be avoided.
taxon_text_5_4614: Feed passively by trolling for planktonic organisms using the extended ‘long-line’ of stinging tentacles.
taxon_text_6_4615: New individuals within the colony arise by asexual division.  New colonies are established via the release of medusae.
taxon_text_7_4616: The only species in the family and the bunches of gastrozooids along the stem are unmistakable. Several other elongate siphonophores are also present in the region though, but these have different arrangements of zooids.
taxon_text_8_4617:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 62).

Mapstone, GM (2003). Redescriptions of two physonect siphonophores, Apolemia uvaria (Lesueur, 1815) and Tottonia contorta Margulis, 1976, with comments on a third species Ramosia vitiazi Stepanjants, 1967 (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa: Apolemiidae). Systematics and Biodiversity, 1(2), 181-212.
taxon_text_1_4620:
Strange-looking, pelagic, colonial hydrozoan formed of a large transparent float and group of swimming bells at the anterior end, from which extends a long, jelly-like column containing rows of clumped zooids (cormids). Each of these clumps contains zooids specialized for different functions, such as capturing food, reproduction, or protection of the colony.

The cormids are generally reddish in colour and trail thin tentacles armed with stinging cells.
taxon_text_2_4621: Colony may be 1 m or more long when extended.
taxon_text_3_4622:
Global: Cosmopolitan in tropical and temperate waters, from surface to 2 500 m depth.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4623:
Drifts and swims sluggishly in open water with the trailing ‘tail’ hanging behind the swimming bells to capture planktonic organisms that come into contact with the extended tentacles.

The tentacles can inflict a painful sting, so contact with skin should be avoided.
taxon_text_5_4624: Feed passively by trolling for planktonic organisms using the extended ‘long-line’ of stinging tentacles. Prey mostly on small planktonic crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_4625: New colonies are established via the release of medusae.
taxon_text_7_4626: The only genus in the family and overall transparent sausage-like shape and leading float and swimming bells are unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_4627: Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 62).
taxon_text_1_4640: Strange-looking hydroid with a very tall, rounded and extensible floppy orange to pink central part (the hydranth) with a terminal mouth and covered in densely-packed, very short tentacles. Basal part surrounded by a single ring of about 20 fairly-thick branches, those of females bearing large (ca 1 mm diameter), pink reproductive gonophores that are each ornamented with a white distal ring and longitudinal lines and with a few short, branching terminal tentacles. (male unknown).
taxon_text_3_4642:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Luderitz to East London.
taxon_text_4_4643:
Usually found singly on the underside of boulders, or on vertical rock faces in the intertidal or in shallow reefs down to about 27 m. Also recorded on algae, including the kelp Ecklonia maxima. The elongate hydranth is very flexible and can be extended and bent laterally to search for prey, or contracted into a short cone.

Nothing else is known about the biology of this remarkable species, which is reported only from a few photographic records.
taxon_text_5_4644: Members of this family have a mouth at the end of the central hydranth and are predatory. This species has been seen bending over and ensnaring amphipods and isopods, which are stung by the short tentacles covering the conical hydranth and then transferred to the terminal mouth and swallowed.
taxon_text_6_4645: No details on this species, but males and females separate. In related species, anemone-like actinulae larvae are released and each have about 18 tentacles.
taxon_text_7_4646:
Easily recognized to group but can be confused with the closely-related Dreadlocks hydroid C. tentaculatum, which is mostly found in deeper water of 10-30 m depth and is often colonial and associated with the false coral bryozoan Laminopora jellyae. That species also has a white rather than pink hydranth and more elongate pink basal branches that are spotted with button-like white tentacles.

Note: Some of the images available appear to show other unknown forms and do not conform to the descriptions of either of the described local species.
taxon_text_8_4647:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52 as C. tentaculatum).

Hewitt, CL & Goddard, JH (2001). A new species of large and highly contractile hydroid in the genus Candelabrum (Hydrozoa: Anthoathecatae) from southern Oregon, USA. Canadian Journal of Zoology, 79(12), 2280-2288.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56 as Myriothela capensis).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 45 as Myriothela capensis).
taxon_text_1_4650:
Large, upright, colonial species with tall, unbranched stems each encased in a transparent sheath and topped by a spectacular crown. Crown consists of a central, dense tuft of white tentacles around the mouth and a second ring of much longer, white tentacles arranged in a neat, flat, outer ring. Between these lie pink, grape-like bunches of reproductive sporosacs.

Female polyps sometimes seen bearing strings of developing larvae.
taxon_text_2_4651: Polyps typically 50-100 mm tall, although a giant variety with polyps up to 250 mm tall is found in False Bay.
taxon_text_3_4652:
Global: Widespread in North Atlantic and Mediterranean, also west coast of USA (introduced), South Africa, Australia and New Zealand. May be introduced to some of those locations, or some of the populations may in reality represent distinct species.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Durban.
taxon_text_4_4653: Easily recognized by the enormous size of the individual polyps and their striking heads. Taxonomy confused and it seems unlikely that the giant species found in False Bay is the same as the much smaller form typically found in harbours and on ships hulls across much of the world.
taxon_text_5_4654: Feeds on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column, including larvae of molluscs and other invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_4655: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies. New individuals arise in the colony asexually by branching. New colonies are established by dispersal of mobile, crawling larvae shaped like little polyps and termed called actinula and there is no swimming stage.
taxon_text_7_4656: Easily identified by its very large size and spectacular polyps.
taxon_text_8_4657:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52).

Hewitt, CL & Goddard, JH (2001). A new species of large and highly contractile hydroid in the genus Candelabrum (Hydrozoa: Anthoathecatae) from southern Oregon, USA. Canadian Journal of Zoology, 79(12), 2280-2288.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 35, as Tubularia warreni).
taxon_text_1_4660: Forms an orange coating between the spiral ridges of shells only of the Scaly dogwhelk Nucella squamosa. The feeding polyps are orange to creamy and each have 5-12 tentacles with longer and shorter tentacles alternating. Between these are both smooth, hollow spines up to 1 mm tall and reproductive individuals (gonozooids), which are shorter with 3-5 very short tentacles and each bearing several round sporosacs.
taxon_text_2_4661: Polyps up to 4 mm, colonies several cm across, completely covering host shells.
taxon_text_3_4662:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_4663: Easily recognized by its obligate association with the Scaly Dogwhelk and assumed to provide protection to the host by repelling predators. In turn, the hydroid benefits by being transported to new, favourable habitats and by avoiding siltation.
taxon_text_5_4664: Not studied, but presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water surrounding the host shell, perhaps also particles released by the feeding activities of the host.
taxon_text_6_4665: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies. Male sporosacs are spherical and up to 0.4 mm in diameter and divided into 4 internal compartments. Female sporosacs oval, up to 0.5 mm and each bearing about 32 eggs in 4 tiers.
taxon_text_7_4666: Easily identified by its obligate host, but several other hydroid species are also found on the surfaces of other gastropod shells, for example H. kaffraria on the estuarine Tick shell Nassarius kraussianus and H. marsupialis on the Purple-lipped dogwhelk Nassarius speciosus.
taxon_text_8_4667:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 25).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 108).
taxon_text_1_4670:
Unusual calcified hydroid that grows on the surfaces of gastropod shells, both while they are still alive and when subsequently occupied by hermit crabs. The colony starts as a thin, hard, chalky-white calcareous crust, but later develops complex ridges, elongate spines and fluted processes that extend well beyond the original shell and render the host shells virtually unidentifiable.

The feeding polyps are creamy white and have 5-12 tentacles, of which one or two are typically longer than the others. The reproductive individuals bear ball-like sporosacs and male and females occur on separate colonies.
taxon_text_2_4671: Polyps about 3 mm, colonies several cm across, completely covering host shells.
taxon_text_3_4672:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Orange River to Durban.
taxon_text_4_4673: Instantly recognizable species that is common on a wide range of both living gastropod shell and shells occupies by hermits. Initially fairly smooth, but later strongly spiked and ridged and may provide additional protection to the host.
taxon_text_5_4674: Not studied, but presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water surrounding the host shell, perhaps also particles released by the feeding activities of the host.
taxon_text_6_4675: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies, smaller than feeding individuals (about 0.5 mm in length), have rudimentary tentacles and bear several sporosacs. Female sporosacs each bear a single egg which develops in situ into a planula larva.
taxon_text_7_4676: Easily identified by the calcareous skeleton, especially where this develops large external processes. Several other hydroid species also found on the surfaces of gastropod shells (for example Hydractinia altispina on the whelk Nucella squamosa), but these lack a calcareous skeleton and are usually restricted to a single gastropod host.
taxon_text_8_4677:
Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 25).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 116).
<p>Top left: Section through colony skel:
Top left: Section through colony skeleton showing calcareous process and contracted hydranths

Top right: Gastrozooids

Bottom: colony with processes, completely covering shell previously inhabited by a hermit crab

Scale bar units in mm.
taxon_text_1_4680: Colonian hydrozoan that floats on the water surface and is frequently cast ashore following onshore winds. The colony members are bright purplish-blue and are supported by a flat, perfectly round, transparent float marked by both radiating ridges and concentric growth rings. The colony members hang beneath the float and extend beyond its margins as a ‘skirt’ and include a single, large central feeding individual (gastrozooid) and a large number of smaller individuals that bear radiating tentacles for prey capture, or are reproductive. The tentacles are of varying lengths and spread out as a ring around the float. Each tentacle is armed with conspicuous groups of nematocysts and becomes darker purple near its tip.
taxon_text_3_4682:
Global: Cosmopolitan in warm and temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Most of region, but absent from upper west coast.
taxon_text_4_4683:
Floats on the ocean surface, where driven along at the mercy of prevailing winds. The feeding tentacles radiate from the float and are used to capture tiny planktonic organisms.
