The stinging cells have very weak venom and are not harmful to humans, although allergic reactions have been reported, so it is still best not to handle live animals.

May be cast ashore in thousands after onshore winds, often along with other ‘blues’ including the related By-the-wind sailor Velella velella, Bluebottle Physalia physalis, and predatory floating molluscs that feed on these species. Sometimes just the floats are found, the body having rotted away, and these are transparent, plastic-like and often confused as being man-made objects!
taxon_text_5_4684: Feeds on small particles and planktonic organisms in the surface water.
taxon_text_6_4685: The familiar floating colony is the polyp phase of the life-cycle.  Reproductive individuals in the colony give rise to numerous tiny medusae (‘jellyfish’) each about 2 mm across, by a process of asexual budding. These in turn produce sperm and eggs which merge and develop into larvae that give rise to new floating colonies.
taxon_text_7_4686: Distinctive, but sometimes confused with the By-the-wind sailor Velella velella, which often washes up at the same time. However, that species has an oval float equipped with an oblique semicircular vertical sail.
taxon_text_8_4687: Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 56).
taxon_text_1_4690: Large fan-like species, often mistaken for a sea-fan (Gorgonacea). The erect colony has an internal chitinous skeleton and is fairly regularly branched in a single plane, to form a fan-like structure up to 400 mm tall. Main stem thick and flattened, but smaller branches rounded in cross-section and grey or yellow-brown in colour. The small polyps are housed within bracket-shaped projections (hydrophores) extending from the sides of the stems, are elongate and bear scattered tentacles irregularly over the body. When preserved they are knob-like, but in life presumably elongate. Reproductive individuals are small and spherical.
taxon_text_2_4691: Colony up to 400 mm tall and with a span of 300 mm.
taxon_text_3_4692:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4693: Unusual appearance for a hydroid and looks much more like a sea-fan. Found on rocky reefs from about 12-130 m depth and extends from the rock face out into the water to intercept the dominant current.
taxon_text_5_4694: Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
taxon_text_6_4695: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies, but male and females individuals look similar. Free-living stages have not been observed.
taxon_text_7_4696: Fairly unique among regional hydroids due to the stiff, branching, fan-like structure and this is the only such species in the Western Cape (one other species in the genus known form Mozambique). Often mistaken for a sea-fan (Gorgonacean), but the polyps are quite different – those of seafans having a ring of 8 elongate tentacles rather than elongate form with scattered tentacles found in Solandaria species.
taxon_text_8_4697:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 59).
taxon_text_1_4700:
As with most hydroids there is both a sedentary polyp phase and a medusa, or jellyfish-like, phase in the lifecycle. However, unlike most other species, in this case the medusa is the dominant and commonly-encountered phase and the polyp is rarely seen.

Polyp tiny and hardly ever seen, arising from a creeping stem and expanding from a narrow base. There are 4-6 slender tentacles part-way up the stem and 3-4 club-like tentacles at the tip. Medusae bud from the side of the stem.

Medusae much more commonly found, transparent mottled pink to red and attach to the fronds of brown algae. Each has a variable number of branched marginal tentacles that bear terminal suckers and conspicuous clusters of nematocysts.
taxon_text_2_4701: Polyps only 1.5 mm tall, medusae about 3-4 mm across.
taxon_text_3_4702:
Global: Falkland Islands, Southern Africa, Australia, New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_4703: The attractive medusae are seasonally common on the surfaces of large algae, but are often mistaken for sea anemones. The lower branches of each tentacle has a terminal sucker at the tip and the medusa can creep around by releasing and reattaching these suckers. The number of tentacles increases as the medusa grows and once it reaches about 40, the medusa divides by fission.
taxon_text_5_4704: Not studied, but presumed to be carnivorous feeding on small prey such as the benthic copepods which are abundant on the algal fronds on which they are found.
taxon_text_6_4705: Medusae can undergo asexual reproduction by fission, but also undertake sexual reproduction, with sexes being separate. The polyp stage produces medusae by budding at the level of the lower cycle of tentacles and medusae are released when they have about 6 tentacles.
taxon_text_7_4706: The creeping, sedentary medusa stage is unique among local hydroids and are easily recognised, although sometimes mistaken for small anemones (form which they are distinguished by having branched tentacles).
taxon_text_8_4707: Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 57).
taxon_text_1_4710: Unusual calcified hydrozoan that has thick, hard stems and is often mistaken as a true coral (Order Scleractinia). The colony is bright pink or orange and shaped like a short, stout tree, with a thick, sometimes flattened base adhering firmly to the substratum and bearing one to many upright, cylindrical, branching stems that become paler towards their tips. The tiny polyps emerge from star-shaped openings in the skeleton.
taxon_text_2_4711: Polyps about 1 mm, colonies up to 25 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_4712:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4713:
Instantly recognizable to group and common on shallow reefs from about 5-100 m in depth, particularly in overhangs and on vertical surfaces.

Unlike most true corals does not host symbiotic algae (zooxanthellae) so is not dependent on light and thrives in dark habitats, such as caves. Very slow growing and can be aged by growth rings formed in the main stems, much like tree rings. Individuals can reach over 100 years in age. A protected species that requires a special permit for collection.
taxon_text_5_4714: Feeds on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water surrounding the host
taxon_text_6_4715: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies, smaller than feeding individuals (about 0.5 mm in length), have rudimentary tentacles and bear several sporosacs. Female sporosacs each bear a single egg which develops in situ into a planula larva.
taxon_text_7_4716: Well-known and easily recognized to genus level although in reality this is just the most common of seven regional species. The wide diversity of colours and shapes in photographed specimens under this name suggests that at least some of these actually represent other species in the genus (for details see Cairns reference below).
taxon_text_8_4717:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 42).

Cairns, SD & Zibrowius, H (2013). Stylasteridae (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa, Filifera) from South Africa. Zootaxa, 3691(1), 1-57.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).
taxon_text_1_4720: Colonial hydrozoan that floats on the water surface and is frequently cast ashore following onshore winds. The colony members are bright blue and are supported by a flat, oval, transparent float marked by concentric grow rings and bearing a distinctive oval vertical ‘sail’ that sits obliquely across it. The colony members hang beneath the float and extend beyond its margins and include a single large central feeding individual and a large number of smaller individuals that bear short, simple tentacles for prey capture, or are reproductive.
taxon_text_3_4722:
Global: Cosmopolitan in warm temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but rare on upper west coast.
taxon_text_4_4723:
Floats on the ocean surface, where driven along at the mercy of prevailing winds blowing on the sails. There are both left and right-handed individuals, so these will be driven in different directions by the wind. The short feeding tentacles extend only about a centimetre below the float and are used to capture tiny planktonic organisms. The stinging cells thus possess very weak venom and are not harmful to humans, although allergic reactions have been reported, so it is still best not to handle live animals.

May be cast ashore in thousands after onshore winds, often along with other ‘blues’ including the related Blue buttons Porpita porpita and Bluebottles Physalia physalis, as well as predatory floating molluscs that feed on these species. Sometimes just the floats are found, the body having rotted away, and these are transparent, plastic-like and often thought to be man-made!
taxon_text_5_4724: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the surface water.
taxon_text_6_4725: The familiar floating colony is the polyp phase of the life-cycle and each colony is either male or female. Reproductive individuals in the colony give rise to numerous tiny medusae (‘jellyfish’) each about 1 mm across, by a process of asexual budding. These reach sexual maturity in 2-3 weeks and in turn produce sperm and eggs which merge and develop into larvae that in turn give rise to new floating colonies.
taxon_text_7_4726: The oblique sail is very distinctive but is sometimes confused with the Blue Button Porpita porpita, which often washes up at the same time. However, that species has a circular, not oval, float and lacks any sail.
taxon_text_8_4727:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 56).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 60).
taxon_text_1_4730: Forms aggregations of polyps embedded in various species of sponges. Each polyp is about 15 mm tall and has a thick, tapering, pale stem, topped by a red to pinkish head consisting of a central tuft of pale tentacles surrounded by bunches of pink sporosacs and then by an outer circle of much longer, paler tentacles. The swollen basal part is rooted within the host sponge.
taxon_text_2_4731: Polyps typically 15 mm tall, colonies typically spread over a few cm in diameter, but basal parts concealed within sponge.
taxon_text_3_4732:
Global: Central and South America, Southern Africa and Japan.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4733: Always associated with host sponges, within which the bases of each polyp are concealed. Few other details available.
taxon_text_5_4734: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4735: Male and female organs occur on the same polyp. The medusa stage (antinulae) has 9-12 tentacles and are thought not to feed, so have limited dispersal abilities.
taxon_text_7_4736: Easily recognized by the fat, pink stems and fact that polyps emerge from a sponge host.
taxon_text_8_4737:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52).

Campos, CJ, Marques, AC & Migotto, AE (2007). A taxonomic revision of the genus Zyzzyzus Stechow, 1921 (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa: Tubulariidae). Zootaxa, 1627(1), 1-22.

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 26 as Tubularia solitaria).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56 as Zyzzygus solitaria).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum 68: 1-513 (p. 40 as Zyzzygus solitaria).
taxon_text_1_4740:
Medium-sized, smooth, thick, saucer-shaped bell typically off-white in base colour and with numerous opaque white spots. There are 16 darker triangular markings radiating around margins of the bell, but these do not reach its apex, which remains as an open circle. Radiating triangles vary greatly in extent and darkness and can be just outlines, or partially or fully filled with pigment.

Eight equally-spaced notches around margin of the bell each bear a dark, flattened, ribbon-like, primary tentacle with 2 smaller secondary tentacles occurring between each pair of primaries, giving a total of 24 tentacles.

Four frilly, cream oral arms project from the underside and are spiral proximally, becoming linear distally.
taxon_text_3_4742:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4743: The most common jellyfish from the Cape Peninsula eastwards. Often brought into shallow waters and experienced by divers, also found stranded in very large numbers. Remarkably, despite this, the species was only very recently described and little is known about its biology.
taxon_text_5_4744: Like many other jellyfish thought to feed primarily on zooplankton.
taxon_text_6_4745: Have a dimorphic life cycle, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and males release sperm into the water which are taken in by females to fertilise their eggs. Larvae are released into the water and ultimately settle onto hard surfaces where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_4746:
Easily confused with the closely related C. fulgida, but that species grows larger, has a pink to orange bell (with similar maroon triangles and markings), has cylindrical rather than flattened, dark tentacles and is primarily a West Coast species.

A third species, C. africana, is found in Namibia, but does not extend to the Western Cape. It is generally paler and has more (up to 48) flattened marginal tentacles all of the same dark colour.
taxon_text_8_4747:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Ras, V, Neethling, S, Englebrecht, A, Morandina, AC, Bayha, KM, Skrypzech, H & Gibbons, MJ (2020). There are three species of Chrysaora (Scyphozoa: Discomedusae) in the Benguela upwelling ecosystem, not two. Zootaxa, 4778, 401-438.
taxon_text_1_4750:
Large, smooth, thick, saucer-shaped bell typically pink to orange in colour with16 darker triangular markings radiating from the centre of the bell (not evident in juveniles). Eight equally-spaced notches around margin of the bell each bear a dark, cylindrical primary tentacle. Up to 2 smaller secondary tentacles occur between each pair of primaries.

Four spiral and very-frilly oral arms project from the underside and are usually orange to brown.
taxon_text_2_4751: Can be very large, with bell up to about 800 mm across, and weighing up to 20 kg, but usually much smaller.
taxon_text_3_4752:
Global: Endemic to Benguela region from Angola to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_4753: Found across the continental shelf and most common in Autumn. Can become extremely common and damage fishing nets. Also subject to mass strandings on beaches. Venom not thought to be dangerous to humans.
taxon_text_5_4754: Like many other jellyfish feed primarily on zooplankton.
taxon_text_6_4755: Have a dimorphic life cycle, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and males release sperm into the water which are taken in by females to fertilise their eggs. Larvae are released into the water and ultimately settle onto hard surfaces where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_4756:
Easily confused with the closely related C. agulhensis, but that species has a whiter bell (with similar marron triangles and markings), has flattened rather than cylindrical, cream tentacles and is primarily a South Coast species, occurring from Cape Town eastwards.

A third species, C. africana, is found in Namibia, but does not extend to the Western Cape. It is generally paler and has more (up to 48) flattened marginal tentacles all of the same dark colour.
taxon_text_8_4757:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Ras, V, Neethling, S, Englebrecht, A, Morandina, AC, Bayha, KM, Skrypzech, H & Gibbons, MJ (2020). There are three species of Chrysaora (Scyphozoa: Discomedusae) in the Benguela upwelling ecosystem, not two. Zootaxa, 4778, 401-438.
taxon_text_1_4760:
Fairly small species with a thin, hemispherical bell that is characteristically covered in small warts, is rough to the touch and (unusually) bears stinging cells on the bell surface. There are eight notches around the bell margin, each bearing a long, hollow, usually strongly-pigmented tentacle. Four long, frilly arms hang from the mouth area.

Colour variable, but often tinged with pink, purple or light brown. The pink to purple gonads are usually clearly visible though the bell.
taxon_text_3_4762:
Global: North Atlantic and Mediterranean, extending all down the west coast of Africa to South Africa. There are also reports from the Indian Ocean, Australia and New Zealand, but these may well represent different species within a closely-related complex and the true P. noctiluca is suspected to be an exclusively Atlantic form.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_4763:
Common in coastal waters where it may undergo seasonal blooms. Well known for its ability to emit light when disturbed.

Inflicts a painful sting and should not be handled, as even the bell bears nematocysts and these can remain active even after stranding. Stings can be painful and last 1-2 weeks, but are not normally dangerous.

Adults typically live for about 9 months.
taxon_text_5_4764: Like many other jellyfish thought to feed primarily on a variety of small zooplankton, including fish larvae.
taxon_text_6_4765: Has an unusual reproductive system in that the bottom-dwelling polyp stage found in almost all other jellies, including others in this family, has been suppressed. Each medusa is either male or female and males and both sexes release gametes into the water which develop into planula larvae, which develop (via an ephyra stage resembling the usual benthic polyp) directly into tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_4766: Fairly easily identified by the unusual warts on the bell surface.
taxon_text_8_4767:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gershwin, L & Gibbons, M (2009). Carybdea branchi, sp. nov., a new box jellyfish (Cnidaria: Cubozoa) from South Africa. Zootaxa, 2088, 41–50.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 52 as C. robsoni).
taxon_text_1_4770:
Box jellyfish have a distinctive cube-shaped bell with either a single trailing tentacle at each corner, or a single branching tentacle at each corner.

This species has a stiff, transparent bell marked with a pattern of opaque white spots. There is a single, elongate, tapering tentacle on each corner which emerges from a short stalk that is usually tinged with brown.
taxon_text_2_4771: Bell up to about 70 mm across, tentacles may be up to 2 m long when extended.
taxon_text_3_4772:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4773:
Unusual amongst jellyfish in that possess a nerve ring around the base of the bell that co-ordinates the contractions of the muscles. Also have fairly advanced eyes with a retina, cornea and lens, which allow them to avoid obstacles and seek prey.

This fairly common species, often forms swarms that feed together in clearings in kelp beds and similar habitats. Due to the restricted opening to the bell, contractions result in a powerful jet current, which allows box jellies to swim much faster than most other jellyfish. The tentacles can be greatly extended when feeding, but can be rapidly contracted when disturbed, or to bring prey back to the mouth. The South African species is venomous and can inflict a painful sting, but is not nearly as dangerous as the well-known related Australian species, which can be fatal.

Known to be eaten by sunfish Mola mola.
taxon_text_5_4774: Feeds on small fish and crustaceans, which are immobilized by the stinging cells on the tentacles and then transferred to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_4775: Thought to have an annual life cycle with adults living for only a few months. Reproduces by internal fertilization, the male transferring a spermatophore to the female (possible during the ‘swarming’ events often observed) after which the female produces an embryo strand, which also containing nematocysts to protect the developing young.
taxon_text_7_4776: Easily recognised by the body shape and the only species of box jelly occurring in the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_4777:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 52 as C. robsoni).
taxon_text_1_4780: Transparent, sack-like body variously described as being, oval, cigar-like, or resembling a rugby ball and with a very wide mouth at one end. Eight longitudinal rows of cilia, each arranged as a series of short transverse plates, run along most of the length of the body. Synchronous beating of these cilial plates propel the animal though the water and create a beautiful flickering iridescent effect. There is a figure-8 shaped ring of papillae at the posterior end of the body.
taxon_text_3_4782:
Global: Widespread in North Atlantic and Mediterranean, also reported from Southern Africa, New Zealand and Southern Ocean. 

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_4783: A pelagic species found swimming in coastal and oceanic waters. Feeds on surprisingly large prey, which are engulfed whole.
taxon_text_5_4784: Feeds mostly on other comb jellies, but also pelagic crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_4785: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae.
taxon_text_7_4786: Fairly easily recognised to group by the smoothly oval body shape, large mouth and lack of tentacles. There are in fact also three other rarer Beroe species known from the region though, these being distinguished both by body shape and length and branching pattern of the cilia rows.
taxon_text_8_4787:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 56).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 66).
taxon_text_1_4790: Spherical to slightly oval but symmetrical. Transparent and found floating in open ocean, but quite frequently washed ashore. Two long, trailing tentacles at the one end bear numerous short, feathery side-branches along just the one edge. There are eight equal ciliary rows that each run for about 75% of body length.
taxon_text_3_4792:
Global: Widespread in Atlantic Ocean, but also reported from New Zealand and Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Whole coast.
taxon_text_4_4793: Little known about biology but can sometimes be very common. Thought to only live for a few months. Hyperiid amphipods sometimes seen associated with this species. European populations make daily vertical migrations, descending to deeper waters of 80-150 m in the early morning and rising again to surface waters in the late afternoon.
taxon_text_5_4794: Feed on small planktonic crustaceans such as amphipods, copepods and crab or barnacle larvae captured by the tentacles, which lack stinging cells (as found in cnidarians), but are instead armed with adhesive cells (colloblasts) with which to ensnare small prey.
taxon_text_6_4795: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae which gradually adopt the adult form.
taxon_text_7_4796: Similar to Hormiphora sp., but members of that genus are wider at the one end, like a pear, while Pleurobranchia are round to oval but symmetrical in shape.
taxon_text_8_4797:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Gibbons, MJ, Haddock, SH, Matsumoto, GI & Foster, C (2021). Records of ctenophores from South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e10697.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 66).
taxon_text_1_4800: Species level identification is uncertain, hence the question mark above. Body, transparent, oval and slightly broader at oral end. Two large and distinctive oral lobes extend from the mouth area and well beyond the main body, but are variable in length. Four longer rows of cilial rows extend from the upper end along the lobes, while 4 shorter rows lie between these.
taxon_text_3_4802:
Global: Widespread in Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean and the most common ctenphore in eastern USA.

Local/Regional: Photographic reports of this genus from False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4803: Can sometimes bloom and become very common and thought to only live a few months.
taxon_text_5_4804: Feeds on small planktonic crustaceans, particularly copepods.
taxon_text_6_4805: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water, where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae which gradually adopt the adult form.
taxon_text_7_4806: The lobes extending beyond the main body are distinctive at genus level, but no species from this genus have been formally described from South Africa, so photographic reports from different regions of the country may well represent disparate species.
taxon_text_8_4807:
Gibbons, MJ, Haddock, SH, Matsumoto, GI & Foster, C (2021). Records of ctenophores from South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e10697.

Kremer, P, Reeve, MR & Syms, MA (1986). The nutritional ecology of the ctenophore Bolinopsis vitrea: comparisons with Mnemiopsis mccradyi from the same region. Journal of Plankton Research, 8(6), 1197-1208.
taxon_text_1_4810: Very striking and unmistakable species and the largest of all ctenophores. The body takes the form of an elongate, flattened and undulating ribbon with iridescent edges and can be over 1 m ‘long’ (anatomically speaking this is in fact the width!). Longitudinal canals run through the body. Tentacles fringe the mouth opening, which runs along the entire length of the lower surface and two setal rows run along either side of the ribbon, curving sharply upwards in the midline.
taxon_text_3_4812:
Global: Pelagic and found in tropical and temperate seas worldwide. 

Local/Regional: False Bay eastwards to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4813: A pelagic species found swimming in coastal and oceanic waters using both undulating contractions of the entire body and the beating of the comb rows, which give an iridescent sheen to the body. Known to bioluminesce when disturbed.
taxon_text_5_4814: Feeds on small crustaceans in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4815: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae.
taxon_text_7_4816: Easily recognised and the only such flattened species occurring in the region.
taxon_text_8_4817:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 56).

Gibbons, MJ, Haddock, SH, Matsumoto, GI & Foster, C (2021). Records of ctenophores from South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e10697.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 66).
taxon_text_1_4820:
Very large, high, smooth, dome-shaped bell with thick, translucent jelly. Margin of bell lacks tentacles, but is ornamented with numerous scallops. A short, thick, fused set of oral arms hangs under the bell like a thick trunk and lacks terminal appendages (as found in the related Rhizostoma). The arms spreads out distally to reveal numerous small mouthlets.

Colour translucent white.
taxon_text_2_4821: Up to 400 mm bell diameter (some sources give up to 1.5 m).
taxon_text_3_4822:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Known only from the southwestern coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_4823: Despite its large size, this species was only recently described and appears to have has a restricted distribution. Little is known about its biology.
taxon_text_5_4824: Not documented, but given the structure of its feeding appendages assumed to feed on small zooplankton.
taxon_text_6_4825: Details unknown, but assumed to have a dimorphic life cycle like other members of this family, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and release gametes into the water. Fertilised eggs develop into larvae that ultimately settle onto hard surfaces, where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_4826: Could be confused with Rhizostoma species, but these have longer oral arms which end on elongate terminal appendages.
taxon_text_8_4827:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 50).
taxon_text_1_4830:
Very large, dome-shaped bell with thick, translucent jelly, firm to the touch. Margin of bell lacks tentacles, but is ornamanted with numerous scallops.

No central primary mouth opening, but instead four pairs of thick oral-arms hang beneath the bell and are equipped with numerous small mouthlets along their edges. Long, club-shaped terminal appendages hang from the ends of the oral arms and can be twice their lenght, but are often lost or damaged, particularly in specimens found on the shore.

Colour translucent with margins of bell and oral arms often white.
taxon_text_3_4832:
Global: Mediterranean and down west coast of Africa to Angola, absent in Namibia, but found again in Western Cape of South Africa. 

Local/Regional: West Coast to Agulhas Bank.
taxon_text_4_4833: A very large species and often washed ashore on beaches, where eagerly consumed by plough shell Bullia spp. (see that page). Stranded specimens often contain hyperiid amphipods that feed on their internal organs. Despite its large size, little is known about the biology of this species.
taxon_text_5_4834: Not documented for this species, but like many other jellyfish thought to feed primarily on zooplankton.
taxon_text_6_4835: Have a dimorphic life cycle, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and males release sperm into the water which are taken in by females to fertilise their eggs. Larvae are released into the water and ultimately settle onto hard surfaces where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_4836: The large size and lack of marginal tentacles distinguish this from most other jellyfish, but there has been some confusion in previous guides as to the species identification (see refs below).
taxon_text_8_4837:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50, as R. cf pulma).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 50, misidentified as Chrysaora sp.).

Kienberger, K, Riera-Buch, M, Schönemann, AM, Bartsch, V, Halbauer, R & Prieto, L (2018). First description of the life cycle of the jellyfish Rhizostoma luteum (Scyphozoa: Rhizostomeae).PloS one, 13(8), e0202093.
taxon_text_1_5442:
Unusual seapen in which the rigid central stem (or rachis), which projects vertically from soft sediments, is completely encircled by a sausage-like cloak of polyps. When uprooted the buried section of the body can be seen as a tapering peduncle that forms about a third of the total length and is devoid of polyps.

Colour variable, but typically from pale-yellow, white or cream to mauve or reddish-purple, often with a metallic sheen.
taxon_text_2_5443: Colonies up to 240 mm long (including buried section).
taxon_text_3_5444:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5445: Found in sand in sheltered sites at depths of 6-222 m, but uprooted specimens sometimes found washed ashore. Bioluminescent. Fed upon by an undescribed species of nudibranch of the genus Armina.
taxon_text_5_5446: Feeding polyps use their tentacles, which are armed with stinging nematocysts, to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5447: Animals grow and develop new polyps by asexual reproduction. Details of sexual reproduction unknown for this family but in other seapens separate male and female individuals release gametes into the water column, the resulting embryos developing into planktonic planula larvae, which settle after about a week to establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5448: Unmistakable and the only species in the family. Other regional seapens have the polyps in branches arranged in a single plane, like a feather.
taxon_text_8_5449:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 40, text only).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46).

Williams, GC (1990). The Pennatulacea of southern Africa (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum/, 99(4), 31-119.
taxon_text_1_4840: Usually a distinctive bright purple in colour, although rarely paler pink, red or orange. Small colonies encrust rocks or other sedentary invertebrates, such as Redbait (Pyura spolonifera) in low shore pools or on shallow reefs. Colonies bear a cluster of fairly elongate and transparent polyps, each with 8 tentacles that have a line of small side branches along their margins.
taxon_text_2_4841: Colonies typically 30-50 mm across, polyps about 5 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_4842:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Richards Bay.
taxon_text_4_4843: Common in low shore rock pools and on shallow reefs, where the conspicuous colonies are easily spotted. Fed on by various nudibranchs, including the Purple softcoral lacedragon Marionia sp. which perfectly matches it in colour and the Frilled Nudibranch Leminda millecra, which is also purple in colour. The nudibranchs appear to acquire bioactive compounds from the octocoral, which probably protect them from predation.
taxon_text_5_4844: Uses the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4845: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the margins. Details of sexual reproduction unknown for this species, but related European species have separate male and female colonies and spawn one a year, the larvae taking 8-22 days to develop and settle to form new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4846: The typical purple colour is distinctive, but often found adjacent to the Variable soft-coral A. variabile, which can adopt a range of colours, including purple. However, A. variabile has a different colony form, resembling a mushroom with a short stalk and round head covered in polyps.
taxon_text_8_4847:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 38).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 44).

McPhail, KL, Davies-Coleman, MT & Starmer, J (2001). Sequestered Chemistry of the Arminacean Nudibranch Leminda millecra in Algoa Bay, South Africa. Journal of Natural Products, 64(9), 1183-1190.
taxon_text_1_4850: Colour extremely variable, as the name indicates, varying from yellow, pink, red or orange to purple or white. Often the polyps differ in colour from the main colony. Colony form resembles a small mushroom bud, with a short stalk and a rounded, unbranched head above. The head bears a cluster of fairly elongate and transparent polyps, each bearing 8 tentacles that have a line of small side branches along their margins.
taxon_text_2_4851: Colonies typically 50-70 mm tall, polyps about 5 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_4852:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4853: Usually the most common octocoral in low-shore rock pools and on shallow reefs, where attached to rocks, often among other encrusting invertebrates such as ascidians and bryozoans, or on kelp holdfasts. Depth range low intertidal to at least 450 m.
taxon_text_5_4854: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4855: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the margins. Details of sexual reproduction unknown for this species, but related European species have separate male and female colonies and spawn one a year, the larvae taking 8-22 days to develop and settle to form new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4856: The colony form is distinctive, but the highly variable colour may cause confusion. Yellow colonies could be mistaken for Sunburst soft-coral Malacacanthus capensis, but that species is typically much larger (150 mm tall) and has a longer, tough stalk topped by a ball-like head bearing many radiating polyps, each with a striped stalk.
taxon_text_8_4857:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 38).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46).

Williams, GC (1986). Morphology, systematics, and variability of the southern African soft coral, Alcyonium variabile (J. Stuart Thomson, 1921) (Octocorallia, Alcyoniidae). Annals of the South African Museum, 96(6), 241-270.
taxon_text_1_4860:
Large, upright, soft and floppy colony with a fairly transparent tapering central stalk that gives rise to tree-like branches, each ending in a bunch of polyps. Colour variable, but most often white or pale pink, polyps often grey and stems with pale opaque lines.

May be extended (as depicted) or contracted into a tight ball which resembles as cauliflower – hence the common name.
taxon_text_2_4861: Colonies typically 300 mm tall, polyps about 2 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_4862:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4863: Reef species found mostly on vertical rock walls in depths of 10 to over 200 m. Often contracted when the light is bright.
taxon_text_5_4864: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_7_4866: Several similar large branching soft-corals occur in the warmer waters off  the east coast, but this is the only such species found in the cool-temperate waters off the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_4867:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 44).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46 as Capnella thyrsoidea).

McFadden, CS & van Ofwegen, LP (2012). A revision of the soft coral genus, Eunephthya Verrill, 1869 (Anthozoa: Octocorallia: Nephtheidae), with a description of four new species from South Africa. Zootaxa, 3485, 1-25
taxon_text_1_4870:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This species is easily identified by its characteristic very long, whip-like, tapering branches. These are flattened towards the base, have few branches and are arranged more or less in a flat plane. Colour orange to red, appearing paler when the polyps are expanded.
taxon_text_2_4871: Colonies up to 700 mm tall, branches 3-5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_4872:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast of Cape Peninsula to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4873:
On rocky reefs in depth of about 10-30 m and usually orientated across the prevailing current. As with other larger seafans thought to be very slow-growing and large individuals may be many decades old.

These and other large seafans host a variety of smaller species, such as basket stars, spider and sponge crabs, brittle stars, gastropods, etc. Cat sharks also regularly attach their egg cases to the stems of large seafans. This species is also fed upon by the Whipfan lacedragon nudibranch Candiella (undescribed species) which perfectly matches it in colour.
taxon_text_5_4874: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4875: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4876: The long whip-like branches are distinctive, but a number of other large orange and red seafans occur in the region that have different shapes and branching patterns, for example E. tricoronata has sinuous branches and Leptogorgonia palma is profusely and repeatedly branched.
taxon_text_8_4877:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48).

Velimerov, B (1971). Beitrag zur Systematik der sudafrikanischen Gorgonarien. Zoologischer Anzeiger, 187(3/4), 266-273.

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 218).
taxon_text_1_4880:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This is a relatively small species that forms a loose fan of fairly slender branches, some of which project at irregular angles. The branches are cylindrical and covered with nipple-like protuberances, from each of which a polyp extends. Colour cream to orange.
taxon_text_2_4881: Colonies up to 180 mm tall, branches 2-4 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_4882:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Luderitz in Namibia to Sodwana Bay.
taxon_text_4_4883: Forms small colonies in areas relatively sheltered from wave action, such as sides of boulders, crevices and caves or reef overhangs. Depth range 1-360 m.
taxon_text_5_4884: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4885: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4886: The nipple-like projections on the branches and are distinctive, but several other small orange and red seafans occur in the region.
taxon_text_8_4887:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48 as E. papillosa).

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum. 101(8): 181-296. (p. 223 as E. papillosa).
taxon_text_1_4890:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This species is easily identified by its characteristic sinuous, slightly-flattened branches, all of which are arranged in a single plane to form a fan-like colony. Colour varies from mustard yellow to vivid orange. When the pale polyps are extended the branches take on a fuzzy appearance.
taxon_text_2_4891: Colonies up to 700 mm tall, branches about 10 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_4892:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about East London.
taxon_text_4_4893:
Fairly common on rocky reefs in depths of about 10-40 m. As with other larger sea fans thought to be slow-growing and large individuals may be many decades old.

These and other large sea fans host a variety of smaller species, such as basket stars, spider and sponge crabs, brittle stars, gastropods, etc. Cat sharks also regularly attach their egg cases to the stems of large sea fans.
taxon_text_5_4894: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4895: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4896: The sinuous branches and flat colony form are distinctive, but several other large orange and red seafans occur in the region.
taxon_text_8_4897:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48).

Velimerov, B (1971). Beitrag zur Systematik der sudafrikanischen Gorgonarien. Zoologischer Anzeiger, 187(3/4), 266-273.

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 228).
taxon_text_1_4900:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This species has a sparsely-branched form with just a few ‘twigs’ that are not arranged into a fan. The branches are densely covered on all sides by small polyps that tend to contrast in colour to the main stems and which usually emerge from distinct swellings (hence ‘warty’ common name). Common colours are yellow or white polyps on red stems, or white polyps on grey stems.
taxon_text_2_4901: Colonies typically 300-400 mm tall mm, branches 3-5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_4902:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana.
taxon_text_4_4903: On rocky reefs in depth of about 20-180 m, often on flat rocks subject to sand inundation. Uncommon and very little else know about the biology. Definitely occurs form Cape Agulhas eastwards but the records form False Bay are not supported by reference specimens.
taxon_text_5_4904: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4905: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4906: Could be confused with the common Multicoloured sea fan Melithaea rubra, which is also small with thin branches, has the polyps each emerging from a distinct bump on the stem and comes a wide range of colours. However, that species usually forms dense tangled clumps mixed with other sessile invertebrates, and not simple twig-like colonies.
taxon_text_8_4907:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48).

Velimerov, B (1971). Beitrag zur Systematik der sudafrikanischen Gorgonarien. Zoologischer Anzeiger, 187(3/4), 266-273.

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 189).
taxon_text_1_4910: Unusual octocoral with a flattened, ribbon-like, creeping stolon that adheres to the surfaces of rocks and branches irregularly, periodically giving rise to isolated (or small groups of) polyps. Polyps borne on short, slightly-opaque, cylindrical stalks, into which they can contract. Stolon yellowish and contains knobbly sclerites, which are clearly visible through the surface, but these are absent from polyps, which are clear and transparent.  Polyps each with 8 tentacles that are lined by small side-branches.
taxon_text_2_4911: Colonies reaching at least 50 mm in length, individual polyps 2-4 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_4912:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_4913: A recently described species, but quite common in its specialized habitat. Usually found on the underside of boulders. Nothing else is known about the biology of this species, which is currently documented only from a few records.
taxon_text_5_4914: Presumed to be predatory on small invertebrates that are stung by the nematocysts on the tentacles and transferred to the mouth.
taxon_text_6_4915: No details on this species, but generally in this group colonies expand asexually by budding new polyps. Sexual reproduction can involve mass spawning of sperm and eggs into the water or brooding, where sperm is released and fertilized eggs are retained and brooded by female polyps until larvae are fully formed, after which these are released.
taxon_text_7_4916: Several other octocorals occur in similar habitats, but the creeping habits and pale colour of this species are unusual and make it fairly easy to identify.
taxon_text_8_4917: McFadden, S & van Ofwegen, LP (2012). Stoloniferous octocorals (Anthozoa, Octocorallia) from South Africa, with descriptions of a new family of Alcyonacea, a new genus of Clavulariidae, and a new species of Cornularia (Cornulariidae). Invertebrate Systematics. 26: 331-356.
taxon_text_1_4920:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This is a large fan-shaped species that branches profusely, the main branches being flatter and the terminal ones cylindrical. Branches form a dense mat and may fuse where they cross. Colour may be white, pink, mauve, yellow, orange or red.
taxon_text_3_4922:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Sodwana Bay.
taxon_text_4_4923:
Fairly uncommon and found on deeper reefs from depth of 10-95 m depth. As with other larger sea fans probably very slow-growing and large individuals may be many decades, perhaps over a century, old.

These and other large sea fans host a variety of smaller species, such as basket stars, spider and sponge crabs, brittle stars, gastropods, etc. Cat sharks also regularly attach their egg cases to the stems.

Known to house a variety of bioactive compounds that may have pharmacological uses.
taxon_text_5_4924: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4925: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4926: The large size and repeatedly-branching, fan-like form are similar to the closely related L. flamea but that species has a sparcer more tree-like branching pattern and is always bright red.
taxon_text_8_4927:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Keyzers, RA, Gray, CA, Schleyer, MH, Whibley, CE, Hendricks, DT & Davies-Coleman, MT (2006). Malonganenones A–C, novel tetraprenylated alkaloids from the Mozambique gorgonian Leptogorgia gilchristi. Tetrahedron, 62(10), 2200-2206.

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 244).

Williams, GC & Lindo, KG (1997). A review of the octocorallian genus Leptogorgia (Anthozoa: Gorgoniidae) in the Indian Ocean and Subantarctic, with description of a new species and comparisons with related taxa. Proceedings of the California Academy of Sciences, 49, 499–521.
taxon_text_1_4930:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

One of the largest and most common seafans in the region and can form spectacular forests on deeper reefs. Easily identified by its thick, flattened and often spreading trunk and repeatedly branching, tree-like form, all the branches being arranged to be fan-like in a single plane. Colour cherry-red. The pale polyps can be retracted into slits in the colony, but when extended give the branches a paler, fuzzy appearance.
taxon_text_2_4931: Colonies up to 2 m tall, branches about 10 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_4932:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast of Cape Peninsula to Sodwana bay.
taxon_text_4_4933:
Common on rocky reefs in depth of about 10-100 m, sometimes in extensive groups that have an almost forest like appearance. As with other larger sea fans thought to be very slow-growing and large individuals may be many decades, perhaps over a century, old.

These and other large sea fans host a variety of smaller species, such as basket stars, spider and sponge crabs, brittle stars, gastropods, etc. Cat sharks also regularly attach their egg cases to the stems.
taxon_text_5_4934: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4935: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4936: The large size and repeatedly-branching, fan-like form are fairly characteristic, but can be confused with various other large red sea fans, especially Eunicella tricoronata, which has wavy, sinuous branches and  Eunicella albicans, which has an elongate and sparsely branched colony form.
taxon_text_8_4937:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48).

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 239).

Williams, GC & Lindo, KG (1997). A review of the octocorallian genus Leptogorgia (Anthozoa: Gorgoniidae) in the Indian Ocean and Subantarctic, with description of a new species and comparisons with related taxa. Proceedings of the California Academy of Sciences, 49, 499–521.
taxon_text_1_4950:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This relatively small species forms dense, bushy colonies with thin cylindrical stems that branch in all directions (not forming a fan). It often grows in tangled clumps among other encrusting organisms, such as bryozoans, tube worms and tunicates. Stems bear knobs from which polyps emerge.

Colour very variable, with polyps often contrasting with stems. Stems red, yellow, white of pink and polyps white, yellow or red.
taxon_text_2_4951: Colonies up to about 200 mm tall, branches about 2-4 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_4952:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_4953: Common on vertical faces and under overhangs or beneath boulders in low shore pools and to a depth of about 150 m. Commonly fed upon by the Coral nudibranch Phyllodesmium horridum, which can denude whole areas of colony of their polyps.
taxon_text_5_4954: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4955: Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4956: The low, bushy, colony form and thin knobbly stems are fairly characteristic.
taxon_text_8_4957:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48 as Acabaria rubra).

Reijnen, BT, McFadden, CS, Hermanlimianto, YT & van Ofwegen, LP (2014). A molecular and morphological exploration of the generic boundaries in the family Melithaeidae (Coelenterata: Octocorallia) and its taxonomic consequences. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, 70, 383-401.

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 197 as Acabaria rubra).
taxon_text_1_4960: Bushy soft-coral with a stout, leathery trunk giving rise to a clump of thick, stubby branches, which then rebranch but can be almost globular when contracted. Polyps white, but usually fully contracted during the day, so that only the stout branches are visible. Colour most commonly pink to red, but can be pale.
taxon_text_2_4961: Colonies typically about 100 mm across and 110 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_4962:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4963: Found on rocky reefs from about 14-30 m depth. Nocturnal and the white polyps are normally retracted when observed during the day, so that only the stubby branches are visible.
taxon_text_5_4964: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4965: Colonies grow by budding new polyps from the margins. Details of sexual reproduction unknown for this species, but related European species have separate male and female colonies and release larvae that develop in the water column and settle to form new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4966: The short, stubby, branching colony form is fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_4967:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 40).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 44 as Alcyonidium valdiviae).

McFadden, CS & van Ofwegen, LP (2013). Molecular phylogenetic evidence supports a new family of octocorals and a new genus of Alcyoniidae (Octocorallia, Alcyonacea). ZooKeys, 346, 59-83.
taxon_text_1_4970: A rigid central stem (or rachis) projects vertically from soft sediments and is covered by a retractable sleeve-like body bearing a basal bulbous ‘root’ and regular lateral branches, each armed with rows of polyps. The whole organism thus resembles the flight feather of a bird.   Colour plain white.
taxon_text_2_4971: Colonies up to 500 mm tall (including buried section), side branches about 10 mm long.
taxon_text_3_4972:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_4973: Can be common in sheltered sediments, where forests of seapens can cover extensive areas. The soft parts of the body can retract back into the sediments and then extend again when conditions are favourable. The individual polyps are specialized for different functions including pumping of water into the colony to inflate it, feeding and reproduction. A single large polyp is responsible for developing the rigid, erect stalk and forms a bulbous ‘root’ at the base that helps anchor the colony.
taxon_text_5_4974: Feeding polyps use their tentacles, which are armed with stinging nematocysts, to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4975: Animals grow and develop new polyps by asexual reproduction. In sexual reproduction separate male and female individuals release gametes into the water column, the resulting embryos developing into planktonic planula larvae, which settle after about a week to establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4976: The only common sea pen with this feather-like body form in the Western Cape. The only other species regularly seen in this region is the radial sea-pen Actinoptilum molle, but that species formed a sausage-shaped colony surrounded by a complete rings of polyps, and is usually mauve or purple.
taxon_text_8_4977:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 40).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46).

Williams, GC (1990). The Pennatulacea of southern Africa (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 99(4), 31-119.
taxon_text_1_4980:
Colony consists of a knobbly red sheet found only on the shells of the whelks Burnupena papyracea and B. pubescens, which are entirely enveloped by the bryozoan.

When viewed closely, each bump has larger male zooids with taller lophophores and elongate tentacles, while the areas between the bumps are colonized by smaller female zooids with shorter tentacles.
taxon_text_2_4981: Individual zooids about 1 mm long, colonies typically 5 cm across.
taxon_text_3_4982:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa (report from Chile on WoRMS is unlikely to be same species).

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4983:
Found exclusively on the shells of whelks of the genus Burnupena, specifically B. papyracea on the west coast and B. pubescens, which extends to the Eastern Cape. It has been shown that the bryozoan provides the whelks with protection from predators, such as rock-lobsters, and hence allows them to survive in areas where lobster predation is intense. The bryozoan probably benefit from the association by being transported to good feeding areas and avoiding sedimentation.

The gaudily-coloured amphipods Ochlesis lenticulosus and Iphimedia gibba gather in large numbers to feed on this bryozoan and it appears highly likely they gain chemical protection by ingesting the toxins within it, advertising this acquired toxicity with their bright warning colouration.
taxon_text_5_4984: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_4985: Hermaphrodite with separate male and female zooids. Colonies expand by budding new zooids around the margins. During sexual reproduction males release sperm into the water, which are taken in by females to fertilise the eggs, which are then released to disperse to find new hosts and establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4986: Easily identified by the red colour and nodular structure, but also by its unique obligate association with whelks of the genus Burnupena.
taxon_text_8_4987:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 8).

Gray, CA, McQuaid, CD & Davies-Coleman, MT (2005). A symbiotic shell-encrusting bryozoan provides subtidal whelks with chemical defence against rock lobsters. African Journal of Marine Science, 27(3), 549-556.

Ryland, J (2001). Convergent colonial organization and reproductive function in two bryozoan species epizoic on gastropod shells. Journal of Natural History, 35, 1085-1101.
taxon_text_1_4990:
Colony consists of soft, rubbery, often pleated yellow to orange lobes, the margins of each lobe being lighter in colour. The lobes form a scrolled wall living on hard substrata.

When viewed closely, the individual zooids, which are found on both sides of the lobes, are diamond-shaped with a smooth gelatinous surface and a small oval aperture that is often raised on a short papilla, giving the colony a rough appearance.
taxon_text_2_4991: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies up to 15 cm across.
taxon_text_3_4992:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4993:
One of several species that form yellow to orange pleated colonies, but unusual in that the colonies are soft and rubbery, rather than being hard and calcified. Usually found on rocky reefs among other encrusting invertebrates, but also extends as deep at 400 m.

Very little other species-specific information available and it is not known whether this species harbours the same protective chemicals recorded in the related Nodular bryozoan A. nodosum.
taxon_text_5_4994: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_4995: Colonies expand by budding new zooids around the margins.  New colonies formed by sexual reproduction, fertilized eggs being released into the water column to disperse and establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4996: The rubbery, soft texture is characteristic. There are several other species (such as Chaperia spp. and Laminopora jellyae) that form pleated orange colonies, but these are strongly calcified, brittle and coral – like in texture.
taxon_text_8_4997:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 8).

Florence, W (2018). Phylum Bryozoa In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Ofshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 227-243. (p. 230).
taxon_text_1_5000:
Colony consists of numerous, thin creeping stems (‘stolons’) forming tangled masses firmly attached to the substratum. The individual zooecia are erect, elongate and flask-shaped and attached to the stolon at intervals in pairs or clumps. Lophophores have only 8 tentacles. Colour transparent to pale yellow or brown when alive. 

Common, but inconspicuous and thus easily overlooked, also often confused as being a hydroid.
taxon_text_2_5001: Individual zooecia about 1 mm tall, colonies may spread 10 cm or more across.
taxon_text_3_5002:
Global: Widespread across both North and South Atlantic Ocean, Pacific coast of Chile, New Zealand. May be introduced in habitats outside North Atlantic.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_5003: Fouling species common creeping across the undersides of boulders in the intertidal and shallow subtidal. Also on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours.
taxon_text_5_5004: All bryozoans are filter feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5005: Hermaphrodite. Single ova are brooded in the vacated tentacle sheaths of feeding zooids, after degeneration of the lophophore. Egg development takes 13-14 days and then the egg is released into the water column. Fertilisation takes place on release and the larvae have a brief planktonic life before settling to found a new colony. Colonies expand by extending the stems and budding new zooecia at their tips.
taxon_text_7_5006: Few South African bryozoans have creeping stolons that are attached to the substratum, making this species fairly easy to identify. It is often misidentified as a hydroid though.
taxon_text_8_5007: Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 10).
taxon_text_1_5010:
Colony a flat sheet suspended a millimeter of two above the substratum, to which it is loosely attached by chitinous filaments. The sheet is composed of a single layer of zooecia that are linked to one another by a network of tubes, giving the colony the appearance of a mesh.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are about 1 mm long and elongate-oval in shape, with a semicircular opening occupying one end and a pair of small avicularia at the anterior end of each. There are no other knobs or spines. Six tubes emerging from each zooecium link it to adjacent individuals to form a perforated mesh.
taxon_text_2_5011: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5-10 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5012:
Global: Widespread across the Southern Hemisphere, including South America, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand and various oceanic islands; also Japan. European specimens have recently been described a separate species, indicating that this may be a species complex with several separate regional species.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about East London.
taxon_text_4_5013: Fairly common on the surfaces of other encrusting invertebrates and on the undersides of boulders, or on ships hulls, but fragments easily and often broken and lost during sampling. The tubes connecting zooecia allow them to share resources.
taxon_text_5_5014: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5015: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margin. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction. Embryos are brooded inside reproductive individuals and then released to have a short planktonic life before settling to found new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5016: Two other species, Beania vanhoefferi and B. minuspina are found on the Cape Peninsula but are easily distinguished from this species as the zooecia of both have obvious spines along their margins.
taxon_text_8_5017:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 127).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 20).

Souto, J, Nascimento, KB, Reverter-Gil, O & Vieira, LM (2019). Dismantling the Beania magellanica (Busk, 1852) species complex (Bryozoa, Cheilostomata): two new species from European waters. Marine Biodiversity, 49(3), 1505-1518.
taxon_text_1_5020:
Colony a flat sheet suspended a millimeter of two above the substratum, to which it is loosely attached by chitinous filaments. The sheet is composed of a single layer of zooecia that are linked to one another by a network of tubes, giving the colony the appearance of a mesh.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are about 1 mm long and elongate-oval in shape. The sides of each are armed with an obvious palisade of about 7-10 sharp, inwardly-pointing spines. Six tubes emerging from each zooecium link it to adjacent individuals to form a perforated mesh. There are no avicularia.
taxon_text_2_5021: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5022:
Global: South Africa and Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Known only from Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_5023: Fairly common on the surfaces of other encrusting invertebrates and on the undersides of boulders, or on ships hulls, but fragments easily and often broken and lost during sampling. The tubes connecting the zooecia allow them to share resources.
taxon_text_5_5024: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5025: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margin. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction. Embryos are brooded inside reproductive individuals and then released to have a short planktonic life before settling to found new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5026: Beania minuspina is similar in colony form but has only about 5 much longer marginal spines that meet across the face of each zooecium. It is found only on the Cape Peninsula on red algae. Beania magellanica has a similar colony form but no spines.
taxon_text_8_5027:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 127).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 20).

Souto, J, Nascimento, KB, Reverter-Gil, O & Vieira, LM (2019). Dismantling the Beania magellanica (Busk, 1852) species complex (Bryozoa, Cheilostomata): two new species from European waters. Marine Biodiversity, 49(3), 1505-1518.
taxon_text_9_5029: Previously incorrectly called Bicellariella ciliata, which is a valid species, but is restricted to the North Atlantic. The local form was only recently recognised and described as a new, endemic species.
taxon_text_1_5030:
Colony white to pale pinkish and bushy, resembles a miniature willow tree with a naked branching ‘trunk’ giving rise to drooping ‘branches’ each made up of a double row of flaring zooecia.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia, which are less than 1 mm long, are oval and arranged alternately on either side of each branch. Each zooecium is elongate-oval with a large tear-drop shaped aperture and ends in 4-7 very long, curved, eye-lash-like spines. There is a single bird’s head avicularium at the base of each zooecium.
taxon_text_2_5031: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 6- 10 cm or more tall.
taxon_text_3_5032:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert‘s Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_5033: Fairly common on rocky substrata, especially under overhangs, on vertical faces and in caves to a depth of about 10 m. Little else know about biology.
