taxon_text_5_5034: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5035: The colony is hermaphrodite, but individual zooids are male or female. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction.
taxon_text_7_5036: There a several other species with similar bushy, branching colony forms. The Spiral moss-animal Menipea triseriata occurs in the same locations, but its branches are spirally arranged and not curved downwards at their tips, and the zooecia also lack long spines. Menipea crispa is shorter with no trunk below the branches and has the branches curved downwards, each zooecium having only 2 long spines at its tip.
taxon_text_8_5037:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 127 as B. ciliata).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 21).
taxon_text_1_5040:
Colony consists of a loose, branching tuft of reddish-brown stalks, each consisting of an alternating chain of zooecia. Easily mistaken for a red seaweed.

When examined closely, each branch consists of a double row of elongate zooecia, arranged in an overlapping chain. The outer corners of the zooecia have sharp corners, but lack terminal spines (unlike the similar Viridentula dentata). The ovicells (reproductive cells) are oval and pearly and the colony lacks beak-like avicularia. When extended, the lophophores are white and have 23-24 tentacles.
taxon_text_2_5041: Individual zooecia about 0.5 mm long, colonies typically 5 but up to 10 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5042:
Global: Cosmopolitan except in polar seas. Currently though to be of European origin and to have been distributed around the world by shipping, but recent research suggest this may be a complex of at least 3 regional species, although these can currently only be distinguished by molecular methods.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban, especially in harbours.
taxon_text_4_5043:
Common introduced fouling species, found on the walls of gullies and other vertical surfaces, as well as on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours. Often grows on the surfaces of large algae or on other bryozoans.

Well-known as a source of a group of bioactive chemical compounds called bryostatins, which have potential for the treatment of cancer, Alzheimer’s Disease and HIV/AIDS. These now appear in fact to be produced by a symbiotic bacteria Candidatus endobugula, rather than by the bryozoan itself.
taxon_text_5_5044: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5045: Zooids are hermaphrodite, first being female and later male. Sperm liberated by males are drawn into female zooids, where they fertilise the eggs. The eggs are brooded and at this stage the zooids develop a rounded cap and are known as ovicells. Once liberated, the larvae have a short larval life before settling to establish new colonies. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips of the branches.
taxon_text_7_5046: The distinctive colour and absence of protective avicularia can be used to separate this from related species. The Blue dentate moss-animal Viridentula dentata is blue and Bugulina colonies are orange or straw coloured and both bear avicularia.
taxon_text_8_5047:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Davidson, SK, Allen, SW, Lim, GE, Anderson, CM & Haygood, M (2001). Evidence for the biosynthesis of bryostatins by the bacterial symbiont “Candidatus endobugula sertula” of the bryozoan Bugula neritina. Applied and Environmental Microbiology, 67(10), 4531-4537.

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 18).

Picker, M & Griffiths, C (2011). Alien and Invasive Animals – a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 201).
taxon_text_1_5050:
Bushy, dichotomously branching, upright colony, speckled yellow to orange, the squared tips of each branch curving slightly inwards. Easily mistaken for a seaweed.

When examined closely, each branch consists of 3-5 parallel rows of elongate, rectangular zooecia arranged in an overlapping manner (not in rows). The zooecia have sharp corners armed with 2-3 small spines. Special smaller protective individuals (avicularia), shaped like birds’ heads, are present along the margins of each branch and numerous globular reproductive individuals (ovicells) are present.
taxon_text_2_5051: Individual zooids about 0.5 mm long, colonies typically 3-5 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5052:
Global: Native to the north-east Atlantic and Mediterranean regions, but widely introduced elsewhere, such as in Brazil, South Africa, Mauritius and Australia.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_5053:
Common introduced fouling species found on the walls of gullies and other vertical surfaces, as well as on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours and similar habitats, down to a depth of 100 m. Often grow on the surfaces of other organisms, including other bryozoans. The birds’ head aviculae serve much like the pedicellaria of echinoderms and keep the colony free of fouling organisms.

Fast growing and a well-known fouling species on ship’s hulls.
taxon_text_5_5054: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5055: Zooids are hermaphrodite, first being female and later male. Sperm liberated by males are drawn into female zooids, where they fertilise the eggs. The eggs are brooded and at this stage the zooids develop a rounded cap and are known as ovicells. Once liberated the larvae have a short larval life before settling to establish new colonies. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips of the branches.
taxon_text_7_5056: Similar to Bugula neritina and Virididentula dentata which both also form bushy, branching colonies, but these differ in colour (purple and blue respectively) and also have only 2 rows of zooecia along each branch, not 3-5.
taxon_text_8_5057:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 17 as Bugula flabellina).
taxon_text_1_5060:
Colony consists of a thick, rounded, purple, calcareous crust bearing rounded bumps on its surface and with a fuzzy appearance (caused by the spines on the surface). Could be confused with a coral, hence the common name.

When viewed closely, the rectangular zooecia are not clearly distinct from one another and each has a large, rounded aperture flanked by a pair of strong spikes and with a triangular anterior projection or ‘rostrum’.
taxon_text_2_5061: Individual zooecia less than1 mm long, colonies typically 2-5 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5062:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_5063: Fairly common in rock pools, under boulders and on kelp holdfasts, usually as a single, isolated colony. No other details available.
taxon_text_5_5064: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5065: No species-specific details known. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins. Also undertake sexual reproduction, but specific details not available.
taxon_text_7_5066:
The purple colour and spiky appearance are fairly reliable identification characters, but several other hard, coral-like species occur in the same habitats, such as the yellowish Gephyrophora polymorpha and the more upright and finger-like orange Turbicellepora cylindriformis.

Note also the confusingly similarly name of the only distantly-related Celleporella hyalina.
taxon_text_8_5067:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 129).
taxon_text_1_5070:
Colony consists of a small flat, rounded, glassy patch lacking surface spines. Colour white to pale yellowish.

When examined microscopically the feeding zooecia are flat, transparent and elongate with parallel striations near the wide, rounded, aperture, which has a rectangular notch on its proximal side. The surface of the zooecia have transverse ridges resembling growth rings. Female zooecia are very short with an aperture that is much wider than long and bear large globular ovicells that each have 9-11 dorsal pores.
taxon_text_2_5071: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 3 cm across. but can reach 10 cm.
taxon_text_3_5072:
Global: Widely distibuted in cooler waters, including Europe, Pacific coast of North and South America, Atlanic coast of Canada and USA. Also Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, where it is likely introduced.

As currently described this is a species complex incorporating an unknown number of genetically distinct forms.

Local/Regional: West coast to Durban.
taxon_text_4_5073: Most commonly found on the primary blades of Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima and Split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida, where it is very common. Also reported from stems of hydroids and on other bryozoans.
taxon_text_5_5074: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5075: Colonies expand by budding new zooids along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites.
taxon_text_7_5076:
The glassy appearance and shapes of zooecia are characteristic, and the habitat (on kelps) is also a useful guide to identification.

There are several other flat, white species common on the blades of algae though – these include Jellyella tuberculata, which has hexagonal zooids with tubercles at their anterior corners, Membranipora rustica, which has rectangular zooids and Electra pilosa, in which zooids are arranged in rows and which bear long spines.

Note also the confusingly similar name of the only distantly-related Celleporaria capensis.
taxon_text_8_5077:
Boonzaaier-Davids, MK, Ma, KC & Mcquaid, CD (2023). Epibiotic association of encrusting cheilostome bryozoans on shells of an invasive mussel from rocky shores of South Africa, with the description of a new aviculiferous species of Chaperia. Zootaxa, 5258(2), 197-210.

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 29).

Hoare, K, Goldson, AJ, Giannasi, N & Hughes, RN (2001). Molecular phylogeography of the cosmopolitan bryozoan Celleporella hyalina: cryptic speciation? Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, 18(3), 488-492.
taxon_text_1_5482:
Colony consists of a series of hard, solid, upright, calcified and brittle interconnected plates that are coloured maroon to purple.

When viewed closely the individual zooecia are hexagonal with a large oval aperture and are strongly ornamented with a pair of large stalked avicularia, a pair of anterior spines and a characteristic large, antler-like structure that grows over and hides much of the surface of the zooid and give the colony its furry appearance.
taxon_text_2_5483: Individual zooecia less then 1 mm long, colonies up to 15 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5484:
Global: South Africa and St Helena Island. Records from New Zealand have bifurcating spines at distal end of zooecia and represent a distinct species.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_5485: Found on rocky substrata in gullies and the sides of deep rock pools and on reefs to a depth of about 375 m. Often mingles with other sedentary invertebrates, such as sponges, other bryozoans and soft corals. Very little other species-specific information available.
taxon_text_5_5486: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5487: Colonies expand by budding new zooids around the margins.  New colonies formed by sexual reproduction, fertilized eggs being released into the water column to disperse and establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5488: Chaperia species form similar brittle, calcified and folded colonies, but these are orange to red and lack the large antler-like projections found in Chaperiopsis.
taxon_text_8_5489:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 14).

Florence, W (2018). Phylum Bryozoa In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Ofshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 227-243. (p. 241).
taxon_text_1_5080:
Colony a flat, cream, elongate sheet growing on and around the fronds of various algae. On narrow-bladed algae, such as Strap caulerpa (Caulerpa filiformis) often completely enclose the algal frond. Colonies formed of regularly-arranged, transverse rows of zooids, and appears ‘hairy’.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are about 1 mm long and elongate with a narrow base from which they expand distally. Surfaces of zooecia perforated by round pores. The dark opening is flanked by one very long, tapering spine and four short spines. The long hair-like spines may be broken off in wave-exposed colonies.
taxon_text_2_5081: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5-10 cm long.
taxon_text_3_5082:
Global: Endemic to Europe, but also found in South Africa and in Australia and New Zealand (where considered introduced). It is debatable whether the South Africa form is native, introduced, or represents an undescribed species.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban, but mostly on west coast.
taxon_text_4_5083: Commonly on the blades of various algae, sometimes completely covering and obscuring the blades of narrow-bladed species. Specimens on different substrata vary considerably in form and this complicates both identification and global taxonomy of the species.
taxon_text_5_5084: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5085: The colony is hermaphrodite, but individual zooids male or female. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margin. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction, with males liberating sperm into the water which is gathered by females to internally fertilise their up to 30 eggs, which they then release into the plankton. In Europe larvae are present year-round, suggesting a long larval duration. Larvae use olfactory cues to find suitable substrata and settle mostly in summer to found new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5086: Easily confused with the Membranous lace animal Jellyella tuberculata which forms similar rounded, white colonies on algae, but mostly on the red alga Epymenia obtusa. The structure and arrangement of the zooecia also differs, those of J. tuberculata being hexagonal, arranges in concentric circles and lacking elongated spines. Could also be confused with Rustic lace animal Membranipora rustica, but that only occurs on kelps, has elongate, rectangular zooecia in alternating rows (like a brick wall) and lacks spines.
taxon_text_8_5087:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 127).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 11).
taxon_text_1_5090:
Colony consists of a thin, flat, pale white-to-grey, more-or-less circular encrustation composed of radiating rows of zooecia.

When examined closely the individual zooecia have flat, irregularly-arranged, oval cases. The distal openings to these are wide and oval with a raised edge and the convex surface is punctured by large, conspicuous pores.
taxon_text_2_5091: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically 2-5 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5092:
Global: Probably endemic to South Africa (reports from Australia on WoRMS probably another species).

Local/Regional: Cape Town to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5093: Common on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal and shallow subtidal and on mussel shells to a depth of 20 m.
taxon_text_5_5094: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5095: Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins. New colonies are established by sexual reproduction. Fertilized eggs are released into the water column, where they undertake a short larval life before finding a suitable habitat and metamorphosing into the adult form.
taxon_text_7_5096: One of several pale, encrusting species found on the undersides of boulders, such as Steginoporella buskii, but has much more distinctive, larger pores on zooids. Definitive identification requires microscopic examination of zooecia ornamentation.
taxon_text_8_5097:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK (2016). Some deep-water cheilostome Bryozoa from the south coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 12, 5-11.

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 35).
taxon_text_1_5100:
As the scientific name suggests colonies can be very variable in morphology, but are hard, calcareous and light-pink to dull -orange in colour. Sections of the colony often take the form of flat undulating sheets, but other sections grow upwards into blunt, projecting and branching finger-like lobes. They are usually securely attached to hard substrata, usually the undersides of rocks or vertical rock faces, but can also overgrow other sedentary invertebrates.

When viewed closely the zooecia are distinctive and are elongate rectangular and dotted with conspicuous round pores. The small round apertures are each guarded by a pair of tiny aviculae which form an arch over the opening.
taxon_text_2_5101: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 3-6 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5102:
Global: Endemic to South Africa (although fossils under this name reported from New Zealand).

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Cape Infanta.
taxon_text_4_5103: Few details available. Fairly commonly found in low shore pools and down to 600 m depth.
taxon_text_5_5104: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5105: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites.
taxon_text_7_5106: The form of the zooecia is diagnostic, but in the field easily confused with the Cylindrical false coral Tubicellopora cylindriformes, which forms similar hard, upright, finger-like processes and is often present under the same rocks. That species is salmon – pink in colour though and has quite different cylindrical, projecting zooecia with large, round apertures.
taxon_text_8_5107:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 129, as Gigantopora polymorpha).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 41).
taxon_text_1_5110:
Colony consists of a flat, white, lacelike sheet growing on flat-bladed algae, especially the red alga Rhodymenia obtusa.

Examined closely the individual zooecia are hexagonal, with a pair of rounded tubercles on each of the distal corners. Zooids with 15 transparent white tentacles.
taxon_text_2_5111: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 10 cm long.
taxon_text_3_5112:
Global: Widely distributed across subtropical and temperate seas including north and south Atlantic and Indo-Pacific. Probably a species complex with unresolved different species in different regions.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast only.
taxon_text_4_5113: Commonly found on the blades of red algae, especially Rhodymenia obtusa. Also occur on drift algae in the open ocean and may be distributed that way. Few other details available.
taxon_text_5_5114: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5115: Hermaphrodite. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites but details unknown.
taxon_text_7_5116: Easily confused with the Rustic lace animal Membranipora rustica, which also forms flat white growths on large, flat-bladed algae. The zooecia of that species are elongate and rectangular though and lack tubercles on the corners. The Hairy lace animal, Electra pilosa, also makes white sheets on algae, but zooecia are elongate triangular with one long and four short spines along margin of orifice.
taxon_text_8_5117:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 129).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 10).

Taylor, PD & Monks, N (1997). A new cheilostome bryozoan genus pseudoplanktonic on molluscs and algae. Invertebrate biology, 39-51.
taxon_text_9_5119: Previously mis-identified as M. triplex, which is a valid species, but occurs in Australia and not in Africa.
taxon_text_1_5120:
Colony consists of a short, branched bush with fairly thick, tapering, bright orange to pinkish stems, resembling a jointed cactus.

When examined closely, the zooecia are urn-shaped and arranged in alternating rows of 4 around the stem. The surface of each is ornamented with a network of fine ridges and the apertures are extended and spout-like.
taxon_text_2_5121: Individual zooecia about 1 mm long, colonies typically 3 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5122:
Global: According to WoRMS widespread across the Indo-Pacific, but given as endemic by Florence et al.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5123: Found on shallow reefs in protected waters from the low intertidal to about 20 m depth. Often growing among other fouling species such as algae, soft corals and hydroids. Few other details available.
taxon_text_5_5124: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5125: Hermaphrodite. Sperm are liberated into the water by male zooids and drawn into other female zooids, where they fertilise the eggs. The larvae are then liberated for a short larval life before settling to establish new colonies. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia at their ends.
taxon_text_7_5126: The colony form is very distinctive so unlikely to be confused with other bryozoan species. In the field can be confused as being a seafan.
taxon_text_8_5127:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 41).
taxon_text_9_5129: Previously misidentified as Membranipora membranacea, which remains a valid, but European, species.
taxon_text_1_5130:
Colony consists of a flat, white, rounded, lacelike sheet growing on the fronds of kelps, especially the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are about 1 mm long, rectangular and arranges in off-set rows (like bricks in a wall). Each zooecium has a tiny knob in each corner and fine denticles along the inner surface of the wall. Lophophore white, with about 20 tentacles.
taxon_text_2_5131: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5-10 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5132:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban, but mostly on west coast.
taxon_text_4_5133: Commonly found on the blade of kelps, mostly the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima. The rounded colonies are most abundant on kelps that are growing in sheltered waters and towards the older, distal portions of the fronds. The zooecia are fed upon by the flattened, round Crazed nudibranch Corambe sp., which is also covered with a lacelike pattern that perfectly matches the bryozoan.
taxon_text_5_5134: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5135: Hermaphrodite. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites, but details unknown.
taxon_text_7_5136: Easily confused with the Membranous lace bryozoan Jellyella tuberculata which forms similar rounded, white colonies, but mostly on the red alga Epymenia obtusa. The shape of the zooecia also differs, those of J. tuberculata being hexagonal, not rectangular. The Hairy lace bryozoan Electra pilosa also makes white sheets on algae, but its zooecia are elongate triangular and have one long and four short spines along the distal margin.
taxon_text_8_5137:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 11).
taxon_text_1_5140:
Colony straw-coloured to brown and forming a short, upright bush with flat branches that bifurcate regularly and are curled over strongly inwards towards their tips. The zooids show up as rows of dark dots along the branches.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are less than 1 mm long, oval and arranged 2-3 abreast. The aperture is large and oval, taking up about 70% of surface and there are two elongate, curved spines at the distal end of each zooecium (often broken off) and a tubular avicularium at the base of each, also occasional larger hooked avicularia along the sides of branches.
taxon_text_2_5141: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 4 but up to 10 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5142:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5143: One of the most common bryozoans found on rocky substrata, especially under rocks in intertidal pools and in gullies and overhands to a depth of 100 m. Little else known about biology.
taxon_text_5_5144: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5145: The colony is hermaphroditic, but individual zooids male or female. Colonies expand by budding new zooids at the tips. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction.
taxon_text_7_5146:
There a several other species with similar bushy, branching colony shape. The Spiral bush bryozoan Menipea triseriata is particularly similar and occurs in the same locations, but its branches are spirally arranged and not curved downwards at their tips, while the zooecia also lack long spines.

The Bonsai bush bryozoan Bicellariella bonsai is taller and has drooping branches (like a bonsai willow bush), but the zooecia occur in pairs and project out laterally from the branches and have three, not two, long curved spines extending from their distal tips.
taxon_text_8_5147:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 128).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 21).

Florence, W (2018). Phylum Bryozoa In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds). Field Guide to the Ofshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 227-243. (p. 235).
taxon_text_1_5150:
Colony upright and bushy with flat branches that bifurcate regularly and are usually arranged in a distinct spiral pattern. Colour light yellow to orange, with zooids showing up as dark spots within the zooecia.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are less than 1 mm long, elongate-rectangular and arranged usually 3 abreast (2 at tips). Each individual has a very large, oval opening about 70% of total length and four tiny short stubby teeth near the orifice. Some lateral zooecia have a single minute avicularium on the outer distal corner and another frontal one at the basal end. Others have a pair of tiny frontal avicularia. (The long, curved distal spines present in several related species are absent).
taxon_text_2_5151: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 4 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5152:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_5153: Found on rocky substrata, especially in shaded areas, often among sponges and other bryozoans. Depth range intertidal to 100 m. Fed on by the Cape silvertip nudibranch Antiopella capensis.
taxon_text_5_5154: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5155: The colony is hermaphrodite, but individual zooids male or female. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction.
taxon_text_7_5156: The spiral branching pattern is fairly diagnostic, but there are a number of other common species that form similar yellow to orange branching bushes. Microscopic examination of the zooecia is needed to distinguish these with certainty. The Curled bush bryozoan Menipea crispa has incurving branches and the Bonsai bush bryozoan Bicellariella bonsai drooping ones (like a bonsai willow bush), but both species have long, curved spines extending from the distal tips of each zooecium. The Fan-shaped bryozoan Bugulina flabellata lack these spines, but has 3-5 rows of zooecia along each branch and bears prominent rounded reproductive bodies (ovicells).
taxon_text_8_5157:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 128).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 21).
taxon_text_1_5160:
Very distinctive coral-like colonies with a delicate, dichotomously-branching, calcareous, white skeleton with lobed tips.

When viewed closely the branches are formed of elongate tubular zooecia which curve away from the main branch at their tips to end in a round orifice from which the tentacles of the zooids emerge when extended.
taxon_text_2_5161: Individual zooecia less then 1 mm long, colonies typically 2 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5162:
Global: Widespread across Indo-Pacific from South Africa to Australia.

Local/Regional: Local records from False Bay to Mossel Bay, but as also occurs in East Africa, probably actually extends all along east coast.
taxon_text_4_5163: Found on the undersides of rocks on rocky shores in sheltered sites. Uncommon and no details about biology available.
taxon_text_5_5164: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5165: No species-specific details, but bryozoans are hermaphrodite with separate male and female zooids. Colonies expand by budding new zooids around the tips. During sexual reproduction males release sperm into the water which are taken in by females to fertilise the eggs, which are then released to disperse to find new hosts and establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5166: Easily identified by exquisite, delicately-branched colony form. Colony form is quite variable and more than one species may be present under this one name.
taxon_text_8_5167:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 131 as Tubulipora pulcherrima).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 7).
taxon_text_1_5170:
Colony a bush of flexible, flat, irregularly-branching fronds that can easily be mistaken for a seaweed. Colour cream to pale green or blue with dark spots marking zooids.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are elongate hexagonal and are arranged in a flat sheet, like tiles on a paved floor. Each zooecium has a large semicircular opening with two tiny spines on each corner of the opening. The front surface is pierced by a central pore (the ‘ascopore’) and 2-4 much smaller holes. Globular ovicells may also be present on some zooecia.
taxon_text_2_5171: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 3 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5172:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_5173: Commonly attached to other bryozoans, or on various algae on rock reefs from about 4-400 m depth. Also rarely in low shore pools and crevices.
taxon_text_5_5174: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5175: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margin. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction. Species specific details not available
taxon_text_7_5176: Unlikely to be confused with other regional species, due to the unusual lightly calcified colony form with its branching blades. The Rubbery bryozoan Alcyonidium rhomboides also has a rubbery texture and hexagonal zooecia, but forms wide convoluted scroll-like orange lobes.
taxon_text_8_5177:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 44).

Florence, W (2018). Phylum Bryozoa In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds). Field Guide to the Ofshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 227-243. (p. 237).
taxon_text_1_5180:
Colony consists of a series of hard, calcified, brittle, interconnected plates punctured by more-or-less regularly-spaced holes, giving the delicate, lacy appearance referred to in the common name. Colour pink to orange.

When viewed closely the individual zooecia are more or less diamond-shaped and irregularly arranged. Young zooecia (towards the tips of branches) bear four long spines, two on either side of the small, round aperture, but in older individuals these are lost (or only two remain). The surfaces of older individuals are also punctured by pores. The colony bears scattered large avicularia that resemble tiny barnacles, and prominent spherical bright red ovicells may be present.
taxon_text_2_5181: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies up to 15 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5182:
Global: South Africa and nominally Australia (but these may represent a distinct species as there are morphological differences).

Local/Regional: Namibian border to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_5183: Found on rocky substrata in gullies and the sides of deep rock pools and on reefs to a depth of about 100 m. Often mingles with other sedentary invertebrates, such as sponges, other bryozoans and soft corals. Very little other species-specific information available.
taxon_text_5_5184: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5185: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins.  New colonies formed by sexual reproduction, fertilized eggs being released into the water column to disperse and establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_5186: Chaperia and Chaperiopsis species form similar brittle, calcified and folded orange to red colonies, but these lack the regularly-spaced holes. Retoporella lata is very similar, but is punctured by small elongate holes less and 1 mm long and is cream when alive.
taxon_text_8_5187:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 130).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 48).
taxon_text_1_5190:
Colony consists of a thin, flat, pale-pinkish or yellow sheet attached to the undersides of rocks, especially in intertidal pools.

The individual zooecia are more or less rectangular with a granular surface. The large semicircular aperture has a thickened margin and a thin transparent lid. Defensive individuals (avicularia) and rare and similar to, but slightly larger than, feeding individuals and have an inverted V-shape structure across the aperture.
taxon_text_2_5191: Individual zooecia about 1 mm long, colonies typically 5-10 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5192:
Global: Virtually cosmopolitan in warmer seas.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban.
taxon_text_4_5193: Common on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal and shallow subtidal to a depth of about 20 m. Colonies more or less circular, but zooids not arranged in rows. No other details available.
taxon_text_5_5194: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5195: Hermaphrodite. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins. Also undertake sexual reproduction, and related species brood the eggs internally, but species -specific details not available.
taxon_text_7_5196: The pale colour and large semicircular apertures distinguish this from the Rust-red bryozoan Watersipora subtorquata, which often also occurs as flat, round colonies under the same boulders.
taxon_text_8_5197:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 25).
taxon_text_1_5200:
Colony consists of a branching tuft of deep blue or blue-grey stalks, usually hanging downwards, and is easily mistaken for a seaweed.

When examined closely, each branch consists of a double row of oval zooecia, arranged in an overlapping chain. There are several long spines around the aperture at the distal end of each zooecium and special smaller protective individuals (avicularia), which are shaped like birds’ heads, are present along the margins of each branch.
taxon_text_2_5201: Individual zooecia about 0.5 mm long, colonies typically 5 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_5202:
Global: Native to the tropical Indo-Pacific, but thought to be widely introduced to other areas by shipping, including temperate South Africa, the Gulf of Mexico, Madieira, New Zealand and Brazil. Recent genetic work though suggests a complex of similar sibling species may fall under this one name and the regional populations may in fact represent different species!

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5203:
Common introduced fouling species found on the walls of gullies and other vertical surfaces, as well as on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours and similar habitats, down to a depth of 20 m. Often grow on the surfaces of other organisms, such as sponges, large ascidians and molluscs.

The birds’ head aviculae serve much like the pedicellaria of echinoderms and keep the colony free of fouling organisms.
taxon_text_5_5204: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5205: Zooids are hermaphrodite, first being female and later male. Sperm liberated by males are drawn into female zooids, where they fertilise the eggs. The eggs are brooded and at this stage the zooecia develop a rounded cap and are known as ovicells. Once liberated the larvae have a short larval life before settling to establish new colonies. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips of the branches.
taxon_text_7_5206: The unusual blue colour is distinctive, but other species in the genus Bugula also form similar bushy, branching colonies of other colours.
taxon_text_8_5207:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 25).

Picker, M & Griffiths, C (2011). Alien and Invasive Animals – a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 201 as Bugula dentata).
taxon_text_1_5210:
Colony consists of a flat, rust-red, hard, crusty plate with a brighter red edge and marked with darker dots (representing opening of zooecia). Found attached to solid substrata, especially undersides of rocks. Smaller colonies are usually circular with concentrically arranged rings of zooecia, but larger ones can become irregular and buckled or folded.

The individual zooids are enclosed in flat, regularly-arranged, coffin-shaped cases (zooecia) and when examined microscopically the surface is finely pitted. The oval opening has a raised edge and proximal notch and is closed by a dark, hinged operculum. When extended, the lophophores are conical and pale orange, each with about 20 tentacles.
taxon_text_2_5211: Individual zooecia about 1.5 mm long, colonies typically 2-5 cm but may be 20 cm across.
taxon_text_3_5212:
Global: Virtually cosmopolitan in warmer seas, where it has been widely introduced by shipping. Thought to have originated in Caribbean.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_5213: Common introduced fouling species found on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal and shallow subtidal. Also common on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours and similar habitats, down to a depth of about 15 m.
taxon_text_5_5214: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_5215: Hermaphrodite. Sperm are liberated into the water and drawn into other zooids where they fertilise the eggs. The larvae are red and at first develop inside the zooids, but are then liberated for a short larval life before settling to establish new colonies. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooids around the margins.
taxon_text_8_5217:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 39).

Picker, M & Griffiths, C (2011). Alien and Invasive Animals – a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 200).
taxon_text_1_5220:
Thin white-to-grey crustose lichen, sometimes with bluish tinge. The surface is broken into numerous small blocks, resembling a mosaic, the whole colony having a distinct darker margin. The reproductive apothecia are black and immersed within the thallus, their surface often being slightly convex.

This large and very complex genus has over 400 species globally and about 100 within the southern African region, so species level identifications should be treated with caution. This identification is based on Wirth (2010) and is influenced largely on habitat – this species being a typically shoreline one.
taxon_text_2_5221: Colonies up to at least 50 mm in diameter, apothecia 0.4 – 0.5 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_5222:
Global: Widely distributed across the Northern Hemisphere, also South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Namibia to at least Cape Point (few details).
taxon_text_4_5223: A fairly common species, but found mostly on rocks along, or adjacent to, the coast. Often adjacent to, or mixed with, other orange lichens of the genera Calloplaca and Doufourea.
taxon_text_6_5225: Colonies can divide asexually by division. Spores are also produced within the apothecia and can spread to form distant colonies.
taxon_text_7_5226: The crazed texture and grey-black colouring fairly distinctive to genus level, but there are many similar species in the region.
taxon_text_8_5227:
Wirth, V (2010). Lichens of the Namib Desert: a Guide to their Identification. Klaus Hess Publishers, Gottingen- Windhoek (p. 73).

Yogesh, J, Xin YW, László L, Young JK & Jae-Seoun, J (2010). Notes on Lichen Genus Buellia De Not. (lichenized Ascomycetes) from South Korea. Mycobiology, 38(1), 65-69.
taxon_text_1_5230:
Typically forms round, flat colonies a few cm in diameter on rocks just above the high-water mark on rocky shores, where it may be found adjacent to, or even mixed with, other Caloplaca and Dufourea species. The lobes are typically flat or convex and sausage-like, being fairly loosely attached to the substratum. They are often covered in numerous rough and paler spots and branch irregularly. The lobe tips typically become broader and fatter.

Colour yellow to orange-yellow, but may be tinged green, especially when wet. Lower surface yellow. If present, the apothecia are orange-yellow and bowl-like, with a flat top and thick raised margin.
taxon_text_2_5231: Colonies typically about 20-40 mm in diameter, apothecia 0.4 – 2.5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_5232:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Fairly restricted range from Saldanha Bay to Tsitsikamma.
taxon_text_4_5233: A common species, but restricted to the coast, mostly in the shore but rarely up to 750 m inland, and geographically to the Cape Floristic region.
taxon_text_6_5235: Colonies can divide asexually by division. Spores are also produced within the apothecia and can spread to form distant colonies.
taxon_text_7_5236: Can be confused with several other orange Dufourea and Caloplaca species that occur in the same habitat, but the fat, sausage-like thali with their widened tips and paler, rough patches are fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_5237:
Arup, U, Søchting, U & Frödén, P (2013). A new taxonomy of the family Teloschistaceae. Nordic Journal of Botany, 31(1), 016–083.

Kärnefelt, I, Arup, U & Lindblom, L (1995). Xanthoria capensis (Teloschistaceae) a new endemic species in the Cape Flora Kingdom. Bibliotheca Lichenologica, 57, 253- 264.
taxon_text_1_5240:
Colonies take the form of yellow or orange bushy clumps, usually attached to the tips of shrubs along the coastline adjacent to wave-exposed coasts. The tufts are formed of long, fingerlike yellow or orange lobes that are about 3 mm across and which branch dichotomously. The fingers may be erect, or hang downwards.

Apothecae inconspicuous and the same colour as the main stems (thallus) taking the form of small (2-3 mm) cup-like ‘mushrooms’ with constricted stems.
taxon_text_2_5241: Bushy tufts up to about 140 mm across.
taxon_text_3_5242:
Global: Endemic to west coast of southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia southwards along west coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_5243: A common species in moist sites especially along the coastline, where it can form extensive colonies on the upper branches of coastal shrubs.
taxon_text_6_5245: Colonies can divide asexually by division. Spores are also produced within the apothecia and can spread to form distant colonies.
taxon_text_7_5246:
At a distance, can be confused with Teloschistes species as both form yellow to orange, bushy clumps on the tips of bushes above the shoreline on rocky coasts. However, in Teloshistes the branches are fine and usually flattened, whereas in Dufourea flammea they take the form of much thicker cylindrical finger-like hollow lobes.

There are several other regional species in the genus, but these form flatter colonies spreading over rocks or branches.
taxon_text_8_5247:
Arup, U, Søchting, U & Frödén, P (2013). A new taxonomy of the family Teloschistaceae. Nordic Journal of Botany, 31(1), 016–083.

Wirth, V (2010). Lichens of the Namib Desert: a Guide to their Identification. Klaus Hess Publishers, Gottingen- Windhoek (p. 34, as Xanthodactylon flammeum).
taxon_text_1_5250:
An obligate marine species found well down in the intertidal in the Littorina (periwinkle) or Balanoid (barnacle) zones of the intertidal.

Forms quite extensive clumps and often mistaken as a seaweed. The dark-brown or olive-green thallus is formed into upright tufts with each ‘frond’ irregularly branched in a single plane (‘palmate‘), like a short brown seaweed. The reproductive bodies (apothecia) and globular or flask-like.

Originally thought to be a globally widespread species, L. pygmaea, but the Southern Hemisphere populations have recently been proven to represent a distinct species.
taxon_text_2_5251: Colonies typically 10 cm or more across. Fronds about 10 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_5252:
Global: Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Poorly documented, but there are records along west coast of South Africa to at least Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_5253:
Common species that was reported as early as 1960 by TA Stephenson, one of the pioneers of intertidal research in South Africa. However, still remains very poorly studied with no research undertaken to date in South Africa. May form large patches on intertidal rocks and thus probably a significant component of the diets of upper intertidal grazers, such as periwinkles and high-shore limpets.

The symbiont is a cyanobacterium rather than an alga.
taxon_text_6_5255: Colonies expand by branching. Spores are produced by small fruiting bodies on the surface of the colony.
taxon_text_7_5256: We are not aware of any published research on intertidal lichens in South Africa, so it is very difficult to say whether there are other similar species in the region. Most easily confused with small brown or red algae, but these lack the apothecia (sporing bodies).
taxon_text_8_5257:
Ortiz-Álvarez, R, de Los Ríos, A, Fernández-Mendoza, F, Torralba-Burrial, A & Pérez-Ortega, S (2015). "Ecological specialization of two photobiont-specific maritime cyanolichen species of the genus Lichina".PloS one. 10 (7), e0132718.

Schultz, M (2017). Morphological and molecular data support Lichina intermedia as a distinct austral-marine species in the L. pygmaea group. The Lichenologist, 49(4), 321-332.
taxon_text_1_5260:
A very unusual lichen both in in terms of its habitat of living within the shells of barnacles, limpets and sometimes other gastropods, and in that it is truly intertidal and submerged for part of the tidal cycle.

The thallus is hardly visible and is buried in the shell substratum. The only visible parts are the small black fruiting bodies, which appear as round dots on the surface of the host shell, each about 0.2 mm across.
taxon_text_2_5261: Colonies immersed in shells, black dots that link to reproductive structures about 0.2-0.3 mm across.
taxon_text_3_5262:
Global: Widespread in Northern Hemisphere, especially Europe, but also both coasts of North America. Also reported from Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Poorly known, but reported mostly on west coast.
taxon_text_4_5263:
Probably common, but very poorly known, as seldom noticed or recognized. Has been noted on the shells of barnacles and especially limpets such as Granular limpet and Pear limpet. Also noted on Mediterranean mussel.

The photobiont is a cyanobacterium, rather than an alga.
taxon_text_6_5265: Colonies can divide and spread asexually by division. Spores are also produced and can spread to infect distant hosts.
taxon_text_7_5266:
The classification of this species, its correct taxonomic name and its true distribution are all uncertain. Some sources give the current name as Collemopsidium, but we follow WoRMS (World Register of Marine Species) by placing it in the genus Pryenocollema.

The species within this group are also poorly defined and it appears likely that a complex of species in involved and confused under this one name.

Can also be confused with the crustose coralline alga Spongites yendoi, which also makes pitted growth on the shells of the same suite of molluscs but which tend to form rounded humps decorated with radiating ridges and patterns of regular holes (see that entry).
taxon_text_8_5267:
Fiorentino, J (2008). First record of Pyrenocollema halodytes (Nyl.) R. Harris (Pyrenulales: Pyrenulaceae). The Central Mediterranean Naturalist, 4, 213-219.

Harada, H (2000). Taxonomic notes on pyrenocarpous lichens in Japan 2. Pyrenocollema halodytes Nyl. RC Harris in Egan, a marine lichen., 13(2), 133-139.

Sagin, WRTB (1995). Pyrenocollema halodytes, a new lichen species. Acta Mycologica, 3(1), 117-150.
taxon_text_1_5270:
Encrusting very dark brown to black lichen, sometimes mistaken for oil pollution on the shore. One of few truly marine lichens in the region, occurring in the upper Balanoid (barnacle) and Littorina (periwinkle) zones on rocky intertidal shores.

When examined closely the thallus is about 0.1-0.3 mm thick and has a slightly uneven, dull surface that is fairly regularly cracked into blocks about 0.2-0.8 mm across and separated by narrow fissures (like crazy paving). The reproductive organs are about 0.3 mm in diameter and are sunken into the thallus with a flat to slightly convex upper surface.
taxon_text_2_5271: Colonies can cover large areas of rock and be 1 m or more across.
taxon_text_3_5272:
Global: Widespread across Europe, Asia, Africa, North America and Australia.

Local/Regional: Poorly documented, but there are records along west coast of South Africa to at least Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_5273:
A common species, but remains very poorly studied. May form extensive patches on intertidal rocks and thus probably a significant component of the diets of upper intertidal grazers, such as periwinkles and high-shore limpets.

The presence of this black lichen has been shown to raise the temperature of the rock relative to adjacent rock surfaces.
taxon_text_6_5275: Spores are produced by small fruiting bodies buried in the thallus.
taxon_text_7_5276: We are not aware of any published research on intertidal lichens in South Africa, so it is very difficult to say whether there are other similar species in the region.
taxon_text_8_5277:
Carter, NEA & Viles, HA (2004). Lichen hotspots: raised rock temperatures beneath Verrucaria nigrescens on limestone. Geomorphology, 62(1-2), 1-16.
(not covered in any of local marine guidebooks!).
taxon_text_1_5281: The largest barnacle in the region. Shell with a calcareous base and formed from six white to pale pink plates. Larger of the plates closing the aperture (scutum) marked with transverse ridges and smaller ones (terga) produced to form prominent ‘fangs’ which project through aperture.
taxon_text_2_5282: Shell diameter up to about 40 mm, shell height may reach 150 mm in close-packed colonies.
taxon_text_3_5283:
Global: Endemic to South Africa, but has been introduced to New Zealand via shipping.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to about Algoa Bay
taxon_text_4_5284: Most commonly found subtidally, but scattered individuals can be found in lower intertidal pools. Most common on jetties and floating structures such as ships hulls and mussel rafts, where it can become a pest. Fast growing and reaches adult size in about 2 years. The closely-related species A. psittacus is a sought-after seafood in Chile, where it is used to make traditional dishes such as ‘Curanto’. Overfishing has caused a decline in natural stocks and there are plans to culture the species for local consumption and export to Japan.
taxon_text_5_5285: Like all barnacles – feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5286: Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go through several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies.
taxon_text_7_5287: Can be readily distinguished from other regional species by its large size and the fact that the terga are extended into pointed ‘fangs’ that project from the aperture.
taxon_text_8_5288:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p82)

Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_5301: Small white or slightly yellow to green tinged, barnacle with six shell valves. Separately growing individuals have an irregular outline and vertical ridges up the shells valves, but those that grow in dense groups become very elongate and columnar. The base is calcareous and leaves a distinct white scar on the rocks when the barnacle dies or is displaced. The margins of the four shell valves closing the aperture form and M-shaped line.
taxon_text_2_5302: Shell diameter up to about 10 mm, may grow up to 50 mm tall when crowded.
taxon_text_3_5303:
Global: Native to the west coast of North America and introduced to Argentina, Japan, Europe and South Africa via shipping.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to about False Bay, but still expanding eastwards.
taxon_text_4_5304:
Only discovered in South Africa in 2008, but likely present for many years previously, as easily confused with the native Toothed barnacle Chthamalus dentatus (see that entry). Now the most common intertidal barnacle all along the west coast, forming a distinct band in the mid to upper intertidal, above zones occupied by the introduced Mediterranean mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis and below that the introduced Bisexual mussel Semimytilus patagonicus. As a result, shores in this region have been greatly transformed by invasive species at all levels.

Frequently settles at extremely high densities. Growing individuals then quickly come into contact with one another and start to grow vertically as they compete for access to the water above. They then become extremely tall, elongated and fragile (much like overcrowded seedlings seeking the light) and as a result are easily displaced in storms, leaving distinctive bare patches on the rocks that remain coated by the calcareous bases.
taxon_text_5_5305: Like all barnacles feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5306: Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies.
taxon_text_7_5307: Easily confused with the Toothed barnacle Chthamalus dentatus, which occurs in similar intertidal habitats. However that species has a membranous base and not a calcareous one. Also the Toothed barnacle is relatively rare along the west coast, where the Pacific barnacle now dominates in the mid intertidal.
taxon_text_8_5308:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p82)

Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Laird, MC & Griffiths, CL (2008). Present distribution and abundance of the introduced barnacle Balanus glandula Darwin in South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 30(1), 93–100.
taxon_text_1_5311: Small, usually flattened, purple or pink-striped barnacle with six ridged shell plates and a calcareous base. Aperture distinctly triangular and the larger of shell plate that closes it (scutum) marked with diagnostic rows of pits.
taxon_text_3_5313:
Global: Cosmopolitan. Thought to be native to the Pacific, but has been widely dispersed around the world by shipping.

Local/Regional: Common across the region, except coast of Northern Cape.
taxon_text_4_5314: A common fouling species. Can be found under rocks in the intertidal but is most common on floating structures such as buoys, ships hulls, mussel rafts, etc. Tolerant of lowered salinity and also occurs in estuaries.
taxon_text_5_5315: Like all barnacles feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5316: Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies.
taxon_text_7_5317: There are several other pink-striped barnacles (mostly Amphibalanus species) in the region, but the pits on the scutum distinguish this species from all other regional barnacles.
taxon_text_8_5318:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 82)
taxon_text_1_5321: Small, rather flat, dirty-white barnacle with six shell valves and a membranous base. Aperture large and closed by 4 neatly-interlocking plates. Projecting finger-like ridges on the shell plates produce a characteristic star-shaped outline, which is the best character for identification.
taxon_text_3_5323:
Global: From Kenya to Angola.

Local/Regional: Throughout region, but more common to the east.
taxon_text_4_5324: Common intertidal barnacle all along the east and south coast, rare on west coast, where largely replaced by the similar looking but introduced Balanus glandula. Recruitment occurs mainly in spring and autumn and mean longevity is only about 1.5 years.
taxon_text_5_5325: Like all barnacles – feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5326: Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies.
taxon_text_7_5327: Easily confused with the Pacific barnacle Balanus glandula, which occurs in similar intertidal habitats. However, that species has a calcareous base and is mostly restricted to the west coast.
taxon_text_8_5328:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M, & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 82)

Dye, AH (1993). Aspects of the population dynamics of Chthamalus dentatus (Crustacea: Cirripedia) on the Transkei coast of southern Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 13(1), 25–32.
taxon_text_1_5331: Flattened, benthic fish with a broad head, large bulbous eyes and very wide, fat-lipped mouth fringed with fleshy tentacles. Skin loose and wrinkled and body scale-less. Pectoral fin large and spread laterally. Colour dark brown with yellowish barring.
taxon_text_3_5333:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_5334: Bottom-dwelling and reluctant to swim, usually just moving a short distance if disturbed. Usually found singly in rock pools and under boulders and seldom deeper than 20 m. Appears to be night active as mostly seen during night dives.
taxon_text_5_5335: Details unknown but assumed to be an ambush predator of invertebrates.
taxon_text_7_5337: Easily recognised to group, but a second smaller and more colourful mottled brown species, the Snakeshead toadfish Batrichthys apiatus, also occurs in the same region.
taxon_text_8_5338:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 272).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 277).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 218).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 359).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 25).
taxon_text_1_5351: Easily identified by the distinctive fleshy ear-like siphons that project backwards from the ‘head’ and after which the common name is derived. The shell plates are greatly reduced, especially in adults, giving a fleshy appearance. Colour normally purplish-brown, but younger individuals marked with indistinct cream and sometimes purple patches.
taxon_text_2_5352: Up to 100 mm total length, including stalk.
taxon_text_4_5354: Goose barnacles are typically found on passively-floating objects but this species (and genus) is unusual in that it settles on moving objects. These would originally have been turtles, whales and other marine vertebrates, but now they are most commonly found on ships’ hulls. They rely on the movement of the host to generate a feeding current and filter food passively from the passing water. The ‘ears’ can be used to moderate the amount of water passing over the feeding appendages, allowing the barnacle to continue to feed even when the host is moving rapidly though the water.
taxon_text_5_5355: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and combing these through the water to capture floating particles. This species has particularly stout feeding appendages - probably an adaptation for feeding in strong currently and for consuming larger planktonic organisms.
taxon_text_6_5356: Barnacles are hermaphroditic, but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable floating objects on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5357: Members of the genus Conchoderma are unlikely to be mistaken for other goose barnacles in the region due to their reduced shell plates and earlike projections on the ‘head’. Another similar species C. virgatum is also quite common on both marine animals and ships across the region, but can be distinguished by having less distinct ‘ears’ and 6 black or purple stripes extending down the length of the body and onto the stalk (see image below).
taxon_text_8_5358:
Best, PB (1971). Stalked Barnacles Conchoderma auritum on an elephant seal: occurrence of elephant seals on South African coast. African Zoology, 6(2), 181–185.

Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p80)
taxon_text_1_5361: Large cylindrical barnacle with six vertically-ridged shell plates surrounding a large fleshy orifice. In the centre of this orifice a pair of shell valves guard the opening through which the feeding appendages are extended. Best identified by its unusual habitat of living partially buried in the skin of large whales, particularly Humpback whales, but also Southern Right whales, Blue whales, etc.
taxon_text_4_5364: Found exclusively buried in the skin of large whales. They are ‘energy parasites’ that rely on the movement of the host to generate a feeding current and then filter food passively from the passing water.
taxon_text_5_5365: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and using these to capture floating particles. This species has short, thick, segmented feeding appendages with short, claw-like setae, which are probably adaptations for feeding in fast currents and taking larger prey.
taxon_text_6_5366: Barnacles are hermaphroditic, but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable hosts on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5367: Unlikely to be mistaken for other barnacles in the region due to their large, globular appearance and unique habitat. Another rarer and smaller species C. reginae also occurs on Humpback whales.
taxon_text_8_5368:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 80)
taxon_text_1_5371: Goose barnacles have a laterally flattened body, enclosed by five white plates and borne on a flexible, fleshy stalk. This species can be recognised by its short stalk, thin, transparent shell plates and translucent–blue colour. Its most distinctive feature is its ability to secrete its own float, which has a texture similar to expanded polystyrene foam.
taxon_text_2_5372: Up to 40 mm total length, including stalk.
taxon_text_3_5373:
Global: Found in temperate seas worldwide.

Local/Regional: Across entire region.
taxon_text_4_5374:
Goose barnacles are typically found on floating objects. This species is highly unusual in that adults are able to secrete their own polystyrene-like floats using modified cement glands at the base of the stalk. Larvae originally have to settle on small floating objects, such as plastic pellets, feathers, Spirula shells or the like, but as adults they tend to form rounded aggregations hanging beneath their home-made floats.

Growth rate is extremely rapid and newly-settled individuals develop into reproductive adults within about 45 days. Although usually rare they occasionally wash up in very large numbers.
taxon_text_5_5375: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and combing these through the water to capture floating particles.
taxon_text_6_5376: Barnacles are hermaphroditic, but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable floating object on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5377: Unlikely to be mistaken for other goose barnacles in the region due to its delicate shell, bluish colour and unique float.
taxon_text_8_5378:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 80)

Ryan, PG & Branch, GM (2012). The November 2011 irruption of buoy barnacles Dosima fascicularis in the Western Cape, South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 34(1), 157–162.
taxon_text_1_5381: Goose barnacles have a laterally flattened body, enclosed by five white plates and borne on a flexible, fleshy stalk. This species is characterized by its relatively thick shell valves, which are separated by only narrow gaps and often show concentric growth lines. The plates also have characteristic bright orange or yellow margins. The stalk is typically quite short and often dark brown to red.
taxon_text_2_5382: Up to 100 mm total length, including up to 80 mm stalk.
taxon_text_3_5383:
Global: Found in tropical and temperate seas worldwide.

Local/Regional: Across entire region.
taxon_text_4_5384: Typically found on floating objects and originally confined to natural substrata, such as driftwood, floating kelps, cephalopod shells, turtles and marine mammals. The availability of suitable habitats has now been vastly increased by the far greater abundance of man-made floating objects. These include ships, buoys, ropes etc., as well as discarded items including floating plastics, shoes, bottles, polystyrene, timber, etc. As a result, goose barnacles are probably much more common now than in the past.
