Growth rate is extremely rapid and objects known to have been in the water only a few weeks can be recovered already covered in large barnacles.
taxon_text_5_5385: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and combing these through the water to capture floating particles.
taxon_text_6_5386: Barnacles are hermaphroditic but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable floating object on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5387: There are several other similar and easily confused goose barnacles on the region, but this one can be fairly reliably recognized by the yellow margins to the shell plates. A distinct subspecies L. anatifera striata can be found from False Bay eastwards and can be recognized by a row of dark, square pits radiating across the centre of the main shell valve (see image above).
taxon_text_8_5388:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 80).

Whitehead, O, Griffiths, CL & Biccard, A (2011). Habitat use and the importance of litter for goose barnacle populations in South Africa. Crustaceana, 84 (5–6), 635-649.
taxon_text_1_5391: Goose barnacles have a laterally flattened body, enclosed by five white plates and borne on a flexible, fleshy stalk. This species should not be confused with the very-similarly named L. anatifera (see that entry). L. anserifera is characterized by its relatively thick, large shell valves, the main plate being almost quadrangular. The plates are separated by very narrow gaps and marked with distinct radiating ridges. The stalk is very short and usually orange. The main plate only (unlike L. anatifera) sometimes has a bright orange or yellow margin.
taxon_text_2_5392: Up to 20 mm total length, including stalk.
taxon_text_3_5393:
Global: Found in tropical and temperate seas worldwide.

Local/Regional: Across entire region, but rarer on west coast.
taxon_text_4_5394:
Goose barnacles are typically found on floating objects and were originally confined to natural substrata such as driftwood, floating kelps, cephalopod shells, turtles and marine mammals. The availability of suitable habitats has now been vastly increased by the far greater abundance of man-made floating objects. These include ships, buoys, ropes etc., as well as discarded items including floating plastics, shoes, bottles, polystyrene, timber, etc. As a result, goose barnacles are probably much more common now than in the past. This species occurs on various natural and man-made objects, often seeming to prefer small objects, such as feathers, Spirula shells and small plastic debris.

Growth rate is extremely rapid and objects known to have been in the water only a few weeks can be recovered already covered in adult barnacles.
taxon_text_5_5395: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and combing these through the water to capture floating particles.
taxon_text_6_5396: Barnacles are hermaphroditic, but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable floating object on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5397: There are several other similar goose barnacles in the region, but this one can be recognized from most by its unusually short stalk and the strong radiating ridges on the main shell plate. L. pectinata also has those features and is very similar externally, the two species being best distinguished only by internal anatomy (number of filamentary appendages - see Biccard reference below for details).
taxon_text_8_5398:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 80).

Whitehead, O, Griffiths, CL & Biccard, A (2011). Habitat use and the importance of litter for goose barnacle populations in South Africa. Crustaceana, 84 (5-6), 635–649.
taxon_text_1_5401: Goose barnacles have a laterally flattened body, enclosed by five white plates and borne on a flexible, fleshy stalk. This species is characterized by its relatively thin white to fairly dark grey shell valves, which are separated by relatively wide gaps and show concentric growth lines. The aperture may have a narrow yellow margin. The stalk is typically very long, pale to brown and often, but not always, covered on soft spiny projections. Particularly commonly seen on floating kelps.
taxon_text_2_5402: Up to 300 mm total length, including very elongate stalks, but head typically only about 30 mm.
taxon_text_3_5403:
Global: Widespread in temperate seas in Southern hemisphere.

Local/Regional: Restricted to cooler waters of west and south coasts, not found on east coast.
taxon_text_4_5404: This species is most commonly recorded attached to floating kelps, where it may occur in extremely large numbers (thousands per kelp) and form clumps up to 300 mm long. Growth rate is thought to be extremely rapid and kelps suspected to have been uprooted in storms only a few weeks earlier can be washed up already covered in large barnacles. As the barnacles are negatively buoyant large infestations probably cause the kelps to sink, which would result in death of the barnacles.
taxon_text_5_5405: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and combing these through the water to capture floating particles.
taxon_text_6_5406: Barnacles are hermaphroditic but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable floating object on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5407: There are several other similar and easily confused goose barnacles on the region, but this one can be fairly reliably recognized by a very elongate, spiky stalk and preference for kelps.
taxon_text_8_5408:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 80)

Whitehead, O, Griffiths, CL & Biccard, A (2011). Habitat use and the importance of litter for goose barnacle populations in South Africa. Crustaceana 84 (5-6), 635–649.
taxon_text_1_5411:
Members of this genus resemble small marginellids (indeed some were once regarded as such) and have similar smooth, elongate shells with a narrowish, slit-like aperture that runs almost the entire length of the shell. The spire is virtually absent and the  inner lip is ornamented with grooves and ridges. Species level taxonomy remains confused, as most species were described from dead shells, (which are fairly featureless in this group) and more modern records show great variations in the colours of the live animals, these possibly representing separate species.

The transparent shell of this species is characterised by having almost no spire, but rather a flattened posterior end, while the anterior end lacks a siphonal notch, instead having a fairly widely--rounded opening. The inner lip bears 2 strong oblique pleats and 2 much smaller ridges (‘lirae’), while the outer lip is thickened, but bears no teeth or ridges.

Live specimens collected from Table Bay (and depicted below) are distinctively coloured and have a bright orange siphon, transparent foot with white central blotch and the internal organs showing though the shell as yellow with 2 broad black crossbars.
taxon_text_3_5413:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Kosi Bay.
taxon_text_4_5414: Very little is known about these small species other than the species descriptions (which were mostly based on shells only). They are found crawling around on the surfaces of rocks or on algae and appear to feed on small crustaceans such a benthic copepods, which are abundant in these habitats. This species is common on the fronds of Tongue weeds (Gigartina spp).
taxon_text_5_5415: Predatory, probably feeding on benthic copepods, which are often seen around them.
taxon_text_6_5416: Details unknown, but all species in this group show direct development of egg capsules into crawling juveniles.
taxon_text_7_5417: The taxonomy of this group of tiny gastropods is confused as most species are known only from dead shells and some known species also remain un-described (see refs. below). Recent photographic evidence also shows great variations in body colour and these may be valuable characters for separating species or discovering new ones!
taxon_text_8_5418:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 200 - incorrectly identified as Gibberula dulcis).

Barnard, KH (1969). Contributions to the Knowledge of South African Marine Mollusca- Part VI- Supplementary Annals of the South African Museum, 47(4), 615-620. (As Persicula arborubida).

Lussi, M & Smith G (unpublished booklet 2007). Cystiscidae of South Africa Part 2 - Genera Plesiocystiscus, Crithe, Cystiscus & Granulina.

Lussi, M & Smith, G (1998). Family Cystiscidae Stimpson, 1865. Revision of the family Cystiscidae in South Africa with the introduction of three genera and the description of eight new species. Malacologia Mostra Mondiale, 27, 3-23.
taxon_text_1_5535: Small white or faintly pink-striped species with six ridged shell plates in the circle and with a calcareous base (best seen when removed from the substratum, or as a white scar on rock where dead animals have broken off). The radii of the shell plates (flat white flanges extending laterally from upper margins of shell plates) bear characteristic transverse canals that distinguish this from other similar species.
taxon_text_2_5536: Small – shell diameter up to only about 5 mm.
taxon_text_3_5537:
Global: Endemic to South Africa, but has been introduced to New Zealand and Australia via shipping.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to central KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5538: Most commonly found on mussel shells or rocks in the lower intertidal or on floating objects such as buoys and ships hulls. Extremely fast growing, reaching maturity in a few weeks, and can cause a serious problem as a fouling organism on marine structures.
taxon_text_5_5539: Like all barnacles feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5540: Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies.
taxon_text_7_5541: Can be confused with several other small white barnacles in the region, but readily distinguished from other regional species by the horizontal canals on the flanges of the shell plates.
taxon_text_8_5542:
Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 82)
<p>Nauplius larva under the microscope -: Nauplius larva under the microscope - magnification about 150x.
taxon_text_1_5545: Easily recognized by the fact that it has eight shell plates in a circle (all other intertidal species in the region have either six or four) and reaches a relatively large size compared to other similar intertidal species. Shell plates dirty white and bearing prominent, meandering vertical ridges. Very common in the mid- to low-intertidal, forming extensive and often closely-packed sheets.
taxon_text_3_5547:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to south-coast of KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5548: One of most common intertidal barnacles in the region, forming extensive sheets in the mid to low intertidal, especially in areas of relatively high wave action. A passive feeder, holding its feeding appendages out into the waves and sieving out passing food particles.
taxon_text_5_5549: Like all barnacles feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.
taxon_text_6_5550: Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies which facilitate later mating.
taxon_text_7_5551: Can be readily distinguished from other regional species by having 8-shell valves in the circle. Other smaller white and vertically ridged, but 6-shelled species, such as Chthamalus dentatus and Balanus glandula are also common in similar intertidal habitats.
taxon_text_8_5552:
Boland, JM (1997). The horizontal zonation of two species of intertidal barnacle in South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 18(1), 49–61.

Delafontaine, MT & Flemming, BW (1989). Physical factors in barnacle community structure: a conceptual model. Scientia Marina, 53(2), 405–410.
taxon_text_1_5555: Distinctive dark-grey barnacle, the outer surface of which is covered with numerous longitudinal rough ridges. There are only four strongly-ribbed shell plates in the circle, although the strong surface texture makes the shell plates hard to count. Shell plates contain numerous air-filled pores (clearly seen if dead shells are viewed from below).
taxon_text_3_5557:
Global: Namibia, South Africa and possibly Mozambique. Records from the tropical Indo-Pacific may be misidentifications of T. rufotincta (see related species below).

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5558: A dominant species in the mid intertidal zone of more temperate shores throughout the region, especially abundant in more sheltered situations. Often occurs together with the Eight-shell barnacle Octomeris angulosa, which tends to replace it in more wave-exposed situations on the same shores. Newly settled larvae grow to a diameter of about 7-8 mm in the first year, declining to 4 mm a year by the third year of life. Average longevity is about 3 years.
taxon_text_5_5559: Active feeders, sweeping their feeding appendages thought the water to filter out food particles, which may include planktonic organisms and particles of algae or other organic material. Larvae have been recorded feeding on mussel eggs.
taxon_text_6_5560: Reproductive season extends for about 5 months with mature larvae most common from Nov-Feb and peak settlement of larvae form Jan- March.
taxon_text_7_5561: Unlikely to be confused with any other intertidal barnacle in the Cape region, but progressively replaced by the similar but more tropical and pink-coloured Rosy volcano barnacle T. rufotincta from the south coast of KwaZulu-Natal northwards.
taxon_text_8_5562:
Boland, JM (1997). The horizontal zonation of two species of intertidal barnacle in South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 18(1), 49–61.

Dye, AH (1992). Recruitment dynamics and growth of the barnacle Tetraclita serrata on the east coast of southern Africa. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 35(2), 167–177.

Griffiths, RJI (1979). The reproductive season and larval development of the barnacle Tetraclita serrata Darwin. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 44(1), 97–111.
taxon_text_1_5565: Very unusual and unmistakable elongate and cylindrical barnacle found buried into the skin of Southern Right Whales. There are six shell valves that are fused to form a cylindrical structure that tapers towards to lower end and is surrounded by 2-10 ribbed annular ridges that secure it firmly in place.
taxon_text_2_5566: Up to 60 mm long and 30 mm in shell diameter.
taxon_text_3_5567:
Global: Southern Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

Local/Regional: Across entire region, but most records from south Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_5568: Found exclusively in the skin of large whales. They are ‘energy parasites’ that rely on the movement of the host to generate a feeding current and then filter food passively from the passing water.
taxon_text_5_5569: All barnacles are filter-feeders, extending their feathery feeding appendages though the aperture and using these to capture floating particles.
taxon_text_6_5570: Barnacles are hermaphroditic, but prefer to cross-fertilise. Larvae are released into the water and seek out other suitable hosts on which to settle.
taxon_text_7_5571: Unlikely to be mistaken for other barnacles in the region due to their highly unusual cylindrical ridged shells and unique habitat.
taxon_text_8_5572: Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_5585: Pale yellow to light orange beetle with dark eyes, a smooth thorax, and with wing covers (elytra) ornamented with fine longitudinal grooves. Best identified by its unusual habits of living under decaying seaweed on the upper reaches of sandy beaches.
taxon_text_3_5587:
Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_5588: Commonly found on sandy beaches along the west coast where it shelters under decaying seaweed on the driftline.
taxon_text_5_5589: Presumed to feed on decaying kelps and other seaweeds.
taxon_text_6_5590: The life history of this species has not been investigated, but larvae are presumed to be similar to those of other tenebrionid beetles, such as mealworms, which are slender, smooth and yellowish with short legs. Larvae presumed to also feed on rotting algae.
taxon_text_7_5591: There are several thousand species of tenebrionid beetle in the region, but this species in fairly easy to distinguish both due to its yellow colour and unusual intertidal habitat.
taxon_text_8_5592: Picker, MD, Griffiths CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 282).
taxon_text_1_5615: Slender, swimming mysid with dark eyes and pink thorax. Abdomen bluish-tinted with red bands across posterior parts of each segment, uropods and telson red. Associated with octopus dens in shallow waters. Telson cleft with about 15 short lateral spines, two longer terminal ones and margins of cleft densely lined with short spines.
taxon_text_3_5617:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Currently known only in False Bay.
taxon_text_4_5618: A recently discovered species first collected by Craig Foster of the Sea Change team. Seen several times in small schools in octopus dens and believed to be associated with octopi, although also found once in intertidal rock pool.
taxon_text_6_5620: As in all mysids the eggs are retained in a marsupial sac until fully developed.
taxon_text_7_5621: Two other closely-related species from this genus have been recorded at this same site. All three of these species are described as new by Wittmann and Griffiths (2017), who also give a morphological key and detailed drawings to allow species level identifications.
taxon_text_8_5622: Wittmann, KJ & Griffiths CL (2017). Three new species of Heteromysis (Mysida, Mysidae, Heteromysini) from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa, with first documentation of a mysid-cephalopod association. ZooKeys, 685, 15–47.
taxon_text_1_5625: Robust benthic mysid generally found singly, perched on rocks on shallow reefs. Best identified in the field by the unusual eyes, which usually bear dramatic circular markings centred on the top of the eye, giving the appearance that the animal is staring upwards (in fact crustaceans have compound eyes and there is no pupil or iris, so the eyes are looking in all directions at once!). There is also a characteristic arc-shaped blue spot on the sides of the thorax. The tongue-shaped telson has short, evenly-spaced spines along its sides and two longer ones at tip. Colour is very variable.
taxon_text_3_5627:
Global: Endemic

Local/Regional: Currently know only from False Bay and west coast of the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_5628: A recently discovered species, first collected by local diver Guido Zsilavesz, after whom the species is named. Found at various sites around the Cape Peninsula and False Bay, sitting on hard substrata among algae, sponges and bryozoans, etc. Reluctant to swim and, when disturbed, moves a short distance then quickly settles again on the bottom.
taxon_text_5_5629: Dissected individuals had remains of small crustaceans in their stomachs, including amphipods, copepods and ostracods; indicating that they are predators on small prey.
taxon_text_6_5630: As in all mysids the eggs are retained in a marsupial sac until fully developed.
taxon_text_7_5631: One of about 12 regional species in this genus, a morphological key to which is provided by Wittmann and Griffiths (2014), but easily recognized on the field by its unique eyes and blue spot on thorax.
taxon_text_8_5632:
Wittmann, KJ & Griffiths, CL (2014). Description of the 'stargazer mysid' Mysidopsis zsilaveczi sp.nov. (Mysida, Mysidae, Leptomysinae) from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. Crustaceana, 87 (11-12), 1411-1429.

Wittmann, KJ & Griffiths, CL (2018). A new species of Mysidopsis Sars,1864 from the Atlantic coast of South Africa, with ¬¬supplementary descriptions of two additional species and notes on colour and diet (Mysida: Mysidae: Leptomysinae: Mysidopsini). Journal of Crustacean Biology, 38(2), 215-234.
taxon_text_1_5635: Although this small species has long been well-known to divers and has an established common name, it has yet to be scientifically described and formally named. The column is marked with rows of violet or purple spots and while normally short and squat, can be greatly extended to allow the animal to bend over and feed on items on the adjacent rock surface. The oral disc is plain and lacks any radiating stripes, but there are usually purple spots at either end of the mouth. There are up to 48 short, stubby white tentacles with purple tips.
taxon_text_2_5636: Column typically about 10 mm high and wide. When extended can reach at least 50 mm length.
taxon_text_3_5637:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine on West coast to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5638: Uncommon and usually found singly on vertical rocks below low tide level. Nothing further known about biology.
taxon_text_5_5639: Prey unknown, but almost all anemones are unselective predators, feeding on a wide variety of invertebrate taxa. This species has been observed to greatly extend the body and reach over to engulf living organisms on adjacent rock, but what species are eaten has not been determined.
taxon_text_6_5640: No details known, but most anemones can both reproduce sexually by releasing sperm and eggs into the water to merge and form plankton larvae, and by division of the adult.
taxon_text_7_5641: Possible to confuse with Violet spotted anemone (Anthostella stephensoni), which is also cream and has purple spots on the column, but that species is larger and has distinctive bright red radiating lines across the oral disc from the mouth to the bases of the tentacles.
taxon_text_8_5642:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_5655:
The Phylum Chaetognatha comprises only about 70 small, almost entirely planktonic, marine species. The body is elongate and dart-shaped and consists of a head bearing a circle of curved chitinous grasping spines and a pair of dorsal eyes, followed by an elongate trunk bearing one of two pairs of lateral fins and a tail fin.

Most of the commonly encountered coastal species belong to the family Sagittidae, which have two pairs of lateral fins and two rows of teeth. Common regional genera include Parasagitta, Pseudosagitta, Serratosagitta and Mesosagitta, but microscopic examination is required to identify specimens to species level.
taxon_text_3_5657:
Global: Not identified to species, so not possible to state distribution.

Local/Regional: Family found across region.
taxon_text_4_5658: Although small, chaetognaths can be extremely common in plankton samples and are important predators of smaller planktonic animals, particularly copepods, but also larval fish and other arrow-worms. They are thus an important link in the food chain. They alternately float and swim using dorsoventral undulations of the body to dart forward and then resting with the fins extended. There are no gills and gas exchange is across the body wall.
taxon_text_5_5659: Voracious feeders, detecting prey from vibrations in the water then darting forward to seize the victim with their grasping spines and injecting it with a bacteria-derived toxin (tetrodotoxin – the same toxin famous for making certain puffer-fish toxic to eat). The prey may be as large as the predator and some chaetognaths have been reported to eat as much as 37% of their own body weight each day!
taxon_text_6_5660: Chaetognaths are hermaphrodites with internal fertilization via a spermatophore transferred from the donor to recipient, following a short signalling interaction. The eggs are fertilized as they pass out of the oviduct and are usually simply ejected into the water, although in some species they may remain attached to the body surface of the parent for some time. Development is direct into tiny arrow-worms, without a larval stage.
taxon_text_7_5661: About 30 species are known from South Africa and they need to be examined microscopically to identify them to species level.
taxon_text_8_5662:
Gibbons, MJ (1997). An introduction to the Zooplankton of the Benguela Current Region. NBD Goodwood, Western Cape.

Stone, JH (1969). The Chaetognatha community of the Agulhas Current: its structure and related properties. Ecological Monographs, 39(4), 433-464.

Stuart, V & Verheye, HM (1991). Diel migration and feeding patterns of the chaetognath, Sagitta friderici, off the west coast of South Africa. Journal of Marine Research, 49(3), 493-515.
taxon_text_1_5675:
Nematodes are an extremely diverse phylum of mostly small, slender and elongate worms. The body tapers at both ends and is covered by a tough cuticle, but is otherwise fairly featureless, unless examined under a high-powered microscope. Although nematodes are abundant across almost all marine (as well as terrestrial and freshwater) habitats and include a wide diversity of both free-living and parasitic forms, identification is thus difficult and the group remains poorly studied and un-noticed by most observers.

The large species illustrated here was common among the byssal threads of mussels in the intertidal zone at Muizenberg, but remains unidentified.
taxon_text_2_5676: Typically <20 mm body length, but the species depicted unusually large at about 30 mm.
taxon_text_3_5677:
Global: Cosmopolitan in almost all marine habitats.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Knysna.
taxon_text_4_5678:
Numerous free-living species are known from marine habitats in South Africa, although probably far more species remain undescribed that are named!

Coles (1977) already reported more than 60 regional free-living species, many of which he recorded from False Bay. Most of these were from grab or dredge samples of soft benthic substrata, but the species shown here is from a rocky shore and is probably un-described.
taxon_text_5_5679: Most free-living nematodes are thought to feed on diatoms, fungi, bacteria or tiny invertebrates, including other nematodes.
taxon_text_6_5680: Most free-living species have separate sexes, females often being larger than males. After copulation the sperm (which are unusual in that they lack flagella and creep around like amoebae) migrate to the uterus where the eggs are fertlised, covered in a tough shell and released into the environment. There is no larval stage and the eggs hatch directly into tiny worms.
taxon_text_7_5681: Nematode worms have few external features and are very difficult to identify without microscopic examination. To view features of many of the free-living marine species in the region see Cole (1977) as cited below.
taxon_text_1_5685:
Monogeneans are mostly external parasites of vertebrates, especially fish. They are adapted for life on the skin or gills of often fast-moving hosts by being dorso-ventrally flattened and having an enlarged posterior organ (the haptor) armed with hooks and suckers to ensure firm attachment to the host. They lack specialised respiratory or circulatory systems and rely on diffusion across the body wall for respiration.

This species has been found on the gills of both Snoek and Pomfret and has an elongated, milky-white body and a lobed posterior attachment organ bearing a ring of about 9 suckers.
taxon_text_3_5687:
Global: Unknown, as only identified to family level.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_5688: Parasitic on the gills of both Snoek and Pomfret (Brama brama). Move about on the gills with an inchworm like motion.
taxon_text_5_5689: Many monogeneans feed on the mucous and superficial cells of the hosts, but some secrete a protease that digests the host’s skin and are able to access its blood.
taxon_text_6_5690: Monogeneans have a direct life cycle that does not involve a secondary host. Each individual has complex hermaphroditic reproductive organs, but individuals cross-fertilise, copulation usually involving an exchange of sperm. Some species release eggs directly in the water, while others are viviparous and release well-developed larvae which immediately settle onto other hosts.
taxon_text_7_5691: Many monogenean species occur in the region but each tends to be confined to one or a group of related hosts.
taxon_text_8_5692:
Acosta, AA & Smit, NJ (2021). A first for Southern Africa: description of a new Heterobothrium (Monogenea: Diclidophoridae) parasitizing the evileye pufferfish Amblyrhynchotes honckenii (Tetraodontiformes: Tetraodontidae). Parasitology Research, 120(3), 819-830.

Nunkoo, MAI, Reed, CC & Kerwath, SE (2016). Community ecology of the metazoan parasites of snoek Thyrsites atun (Euphrasen, 1791)(Perciformes: Gempylidae) off South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 38(3), 363-371.

Weston, M, Nunkoo, I, Reed, C & van der Lingen, CD (2021). Ectoparasites infecting the heads and gills of commercially valuable marine fishes in South Africa. African Zoology, 56(4), 303-311.
taxon_text_1_5705: As a group, ostracods are easily recognized by the fact that the body is protected by a pair of dorsally-hinged valves of ‘shells’ that largely conceal the body and limbs. Although they are common in most marine habitats (indeed we have found up to five clearly-distinct species in single sediment samples), we have been unable to source a single paper that names or describes any marine species from South Africa. By contrast about 150 freshwater species are known from the region.
taxon_text_2_5706: Most ostracods are small (less than about 2 mm in length) although a few ‘giant’ species reach up to 30 mm.
taxon_text_3_5707:
Global: Cosmopolitan

Local/Regional: Found in most marine habitats throughout the region, including on rocky shores, but especially in sediments from the intertidal to the deep sea.
taxon_text_4_5708: No research has been done on the biology of marine ostracods in South Africa and no regional species have even been named. Their biology is thus unknown. They are common in sediment samples but also found under boulders, in kelp holdfasts, etc.
taxon_text_5_5709: This is a large and diverse group that included scavengers, filter-feeders, herbivores and predatory species.
taxon_text_6_5710: Mating in ostracods from other regions usually occurs during swarming in the water column. Male copepods have two penises and the sperm cells are very unusual in that they are enormously large and are coiled up when in the testes – when uncoiled individual sperm may be up to five times the length of the adult ostracod! Eggs may be laid directly into the water or attached to the substratum, or to algae. A few species brood their eggs inside the shell and  only the release them as larvae, which already have a hard shell.
taxon_text_7_5711: The number of regional marine species remains unknown and the group is in dire need of investigation. Morphology of observed species differs widely, some being smooth, other strongly patterned, ridged or ornamented. Shape may be bean-shaped, others round or oval. Most species have a smooth outline, but many have a distinctive anterior notch, though which the hairy antennae project.
taxon_text_1_5715:
Strange, transparent, planktonic animals found in surface waters worldwide. Resemble tiny tadpoles (or giant sperm cells!), with a long flat, flexible tail and a small sea-squirt-like body attached at right angles to the tail and containing the organs. Usually surrounded by much larger, delicate spherical mucus ‘houses’ used to capture food.

South African species are little studied and it is not possible to allocate specific names to regional species, certainly not on the basis of photographic images. Since several genera and at least 19 species in the family Oikopleuridae have broad global distributions it is, however, likely that a number of different species occur in South Africa waters.
taxon_text_2_5716: Body about 5 mm long (excluding tail), house up to the size of a golf ball (other much larger larvaceans occur in other genera).
taxon_text_3_5717:
Global: Not identified to species, but genus widespread globally.

Local/Regional: Throughout region (may be different species in different areas, but not identified to species level).
taxon_text_4_5718: Common planktonic species, but small and fragile, so seldom noticed and usually damaged if caught with conventional plankton nets. A current is generated thought the house by beating of the elongate flattened tail. The house is replaced several times a day and discarded houses may form an important component of marine snow, which sinks slowly to the ocean floor and supports many deep-sea benthic organisms. Some larvaceans are bioluminescent.
taxon_text_5_5719: Secretes a remarkable mucus house through which it pumps water by beating the large, flattened tail. The house has a course mesh on the incurrent side to strain out large particles and a much finer mesh to retain fine organic particles, down to the size of bacteria, on the other, exhalent side. Food collected on this sieve is constantly transported to the mouth. Very fine particles can be captured, allowing larvaceans to feed on minute particles as small as bacteria and unavailable to other filter-feeders with more conventional feeding organs (like gills). Once the house gets clogged with filtered material the entire structure is discarded and sinks slowly to the ocean floor and a new one is constructed. This happens several times a day!
taxon_text_6_5720: Reproduction is sexual, eggs and sperm being released into the water. Fertilised eggs develop into tadpole larvae and the tail moves from the rear to the side of the body as these metamorphose into the adult form.
taxon_text_7_5721: Larvaceans are unlikely to be confused with other groups, but other families and genera are also found in the region, including some (possibly genus Bathochordaeus) that make a large circular, pleated house resembling at transparent croissant!
taxon_text_8_5722:
Fenaux R, Bone, Q & Deibel, D (1998). Appendicularian distribution and zoogeography. In Q. Bone [ed.], The biology of pelagic tunicates. Oxford University Press, Oxford.

Gibbons, MJ (1997). An introduction to the Zooplankton of the Benguela Current Region. NBD Goodwood, Western Cape.

Jaspers, C, Nielsen, TG, Carstensen, J, Hopcroft, RR & Møller, EF (2009). Metazooplankton distribution across the Southern Indian Ocean with emphasis on the role of larvaceans. Journal of Plankton Research, 31(5), 525-540.
taxon_text_1_5735:
Small, transparent, white or pink leech with a sucker at each end. Body smooth, the anterior part narrowly extended and with four red eye-spots arranged in a square at the head (not visible in preserved material). Posterior half of body elongate-oval.

Also easily recognized by its habit of living on the bodies of rock–lobsters, particularly on the abdomen and pleopods.
taxon_text_2_5736: Body length typically 4 mm, but up to 9 mm.
taxon_text_3_5737:
Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_5738: A long-known but only recently formally described species associated with rock-lobsters and presumed to feed on their blood. Usually found on the abdomen and particularly on the pleopods. Often numerous leeches present on each host.
taxon_text_5_5739: Probably feeds on the blood of the rock-lobster Jasus lalandii although some leeches found on crustaceans do also feed on the blood of fishes.
taxon_text_6_5740: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but leeches are hermaphrodites and although some brood their young, most lay their eggs in a cocoon attached to the favoured substratum, in this case probably the host.
taxon_text_7_5741: Very few marine leeches have been reported from South Africa and this is the only species known to occur on rock-lobsters. The smooth, transparent body, 4 red eye spots (not visible in preserved specimens) and narrow anterior extension of the body are characteristic features. It is presumed here that the species described by Utevsky is indeed the same as that previously reported from this host by Day and by Branch et al. The descriptions of body form are similar, although Utevsky reports the eyes being absent in preserved specimens and these are clearly visible in the live image in Branch et al. It is common for eye pigments to disappear in alcohol though, so this is probably a function of  the description being based only on preserved material.
taxon_text_8_5742:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64, as Heloblella sp.).

Day, JH (1969). A guide to marine life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town (p. 67, as Helobdella)

Utevsky, AY (2004). A new species of marine leeches (Hirudinea, Piscicolidae) from the coastal waters of South Africa. Vestnik Zoologii, 38(5), 79-83.
taxon_text_1_5745: Uncommonly seen and usually solitary. Fairly easily recognized by the elongate, flexible body that tapers towards anterior end, presence of a sucker at each end of the body, inchworm-like mode of locomotion and particularly by ring of wart-like tubercles on each body segment.
taxon_text_2_5746: Body length typically about 20 mm, but can be up to 50 mm.
taxon_text_3_5747:
Global: Widespread in Indo-Pacific and recently observed by C.L. Griffiths in Namibia.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5748:
A long-known but only fairly recently formally described species.  Parasitic on a wide range of fish species in both fully marine and estuarine habitats. Infests cultured fish in Australia, the Philippines and Malaysia, causing mortality among infected fish and causing secondary bacterial infections.

In South Africa has been found on a variety of coastal fishes, as well as freely moving around under boulders on rocky shores. Known to be responsible for transmitting hemogragarine and trypanopome blood parasites between various species of coastal fishes in the region.
taxon_text_5_5749: Feeds on the blood of a variety of fish species, especially klipfishes (family Clinidae).
taxon_text_6_5750: Leeches are hermaphrodite and although some species brood their young, most lay their eggs in a cocoon. In this species cocoons take about 7 days to hatch at 27 C and only another 9-10 days was required for juveniles to grow into mature adults. Self-fertilization has also been reported in this species.
taxon_text_7_5751: Very few marine leeches have been reported from South Africa and this is the only common species found free-living in the intertidal zone. It is unlikely to be confused with any other regional leech due to the wart-like tubercles on the body.
taxon_text_8_5752:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64, as Pontobdella sp.).

De Silva, PHDH (1963). Zeylanicobdella arugamensis gen. nov. and sp. nov. from Arugam Kalapu, Eastern Province, Ceylon. Spolia Zeylanica, 30(1):, 47-53.

Hayes, PM, Smit, NJ, Seddon, AM, Wertheim, DF & Davies, AJ (2006). A new fish haemogregarine from South Africa and its suspected dual transmission with trypanosomes by a marine leech. Folia parasitologica, 53(4), 241-248.
taxon_text_1_5755:
Myzostomids are a very unusual group of polychaetes with superficially unsegmented, oval bodies that lack any distinct head and have only five pairs of short, hooked, caterpillar-like appendages. All are obligatory symbionts of echinoderms, particularly crinoids, and while most are mobile and roam over the host, stealing food from it, others form galls or cysts around themselves, or are internal parasites living in the gut, body cavity or gonads.

This is a free-roaming, oval species found only on the arms of the elegant feather-star Tropiometra carinata. It has a yellow ground colour and a row of five oval black patches dorsally along each side, the overall effect closely matching the colour pattern of its host. It is the only free-living myzostomid currently known from South Africa, and the only species found in the temperate waters of the Atlantic coast. Other species have been seen and photographed on crinoids along the tropical east coast though and these may well represent other, undescribed species.
taxon_text_3_5757:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from False Bay.
taxon_text_4_5758:
This species was only recently discovered and is currently reported only from False Bay, although as its host has an extensive distribution from False Bay eastwards, its true range is almost certainly much more extensive. Individuals are seen moving along the arms of the host and are thought to steal food from the ambulacral groove by reaching around with the proboscis and sucking this up!

In False Bay 62% of hosts inspected carried at least one myzostomid and infected individuals carried a mean of 7 and a maximun of 32 myzostomids each.
taxon_text_5_5759: Parasitic, stealing food from the ambulacral groove running down the arms of the host.
taxon_text_6_5760: Mysostomids are hermaphrodite, some changing from initially being male to female as they grow and others (including this species) being simultaneous hermaphrodites. Males have paired penises and fertilization is internal. The fertilized eggs of other Myzostoma species are very small (50 microns in diameter) and are released into the water, where they give rise to non-feeding planktonic larvae, which have a short larval life of 5-8 days before settling on new hosts. After settling, the larvae undergo further development in a cyst before becoming free-living.
taxon_text_7_5761: Unmistakable and the only free-living myzostomid currently known from the temperate regions of South Africa.
taxon_text_8_5762:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Lanterbecq, D, Hempson, T, Griffiths, C & Eeckhaut, I (2009). Myzostoma fuscomaculatum (Myzostomida), a new myzostome species from False Bay, South Africa. Hydrobiologia 619, 145-154.
taxon_text_1_5765:
Fairly short, broad-bodied worm with the dorsal surface completely covered by 15 pairs of large, overlapping scales. Each scale has a central white area encircled by a broad purple margin. The scales become smaller and more strongly purple-coloured towards the anterior end.

Also easily recognized by its obligate commensal relationship with the heart urchin Spatagobrissus mirabilis. Appears to be an undescribed species, although another similar species, but with different colour patterns, is known from other heart urchin in the region.
taxon_text_3_5767:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from False Bay, although the host urchin does extend into Namibia.
taxon_text_4_5768:
Recently discovered by the Sea Change Team while investigating species associated with the host urchin. Observed crawling through the spines of the heart-urchin Spatagobrissus mirabilis, with which it appears to be an obligate commensal.

A sample of 10 urchins taken to investigate numbers of commensals associated with each host yielded a total of four polychaetes with no more than one polychaete found on any one of the urchins sampled.
taxon_text_5_5769: Carnivorous, feeding on small invertebrates. The gut contents contained fragments of amphipods, many individuals of which are also commensal among the spines of the urchins.
taxon_text_6_5770: Little is know about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_5771:
Scaleworms are easily recognised as a group due to the flat dorsal scales that cover all, or much of, the body, but there are more than 50 species in the region and many of these are hard to distinguish from each other. Useful clues to species identification include number of pairs of scales, and whether these cover the whole, or only the front half of the body, as well as scale colour and ornamentation.

This species is easily recognised by the wide purple borders on the scales and by its obligate relationship with this particular heart urchin. A similar species, M. capensis is also found associated with another urchin Spatangus capensis, which occurs in deeper waters in the region, but this differs in colour pattern, the elytra being described as having the posterior two-thirds uniformly dark-coloured.
taxon_text_8_5772:
Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 Errantia (p. 48 onwards, genus entries).

Pettibone, MH (1993). Scaled polychaetes (Polynoidae) associated with ophiuroids and other invertebrates and review of species referred to Malmgrenia McIntosh and replaced by Malmgreniella Hartman, with descriptions of new taxa. Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology, 538, 1-92.
taxon_text_1_5775: Firm, fairly large, usually white or pale worms with a distinctly rectangular cross-section and dis-proportionately tiny, conical, pentagonal head that bears just a very short pair of antennae and another of palps. The eyes are absent or externally invisible. When everted, the proboscis is large and bulbous, and is lined with longitudinal rows of soft fleshy lobes and ends in a ring of finger-like papillae. The parapodia are broad and flat with two well-separated lobes, between which there is a curled and lobed gill. The dorsal and ventral blood vessels are often conspicuous.
taxon_text_3_5777:
Global: Group has a worldwide distribution.

Local/Regional: Genus found from Namibia to Mozambique (several similar species each with differing distributions).
taxon_text_4_5778: Fairly large, active worms that burrow in sandbanks and feed on benthic invertebrates. Have a reputation of being difficult to identify to species level and several different taxa often occur in the same sample.
taxon_text_5_5779: Carnivorous, thought to feed on molluscs, other worms and smaller crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_5780: Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released via the anus onto the sediment surface or directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_5781: The rectangular cross-section and small, pentagonal head make these worms fairly easy to identify to group, but species are hard to separate from one another and require detailed microscopic examination.
taxon_text_8_5782:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 340 onwards).
taxon_text_1_5785:
Very small worms that live in minute, coiled, white, calcareous shells that are firmly cemented by one side to rocks, shells or other hard surfaces. The head bears a small number of usually bright-red, feathery feeding appendages and when the worm retracts the aperture is closed by a funnel-shaped, stalked operculum.

In reality there are a large number of similar species that fall into several genera, but as these require microscopic examination and a good deal of skill to separate, we treat the entire group as a unit here.
taxon_text_2_5786: Coiled shell typically about 2 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_5787:
Global: The group is cosmopolitan.

Local/Regional: Found throughout the region.
taxon_text_4_5788: Certainly the most common of all polychaete worms and found in enormous numbers (of many thousands per square meter) on virtually all hard surfaces, including rocks, mollusc shells, the exoskeletons of larger crustaceans and the fronds of larger algae, as well as virtually all man-made structures placed into the sea!
taxon_text_5_5789: Filter feeders, removing fine particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_5790: Cross-fertilizing hermaphrodites and brood the eggs inside the tube, releasing the eggs at an advanced stage of development, such that they spend only a few hours in the water before settling on nearby surfaces. Grow to maturity within about 2 months and lifespan is typically about a year.
taxon_text_7_5791: The minute size and coiled shell identify the group, but there are numerous species, some that are fairly easily distinguished in that, for example, they have ridged or anticlockwise–coiled shells, but most of which require expert examination to identify to species level.
taxon_text_8_5792:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 793 onwards).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 78).

Knight-Jones, P, Darbyshire, T, Petersen, ME & Tovar-Hernández, MA (2017). What is Pseudopotamilla reniformis (Sabellidae)? Comparisons of populations from Britain, Iceland and Canada with comments on Eudistylia and Schizobranchia. Zootaxa, 4254(2), 201-220.
taxon_text_1_5795: Very easily identified to group, as the body is long, soft, and cylindrical and the segments greatly elongated, each bearing short rows of hooked setae. The body thus resembles a length of bamboo. Each species has a consistent number of segments. The head in this genus is unusual, comprising a flat, oblique plate with a raised rim and no other appendages. The even more characteristic last segment is in the form of a frilly, flared funnel, within which the anus opens. There are about 10 regional species and these are difficult to distinguish from one another.
taxon_text_3_5797:
Global: The group is widespread, but as this entry is not to species level, global distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Members of genus found across region.
taxon_text_4_5798: Burrow head down into the sediments and secrete a friable tube made out of pieces of shell and sand cemented together with a membranous lining. The anal cone blocks the upper entrance to the tube. Found on sheltered sandbanks and also in sandy pools on rocky shores.
taxon_text_5_5799: Ingest sand, from which they digest organic particles, including protists and bacteria.
taxon_text_6_5800: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that sperm and eggs are released into the water column and that these develop into planktonic larvae. Have good powers of regeneration and if segments are lost the exact correct number of segments typical of each species is regenerated.
taxon_text_7_5801: Easy to identify to group, but there are several species that can only be distinguished by microscopic examination. The genus Nicomache is similar in overall body form, but the head has an arched dorsal keel and lacks the flat plate found in Euclymene. Again there are several species which make sandy tubes, typically on boulders partially buried in sand.
taxon_text_8_5802:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 645 onwards).
taxon_text_1_5805:
Bamboo worms are very easily identified to group, as the body is long, soft and cylindrical and the segments greatly elongated, each bearing short rows of longish hooked setae. The body thus resembles a length of bamboo. Each species has a fixed number of segments.

The head in this genus has an arched dorsal crest and is extended into a short point, but has no other appendages. The last segment is in the form of a distinctive frilly, flared funnel with a ridge part way along it, and the anus opens within the funnel. There are several regional species and these are difficult to distinguish from one another.
taxon_text_3_5807:
Global: The group is widespread, but as this entry is not to species level, global distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Members of genus found across region.
taxon_text_4_5808: Burrow head down into the sediments and secrete a friable tube made out of pieces of shell and sand cemented together with a membranous lining. The anal cone blocks the entrance to the tube.  Usually found attached to the sides of boulders that are buried in or are lying on sand.
taxon_text_5_5809: Ingest sand from which they digest organic particles, including protists and bacteria.
taxon_text_6_5810: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that sperm and eggs are released into the water column and that these develop into planktonic larvae. Have good powers of regeneration and if segments are lost the exact correct number of segments typical of each species is regenerated.
taxon_text_7_5811:
Easy to identify to group, but there are several species that can only be distinguished by microscopic examination.

The genus Euclymene is similar in overall body form, but the head consists of a flat plate with a raised rim. Again there are several species in that genus which make sandy tubes in sand or in sand-inundated areas on rocky shores.
taxon_text_8_5812:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 621).
taxon_text_1_5575:
Members of this unusual group are small, soft-bodied barnacles that lack their own shells, but instead occupy burrows excavated into other calcareous substrata, particularly mollusk shells (but also corals, limestone and even coralline algae). Sexes are separate (unlike other barnacles, which are hermaphroditic), but males are minute, non-feeding and live attached to the much larger females.

This species can be distinguished by its short, compact body; relatively large, boat-shaped aperture and pair of large hook-like processes that project from posterior end of this aperture. The body and feeding appendages are also bright red.
taxon_text_2_5576: Female up to 5 mm, aperture 1–2 mm, dwarf males 0.6 mm.
taxon_text_3_5577:
Global: Endemic

Local/Regional: Along the coast of Western and Eastern Cape provinces from northern suburbs of Cape Town to just east of East London.
taxon_text_4_5578:
Females excavate burrows in the shells of various molluscs and also commonly in thicker species of coralline algae. Many larger gastropod molluscs may be infected, especially Abalone (Haliotis midae), which may host over 200 females in a single shell. Smaller numbers also recovered from Turbo, Burnupena, Argobuccinum, and in the Eastern Cape Ranella and Mancinella shells. Also sometimes found in the shell plates of the Giant chiton (Dinoplax gigas). The burrow openings are oval, with one end broader than the other (‘boat shaped’).

The most common and easily seen burrowing barnacle in the region, but in the Western Cape often found in the same hosts with the smaller Australophialus turbonis. Empty burrows of this barnacle are often occupied by the unique amphipod Ampelisca excavata (see that entry), which appears to be restricted to, and anatomically adapted to live only in this specialised niche.
taxon_text_5_5579: Females feed by projecting their feather-like limbs through the burrow opening and combing them through the water.
taxon_text_6_5580: Most barnacles are hermaphroditic but burrowing barnacles are unusual in having separate sexes, the males being tiny, non-feeding and attached to the much larger females. Larvae are initially brooded then released to seek out and burrow into new hosts.
taxon_text_7_5581: Often occur in the same shells as the smaller Australophialus turbonis, but that species is usually white in colour, has a long neck and smaller oval aperture. It also lacks the pair of distinct hook-like processes projecting from the opening that best identify W. spinosa.
taxon_text_8_5582:
Botha, TPA & Griffiths CL (2021). South African Acrothoracia (Crustacea: Cirripedia). Zootaxa 4949 (1), 048–078.

Botha, TPA, Griffiths, CL & Maneveldt, GW (2020). Coralline red algae – a new host taxon for burrowing barnacles (Cirrepedia, Acrothoracica). Marine Biodiversity 50(1), 6.
taxon_text_9_5340: The taxonomy of this species-complex is still not fully resolved and the South African species is sometimes referred to as B. edeni. Both names may in fact be valid, as two forms, with somewhat different sizes and distribution patterns, occur in the region and future research may result in these being recognised as separate species.
taxon_text_1_5341:
Body relatively slender and elongated, with a pointed head and three characteristic longitudinal ridges running along the head, one down the centre and one along either side. Small, hooked dorsal fin situated far (two-thirds) along the back. Flippers small and dark. Throat grooves between 42–54 and extend far back along the belly to the naval. Tail flukes broad and triangular, their hind margin concave with a central notch.

Colour black with a lighter belly. Some populations bear numerous round gray scars on their flanks, the result of bites by cookie-cutter sharks. The blow is low and bushy.
taxon_text_2_5342: Maximum length of males about 13 m and of females 14 m and mass up to about 38 tonnes. Members of the offshore population somewhat larger than those in inshore population.
taxon_text_3_5343:
Global: Worldwide in tropical, subtropical and temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_5344:
Unique among baleen whales in remaining in warmer waters and not making annual migrations between the poles and lower latitudes. 

There appear to be two subpopulations in the southern African region – an inshore one mostly resident on the Agulhas Bank and that follows shoals of pelagic fish up the east coast in winter, and a west coast population of mostly more offshore animals. The populations also differ slightly in mean size (west coast form slightly larger) and shape of the baleen plates. The offshore west coast population also bear numerous scars from the bites of cookie-cutter sharks, these being rare in the south coast inshore population.

Bryde’s whales are usually found singly or in small, loose groups that assemble where prey is abundant. They are lunge feeders, swimming upwards though shoals of fish with the mouth and throat massively distended. They are not deep divers and usually undertake a series of short dives, each lasting about one minute, often followed by a longer dive of about five minutes.

Bryde’s whales were often not distinguished from Sei whales by early whalers, making fishing statistics unreliable, however, it is thought that they were less impacted than most other species by commercial whaling. The South African population was estimated as 582 individuals in 1983.
taxon_text_5_5345: Feeds mostly on pelagic shoaling fish, mainly anchovy, maasbanker and pilchard, but also on shoaling squid and euphausiids.
taxon_text_6_5346: Both males and females reach sexual maturity at about 12–13 m and an age of 8–13 years. Reproduction takes place throughout the year (as it is not driven by the seasonal migration patterns typical of other baleen whales). Gestation period is estimated at 12 months and calves are born at a length of 3.4–4.0 m and mass of 1 000 kg. Calves are nursed for 6–12 months.
taxon_text_7_5347: Unlikely to be confused with other regional whales due to the small, hooked and well set-back dorsal fin and unique ridges on the head.
taxon_text_8_9181:
Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 78).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 58).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 364).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 56 – as B. edeni).
taxon_text_1_5695: Relatively fat species with the body distinctively curved into a U-shape, the upper surface dark brown (never black) and the lower surface much lighter yellow to grey. The tube feet are large and arranged into five distinctly-defined bands, each containing 4-6 rows (declining to 2-3 rows at extremities of body). There are ten more or less equal-sized black tentacles. Habitat also distinctive, lying buried in sand in crevices adjacent to rocks, to which the tube feet are strongly attached.
taxon_text_2_5696: Body length up to about 90 mm, excluding tentacles.
taxon_text_3_5697:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_5698: A crevice-dwelling species living buried beneath the sand with only the tentacles and anus reaching the sand surface and the body entirely buried. Always attached to rocks though, and not found in open sand. Can be very common in suitable sites, where rows of animals line sand-filled crevices. When feeding, the black tentacles reveal their presence, but when tentacles retracted can only be found by digging in the sand.
taxon_text_5_5699: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.
taxon_text_6_5700: Not studied in this species, but in most sea cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_5701: The bent horseshoe shaped body shape and specific habitat preferences are fairly distinctive and unlikely to be confused with other local species.
taxon_text_8_9174:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 117).
taxon_text_1_5725: Elongated, shrimp/lobster-like crustaceans, typically recognised by the large and powerful raptorial claws resembling those of a praying mantis. 15–17 teeth on the finger of the raptorial claw. Eyes stalked and T-shaped with large bilobed cornea. Rostral plate smooth, either semi-circular or elongated to form point. Smooth carapace, thorax and abdomen. Short carapace partly covers thorax which is comprised of four segments visible from above. Six segments make up the abdomen with paddle-like swimming pleopods and ending in a characteristic telson and pair of uropods. Telson with a central smooth boss and four small, fixed teeth; without any small teeth between primary teeth. Colour in life unknown. Description (Barnard, 1950) describes a pinkish overall colour.
taxon_text_2_5726: Total length (TL) measured from rostrum to telson, excluding antennae. Males TL up to 112 mm, females around TL 45 mm.
taxon_text_3_5727:
Global distribution: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: False Bay, Agulhas Bank, Knysna Estuary Gqeberha (formerly Port Elizabeth) and Coffee Bay.
taxon_text_4_5728: Associated with level sand or mud substrates suitable for their burrowing lifestyle. Inhabits U-shaped burrows with two entrances. Relatively rare with no recent sightings and few preserved specimens. Known only from South African waters, shore to 88 m. Reported from False Bay at depths between 18–88 m. Like all mantis shrimps, the species possess highly specialized compound eyes with more photoreceptor types than any other animal. Each eye acts independently with a wide range of motion and has the ability to see ultra-violet and infrared light. Some species can even see polarized light with up to 16 visual pigments.
taxon_text_5_5729: Highly specialized benthic predators, mantis shrimp either exhibit an extended raptorial claw for spearing or a folded dactylus in the form of a club for smashing. These two methods of striking prey define two broad functional groups within the Stomatopoda: the ‘spearers’ and the ‘smashers’. Lysiosquilla capensis is expected to be a nocturnal predator similar to other species of family Lysiosquillidae and will ambush prey from their burrows and attack by spearing prey with their toothed claws. With extremely high attack speeds, the mechanism involves a spring and latch structure located at the base of the raptorial claw which creates a spring-loaded strike. Spearers typically have slower attack speeds when compared to the smashers. It is thought that while smashers need to apply a greater force to stun their usually hard-shelled prey, spearers rely on a greater reach with their strategy of ambushing soft-bodied prey (Anderson et al. 2014). Expected to predate on soft-bodied prey such as shrimp and fish and be a prey species for predatory fish, seals, seabirds and dolphins.
taxon_text_6_5730: Mating strategy unobserved for L. capensis but species of Lysiosquilla are known to be monogamous. Females carry and care for the eggs, holding and using the maxillipeds to clean and circulate water around them. Once hatched larvae are predatory and use their raptorial appendages to hunt. It takes 1 to 3 months for the larvae to go through several developmental stages before becoming adults. Lifespan unknown for species but mantis shrimps typically live 3 to 6 years, but some species have been known to live for 20 odd years.
taxon_text_7_5731: Other than Lysiosquilla capensis, only two species have been recorded for False Bay, Cape Town; Natosquilla investigatoris and the endemic Cape mantis shrimp Pterygosquilla capensis.  Species distinguished by smooth carapace, thorax and abdomen as well as form of the telson. See Brokensha et al. (2022).
taxon_text_8_5732:
Anderson, PSL, Claverie, T & Patek, SN (2014). Levers and Linkages: Mechanical Trade-Offs in a Power-Amplified System. Evolution, 68(7), 1919-1933.

Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive list of South African stomatopod Crustacea (Mantis Shrimps). Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 838– 933.

Brokensha, RM, Landschoff, J & Griffiths, CL (2022). Review of the South African and Mozambican stomatopod fauna. M.S. thesis, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa.

Manning, RB (1969). Notes on some stomatopod Crustacea from southern Africa. Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology, 1, 1–17.
taxon_text_1_5825:
Tangle worms, or spaghetti worms as they are also sometimes known, of this family are easy to recognize as a group, as the head bears a tangle of multiple, elongate, sticky, grooved tentacles (correctly termed palps) that are extended out from the burrow to gather food. Behind the palps are tufts of gills, which are usually bright red, but may be unbranched, or branched in tree-like fashion (dendritic). The body is soft, floppy and tapering and generally enclosed within a fragile, sandy tube. The segmental appendages (parapodia) are normally short ridges and are devoid of gills.

The group is very diverse, with over 40 regional species and these are hard to identify to species level, especially as the gills and tentacles have a tendency to break off if the worm is handled! This genus differs from most other coastal common genera in that the gills are un-branched.
taxon_text_3_5827:
Global: The group is widespread, but as this entry is not to species level, so global distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Members of genus found across region.
taxon_text_4_5828: Construct fragile mucus tubes of sand and shell particles, usually attached to the sides of boulders buried in sand, on the undersides of rocks in sandy pools, etc. The worm remains in the tube and extends the feeding palps (tentacles) in all directions to collect organic particles. These are then not transported back to the mouth along ciliated grooves (as in fanworms for example), but rather the tentacle itself is periodically withdrawn and food particles licked off it by the mouth.
taxon_text_5_5829: Detritus feeders, extending the tentacles to gather fine organic material from of the sediment surface.
taxon_text_6_5830: Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and some Theleus species are known to lay their eggs in cocoons attached to the outside of the tubes.
taxon_text_7_5831:
Easy to identify to group, but there are many genera and species that can only be distinguished by microscopic examination.

The Lobed tangleworm Telothelepus capensis also has unbranched gills, but its head is extended into a long, frilly lobe from the margins of which the tentacles emerge. It is also mostly estuarine. Species of the genera Nicolea, Terebella and Loimia are also common, but all have branched, not simple, gills, two pairs in the first two of these genera and three pairs in Loimia.
taxon_text_8_5832:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 727 onwards).
taxon_text_1_5835:
Several similar species occur in the region and are difficult to identify from photographs, which tend not to show taxonomically important features, such as the aperture shape. The genus is thus presented here as a group.

Easily identified to genus by their thin, very fragile, violet, globular shells and their unique habit of floating upside-down on the sea-surface beneath a raft of mucus-coated bubbles. Operculum absent, body blue to violet.
taxon_text_3_5837:
Global: World-wide in temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but more common on Indian Ocean coast.
taxon_text_4_5838: A remarkable group of planktonic gastropods that spend their entire lives floating beneath the surface of the ocean, hanging beneath a raft of mucus-covered bubbles secrete by the foot. Frequently washed ashore after storms. The shell is unusually reverse countershaded, because of its upside down position in the water column. It is thus darker on the upward-facing aperture side, disguising it against the dark ocean when viewed from above, but paler on the spire side, making it less visible against the bright sky when viewed from below!
taxon_text_5_5839: Predators, feeding on pelagic hydroids such as the Bluebottle Physalia physalis, the Blue button Porpita porpita and the By-the-wind sailor Velella velella.
taxon_text_6_5840: Protandrous hermaphrodites, starting adult life as males and later changing to become females. Most species lay pear-shaped eggs capsules and attach these to the underside of the float. A single float may carry up to 400 egg cases of varying ages and these become darker as they mature towards the distal end of the float. There may be 75-7500 larvae per egg case (depending on species) and these hatch into planktonic larvae. The largest species J. janthina is an exception in this regard, as it broods the young within the ovary and does not lay egg cases.
taxon_text_7_5841: There are several related species that occur on the same shores. The large J. janthina has a squarish, dark aperture, while J. globulosa has an elongate, pear–shaped aperture and J. pallida a very pale shell that is only purple anteriorly. In J. exigua the shell is ornamented with fine ridges that form a v-shaped notch in the aperture where they meet.
taxon_text_8_5842:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 188)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 79).
taxon_text_1_5845:
Shell cowrie-like, pure white and with a smooth, glossy external texture and very inflated globular shape. Spire very short and more of less parallel-sided; aperture runs length of the underside. Both inner and outer lips of aperture bear a series of transverse teeth, but these do not extend across smooth glossy ventral surface, or onto dorsal surface.

In life the shell is usually completely obscured by the mantle, which is very variable on colour pattern. The usual colour is pale pinkish with small black spots, each surrounded with a while halo, but can be pure white, yellow with meandering white lines, or with larger black spots.
taxon_text_3_5847:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_5848:
Most common on the west coast in depths of 8-70 m and on the S. coast tends to occur in cooler, deeper waters. Normally associated with compound ascidians, on which it feeds.

Colour pattern thought to mimic various toxic dorid nudibranchs, such as Doriopsilla spp.
taxon_text_5_5849: Feed on compound ascidians, biting of the tough test with the jaws to get to the soft tissues inside.
taxon_text_6_5850: Not specifically studied in this species, but other species in the genus embed vase-shaped egg capsules inside the host ascidians. Each capsule contains numerous eggs and in British species the larvae are planktonic.
taxon_text_7_5851:
This species is largely defined by the white, very inflated, smooth shell and the mantle colour. The closely related T. ovulata normally has a pink shell and greyish-white mantle. Many other species in the genus have transverse ridges that extend across the ventral surface, or right around to the dorsal surface of the shell.

Species level identifications within this genus are complicated though, as there are some 30 similar endemic species in the region. Also, these species are largely defined by features of the shell, which is usually concealed by the mantle in live images. To complicate matters further, mantle colour can be highly variable within species! Readers are referred to the detailed accounts in Liltved (2000 - see refs below) for more information and multiple images showing variations within these species.
taxon_text_8_5852:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 186)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 59).

Liltved, WR (2000). Cowries and their Relatives of Southern Africa (second edition). Gordon Verhoef, Seacomber Publications (p. 162).
taxon_text_1_5855: Well-known and very attractive ‘top-shaped’ shell, the base sharply separated from the conical upper section by an acute angle.  Apex comes to a sharp point. Umbilicus closed. Each whorl marked with fine spiral ridges of which 2-3 are markedly stronger. Colour red to violet, often with lines of light blotches around the lower whorls. Aperture smoothly rounded and lacking an internal tooth. Operculum round, horny and flexible. Head and foot bright orange; there are distinct eyes at the bases of the long, orange tentacles.
taxon_text_3_5857:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to about East London.
taxon_text_4_5858: The commonest of several Calliostoma species found in the region and the only one extending a far west as False Bay. Usually found singly in the low intertidal, but extends down to 50 m depth. Habits poorly known but often found on seafans, on which it might feed.
taxon_text_5_5859: Unknown, but may feed on seafans, with which it often seems to be associated.
taxon_text_6_5860: Reproduction in this species has not been studied, but other members of this genus have separate sexes and lay their eggs in a sheet or ribbon of jelly, the eggs lacking a planktonic swimming stage, but rather hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.
taxon_text_7_5861: Several other similar Calliostoma species occur along the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal coasts, but this is the only common species in the Western Cape. The similarly top-shaped and mottled red members of the genus Clanculus have a distinctly open umbilicus and a strong tooth in the aperture.
taxon_text_8_5862:
