Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 39).
taxon_text_1_5875:
Body very elongate, slender, and flexible, armored with 56–64 ring-like plates. Snout characteristically longer than rest of head and with a small, tubular, terminal mouth. Pectoral fin small, dorsal fin low but elongate, caudal fin rounded and situated at end of elongate, mobile tail.

Colour cryptic greeny-brown.
taxon_text_3_5877:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Walvis Bay in Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5878: Common in estuaries and lagoons, especially among seagrass beds, but also on the open shore among seaweeds, especially in more sheltered sites and to a depth of at least 110 m. Very cryptic and moves slowly through the substratum, much like a snake, stalking small crustaceans and similar prey, which are ingested using a sudden sucking action.
taxon_text_5_5879: Feeds on small arthropods such a planktonic copepods, amphipods and (in estuaries) insect larvae.
taxon_text_6_5880:
Sexual maturity is reached at a length of 12 cm and reproduction occurs from November to March.

The unusual mode of reproduction is similar to that in seahorses (which are in the same family). The female deposits her eggs in the male’s pouch, where they are fertilized. Development then takes place within the male’s pouch and fully-developed young are released.
taxon_text_7_5881: Unmistakable and the only pipefish in the region, although there are other rarer species in estuaries in the eastern Cape and in KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_8_5882:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 276).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 141).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 2 (p. 493).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 220).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 457).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 29).
taxon_text_1_5885:
Members of the family Arcturidae are unusual, isopods that have elongate bodies that are usually bent between the thorax and abdomen. The antennae are often very long and the second to fourth pairs of walking limbs elongate and setose for filter-feeding, while the last three pairs are much shorter and adapted for clinging. The fourth thoracic segment is often greatly elongated and/or laterally expanded.

This species has a greatly expanded fourth thoracic segment that is raised posteriorly into a large, blunt, upright projection. The colour pattern is also distinctive as both the elongate, robust antennae and the enlarged triangular thoracic segment are dark red-brown and the rest of the body white. Although several species in this genus are known from South Africa, this species appears to be new to science.
taxon_text_3_5887:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Known only from the collections site at Kommetjie on the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_5888: This specimen was found under a boulder in an intertidal rock pool but members of this group are typically associated with hydroids, bryozoans, octocorals and other sedentary invertebrates, to which they cling, extending the front part of the body into the water column to filer feed.
taxon_text_5_5889: Presumed to be a filter-feeder, like most other members of this family, grasping floating particles with the setose anterior limbs.
taxon_text_6_5890: As with all isopods, the eggs are retained in a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_5891: This species appears to be undescribed, although six other members of this genus are known from the region (described and depicted in Kensley 1978 under the generic name Arcturella, which has now been incorporated within Astacilla).
taxon_text_8_5892:
Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 19 – this species not featured but several others in the genus depicted as Arcturella species).

Kensley, BF & Schotte, M (1984). Redescription of Arcturella lineata (Stebbing) from South Africa (Crustacea: Isopoda: Arcturidae). Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 97(1), 240-244.
taxon_text_1_5895:
Tiny, cylindrical amphipods with unusually short, relatively-fat antennae of equal length and made up of only a few elongate segments and with vestigial flagellum. Head bearing a round eye made up of individually-visible ommatidea. First pair of limbs (gnathopod 1) very slender and lacking claws; second pair (gnathopod 2) with claws, which can be large in males. Last two abdominal segments (urosome segments 2-3) fused.

There are several regional species in this specialized family of very small commensal amphipods, which includes only the two genera Colomastix and Yulumara, both of which are represented in South Africa. Although there are four described species of Colomastix in the region, of these only C. pusilla is found in the South Western Cape. The setose species depicted below appears to be another as yet undescribed form.
taxon_text_3_5897:
Global: Family widely distributed. The most common regional species is Colomastix pusilla, which is reputedly widespread across Europe, the Mediterranean and Black Sea, as well as the Caribbean and Southern Africa (although this may in reality represent a complex of similar species). The depicted species has only been recorded from the Cape Peninsula and is probably undescribed.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5898: Species in this group are commensal in the cavities within sponges or tunicates. They are probably far more species diverse and numerous than existing samples indicate, as they are easily missed when sorting samples and most pass though the 1 mm sieves used by most researchers to wash benthic samples prior to processing. The depicted species is common in the body cavities of ascidians. Few other details of biology known.
taxon_text_5_5899: Assumed to scavenger on food particles pumped though the internal cavities of sponges and tunicates, within which the amphipods dwell.
taxon_text_6_5900: As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release. Given the small size of the species, females carry only a few relatively very large eggs in their brood pouches.
taxon_text_7_5901: In South Africa, Colomastix is represented by only four species, of which only C. pusilla is reported in the Western Cape. However, the group has been very poorly sampled and studied and, based on their diversity in other better researched regions, other species almost certainly remain undescribed. The only other genus in the family is Yulumara, which is represented by a single regional species, Y. improvisa, recovered from kelp holdfasts on the Cape Peninsula. That unusual species is easily distinguished by its knobbly body, greatly expanded and flattened basal segment of antenna 1 and toothed ramus of uropod 3.
taxon_text_8_5902:
Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 31).

Lecroy, S (1995). Amphipod Crustacea III. Family Colomastigidae. Memoirs of the Hourglass Cruises, 9, 1-139.

Milne, R & Griffiths, CL (2013). Additions to and revisions of the amphipod (Crustacea: Amphipoda) fauna of South Africa, with a list of currently known species from the region. African Natural History, 9(1), 61-90.
taxon_text_1_5905: Small, fairly plump, shiny-blue beetle. Head blue, first thoracic segment (pronotum) with laterally extended orange lobes. Elytra shiny metallic blue with fine stipples. Abdomen fat and extending well beyond tips of elytra, orange, but with last two segments metallic blue.
taxon_text_3_5907:
Global: Unknown.

Local/Regional: Common amongst dry drift kelp and other driftline debris in western Cape.
taxon_text_4_5908: There are more than 15 similar species of this very diverse and little known genus recorded from South Africa so it is not possible to identify this beetle to species level. It is, however, common amongst wrack along the driftline of sandy beaches. Most species in this group are predatory so this species may well feed on fly larvae of other typical decomposers common in wrack. Very active and runs rapidly as soon as exposed but reluctant to fly.
taxon_text_5_5909: Probably feed on small invertebrates associated with kelp wrack.
taxon_text_6_5910: Details unknown, but the larvae of most species in the is family are predatory.
taxon_text_7_5911: Many similar species in the region, but the red shoulders on the pronotum and littoral habits fairly characteristic.
taxon_text_8_5912: Wittmer, W (1988). Neue Gattungen und neue Arten der Familie Malachiidae (Coleoptera) hauptsächlich aus dem südlichen Afrika. Annals of the Transvaal Museum, 34(25), 557-619.
taxon_text_1_5915:
Adult beetle oval and black, with patch of white hairs of sides of thorax. Antennae end in a three-segmented club and can be folded back against the body. Ends of elytra serrated and inner corners end in a pointed spike. Underside of body largely white. Perhaps best identified by its association with the rotted carcasses of dead animals, especially birds and mammals.

Very distinctive larvae seen more often than adults and are dark brown, covered in long reddish-brown hairs. End of the abdomen bears a pair of conspicuous curved, horn-like projects called urogomphi.
taxon_text_2_5916: Adults 5-10 mm, depending of amount of food available to larvae.  Larvae up to about 20 mm.
taxon_text_3_5917:
Global: Cosmopolitan and found on all continents except Antarctica.

Local/Regional: Entire region, both inland and along coast.
taxon_text_4_5918:
Common in terrestrial habitats where associated mainly with the carcasses of dead animals that have decomposed for some time, particularly those of mammals and birds. The age and stage of development of larvae can be used to estimate time of death, including the bodies of murder victims!  Adult beetles generally arrive 5-20 days after death and larval development takes 5-7 weeks, depending on temperature. Also can be pest of stored animal products, such as dog food, dried fish, bacon, etc.

On the seashore, larvae are commonly found scavenging on sandy beaches along the west coast, especially in the vicinity of seal and bird colonies, where dead animals are regularly cast ashore. Adults usually seen only on well decomposed and dried bodies cast up along on the driftline.
taxon_text_5_5919: Feed on well-decomposed carrion, on the seashore especially dead seals and seabirds.
taxon_text_6_5920: Females lay eggs in crevices on the food material. Larval development normally takes 5-7 weeks, depending on temperature and food available. When ready to pupate the larvae construct an oval pupation chamber on a solid surface, such as bone or wood. Adults live for 4-6 months and disperse to search for new food items by flying.
taxon_text_7_5921: There are about 85 regional species of dermestid beetles, but the white hairs of this species are fairly distinctive and it is by far the most common species found on the seashore.
taxon_text_8_5922: Picker, MD, Griffiths, CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 264)
taxon_text_1_5925:
Striking beetles with slightly-flattened bodies, long legs, prominent eyes and large, curved scimitar-like mandibles. The metallic coloured thorax is fringed by white setae and the elytra are yellowish with characteristic complex patterns of black markings.

There are over 20 similar species in the region, distinguished mostly by subtle differences in the pattern of black lines or blotches on the elytra, so the genus is treated here as a group and species level identification is not attempted.
taxon_text_3_5927:
Global: Genus widespread across Africa, Asia and Europe.

Local/Regional: Entire region, both inland and along coast.
taxon_text_4_5928:
Common in sandy areas, both inland and along the seashore. Active in heat of the day and appear to be seasonal, being seen mostly in summer. Run rapidly and if disturbed tends to fly close to the ground for a short distance and then settle again. Active predators pouncing on other insects and grasping them with their sharp mandibles.

The larvae are also predatory and occupy vertical burrows in the sand with the head positioned level with the surface. They lunge out to grasp passing prey with their large mandibles and then pull them back into the burrow.
taxon_text_5_5929: All species are predatory on other insects and those found on the shore adjacent to kelp beds appear to target mainly kelp flies.
taxon_text_6_5930: The elongated larvae live in vertical burrows excavated in the sand and also have large mandibles with which to predate other invertebrates. They have unusually long lives, some species taking 1-3 years to complete their larval development.
taxon_text_7_5931: There are about 150 regional species in this family, some other genera also having black and yellow markings, but most species found on the seashore belong to this genus. The plain yellow Night tiger beetle also occurs in the intertidal along the west coast, but is strictly nocturnal.
taxon_text_8_5932: Picker, MD, Griffiths, CL & Weaving, A (2019). Field Guide to Insects of South Africa. Third Edition. Struik Nature, Cape Town, 527 pp. (p. 230)
taxon_text_1_5935: Strange-looking hydroid with a tall, rounded, white central part (the hydranth) with a terminal mouth and covered in densely-packed, very short tentacles. Basal part surrounded by a single ring of about 17 long, unbranched, floppy, pink branches, each bearing 4-8 reproductive gonophores near the base and over 25 button-like white structures distally.
taxon_text_2_5936: Individuals typically about 30 mm tall, usually found in colonies.
taxon_text_3_5937:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from False Bay and the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_5938:
May be seen singly, or in quite extensive colonies of tens or even hundreds of closely-associated individuals (which probably originated by budding of an original specimen), usually in overhangs and in 10-30 m of water. Frequently associated with the false coral bryozoan Laminopora jellyae.

Nothing else is known about the biology of this remarkable species, which is known only from a few photographic records and even fewer preserved samples.
taxon_text_5_5939: Members of this family have a mouth at the end of the central hydranth and are predatory. Related species have been seen bending over and ensnaring amphipods and isopods, which are then passed to the mouth and engulfed.
taxon_text_6_5940: No details on this species, but males and females separate. In related species anemone-like actinulae larvae are released and each have about 18 tentacles.
taxon_text_7_5941: Easily recognized to group, but can be confused with the closely-related Gnome’s hat hydroid C. capensis, which always seems to be solitary and occurs under boulders or attached to algae intertidally and in shallow water. It also has a longer, dark pink hydranth and many short, tangled basal branches that bear large (1 mm diameter) ball-like gonophores.
taxon_text_8_5942:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52, note incorrect image, which is of C. capensis).

Hewitt, CL & Goddard, JH (2001). A new species of large and highly contractile hydroid in the genus Candelabrum (Hydrozoa: Anthoathecatae) from southern Oregon, USA. Canadian Journal of Zoology, 79(12), 2280-2288.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56, as Myriothela tentaculata).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 46, as Myriothela tentaculata).
taxon_text_1_5945:
Colonial hydroids with an erect, repeatedly branched, bushy appearance. The stems are enclosed in a firm sheath that bears several rings (is ‘annulated’) at the base of each branch. The polyps are relatively large, extend from the tips of the sheath and bear a single whorl of longish tentacles. Reproductive structures emerge from below the tentacles.

Stems often brown and polyps pink.

Although fairly easy to identify to genus, there are several very similar species in the region and their classification remains confused, so only a generic identification is given here.
taxon_text_2_5946: Polyps less than 1 mm, colonies up to 170 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_5947:
Global: Over 100 species in this large genus and species occur all around the globe.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_5948: Widely distributed on rocky reefs, algae and other hydroids and common fouling organisms on ship’s hulls and other man-made structures.
taxon_text_5_5949: Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
taxon_text_6_5950: Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) usually borne on different colonies, but there are species which have hermaphrodite colonies. Male reproductive individuals consist of several bulbous chambers. Females consists of a branched stem (spadix) arching around a single large egg.
taxon_text_7_5951: The rigid, annulated sheath and bushy colony form are fairly characteristic.
taxon_text_8_5952:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 26).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 79).
taxon_text_1_5955:
Delicate, relatively flat, saucer-shaped bell with a smooth, fairly-thick, clear central portion surrounded by a thinner marginal area marked by very variable (16->2000) number of straight, unbranched radiating canals. Tentacles long and thin, each originating from a basal bulb along the margin of the umbrella. Colour transparent with opaque radiating canals.

Two species, A. forskalea and A. coerulescens, are known from the west coast region of South Africa, but differentiating between photographs of these is very difficult, so we stick to a genus level identification here.
taxon_text_3_5957:
Global: Along the west coast of Africa from Morocco to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_5958: Actually a hydrozoan with an unusually large medusa stage, but included in this section as closely resembles jellyfish of the class Scyphozoa. Pelagic species found over the continental shelf and along the coast across the region. Can be seasonally abundant. Contain bioluminescent proteins.
taxon_text_5_5959: Feed on soft-bodies plankton including other jellyfish, also copepods and other planktonic organisms.
taxon_text_6_5960: Have a dimorphic life cycle, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and releases gametes into the water which fertilise and settle onto hard surfaces where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_5961: Fairly easily recognised by the flat body shape and delicate appearance.
taxon_text_8_5962:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 52).
taxon_text_1_5965:
Delicate, saucer-shaped, transparent bell thickened towards the center. Eight equally-spaced notches present in the margin of the bell, which has a large number of short tentacles along its margin. Four frilly oral arms project from the underside. Four pigmented gonads are visible though the transparent bell.  

The genus contains at least 25 described and many other undescribed forms. Many species are very similar to one another and accurate species-level identifications are difficult, so the group is only dealt with at genus level here.
taxon_text_2_5966: Bell up to about 400 mm across, but usually much smaller.
taxon_text_3_5967:
Global: Genus common in coastal waters globally. 

Local/Regional: Previously thought to be absent from South Africa, but this un-named species recently reported from SW Cape.
taxon_text_4_5968: Usually in coastal waters. Can become very common in some parts of the world and interfere with fishing operations by clogging and damaging fishing nets. Do not have dangerous stings.
taxon_text_5_5969: Like many other jellyfish feed primarily on zooplankton. These may include the larvae of commercially important fish.
taxon_text_6_5970: Have a dimorphic life cycle, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and males release strings of sperm into the water which are sucked in by females to fertilise their eggs. Larvae are released into the water and ultimately settle onto hard surfaces where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_5971: Fairly easily recognised by the delicate transparent bell with its many marginal tentacles, as well as the opaque gonads.
taxon_text_8_5972:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome.
taxon_text_1_5975:
Transparent and pear-shaped pelagic species, slightly broader at the one end and with two trailing tentacles at the other end that bear short, club-shaped side-branches. There are eight equal ciliary rows that each run for about 75% of body length.

There are no formally described species from this genus reported from South Africa so it is not possible to allocate a species name to regional images.
taxon_text_3_5977:
Global: There are 17 described species in this genus, which occurs worldwide.

Local/Regional: Photographic records from False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_5978: Known only from a few photographic records and has not yet been described or named, so very little known about biology. Hyperiid amphipods sometimes seen associated with this species, as seen in image below.
taxon_text_5_5979: Presumed to feed on small planktonic organisms captured by the tentacles, which lack stinging cells (as found in cnidarians), but are instead armed with adhesive cells (colloblasts) with which to ensnare small prey.
taxon_text_6_5980: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae which gradually adopt the adult form.
taxon_text_7_5981: Similar to Sea-gooseberies Pleurobranchia sp., from which they are distinguished by body shape, Hormiphora being wider at the one end like a pear, while Pleurobranchia are round to oval but symmetrical in shape.
taxon_text_8_5982:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Gibbons, MJ, Haddock, SH, Matsumoto, GI & Foster, C (2021). Records of ctenophores from South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e10697.
taxon_text_1_5985:
Strikingly beautiful transparent animal with an elongate-oval body that is characteristically covered in numerous small papillae and divided into two broad lobes. Four bands of cilia extend from the top of the animal and two long, trailing tentacles arise next to the mouth.

Since some taxonomically-important features require examination of specimens, it is not possible to identify the images taken to species level.
taxon_text_3_5987:
Global: Eight species are described from tropical and temperate waters worldwide. 

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_5988: A pelagic species, found swimming in coastal and oceanic waters. Capable of swimming rapidly using jet propulsion, but unlike most other ctenophores often switch off their ciliary rows and just drift passively though the water with the lobes held widely extended. Small prey then adhere to the papilliae on the body surface, although the tentacles also act in prey capture.
taxon_text_5_5989: Species in this genus feed mostly on copepods.
taxon_text_6_5990: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae. Members of this genus are also known to self-fertilise.
taxon_text_7_5991: Fairly easily recognised to genus by the papillae covering the body surface.
taxon_text_8_5992:
Gibbons, MJ, Haddock, SH, Matsumoto, GI & Foster, C (2021). Records of ctenophores from South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e10697.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 66).
taxon_text_1_5995:
Strange, flattened, benthic ctenophore found creeping on the surfaces of other benthic invertebrates and easily mistaken for a flatworm. Body lacking distinctive features and without the rows of setal combs characteristic of most other ctenophores. Two branched tentacles and extensible papillae arise from dorsal surface of body. Colour bright red and appears to always be associated with Purple soft coral Alcyonium fauri.

At least two different species have been reported in South Africa, the other being Coeloplana gonoctena, which has been reported form the alcyonarian Studeriotes longiramosa (formerly Sphaerella krempfi) in more tropical waters of KZN and Mozambique. The Cape species has not yet been formally named.
taxon_text_3_5997:
Global: Appears to be endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from False Bay, but probably more widespread as its host extends as far east as Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_5998: Known only from a few photographic records and has not yet been described or named so very little know about its biology other than host species.
taxon_text_6_6000: Almost all ctenophores are hermaphroditic and shed eggs and sperm into the water where fertilization takes place, leading to development of free-swimming larvae.
taxon_text_7_6001: Unique in appearance although sometimes misidentified as being a flatworm.
taxon_text_8_6002:
Gibbons, MJ, Haddock, SH, Matsumoto, GI & Foster, C (2021). Records of ctenophores from South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e10697.

Pople, W (1960). The occurrence of Coeloplana in Natal, South Africa. South African Journal of Science, 56(2), 39-42.
taxon_text_1_6005:
Cup-corals are solitary corals that lack symbiotic photosynthetic algae (are ‘azooxanthellate’) and hence often live in caves and other dark overhangs, or at great depths, where there are low light levels. Each polyp lives in a separate, small stony cup, although individuals often live in groups. The outer surface of the cup may be parallel-sided, or strongly flared, but is generally smooth. The inner surface of the cup is ringed with radiating septa of varying number and design. The living polyps are normally red in colour.

Members of this genus are relatively small and have more-or-less cylindrical cups, the inner surfaces of which are lined with radiating septa. There are seven local species that are difficult to distinguish in the field, so the genus is treated as a group here. Most previous guides identify the common local species as B. bonaespei, but the most recent guide (Filander et al. 2021) states that only a single specimen of this species has been collected since its original description in 1938 and that B. capensis is by far the more common species in the Western Cape.
taxon_text_2_6006: B. capensis cup about 16 mm diameter, B. bonaespei about 9 mm.
taxon_text_3_6007:
Global: Both B. capensis and B. bonaespei endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: B. capensis Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal; B. bonaespei Cape Peninsula and Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_6008: On vertical faces and under overhangs in shallower waters and extend to depths of at least 230 m.
taxon_text_5_6009: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_6010: Details unknown for local species, but a European species in this genus that has been studied is hermaphrodite and produces planula larvae. Daughter polyps may also bud from the base of larger individuals asexually.
taxon_text_7_6011: Several other genera occur in deeper waters, but in shallower waters frequented by divers the only other common genus is Caryophyllia, which has a tusk-shaped cup arising from a narrow base and had a group of scroll-like plates in the center of the oral cavity.
taxon_text_8_6012:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 42).

Filander, ZN, Kitahara, MV, Cairns, SD, Sink, K. J & Lombard, AT (2021). Azooxanthellate Scleractinia (Cnidaria, Anthozoa) from South Africa. ZooKeys, 1066, 1.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 44).

Sink, K, Gibbons, M, Laird, M & Atkinson L (2018) Phylum Cnidaria. In: Atkinson L. and Sink K. Field Guide to Offshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malechite Marketing, Pretoria (p. 93).
taxon_text_1_6015:
Cup-corals are solitary corals that lack symbiotic photosynthetic algae (are ‘azooxanthellate’) and hence often live in caves and other dark overhangs, or at great depths, where there are low light levels. Each polyp lives in a separate, small stony cup, although individuals often live in groups. The outer surface of the cup may be parallel-sided, or strongly flared, but is generally smooth. The inner surface of the cup is ringed with radiating septa of varying number and design. The living polyps are normally red in colour.

Members of this genus have cups that are bent and expand dramatically from a narrow base, giving a tusk- or horn-like shape. There is both an outer circle of septa lining the cup and an inner circle and these also surround a central group of finger-like or scroll-like twisted central plates. As there are over 400 species in the genus globally and more than a dozen in the region, the local species are treated as a group here.
taxon_text_2_6016: Individuals up to about 20-40 mm across and 55 mm tall.
taxon_text_4_6018: On vertical faces and under overhangs in shallower waters and extend to depths of at least 300 m.
taxon_text_5_6019: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_6020: Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for local species, but species from other regions have separate male and female polyps. Females retain and brood their eggs until they have developed into planula larvae that are then released to have a short larval life (mean 8 days) before settling and beginning to develop the skeleton and tentacles typical of adults.
taxon_text_7_6021: Several other genera occur in deeper waters, but in shallower waters frequented by divers the only other common genus is Balanophyllia, which are generally smaller (10 mm diameter), have more-or-less cylindrical cups and lack central projections within the outer ring of septa.
taxon_text_8_6022:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 42).

Filander, ZN, Kitahara, MV, Cairns, SD, Sink, K. J & Lombard, AT (2021). Azooxanthellate Scleractinia (Cnidaria, Anthozoa) from South Africa. ZooKeys, 1066, 1.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 44).

Sink, K, Gibbons, M, Laird, M & Atkinson L (2018) Phylum Cnidaria. In: Atkinson L. and Sink K. Field Guide to Offshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malechite Marketing, Pretoria (p. 92).
taxon_text_1_6035:
Colonies consist of a series of hard, solid and well calcified, brittle, interconnected plates that are usually yellow, orange or red and are often bristling with spines and avicularia, giving them a furry appearance.

Two difficult to distinguish species occur in the Western Cape – C. capensis and C. septispina and these are dealt with as a group here.  (A third species, C. atypica, occurs in the Eastern Cape but, as indicated by the name, has an atypical, encrusting colony form and is found on mussel shells).

When viewed closely the individual zooecia are more or less diamond-shaped and irregularly arranged.
taxon_text_2_6036: Individual zooecia less then 1 mm long, colonies up to 20 cm across.
taxon_text_3_6037:
Global: Both species endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Chaperia capensis Cape Peninsula to East London, C. septispina known only from False Bay.
taxon_text_4_6038: Form upright folded colonies on rocky substrata in gullies and the sides of deep rock pools and on reefs to a depth of about 100 m. Often mingled with other sedentary invertebrates, such as sponges, other bryozoans and soft corals. Very little other species-specific information available.
taxon_text_5_6039: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_6040: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins. New colonies formed by sexual reproduction, fertilized eggs being released into the water column to disperse and establish new colonies.
taxon_text_7_6041: Chaperiopsis multifida forms similar brittle, calcified and folded colonies, but is maroon in colour and the zooecia have a pair of characteristic antler-like spines that obscure much of the front surface of each zooid. Several other genera form similar plates, but which are punctured by regularly-spaced holes rather than being solid.
taxon_text_8_6042:
Boonzaaier-Davids, MK, Ma, KC & Mcquaid, CD (2023). Epibiotic association of encrusting cheilostome bryozoans on shells of an invasive mussel from rocky shores of South Africa, with the description of a new aviculiferous species of Chaperia. Zootaxa, 5258(2), 197-210.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 128).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 12).
taxon_text_1_6055:
One of the most easily-identified lichens to group, by virtue of the pale grey-green colour and shrubby, branching appearance, usually arising from a single holdfast. Main stems somewhat flattened and giving rise to fine lateral branches near tips. Habitat also characteristic, being common either attached to coastal plants, or directly attached to soil or rocks in the immediate coastal zone.

The detailed taxonomy remains confused though and has been the subject of recent phylogenetic research (see references below) leading, among other changes to the erection of the new genus Namibialina for endemic southern African species. There may, however be several species within the N. angulosa complex and these are not currently resolved.
taxon_text_2_6056: Main branches up to 20 cm long, typically forming tangled bushes about 6 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_6057:
Global: Endemic to west coast of southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia southwards along west coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6058: Common and characteristic species that may form extensive fields in areas close to the coast along the Namibian coast. Less common in the southern parts of its range.
taxon_text_6_6060: Broken stems may form new colonies asexually. Spores are produced by small fruiting bodies on some of the branches and disperse to establish distant colonies.
taxon_text_7_6061: Easily recognized to group, but the detailed taxonomy of this species remains confused, partly because the type specimen is missing. Probably a species complex with different species in various parts of distribution.
taxon_text_8_6062:
Spjut, R, Simon, A, Guissard, M, Magain, N & Sérusiaux, E (2020). The fruticose genera in the Ramalinaceae (Ascomycota, Lecanoromycetes): their diversity and evolutionary history. MycoKeys, 73, 1.

Wirth, V (2010). Lichens of the Namib Desert: a Guide to their Identification. Klaus Hess Publishers, Gottingen- Windhoek (p. 56).
taxon_text_1_6065:
Common shrubby and finely branched, orange lichen typically growing upright on the twigs of shrubs along the coast, but also may be attached to rocks or gravel. The main branches are only about 0.5 mm in diameter and give rise to short even thinner margin branchlets to form a dense bush.

Reproductive structures (apothecia) are frequent and take the form of bright orange discs about 3 mm in diameter and are surrounded by a prominent margin that bears a frill of numerous orange to yellow fibrils.
taxon_text_2_6066: Bush typically about 30-80 mm across, apothecia 1-3 mm across.
taxon_text_3_6067:
Global: Endemic to west coast of southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia southwards along west coast of South Africa to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_6068: A common and characteristic species that may form extensive fields in areas close to the coast along the Namibian coast. Less common in southern parts of its range, where it is normally common on shrubs just above the drift-line on rocky shores where strong wave action generates sea-spray.
taxon_text_6_6070: Colonies can divide asexually by division. Spores are also produced within the apothecia and can spread to form distant colonies.
taxon_text_7_6071: Easily recognized to group, but there are in fact several regional species that differ in branching pattern and size and shape of apothecia. The similar T. puber has a denser structure and the main branches are flattened with the upper surface orange, but the lowed surface white or grey.
taxon_text_8_6072:
Almborn, O (1989). Revision of the lichen genus Teloschistes in central and southern Africa. Nordic Journal of Botany, 8 (5), 521–538.

Wirth, V (2010). Lichens of the Namib Desert: a Guide to their Identification. Klaus Hess Publishers, Gottingen- Windhoek (p. 36).
taxon_text_1_6075: Dorsally flattened mollusk with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide with minute, needle-like spicules on the top and smooth, pointed scales. Shell plates broadly rectangular with triangular anterior extensions. Middle plates have straight margins and raised sides. Texture of shell minutely granulose in radiating riblets that seem like pits to the naked eye, with characteristic dark spots (shell eyes) on the side areas and growth-lines. Yellow orange to chestnut colour with inner layer of shells white/pink.
taxon_text_2_6076: Large, typically around 20-55 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6077:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban.
taxon_text_4_6078: Found in the intertidal zone solitary under stones.
taxon_text_5_6079: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula, as in many gastropods.
taxon_text_6_6080: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6081: One of three regional species in the genus. Differs from C. herberti (Sodwana to Kosi Bay) and C. jeareyae (False Bay to Algoa Bay) by the yellow chestnut colour and pitted texture and shape of shell plates.
taxon_text_8_6082:
Ashby, E (1931). Monograph of the South African Polyplacophora (Chitons). Annals of the South African Museum, 30, 1–59.

Buckland‐Nicks, J & Reunov, AA (2010). Egg hull formation in Callochiton dentatus (Mollusca, Polyplacophora): the contribution of microapocrine secretion. Invertebrate biology, 129(4), 319-327.

Kaas, P & van Belle, RA (1985-2006). Monograph of living chitons (Mollusca: Polyplacophora), Volume 2: Suborder Ischnochitonina. Ischnochitonidae: Schizoplacinae, Callochitoninae & Lepidochitoninae: Brill, Netherlands.
taxon_text_1_6085: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating on its dorsal side, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide bearing fine spicules on the top, some longer, smooth spines close to the margin, as well as smooth, oviform, imbricating scales on the bottom. Shell plates broadly rectangular. Middle plates sharpen to the hind margin. Texture of shell minutely granulose with 6-7 longitudinal grooves on either side of the central area. Dark spots (shell eyes) closely set on the head valve, the side areas and the posterior area of the tail valve. Colour red, sometimes with white or cream blotches.
taxon_text_2_6086: Medium, typically around 5-17 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6087:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_6088: Found in the subtidal zone (15-18m) in between and under stones or reefs.
taxon_text_5_6089: Herbivorous – radula rasping algae off the rocks.
taxon_text_6_6090: External fertilization releasing eggs and sperm into the water. Eggs develop into planktonic trochophore larvae that metamorphose and then settle as juvenile chitons.
taxon_text_7_6091: One of three regional species in the genus, although only two have distributions in the Western Cape. Differs by means of flat lateral areas from Callochiton dentatus (Port Nolloth to Durban) and by both flat lateral areas and shell eyes not just restricted to the anterior third of the lateral areas from Callochiton herberti (Sodwana to Kosi Bay). The colour of this species is also very striking, separating it from the other two species.
taxon_text_8_6092: Dell'Angelo, B & Mifsud, C (1997). Callochiton jeareyae, a new species from South Africa (Mollusca, Polyplacophora). Bollettino Malacologico, 33, 25-28.
taxon_text_1_6095: Dorsally flattened mollusk with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide with small, ribbed scales and along the margin of to the shell as well as prominent bunches of small spicules with hyaline hairs. Articulamentum thin with subrectangular anterior extensions. Shell plates short, almost rectangular and raised lateral areas. Texture of shell with radiating riblets on outer areas and longitudinal riblets on the central areas quite coarse. Growth-lines also visible. Red-brown animal with cream shell plates covered with brown or red streaks and spots.
taxon_text_2_6096: Medium, typically around 10-30 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6097:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay, Hermanus and East London.
taxon_text_4_6098: Under rocks imbedded in sand in the subtidal zone only.
taxon_text_5_6099: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6100: External fertilization in surrounding water. Eggs hatch into planktonic trochophore larvae that is free-swimming, which later settle to the bottom and metamorphose to juvenile chitons.
taxon_text_7_6101: One of five regional species in the genus. Differs from the other species by the bunches of small spicules with hyaline hairs on its soft flesh and very fine shell texture centrally and lifted beads on ribs laterally. The other species have much more prominent sculpture or, as in C. papilio, a much more prominent girdle armour.
taxon_text_8_6102: Strack, H (1996). Report on a collection of South African chitons, including the description of a new Lepidozona species. Basteria, 59, 127-133.
taxon_text_1_6105: Dorsally flattened, eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide bearing characteristic large, thick and black spicules spaced out, bristles and small rectangular scales with a triangular protuberance. Articulamentum is thick with small brown spots on a white background with triangular/subrectangular anterior extensions. Shell plates near rectangular but rounded to the front with lifted sides. Texture of shell almost smooth, with microscopic pustules, middle area with backwards converging grooves. Growth lines are quite prominent. Brown or maroon shell with light brown or black stripes (sometimes with blue or white spots). Blue colour morphs rare.
taxon_text_2_6106: Large, typically around 40-70 mm total body length, though some up to 90 mm.
taxon_text_3_6107:
Global: Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: From Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6108: Often found in crevices and under rocks in low tide pools or on shallow reefs. Occasionally bears fouling organisms such as barnacles and crustose coralline algae.
taxon_text_5_6109: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6110: External fertilization in surrounding water. Eggs hatch into planktonic trochophore larvae which later settle and metamorphose into juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6111: One of five regional species in the genus. Easily identifiable by the almost smooth shell plates and the extremely hairy girdle with large, thick and dark spicules.
taxon_text_8_6112:
Kilburn, RN & Rippey, E (1982) Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg, xi + 249 pp. (p. 138).

Schwabe, E (2006). Taxonomic notes on chitons. On some species of Chaetopleura from South Africa (Mollusca: Polyplacophora: Ischnochitonidae). African Invertebrates, 47, 23–30. (p. 27, figs 3, 4).
taxon_text_1_6115: Dorsally flattened mollusk with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide with spicules rising from chitinous cusps, corneous hairs scattered in bunches, some bearing a terminal spicule. Also with rectangular scales that have a concave base and rounded top. Articulamentum thick and whitish pink with subrectangular anterior extensions. Shell plates near rectangular but with round sides. Shell sculpture coarse with longitudinal riblets and pits on central area of middle plates and front of tail plate; radially arranged pustules on most areas. Brown or reddish pink.
taxon_text_2_6116: Small to medium, typically around 10-20 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6117:
Global: Namibia, South Africa, Mozambique, as well as Gough Island.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6118: Under rocks in the low-tidal and subtidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6119: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6120: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6121: The radial numerous fine riblets on the side areas of the middle plate and the longitudinal fine riblets on the central and front tail plate areas separate C. pertusa from C. pustulata (KwaZulu-Natal). The granule sizes are small and prominent, while bigger in C. pustulata and less prominent in C. papilio (same region, but with very thick, dark spines covering the whole girdle).
taxon_text_8_6122:
Kilburn, RN & Rippey, E (1982) Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg, xi + 249 pp. (p. 138).

Schwabe, E (2006). Taxonomic notes on chitons. On some species of Chaetopleura from South Africa (Mollusca: Polyplacophora: Ischnochitonidae). African Invertebrates, 47, 23–30. (p. 27, figs 3, 4).
taxon_text_1_6125: Dorsally flattened mollusk with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates rectangular and centrally raised. Texture of shell characteristic with spaced-out and highly raised radially arranged large pustules on the sides (about 5 rows) and smaller, longitudinally arranged lower pustules on the centre. Girdle wide with scale-like spicules bearing chitinous cups or chitinous hairs, tips needle-like; elongated scales on the ventral side. Articulamentum thin and white with small subrectangular anterior extensions. Colour orange brown-pale.
taxon_text_2_6126: Medium, typically around 10-20 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6127:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay, Kommetjie, Muizenberg and Zout River.
taxon_text_4_6128: In crevices or under rocks in the intertidal to subtidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6129: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6130: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6131: One of five South African species, of which four are found in the Western Cape. The small size, long hairs and paleness, as well as the prominent granules in radial and longitudinal lines are characteristic.
taxon_text_8_6132:
Barnard, KH (1963). Contributions to the knowledge of South African marine Mollusca. Part IV. Gastropoda: Prosobranchiata: Rhipidoglossa, Docoglossa. Tectibranchiata. Polyplacophora. Solenogastres. Scaphopoda. Annals of the South African Museum, 47(2), 201–360. (p. 335, fig. 29i).

Kaas, P & Van Belle, RA (1985). Monograph of living Chitons (Mollusca: Polyplacophora). Vol. 1. Order Neoloricata: Lepidopleurina. E. J. Brill/W. Backhuys eds. Leiden 244 pp. (p. 91).
taxon_text_1_6135: Dorsally flattened with eight smallshell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a very wide,soft fleshy girdle. Girdle further broadening to the front, covered with hairs, scales and minute tufts visible under high magnifications and otherwise appears naked. Texture of shell with convex, raised granules and slight growth-lines. When turned over, gills extend halfway to the anus. The articulamentum is thin with small anterior extensions widely separated. Colour variably brown/yellow or pink/orange, mottled white and red. Subtriangular shell-plates with light central stripe.
taxon_text_2_6136: Large, typically around 20-40 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6137:
Global: Possibly in New Caledonia (unconfirmed), Philippines and Central West Africa, as well as South Africa.

Local/Regional: Hout Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_6138: Found in the subtidal zone on rocks and reef platforms.
taxon_text_5_6139: The only carnivorous chiton genus in South Africa, feeding on mobile invertebrates such as small crustaceans. Waiting for the right moment to strike the widened girdle is lifted up, then folded over to trap the prey underneath.
taxon_text_6_6140: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6141: One of three South African species in this genus but the only one in the Western Cape. The group is still under taxonomic consideration regarding species delineation.
taxon_text_8_6142: Schwabe, E & Els, R (2019). The genus Craspedochiton (Mollusca: Polyplacophora: Acanthochitonidae) in South African waters: what do we really know about it? Archiv für Molluskenkunde, 148(1), 73-92.
taxon_text_1_6145: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates are almost V-shaped with a lifted middle area sinking to the sides, then lifted on the lateral edges again. Texture of shell often eroded. If not, many flat, radiating ribs on the side areas and faint punctations on the rest of the plate. Girdle narrow and leathery with fine spinelets, cupped spicules and scattered tufts of spicules between the smaller spinelets. The articulamentum has wide, rounded anterior extensions. Colour grey or brown/green.
taxon_text_2_6146: Large, typically around 60-150 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6147:
Global: South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay (Western Cape) to Jeffrey’s Bay and once found in Northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6148: Under rocks and boulders in sand in intertidal zone, common on flat rocky reefs, often sand-covered in the subtidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6149: Herbivorous – catches dislodged algae such as kelp.
taxon_text_6_6150: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6151: This is by far the largest South African chiton and one of four South African species in this genus, but the only one present in the Western Cape. Other than the distribution and the large size, bunches of spines, as well as foveolate shell texture, separate this species from the others.
taxon_text_8_6152:
Ashby, E (1928). South African chitons, being a description of the Polyplacophora represented in the Turton Collection. Proceedings of the Malacological Society of London, 18 (2), 76-92. (p. 82, pl. 8, figs 22-24).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 162).

Kaas, P & Van Belle, RA (1985). Monograph of living Chitons (Mollusca: Polyplacophora). Vol. 1. Order Neoloricata: Lepidopleurina. E. J. Brill/W. Backhuys eds. Leiden 244 pp. (p. 110).

Kilburn, RN & Rippey, E (1982) Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg, xi + 249 pp. (p. 138, pl. 33, fig. 5).
taxon_text_1_6155: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates very even and rectangular with smooth, rounded edges. Shell texture with forwardly converging rows of granules along the areas aside the centre, leading to a minutely granulated, finer pattern towards the middle, while growth-lines surround the shell. Girdle with scales, clearly ribbed in 3-6 rows. Articulamentum white or blue with wide, rounded anterior extensions. Colour brown or pale white.
taxon_text_2_6156: Small, typically around 5-15 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6157:
Global: Islands of the Atlantic Ocean as well as South Africa and southern Angola.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.
taxon_text_5_6159: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6160: External fertilization, but eggs retained in the pallial fold between the animal’s foot and surrounding fleshy part where the eggs are brooded and grow until juveniles are ready to be independent.
taxon_text_7_6161: This is one of three brooding species that occur in the same region, but the other two, the Brooding chiton Radsia nigrovirescens and the Ribbed-shell chiton Rhyssoplax crawfordi have utterly different appearances and colour and cannot be confused. In the same genus, I. elizabethensis, I. oniscus and I. textilis co-occur, but all display much smoother or finer scales smooth to the naked eye. I. bergoti has more elevated valves and more prominent growth lines, but the biggest difference is in the clear ribbing on the girdle scales of I. bergoti which is absent or much reduced in the other species of the genus.
taxon_text_8_6162:
Ashby, E (1931). Monograph of the South African Polyplacophora (Chitons). Annals of the South African Museum, 30, 1–59.

Kilburn, RN & Rippey, E (1982) Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg, xi + 249 pp. (p. 139).
taxon_text_1_6165: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates short, very flat and rectangular with rounded margins widening to the back. Texture of shell with randomly dispersed to wavey patterns of circular granules. Growth lines very clear. Girdle narrow with smooth, thin, broad and clear scales with micro-striation. Articulamentum white with brown or grey blotches and medium, rounded anterior extensions. White to buff or olive brown.
taxon_text_2_6166: Small, typically around 5-10 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6167:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western Cape to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_6168: Grouped under smooth rocks in sandy pools in the intertidal-subtidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6169: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6170: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6171: Differs from I. oniscus by larger, polished, broader scales more densely arranged on the girdle and overall, randomly arranged, courser sculpture on the shell plates with granules more circular, central area also much less elevated and flatter than in I. oniscus. Differs from I. bergoti by having scales smooth to the naked eye and from I. textilis and I. indianus with having no punctation or ribs on shell plates.
taxon_text_8_6172:
Ashby, E (1928). South African chitons, being a description of the Polyplacophora represented in the Turton Collection. Proceedings of the Malacological Society of London, 18 (2), 76-92. (p. 85, pl. 6, figs 9-11).

Sirenko, B & Schwabe, E (2002). Taxonomic notes on chitons. 2. Taxonomic status of chitons of the Ischnochiton oniscus group. Spixiana, 25(3), 193–198.
taxon_text_1_6175: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates are short and almost rectangular but produced backwards in the middle. Texture of shell with irregular bumps, almost radial on head plate while more longitudinal or wavey on other plates, with many growth-lines. Girdle thin with spicules on the edge, while the top carries short opaque, brown and white, striated and thin scales. Shell plates with notched, rounded anterior extensions. Variable colour but mostly cream with brown and green patterns and blotches.
taxon_text_2_6176: Small, typically around 5-15 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6177:
Global: South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Hout Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6178: Grouped under smooth rocks in sandy pools in the intertidal-subtidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6179: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6180: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6181: Several species from the genus occurs in the region. Differs from I. textilis by smoother sculpture. Differs from I. elizabethensis by having striated scales and longitudinal sculpture on lateral areas, where more wavey in the case of I. elizabethensis. Differs from I. bergoti by more subtle scale sculpture and colour.
taxon_text_8_6182:
Ashby, E (1928). South African chitons, being a description of the Polyplacophora represented in the Turton Collection. Proceedings of the Malacological Society of London, 18 (2), 76-92. (p. 85, pl. 6, figs 9-11).

Sirenko, B & Schwabe, E (2002). Taxonomic notes on chitons. 2. Taxonomic status of chitons of the Ischnochiton oniscus group. Spixiana, 25(3), 193–198.
taxon_text_1_6185: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating dorsally, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide with ridged scales. Shell plates rectangular with side margins rounded and lateral areas visible. Texture of shell with radial granulose riblets radiating on lateral area, and with punctuated diamond-shaped pits and radiating riblets on central area. Growth lines visible. Articulamentum thin and white with notched, wide, short and triangular anterior extensions. Turned over, the gills fill the whole fold between the foot and ventral surrounding flesh and reach the anus. Variable colours, often orange, white or brown with cream, while shell often shows zebra stripes.
taxon_text_2_6186: Medium, typically around 20-30 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6187:
Global: Southern Africa including Angola.

Local/Regional: West Coast to Umsikaba, KwaZulu-Natal
taxon_text_4_6188: Under boulders in the low-tidal to subtidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6189: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6190: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6191: The most common and easily distinguishable of the several regional species of Ischnochiton due to its shell texture. Western Cape specimens have smoother sculpture, while specimens from the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal have coarser sculpture.
taxon_text_8_6192:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 160).

Krauss, F (1848) Die Südafrikanischen Mollusken. Ein Beitrag zur Kenntniss der Mollusken des Kap- und Natallandes und zur Geographischen Verbreitung derselben mit Beschreibung und Abbildung der neuen Arten. Ebner and Seubert, Stuttgart, 140 pp., 6 pls. (p. 38, pl. 3, fig. 5).
taxon_text_1_6195: Chitons have eight dorsal shell plates surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Animal oval shaped. Shell plates are thicker than most others in the genus, rectangular with thin, rounded anterior shell extensions and clear lateral areas. Elevation of this species is quite high compared to others. Texture of shell smooth to the naked eye with aesthete canals visible on some areas and some growth-lines. Last shell-plate with a steep slope. Girdle with spicules and many tufts of long, curved needles between the plates. Another row of tufts near the edge, which is also surrounded with smooth, ribbed needles. Some scales on the bottom. Underside with gills extending only from half down the animal to the anus. Colour very variable, but can include shades of brown, white, blotches of blue or dark brown spots, with a thick, white ventral layer of the shell.
taxon_text_2_6196: Small, typically around 5-15 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6197:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Glencairn (False Bay) to Mpenjati (KwaZulu-Natal).
taxon_text_4_6198: Intertidal on or under rocks or boulders to 1.5 m depth, might occur deeper but this is unconfirmed.
taxon_text_5_6199: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6200: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6201: Genus identified by a single slit on all intermediate valves and the absence of corneous branching on girdle. The only local species in the genus that has tufts of spicules/needles. Apophyses also more triangular shaped than in L. turtoni.
taxon_text_8_6202: Sirenko, B (2023). Chitons of the genus Lepidochitona (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) in the Indian Ocean and ordering of species compositions of some genera of the subfamily Tonicellinae. Zootaxa, 5228 (3), 292–316.
taxon_text_1_6205: Chitons have eight dorsal shell plates surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates thin and brittle, rectangular with rounded sides and pointed posterior margin. Anterior shell extensions triangular in second valve, while short and rounded on other valves with clear sinus between the two extensions. Texture of shell seems smooth with some granules on the centre and randomly arranged aesthete canals. Some growth-lines visible. Girdle quite narrow with minutely grained scales and spicules on the surrounding edge. Underside with gills extending from halfway down the animal to the anus. Colour ivory with red or brown markings and striped girdle.
taxon_text_2_6206: Small, typically around 5-10 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6207:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Elands Bay (Western Cape) to Port Alfred (Eastern Cape).
taxon_text_4_6208: Subtidal to intertidal under rocks and in crevices or in the open on coralline algae.
taxon_text_5_6209: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6210: External fertilization but in the pallial fold of the animal. Eggs hatch into juveniles brooded in the fold until big enough to be released.
taxon_text_7_6211: Genus identified by a single slit on all intermediate valves, absence of corneous branching on girdle and habitat of crustose coralline algae. Differs from most species in the genus by the absence of girdle tufts.
taxon_text_8_6212: Sirenko, B (2023). Chitons of the genus Lepidochitona (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) in the Indian Ocean and ordering of species compositions of some genera of the subfamily Tonicellinae. Zootaxa, 5228 (3), 292–316.
taxon_text_1_6225: Chitons have eight dorsal shell plates surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates rectangular and flat with triangular anterior shell extensions and no insertion plates. Texture of shell unusual and characteristic, with longitudinal grooves and widely spaced out longitudinal rows of granules, some areas carrying radially-arranged granules. Girdle very narrow with needle-like, smooth spicules in chitinous cups; broad, small scales on the top, while the animal’s edge is surrounded with spicules. Underside with gills that extend from halfway along the animal to the anus. Colour white, red or orange.
taxon_text_2_6226: Small, typically around 10-15 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6227:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Simon’s Town, Western Cape to Shelly Beach, KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6228: Found in the intertidal zone solitary under stones.
taxon_text_5_6229: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6230: External fertilization, but in the pallial fold of the animal. Eggs hatch into juveniles brooded in the fold until big enough to be released.
taxon_text_7_6231: The wide and characteristically armored plates with longitudinal ridges and grooves, in combination with the very narrow girdle, easily identify this species. This is a rare species and the only one in the genus from the area. Other genus members of this occur in deep water.
taxon_text_8_6232:
Sirenko, B (2000). A new and unusual species of Parachiton (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) from South Africa. African Zoology, 35(1), 93–98.

Sirenko, B (2016). A new South African Leptochiton (Mollusca: Polyplacophora: Lepidopleurida). Ruthenica, 26(3-4), 145-151.
taxon_text_1_6235: Chitons have eight dorsal shell plates surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. This species is readily identified by the smooth and large girdle scales and the girdle colour with banded black and brown. Shell plates almost rectangular. Texture of shell with radial riblets on most areas and central areas smooth or finely threaded.. Articulamentum with rounded anterior extensions. Colour black, girdle brown with black stripes.
taxon_text_2_6236: Small/medium, typically around 10-20 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6237:
Global: West Coast of South Africa up to Namibia.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_6238: Under rocks and damp crevices in the mid-intertidal zone. Usually clustered together, mostly under rocks but have also often been seen on open surfaces of the intertidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6239: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6240: External fertilization but in the pallial fold of the animal. Eggs hatch into juveniles brooded in the fold until big enough to be released.
taxon_text_7_6241: Very common and the only species in this genus to the region. Unmistakable dark appearance and striped girdle. Also characteristic are the brooded eggs or young chitons underneath the adults.
taxon_text_8_6242:
Blainville, HMD de (1825). Oscabrion, Chiton, pp. 519-555, in: Dictionnaire des Sciences Naturelles (F. Cuvier, ed.), vol. 36. Levrault, Strasbourg & Paris, & Le Normant, Paris. (p. 538).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 160).
taxon_text_1_6245: Chitons have eight dorsal shell plates surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Shell plates rectangular with rounded anterior shell extensions and raised sides. Texture of shell with clear longitudinal ribs on the area between the middle and the sides and microscopic punctation/smooth texture on the rest on the valves with very light growth-lines. Girdle wide with large, ribbed scales and spicules around the edge. Colour orange, pink, olive or brown with lighter blotches.
taxon_text_2_6246: Medium, typically around 15-30 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6247:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Durban.
taxon_text_4_6248: On sand, rocks or marine debris in the subtidal to intertidal zone.
taxon_text_5_6249: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6250: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6251: One of two species in the genus, but the Tulip chiton R. polita, is larger, more common, and has smooth scales and no spicules along the edge of the animal.
taxon_text_8_6252: Sykes, ER (1899). On Dinoplax fossus, n. sp., and Chiton crawfordi, n. sp., from South Africa. Proceedings of the Malacological Society of London, 3(5), 277-279.
taxon_text_1_6255: Chitons have eight dorsal shell plates surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. This species is easily identifiable by its beautiful patterns and colours. Shell plates have rounded to subtriangular anterior shell extensions. Middle plates rectangular shaped and lateral areas raised. Texture of shell mostly smooth. The valves are elevated in the mid-section, girdle wide and thick with large, striped, smooth, thick scales. Various beautiful colours with abstract patterns.
taxon_text_2_6256: Large, typically around 20-55 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_6257:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Langebaan (Western Cape) to Xhora River mouth (Eastern Cape).
taxon_text_4_6258: One of the most common chitons in the intertidal and subtidal zone that occurs in a remarkable range of colour patterns. Solitary under stones or on reef platforms.
taxon_text_5_6259: Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.
taxon_text_6_6260: External fertilization, pelagic trochophore larvae metamorphizes and settles as juvenile chiton.
taxon_text_7_6261: Very distinguishable by its beautiful patterns. Rhyssoplax crawfordi can be found around the same areas but is more scarce, smaller and has clear ribbing on the valves between the middle and the sides.
taxon_text_8_6262:
Ashby, E (1928). South African chitons, being a description of the Polyplacophora represented in the Turton Collection. Proceedings of the Malacological Society of London, 18 (2), 76-92.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 160).
taxon_text_1_6265:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This species is fairly easily identified by its characteristic net-like body form consisting of a lattice of thin, smooth, white, interconnecting tubes without visible oscula. Somewhat resembles a plastic pot scourer!
taxon_text_3_6267:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Presently known only from the Cape Peninsula, but probably more widespread.
taxon_text_4_6268: Found intertidally under boulders and in crevices and rock pools. Only fairly recently described and little else known about biology of this unusual sponge.
taxon_text_5_6269: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6270:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_8_6272:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 14).

Klautau, M & Valentine, C (2003). Revision of the genus Clathrina (Porifgera: Calcarea). Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 139, 1–62.
taxon_text_1_6275:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small openings on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This species is fairly easily identified by its characteristic tree-like shape, emerging from a small disc-like attachment to expand into broad upright, flattened branches or wide fans. The surface is soft, but slightly hairy and lacks prominent oscula and the colour is consistently bright-orange to red.
taxon_text_3_6277:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of South Africa to False Bay, at depths of about 15-272 m.
taxon_text_4_6278: Always subtidal and usually found on vertical faces of rocky reefs among other sponges and encrusting invertebrates. Common in kelp bed systems along the west coast.
taxon_text_5_6279: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6280:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6281: Form may vary considerably, with blades sometimes very broad and sometimes broken into narrower fingers, but fan-like form and red colour distinctive. The related Tree sponge Echinoclathria dichotoma has much narrowed and cylindrical branches.
taxon_text_8_9177:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 16).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 24).

Samaai, T & Gibbons, MJ (2005). Demospongiae taxonomy and biodiversity of the Benguela region on the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 1, 1-96. (p. 38).
taxon_text_1_6285:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This distinctive golden-yellow boring species lives largely buried within limestone rocks from which the flat-topped, circular inhalant siphons emerge. These are fairly flush with the substratum and the aperture is covered with a characteristic mesh-like lattice to keep out course particles. The larger oscula tend to have taller columns and have a round, open aperture.
taxon_text_2_6286: Can be very large with colonies up to 1 m across and typically about 10-20 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6287:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western Cape to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6288: Found burrowing into soft rocks on reefs from 5-25 m depth. Little else know about biology.
taxon_text_5_6289: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6290:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6291: The unusual boring habits, bright golden colour and sieve-like structures on the inhalant siphons make this species distinctive
taxon_text_8_6292:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 16).

Samaai, T, Pillay, R & Janson, L (2019). Shallow-water Demospongiae (Porifera) from Sodwana Bay, iSimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. Zootaxa, 4587(1), 1-85.
taxon_text_1_6295:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton.
