All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

Thinly-encrusting, bright-orange sponge that spreads across the undersides of boulders and the surfaces of rocky reefs. Surface smooth and hard. Oscula not prominent, but surrounded by a radiating network of grooves, after which the common name is derived.
taxon_text_2_6296: Can form extensive sheets up to 100 cm across, but typically about 20 cm across. Only about 2 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6297:
Global: South Africa, but also reported form Madagascar, Kenya and Red Sea. 

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_6298: Common on rocky reefs and in pools from the intertidal to a depth of about 183 m. Fed on by the red pleurobranch Berthellina granulata which can match the colour of the sponge perfectly.
taxon_text_5_6299: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6300:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6301: The very thin, hard form, bright orange colour and star-like ridges around the inconspicuous oscula are distinctive .
taxon_text_8_6302:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 16).

taxon_text_1_6305:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This species is fairly easily identified by its characteristic tree-like shape, consisting of an upright stem which then branches into a series of cylindrical upright stalks, each with a rounded tip. The surface texture is soft and fuzzy with tiny openings all over the surface and no large terminal oscula. Colour orange to red. Frequently acts as host to a white zoanthid, Parazoanthus sp. the polyps of which emerge all over the branches of the sponge.
taxon_text_3_6307:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West and South coasts of South Africa, at depths of about 15- 43 m.
taxon_text_4_6308: Found usually singly on shallow subtidal reefs or in deep overhangs, mostly on the west coast.
taxon_text_5_6309: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6310:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6311: Unmistakable but the presence of polyps of the zooanthid emerging from the branches of the sponge may confuse observers into mistaking this as being a soft coral or sea-fan.

taxon_text_1_6314:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

This species forms a soft, compressible bright purple to pinkish sheet on rocky substrata. Numerous tubular, sometimes coalescent, turret-like branches of varying lengths extend upwards from the surface, each with a rounded end bearing a circular osculum.
taxon_text_2_6315: Sheet up to 50 cm across, turrets up to 15 cm long.
taxon_text_3_6316:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: West and south coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6317: Common on rocky reefs and low-shore pools to a depth of at least 144 m, often growing among, or overgrowing, other benthic invertebrates or foliose and coralline algae.
taxon_text_5_6318: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.

Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6320: One of several fairly similar purple tubular sponges in the region and differentiating these can be difficult from images and without examination of spicules.

taxon_text_1_6323:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

This very fragile species forms soft, fluffy bluish-grey amorphous sheets coating the undersides of rocks in the mid-intertidal, where it can be very common. It frequently overgrows other sedentary invertebrates, such as mussels or slipper limpets, and covers foliose seaweeds. The surface is lumpy and thrown into numerous small bumps and folds and the oscula are small and not obvious. The texture is very soft and the colony breaks up easily if touched. Although common the species appears to be undescribed.
taxon_text_2_6324: Sheet up to 50 cm across but only about 10 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6325:
Global: Appears to be endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: West coast of South Africa. Currently only know from Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_6326: This fragile species is easily overlooked as it has few distinguishing features and breaks up very easily when handled, so is hard to examine or collect. Indeed many observers fail to recognise that it is an organism and not just sediment on the rocks!
taxon_text_5_6327: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6328:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6329: The amorphous form of this species and its fragile texture are fairly easy to recognise, but the species appears to be undescribed.
taxon_text_1_6341:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This is the most common sponge found in the mid intertidal and is fairly easily identified by its lumpy, thickly-encrusting form, dark yellow to orange colour and numerous oscula, each usually set on a short turret.

Like many sponges tends to be variable in colour and form, with intertidal samples darker orange and those from subtidal sites paler yellow. Those in wave exposed conditions also tend to be smoother and those in more sheltered locations bear more erect processes.
taxon_text_2_6342: Up to at least 200 mm across and typically about 10-20 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6343:
Global: Widespread across the North Atlantic Ocean, Mediterranean, Pacific coast of South America, Japan, New Zealand, Australia and southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia and entire coasts of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6344:
Extremely common in the intertidal and on shallow reefs, where it encrusts crevices and the margins of rock pools, as well as on shallow reefs. Recent research based on historically documented range expansions and low genetic diversity among global populations suggests that this may be an alien species that has been widely-distributed around the world by human activities, but the origins of the South African populations remain unclear.

Grazed on by the Warty dorid nudibranch Doris granosa, which are common on this sponge, but very difficult to spot as it is perfectly camouflaged in both colour and texture.
taxon_text_5_6345: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6346:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6347: One of several yellow or red encrusting sponges, but fairly easy to recognize by the ability to live high in the intertidal and by the lumpy surface texture.

taxon_text_1_6350:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This species is composed of a series of flat, upright blades which each narrow to a pointed tip. The texture is smooth and slightly hairy and there are small oscula along the edges of each blade. Colour in life orange-red.
taxon_text_2_6351: Up to at least 200 mm tall with blades about 10 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6352:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of South Africa to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_6353: Found on rocky reefs from about 15-37 m depth. Usually among other sedentary species including algae, bryozoans, soft corals and other sponges.
taxon_text_5_6354: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6355:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6356: Could be confused with the Broad-bladed tree sponge Clathria dayi which is also upright and red and occurs in similar habitats, but that species has thicker blades that do not narrow to points.
taxon_text_8_6357:

taxon_text_1_6359:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This species is round and olive green (a relatively rare colour for sponges) and has a distinctive surface texture consisting of round pore areas each encircled by an elevated collar, interspersed with round open oscula.
taxon_text_2_6360: Typically about 40 mm in diameter and in height.
taxon_text_3_6361:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_6362:
Typically occur on deeper reefs up to about 20 m depth in cool-temperate areas. Usually on flat rocks with a fine covering of sand and amongst cnidarians and other sponges.

Members of this genus are well-known for the diverse array of chemical compounds found in component species, many of which are of medical importance, including anti-cancer agents.
taxon_text_5_6363: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6364:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

 

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6365: The unusual colour and moon-like appearance are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_9180: Samaai, T, Gibbons, MJ, Kelly, M & Davies-Coleman, M (2003). South African Latrunculiidae (Porifera: Demospongiae: Poecilosclerida): descriptions of new species of Latrunculia du Bocage, Strongylodesma Lévi, and Tsitsikamma Samaai & Kelly. Zootaxa, 371(1), 1-26.
taxon_text_1_6377:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

Teat sponges are fairly easily identified to group level as they form massive, thick, usually yellowish pancake-like encrustations on rocky reefs and their surfaces bear numerous teat-like projections.

There are several similar species though and distinguishing between these is difficult. The two most common species on the west coast are P. littoralis which tends to be firm reddish-brown and is one the most common coastal sponges in the region and P. atlanticus, which is yellowish and occurs from 1-24 m depth along the entire west coast
taxon_text_2_6378: Up to about 30 cm across and 50 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6379:
Global: The genus is widespread globally and contains over 30 species. The two species mentioned above occur only in Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: West and South coasts of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6380:
Large and conspicuous encrusting or dome-shaped sponges common on shallow reefs. Little else known about biology.

Uprooted specimens are frequently cast up on beaches and their unusual rubbery, tough appearance and regular finger-like projections often intrigue beachcombers.
taxon_text_5_6381: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6382:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6383: Easily identified to genus, but species variable in form and hard to identify accurately without examining spicules.
taxon_text_8_6384:

taxon_text_1_6386:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

This species forms thick purple to black sheets on rocks. The surface may be covered with a fine sandy layer and the sheet has slightly-raised, rounded edges. The texture is firm, but slippery to the touch The oscula are inconspicuous and form small dimples on the surface. When handled the sponge has a distinctive strong pungent smell from which the common name is derived.
taxon_text_2_6387: Sheet up to 20 cm across and about 10 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6388:
Global: Australia and South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Namibia to south coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6389: Common on rocky reefs and in pools from the intertidal to a depth of about 183 m.
taxon_text_5_6390: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6391:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6392: The black colour, sheet-like form and characteristic, pungent smell are fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_6393:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 16).

taxon_text_1_6368:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

This genus belongs to the class Calcaria, which are characterized by having calcium carbonate spicules, and forms colonies that branch from a common base into distinctive elongate, white tubes that each end in a single, round, terminal osculum. The whole colony resembles a bunch of tiny bananas.

There are two described local species and probably other undescribed ones and species are difficult to distinguish from photographs, so the group is treated at genus level only here.
taxon_text_3_6370:
Global: There are over 110 species in this genus, which is found worldwide. 

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_6371: Colonies fairly common on vertical rock-faces or in gullies and pools, to a depth of at least 18 m, often attached to, or among, other benthic invertebrates, such as hydroids or bryozoans.  Sometimes abundant on surfaces of seaweeds.
taxon_text_5_6372: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6373:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6374: Members of this genus are fairly easy to identify by the colonial form and smooth, white, tubular branches. Sponges of the genus Sycon are also small, white and tubular, but are solitary and the oscula are surrounded by long spiky spicules.
taxon_text_8_6375:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 14).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 22).
taxon_text_1_6025:
Colonies erect, branching and bushy, easily confused as being algae. Blades narrow to wide, divide regularly and are stiff, but may be flexible or heavily calcified and brittle. They bear rows of zooids on both sides, and these are arranged in distinctive regular, diagonal lines. Viewed microscopically, the zooecia are mostly flat and rectangular to rounded, with round to oval apertures and without conspicuous spines.

There are over 40 species in this genus, of which nearly 30 occur in the waters around southern Africa, so these are treated here as a group. Although the species are similar in overall structure, they differ in colour (usually white but some pink or brown), width of the lobes and microscopic structure of the zooecia.
taxon_text_2_6026: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5 but up to 20 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_6027:
Global: Over 40 species in the genus with many known from South Africa, each with different distribution range.

Local/Regional: Whole region, shallow water to at least 880 m.
taxon_text_4_6028: Usually found on rocky reefs from shallow to deep water, but seldom in intertidal.
taxon_text_5_6029: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_6030: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the tips of the branches. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction with some species in this group brooding their larvae internally.
taxon_text_7_6031: There are several other regional genera that form flat, branching blades, for example Onchoporella, but Adeonella species can fairly easily be distinguished as the zooecia are arranged in distinctive, regular, diagonal rows.
taxon_text_8_6032:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

taxon_text_1_6395:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This is a massive, dark-grey sponge that tends to form a ‘wall’ with vertical sides separated from a flat upper surface by a distinct ridge that is marked by a row of fine spicules that protrude from the surface. The texture is firm and the upper surface bears small oscula. The inner flesh is light orange.
taxon_text_2_6396: Up to at least 10 cm thick and about 50 cm in length.
taxon_text_3_6397:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6398: Lives on rocky reefs from about 2-90 m of water where it forms large growth on both vertical and horizontal surfaces. Sometimes overgrown with seaweeds.
taxon_text_5_6399: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6400:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6401: The Orange wall sponge Trachycladus spinispirulifera also forms large wall-like growths in similar habitats, but as the name suggests, is orange rather than grey.
taxon_text_8_6402:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 22).

Samaai, T & Gibbons, MJ (2005). Demospongiae taxonomy and biodiversity of the Benguela region on the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 1, 1-96. (p. 12).
taxon_text_1_6404:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This is a large, thick, cushion-like sponge with a smooth surface that is thrown into rounded lobes. There are usually several round oscula positioned towards the tops of the lobes. Texture is firm and elastic and colour orange, internally orange-yellow.
taxon_text_2_6405: Up to at least 300 mm across and typically about 20-50 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6406:
Global: Widespread across the Arctic, Pacific Ocean, North Atlantic, Mediterranean, down the west coast of Africa to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia and west coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6407: A widespread and common benthic species found on hard substrata from the low water mark to depths of over 1000 m. Thought to be unpalatable to most predators and often found growing on shells occupied by hermit crabs, which may gain protection from the sponge. Has been investigated as a possible source of antibiotics, anti-fouling and other biologically active compounds.
taxon_text_5_6408: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6409:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6410: One of several Suberites species that occur in the region (see references below) but the most common of these, S. dandelenae, occurs in deeper waters of 80-500 m and is yellow rather than orange.
taxon_text_8_6411:
Samaai, T & Gibbons, MJ (2005). Demospongiae taxonomy and biodiversity of the Benguela region on the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 1, 1-96. (p. 28).

Samaai, T, Maduray, S, Janson, L, Gibbons, MJ, Ngwakum, B & Teske, PR (2017). A new species of habitat–forming Suberites (Porifera, Demospongiae, Suberitida) in the Benguela upwelling region (South Africa). Zootaxa, 4254(1), 49-81.
taxon_text_1_6413:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best though of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one of more larger openings called oscula.

This genus belongs to the class Calcaria, which are characterized by having elongate calcium carbonate spicules, and has a distinctive vase-like shape with a prominent ring of stiff, elongate spicules surrounding the single terminal osculum, the whole organism resembling a small, white pineapple!

There are several local species and these are difficult to distinguish from photographs, so the group is treated at genus level here.
taxon_text_3_6415:
Global: There are over 100 species in this genus, which is found worldwide. 

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_6416: Usually found singly or in small groups of separate individuals. Fairy common on vertical rock-faces or in gullies and pools, often attached to, or among, other benthic invertebrates, such as hydroids or bryozoans, or among algae.
taxon_text_5_6417: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6418:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take to form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, or by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6419: Members of this genus are fairly easy to identify by the prominent crown of erect spicules around the aperture. Branching sponges of the genus Leucosolenia are also small, white and tubular, but the oscula lack spiky spicules. They are also colonial, with many branches emerging from a common base.
taxon_text_8_6420:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 14).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 22).
taxon_text_1_6422:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

This species can be identified by its characteristic spherical shape, orange to red colour and slightly knobbly or ‘warty’ surface, which is marked with a number of round oscula, each with a raided margin. The underside has root like processes to attach the sponge firmly to the substratum.
taxon_text_3_6424:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West and South coasts of South Africa, as far east as Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_6425: Found singly or in clusters on shallow subtidal reefs, mostly on the west coast.
taxon_text_5_6426: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6427:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6428: One of a number of spherical ‘ball sponges’ found in the region, but can be identified by its colour and surface texture.
taxon_text_8_6429:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 16).

Samaai, T, Gibbons, MJ & Muricy, G (2017). Validation of Tethya samaaii Ribeiro & Muricy, 2011, replacement name for the sponge Tethya rubra Samaai & Gibbons, 2005 (Demospongiae, Tethyida, Tethyidae). Zootaxa, 4347(3), 592-594.
taxon_text_1_6431:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more usually larger openings called oscula.

This species is fairly easily identified by its enormous size, orange to red colour and wall-like shape, and is one of the most conspicuous sponges found on the region. Also characteristic are the numerous round openings on the upper surface, each of which is raided on a short turret.
taxon_text_2_6432: Massive, reaching up to 2 m long and 30 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_6433:
Global: Widespread across the West and South coasts of South Africa, Australia and New Zealand. Also reported from Zanzibar.

Local/Regional: West and South coasts of South Africa, at depth of about 5-350 m.
taxon_text_4_6434:
Very large and conspicuous species that forms large wall-like structures on shallow reefs and is one of the most commonly seen species on shallow reefs in the Western Cape. External colour orange to red, but interior yellow.

Has been found to contain two potent human cancer-cell inhibiting chemicals and thus has potential uses in drug development.
taxon_text_5_6435: Filters small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6436:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6437: There are other large wall sponges in the region, but the combination of size, colour and the many round raised vents on the surface easily identify this species.
taxon_text_8_6438:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 18).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 23).

Pettit, GR, Herald, CL, Cichacz, ZA, Gao, F, Schmidt, JM, Boyd, MR, Christie, ND & Boettner, FE (1993). Isolation and structure of the powerful human cancer cell growth inhibitors spongistatins 4 and 5 from an African Spirastrella spinispirulifera (Porifera). Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications, (24), 1805-1807.

Samaai, T & Gibbons, MJ (2005). Demospongiae taxonomy and biodiversity of the Benguela region on the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 1, 1-96. (p. 23).

Samaai, T, Payne, R, Maduray, S & Janson, L (2018). Phylum Porifera In: Atkinson LJ and Sink KJ (eds) Field Guide to the Ofshore Marine Invertebrates of South Africa. Malachite Marketing and Media, Pretoria, 37-64. (p. 63).
taxon_text_1_6458:
Large, easily recognized and charismatic wader with completely black plumage, red legs, bright red eye-rings and powerful, straight, red bill. Sexes alike, although female slightly heavier and with longer and more pointed bill.

Also easily recognized by the distinctive loud, strident, piping call.
taxon_text_2_6459: Total length 42-45 cm, wingspan 80-88 cm, mass of male about 665 g, of female 730 g.
taxon_text_3_6460:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Core range Northern Namibia (rarely S. Angola) to Eastern Cape (rarely KwaZulu-Natal).
taxon_text_4_6461:
Usually seen in pairs or small groups foraging in intertidal during low tide, or roosting above the high-water mark, often communally, during high tide. Mussels eaten by inserting the sharp bill between the valves when these gape, severing the adductor muscle and then scissoring out the flesh. Limpets are knocked off the rocks by a sharp jab to their posterior margin, turned over and wedged upside down while flesh scissored out.

World population was only about 4000 in 1980’s, but is now rising due both to restrictions on the driving of vehicles on beaches and to the invasion of rocky shores by the invasive Mediterranean mussel. This has vastly increased both absolute amount of food available, and also time for which this is available, as this mussel occurs higher in the intertidal than other native species.

Adults mostly sedentary and territorial, but young birds may migrate to nursery areas, often north of core adult range in Namibia, returning south after 2-3 years. Longevity up to 35 years.
taxon_text_5_6462: Feeds mostly on mussels and limpets, but also polychaete worms and whelks. On sandy beaches may take white mussels (Donax serra) and sandhoppers.
taxon_text_6_6463: Monogamous, solitary nester, although on islands nests may be just meters apart. Nests usually within about 30 m of high-water mark. Breed mostly November – January, slightly later in Namibia than in South Africa. Nest a shallow scrap, usually on sandy ground, when on rock that cannot be scraped margins may be built up with shells or stones. Eggs 1-2, rarely 3, buff green or brown with black and brown lines and spots. Incubated by both parents, incubation time 27-39 days and young take a further 38 days to fledge. Eggs and chicks subject to mortality due to human disturbance, dogs on beaches, off road vehicles etc. and breeding success higher on islands than on mainland due to reduced disturbance.
taxon_text_7_6464: Unmistakable. The black and white European oystercatcher has a similar body shape and is a rare visitor to the Southern African coast.
taxon_text_8_6465:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 348).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 389).
taxon_text_1_6467: Easily recognized, flightless species with wings modified into flippers. Face with a black mask and distinctive patches of bare pink skin above eyes. Broad white stripe runs from above eye around ear and down side of neck to merge with white breast. Broad inverted U-shaped black stripe on chest. Back and dorsal surface of flippers black. Legs and feet black with pink blotches. Chicks fluffy and brown.
taxon_text_2_6468: Total length 55-65 cm, mass 2.9-3.5 kg, sexes alike, but male slightly larger than female.
taxon_text_3_6469:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Breeding colonies only between Namibia and Algoa Bay, but sometimes seen as far east as KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6470:
When at sea mostly found swimming in small groups within about 3-4 km of the coast, but may range up to 100 km offshore. Feed mostly by day, but foraging trips may last several days. Feed by pursuit diving and can dive up to 130 m depth, but most dives to less than 50 m. Dive duration typically about 1 minute, but over 4 minutes reported. Often hunt co-operatively, herding shoals of fish together and seizing them from below. Prey may be swallowed underwater. On land, walk upright, hopping over small gaps and sliding down inclines.

Overall numbers have declined drastically over past century from about 2 million to 20 000 breeding pairs. Causes include harvesting of eggs and exploitation of guano on breeding islands, depletion of food due to competition with commercial fishing operations, oil spills and competition with expanding seal populations, which have eliminated penguins from several breeding islands. Although previously restricted to islands due to high predation pressure on mainland, three mainland colonies are now established and some of these, notably Boulders Beach on Simonstown, have become significant tourist attractions.

When undergoing their annual (synchronized) moult, penguins are unable to feed at sea, as their feathers are not waterproof, so they fast during this period, which lasts about 3 weeks, losing almost half their body weight. Voice a loud donkey-like braying, hence the alternative common name Jackass penguin.
taxon_text_5_6471: Feed mainly on shoaling pelagic fish, such as sardine, anchovy, horse mackerel, mullet, but also take some invertebrates, such as squid and other cephalopods, rock lobster, mantis shrimp and polychaetes. Each penguin consumes about 500 g food a day, this increasing to over 1 kg when feeding larger chicks.
taxon_text_6_6472: Monogamous and may retain same mate over several years. Colonial breeders, but defend immediate area around nest. Nests in burrows in sand or guano, in crevices in rocks, or under vegetation. Burrows on average angled at about 27 degrees and 56 cm long, lined with seaweed, pieces of vegetation and feathers. Laying dates protracted and vary between colonies. Eggs 1-3, usually 2, rounded oval and white, soon becoming nest-stained. Incubation equally by both parents with change-over every 1-2 days, incubation time 38-41 days. Large chicks join a creche and are fed by regurgitation, fledging after 60-130 days, depending on amount of food available.
taxon_text_7_6473: Unmistakable and the only penguin in the region, other than rare vagrants.
taxon_text_8_6474:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 356).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 631).
taxon_text_1_6476: Unmistakable. Bill greatly elongated, black and curved downwards. Head and neck bare, showing black skin. Eyes brown, eye-ring dark red. Body and tail white, trailing edge of wing black and with loose net of blue-black plumes on rump. Legs and feet black.
taxon_text_2_6477: Total length 65-89 cm, mass 1250 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6478:
Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa.

Local/Regional: Found inland and along coast in moister habitats across whole region, except arid western parts.
taxon_text_4_6479:
Mainly found along margins of inland wetlands, grasslands and agricultural lands, but also coastal lagoons and the intertidal zone. Has benefited from human developments and now common on farm dams, sewage works, farmyards, etc. Populations in the Western Cape have increased dramatically in recent decades.

Active diurnally, roosting at night in communal roosts in trees, or on the ground if on islands. Usually forage in small groups, sometimes mixed with other species, such as the Hadeda ibis and Little egret, walking slowly and pecking with the long beak, or running forward to snatch mobile prey.
taxon_text_5_6480: Taking a wide variety of prey. On dry land take insects, crustaceans, worms, offal, seeds, etc. In aquatic habitats feed on crustaceans, insect and their larvae, fish, frogs, etc.  Commonly seen feeding on invertebrates associated with drift kelp on marine beaches in Western Cape.
taxon_text_6_6481: Monogamous and nest in colonies of closely-packed nests in trees and bushes, or on the ground if on islands. Colonies often mixed with other species, such as storks, herons, or cormorants. Nest a large platform of sticks and stems, lined with softer material. Eggs 2-5, elongate, rough-white, speckled with red-brown. Incubation 28-29 days, shared by both parents. Fed by regurgitation, juvenile thrusting head and neck into adult’s mouth. Fledge at about 40 days and independent after 44-48 days.
taxon_text_7_6482: Unmistakable. Hadeda ibis has a shorter bill and is brown to bronze.
taxon_text_8_6483:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 356).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 611).
taxon_text_1_6485:
Adults in breeding plumage have a grey belly and a distinctive white cheek-stripe separating this from the black cap, which extends just below the eye and down the nape of the neck. Bill deep red, eyes dark brown. Legs coral red. Rump and deeply-forked tail white.

In non-breeding plumage the bill becomes blacker, the forehead white and the black cap less pronounced.
taxon_text_2_6486: Total length 35-40 cm, wingspan 72-80 cm, mass 140 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6487:
Global: Southern Ocean, Antarctic Peninsula and sub-Antarctic islands, extending north to coasts of South Africa and Argentina.

Local/Regional: Primarily in the Western Cape as far north as Lambert‘s Bay, extending to Bird Island in Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_6488:
Do not breed in South Africa, but locally common visitors in winter, most birds arriving around May and leaving by October. Totally marine and come ashore only to roost, the main roosting colonies being on Dyer Island and Dassen Island in the Western Cape and Bird Island in Eastern Cape. Usually form compact roosts of up to thousands, often with other terns. Sometimes also roost on rocky headlands of shorelines.

Forage by day, sometimes on moonlit nights, plunge diving over calm waters or surface dipping over rougher seas.
taxon_text_5_6489: Hunt a variety of small fish, especially anchovies, also crustaceans, especially euphausiids (krill), isopods, molluscs, insects.
taxon_text_6_6490:
Breed on Antarctic Peninsula and sub-Antarctic islands, not in South Africa.

Start breeding at 3 years old and nest in November-December, the nest being a shallow scrape, often on a cliff edge. Eggs 1-2, light brown to green, heavily speckled with black; incubated by both parents for 23-25 days. Chicks take 27-32 days to become independent.
taxon_text_7_6491: Arctic tern (mostly only seen at sea and not on coast) is very similar, but has shorter legs and shorter, slimmer bill.
taxon_text_8_6492:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 461).
taxon_text_1_6494: Large, fairly stout cormorant, entirely black apart from white rump during breeding season. Head with a small peaked crest. Bill and surrounding skin entirely black (distinguishing it from Cape and Crowned cormorants). Eyes divided horizontally – top half orange, bottom half green with narrow orange border. Legs and feet black.
taxon_text_2_6495: Total length 75 cm, wingspan 130 cm, mass about 1800 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6496:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: West coast species, found from northern Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_6497:
Uncommon species, with a restricted range more or less corresponding to that of kelp forests.  Total population probably only about 3000 pairs and has declined by more than 50% in recent decades, probably due to decreasing food supplies and displacement from some colonies by expanding seal populations.

Found in small colonies mostly on islands, and seldom ranges inland, or more than 10 km from breeding sites. Often seen mixed with other cormorants. Flight rather heavy and laboured, usually low over water. Forages close inshore, but can dive to at least 28 m, deeper dives initiated by jumping out of water. Dives each about 30-60 secs and occur in bouts of about one hour, with rests between. Sometimes spread wings after foraging to warm body and aid digestion.
taxon_text_5_6498: Feeds mainly on a variety of small benthic fish including klipfish, gobies, sucker fish and blennies, but also range of invertebrates, mainly rock lobster, rock crabs and mantis shrimp, but also cephalopods, abalone, etc.
taxon_text_6_6499: Usually nests in small colonies of 20-100 pairs on islands or large rocks, cliffs, breakwaters etc. adjacent to the sea. Nest a large mound made almost entirely of seaweeds and cemented together with guano. Eggs 1-3 pale bluish-white with chalky outer layer. Breed year round in the Western Cape, but mainly May-October. Incubation period 28-32 days, fledge after 55-70 days but cared for by parents to 3 months.
taxon_text_7_6500: Could be confused with Cape or Bank cormorants, but those are smaller and both have orange colouring around gape of bill. Crowned cormorant also has red eye and longer tail and Cape cormorant blue eye and no crest.
taxon_text_8_6501:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 577).
taxon_text_1_6503: Medium-sized cormorant, entirely blue-black apart from distinctive large orange-yellow patch of bare skin around bill and throat. Head without crest, bill black. Eyes turquoise blue with greenish eye-ring. Legs and feet black.
taxon_text_2_6504: Total length 61-64 cm, wingspan 110 cm, mass about 1300 g for males, 1100 g for females, sexes otherwise alike.
taxon_text_3_6505:
Global: Southern Africa - from Angola to Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Mostly from Namibia to Eastern Cape, less common on east coast.
taxon_text_4_6506: The most common cormorant along the west coast, seldom venturing inland, or more than 20 km offshore. Roosts in large flocks that can number many thousands. Leave the colonies to feed in large flocks that fly rapidly (up to 75 km per h) low over water, often in extended V-formations, each bird gaining lift from the one in front and hence conserving energy. Often seen following shoals of pelagic fish, birds leap-frogging from the back of the group to the feeding area as the fish move forward. Settle on the sea and then plunge-diving to capture prey by pursuit-diving.  Unusually among cormorants rests at sea between foraging bouts, the ability to do so being linked to denser plumage and greater buoyancy.
taxon_text_5_6507: Feeds primarily on pelagic shoaling fish, especially pilchard, anchovy and horse mackerel, but also other fish and crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_6508: Colonial nesters, often in large colonies of closely adjacent nests. Nest constructed by female from material brought by male, comprising a loose pile of sticks, feathers, dried seaweed and various other natural and human debris. Eggs 1-4, pale bluish-or greenish white. Incubated equally by both sexes, incubation time 22-23 days. Chicks leave nest after about 5 weeks, but remain dependent on adults for several more weeks.
taxon_text_7_6509: Bank cormorant is larger and bulkier and lacks orange skin around bill. Crowned cormorant smaller, has crest on head, red eye and longer tail.
taxon_text_8_6510:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 579).
taxon_text_1_6512: Easily recognized by its large size and mainly white plumage, with its distinctive yellow head and neck and black trailing edge to wings. The powerful, pointed bill and eyes are blue and there is a black stripe across the eye and another down the throat. There are no external nostrils (an adaptation to high- speed plunge diving which would force water up any nostrils). Legs and dark grey.
taxon_text_2_6513: Total length 84-94 cm, wingspan 171-185 cm, mass about 2 600 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6514:
Global: Breeding range restricted to southern Africa, but non-breeding birds disperse as far as Gulf of Guinea and Mozambique, with vagrants sometimes seen in Australasia and South America.

Local/Regional: Breeds only on six islands from Namibia to Bird Island in Algoa Bay, but seen all along the coast.
taxon_text_4_6515:
Restricted to only a few breeding islands, the main colonies being in South Africa and hosting tens of thousands of breeding pairs. Namibian colonies have declined considerably over past 50 years due to decline in fish stocks, but South African population have increased over same period. Adults leave colonies to forage 1-4 hours after sunrise and return1-2 hours before sunset, but some may spend several days away, roosting at sea, sometimes in large rafts. In calm weather need to run to get airborne, and when returning to colony typically make one or more circuits, calling loudly, before landing. 

Feeding range extends across continental shelf and birds from the various South African colonies tend to have fairly discreet feeding ranges. In winter large numbers also follow sardine run along KwaZulu-Natal coast. Often feed in large groups on shoals of pelagic fish, often in company of other predatory seabirds, seals, dolphins, whales and gamefish in ‘feeding-frenzies’. Usually plunge dive from height of 5-20 m, but also dive from surface.  Shallow dives use momentum alone, birds bobbing back to surface passively due to their positive bouyancy, but can dive to at least 20 m by underwater swimming and flapping.
taxon_text_5_6516: Feed mainly on shoaling pelagic fish, such as sardine, anchovy, round herring, snoek, horse mackerel, etc. Squid make up small proportion of diet and also scavenge demersal fish, such as hake, from fishing vessels.
taxon_text_6_6517: Form dense breeding colonies on few select islands, with nests placed only about 50 cm apart. Pairs remain together over several seasons and perform elaborate greeting rituals, pointing the head and neck skywards and tapping the bills together.  Nest a mound of guano and vegetation with a cup-shaped depression on top. One to two chalky-white, elongate-oval eggs are laid, mainly from mid-September to mid-December. Incubated by both parents, using their highly vascularised food webs to wrap around and warm the eggs.  Incubation period 43-44 days. Chicks at first first blackish with sparce white down, but after about 11 weeks this is replaced by dark grey juvenile plumage. Juveniles leave nest at about 90-105 days.
taxon_text_8_6519:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 356).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 567).
taxon_text_1_6521: Small, mostly grey with a white throat, a white brow above the eye and a distinctive dark triangular bib on the upper chest. Wings darker grey with white edges to feathers. Tail long and dark with white margins and characteristically wagged up and down as the bird walks. Beak, eyes and legs black. One of few passerine (perching) birds regularly found on the seashore.
taxon_text_2_6522: Total length 20 cm, mass 20 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6523:
Global: Eastern and southern Africa, with three regional subspecies.

Local/Regional: Widespread throughout South Africa, both inland and on the coast, rare in Namibia and north-western parts of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6524: Common resident, found almost anywhere there is open ground next to water, including in parks and gardens and along both rocky and sandy coasts. Particularly abundant on coastlines where kelp wrack is abundant, being attracted by abundant kelp-flies. Walks purposefully along the ground while wagging the tail, periodically darting forward to capture prey; may also fly up to hawk insects in flight. Roots as night in trees, often communally.
taxon_text_5_6525: Feeds almost entirely on insects, especially flies, but also various other groups. Prey may be captured alive, or scavenged when already dead, as when washed up on the driftline, fallen to the ground under lights, or picked from radiator grills of vehicles. On the seashore also take beach hoppers (Amphipoda), small crabs and other crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_6526: Monogamous, retaining the same mate in successive seasons and territorial in the breeding season, chasing away other birds and attacking reflections in mirrors, hub-caps, etc.  Nest a deep bowl of grasses, roots, weeds etc. lined with hair, wool or feathers. Either concealed in vegetation on ground, often on steep banks, or in bushes, creepers or hedges, in cavities in human structures, etc. May construct several nests before choosing one, or re-use old nests in successive years. Eggs usually 2-4, grey to yellowish, streaked or spotted with browns or greys at broad end. In Western Cape mostly laid in July-November. Incubation time 13-14 days, fledglings leave nest after 14-18 days, but continue to be fed by adults up to 20-25 days. Adults with newly-fledged young may feign injury to distract predators.
taxon_text_7_6527: Mountain and Pied wagtails somewhat similar, but have white bellies and are scarce or absent in South Western Cape and not found on the seashore.
taxon_text_8_6528:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 348).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 1091).
taxon_text_1_6530: The largest species of tern. Body with pale grey upper parts and white underparts, a black crest on the head covers eye. Black tips to underwings visible in flight. Long, bright-red, dagger-like bill with black tip. Eyes reddish brown, legs and feet black with orange soles.
taxon_text_2_6531: Total length 47-54 cm, wingspan 130-145 cm, mass 690 g, sexes alike, but female slightly smaller than male.
taxon_text_3_6532:
Global: Widespread across Europe, North America, Asia, Africa and Australasia, but absent from South America.

Local/Regional: Along the coast across region, more rarely inland.
taxon_text_4_6533:
Found mostly along the coast mostly in sheltered bays, estuaries and lagoons. Usually solitary or in family groups, congregating in larger groups when roosting. Flight leisurely and gull like with deep, powerful wing beats.

Forages in clear, shallow water, hovering 3-20 m above the water with bill pointed downwards and then flexing wings inwards and plunging into the water, feeds during the day, mostly in morning.
taxon_text_5_6534: Feeds almost entirely small fish of <20 cm which are swallowed head first while on the wing. Most common prey species in Western Cape are mullet.
taxon_text_6_6535: Monogamous, with pair bond persisting from year to year and solitary of colonial nesters. Nest a shallow scrape on the ground, usually lined with dried vegetation, defend a territory around the nest site. In Western Cape mostly lay in October-January. Eggs sandy to greenish-cream, blotched with brown or purplish spots. Incubation 22-24 days, fledge at 30-35 days but depending on parental feeding up to 8 months.
taxon_text_7_6536: The bright red, blacked-tipped bill and large size are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_6537:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 450).
taxon_text_1_6539: Fairly large, tall wader with long, slightly-recurved, dark-grey bill. Upper parts white with dense black streaks. Wings darker towards flight feathers. Back, rump and underparts white. Legs distinctively pale olive-green.
taxon_text_2_6540: Total length 30-33 cm, wingspan 68-70 cm, mass 170 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6541:
Global: Breeds in northern hemisphere, across both Europe and Asia. Summer migrant to Africa, India and Australia.

Local/Regional: Widespread across whole region, both inland and along the coast, but least common in arid areas.
taxon_text_4_6542: Migrates from Europe in the southern summer, arriving in August-September and leaving again in March-April. Found both along gravel or sandy margins of inland waters, such as dams, riverbeds, ponds, salt-works etc., in estuaries and lagoons, and along both rocky and sandy seashores. Usually solitary, but sometimes in loose groups, moving constantly and following the tides, either along water margin or wading in shallows. Most prey caught by picking rather than probing, also by scything the bill from side to side with tip on surface.
taxon_text_5_6543: Takes a variety of crabs, shrimps, sand and mudprawns, polychaetes and small fish.
taxon_text_6_6544: Does not breed on South Africa, but in northern latitudes. Monogamous, but usually pair up with new mate each season. Lay 3-4 light cream eggs, which are heavily marked with darker brown splotches, from April to June. Nest a scrape on the ground close to solid structures, such as rocks, logs or trees. Incubation takes 23-26 days.
taxon_text_7_6545: Green legs and upturned bill fairly distinctive. Marsh sandpiper also has green legs, but is much smaller and has a thin, straight bill.
taxon_text_8_6546:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 346).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 354).
taxon_text_1_6548:
Adults in breeding plumage have relatively dark grey upperparts, a black cap extending from forehead across base of eye to nape of neck. Neck and belly white. Bill quite long, red, sometimes with a black tip. Wings mostly grey, undersides white. Eyes dark brown. Legs and feet scarlet.

In non-breeding plumage (as seen most commonly in South Africa) bill and legs black; forehead white and black cap less pronounced, but a distinct black patch remains in front of eye.
taxon_text_2_6549: Total length 31-35 cm, wingspan 72-82 cm, mass 95-160 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6550:
Global: Breeds in temperate regions across the Northern Hemisphere and migrate to the south in the southern summer.

Local/Regional: Found across the region in a variety of coastal habitats.
taxon_text_4_6551:
As the name suggests, most common coastal tern in the region, occurring around the entire coast and sometimes roosting in groups of many thousands. Migratory, so present only in southern summer, arriving by about September and departing by May. Roost on sandy beaches, low rocky points or offshore islands, sometimes in flocks of many thousands.

When hunting mostly coastal, but can range far out to sea, most active early in the morning. Fly with stable, directed flight while looking downwards. Plunge dive from 1-6 m, either submerging totally or belly only. Also dip for surface prey such as crustaceans.
taxon_text_5_6552: Feed on small pelagic fish and crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_6553:
Does not breed in South Africa, but across temperate zone of Northern Hemisphere.

Nest a saucer-shaped scrape that may be rimmed with seaweed or stones or lined with vegetation. Lay in May-June, clutch normally three cream to brown eggs marked with black or brown streaks of blotches. Eggs incubated by both parents. Incubation time 21-22 days, precocial chicks fledge in 22-28 days.
taxon_text_7_6554: Can be confused with various other smaller terns. Antarctic tern very similar but has shorter legs and shorter, heavier bill.
taxon_text_8_6555:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 459).
taxon_text_1_6557: Fairly-large wader with distinctively long, downwardly-curved, dark brown beak, often with fleshy base. Top of head brown with pale median line, another pale stripe above eye and a dark stripe though dark-brown eye. Rest of upper body speckled densely in brown; lower back, belly and rump white.  Legs and feet grey.
taxon_text_2_6558: Total length 40-46 cm, wingspan 76-88 cm, mass c 400 g, sexes alike, but female larger than male and with longer bill.
taxon_text_3_6559:
Global: Breeds in northern hemisphere in both Asia and N Europe. Summer migrant to coastal areas of Africa, Asia and Australia.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region.
taxon_text_4_6560: Found mostly along the coast or in coastal wetlands and estuaries and not on inland water bodies. Roosts in flocks at high tide, often communally with other shorebirds. Flight rapid and low over water. Forages single or in loose groups both by day and at night, mostly in intertidal zone, following the tide as it falls. Usually walks continuously while foraging, but may pause with one foot raised before darting forward to capture burrowing crabs.
taxon_text_5_6561: Takes mostly crabs and mudprawns, but also molluscs, polychaete worms and small fish.
taxon_text_6_6562: Does not breed in South Africa, but in northern latitudes, where 3-4 eggs laid in a bare scrap on the ground in tundra of arctic moorland.
taxon_text_7_6563: Long, downwardly-curved beak distinguishes Whimbrel from most other waders, but similar to Eurasian curlew. That species is 30% larger with longer beak and legs and no stripes on head and is mostly in wetlands and lagoons (especially Langebaan Lagoon) and seldom on exposed seashores.
taxon_text_8_6564:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 346).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 349).
taxon_text_1_6566: Small, glossy greenish-black cormorant with relatively long tail, an obvious upright tuft of feathers on the head (hence common name). Eyes distinctively ruby-red. Bill shortish and black, lower mandible with yellow-orange base and gape orange. Bare pinkish skin above and in front of eyes swells and becomes red during courtship. Legs and feet black.
taxon_text_2_6567: Total length 54 cm, wingspan 85 cm mass about 790 g in males, 730 g in females, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6568:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: West coast species, found from northern Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_6569:
Uncommon species with a restricted range and a total population of probably only about 2 500 pairs. Found only along the coast and seldom range inland or more than 10 km out to sea. Fairly resident and occur in small colonies on islands, piers and artificial platforms, often mixed with other cormorants.

Forages by pursuit-diving close inshore, usually singly and in water less than 5 m deep along rocky shore or in kelp beds, not along beaches. Usually undertake a bout of short dives of duration less than 1 min separated by intervals of a few seconds; then rests ashore, often with wings spread to warm body and aid digestion.
taxon_text_5_6570: Feeds mainly on small benthic fish, such as klipfish, pipefish and blennies, but also takes crustaceans, molluscs including cephalopods, and polychaete worms.
taxon_text_6_6571: Nests in small colonies of usually less than 30 pairs, often among colonies of other species. Usually on islands or other sites inaccessible to mammalian predators, such as cliffs, shipwrecks, piers, moored boats, etc. Nest a rough platform of sticks, seaweeds, feathers and bones. Eggs 1-5, pale bluish-white with chalky outer layer. Incubation period 22-23 days, chicks form creches at about 22 days and are independent after 45-60 days
taxon_text_7_6572: Could be confused with Cape and Bank cormorants, but these are both larger with longer bills, and shorter tails. Both also lack both red eyes and prominent crest on head characteristic of crowned cormorant.
taxon_text_8_6573:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 573).
taxon_text_1_6575: Large, robust species with brown to grey underparts. There are distinctive brown patches around the eyes, a brown collar around the neck and an irregular brown patch in the centre of the breast. Back, rump and tail black and wings dark glossy brown with wide white band on leading edge that is conspicuous in flight. Legs and feet orange.
taxon_text_2_6576: Total length 60-75 cm, mass about 1.9 kg in females, 2.3 kg in males g, sexes alike in colour, but male larger.
taxon_text_3_6577:
Global: Indigenous to Sub-Saharan Africa and Nile Valley, but has also been introduced to Europe.

Local/Regional: Widespread across region except dry parts.
taxon_text_4_6578:
One of the most common and conspicuous of all waterfowl in the region. Mostly found along the margins of rivers, lakes, wetlands and estuaries and common in suburban parks and gardens, golf courses and the like. Also found along the coastline and recently started roosting on offshore islands in the Western Cape.

Typically have feeding bouts in the morning and afternoon, resting and preening in middle of the day.
taxon_text_5_6579: Herbivorous taking mostly grasses, seeds, leaves and aquatic plants. Do also take insects and small aquatic invertebrates and have been observed feeding on plankton.
taxon_text_6_6580: Monogamous, territorial nesters with complex courtship behaviour. Nests may be on the ground, on cliffs or buildings, or in holes or on platforms in trees. Nest year round, but in Western Cape peaking in July- October with an average of 8 eggs laid per clutch. Eggs unmarked and creamy white. Incubation 28-30 days by female only, with male often guarding territory from vantage point nearby. Chick precocial and leave nest within hours of hatching, sometimes by jumping from elevated nests. Chicks guided to water by adults, sometimes crossing busy roads! Fledging period variable at 55-84 days. Adults defend chicks by herding them to water when threatened, making alarm calls, feining injury and by attacking intruders.
taxon_text_7_6581: Distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other species.
taxon_text_8_6582: Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 91).
taxon_text_1_6584: Very large and readily identified by size alone. Feathers on top of head and nape of neck form a shaggy crest. Head and wings black, speckled with white. Eyes dark brown. Bill black, long and dagger-like. Chest and belly differ between sexes: Male has chest reddish-brown and belly white, marked with black; female has colours reversed, with white breast and belly reddish-brown. Legs and feet dark grey.
taxon_text_3_6586:
Global: Throughout Africa, except desert regions, two regional subspecies recognised.

Local/Regional: Across the wetter eastern and southern regions of South Africa, mostly associated with inland waters, but also along the coast.
taxon_text_4_6587: Fairly common resident around almost any water body with sufficient food and suitable perches. Normally hunts from perch in trees alongside ponds or rivers, periodically raising crest and moving tail up and down. Flies low when changing perches, rising steeply to perch in new location. Seldom hovers, although does so more when fishing at sea. After diving at sea usually washes in freshwater. Prey taken to perch and beaten again solid object till dead, large crabs dismembered before swallowing, smaller ones eaten whole; fish swallowed head first.
taxon_text_6_6589:
Solitary nester. Nests in holes excavated by both sexes in vertical sand or mud banks adjacent to water. The nest hole takes about seven days to dig and is about 90—345 cm long, ending in an unlined chamber. Nest holes may be reused in subsequent years.  

Peak laying dates August – October, usually laying 3-5 almost spherical, glossy white eggs. Incubation time about 25-27 days and young remain in the nest for about 37 days.
taxon_text_7_6590: Very distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other species.
taxon_text_8_6591: Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 183).
taxon_text_1_6593: Relatively small and slender for an ibis, with long neck and legs and very long, relatively pale grey-brown, downwardly-curved bill. Head and neck chestnut brown with a narrow white band running from base of bill around the eyes and across the forehead. Wings dark glossy green. Legs and feet olive grey.
taxon_text_2_6594: Total length 49-66 cm, mass 600-650 g, sexes alike in colour, male slightly larger than female.
taxon_text_3_6595:
Global: Widespread across the Americas, Eurasia, Africa and Australasia.

Local/Regional: Found mostly inland and only reported from Western Cape since the 1940‘s.
taxon_text_4_6596: Mostly found along the margins of rivers, lakes, wetlands and estuaries, but also forms mixed groups with other ibis species feeding on drift seaweeds along the coastline. Mostly diurnal, walking slowly and deliberately and probing into the mud or wrack for live food with the long beak.
taxon_text_5_6597: Takes a wide variety of adult and larval insects, crustaceans and worms, as well as occasional vertebrates. Commonly seen feeding on invertebrates associated with drift kelp on marine beaches in Western Cape where probably taking kelp flies and their larvae and small crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_6598: Nest colonially, often with nests scattered among those of other herons, cormorants and ibises. Nest a small platform of reeds and sticks lined with leaves and grass. In Western Cape nest September to November. Eggs 2-4 deep greenish blue. Incubation alternating between both sexes, duration 20-23 days. Young leave the nest to form creches at about 14 days and can fly and feed themselves after about 42 days.
