taxon_text_7_6599: Could be confused with Hadeda Ibis, but that species is larger, with a much heavier build and shorter, more robust legs and bill. It also has a grey head and neck and a narrow white stripe under the ears.
taxon_text_8_6600: Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 607).
taxon_text_1_6602: Small, mainly white gull with grey back and upper wings, outermost primaries black with white tips. Head and throat with pale grey ‘hood’ (darker and more prominent in breeding season) that is bounded by darker line along its lower edge. Eyes yellowish-white. Bill and legs bright red. Juveniles with head white, upper parts brown, bill black, legs pinkish.
taxon_text_2_6603: Total length 42 cm, wingspan 102 cm mass about 280 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6604:
Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa, the supposed South American population probably representing a distinct species.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but relatively uncommon along west coast.
taxon_text_4_6605: Found both along the coast and across the wetter parts of interior, where associated with lakes and dams, larger rivers, sewage pans, etc. Uncommon on west coast, where they may mix with flocks of Hartlaub’s gull. Usually live in small flocks. Spend the night in communal roosts, departing for feeding grounds in the morning and returning in the evening.
taxon_text_5_6606: Opportunistic and feeds by day. In marine habitats may plunge dive, dip for small invertebrates while swimming, or catch prey by running though shallow water or on drift-line. Inland feed on aquatic invertebrates such as snails and insect larvae, on termite alates, moths around lights and the like. Also follows ploughs, scavenges at dumps, picnic sites or for offal and scraps.
taxon_text_6_6607: Breeds in colonies of a few to several hundred pairs, especially on islands. Nest a shallow bowl of grass, twigs and leaves. Mostly breeds in winter, usually laying 3 eggs which are pale blue-green or brown with spotted and blotched with brown.
taxon_text_7_6608: Can easily be confused with Hartlaub’s gull, which is the dominant species on the west coast, where Grey-headed gull is rare. Hartlaub’s gull is slightly smaller with shorter legs and bill and has a much less pronounced, lavender hood, dark brown to red legs and dark-brown eyes.
taxon_text_8_6609:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 350).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 443).
taxon_text_1_6611: Large, tall heron with white head and long, sharply-pointed, pinkish beak; head with broad, horizontal, black stripe extending from eye to 2-3 long black plumes extending from nape. Neck white with broken black stripes down front. Back, tail and wings grey, wings with black shoulders. Legs and feet pinkish.
taxon_text_2_6612: Total length 90-98 cm, mass 1-2 kg, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6613:
Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa, Europe and Asia.

Local/Regional: Widespread inland and along the coast, except in Namibia, Northern Cape and Kalahari, where rare.
taxon_text_4_6614: Fairly common along the margins of various inland water bodies, as well as along the coastline, rarely also in dry grassland. Usually solitary and active both by day and night. Usually seen standing motionless in or next to water, rapidly striking to spear or grasp prey in beak. Small items may be immediately swallowed alive, but larger ones are shaken or stabbed to death then manipulated into a head-first position before being swallowed.
taxon_text_5_6615: Feeds mainly on fish, but also take crustaceans, molluscs and other invertebrates (also frogs, reptiles and small rodents and birds when in freshwater).
taxon_text_6_6616: Monogamous and usually nests in colonies, sometimes mixed among other water birds. Nest a large basin of sticks and reeds lined with grass and other softer materials, may be placed on top of an earlier nest, resulting in a massive structure. Usually placed above water, built by female from material supplied by male. Eggs 1-4, oval and pointed at both ends, blue or greenish blue, in Western Cape laid mainly July - January. Incubation period 23-28 days. Young fully fledged by 28 days, nestlings compete and younger chicks of larger broods progressively smaller, youngest seldom survive. Leave nest at about 20 days and sit on nearby branches, where continue to be fed by both adults.
taxon_text_7_6617: Similar to Black-headed heron, but that has black back up to head and neck and is largely terrestrial and seldom found on the shore.
taxon_text_8_6618:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 587).
taxon_text_1_6620:
Large ibis with long, dark, slightly downwardly-curved bill with a red patch at base of upper mandible. Head and neck grey with white stripe below ear. Back olive-brown and broad, powerful wings iridescent purple to green. Legs black with red on upper surface of toes. Sexes alike, juveniles like adults, but duller and with shorter beak.

Also easily recognised by the frequent, loud, raucous ‘ha-dee-da’ call.
taxon_text_2_6621: Total length 76 cm, mass 1250 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6622:
Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa.

Local/Regional: Found inland and along coast in moister habitats across whole region, except arid western parts.
taxon_text_4_6623:
Widespread across region, but only recently extended its range into Western Cape, probably as a result of increasing availability of both food and of large alien trees in which to nest. Only arrived in Cape Peninsula in 1980’s, but now abundant in the area.

Found in pairs or small family groups, mainly in grassland, forest clearings, parks, playing fields, gardens and playing fields, but also on the seashore, especially where kelp wrack is abundant. Probe for food with the long beak, which may be thrust deep into the soil.
taxon_text_5_6624: Takes a wide variety of prey from the ground, feeding both at the surface and by probing for earthworms and other invertebrates. Commonly seen feeding on invertebrates associated with drift kelp on marine beaches in Western Cape.
taxon_text_6_6625: Monogamous and, unusually for ibis, solitary nesters, breeding in the Cape mostly in October-November. Nest a large platform made of sticks, lined with grass, lichen and leaves and placed in the fork of a horizontal branch, usually 4-5 m above the ground in a large tree, often above water, rarely on cliffs or man-made structures. Eggs 1-5 broad-oval, light brown to greenish, densely marked with brown streak and spots. Both parents incubate eggs. Incubation about 26 days. Young fed by regurgitation and fledge in about 33 days.
taxon_text_7_6626: Could be confused with Glossy ibis, but that species is darker chestnut-brown and smaller, with a much lighter build and longer, more slender legs and bill.
taxon_text_8_6627: Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 609).
taxon_text_1_6629:
Small, mainly white gull with grey back and upper wings, outermost primaries black, the outer two with white tips and white flashes. Head with pale lavender-grey ‘hood’ often only visible as a slightly darker line along its lower edge. Eyes dark brown. Bill and legs dark red.

Juveniles with upper parts mottled brown.
taxon_text_2_6630: Total length 36-38 cm, wingspan 92 cm, mass of male about 290 g, of female 265 g.
taxon_text_3_6631:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Primarily along west coast from northern Namibia to Cape Agulhas, but recorded in lower numbers as far east as Algoa Bay and vagrants to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6632: Predominantly a coastal and estuarine species, seldom found far out to sea. Habituate readily to transformed landscapes and common in urban areas, nesting on buildings, bathing in urban ponds and swimming pools and scavenging from bins, picnickers and restaurant tables, etc. About half the total population occur in the greater Cape Town area, where very common.
taxon_text_5_6633: Omnivorous and under natural conditions feed by snatching prey from the water surface at sea, or small estuarine fish, by puddling for invertebrates in shallow water, on dead animals washed up along the drift-line, on kelp-fly larvae washed out of wrack beds at high tide and the like. Also commonly feed inland, following ploughs, feeding on termite alates, moths, grasshoppers, etc. Commonly scavenge behind trawlers, or from domestic waste, around open-air restaurants and picnic sites, etc.
taxon_text_6_6634: Historically probably bred only on offshore islands, but now regularly use roofs of buildings. Nest an untidy structure of plant stems. Breeds mostly in winter, laying 1-3 light brown to dark green eggs overlain with brown or grey blotches or scrolls. Incubation period about 25 days, young fed by regurgitation.
taxon_text_7_6635: Can easily be confused with Grey-headed gull, which is relatively rare on west coast and more common inland and along south and east coasts. That species is also slightly larger with longer legs and bill and has a more pronounced grey hood and pale eyes.
taxon_text_8_6636:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 350).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 444).
taxon_text_1_6638:
Large gull with white head, neck, trailing edge of wing and underside; back and upper surface of wings black; outer primary feathers with white spots. Bill bright yellow with distinctive red spot on the underside. Eye dark brown with orange ring. Legs and feet dark yellow or dull green to grey. Juveniles mottled brown with dark bill.

There are five recognized subspecies in different parts of the range, the South Africa subspecies is named L. d. vetula and recognized by its slightly smaller, shorter bill and darker eyes.
taxon_text_2_6639: Total length 49-65 cm, wingspan 128-142 cm mass 1000 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6640:
Global: Widespread across Southern Hemisphere with different sub-species in southern Africa; subantarctic islands in the Indian Ocean; Madagascar; the Antarctic; and in South America, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Found along coast across whole region.
taxon_text_4_6641: Predominantly coastal species, seldom found far inland or far out to sea. Common resident found in diverse marine, estuarine and coastal land habitats. Roosts at night in communal sites mostly on islands or coastal buildings, dispersing to feeding areas in the morning. Breeds on offshore islands and on coastal cliffs.
taxon_text_5_6642: Generalist forager and scavenger feeding on a wide range of natural prey, as well as on scraps from fishing boats, on rubbish dumps, etc. Also take scraps from feeding seals at sea; scavenges for dead animals cast ashore after storms; puddles for invertebrates on beaches; drops large mussels or turban shells on rocks to crack their shells, etc. In terrestrial sites takes insects, berries, frogs, snakes and carrion. May also predate eggs and chicks of other seabirds, or rob them of food.
taxon_text_6_6643: Monogamous and thought to retain same mate for successive years. Nest a shallow depression on the ground on islands or cliffs; lined with grass, twigs, shells, kelp and other debris. Usually lays 2-4 eggs that are off-white to blue-green, mottled with blotches or spots of black or brown. Incubation period 26-27 days; fledge after 46-73 days. Both parents brood and feed young.
taxon_text_7_6644: Unmistakable and the only large gull in the region.
taxon_text_8_6645:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 350).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 439).
taxon_text_1_6647: Plumage almost entirely white, 2-3 long plumes forming a crest on back of head. Bill black, long and slender, an area of bare orange skin around eye and base of bill; eyes yellow becoming orange to red when breeding. Legs black and feet characteristically yellow (becoming more orange when breeding).
taxon_text_2_6648: Total length 64 cm, mass about 520 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6649:
Global: Widespread across Africa, Middle East, Asia and Australia (regional subspecies recognised).

Local/Regional: Inland and along the coast, except in driest regions.
taxon_text_4_6650: Fairly common along the margins of inland water bodies, as well as along the coastline. Roosts communally at night, but often solitary during the day, patrolling the water margin with a high stepping gait that reveals the distinctive yellow feet. Hunts by either walking or running though shallow water stabbing at prey, or by standing motionless waiting for prey to reveal themselves.
taxon_text_5_6651: Feeds mainly on small fish, but also take crustaceans, molluscs and other invertebrates (also frogs, reptiles and small birds when in freshwater).
taxon_text_6_6652: Monogamous and nests in colonies, almost always mixed among other water birds. Nest a platform of sticks and reeds usually placed above water, built by female from material supplied by male. Eggs 2-4, oval, greenish blue, in Western Cape laid mainly August – December. Incubation period 21-25 days. Young brooded and fed by both adults, leave nest at about 30 days and fully fledged after 40-50 days, but continue to be fed by adults well after fledging.
taxon_text_7_6653: Yellow feet a characteristic feature. Several otherwise similar egrets in the region, but these seldom seen on the seashore.
taxon_text_8_6654:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 583).
taxon_text_1_6656: Medium-sized kingfisher with black crest on head, eyes black, bill long, black and dagger-like. Dorsal parts black with white markings. Neck and chest white with broad black collar almost broken in centre. Male has a second much narrower black band below, but this absent in female. Legs and feet black.
taxon_text_3_6658:
Global: Across Africa, Middle East and Asia, except driest parts. Five regional subspecies recognised.

Local/Regional: Across the wetter eastern and southern regions of South Africa, mostly associated with inland waters, but also along the coast.
taxon_text_4_6659:
Common resident and one of the three most common kingfishers in the world. Found on almost any inland water body with small fish, less abundant in fast-flowing streams and mountainous areas. Also common along seashores.

Usually seen singly or in pairs, but roosts communally at night. Perches conspicuously, often raising and lowering the tail. Frequently hovers with body held almost vertical and head forward. Also bathed by making several rapid shallow dives, then preening vigorously. Prey are battered to death before being swallowed head first.
taxon_text_5_6660: Feeds mainly on small fish, but also takes crustaceans and large insects.
taxon_text_6_6661:
Nests in holes excavated by both sexes in vertical sand or mud banks adjacent to water. The nest hole takes an average of 27 days to dig and is about 6 cm in diameter and 80-240 cm long, ending in an unlined chamber.  

Peak laying dates August – November, usually laying 4-6 almost spherical, glossy white eggs. Incubation time about 18 days and young remain in the nest for about 24-29 days.  Unusual in that they are often co-operative breeders with young birds from previous broods assisting the parents, or even unrelated adults, to raise their young. Number of helpers increases in sites with poor food supply.
taxon_text_7_6662: Very distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other species.
taxon_text_8_6663: Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 184).
taxon_text_1_6665: Small wader with a hunched appearance, short black bill, white belly and black markings on neck and chest. Perhaps best identified by the short, distinctively bright-orange legs. Intensity of plumage varies considerably with breeding condition. Breeding birds have mainly white head with intense black collar and bands, bright white chest and striking chestnut and black patches on wings. Non-breeding birds duller and more muted with darker head and less-obvious black markings.
taxon_text_2_6666: Total length 21-25 cm, wingspan 50-57 cm, mass 85-150 g.
taxon_text_3_6667:
Global: Breeds in northern hemisphere in both Asia and Northern Europe. Summer migrants to coastal areas of Africa, Asia and Australia.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region.
taxon_text_4_6668: Almost entirely coastal in their non-breeding range and found mostly on rocky shores, or on beaches where kelp or seagrass are deposited. Forages mostly by day in small, loose flocks, sometimes with other small waders such as Sanderlings. Has a characteristic feeding behaviour in which flips over stones or drift seaweeds with the strong neck and bill to access invertebrates hiding beneath.
taxon_text_5_6669: Eats a diversity of invertebrates including gastropods, isopods and amphipods, polychaete worms and insect larvae.
taxon_text_6_6670: Does not breed in South Africa, but in northern latitudes, where lay 2-5 eggs laid in a shallow scrape among vegetation or on stony or rocky ground.
taxon_text_7_6671: The distinctive colour pattern and orange legs make this species unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_6672:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 346).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 361).
taxon_text_1_6674: Small, plump wader with straight, black bill. Non-breeding birds mostly pale (hence the species name alba, meaning white) except mottled grey wings and tail and marked dark shoulder patch. Head with darker cap, band through eye and band across back of neck. Underside white. Eyes dark brown, legs and feet black. Breeding birds much darker.
taxon_text_2_6675: Total length 20-21 cm, wingspan 43 cm, mass 55-60 g.
taxon_text_3_6676:
Global: Breeds in the high Arctic of North America, Asia and Europe. Summer migrant to coastal areas across the world.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region, but most common on west coast, especially Namibia.
taxon_text_4_6677: Arrives in South Africa from breeding grounds in Siberia and Greenland in about September and leaves again in May. Primarily found in small groups on beaches, less often on rocky shores, often running rapidly ahead of the waves and probing for small invertebrates. May use ‘stitching’ technique, which leaves characteristic pattern zig-zag lines of holes in sand. Roosts above the high-water mark, often communally with other waders.
taxon_text_5_6678: On west coast beaches with kelp wrack takes mostly beach hoppers (talitrid amphipods) and kelp fly larvae. On beaches without wrack consumes burrowing amphipods and isopods, polychaete worms, white mussels (sometimes just their siphons) and mysids shrimps. On rocky shores may also take small bivalves, insect larvae and juvenile klipfish.
taxon_text_6_6679: Does not breed in South Africa, but only in northern latitudes. Solitary nester, the nest is a shallow scrape on the ground, often lined with lichen or dry leaves. Eggs 2-4, laid in June and July, greenish with small brown markings. Incubation by both parents, duration 24-32 days, young fledge after 17 days. Often two clutches raised in the breeding season.
taxon_text_7_6680: Can be confused with Little or Red-necked stints, but these are much smaller (12-16 cm).
taxon_text_8_6681:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 348).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 364).
taxon_text_1_6683:
Adults in breeding plumage have a full black cap extending from base of bill, through bottom of eye to nape of neck, where extended into a crest. Bill long, thin and black with a characteristic yellow tip. Back and upper wings ash-grey, outer wing feathers dark. Rump, neck and belly white. Eyes very dark brown, legs and feet black.

In non-breeding plumage the forehead becomes white and the black cap much less pronounced.
taxon_text_2_6684: Total length 36-41 cm, wingspan 95-105 cm, mass 190-230 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6685:
Global: Breeds in Western Europe and North America, non-breeding in Southern Africa and South America.

Local/Regional: Widely distributed along entire coastline, with greatest numbers on West Coast.
taxon_text_4_6686: Does not breed in South Africa, but migrates here in southern summer, arriving about September and leaving by about March. Totally marine and rarely found inland. May form mixed flocks with other terns. Mostly found on mixed sandy and rocky coastlines with clear, shallow water. May bathe in shallow salt water, but rarely swims.
taxon_text_5_6687: Hunts a variety of small fish up to 120 mm long, also crustaceans and molluscs.
taxon_text_6_6688: Breeds in Europe and North America, not in South Africa. Start nesting at age 3-4. Nest a shallow scrap on the ground sometimes lined with debris, often positioned among other nesting terns. Eggs 1-2, rarely 3, green, heavily speckled and blotched with black and brown; incubated by both parents for 21-29 days. Chicks make first flight 28-32 days, but may remain with parents a further 4 months
taxon_text_7_6689: Fairly easily identified by the long, thin, black bill with its yellow tip.
taxon_text_8_6690:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 455).
taxon_text_1_6692: Relatively large tern with grey upper parts and white underparts. Easily identified by the long, pointed, uniformly yellow bill and shaggy black crest on the head. Eyes dark brown, legs and feet black.
taxon_text_2_6693: Total length 46-50 cm, wingspan 90-115 cm, mass 380-395 g, sexes alike.
taxon_text_3_6694:
Global: Widespread around the coasts of the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans (several regional subspecies recognised).

Local/Regional: Along the coast across region, not inland.
taxon_text_4_6695:
Fairly common in nearshore marine environments, estuaries and lagoons. May be solitary, or in flocks of up to several hundred birds. Roosts or rests on beaches, rocky shores or saltworks, sometimes perching on artificial structures such as bridges, boats and harbour buildings.

Forages by plunge diving or dipping, but does not penetrate beyond top 1 m of water. Usually feeds within 10 km of land. Food usually swallowed in flight.
taxon_text_5_6696: Feeds mainly on small pelagic shoaling fish, particularly anchovy and sardine. May also scavenge discards from commercial fishing operations.
taxon_text_6_6697: Monogamous and may retain pair bond between years. Colonial nesters, often with other seabirds, particularly Hartlaub’s gulls. Nest a shallow scrape in sand or flat, open ground, often unlined. Breeding season in Western Cape mostly January to April, eggs usually 1-2 cream or pale pink or blue, spotted and streaked with brown or mauve. Incubation 21-30 days. Chicks fledge at 38-40 days, older chick forming creches, adults locating their young by voice. Chicks remain dependent on adults till they are about four months old.
taxon_text_7_6698: The yellow bill is distinctive. Several other tern species are found in the region, but have red or black bills.
taxon_text_8_6699:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 453).
taxon_text_1_6701: Small, chubby wader with short, black beak. Male with top of head grey, a dark band on forehead, a narrow, dark line from neck running though eye to beak. Wings and back brown to grey with central tail feathers black. Underside white with a pale brown patch on upper breast. Eyes dark brown, legs and feet grey to green-grey. Female similar, but black band on forehead less obvious to absent.
taxon_text_3_6703:
Global: Endemic to Sub-Saharan Africa.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region, also inland in northern areas.
taxon_text_4_6704: Resident species present year-round and one of the most common of coastal shorebirds, especially in Western Cape. Mostly on beaches, but also estuaries, rocky shore and inland water bodies. Usually resident in pairs or small parties. Forages in intertidal or among kelp wrack both by day and at night, running around and stopping suddenly to peck at an item before continuing on. Prey may be pecked from shallow water, or by jabbing bill into the sand.
taxon_text_5_6705: Feeds on a variety of small gastropods, bivalves, crustaceans, worms and insects.
taxon_text_6_6706: Solitary nesters and maintain territories which are defended against both neighbouring pairs and other waders. Nest a simple scrape in the sand above the high-water mark, or in dunes. Breeds year round but peak in Western Cape September - November. Eggs 1-3, putty-coloured, sparsely marked with fine brown or black spots and lines. Incubation 27-29 days, fledge after 35-38 days.
taxon_text_7_6707: Three regional subspecies differ slightly in colour, east coast form paler. Can be confused with Kittlitz’s plover, but that is darker with more striking head markings, including wide black band though eye.
taxon_text_8_6708:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 348).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 403).
taxon_text_1_6710: Easily recognized by its much larger size than other regional cormorants and by the distinctive white throat and pinkish-white chest. Bill powerful, with hooked tip. Rest of body dark glossy brown to black. Feathers on back brown with black margins. Eyes green, legs and feet black.
taxon_text_2_6711: Total length 90 cm, wingspan 150 cm mass about 2000 g, sexes look alike, but female slightly smaller than male.
taxon_text_3_6712:
Global: Widespread across southern half of Africa, both inland and along coasts.

Local/Regional: Whole region, along coast and inland across wetter southern and eastern parts.
taxon_text_4_6713:
Common and widespread in both salt and freshwater habitats and often seen in groups roosting on rocks, logs, etc., where may associate with other cormorants. Stands erect, drying, oiling and preening plumage, often spreading the wings to dry and to warm stomach contents. Regularly commutes up to 10 km between roosting and foraging sites.

Flies with neck outstretched and lands belly-first in water, often using depressed tail as a brake. Sits low in the water with only head, neck and upper back exposed and forages by diving and seizing prey underwater. Feeds on bouts, each comprising a series of short dives of about 30 seconds with brief rests between. Longer rest periods between foraging bouts.
taxon_text_5_6714: Feeds on fish, which are grasped between the mandibles underwater, the hook on the upper mandible often puncturing the skin. Small prey may be swallowed underwater. Larger prey swallowed head first and can take fish up to 376 g. May also swallow stones to reduce buoyancy.
taxon_text_6_6715: Colonial nester, often in association with other cormorants or pelicans. Coastal populations mostly nest on islands or cliffs, but also on man-made structures. Nest a flat platform male of sticks, seaweeds and sundry other debris and guarded to prevent theft of materials by other individuals. Nest year round in Western Cape, but peaking in September - December. Eggs 2-5, bluish-white with chalky white layer. Incubation 27-28 days and brooded by both parents with changeovers at least twice a day. Chicks fledge at 49-56 days.
taxon_text_7_6716: Unmistakable due to white breast and much larger size than other cormorants.
taxon_text_8_6717:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 575).
taxon_text_1_6719: A small white-bodied dorid with a visible dark visceral mass. Head white with white rhinophores. Gills white, forming a complete circle. Posterior end of foot tapered, white. Lateral edges of mantle with distinct white line. Egg ribbon a flat spiral of large yolky white eggs, suggesting a reduced larval stage.
taxon_text_3_6721:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, intertidal to 42m.
taxon_text_4_6722: Often encountered on densely colonised rocky reefs and especially on False lace corals (Chaperia spp.) which they feed on.
taxon_text_5_6723: This species preys on bryozoans using their radula to scrape off individual zooids, which is the modular animal a bryozoan colony comprises of. The Scroll false-coral bryozoans Chaperia spp. has frequently been observed to be preyed upon.
taxon_text_6_6724: As in all nudibranchs, individuals are hermaphrodites.
taxon_text_7_6725: Unmistakable, as it is the only small, white nudibranch in the region. Though, it is worth noting this species forms part of a species complex that comprises at least three species. Further research is required to separate these.
taxon_text_1_6728: Elongated, more-or-less parallel-sided isopod with large bulging eyes and obvious side plates. Some specimens swollen around body segments 4-5. Head crossed by a transverse dorsal furrow behind the eyes. Abdominal segments fused and joined to telson to form an elongate ‘pleotelson’ which is more-or-less parallel–sided with a squared-off end. The pleotelson has one complete segmental division at its base followed by two partial crimp-like ‘sutures’ or partial joints on either side. Colour dark brown, often with silvery metallic sheen.
taxon_text_4_6731: Usually associated with drifting seaweeds or other debris on the high seas and may be cast ashore after inshore winds, when it can be abundant.
taxon_text_6_6733: As with all isopods the eggs are retained in a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.
taxon_text_7_6734: The metallic sheen is a useful identification feature, but can otherwise be confused with species of the genus Paridotea, which have a similar elongated and parallel-sided body form. Paridotea however, have smaller eyes, lack the groove across the head and often have pointed tips to the corners of the pleotelson.
taxon_text_8_6735:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isodods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 38)
taxon_text_1_6737: Small, and very unusual in shape with a broad, depressed body, very short antennae that turn to the side after the first joint and broad splayed side plates and posterior legs. A distinct ridge also runs down the midline of the back. Colour green.
taxon_text_3_6739:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6740: Rarely seen and previously known only from the more tropical east coast. This is the first record of this small but distinctive species from the Western Cape. Found on a kelp holdfast, but nothing known about the diet or biology of this species.
taxon_text_5_6741: Unknown but likely herbivorous - most species in this family being associated with algae.
taxon_text_6_6742: As with all amphipods the eggs are released into a brood pouch between the legs of the female, where they are fertilized by males and develop into fully-formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_6743: Unmistakable, but could easily be mistaken for an isopod as has the depressed body shape more typical of that group than of amphipods, which are typically compressed side to side (structure of the abdomen is definitely that of an amphipod though!).
taxon_text_8_6744:
Barnard, KH (1940). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa 12. Further additions to the Tanaidacea, Isopoda, and Amphipoda, together with keys for the identification of the hitherto recorded marine and freshwater species. Annals of the South African Museum, 32, 381-543.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 75 as Palinnotus natalensis).
taxon_text_1_6818:
Small brown algae that grow in tufts of flattened, dichotomously-branching fronds with no midrib. Fronds 3 cells thick. Clumps attached to the substratum by branching rhizoids. Colour often bright green with paler edges to fronds. The east coast D. humifusa is bright blue.

Several similar species occur in the region, at least one of which is still undescribed, so we group these under a single generic entry. The species depicted is probably D. dichotoma.
taxon_text_2_6819: Small tufts typically from 2-6 cm tall and blades 2-5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6820:
Global: Genus widespread, with over 90 described species.

Local/Regional: Langebaan to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6821: Form small clumps in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_6823: Alternating generations of spore-producing sporophytes and separate male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6824: The small size and dichotomous branching fronds are good identification features at genus level, but species can be hard to distinguish.
taxon_text_8_6825:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 382).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 165).
taxon_text_1_6449:
Familiar blue colonian hydrozoan that floats on the water surface and is frequently cast ashore following onshore winds. The colony is supported by a large inflated float with a crimped upper margin. Hanging beneath this are other zooids specialized for prey capture, feeding or reproduction. Most conspicuous are the long trailing tentacles used for prey capture and which can be extended many meters below the float, or contracted into a tight spiral. These are armed with conspicuous nematocysts which can inflict a painful sting.

Until recently all bluebottles were grouped under the one name Physalia physalis, but recent research has shown that there are in fact 4 species and some earlier names, including this one, have now been re-established. Physalia utriculus can be recognised by its relatively long, nearly un-crimped, low and even crest to the float, which has a plain blue edge and a short ‘float-tail’; by the gap between two groups of hanging zooids and by the fact that there is usually just one long major feeding tentacle. Colour is distinctive with this species having a plain blue float and tentacles, with the feeding zooids having yellow mouths.
taxon_text_2_6450: Floats typically 50 mm long, but stinging tentacles can be over 10 m when extended, typically 300 mm when contracted.
taxon_text_3_6451:
Global:  Widespread in warm and temperate seas, but not N Atlantic where replaced by P. physalis.

Local/Regional: Whole region but less common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_6452:
Floats on the ocean surface, where driven along at the mercy of prevailing winds blowing on the sail. There are both left and right-handed individuals, so these will be driven in different directions by the wind. The extremely long feeding tentacles extend far below the float and are used to capture prey swimming in the water column. The stinging cells are very venomous and can paralyse even quite large fish, which are then ‘reeled in’ by contraction of the tentacle and engulfed by feeding ‘gastrozooids’ for digestion and distribution of the nutrients among colony members.

Bluebottles can inflict painful and even dangerous stings, so should not be handled, even after they have been washed up on beaches, as the nematocysts remain potent for many hours after death. Swimming in the presence of bluebottles is also dangerous, as the extended tentacles can wrap around the body and inflict long, painful welts of stings. Despite their strong venom they are fed upon by several predators, including Sea swallow nudibranchs, plough shells and loggerhead turtles.
taxon_text_5_6453: Feed on small fish, as well as on planktonic crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_6454: Each colony is either male or female and eggs and sperm are shed into the water, where they merge to form larvae that drift in the water column and bud off new zooids as they develop. Once a pneumatophore or float-forming zooid is formed, the developing colony rises to the surface and begin its adult life.
taxon_text_7_6455: Genus unmistakable and perhaps the best known of all hydrozoans. Two species are currently reported from South Africa, the other being P. megalista which has a more elevated sail with a pink margin and often a long, upturned tail to the float, and no yellow around the openings of the feeding zooids. Being an Atlantic species the true Physalia physalis may also well extend down into South African waters, but that species is more similar to P. megalista.
taxon_text_8_6456:

taxon_text_1_6755:
Usually solitary, initially light brown, darkening with age to become almost black. Fronds emerge from a conical, grooved holdfast and are thick and leathery, with flattened, wing-like expansions, forming a row of triangular sections. Main axis branches alternately in a single plane.

Reproductive receptacles paddle-like and borne on a short stalk arising from upper conners of the main segments.
taxon_text_3_6757:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution from Cape Peninsula to Cape Columbine.
taxon_text_4_6758: Fairly large and conspicuous species, but has a very restricted distribution of only about 200 km. The taxonomic position of this unusual genus is confused and it has been moved between families several times!
taxon_text_6_6760: Reproductive structures borne on the upper corners of the triangular, paddle-shaped fertile branches.
taxon_text_7_6761: The unusual segmented-looking form of the main axes is fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_6762:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 388).

taxon_text_1_6773: Forms extensive bunches of upright yellow-brown stems emerging from a mat of intertwining root-like rhizomes. Stems about 3-4 mm diameter, initially unbranched, but soon develop flattened alternate lateral branches. Older branches constricted at their bases.
taxon_text_2_6774: Upright stems reaching in height, stems about 3 mm wide. Single individual can form dense mats up to 1 m in diameter.
taxon_text_3_6775:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Has a surprisingly limited distribution from only about the Cape Peninsula to Cape Agulhas (with a couple isolated records beyond).
taxon_text_4_6776:
An interesting species in that it forms extensive colonies that can dominate considerable areas of the lower intertidal, but nevertheless has an extremely limited geographic range. Holdfasts appear to be long lived, but give rise to new generations of upright stems each year. The unusual and equally range-restricted amphipod Macropisthopus stebbingi, which has an enormously swollen last pair of legs, appears to have an obligate association with this alga, weaving small nests in the branches between the main stem and its lateral branches.

Edible and has a pleasant, crunchy texture and nutty taste when eaten raw.
taxon_text_6_6778: Dominance achieved primarily by vegetate spread of the rhizomes. Individuals are of a single sex and reproductive organs are borne in two tows or conceptacles on either side of lateral stems.
taxon_text_7_6779: Can be confused with Upright wrack Bifurcariopsis capensis (also because of similarly long generic name!) but that species emerges from a single disc-shaped holdfast and has a more bush-like form with sparser, tougher, more woody branches.
taxon_text_8_6780:

taxon_text_1_6782: Elongate, stringy, yellow-brown, but darkening with age. Several thin thali arise from a crustose base and give off numerous side branches. Secondary branches may lack further branching, but sometimes have a profusion of short lateral branches.
taxon_text_2_6783: Total length can reach 40 cm. Strings only about 1 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6784:
Global: New Zealand, South Africa, Antarctica and Southern Ocean islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Tsitsikamma.
taxon_text_4_6785: Can be one of dominant species in mid to lowshore pools. Often lying flaccidly on bottom of sandy pools.
taxon_text_6_6787: Tiny cylindrical sporangia embedded in the branches.
taxon_text_7_6788: Elongate, stringy form fairly distinctive among brown algae.

taxon_text_1_6791: Thin, pale yellowish-brown, cushion-like alga, attached by a broad base. Comprised of a thin, smooth, convoluted surface skin comprising only a few layers of cells and enclosing a large internal cavity.
taxon_text_2_6792: Total length can reach 10 cm, but more typically 2-4 cm.
taxon_text_3_6793:
Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate seas around the world.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6794: Typically found attached to other algae, on intertidal rocks, or in pools. During the day oxygen generated by photosynthesis may accumulate in the internal cavity and the ball may become buoyant, lifting not only the alga itself but anything it is attached to – hence the common name oyster thief!
taxon_text_6_6796: Tiny sporangia embedded in surface and often in clusters around hair bundles.
taxon_text_7_6797: Often confused with Brown brains Leathesia marina, but that species is darker in colour and has thicker walls and a smaller internal cavity.

taxon_text_1_6809: Erect thallus emerging from a holdfast of matted rhizoids branches dichotomously several times, final fronds about 1 cm wide and pale brown to yellowish-brown, often with a bluish tinge. Oval reproductive sori form dark marks on both surfaces of fronds, each elongate-oval, about 1.5 mm long and often with hair-tufts.
taxon_text_2_6810: Forms fairly large tufts, typically about 35 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_6811:
Global: Widespread with records from South Africa, Canary Islands, Senegal, Japan, Australia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal
taxon_text_4_6812: Fairly common in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs on wave-exposed coasts.
taxon_text_6_6814: Alternating generations of similar looking spore-producing sporophytes and separate male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6815: Several regional species in the genus. D. liturata has a similar range but narrower fronds with much more extensive branching.
taxon_text_8_6816:

taxon_text_1_6827: The largest and best known of all regional algae and an iconic feature of the west coast. The large, conical holdfast is comprised of a network of cylindrical, branched, root-like haptera. This gives rise to a long, hollow stipe that arises from a thin base and then swells distally, ending in a gas-filled bulb that buoys the fronds to the surface. Primary frond ribbon-shaped in juveniles, but becomes broadly triangular in adults and gives rise to long, strap-like secondary blades along its margins. Spores are borne on raided patches on the blades.
taxon_text_2_6828: Total length varies with water depth, as stipe stops growing when fronds reach surface. Typically about 5 m, but can reach up to 15 m.
taxon_text_3_6829:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas, but is spreading eastwards as a result of climate change and recently reported from De Hoop.
taxon_text_4_6830:
Forms extensive beds that extend from the low water mark to about 10 m depth. Since the gas-filled stipe raises the fronds to the water surface the beds are very visible and are a prominent feature of the west coast.

Play numerous important roles, including protection of the coastline from wave action and acting as a substratum for numerous smaller species, many of which occur only on this one host species. Kelp beds support a rich and diverse community of understory algae, invertebrate and fish species that include commercially important species, such as rock-lobsters and abalone. Some of these have an obligate relationship with the kelps and are found nowhere else.

Kelp wrack washed up on adjacent beaches also supports a rich and diverse fauna of beach-hoppers, isopods, kelp flies, etc.

Kelps are also directly harvested to feed farmed abalone and for production of an agricultural growth stimulant. Young fronds are also edible and can be used to make delicious kelp noodles!
taxon_text_6_6832: Alternating generations of the familiar large spore-producing sporophytes and separate microscopic male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6833: Sometimes confused with the Split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida, which occurs in mixed beds, but that species has a solid stipe with no terminal bulb and a single, flat frond that is split into parallel straps.

taxon_text_1_6845: Forms small, but dense tufts of thin branching filaments each made up of a single chain of cells. Main filaments and side branches taper towards tips and bear numerous conical sporangia along their margins. Colour reddish-brown.
taxon_text_2_6846: Colonies typically up to about 2-3 cm tall, but rarely up to 20 cm. Axes a fraction of 1 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6847:
Global: Cosmopolitan.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth on west coast to about East London.
taxon_text_4_6848: A small but common species forming short tufts on rocks or other larger algae from the high intertidal downwards. Often abundant and larger in brackish habitats.
taxon_text_6_6850: Alternating sporophyte and gametophyte generations. Sporophyte bears conical sporangia directly along the margins of main axes.
taxon_text_7_6851: A confusing genus containing many species , some of which are probably incorrectly named. This species, which was originally described from the UK, also has numerous synonyms and may turn out to be a complex of regional species.

taxon_text_1_6854: Forms a series of broad, flat, partially-overlapping, fan-like lobes that are stacked horizontally one above the other. Texture firm and colour yellowish-brown with a pale marginal band, sometimes showing a blue iridescence. Primary fans divided into a series of secondary lobes by slits that extend about a third back from margin.
taxon_text_2_6855: Lobes about 30 mm long, entire colony up to about 100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_6856:
Global: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6857: Found on rocky reefs from the low intertidal to a depth of about 40 m.
taxon_text_6_6859: Sporangia mainly on ventral surfaces of fronds, each containing 8 spores.
taxon_text_7_6860: Fairly distinctive growth form. To the east of their range could be confused with Turkey-tails Padina spp., but those do not occur in Western Cape.

taxon_text_1_6863: Fairly short, tufted species with many-branched axes arising from a root-like holdfast. Each axis with numerous stiff, distally directed, bristle-like side-branches coming off in all directions, like a furry bottle-brush. Colour light to dark brown, with pale tips.
taxon_text_2_6864: Total length can reach 200 mm but typically much shorter.
taxon_text_3_6865:
Global: Namibia, South Africa, Argentina, Chile, Antactica and Southern Ocean islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_6866: In kelp understorey or in mid to lowshore pools down to a depth of about 12 m.
taxon_text_6_6868: Gametophytes rare, probably dioecious. Sporangia in dense clusters in axils of laterals. Oogonia spherical, each borne on a pedicel clusters of up to 3 in axils of laterals.
taxon_text_7_6869: The stiff, brush like branches are fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_6870:

taxon_text_1_6872: Forms knobbly, hemispherical yellowish to light-brown cushions weakly attached to substratum. Initially solid, but larger individuals develop a central cavity.
taxon_text_2_6873: Total diameter can reach about 10 cm, with a height of about 4 cm.
taxon_text_3_6874:
Global: North-west Indian Ocean (India, Pakistan, Arabian Sea), Singapore and Papua New Guinea and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6875: Typically found attached to rocks in sheltered intertidal pools. Avoids wave-swept areas as attachment is weak.
taxon_text_6_6877: Tiny sporangia in groups embedded in surface.
taxon_text_7_6878: May be confused with Oyster thief Colpomenia sinuosa, but that species has a much smoother surface and very thin walls surrounding a large internal cavity. The rather odd distribution suggests that the South African species may be incorrectly named and distinct from that in the more tropical Indo-Pacific.

taxon_text_1_6746: Large, bushy, dark to yellowish-brown species emerging from a conical holdfast. Primary stipes flattened and twisted and give rise to alternating and very-elongate, spear-shaped ‘leaves’ with serrated margins. Some of these have bladders at their bases. Fertile branches emerge from the axils of the main ‘leaves’ and consist of grape-like clusters of receptacles.
taxon_text_3_6748:
Global: India, Mozambique, and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6749: Large species forming dense beds in deep pools and on shallow reefs down to a depth of about 10 m depth. Often dominate in deep pools.
taxon_text_6_6751: Reproductive receptacles are born in delicate, many-branched structures borne at the bases of the leaves.
taxon_text_7_6752: Distinguished by the very long, serrate leaves. The related Sargassum incisifolium has much shorter leaves that come in two different forms, one wide and smooth edged and the other serrate, but relatively short.

taxon_text_1_604:
Pycnogonids are bizarre animals sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, they are not closely-related to true spiders, so we prefer the term pycnogonid. The body consists of a head with a tubular proboscis, usually a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming and, in the males, to carry the eggs. Behind the head is an elongate trunk consisting of usually four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes to which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical abdomen.

This species is a particularly strange and distinctive one. It has an unusually stout body and legs and is bright pink or orange in colour. The first body segment is broadly triangular and inflated into three anterior knobs, while the head and tapering proboscis are downwardly flexed and invisible from above. The entire body and legs are covered with tiny conical spines. The legs are unusual in that they end in a single simple claw (most pycnogonids have a pair of auxilliary claws on either side of the main terminal claw).
taxon_text_3_606:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_607: Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, but this species has found on rocky shores, and more commonly on gorgonians. Barnard records it as being common in False Bay where ‘almost every piece of fan-coral (Gorgonia fammea – now Leptogorgia palma) which I have examined in a fresh state, has one or more of these little pycnogonids clasping its branches’. He also records it on several other genera of branching seafans, suggesting that it feeds on these, although he also reports specimens from in the intertidal zone among hydroids and bryozoans.
taxon_text_5_608: Almost all pycnogonids feed on cnidarians and this unusual species is most often found on branching seafans, on which it is presumed to feed. The pink or orange colour would blend in with this substratum and the short strong legs would be an adaptation to gripping the branches of seafans.
taxon_text_6_609: Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits.  The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
taxon_text_7_610: Easily distinguished from other local species by the unusual pink or orange colour, short compact body, swollen first body segment and spiky texture.
taxon_text_8_611: Barnard, KH (1954). South African Pycnogonida. Annals of the South African Museum, 39, 81-159.
<p>De Hoop - from Bamboo kelp holdfasts: De Hoop - from Bamboo kelp holdfasts Ecklonia maxima; PhD sampling of Chaitanya Katharoyan, Kelp Holdfast Biodiversity Project, PI Dr. Nasreen Peer, NRF-FBIP Grant FBIS22101863331
taxon_text_1_4940: Yellow to orange with a distinctive body form comprising a tall, tough cylindrical stalk topped by a paler, rounded ball bearing numerous bright yellow to orange polyps, each with 8 pinnate (fringed with short side branches) tentacles borne on a long, banded stem.
taxon_text_2_4941: Colonies up to 50 mm tall, polyps about 5 mm long.
taxon_text_3_4942:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_4943: Found on rocky reefs from the subtidal to depths of about 40 m, usually singly or in small groups. The polyps can be retracted into the head when disturbed. When examined closely small dot-like siphonozooids can been seen between the polyps on the head and are used to re-inflate the colony after it contracts. The stalk that holds the body makes this the most unusual octocoral that was recently placed into its own family, only known from South Africa!
taxon_text_5_4944: Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.
taxon_text_6_4945: Details unknown but octocoral normally reproduce by broadcast spawning, eggs developing into pelagic larvae that settle on new sites.
taxon_text_7_4946: The colony form is distinctive but could be mistaken for Variable soft-coral Alcyonium variabile, which has a similar, but non-stalked form and is typically much smaller (<50 mm tall) and also much more variable in colour.
taxon_text_8_4947:

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 46).

Williams, GC (1987). The aberrant and monotypic soft coral genus Malacacanthus Thomson, 1910 (Octocorallia: Alcyoniidae) endemic to southern Africa. Journal of Natural History, 21(6), 1337-1346.
taxon_text_1_2086: Large worm normally found singly and within a hard, round, calcareous tube that is firmly cemented to the rock face. The head bears two bright red or orange spirals of feathery branches that are normally held spread widely outstretched. The body has an obvious ‘collar’ that is used to secrete the tube, but unlike many other serpulid worms, there is no operculum to close up the aperture when the worm withdraws.
taxon_text_2_2087: Body length typically about 65 mm, tubes up to about 10 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_2088:
Global: Widespread across Indo-Pacific including Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2089: Large and spectacular species with its contrasting white tube and bright red tentacles normally found in small numbers attached to vertical rock faces or in crevices from low water mark to at least 25 m depth.
taxon_text_5_2090: Filter feeder, removing fine particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.
taxon_text_6_2091: Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.
taxon_text_7_2092: Many other serpulid worms are found in the region and all construct calcareous tubes and have crowns of feeding tentacles. The large size, bright white tube and lack of an operculum are fairly characteristic of this species though.
taxon_text_8_2093:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 818).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group Press, Cape Town. (p. 78).
taxon_text_1_6332:
Sponges are the most primitive of multicellular organisms and lack most of the features typical of other groups, such as a head, limbs or distinct sensory or body organs. They are best thought of as colonies formed from a few types of collaborating cells. Size and colony shape is often very variable within a species and accurate identification relies largely on examining the microscopic spicules that make up the skeleton. All are filter feeders, drawing in water through small opening on the body surface, removing fine particles and ejecting the waste water from one or more larger openings called oscula.

This species forms thin, delicate encrustations that frequently overgrow and cover beds of mussels, or other sedentary invertebrates. The sheet-like semi-transparent body bears numerous small low turrets each ending with a round opening surrounded by a white ring. Colour blue-grey to dark blue and purple with white rings around oscula.
taxon_text_2_6333: Sheet up to 30 cm across, but only about 10 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_6334:
Global: Namibia and South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Namibia to south coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_6335: Common on rocky reefs and in pools to a depth of at least 15 m, where it forms a thin growth often covering large ascidians, mussels or other sedentary invertebrates.
taxon_text_5_6336: Filter small organic particles from the water with the aid of collar cells which line the internal cavities.
taxon_text_6_6337:
Little work has been done on the reproductive biology of South African sponge species. However, most sponges can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction may take the form of sending out root-like extension from which new individual bud, by simply growing from broken fragments of another individual, or by production of special clumps of cells called gemmules expelled from an adult sponge.

Most sponges are hermaphrodite and sexual reproduction involves the production of larvae which undergo a brief planktonic life before settling to establish new individuals.
taxon_text_7_6338: There are several other purple encrusting sponges in the region, but the fragile texture, and white rings around the oscula in this species provide fairly reliable identification features.
taxon_text_8_9179:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 14).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 26).

Samaai, T & Gibbons, MJ (2005). Demospongiae taxonomy and biodiversity of the Benguela region on the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 1, 1-96. (p. 86).
taxon_text_9_4367: Cypsiphimedia gibba (and previously placed in family Acanthonotozomatidae)
taxon_text_1_4368: Very conspicuous iridescent blue in colour with a yellow stripe along the back and bright yellow vertical stripes. Much photographed species with characteristic laterally-flattened body with a peculiar greatly enlarged, hunched first body segment that pushes the head downwards. Head with a large pointed rostrum that projects like a visor in front of antennae.
taxon_text_3_4370:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_4371: A common species on shallow reefs, where it moves around brazenly in the open, clearly defended by its bright warning colouration, which presumably warns predators that it is distasteful. Often seem gathering, together with the Ridgeback amphipod Ochlesis lenticulosus, on whelk shells that are covered by the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum.
taxon_text_5_4372: Appears to feed on the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum, which occurs only on the shells of the whelk Burnupena papyracea. Often seen gathered in large numbers on these whelks. Exactly what chemical are sequestered from the bryozoan and how these are involved in protecting the amphipod are unknown, but would make for a fascinating study.
taxon_text_6_4373: As with all amphipods the eggs are released into a brood pouch between the legs of the female, where they are fertilized by males and develop into fully-formed young before being released.
taxon_text_7_4374: Unmistakable, but often found along with Ridgeback amphipod which is also brightly coloured and has a similar yellow stripe along the back, but has a quite different body form.
taxon_text_8_4375:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 98).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 19 as Cypsiphimedia gibba).
taxon_text_1_262: Most easily identified by the unique habit of burrowing into the heads of Ecklonia maxima. Colour cream or greenish orange with small, round, red-centered white eyes. Antennae and legs short and sturdy, first two pairs of legs with small nippers. Most distinctive feature strong rows of dorsal spines along first and second pairs of uropods, which are thought to be used to excavate the burrows. Third pair of uropods with short equal branches, the outer ending in two strong, upturned spines.
taxon_text_3_264:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Officially reported only from False Bay, but thought to extend at least from Saldanha Bay to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_265:
Have the unique habit of living in slit-like burrows excavated into the distal margin of the heads of the sea-bamboo Ecklonia maxima. It is thought that the burrows are excavated by scraping action of the heavily-spined uropods 1 and 2. The burrows appear to begin as small semicircular structures each inhabited by one of two adult amphipods and their young, but over time numerous burrows may develop and merge so that the entire distal margin of the head becomes irregularly eroded back. Heavily infected kelps are easily recognized by eye, even from the shore. Up to a third of adult kelps may host amphipods, older individuals with larger heads being most frequently infected. Heavily infected kelps may house more than 100 individuals (most of them juveniles), the mean number of amphipods per infected host being 20.

It is remarkable that this species was only recently discovered, given that is it both relatively large and causes conspicuous damage, and that a great deal of earlier research done on the fauna of kelp beds in the region failed to note its presence. The species is named after Dr Roberta Griffiths (wife of the describer, and author of this species account) in recognition of their joint research on kelp beds.
taxon_text_5_266: Assumed to feed on kelp tissue eroded from the walls of the burrow.
taxon_text_6_267: As with all amphipods the eggs are released into a brood pouch beneath the walking legs of females and brooded there until they develop into fully-formed juveniles. In this species free-living juveniles were commonly observed in the same burrows as adults, indicating that they remain there for some time before dispersing to construct their own burrows.
taxon_text_7_268: There are some 40 species in this genus including two others in the region, one of which, S. africana, is also associated with kelps. However, S. africana lacks the rows of strong spines along the uropods, characteristic of S. roberta and makes nests by folding over and weaving together the tips of the secondary fronds of the kelps, whereas S. roberta burrows directly into the primary frond, or head, of the kelps.
taxon_text_8_269:
Griffiths, CL (2019). A new species of Sunamphitoe (Amphipoda: Ampithoidae) that bores into the primary fronds of kelps in South Africa. Journal of Crustacean Biology, 39(4), 436–439.

Peart, R (2017). Analysis of the genus Sunamphitoe Spence Bate, 1857 (Amphipoda: Ampithoidae) with descriptions of eight new species. Zootaxa, 4269(3), 301–345.

Wilcox, MJ, Landschoff, J & Griffiths, CL (2022). Prevalence, population structure and burrow morphology of the kelp-boring amphipod Sunamphitoe roberta. African Journal of Marine Science, 44(2), 181-187.
taxon_text_1_6440:
Familiar blue colonian hydrozoan that floats on the water surface and is frequently cast ashore following onshore winds. The colony is supported by a large inflated float with a crimped upper margin. Hanging beneath this are other zooids specialized for prey capture, feeding or reproduction. Most conspicuous are the long trailing tentacles used for prey capture and which can be extended many meters below the float, or contracted into a tight spiral. These are armed with conspicuous nematocysts which can inflict a painful sting.

Until recently all bluebottles were grouped under the one name Physalia physalis, but recent research has shown that there are in fact 4 species and some earlier names, including this one, have now been re-established. This species can be recognised by the medium-sized, elevated and strongly crimped crest to the float, which has a purple to pink upper margin and a fairly long often upturned ‘float-tail’; by the gap between two group of hanging zooids and by usually one very long major feeding tentacle (and second but shorter main one). Colour also appears to be distinctive with this species having a combination of a purple crest margin and mostly evenly blue-whitish (no red) tentacles and zooids.
taxon_text_2_6441: Floats typically 50 mm long, but stinging tentacles can be over 10 m when extended, typically 300 mm when contracted.
taxon_text_3_6442:
Global:  Widespread in tropical Indo-Pacific

Local/Regional: Whole region but un-common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_6443:
Floats on the ocean surface, where driven along at the mercy of prevailing winds blowing on the sail. There are both left and right-handed individuals, so these will be driven in different directions by the wind. The extremely long feeding tentacles extend far below the float and are used to capture prey swimming in the water column. The stinging cells are very venomous and can paralyse even quite large fish, which are then ‘reeled in’ by contraction of the tentacle and engulfed by feeding ‘gastrozooids’ for digestion and distribution of the nutrients among colony members.

Bluebottles can inflict painful and even dangerous stings, so should not be handled, even after they have been washed up on beaches, as the nematocysts remain potent for many hours after death. Swimming in the presence of bluebottles is also dangerous, as the extended tentacles can wrap around the body and inflict long, painful welts of stings. Despite their strong venom they are fed upon by several predators, including Sea swallow nudibranchs, plough shells and loggerhead turtles.
taxon_text_5_6444: Feed on small fish, as well as on planktonic crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_6445: Each colony is either male or female and eggs and sperm are shed into the water, where they merge to form larvae that drift in the water column and bud off new zooids as they develop. Once a pneumatophore or float-forming zooid is formed, the developing colony rises to the surface and begin its adult life.
taxon_text_7_6446: Genus unmistakable and perhaps the best known of all hydrozoans. Two species are currently reported from South Africa, the other being P. utriculus which has a lower, more even sail (almost no ‘crimp’) without a pink margin, a short ‘float-tail’, only one major feeding tentacle that is comparatively shorter, deep blue tentacles and feeding zooids, the latter having bright yellow mouth openings. Being an Atlantic species the true Physalia physalis may also well extend down into South African waters. Of all species it has the largest crest with a bright pink margin, no gap between two group of hanging zooids, four or many major feeding tentacles, and red-purple tentacles and feeding zooids.
taxon_text_8_6447:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Church, SH, Abedon, RB, Ahuja, N, Anthony, CJ, Ramirez, DA, Rojas, LM, ... & Dunn, CW (2024). Global genomics of the man-o’-war (Physalia) reveals biodiversity at the ocean surface. BioRxiv, 2024-07.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).
taxon_text_1_6989: Unusual pelagic, colonial hydrozoan siphonophore. The colony consists of a bulb-like float (the pneumatophore), below which hangs a long stem bearing repeated units. Each unit includes a feeding zooid with an elongate tentacle and, when mature, a reproductive zooid. The pneumatophore may be highly reflective due to the presence of an internal air bubble, while the zooids along the stem are largely transparent, with the tentacles appearing light pink. Feeding zooids can be short and contracted while feeding or sometimes appear swollen after engulfing fish or other prey. Tentacles can extend significantly while capturing prey.
taxon_text_2_6990: Stem length varies greatly depending on whether the colony is expanded or contracted, but total length can reach 80 cm.
taxon_text_3_6991:
Global: Widespread in Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans.

Local/Regional: West coast southwards to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_6992:
Colonies float below the water surface, drifting along with their tentacles extended like long fishing lines either passively intercepting with prey, or actively attracting prey through light emission. Predominantly feed on fish larva. May repeatedly contract and extend the stem to maintain position or to arrange and move tentacles, giving the colony a ghostly appearance. Position in the water column modified by secreting carbon monoxide into the float, or releasing it through the apical pore.

The tentacles bear stinging cells, but as the species is rarely seen and pelagic it is seldom encountered by humans. There are, however, accounts of specimens stinging the hands of fishers handing nets and fishing lines with which the animals have become entangled.
taxon_text_5_6993: Feed predominantly on small fish and fish larvae.
taxon_text_6_6994: Gametes are released by specialised medusiod individuals, each of which releases gametes of one sex only.
taxon_text_7_6995: Related to the Bluebottle or Portuguese man-of-war Physalia spp., but those species are supported at the water surface by a large blue float from which the various zooids hang directly, without a stem.
taxon_text_8_6996:
Cooke, TS & Halstead, BW (1970). Report of stingings by the coelenterate Rhizophysa eysenhardti Gegenbaur in California waters. Clinical Toxicology, 3(4), 589-595.

Mapstone, GM & Landschoff, J (2024). The rare siphonophore Rhizophysa eysenhardtii Gegenbaur, 1859 (Hydrozoa, Siphonophora, Cystonectae) from False Bay, South Africa. African Invertebrates, 65(2), 213-221.

Purcell, JE (1981). Feeding ecology of Rhizophysa eysenhardti, a siphonophore predator of fish larvae. Limnology and Oceanography, 26(3), 424-432.
taxon_text_1_6998:
As the name implies flatworms have wide, flat, leaflike bodies and either glide around on a bed of cilia or, in larger species, by using ripples of muscular contraction that pass along the edges of the body. Many tropical species are very brightly coloured, but those found in the temperate parts of South Africa tend to be more cryptic.

This species is very flat and almost completely transparent (hence the common name). The body is fairly elongate and more or less parallel-sided with ruffled edges (not oval, as in some similar species). Some specimens are almost completely transparent, but other bear pale blotches. The central ruffled pharynx is the only opaque region and shows up as a white central band. There are no tentacles, but a distinct pair of fairly-large black eyes.
taxon_text_3_7000:
Global: Widespread in Mediterranean, Red Sea, Australia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7001: Normally found creeping on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal zone, or on shallow reefs. Usually solitary or in pairs. Can swim well if disturbed using undulations of the body. Little else know about biology but fairly commonly seen on both sides 0f the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_5_7002: The feeding organ of flatworms is a tubular proboscis on the underside and this leads into a blind-ending gut with no anus. This species probably feeds on small worms, crustaceans and mollusks.
taxon_text_6_7003: Flatworms are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilise one another by hypodermic impregnation – a process whereby the penis of one individual is stabbed into the partner and sperm injected into the body cavity. The spermatozoa then make their way to the ovaries of the receiving partner. Eggs are laid in gelatinous strings that are often deposited in spiral coils and hatch into free-swimming larvae. These float for a few days in the plankton before settling at new sites.
taxon_text_7_7004: Fairy easily recognised by the elongate, transparent body, lack of dorsal tentacles and presence of large, black eyes. Gilchrist’s flatworm Planocera gilchristi has a similar distribution but darker markings, a more oval shape and a pair of short dorsal tentacles. The limpet flatworm Notoplana patellarum lacks dorsal tentacles but has a more oval body and darker colour, is smaller, lacks eyes and is found only under limpets.
taxon_text_8_7005:
Newman, L & Cannon, L (2003). Marine flatworms – the world of polyclads. CSIRO Publishing, Collingwood, Australia. (p. 55).

Prudhoe, S (1989). Polyclad turbellarians recorded form African waters. Bulletin of the British Museum of Natural History (Zoology), 55(1), 47-96 (p. 69).
taxon_text_1_7025:
Erect axes with stout, short, cylindrical or flattened segments often shaped like irregular wedges. Non-fertile sections may bear up to 4 branches, forming a flat fan, but fertile segments branch dichotomously and have a terminal pore between the branches leading to the reproductive conceptacle. Usually deep pink but often bleached white at tips of fronds.

There are several regional species, but these seem to show a great deal of variability and are poorly defined. We thus only commit to a genus level identification here, although the most common species on the west coast and which forms small, dense, matted fans is usually referred to as A. filicula and the common intertidal south coast species with more cylindrical segments as A. corybosa.
taxon_text_2_7026: Colonies typically 30- 50 mm tall segments 0.5-1.5  mm wide.
taxon_text_4_7028: Common and abundant, forming dense clumps in lowshore pools and on subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_7030: Conceptacles bearing reproductive structures situated at the tips of the segments and opening via a pore located between the bases of the next pair of segments.
taxon_text_7_7031: Several variable and difficult to distinguish local species present that need further resolution.
taxon_text_8_7032:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.
