Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 578).
taxon_text_9_7033: Spongites yendoi (misapplied previous name to what are now several species).
taxon_text_1_7034:
Moderately thick, encrusting and distinctly knobbly species usually associated with the gardening limpet Scutellastra cochlear although also spreads onto rocks away from limpets. Colour bright to dusky pink. Individuals do not fuse together and can be distinguished, but also do not form distinct ridges where they meet.

The taxonomy of this entity is complex and several closely-related species from this genus co-exist on the same shores The original name Spongites yendoi was applies to all of these and remains a valid species name, but for a species that occurs in Japan.
taxon_text_2_7035: Colonies typically about 1 mm thick, but can spread over large areas of rock, with individuals indistinct.
taxon_text_3_7036:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution in SW Cape.
taxon_text_4_7037: Forms extensive sheets in the mid to lower intertidal often associated with the gardening limpet Scutellastra cochlear, growing both on the backs of the limpets and on the rock between them.
taxon_text_6_7039: Reproductive conceptacles form small low mounds with a central opening which maybe occluded by a circle of filaments.
taxon_text_7_7040: One of three very similar knobbly and difficult to separate species in this genus. Location can assist in identification though, as C. capense only occurs over a restricted range in the SW Cape, whereas the very similar C. globosum and C. occidentale extend all the way up the west coast. See references below for details accounts of how to differentiate these species.
taxon_text_8_7041:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Puckree-Padua, CA, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2021). DNA sequencing reveals three new species of Chamberlainium (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) from South Africa, all formerly passing under Spongites yendoi. Botanica Marina, 64(1), 19-40.

Puckree-Padua, CA, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2022). Chamberlainium (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) in South Africa, an exemplar for the study of coralline algae, description of C. tenue sp. nov., biogeography of the genus, and species keys. South African Journal of Botany, 150, 178-193.

Puckree-Padua, CA, Haywood, A, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2020). Reassignment of some South African species to Chamberlainium, with a comment about the recognition of families of Corallinales (Rhodophyta). Phycologia, 59(6), 464-496.
taxon_text_1_7043:
Forms thin, continuous sheets in which individuals merge without forming distinct contact ridges, so appears as a single individual. Sheets have a rough texture, but lack distinct knobs. Characteristically associated with the gardening limpet Scutellastra cochlear. Colour pinkish-purple in shady areas, but can fade to chalky-grey or white in the sun.

The taxonomy of this entity is complex. The original name Spongites yendoi remains as a valid species and was described from Japan, but the South African form was recognised as a separate species in 2020.
taxon_text_2_7044: Colonies typically only about 0.5 mm thick, but can spread over large areas of rock, with individuals indistinct.
taxon_text_3_7045:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7046: Forms extensive sheets in the lower intertidal associated with the gardening limpet Scutellastra cochlear, growing both on the backs of the limpets and on the rock between them. The limpets feed both on the coralline and on several species of small algae that form narrow gardens around the limpet.
taxon_text_7_7049: Fairly easily identified to genus due to association with gardening limpets. but there are in fact seven local crypic species in this genus, each with different textures and distributions (see references below).
taxon_text_8_7050:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Puckree-Padua, CA, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2021). DNA sequencing reveals three new species of Chamberlainium (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) from South Africa, all formerly passing under Spongites yendoi. Botanica Marina, 64(1), 19-40.

Puckree-Padua, CA, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2022). Chamberlainium (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) in South Africa, an exemplar for the study of coralline algae, description of C. tenue sp. nov., biogeography of the genus, and species keys. South African Journal of Botany, 150, 178-193.

Puckree-Padua, CA, Haywood, A, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2020). Reassignment of some South African species to Chamberlainium, with a comment about the recognition of families of Corallinales (Rhodophyta). Phycologia, 59(6), 464-496.
taxon_text_1_7052:
Forms thin, continuous sheets in which individuals merge without forming distinct contact ridges, so appears as a single individual. Sheets have a rough texture, but lack distinct knobs. Characteristically associated with the gardening limpet Scutellastra cochlear. Colour pinkish-purple in shady areas, but can fade to chalky-grey or white in the sun.

The taxonomy of this entity is complex. The original name Spongites yendoi remains as a valid species and was described from Japan, but the South African form was recognised as a separate species in 2020.
taxon_text_2_7053: Colonies typically only about 0.5 mm thick, but can spread over large areas of rock, with individuals indistinct.
taxon_text_3_7054:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional:  Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7055: Forms extensive sheets in the lower intertidal associated with the gardening limpet Scutellastra cochlear, growing both on the backs of the limpets and on the rock between them. The limpets feed both on the coralline and on several species of small algae that form narrow gardens around the limpet.
taxon_text_7_7058: Several local cryptic species in this genus, each with different textures and distributions (see references below).
taxon_text_8_7059:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Puckree-Padua, CA, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2021). DNA sequencing reveals three new species of Chamberlainium (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) from South Africa, all formerly passing under Spongites yendoi. Botanica Marina, 64(1), 19-40.

Puckree-Padua, CA, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2022). Chamberlainium (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) in South Africa, an exemplar for the study of coralline algae, description of C. tenue sp. nov., biogeography of the genus, and species keys. South African Journal of Botany, 150, 178-193.

Puckree-Padua, CA, Haywood, A, Gabrielson, PW & Maneveldt, GW (2020). Reassignment of some South African species to Chamberlainium, with a comment about the recognition of families of Corallinales (Rhodophyta). Phycologia, 59(6), 464-496.
taxon_text_1_7061: Forms bushy clumps or extensive carpets firmly anchored to the rock, or to limpet shells. Clumps formed of numerous short, densely-packed, pink to purple axes, often faded towards the exposed tips. The axes are upright and vary from almost cylindrical to distinctly flattened, segments short and often with pyramid-shaped or pentagonal outline. Axes branch repeatedly forming broad ‘fronds’. Reproductive conceptacles club-shaped and white, borne at the ends of the branches.
taxon_text_2_7062: Axes typically up to about 50 mm tall. Clumps typically about 50 mm across, but can be extensive, covering areas 200 mm or more across.
taxon_text_3_7063:
Global: Widely distributed in temperate seas including Europe, USA, Argentina, South Africa, China, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula eastwards.
taxon_text_4_7064: Common and abundant, forming dense clumps in low-shore pools and on subtidal rocks. The taxonomic position of the South African specimens is uncertain and recent genetic studies have shown that they are not the same as the European C. officinalis, so need to be either reclassified or described as new species. As this has not yet been done though, we retain the currently used name.
taxon_text_6_7066: Conceptacles appear as rounded chalky white nodules on the terminal segments of axes.
taxon_text_7_7067: Specimens classified under this name seem to vary variable and several species may in fact be involved. The repeatedly branching axes and rounded terminal conceptacles as fairly good identification features though.
taxon_text_8_7068:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Kogame, K, Uwai, S, Anderson, RJ, Choi, H-G & Bolton, JJ (2017). DNA barcoding of South African geniculate coralline red algae (Corallinales, Rhodophyta). South African Journal of Botany, 108, 337-341.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 584).

Williamson, CJ, Walker, RH, Robba, L, Yesson, C, Russell, S, Irvine, LM & Brodie J (2015). Toward resolution of species diversity and distribution in the calcified red algal genera Corallina and Ellisolandia (Corallinales, Rhodophyta). Phycologia 54: 2-11.
taxon_text_1_7070: Forms thick, deep-pink to purple crusts that often have distinct white margins. Smaller individuals tend to be smooth with a porcelain-like surface and often forms round colonies, leading to the alternative common name ‘dinner-plate coralline’. Larger individuals often take on a wavy or slightly knobbly appearance and the white margins become less distinct (see second image). Abundant in shallow subtidal habitats, where it is a dominant species.
taxon_text_2_7071: Colonies typically up to 300 mm wide and 3-15 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_7072:
Global: South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Doring Bay on west coast to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7073: Abundant on shallow reefs where overgrows other coralline algae. When adjacent colonies meet the white margins tend to curve upwards and meet like a pair of lips with a line between. Often bored into by burrowing polychaetes of the genera Polydora and Dodecaceria and by burrowing barnacles.
taxon_text_7_7076: One of the more easily recognised of this confusing group of encrusting coralline algae due to its very thick crust and white margin.
taxon_text_8_7077:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Maneveldt, GW, Chamberlain, YM & Keats, DW (2008). A catalogue with keys to the non-geniculate coralline algae (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) of South Africa. South African Journal of Botany, 74(4), 555-566.
taxon_text_1_7079: Erect and emerging from a tangled holdfast. Axes mostly in a single plane and dichotomously branched. Segments arrowhead-shaped and distinctly winged, tips of wings may be blunt, pointed or weakly toothed, joints between segments barely visible. Colour bright pink.
taxon_text_2_7080: Colonies typically about 60 mm tall. Segments up to 1 mm long and 1-2 mm wide across wings.
taxon_text_3_7081:
Global: Widespread in Indo-Pacific.

Local/Regional:  West coast of Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7082: Common on rocks and attached to limpets and mussels along south and east coast in low-shore pools and on shallow subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_7084: Spore capsules (conceptacles) 1-3 per segment, visible as swellings on the upper margin of the segments.
taxon_text_7_7085: The closely-related J. sagittata (Cape Peninsula to northern KZN) is more delicate and is mauve. It has longer, more pointed tips to the arrowheads on each segment and only one spore capsule per wing.
taxon_text_8_7086:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 416).

Kim, JH, Guiry, MD, Oak, JH, Choi, DS, Hosung Chung, S-H. K & Choi, H-G (2007). Phylogenetic relationships within the tribe Janieae (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morphological data: A reappraisal of Jania. Journal of Phycology, 43, 1310-1319.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 581 as Cheilosporum cultratum).
taxon_text_1_7088: Erect and emerging from a tangled holdfast. Axes fairly elongate and delicate, mostly in a single plane and dichotomously branched. Segments arrowhead-shaped and widely-winged, tips of wings acutely pointed. Joints between segments barely visible. Conceptacles form swellings on upper margin of each segment, only one per side. Colour mauve.
taxon_text_2_7089: Colonies typically about 70 mm tall. Segments up to 1 mm long and up to 3 mm wide across wings.
taxon_text_3_7090:
Global: From South Africa into tropical Indian Ocean (Mauritius, Kenya, Somalia) and Pacific (Australia, New Zealand, Philippines, Indonesia), also reported from Brazil.

Local/Regional:  Table Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7091: Common on rocks and attached to limpets and mussels in low-shore pools and on reefs to a depth of at least 24 m.
taxon_text_6_7093: Spore capsules (conceptacles) 1 per segment, visible as swellings on the upper margin of the segments.
taxon_text_7_7094: The closely-related J. cultrata (Cape Peninsula to northern KZN) is more robust and is pink. It has shorter, less pointed tips to the arrowheads on each segment and 1-3 spore capsule per wing.
taxon_text_8_7095:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 416).

Kim, JH, Guiry, MD, Oak, JH, Choi, DS, Hosung Chung, S-H. K & Choi, H-G (2007). Phylogenetic relationships within the tribe Janieae (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morphological data: A reappraisal of Jania. Journal of Phycology, 43, 1310-1319.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 584 as Cheilosporum sagittatum).
taxon_text_1_7097: Thin, epiphytic species forming small light-pink to purple patches encrusting the surfaces of other algae. Reproductive individuals have conspicuous groups of round poles on the surface which are the reproductive conceptacles.
taxon_text_2_7098: Typically up to about 20-50 mm in diameter and only 0.1 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_7099:
Global: Widespread around coast of Europe, including Mediterranean, east coasts of Canada and USA, South Africa, Madagascar, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: No details but photographed in Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_7100: Form thin, roundish colonies on the stipes and fronds of various other red, green or brown algae and can be very common, covering much of stipe surface.
taxon_text_6_7102: Reproductive conceptacles form minute swellings on thallus surface and have central pores.
taxon_text_7_7103: One of several similar encrusting coralline species found in this habitat.
taxon_text_8_7104:
(not covered in any of the standard South African guides)

Borges, VP, Bastos, E, Batista, MB, Bouzon, Z, Lhullier, C, Schmidt, EC, ... & Horta, PA (2014). The genus Melobesia (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) from the subtropical South Atlantic, with the addition of M. rosanoffii (Foslie) Lemoine. Phytotaxa, 190(1), 268-276.
taxon_text_9_7105: Previously misidentified as Mesophyllum engelhartii, which remains a valid species found in Australia and New Zealand, but has since changed its name to Magnephycus engelhartii. The genus Mesophyllum is now restricted to the Northern Hemisphere.
taxon_text_1_7106: Forms thin brown to purple sheets with small protuberances on the surface. These tend to erode to reveal white spots and caps. Where two individuals meet both edges are raised to form a white. back-to-back raided ridge (the ‘hedge’ in the name) about 1 mm tall and 1.5 mm across. The scientific and common names are derived from the Latin Phragma = hedge as a result of this feature.
taxon_text_2_7107: Colonies typically reach about 70 mm diameter and about 1 mm thick with the edges rising to form walls an additional 1 mm high.
taxon_text_3_7108:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Groenriviermond on the west coast to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7109: Common and forms sheets in the lower intertidal and on reefs to a depth of about 8 m. Grows on rock faces, shells and kelp holdfasts and often found on limpet shells.
taxon_text_7_7112: One of many purple-ish crusts, but the raised, white-edged margins and white spots on the surface are good identification features.
taxon_text_8_7113:
Athanasiadis, A (2020). Phragmope discrepans, gen. & comb. nov.(Mesophyllaceae, Corallinales, Rhodophyta), the species known as ‘Mesophyllum engelhartii’ from South Africa. Marine Biology Research, 16(6-7), 532-549.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418, as Mesophyllum engelhartii).
taxon_text_1_7115: Colonies adhering to rocks or to worm tubes, usually thick and very lumpy or warty, sometimes forming ridges reminiscent of a brain. Secondary margins may form mouth-like depressions where they meet. Colour mauvish-grey.
taxon_text_2_7116: Colonies typically about 50 mm across, thallus about 0.5 mm thick, but with protuberances up to 10 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7117:
Global: Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional:  Entire coastline, but most common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_7118: Found on hard substrata including rock surfaces, worm tubes and barnacles from the intertidal to shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_7120: Dioecious. Conceptacles raised above surrounding thallus and about 0.5 mm across.
taxon_text_7_7121: Confusing, as surface texture can be variable, ranging form fairly smooth to extremely warty and lumpy (as depicted below). There are also several other similarly lumpy species in the region, with somewhat different textures and colours, for example see Roseolithon superpositum.
taxon_text_8_7122:
Maneveldt, GW, Jeong, SY, Cho, TO, Hughey, JR & Gabrielson, PW (2020). Reassessment of misapplied names, Phymatolithon ferox and P. repandum (Hapalidiales, Corallinophycidae, Rhodophyta) in South Africa, based on DNA sequencing of type and recently collected material. Phycologia, 59(5), 449-455.

Van der Merwe, E & Maneveldt, GW (2014). The genus Phymatolithon (Hapalidiaceae, corallinales, rhodophyta) in South Africa, including species previously ascribed to Leptophytum. South African Journal of Botany, 90, 170-192.
taxon_text_1_7124: Form fairly thick, pale rosy-pink slightly mottled sheets that encrust rocks and are distinctively thrown up into upright folds that either resemble pursed lips, or can be tubular with a central opening. Margins of the openings paler than rest of surface.
taxon_text_2_7125: Typically about 1 mm thick, but can be 100 mm or more across the entire specimen.
taxon_text_3_7126:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7127: Common on rock from the mid- to low intertidal to shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_7129: Reproductive conceptacles occur on the thallus surface.
taxon_text_7_7130: Can be distinguished from most other coralline algae by the raised tubular extensions or lip-like ridges with their pale margins.
taxon_text_8_7131: Jeong, SY, Diaz‐Pulido, G, Maneveldt, GW, Gabrielson, PW, Nelson, WA, Won, BY & Cho, TO (2022). Phymatolithopsis gen. nov. (Hapalidiales, Corallinophycidae, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morpho‐anatomical evidence. Journal of Phycology, 58(1), 161-178.
taxon_text_1_7133:
These two forms cannot be differentiated in the field but have been shown to be genetically distinct species, so are treated together here.

They form thin, pale, rosy-pink sheets that encrust bedrock and especially loose pebbles and boulders. They can have a matt to glossy appearance and although flat and fairly featureless, often have a pitted surface due to sunken conceptacles. Individuals remain distinguishable, but are confluent and can coalesce to cover large areas.
taxon_text_2_7134: Typically only about 1 mm thick, but can be 100 mm or more across.
taxon_text_3_7135:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  C acervata False Bay to Kwazulu-Natal; C. roseola Cape Peninsula to East London.
taxon_text_4_7136: Both species common on both bedrock and especially on loose boulders and pebbles, which is an unusual habitat and indicated these are pioneer species able to survive frequent disturbance when these loose stones are rolled during storms. Found from the mid- to low intertidal to a depth of about 14 m.
taxon_text_6_7138: Reproductive conceptacles occur in pits on the thallus surface.
taxon_text_7_7139: These species can be distinguished from most other coralline algae due to their ability to live on small, loose pebbles and stones that are often tumbled by the waves. Also by the smooth surface marked by regulalry spaces pits when reproductive conceptacles are present.
taxon_text_8_7140:
Jeong, SY, Diaz‐Pulido, G, Maneveldt, GW, Gabrielson, PW, Nelson, WA, Won, BY & Cho, TO (2022). Phymatolithopsis gen. nov. (Hapalidiales, Corallinophycidae, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morpho‐anatomical evidence. Journal of Phycology, 58(1), 161-178.

Maneveldt, GW, Jeong, SY, Hughey, JR & Gabrielson, PW (2024). Phymatolithopsis acervata comb. nov., and P. roseola sp. nov.(Hapalidiales, Rhodophyta) from South Africa with a comment on infraordinal classification. Botanica Marina, 67(3), 249-275.
taxon_text_1_7142: Thin, roundish, flat, pink plants firmly attached to the stipes and holdfasts of the kelp Ecklonia maxima. Surface smooth and may be marked with paler scribbles, becomes bleached when exposed to the sun (as in lower part of photograph below). Margins wavy and when adjacent plants meet they usually remain flat, but may overgrow one another.
taxon_text_2_7143: Less than 0.05 mm thick and typically about 30 mm across.
taxon_text_3_7144:
Global: Australia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_7145: Forms thin, roundish colonies on the stipes and holdfasts of the kelp Ecklonia maxima and can be very common, covering much of stipe surface.
taxon_text_6_7147: Reproductive conceptacles occur all over the thallus surface except for a narrow marginal area.
taxon_text_7_7148: One of several similar encrusting coralline species found in this habitat. The closely related P. keatsii occurs in the same habitat but is purple-ish in colour, thicker (0.18 mm) and has long robust filaments emerging from the tetrasporangial conceptacles.
taxon_text_8_7149: Chamberlain, YM (1994). Pneophyllum coronatum (Rosanoff) D. Penrose comb. nov., P. keatsii sp. nov., Spongites discoideus (Foslie) D. Penrose et Woelkerling and S. impar (Foslie) Y. Chamberlain comb. nov.(Rhodophyta, Corallinaceae) from South Africa. Phycologia, 33(3), 141-157.
taxon_text_1_7151: Forms thin, round, matt, purpleish-grey colonies attached to the stipes of the kelp Ecklonia maxima. Strongly adherent, flat and smooth and adjacent thalli flush where they meet. Conceptacles grouped in thallus centre.
taxon_text_2_7152: Colonies typically about 20-30 mm in diameter and less than 0.5 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_7153:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  Known only from Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_7154: Forms thin, roundish colonies on the stipes and holdfasts of the kelp Ecklonia maxima and can be very common, covering much of stipe surface. Often partially overgrown by another epiphytic kelp-associated species Lithothamnion eckloniae.
taxon_text_6_7156: Reproductive conceptacles flush with or slightly sunken below thallus surface and have large pores.
taxon_text_7_7157: One of several similar encrusting coralline species found in this habitat. Can be distinguished from the closely-related P. coronatum by the purple-ish colour and the fact that conceptacles are flush with surface, whereas in P. coronatum the colour is pink and the conceptacles are domed and surrounded by a crown of filaments.
taxon_text_8_7158:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Chamberlain, YM (1994). Pneophyllum coronatum (Rosanoff) D. Penrose comb. nov., P. keatsii sp. nov., Spongites discoideus (Foslie) D. Penrose et Woelkerling and S. impar (Foslie) Y. Chamberlain comb. nov.(Rhodophyta, Corallinaceae) from South Africa. Phycologia, 33(3), 141-157.
taxon_text_1_7160: Colonies thick and encrusting and firmly attached to the rocks. Small colonies initially round to oval, but as they grow, they may merge and become confluent. The upper surface has a smooth undulating margin surrounding a central area of large protuberances, which may be conical or thickened distally (like a button mushroom). The smoother areas around the margins of the colony are thick and purplish-brown, the protuberances often with whiter areas where surface cells are sloughing.
taxon_text_3_7162:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Groenriviermond on west coast to Algoa Bay in Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7163: Abundant on hard substrata from the low intertidal to depths of about 18 mm, but less common towards the east of range. Overgrows other encrusting species.
taxon_text_6_7165: Reproductive conceptacles are  raised as low conical projections that are initially flat-topped, but become pitted as cells around the central pore are shed.
taxon_text_7_7166: Fairly easily identified by the thick base and strongly knobbed upper surface.
taxon_text_8_7167:
Gabrielson, PW, Maneveldt, GW, Hughey, JR & Peña, V (2023). Taxonomic contributions to Hapalidiales (Corallinophycidae, Rhodophyta): Boreolithothamnion gen. nov., Lithothamnion redefined and with three new species and Roseolithon with new combinations. Journal of Phycology, 59(4), 751-774.

Keats, DW, Maneveldt, G & Chamberlain, YM (2000). Lithothamnion superpositum Foslie: a common crustose red alga (Corallinaceae) in South Africa. Cryptogamie Algologie, 21(4), 381-400.
taxon_text_1_7169: Forms flat, bright rosy-pink encrusting thalli with a matt surface. Thalli often rectangular in shape and crossed by fine straight paler lines. Older thalli often touch and the confluences may be slightly humped.
taxon_text_2_7170: About 0.5 mm thick and reaching about 30 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_7171:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  West coast to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_7172: Found only on the stipes, or more rarely holdfasts, of the kelp Ecklonia maxima, where can cover large areas of the stipe.
taxon_text_6_7174: In mature individuals reproductive conceptacles occur as crowded group of pits in the centre of the thallus surface.
taxon_text_7_7175: Distinguished by its bright pink colour and characteristic habitat only on the stipes of the kelp Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_8_7176:
Keats, DW & Chamberlain, YM (1997). The non-geniculate coralline algae Synarthrophyton eckloniae (Foslie) comb. nov. and S. magellanicum (Foslie) comb. nov. (Rhodophyta) in South Africa including comparison with relevant types. European Journal of Phycology, 32(1), 55-79.

Maneveldt, GW, Van der Merwe, E & Keats, DW (2016). Updated keys to the non-geniculate coralline red algae (Corallinophycidae, Rhodophyta) of South Africa. South African Journal of Botany, 106, 158-164.
taxon_text_1_7178: Medium-sized whelk with a fairly-heavy shell which is quite variable in shape, some specimens being very short and squat and others with a longer spire and siphonal canal. The most distinctive feature is that each whorl bears seven very strong, spiral, grooved ridges.  In live specimens, the external surface is also covered in a dense brown proteinaceous fur. Outer lip corrugated and white (lacking the distinct brown bars found in several related species). Inner lip white. External colour generally dark brown, paler on underside. Operculum elongate-oval, horny and with concentric ridges. Foot orange to purplish, heavily spotted with black.
taxon_text_2_7179: Shell up to 110 mm, but more typically 50 mm in length.
taxon_text_3_7180:
Global: Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Whole region.
taxon_text_4_7181: In lowshore pools or on shallow reefs to a depth of at least 37 m. Typically found among ascidian colonies on which they are presumed to prey. Beach cast shells common but less often seen alive.
taxon_text_5_7182: Not known with certainly, but thought to feed on ascidians such as redbait Pyura stolonifera.
taxon_text_6_7183: Egg mass a circular consisting of many more of less rectangular egg cases each containing multiple eggs (see image).
taxon_text_7_7184: Fairly easily distinguished by the seven strong grooved didges running around each whorl and the coating of brown ‘fur’ on live specimens.
taxon_text_1_7187: Large whelk with a heavy shell extended into a fairly-long spire, but with a short siphonal canal. Whorls separated by fairly-deep notches and each bearing a row of low nodules (sometimes also smaller side rows on last whorl) and faint spital ridges. Positions of previous apertures marked by transverse ridges spaced about a half-turn apart. Aperture with thick wavy outer lip marked with a series of distinct dark brown transverse bars (these also visible on ridges formed by previous apertures). Inner lip mostly white, but may have darker brown blotches. External colour generally dark brown. Operculum elongate-oval, horny and with concentric ridges.
taxon_text_3_7189:
Global: South Africa and Mozambique (records from Gulf of Mexico almost certainly represent misidentifications).

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7190: Usually found in sand or gravel on lowshore pools or around shallow reefs.
taxon_text_5_7191: Not known with certainly but all species in this group are predators and though to feed on polychaete worms.
taxon_text_6_7192: Egg cases are deposited in winter and are laid in flat-topped oval sheets of 115-130 capsules. Each capsule is stalkless, flattened and more-or-less rectangular and contains 300-600 eggs which hatch after 6-7 weeks.
taxon_text_7_7193: One of several easily-confused large robust predatory whelks in the region. The pustular triton Argobuccinum pustulosum has similar habits but lacks the dark markings on the outer lip. The furry-ridged triton Cabestana africana is shorter, has much more pronounced external ridges, a white outer lip and when live is coated by a brown fur. The pink lady Charonia lampas grow much larger (to 250 mm) and has transverse brown wrinkles on the inner lip.
taxon_text_1_7196:
Typical puffer fish with small, plump body, large head with prominent chin, conspicuous, bulging, eyes and small upwardly-directed mouth, the teeth fused to form a parrot-like ‘beak’. Body soft and swollen with reduced scales and tapering to a narrow tail-peduncle. Dorsal fin rounded and set very far back, above the anus.

Species in this group are mostly identified by their distinctive colouration. In this species the body has a white basal colour, but is marked with numerous, bold, broken longitudinal brown stripes and by irregular brown blotches. The area around the base of the pectoral fins and the gill openings is black and the fins dusky brown. The caudal fine is marked with pale rays and in juveniles has a narrow pale margin.
taxon_text_3_7198:
Global: False Bay eastwards to southern Mozambique

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique (previous records only from Knysna eastwards, but photographed here in False bay).
taxon_text_4_7199:
Details unknown but most puffers are carnivorous, feeding mainly on sandy bottoms. Found from intertidal to about 150 m depth. Appears to have extended its range westwards in recent years. Few other details known.

As with other members of this family, the flesh is presumed to contain the potent toxin tetrodotoxin, so fish should be handled with care and not eaten, or allowed to interact with pets.
taxon_text_7_7202: Colour pattern fairly unmistakable and one of only a few pufferfish species whose distributions extend as far west as Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_7203:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 458).

Smith, JLB (1958). Tetraodont fishes from South and East Africa. Annals and Magazine of Natural History (Series 13), 1(2), 156-160.
taxon_text_1_7205:
Belongs to the filefish family, which are characterized by a very compressed body, small projecting mouth and (usually) by a greatly enlarged fist spine on the dorsal fin, which can be locked into a upright position by a smaller second spine. The pelvic fin is also reduced to a tiny bony rudiment. Most species occur in more tropical waters and this is one of few extending into the Western Cape.
This species is easily recognized by its characteristic shape, and pale colour which bears irregular dark blotched along its sides, although the extend and darkness of these markings in variable. Males may have blue spots and dashes at the bases of the dorsal and anal fins.
taxon_text_3_7207:
Global: Widespread across western Indian Ocean from Somalia to False Bay.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7208: Found on sandy and rocky bottoms to a depth of about 18 m. Small juveniles may congregate under floating objects such as patches of Sargassum weed or jellyfish in the open ocean.
taxon_text_5_7209: Details unknown for this species but filefish typically feed on a variety of benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_7_7211: Combination of compressed shape, distinctive dorsal spine and colour pattern unmistakable and the only filefish whose range extends into the colder waters of the South Western Cape (several other species found in warmer waters of east coast).
taxon_text_8_7212:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 334).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 446)

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 443).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 236).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 886).
taxon_text_1_7214:
Tonguefish are fairly-easily recognized as a group, as they have become extremely flattened and lie on their right side (not left side, as in soles) with both eyes displaced onto the left side. The pectoral fin is absent and the dorsal and anal fins join seamlessly to the anal fin, so the fish comes to a point at the posterior end.

This species has a rounded snout that is characteristically hooked over the lower jaw (creating a ‘sad-face’) and is mottled grey to brown, often with darker blotches. There are three lateral lines, one central and one close to each margin) on the upper, eyed side, but none on the underside.
taxon_text_3_7216:
Global: Endemic to Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7217: Found to a depth of at least 110 m on sandy and muddy bottoms. As with other flatfish buries readily in the sediment with only the eyes protruding.
taxon_text_5_7218: Details unknown, but tonguefish typically feed on small invertebrates such as crustaceans, molluscs and worms.
taxon_text_7_7220:
Tonguefish are often confused with soles (family Solidae) but these lie on their left side with the eyes displaced to the upper or right side, retain the pectoral fin and have a distinct caudal or tail fin separate from the dorsal and anal fins.

There are several tonguefish species in the region, of which the most frequently encountered is the Redspotted tonguefish C. zanzibarensis. This occurs from the western Cape eastwards to Kenya and is brown with distinctive dark red to orange spots on the dorsal and anal fins.
taxon_text_8_7221:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 334).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 446).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 443).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 865).
taxon_text_1_7223:
Typical pufferfish with small, plump body, large head with prominent chin, conspicuous, bulging, eyes and small upwardly-directed mouth, the teeth fused to form a parrot-like ‘beak’. Body soft and swollen with reduced scales and tapering to a narrow tail. Dorsal fin rounded and set far back, above anus.

Species in this group are mostly identified by their distinctive colouration. In this species the upper surface has numerous pale brown spots, which form rosettes surrounding larger white spots. The brown spots along the flanks are arranged into distinct horizontal rows and the underside of body lack spots and fades to pale pink or white.
taxon_text_3_7225:
Global: Western Indian Ocean, from Cape Peninsula eastwards through East Africa and Seychelles to Red Sea and Persian Gulf. Also recently introduced to Mediterranean where it was first recorded in 1987.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7226:
Carnivorous species feeding on sandy bottoms from intertidal to about 287 m depth. Thought to live for about 4 years. Recently invaded the eastern Mediterranean, probably by moving though the Suez Canal, and is considered a problem species there due to rapidly expanding population. Also appears to have become much more abundant in western a parts of South Africa in recent years.

As with many other members of this family, the flesh contains the potent toxin tetrodotoxin, so fish should be handled with care and not eaten, or allowed to interact with pets.
taxon_text_5_7227: Feeds mostly on polychaete worms, small bivalves and gastropods, crustaceans and sea urchins.
taxon_text_6_7228: Matures at about 10 cm length. In the Mediterranean breeds in summer.
taxon_text_7_7229: Colour pattern fairly unmistakable and one of only a few pufferfish whose distributions extend as far west as Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_7230:
Chartosia, N, Michalidis, N, Constantinou, A & Karachle, PK (2021). Shedding light on the diet of the Lessepsian yellowspotted puffer Torquigener flavimaculosus Hardy and Randall, 1983 in the Eastern Mediterranean. Acta Adriatica, 62(2), 199-208.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 443).

Kosker, AR, Özogul, F, Durmus, M, Ucar, Y, Ayas, D, Šimat, V & Özogul, Y (2018). First report on TTX levels of the yellow spotted pufferfish (Torquigener flavimaculosus) in the Mediterranean Sea. Toxicon, 148, 101-106.

Tikochinski, Y, Ohana, T, Motro, U & Golani, D (2024). Successful colonization of the Red Sea Yellowspotted Puffer, Torquigener flavimaculosus in the Mediterranean without a genetic bottleneck. Aquatic Invasions, 19(1), 25-34.
taxon_text_1_7232:
More-or-less spherical unicellular organism only about 25 microns in diameter. When examined microscopically the cells have a finely reticulated surface and are encircled by deeper channels that contain two flagella, one which wraps around the cell and controls rotation and the other which extends behind the cell and controls direction.

The cells may occur singly, but more often occur in short chains of 2, 4 or 8 cells.
taxon_text_2_7233: Cells typically only about 25 microns in diameter.
taxon_text_3_7234:
Global: Cool-temperate coastal waters on west coast of North America, and in Japan, Australia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast only.
taxon_text_4_7235:
This species is an important cause of Harmful Algal Blooms (HAB’s) and is associated with Paralytic Shellfish Poisoning, which can be fatal.

The organism spends most of its life in a resting cyst stage on the sea floor, but emerges when environmental conditions are favourable and produces mobile cells capable of photosynthesis and rapid asexual reproduction forming HABs.

The cells produce saxitoxin, which is a highly-potent neurotoxin that can cause numbness, incoherence, respiratory paralysis and even death. Humans ingest the toxin primarily by consuming infected shellfish, such as mussels, which filter large volumes of water and concentrate the toxins within their bodies. Blooms of this species are confined to the west coast and occur most often in late summer. 

As with other similar species, the algal blooms may cause de-oxygenation of the water, resulting in mortalities of fish and other organisms, or rock-lobster walk-outs. These occur due to oxygen depletion and are independent of any toxic effects.
taxon_text_7_7238: Distinctive under the microscope, but is only one of several species which cause Harmful Algal Blooms in the region. Some of these are harmless, but others, such as blooms of dinoflagellates of the genus Dinophysis, are responsible for Diarrhetic Shellfish Poisoning, a less severe complaint caused by the toxin okadaic acid.
taxon_text_8_7239:
Pitcher, GC & Calder, D (2000). Harmful algal blooms of the southern Benguela Current: a review and appraisal of monitoring from 1989 to 1997. South African Journal of Marine Science, 22(1), 255-271.

Pitcher, GC & Louw, DC (2021). Harmful algal blooms of the Benguela eastern boundary upwelling system. Harmful Algae, 102, 101898.
taxon_text_1_7241:
Diatoms are a very important group of typically single-celled, photosynthetic, planktonic organisms that together make up a significant proportion of the earth’s biomass. They are best known for possessing hard silica cases called ‘frustules’. Most species are solitary, but some join together to form colonial structures of various shapes, including chains ribbons, fans, stars, or even larger colonies that resemble seaweeds.

In this species the cells are rectangular and pillow-shaped and may occur singly or in chains of two to a few attached cells. The blooms form brown, slick-like scums on the water surface and are often stranded as foam-like deposits. Blooms are characteristic of long, dissipative beaches subject to strong wave action.
taxon_text_2_7242: Cells typically only about 10-20 microns broad and 15-60 microns long.
taxon_text_3_7243:
Global: Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_7244:
The blooms are restricted to long, unbroken beaches with broad dissipative surf zones (in our area notably Muizenberg Beach) where they form brown patches that are often mistaken as pollution.

The blooms show a distinct diurnal pattern, cells emerging from the sand in the morning and entering the water column, where they attach to bubbles and form a surface foam. In the late aftenoon, they drop out of the foam and sink back to the botton, where they enter the sand. This behaviour also traps the blooms within the surf zone, as cells tend to get pushed shorewards by the breaking waves during the day and returned into the surf zone by rip currents when they sink back to the bottom in the afternoon.

The blooms are important primary producers on such beaches and sustain a whole community of associated animals.
taxon_text_7_7247: Easy to distinguish by virtue of the unusual habitat and bloom-forming behaviour.
taxon_text_8_7248:
Kruger, I & Wilson, EG (1984). Morphology and affiliation of the centric diatom Anaulus birostratus (Grunow) Grunow from South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 2(1), 163-194.

Talbot, MMB & Bate, GC (1986). Diel periodicities in cell characteristics of the surfzone diatom Anaulus birostratus: their role in the dynamics of cell patches. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 32, 81-89.

Talbot, MMB & Bate, GC (1988). The use of false buoyancies by the surf diatom Anaulus birostratus in the formation and decay of cell patches. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 26(2), 155-167.
taxon_text_1_7250:
Unicellular green alga with a round to egg-shape, two long, equal flagella and a large single cup-like chloroplast which can hold large amounts of beta-carotene, which gives the cells their characteristic orange to red colour.

Best identified by the unusual habitat and colour.
taxon_text_3_7252:
Global: Worldwide.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but blooms only in high salinity habitats, such as evaporation ponds in salt works, or natural rock pools subject to high rates of evaporation and hence increased salinity.
taxon_text_4_7253:
Characteristic of high salinity habitats and found extensively in salt works, turning the evaporation ponds bright red. In the natural environment common in high-shore rockpools during summer, when evaporation raises the salinity to several times that of seawater.

Is cultivated for the production of beta-carotene which is an anti-oxidant as well as a vitamin-A precursor. The species is used in the manufacturing of cosmetics and as a pro-vitamin-A food supplement and has a number of other potential commercial applications, for example as animal feed, for the production of bio-diesel, or for the desalination of seawater.
taxon_text_6_7255: Cells can reproduce asexually by division, or sexually by the fusion of two games to form a zygote. Zygotes are extremely resistant and can tolerate both drying out and exposure to freshwater.
taxon_text_7_7256: Best distinguished by the characteristic and unusual preference for high salinity environments and the bright red colour.
taxon_text_8_7257:
Abd El-Baky, HH, El Baz, FK & El-Baroty, GS (2004). Production of antioxidant by the green alga Dunaliella salina. International Journal of Agriculture and Biology, 6, 49-57.

Borowitzka LJ, Borowitzka MA, Moulton TP (1984). The mass culture of Dunaliella for fine chemicals: from laboratory to pilot plant. Hydrobiologia, 115–121.

Moayedi, A, Yargholi, B, Pazira, E & Babazadeh, H (2019). Investigated of desalination of saline waters by using Dunaliella salina algae and its effect on water ions. Civil Engineering Journal, 5(11), 2450-2460.
taxon_text_1_7259:
Diatoms are a very important group of typically single-celled, photosynthetic, planktonic organisms that together make up a significant proportion of the earth’s biomass. They are best known for possessing hard silica cases called ‘frustules’. Most species are solitary, but some join together to form colonial structures of various shapes including ribbons, fans, stars, or in this case larger colonies that resemble seaweeds.

The genus Navicula is a diverse genus containing over 1200 typically boat-shaped species, several of which form colonies. This species has been examined by specialists, who confirm the genus identification, but also that this represents an undescribed species. It is an unusual colonial species that forms a soft, jelly-like structure that look very like a brown seaweed and consists of clump of fairly thick, soft, knobbly, ‘fingers’’ firmly attached to the substratum.  The most distinctive feature of the colony is its soft, slippery, jelly-like texture and semi-transparent appearance. The outer layer of the colony is formed of tightly-packed, more rectangular cells and the inner matrix is packed with typical boat—shaped cells.
taxon_text_2_7260: Small upright tufts typically from 2-6 cm tall and blades about 5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7261:
Global: Probably endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Currently known only from both sides of the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7262: Forms small soft and slippery clumps in lowshore pools, where it wafts with the slightest water movement. Hard to pick, as the jelly-like branches just slip though the fingers. The species is fairly common but is undescribed and hence nothing further is known about its distribution or biology.
taxon_text_7_7265: Easy to distinguish by virtue if its jelly-like texture and lack of internal structures.
taxon_text_8_7266:
Not described so no literature, but the following reference deals with another regional species with similar habits:

Basson, PW & Sims, PA (1998). A tube-dwelling diatom and its co-habitant from South Africa. Diatom Research, 13(2), 395-401.
taxon_text_1_7277:
Forms small, erect tufts of fine, light grass-green filaments. The filaments are each formed of one very large cell containing multiple nuclei and chloroplasts (coenocytic) and have numerous terminal branches. In different species the colony many form a dense moss-like clump of a loose tuft of just a few filaments. The branching pattern can also vary from regular and feather-like to more disorganized, with laterals sometimes bearing a second order of branching.

There are several species in the region, but these are poorly defined and so we give only a genus entry here. The species depicted has been referred to as B. myosuroides.
taxon_text_2_7278: Depicted species with clumps about 50 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7279:
Global: Genus widespread across tropical and temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Genus found all around coast.
taxon_text_4_7280: Form small cushions of clumps on rocks in the intertidal and on shallow reefs, often associated with sand.
taxon_text_6_7282: Alternating generations with the sporophyte being the dominant generation and the gametophyte smaller. A wide range of life-history patterns is evident across different species in this genus though.
taxon_text_7_7283: Branching form highly variable within species, making species-level identifications difficult. Can be confused with Caulerpa species some of which have a similar feather-like form, but Caulerpa species have root like stolons from which the uprights emerge at intervals.
taxon_text_8_7284:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 128).
taxon_text_1_7286: Upright dark-green, strap-like fronds each have a basal section which is annulated and upper section that branches dichotomously 1-3 times. Fronds emerge from a smooth white horizontal stolon with pale root-like rhizoids that anchor it to the bottom.
taxon_text_2_7287: Strap-like fronds 3-5 mm wide and up to about 200 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7288:
Global: Widespread but disjunct distribution, with records from Peru, Australia and Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7289: Forms dense seagrass-like beds attached to rocks in intertidal pools and on shallow reefs. Typically accumulates sand, which covers the stolon and bases of the fronds. Unusual in that the frond is one enormous cell containing many nuclei.
taxon_text_6_7291: Usually reproduces asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas.
taxon_text_7_7292: Unusual upright, strap-like fronds characteristic but sometimes confused with eelgrass (Zostera capensis) which is a flowering plant, not an alga, and has longitudinal veins in the leaf.
taxon_text_8_7293:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 376).

De Clerck, O, Bolton, JJ, Anderson, RJ & Coppejans, E (2005). Guide to the seaweeds of KwaZulu-Natal. Scripta Botanica Belgica, 33, 1-294 (p. 64).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 123).
taxon_text_1_6899: Easily recognized by its great length and unusual flowing growth form. Attached by a large holdfast made up of a tangle of slender haptera, from which multiple thin, unbranched, rope-like stipes emerge. Along each stipe thin lateral blades emerge at irregular intervals. Each blade has a rippled surface, a toothed margin, a sharp tip and an air-filled bladder at its base that provides buoyancy.
taxon_text_2_6900: The longest of all algae, typically up to about 10 m long, but recorded as reaching a length of 45 m!
taxon_text_3_6901:
Global: Very widely-distributed along the Pacific coast of North America from Alaska to California and in South America, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Restricted to a few sheltered locations between about Saldanha Bay and Cape Point.
taxon_text_4_6902:
The rarest of the South African kelps, occurring at only about 10 sites along the southern part of the west coast, but forms extensive beds in other parts of the world. Previously – recognized regional species are now all synonymized under this one name. Well known as not only the longest of all algae, but also the fastest growing, with growth rates of up to 60 cm per day!

In other regions an important ecosystem engineer, generating food and creating habitat for a wealth of other species, protecting the coastline from wave action, etc. Also used by humans as a source of alginates and as food.
taxon_text_6_6904: Alternating generations of the familiar large, spore-producing sporophytes, which release haploid spores that develop into microscopic male and female gametophytes that produce eggs and sperm that merge to form a new generation of diploid sporophytes.
taxon_text_8_6906:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 386).

Fleischman, MJ, Bolton, JJ & Rothman, MD (2020). Macrocystis (Laminariales, Phaeophyceae) in South Africa: distribution, morphology, and potential susceptibility to warming events. Journal of Applied Phycology, 32(4), 2447-2457.

Fleischman, MJ, Bolton, JJ & Rothman, MD (2021). Macrocystis (Laminariales, Phaeophyceae) in South Africa: potential for cultivation through holdfast fragmentation and use as feed for the aquacultured abalone, Haliotis midae. Journal of Applied Phycology, 33(3), 1731-1740.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 193).
taxon_text_1_6917: Forms a group of flattened, tapering, strap-like blades emerging from a single, discoid holdfast. The blades are thicker at the centre and thinner towards the edges and are fairly thin but opaque and medium brown in colour.
taxon_text_2_6918: Blades typically about 100-200 mm long and up to about 20 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6919:
Global: Widespread but scattered records in warm-temperate seas.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal. Also reported from Namibia.
taxon_text_4_6920: Typically found attached to rocks in rockpools, growing to a larger size in the lower shore.
taxon_text_6_6922: Sporangia found across large areas of the blade surface and on both sides.
taxon_text_7_6923: The almost identical P. fascia is found mainly along the west coast and, apart from this difference in distribution range, can only really be distinguished anatomically by examining internal structure of the blades.
taxon_text_8_6924:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 384).
taxon_text_1_6926: Distinctive encrusting species forming irregular concentric rings, often comprised of overlapping plates. Colour yellow-brown, becoming darker with age, colonies thus with paler edges formed of tightly packed filaments that are fused together and curve upwards.
taxon_text_2_6927: 1-2 mm thick with colonies typically up to 150 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6928:
Global: Widespread across Europe, Mediterranean, east coast of USA, west coast of Africa, Argentina, India, Japan, China, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_6929: Common encrusting species on intertidal rocks and also often found on the shells of limpets and other gastropods. Forms gardens grazed on by the Long-spined limpet Scutellastra longicosta. The tissues contain polyphenols to act as a deterrent to grazers.
taxon_text_6_6931: Alternating generations of spore-producing sporophytes and separate male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6932: Easily identified by the encrusting form and distinctive concentric ring pattern.
taxon_text_8_6933:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 384).

Parente, MI, Fletcher, RL, Costa, FO & Saunders, GW (2020 '2021'). Taxonomic investigation of Ralfsia-like (Ralfsiales, Phaeophyceae) taxa in the North Atlantic Ocean based on molecular and morphological data, with descriptions of Pseudoralfsiaceae fam. nov., Pseudoralfsia azorica gen. et sp. nov. and Nuchella vesicularis gen. et sp. nov.. European Journal of Phycology, 56(1), 12-23.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 147).
taxon_text_1_6944: Forms flaccid, hollow, unbranched tubes emerging from a small disc-like holdfast. Tubes constricted at regular intervals and have a gas-filled central cavity.
taxon_text_2_6945: Total length reported to reach 1 m, but typically much shorter at about 150 mm. Tubes about 3-5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6946:
Global: Widespread in temperate seas worldwide.

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_6947: Typically found attached to rocks in high-shore rockpools. Edible species that is cultured for human consumption in China and Japan and has been shown to have strong anti-oxidant properties.
taxon_text_6_6949: Has a biphasic life cycle alternating between the erect gametophyte (depicted) and a small prostrate sporophyte. The erect gametophyte is seasonal in spring and early summer.
taxon_text_7_6950: May be confused with Ulva intestinalis, which has a similar form and habitat but is green and not brown.
taxon_text_8_6951:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 390).

Kuda, T, Tsunekawa, M, Hishi, T & Araki, Y (2005). Antioxidant properties of driedkayamo-nori', a brown alga Scytosiphon lomentaria (Scytosiphonales, Phaeophyceae). Food Chemistry, 89(4), 617-622.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 185 as S. simplicissima).
taxon_text_1_6962: Forms large, dark greenish-brown crusts covering open rock surfaces (rarely shells) from the low water mark to about 10 m depth. Surface smooth and quite slippery and with a well-defined, fairly regular margin. Lower surface attached by numerous short rhizoids.
taxon_text_2_6963: 1-2 mm thick with colonies typically up to 10 mm across, but sometimes much larger, covering whole boulders.
taxon_text_3_6964:
Global: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: Yzerfontein on west coast to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_6965: Common encrusting species covering large areas of rock from very low intertidal pools to about 10 m depth. Forms gardens defended and grazed on by the Giant limpet Scutellastra tabularis. This is the only known species in the fairly recently erected family Zeacarpaceae.
taxon_text_6_6967: Tiny elongate sporangia, each of which produces 16 spores when mature, are borne in groups in the surface of the thallus.
taxon_text_7_6968: Could be confused with the encrustng red alga Hildenbrandia lecannellieri, which forms similar large dark crusts, but that has a gnarled rough surface and normally occurs higher in the shore.
taxon_text_8_6969:
Anderson, RJ, Simons, RH & Bolton, JJ (1988). Zeacarpa leiomorpha (Ralfsiaceae), a new genus and species of crustose marine Phaeophyceae from southern Africa. Phycologia, 27, 319-326.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 149).
taxon_text_1_6971: Tall, erect, leathery, strap-like blades emerge from a matted holdfast and branch profusely, but in a single plane. Branches contain many large, dark storage bodies that are concentrated in transverse bands which give appearance of dark joints. Ends of branches lobed and with pale margins. Colour yellowish-brown, often with grey tinge.
taxon_text_2_6972: Forms fairly large tufts, up to 300 mm tall. Branches 3-4 mm wide expanding at tips.
taxon_text_3_6973:
Global: South Africa, Mozambique, Madagascar and Mascarene Islands.

Local/Regional: False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_6974: Found in lowshore pools and gullies down to a depth of about 40 m. Relatively scarce in Western Cape, but can be abundant in gullies further east.
taxon_text_7_6977: The colour pattern and swollen tips to the flattened branches are good identification features.
taxon_text_8_6978:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 384).

De Clerck, O, Bolton, JJ, Anderson, RJ & Coppejans, E (2005). Guide to the seaweeds of KwaZulu-Natal. Scripta Botanica Belgica, 33, 1-294 (p. 173).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 149).
taxon_text_1_7007: Fairly tall, bushy species with elongate segments that branch dichotomously at fairly regular intervals. Joints between segments narrow and not obvious (unlike related A. ephdraea), being largely concealed by ‘aprons’ extending from the ends of the segments. Surfaces of segments distinctively covered with warty reproductive structures. Colour pink with white tips.
taxon_text_2_7008: Colonies up to about 150 mm tall. Segments up to 12 mm long and 1-2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7009:
Global: Considered a South African endemic, as a record from West Africa has been discounted.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_7010: Usually found in deep rock pools (photographed here in tidal swimming pool). May grow among other algae and often serve of substrate for tiny epiphytic algae of order Ceramiales (as in right hand side of provided image)
taxon_text_6_7012: Hemispherical structures containing reproductive organs form conspicuous bumps on segments.
taxon_text_7_7013: Easy to identify to genus due to elongate segments with prominent reproductive conceptacles on surface. The similar but taller A. ephydraea also occurs in the SW Cape, but in that species the black joints are much wider and more conspicuous.
taxon_text_8_7014:

taxon_text_1_6980: Smallish species with more of less pentagonal disc, indented between each pair of arms, upper surface covered with small plates. Radial shields distinctive, large and oval, adjacent at their outermost tips, but diverging markedly towards centre of the disc, hence leaving a V-shaped gap between each pair. Arms moderately spinose and with just single dorsal scale on each segment. Colour very variable, most commonly uniform yellow, orange, red or purple, but can also have a dark grey disc and yellow and black banded arms.
taxon_text_2_6981: Arm length up to 25 mm. Up to 11 mm disc diameter.
taxon_text_3_6982:
Global: Gambia, Senegal, Angola and Namibia, though to east coast of South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Sodwana Bay, intertidal to 180 m.
taxon_text_4_6983: A common species that can be very abundant under stones and in gravel in the intertidal, but also reported down to 179 m depth. Within a particular group mostly uniform in colour, but adjacent groups can be very different in colour. Tends to aggregate in dense colonies. Parasitised by copepod Cancerilla oblonga, thought to be found on 10% of A. capensis.
taxon_text_5_6984: Presumed to feed on detrital particles on the sediment surface, as arms are not held up into the water column. In most deposit feeding brittle stars the tube feet grasp prey items and compact them into balls, which are then transported along cilial tract along the undersides of the arms to the central mouth.
taxon_text_6_6985: A hermaphroditic brooding species that becomes sexually mature at 5 mm disc diameter. Eggs and young are retained and nurtured within the disc in respiratory sacs called bursae where the young develop directly into juveniles, possibly without a larval stage. Duration of brooding estimated at 6 months and one individual can brood over 10 young at a time. Reproduces all-year-round, but brooding peaks in austral winter – coinciding with warmer water temperatures in the region.
taxon_text_7_6986: The most common of several regional species in this diverse genus and can be distinguished from most of these by the strongly diverging radial shields. Other common regional species, such as A. incana, share that character though, and detailed microscopic examination of the arm spines etc is needed to definitely separate these species (see Olbers ref. below for details and key to regional species). Amphioplus integer (Port Nolloth to Maputo) shares most of the features described for Amphuira capensis, but its radial shields are in contact with one another for their full length instead of diverging.
taxon_text_8_9176:

taxon_text_1_7268: Large (1 mm), single-celled, more-or-less spherical, gelatinous organism. A network of beaded cytoplasmic strands radiate from a central nucleus, and on one side of the cell is a slight notch bearing a cytostome or ‘mouth’ and an adjacent tentacle used for both locomotion and food capture.
taxon_text_3_7270:
Global: Temperate and tropical coastal seas worldwide.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but blooms more common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_7271:
Feeds on minute organisms, such as bacteria, copepods and diatoms, which are engulfed by the cytostome. Often also contain a photosynthetic endosymbiont called Pedinomonas noctilucae, thousands of which may live within an individual Noctiluca cell and which may give it a green colour and contribute significantly to its nutrition.

Blooms occur mainly in the later summer and are most common on the west coast. During blooms the sea surface may be blood red in colour, but the bloom is often restricted to the surface and the water below may remain completely clear. This species is not toxic, but as with all red tides, the bloom may consume all the oxygen in the water and thus result in mortality of marine life.

As fascinating and well-known feature of this species is that the cells produce luminous blue flashes when disturbed, for example in the breaking waves, or by a boat, dolphin, or swimmer agitating the water. During blooms this may result in spectacular light displays and is an exciting phenomenon to experience!
taxon_text_7_7274: Easy to distinguish when observed under the microscope, but several other organisms also cause red tides in the region, including the toxic Alexandrium catenella (see that page).
taxon_text_8_7275:
Dela-Cruz, J, Middleton, JH & Suthers, IM (2008). The influence of upwelling, coastal currents and water temperature on the distribution of the red tide dinoflagellate, Noctiluca scintillans, along the east coast of Australia. Hydrobiologia, 598, 59-75.

Pitcher, GC & Probyn, TA (2016). Suffocating phytoplankton, suffocating waters—red tides and anoxia. Frontiers in Marine Science, 3, 186.
taxon_text_1_7016: Large, tall, bushy species attached by a crustose holdfast and with elongate segments separated by very distinct and wide (1-2 mm) black joints. Segments cylindrical and fairly uniform in width, slightly flattened. Branches regularly, the ends of branches rounded and white. Surfaces of segments distinctively covered with warty reproductive structures. Colour purplish-pink.
taxon_text_2_7017: Colonies can be up to 300 mm tall, but more typically 150 mm. Segments up to 7 mm long and 1-2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7018:
Global: Gambia in West Africa, South Africa, Madagascar, Tanzania and several other Indo-Pacific localities, including Australia (type-locality).

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7019: Common and abundant on south and east coast, where can form large hanging clumps in lowshore pools and on subtidal rocks.
taxon_text_6_7021: Hemispherical structures containing reproductive organs form conspicuous bumps on segments.
taxon_text_7_7022: Easy to identify to genus due to elongate segments with prominent reproductive conceptacles on surface. The smaller A. capensis (typically 50-100 mm) also occurs in the SW Cape, but in this species the black joints are largely concealed by apron-like extensions on the ends of the segments.
taxon_text_8_7023:

taxon_text_1_6881: One of the largest and best known of regional algae. The conical holdfast is comprised of a network of cylindrical, branched, root-like haptera and gives rise to a thick, solid stipe that tapers distally. The single broad blade is split into several parallel longitudinal straps. In juveniles the blade is entire. Colour uniformly light-brown, golden with sori (reproductive structures) appearing as darker spots on the blades.
taxon_text_2_6882: Total length up to at least 5 m.
taxon_text_3_6883:
Global: Basically a southern African species, but also found on Tristan da Cunha, Gough Island and St Paul Island.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Danger Point.
taxon_text_4_6884: At southern end of distribution tends to occur mainly in deeper water below about 8 m and to form a fully-submerged forest seaward of the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima, which reaches the surface. Further up the west coast becomes a more dominant component of kelp beds and occurs in shallower water, extending into the intertidal.  Important ‘ecosystem engineer’ creating habitat for numerous smaller species that colonise the holdfasts, stipes and blades. During storms bend over such that the sweeping action of the blades across adjacent rock surfaces sweeps away sea urchins and other grazers, increasing survival of sporelings around existing adults.
taxon_text_6_6886: Alternating generations of the familiar large spore-producing sporophytes and separate microscopic male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6887: Occur in association and close proximity with the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima, but that species has a hollow stipe that expands distally into a gas-filled bulb, from which the fronds spread laterally. Specimens from Namibia and Northern Cape tend to have longer, hollow stipes that broaden distally and were once regarded as a separate species L. schinzii, but these are now considered conspecific with L. pallida.
taxon_text_8_6888:

taxon_text_1_7295: Upright, dark-green fronts emerge from a horizontal annulated stolon with root-like rhizoids that anchor it to the bottom. Each frond has a basal section which is annulated and upper section that bears many fine lateral branches, like a flight-feather.
taxon_text_2_7296: Feather-like fronds 300 mm tall. Lateral branches about 7 mm long.
taxon_text_3_7297:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Point to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7298: Common on shallow reefs, where it may form extensive clumps that cover large areas of reef and tend to accumulate sand. Members of this genus are unusual in that they have very large multinucleate cells. Most regional species are more tropical and only a few penetrate into the cooler waters of the Western Cape.
taxon_text_6_7300: Usually reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump.
taxon_text_7_7301: One of several similar feathery species in this genus, but these occur mostly in warmer waters further to the east.
taxon_text_8_7302:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 123).
taxon_text_9_7303: Sometimes cited as a synonym of Chaetomorpha linum or as C. linum f. aerea, but the two species differ considerably in both morphology and habitat, so are listed separately here.
taxon_text_1_7304: Forms a vivid dark green mass of very long, slender, unbranched and fairly-straight filaments, each composed of a row of cylindrical cells placed end to end. The clump is attached by an enlarged basal cell about 1 mm long bearing root-like rhizoids.
taxon_text_2_7305: Filaments about 0.2 mm wide, clump about 100 mm or more tall.
taxon_text_3_7306:
Global: Very widespread across temperate and tropical seas.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7307: Common in highshore rockpools, often attached to rocks that are covered in a shallow layer of sand.
taxon_text_6_7309: Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes. Also reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump.
taxon_text_7_7310: Some sources consider the attached and unattached forms as being varieties of C. linum, but this seems extremely unlikely, as they differ greatly in both form and habitat. Thus we follow both Algaebase and the local west and south coast guides listed below, in retaining them as distinct species.
taxon_text_8_7311:

taxon_text_1_7313: Forms tangled masses of unattached, dark-green, slender, branched filaments, each composed of a row of cylindrical cells placed end to end. Stiff and often curled and may form clumps, or be entangled among other algae.
taxon_text_2_7314: Filaments about 0.25-0.3 mm wide, can be extremely long, up to at least 500 mm.
taxon_text_3_7315:
Global: Very widespread across temperate and tropical seas.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7316: Common in sheltered sites, such as harbours and estuaries, but also tidal swimming pools, where the photographed specimen was found. Unattached and often curled around the stipes of other algae to maintain position. Stiff and hard to the touch.
taxon_text_6_7318: Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes. Also reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump.
taxon_text_7_7319: Some sources consider the attached and unattached forms as both being varieties of C. linum, but this seems extremely unlikely, as they differ greatly in both form and habitat. Thus we follow both Algaebase and the local west and south coast guides listed below, in retaining them as distinct species and terming the attached form C. aerea.
