taxon_text_1_7322: Distinctive species forming a dark green brush of thick, unbranched filaments, each composed of a row of large barrel-shaped cells placed end to end and firmly attached basally by a holdfast. Cells near the ends of each filament may be empty and white, indicating that the spores have been released.
taxon_text_2_7323: Filaments up to 2 mm wide, clump typically about 100 mm or more tall.
taxon_text_3_7324:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7325: Found in dense clumps in lowshore pools and shallow subtidal.
taxon_text_6_7327: Alternating generation of similar looking sporophytes and gametophytes. Sporophytes produce spores that bear 4 flagella and develop into gametophytes that in turn produce male and female gametes that merge and develop into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7328: Unmistakable due to very large cells making up the filaments.
taxon_text_8_7329:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 374).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 101).
taxon_text_1_7331: Forms dense, erect tufts of fine, light grass-green filaments. The filaments are formed of a single chain of cells that branch repeatedly and emerge from a fibrous mass of rhizoids.
taxon_text_2_7332: Filaments about 0.2 mm wide, clump typically about 300 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7333:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7334: Can be long and flexible when found in subtidal gullies, or shorter and more bushy when in intertidal pools.
taxon_text_6_7336: Usually reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump or production of small motile spores. Sexual reproduction involves alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this genus are smaller and less conspicuous that the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7337: One of several similar and confusing species in this genus. See references below for details and key to species.
taxon_text_8_7338:

taxon_text_1_7340: Forms a short cushion of repeatedly branching grass-green filaments a few cm tall. Filaments comprised of a single chain of cells each 1-3 times longer than wide. These are interwoven and attached by rhizoids at several places along their length.
taxon_text_2_7341: Filaments about 0.15 mm wide, clump typically about 300 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7342:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7343: Found on sandy rocks in the intertidal and on shallow reefs and confined to west coast.
taxon_text_6_7345: Usually reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump or production of small motile spores. Sexual reproduction involves alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this genus are smaller and less conspicuous that the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7346: One of several similar and confusing species in this genus. See references below for details and key to species. Habitat and range similar to C. flagelliformis, but that species has much longer filaments reaching at least 150 mm long and is darker blue-green in colour.
taxon_text_8_7347:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 374).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 105).
taxon_text_1_7349: Forms dense erect tufts of fine, wiry, dark blue-green filaments that emerge from a small matted holdfast. The filaments are formed of a single chain of cells that branches repeatedly. Filaments widen towards their tips and are dark when filled with spores, but transparent after the spores have been shed.
taxon_text_2_7350: Filaments about 0.3 mm wide, clump typically about 150 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7351:
Global: Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania, Tristan da Cunha.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Durban.
taxon_text_4_7352: Found in isolated dense clumps on the walls of mid- to low-shore pools and shallow subtidal.
taxon_text_6_7354: Usually reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump or production of small mitile spores. Sexual reproduction involves alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this genus are smaller and less conspicuous that the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7355: One of several similar species in this genus. Easily confused with C. capensis, but that species is lighter grass green.
taxon_text_8_7356:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 374).

taxon_text_1_7358:
Forms tall, dark-green, tree-like growths of soft spongy branches emerging from a single holdfast. The repeatedly branching fronds are fairly thick and obviously flattened at the branches (and sometimes the tips).

Internally the branches are made up of large interwoven tubes that are each single multinucleated cells. On the surface these emerge as distinct swellings (utricles) and the shapes of these needs to be examined microscopically to distinguish between many of the species. In this species the utricles are unusually large (about 1 mm) with rounded apices and may sometimes bear hairs (variable).
taxon_text_2_7359: Total height typically about 300 mm with flattened branches reaching at least 40 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7360:
Global: Namibia, South Africa, Mozambique, Kenya, Oman, Vietnam, Australia and New Zealand

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7361: Intertidal pools and on shallow sublittoral reefs across the region. Like other species in this genus fed on by sap-sucking sea slugs, mostly of the genus Elysia, which penetrate the large calls and suck up the contents, including the chloroplasts, which continue to photosynthesize within the slug’s body, making it essentially ‘solar-powered’.
taxon_text_6_7363: Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
taxon_text_7_7364: There are several similar, tree-like species in this genus and the utricles need to be examined under the microscope for accurate identification. This species has unusually large, rounded utricles. Other similar species in the region include C fragile (small apical spines on utricles)) and C. extricatum (hairs on tips of utricles).

taxon_text_1_7367:
Forms tall, dark-green, tree-like growths of soft, spongy branches emerging from a single holdfast. The repeatedly branching fronds are fairly thick and cylindrical and internally are made up of large interwoven tubes that are each single multinucleated cells. On the surface these emerge as distinct swellings (utricles) and the shapes of these need to be examined microscopically to distinguish between many of the species.

In this species the utricles each bear one to several elongate hairs which gives the branches a distinctly furry appearance.
taxon_text_2_7368: Cylindrical fronds 5-8 mm in diameter; whole tree-like structure up to 300-500 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7369:
Global: South Africa, Kenya, Australia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7370: Common in rock pool and in low intertidal. Fed on by sap-sucking sea slugs of the genus Elysia, which penetrate the large calls and suck up the contents, including the chloroplasts, which continue to photosynthesize within the slug’s body, making it essentially ‘solar-powered’.
taxon_text_6_7372: Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
taxon_text_7_7373: There are several similar tree-like species in this genus and the utricles need to be examined under the microscope for accurate identification. This species is fairly easily identified in the field by the long hairs emerging from the utricles and surrounding the branches in a delicate pale halo.
taxon_text_8_7374:

taxon_text_1_7376: Forms tall dark-green tree-like growths of soft spongy branches emerging from a single holdfast. The repeatedly branching fronds are fairly thick and cylindrical, but may be somewhat flattened towards their bases. Internally they are made up of large interwoven tubes that are each single multinucleated cells. On the surface these emerge as distinct swellings (utricles) and the shapes of these needs to be examined microscopically to distinguish between many of the species. In this species the utricles have distinctively pointed tips.
taxon_text_2_7377: Cylindrical fronds 5-8 mm in diameter; whole tree-like structure 100-300 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_7378:
Global: The species has a widespread distribution in both northern and southern hemispheres, including several introduced populations, but the subspecies capense is endemic to Southern Africa. There is still considerable confusion though as to the entities within C. fragile.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7379: Grows on the margins of intertidal pools and on shallow sublittoral reefs. Fed on by sap-sucking sea slugs of the genus Elysia, which penetrate the large calls and suck up the contents, including the chloroplasts, which continue to photosynthesize within the slug’s body, making it essentially ‘solar-powered’.
taxon_text_6_7381: Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’ or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
taxon_text_7_7382: There are several similar tree-like species in this genus and the utricles need to be examined under the microscope for accurate identification. This species has spine-like projections on the ends of the utricles. Other similar species in the region include C. isaacii and C. duthieae (rounded tips to utricles) and C. extricatum (hairs on tips of utricles).

taxon_text_1_7385: Forms flat growths consisting of a series of irregular sausage-like lobes that adhere strongly to the substratum. Colour dark green, sometimes brown tinged. Utricles cylindrical and about 1 mm long and 0.1 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_2_7386: Lobes about 50 mm long and 5 mm thick, colonies up to 100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_7387:
Global: The species has a widespread distribution including Mozambique, Kenya, Australia and New Zealand, but the subspecies capense is endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7388: Grows in pools and on rocks in the mid-to low intertidal.
taxon_text_6_7390: Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
taxon_text_7_7391: The flattened growth form is fairly unique among Western Cape species, but similar to the Creeping codium C. prostratum which occurs along the east coast. That species has a more tubular branching body form though.
taxon_text_8_7392:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

taxon_text_1_7403:
Small, slow-moving fish able to inflate the body to deter predators by swallowing water (or air) to form an almost spherical ball. Mouth small and teeth fused into single sharp upper and lower dental plates (hence the family name Diodontidae). Pelvic fins absent and dorsal and anal fins both placed far back near tail fin. Body surface armoured with shortish, pointed spines, those on the head permanently erect. No spines on peduncle of tail.

Colour mottled brown or grey with black spots on back and sides. Transverse bands of faint brown on all fins.
taxon_text_2_7404: Up to 30 cm, but more typically 15 cm.
taxon_text_3_7405:
Global: Wide-spread across Indo-Pacific including Red Sea and Persian Gulf.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7406: Usually solitary and seen around reefs at depth 15-170 m. Mostly nocturnal and sleep during the day. Juveniles are pelagic and are often found cast ashore on the driftline.
taxon_text_5_7407: Feeds on a range of invertebrate prey, including urchins, gastropods and crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_7408: Eggs are buoyant and larvae are pelagic.
taxon_text_7_7409: Family unmistakable and the only species in the genus found in the temperate waters of the Western Cape. Porcupine fish (Diodon spp.) are similar in body shape, but have much longer, more-pointed spines
taxon_text_8_7410:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 284).

Doi, H, Ishibashi, T & Sakai, H (2015). Spawning and rearing of a porcupine puffer Cyclichthys orbicularis (Diodontidae, Tetraodontiformes) in captivity. Aquaculture Science, 63(2), 207–212.

Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 455).

Lee, WC, Kim, JB, Kim, HC, Bae, SE, Ryu, JH & Kim, JK (2014). New Record of the Birdbeak Burrfish Cyclichthys orbicularis (Pisces: Diodontidae), in Korea. Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 17(4), 491–496.
taxon_text_1_7394: Distinctive, large, upright species with very dark-green, flaccid, spongy lobes that branch dichotomously.
taxon_text_2_7395: Whole structure can be as much as 1000 mm tall. Individual lobes about 2 mm thick and up to 240 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7396:
Global: Previously reported as endemic to South Africa, but subsequently recorded from Senegal and Korea (seems unlikely these records are of the same species though).

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7397: Distinctive and unusually large species found in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs, most common on south coast. Often encrusted by patches of the Flat red alga Placophora binderi, as seen on image below.
taxon_text_6_7399: Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
taxon_text_7_7400: The only flat-bladed, erect Codium in the region.
taxon_text_8_7401:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 121).
taxon_text_1_7412: Encrusting species formed of thick dark-green ear-like lobes that are free from the substratum along the growing edges, but attached centrally by patches of rhizoids. Younger lobes rounded, but older ones irregularly cleft into lobes. Utricles with a constriction below tip giving them a ‘nine-pin’ shape.
taxon_text_2_7413: Lobes up to 5 mm thick and up to 300 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_7414:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7415: Distinctive species that forms large colonies in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs. Extensively fed on by green sap-sucking sea slugs of the genera Placida and Elysia, which penetrate the large calls and suck up the contents, including the chloroplasts, which continue to photosynthesize within the slugs’ bodies, making them essentially ‘solar-powered’.
taxon_text_6_7417: Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
taxon_text_7_7418: Could be confused with Lucas‘ codium C. lucasi, but that species is formed of smaller, sausage-like lobes that form irregular mats that are strongly adherent to the substratum.
taxon_text_8_7419:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 121).
taxon_text_1_7421: Forms delicate, membranous light green to yellowish, elongate tubes with walls just one cell thick. Margins often wrinkled. Habitat also a good identification feature.
taxon_text_2_7422: Typically about 100 mm long, but can reach 500 mm.
taxon_text_4_7424: Tolerant of wide fluctuations on both temperature and salinity and often forms dense colonies in mid- to high-shore rockpools and in lagoons and estuaries. Bubbles often become trapped within the tubes, buoying them to the water surface.
taxon_text_6_7426: Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7427: The most common of several easily-confused tubular species in this genus.
taxon_text_8_7428:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 86).
taxon_text_1_7430: Tough pale to grass-green fronds form elongate, strap-like blades that have undulating, ruffled edges and are attached at base by a small holdfast. Fronds thicker and paler along center than on margins.
taxon_text_2_7431: Blades typically 10-30 mm wide and can be 300 mm or more long.
taxon_text_3_7432:
Global: Widespread across temperate and tropical seas.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7433: On exposed shores, where it can hang in long, trailing clumps from intertidal rocks. In Saldanha Bay specimens of at least 1m across have been identified as this species.
taxon_text_6_7435: Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7436: One of several confusing species in this genus, but the elongate, frilly blades fairly diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_7437:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024. (as U. fasciata).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 372).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 92).
taxon_text_1_7439: Forms firm, flat, light- to grass-green lobes emerging from a central holdfast. Smaller individuals often take the form of small, tight rosettes. Blades two cells thick and have minute teeth near the base.
taxon_text_2_7440: Typically about 100 mm long, but can reach 500 mm.
taxon_text_3_7441:
Global: Widespread across temperate ad tropical seas.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7442: Abundant on exposed intertidal rocks, where it can form dense beds, and in rockpools and shallow sublittoral reefs.
taxon_text_6_7444: Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7445: One of several easily-confused species in this genus. See references for keys and full accounts of these.
taxon_text_8_7446:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_7448:
This unusual jellyfish belongs to the small and recently-created family Drymonematidae, which contains just the single genus Drymonema.  There are three described species, one from the Mediterranean region, and one each from the Atlantic coasts of North and South America. The southern African species depicted here has not yet been named or scientifically described.

The species can be recognised by its pink colour, fairly flat umbrella, numerous, multi-layered, frilly, petticoat-like oral arms and long trailing marginal tentacles.
taxon_text_3_7450:
Global: Though to be endemic to west coast of southern Africa. 

Local/Regional: West coast.
taxon_text_4_7451: Little is known about this newly discovered species, which is thought to be endemic to the Benguela region along the west coast of Southern Africa. Other species in the genus are effective predators of other jellyfish and thought to be effective control agents of these species.
taxon_text_6_7453: Details unknown but jellyfish have a dimorphic life cycle, alternating between an asexual benthic polyp that resembles a tiny sea-anemone, and the sexual planktonic medusa. Each medusa is either male or female and males release sperm into the water which are taken in by females to fertilise their eggs. Larvae are released into the water and ultimately settle onto hard surfaces where they develop into the polyp stage, which finally buds off tiny medusae.
taxon_text_7_7454: Easily identified by the pink colour and numerous pink petticoats.
taxon_text_8_7455:
Bayha, KM & Dawson, MN (2010). New family of allomorphic jellyfishes, Drymonematidae (Scyphozoa, Discomedusae), emphasizes evolution in the functional morphology and trophic ecology of gelatinous zooplankton. The Biological Bulletin, 219(3), 249-267.

Bayha, KM, Graham, WM, Higgins III, JE & Fletcher, HA (2012). Predation potential of the jellyfish Drymonema larsoni Bayha & Dawson (Scyphozoa: Drymonematidae) on the moon jellyfish Aurelia sp. in the northern Gulf of Mexico. Jellyfish Blooms IV: Interactions with humans and fisheries, 189-197.

Gibbons, MJ, Morandini, AC, Straehler-Pohl, I & Bezio, N (2022). Identification Guide to Macro Jellyfishes of West Africa. Food & Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Rome. (p. 83, family entry).
taxon_text_1_7457: Forms fan-shaped tufts of short, thin, but fairy-wide translucent pinky-red blades that lack a central midrib. Blades branch once or twice and can be variously incised or lobed along sides and at tips.
taxon_text_2_7458: Typically about 50 mm tall. Blades about 20 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7459:
Global: South Africa, Namibia and St Paul Island.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7460: Attached to rocks and sometimes to other algae, usually in rock pools. Can form low but extensive patches, even in pools quite high in the intertidal. Also extends into shallow sublittoral.
taxon_text_6_7462: Tetrasporangia in patches near edges of blades; cystocarps scattered on blades, distinctly swollen and with a single prominent opening.
taxon_text_7_7463: There are two other, similar members of this genus in the region. The Curled acrosorium A. ciliolatum has narrowed blades with distinctly curling tips, while the Spotted acrosorium A. maculatum has pale spots all over the thallus surfaces.
taxon_text_8_7464:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Papenfuss, GF (1939). The development of the reproductive organs in Acrosorium acrospermum. Botaniska Notiser, 11-20.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 462).
taxon_text_1_7484: A small holdfast leads to a short stipe that branches into broad, oval, leathery blades. These lack a distinct midrib and split into wide oval lobes, often with tattered margins. Small accessory blades may grow from the surface and mature plants have small, dark, foliaceous growths scattered over the blade surface (hence the term ‘black spots’). Colour a distinctive coppery red. May turn black after collection.
taxon_text_2_7485: Up to about 200 mm tall. Blades about 40 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7486:
Global: Southern African endemic. A record from the Philippines is unlikely to actually represent this species.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7487: Attached to rocks from low water mark downwards. Often associated with kelp beds.
taxon_text_6_7489: Tetrasporangia in clusters scattered over both surfaces of the dark proliferations on the blades.
taxon_text_7_7490: Neuroglossum and Botryoglossum have similar habits and growth forms, but have a distinct midrib. Hymenena venosa is also similar, but has parallel veins along the blades.
taxon_text_8_7491:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 396).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 466).
taxon_text_1_7493: Long, narrow, dark, branching stipe emerges from a root-like holdfast and gives rise to neat, transparent, red blades which fan out. Blades have rippled margins and have a prominent midrib and microscopic venation in the apices.
taxon_text_2_7494: Up to about 300 mm tall. Blades about 15 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7495:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7496: Attached to rocks from low water mark downwards. Often associated with kelp beds.
taxon_text_6_7498: Tetrasporangia small and circular and found in small proliferations on the thallus margins or midrib.
taxon_text_7_7499: Neuroglossum is similar, but lacks microscopic venations at apices of blades, which often have lateral leaflets.
taxon_text_8_7500:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 396).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 467).
taxon_text_1_7502:
Delicate bushy and flexible with a small holdfast attached to other algae and a prominent, segmented main stem. Laterals emerge from the main stem, one per segment, in a spiral arrangement and become progressively shorter from base to tip, so the whole structure resembles as tapered bottle-brush.  Each side branch is similarly tapered. Colour purple-red.

The common name is a reflection of the earlier generic name.
taxon_text_2_7503: Up to 300 mm tall, but typically less than 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_7504:
Global: Mainly Southern African, but also reported from Sri Lanka.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_7505: Distinctive and attractive species which is fairly common, especially on west coast. Forms soft, epiphytic growth on other larger algae from the mid-intertidal downwards.
taxon_text_7_7508: There are 12 regional species in this genus, which has been the subject of much revision and still require further taxonomic clarification. The regional species are discussed and listed by Reddy et al. (2020) – see references.
taxon_text_8_7509:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

McIvor, L, Maggs, CA & Stanhope, MJ (2002). RbcL sequences indicate a single evolutionary origin of multinucleate cells in the red algal tribe Callithamnieae. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, 23, 433-446.

Reddy, MM, Stegenga, H, Anderson, RJ & Bolton, JJ (2020). An updated species inventory of Callithamnion sensu lato Rhodophyta, Callithamniaceae in South Africa with the description of Callithamnion africanum sp. nov. Phytotaxa, 461(3), 139-154.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 390 as Aristothamnion collabens).
taxon_text_1_7511: Found exclusively growing as an epiphyte on kelps of the genus Ecklonia. Several erect, flattened main axes emerge from a base which penetrates the tissues of the host.  Main axes are long and flattened and bear irregular lateral branches of various lengths. These in turn are lined by a frill of tiny branchlets (which may even have even more smaller branchlets along their margins!). Colour reddish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7512: Main blades up to about 300 mm tall, and typically about 2-3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7513:
Global: Chile and Southern African.

Local/Regional: Namibia to de Hoop, on Ecklonia maxima, but also extends to Eastern Cape on E. radiata.
taxon_text_4_7514: A very common epiphyte of Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima, often forming dense growths on older fronds.
taxon_text_6_7516: Reproductive structures found in marginal branches. There is a complex life cycle involving both a sporophyte (spore producing) generation and similar-looking separate male and female gametophyte (gamete producing) generations.
taxon_text_7_7517: Both growth form and habitat distinctive, but several other epiphytic frilly red algae also occur on kelps, including Red ribbons Gelidium vittatum and Hypnea ecklonii. The much smaller C. minima occurs on Split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida.
taxon_text_8_7518:
Anderson, RJ, Rothman, MD, Share, A, et al. (2006). Harvesting of the Kelp Ecklonia maxima in South Africa affects Its three obligate, red algal epiphytes. Journal of Applied Phycology, 18, 343–349.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 403).
taxon_text_1_7520: Found exclusively growing as an epiphyte on the split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida. Small, growing to only about 50 mm tall and anchored by a base which penetrates the tissues of the host.  Main axes are long and flattened and bear irregular lateral branches of various lengths. These in turn may be lined by a frill of tiny branchlets. Colour reddish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7521: Main blades up to about 50 mm tall, and typically about 0.3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7522:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7523: A small epiphyte found on the stipes and fronds only of the split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida.
taxon_text_6_7525: Reproductive structures (tetrasporangia) found in main axes and on principal lateral branches.
taxon_text_7_7526: Very similar to the much larger flaccid kelp-weed C. flaccida but that species occurs only on the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_8_7527:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 412).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 404).
taxon_text_1_7529: Forms attractive fairly stiff fan-like branching plants arranged all in one plane. Axes segmented and main branches occur at intervals of about 6-20 segments, diverging at a fairly wide angle to form an open lattice. There are rows of tiny branchlets along the main axes between the main branches. Tips of branches strongly tapering and not distinctly incurved. Colour reddish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7530: Reaches about 200 mm on west coast, but much smaller on south coast. Main branches less than 1 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7531:
Global: Namibia and South Africa, also reported from Brazil.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Durban.
taxon_text_4_7532: May be attached to rocks, but often epiphytic of other algae. Common in low intertidal pools and on sublittoral fringe.
taxon_text_6_7534: Reproductive structures on small branchlets along main axes.
taxon_text_7_7535: Several other similar regional species in this and closely-related genera – see Stegenga reference for a more detailed account of and identification key to west coast species. This species a mainly identified by the flat, fan-like shape, branching pattern and rows of small branchlets along main axes.
taxon_text_8_7536:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 419 as Ceramium obsoletum).
taxon_text_1_7538: Dark purple-red to almost black and usually found growing as epiphyte on the kelp Ecklonia maxima. Forms long, thin whip-like axes emerging from a basal holdfast. Axes branch repeatedly from main central stem to form a fine, bushy growth.
taxon_text_2_7539: Up to about 300 mm tall, with main axis only about 2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7540:
Global: Endemic to Southern African (records from Australia and South America discredited).

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7541: Epiphytic on the kelp Ecklonia maxima, rarely also on Laminaria pallida and on rock surfaces. Usually on the stipes and can be common and form extensive growths.
taxon_text_6_7543: Tetraspores in linear series borne in the apical parts of the branches.
taxon_text_7_7544: Easily recognised by the dark colour, thin branches and  epiphytic habits. Several other more robust epiphytic species are also found on kelps though, the most common of which are the Flaccid kelp weed Carpoblephais flaccida and Red ribbons, Gelidium vittatum.
taxon_text_8_7545:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 404).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 554 as Polysiphonia virgata).
taxon_text_1_7547: Forms very short, dense, bushy, cushion-like clumps of interwoven, wiry axes high in the intertidal. On close inspection, the axes are cylindrical and frequently branched, the tips of the branches produced into spike-like tips. Axes are secondarily attached to each other or the substratum, so the patch is attached across its entire area. Colour pale yellowish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7548: Clumps typically about 50 mm across and 10-20 mm tall, with axes about 1 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_7549:
Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate seas worldwide.

Local/Regional: Found all along Southern African coastline.
taxon_text_4_7550: Common species in the mid- to upper intertidal, where it forms low, moss-like cushions on patches of mussels, reef worms and other sedentary invertebrates. Occurs higher than most other algae.
taxon_text_7_7553: Fairly distinctive due to cushion-like form and habitat high in intertidal. Could be confused with smaller Gelidium species.
taxon_text_8_7554:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 313).

taxon_text_1_7556:
Small, delicate species forming tufts of long, thin, branching filaments, each branching dichotomously or alternately (depending on species) and ending in a pair of strongly-incurved, claw-like tips. The filaments appear segmented, but each segment is composed of many rows of small cells. Small bud-like growths may be present in the forks of the main filaments. Colour dark reddish-brown.

The taxonomy of this group in South Africa remains confused, so we do not venture to give a species name to the images provided. Species with dichotomous branching (as illustrated) were previously referred to C. clavulatum, but recent work by Won et al. (2009, 2010) failed to reveal that species, which was described from Peru, in South Africa, but instead reported several others, including some described as new, despite the study being based on examination of relatively few specimens. The true numbers of species in the region and their distributions thus remain poorly known, although a key to the known species is given by Won et al. (2010).
taxon_text_2_7557: Up to 100 mm tall, typically smaller, with filaments only about 0.2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7558:
Global: Genus found in tropical and temperate waters around the world.

Local/Regional: Genus found all along southern African coast.
taxon_text_4_7559: Several species common in low intertidal and shallow sublittoral reefs around different parts of the coast.
taxon_text_6_7561: Tetraspores in whorls borne in the apical segments.
taxon_text_7_7562: There are many similar regional species in this and closely-related genera and these can be easily confused – see Stegenga reference for identification key to west coast genera in the family and Won et al. (2010) for key to regional species in the genus.
taxon_text_8_7563:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 405).

Won, BY, Fredericq, S & Cho, TO (2010). Two new species of Centroceras (Ceramiaceae, Rhodophyta) from KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. European Journal of Phycology 45(3): 240-246.
taxon_text_1_7565: Small and very delicate species consisting of thin, branching filaments each ending in a pair of strongly-incurved, claw-like tips. The filaments are strongly banded with alternating rings of small red cells and larger transparent ones, creating a distinctive beaded appearance. Often grows epiphytically on other algae, such as Codium spp.
taxon_text_2_7566: Typically about 30 mm tall, with filaments only about 0.25 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7567:
Global: Endemic to southern African.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_7568: Often epiphytic of other algae and common both in algal turfs and attached to the fronds of other larger algae.
taxon_text_6_7570: Tetraspores oval and borne in the apical segments.
taxon_text_7_7571: There are several similar regional species in this and closely-related genera and these can be easily confused – see Stegenga reference for a more detailed account of, and identification key to, west coast species.
taxon_text_8_7572:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 410).
taxon_text_1_7574: Attractive and delicate purplish-red species forming flat, fern-like fronds. Main axes segmented (but nor banded in colour) and give off alternating lateral branches to left and right, but all in the same plane, at intervals of 3-4 segments. These re-branch several times into fairly dense tufts, but tips are not strongly incurved (as in many other Ceramium species).
taxon_text_2_7575: Reaches about 200 mm on west coast, but much smaller on south coast. Main branches about 1 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7576:
Global: Southern Africa and Antarctica. Also reported from Mozambique, but that record is considered suspect.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_7577: Primarily a west coast species and often epiphytic of other algae. Common in low intertidal and subtidal reefs.
taxon_text_6_7579: Tetraspores borne externally around the branches of the axes.
taxon_text_7_7580: The branching pattern is distinctive, but there are several other similar regional species in this and closely-related genera – see Stegenga reference for a more detailed account of and identification key to west coast species.
taxon_text_8_7581:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 423).
taxon_text_1_7583: Small creeping species forming clumps just a few cm tall. Main axed flattened and divided at short intervals by transverse septa, giving a distinctly segmented appearance. Lateral branches emerge in one plane, each emerging from a slender base and tending to become shorter towards the tip. Colour pinkish to dark red, often with brilliant iridescent green or blue gloss.
taxon_text_2_7584: Clumps typically about 20 - 30 mm tall. Flattened axes about 2-3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7585:
Global: South Africa northwards into Indian Ocean and its islands, also Phillippines, Korea, Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine on west coast through to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7586: Small but fairly common in algal turfs from low intertidal and shallow reefs. Often easy to spot due to bright iridescence.
taxon_text_6_7588: Spore-producing structures (tetrasporangia) spherical and about 0.1 mm in diameter found in central cavities of axes.
taxon_text_7_7589: The related Earthworm champia C. lumbricalis is a larger, stiffer species with rounded axes and forms upright clumps. It is also dark reddish-brown and lacks iridescence.
taxon_text_8_7590:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 368).
taxon_text_1_7592: Forms clumps of stiff, upright, dark-red, cylindrical axes emerging from a stiff holdfast of interwoven stolons. Axes taper at each end and are divided internally by transverse septs (hence the similarity to segments of an earthworm and the common name). More terminal branches tend to form as clusters.
taxon_text_2_7593: Clumps typically about 200 mm tall, but up to 300 mm. Axes about 2-4 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7594:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7595: Distinctive and common species on wave-washed intertidal shore, particularly on the west coast coasts, where it can form a distinct band.
taxon_text_6_7597: Spore-producing structures (tetrasporangia) concentrated in branching from the ends of the main uprights.
taxon_text_7_7598: The related Compressed champia C. compressa is a smaller and more delicate species with flattened axes and tends to form more flat creeping clumps. It also often sports bright blue or green iridescence.
taxon_text_8_7599:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 406).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 370).
taxon_text_1_7601: Characteristic ‘ice-cream’ pink in colour and forming dense cushions of short, closely-packed upright axes, each of which bears tapering lateral branchlets, much like a pine-tree. Tips of branches acute.
taxon_text_2_7602: Short, reaching only about 20 mm in height, branches about 1 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_7603:
Global: Primarily a tropical species widespread in Indian Ocean and western Pacific.

Local/Regional: Previous distribution given as KwaZulu-Natal to Algoa Bay but the photographed specimens were seem in Muizenberg, extending the distribution to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_7604: In more tropical areas can form carpets in low intertidal pools and on shallow reefs, but in False Bay found growing commonly on margins of mussels (Choromytilus meridionalis) in a low intertidal pool. Produced a potent neurotoxin, demoic acid, that is usually associated with toxic phytoplankton blooms and which causes amnesic shellfish poisoning.
taxon_text_7_7607: Unlikely to be mistaken for any other species, due to unusual pink colour and short, closely-packed cushions with distinctive branching pattern.
taxon_text_8_7608:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 408).

Steele, TS, Brunson, JK, Maeno, Y, Terada, R, Allen, AE, Yotsu-Yamashita, M, ... & Moore, BS (2022). Domoic acid biosynthesis in the red alga Chondria armata suggests a complex evolutionary history for toxin production. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 119(6), e2117407119.
taxon_text_1_7610: Emerges from a small base and divides into well-spaced, stiff, erect, cylindrical axes which are each tapered at both ends. End branchlets are conspicuously terminally swollen or spindle-shaped, often numerous and crowded and bear prominent apical tufts of branched filaments. Colour dark purplish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7611: Clumps up to 300 mm tall, axes about 3 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_7612:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7613: Found on low intertidal and in shallow sublittoral of exposed rocky shores. Often occurs together with Hypnea spicifera.
taxon_text_7_7616: Fairly easy to identify due to the swollen terminal branches with their bunches of apical hairs.
taxon_text_8_7617:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 408).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 517).
taxon_text_1_7619: Small to medium, dark-red species, often with patches of iridescent green, blue and yellow. Erect axes emerge from an extensive holdfast and some of these curve to the sides and are secondarily attached to the substratum by small pads. Vertical axes formed of a series of bulging bead-like segments that are each longer than broad. At the joints short lateral branches emerge, often arranged in whorls around main axis.
taxon_text_2_7620: Two forms see. Iridescent clumps typically only about 20 mm tall, but pale brown ones as large as 200 mm. Axes about 2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7621:
Global: South Africa endemic.

Local/Regional: West coast though to about Port St. Johns.
taxon_text_4_7622: Common in algal turfs from low intertidal and shallow reefs, especially in pools. Iridescent plants are easy to spot, but many of larger ones are plain brown and recognised by their beaded structure.
taxon_text_6_7624: Spore-producing structures (sporangia) found in central cavities of axes; spherical and about 0.1 mm in diameter, each divided into 8 spores.
taxon_text_7_7625: Can be confused with the Compressed champia C. compressa, which is also dark reddish-brown, has similar habits and distribution and is also iridescent, but that species has flattened rather than cylindrical axes.
taxon_text_8_7626:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 370).
taxon_text_1_7628: Large, firm and fern-like with multiple erect axes emerging from a root-like holdfast. Axes cylindrical near base, but becoming compressed distally, giving off lateral branches at right angles to main stem which then bend towards tip and branch again repeatedly to create a dense bush. Colour dark red to brown.
taxon_text_2_7629: Clumps up to about 400 mm tall, axes about 1.5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7630:
Global: South Africa, Madagascar, Mauritius, Oman. A record from Philippines is unlikely to be this species.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7631: Can form dense bushy clumps from low-shore pools to shallow subtidal. Like other Gelidium species used as a source of agar and is commercially collected from Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_7_7634: One of about 10 regional species in this genus, but distinguished from most by large size and cylindrical main axes.  The very similar G. abbottiorum has thinner, more delicate axes only 1 mm wide.
taxon_text_8_7635:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

taxon_text_1_7637: Most often seen in a strongly-grazed form, as narrow gardens surrounding the Pear limpet Scutellasta cochlear. This form consists of prostrate axes with short lateral lobes and is only a few mm tall. Larger plants, not included in limpet gardens, are rare and have soft, fleshy, flattened central axes which give off paired lateral lobes that in turn bear short secondary branches. Colour brownish red.
taxon_text_2_7638: Grazed specimens are prostrate and form narrow gardens about 10 mm wide around the host limpet, but are only a few mm tall. Un-grazed clumps typically up to about 50 mm long, blades about 1 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7639:
Global: Endemic to South Africa (Namibian records probably not this species).

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7640:
Mostly seen as narrow gardens surrounding the Pear limpet Scutellastra cochlear. The limpets eliminate other algae from their gardens and by ‘mowing’ them (and probably also by fertilizing them with their urine) they stimulate growth of the algae and are able to subsist on a tiny ‘plot’, thus maintaining remarkably high populations densities. The fact that they hardly move, grow very slowly and have a lower reproductive rate than most other limpets also reduced their energy requirements, making them the ‘tortoises’ of the seashore!

Un-grazed plants often seen on the backs of limpets.
taxon_text_6_7642: Individual tufts often include a mixture of sporophyte and gametophytes stages of the life cycle, as well as juveniles.
taxon_text_7_7643: One of about 10 regional species in this genus, but most easily recognised by its association with limpets.  Plants growing separate from limpets recognised by their soft texture and strongly-flattened axes.
taxon_text_8_7644:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

taxon_text_1_7646: Short, bushy, tough, dark olive-brown species with numerous erect axes emerging from a dense stoloniferous base. Fronds narrow and strap-shaped, with a distinct midrib and irregularly and strongly lobed, toothed and with undulating margins. Typically forms dense, bushy clumps in the mid-intertidal.
taxon_text_2_7647: Clumps typically up to about 100 mm tall, blades about 3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7648:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7649:
Very common species within its range and often dominant in the mid-intertidal, where frequently restricted to growing on the backs of limpets or barnacles, where it can escape from the attention of grazers. 

Like other Gelidium species used as a source of agar. It is one of the most important commercially-harvested seaweeds in South Africa and hence its ecology and the optimal methods of harvesting have been researched in some detail (see references).
taxon_text_6_7651: Individual tufts often include a mixture of sporophyte and gametophytes stages of the life cycle, as well as juveniles.
taxon_text_7_7652: One of about 10 regional species in this genus, but distinguished by the flat, prolifically-lobed fronds.
taxon_text_8_7653:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

taxon_text_1_7655: Emerges from a small holdfast growing out of the stipes of the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima, or alternatively attached to the shells of the Kelp limpet Cymbula compressa. Forms clumps of elongate, narrow, terminally-pointed fronds, each with a distinct midrib and often spiraled. The elongate main fronds bear a few side branches and the margins of both main and side branches are lined with a frill of tiny oval leaflets. Texture tough and not slippery; colour purple-red.
taxon_text_2_7656: Clumps up to 500 mm long, blades about 10 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7657:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7658:
Found only on the stipes of kelps, or growing on the shells of the kelp limpet, which is also restricted to living on Ecklonia. The algae find protection from grazing by growing on the limpet shell, but the limpet can then get ripped off the kelp stipe during storms due to the drag caused by large clumps of algae attached to it!

Traditionally used as a source of agar for jelly-making, but not commercially collected (as are several other Gelidium species).
taxon_text_6_7660: The reproductive structures are borne on the marginal leaflets.
taxon_text_7_7661: Easily distinguished both by form and habitat, although might be confused with the Flaccid kelp-weed Carpoblepharus flaccida, which is also elongate, branched and epiphytic on kelps, but that species has a much softer, fleshier texture and lacks midribs.
taxon_text_8_7662:

Ag.(Rhodophyta: Gelidiaceae) for mariculture: geographical distribution, reproductive phenology and growth of sporelings in culture in relation to light and temperature. taxon_text_1_7664: Forms large, tough, dark-red, oval blades emerging from a narrow stem and attached to a small, disc-like holdfast. Gametophyte phase has a few surface papillae and numerous small ones around perimeter of blade. Tetrasporophyte (depicted in photograph) has a smooth surface and marginal papillae, but its most characteristic feature is that when spores are released the blade disintegrates to becomes a lacy mass of holes.
taxon_text_2_7665: Blades up to about 500 mm tall, but more typically 250 mm.
taxon_text_3_7666:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape of Good Hope.
taxon_text_4_7667: Very distinctive and common species found on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore. As with other species in this group has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_6_7669: Tetrasporangial sori disintegrate after producing spores, leaving holes in the blades.
taxon_text_7_7670: The holes on the fronds of mature tetrasporophyte easily distinguish this from several other local Gigartina species.
taxon_text_8_7671:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 398).

taxon_text_9_7672: Gigartina radula (which remains a valid species in Australia).
taxon_text_1_7673:
Forms large, tough, oval blades emerging from a narrow stem and attached to a small disc-like holdfast. There are usually 2-3 main blades and a series of much smaller ones around their bases. The main blades are characteristically covered with short papillae, hence the common name tongue-weed. Colour dark reddish-brown.

The South African form was separated from G. radula, which was originally described from Australia, by Hommerstrand et al. 1994, but without examining South African material, so this requires confirmation.
taxon_text_2_7674: Blades up to about 400 mm tall, but more typically 150 mm.
taxon_text_3_7675:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Port Alfred, but most common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_7676:
Very distinctive and common species found on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore, where it is often the dominant algal species.

The rough surface forms habitat for numerous small invertebrates, especially the tiny red copepod Porcellidium algoense, which scuttle around on the fronds in their thousands.

Has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_7_7679: The dense papillae on the fronds distinguish this from several other local Gigartina species.
taxon_text_8_7680:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 350).
taxon_text_1_7682: Forms large, tangled masses of profusely and irregularly branching long, cylindrical fronds. Emerges from a small holdfast, but often found unattached or partially buried in sand. Colour straw to pale reddish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7683: Clumps up to 1 m long, blades only 1-2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7684:
Global: Temperate and tropical localities worldwide.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Swartkops Estuary in Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7685:
Very common in sheltered bays, lagoons and estuaries, where it forms large patches and often lies loose on the bottom, where it forms habitat for numerous small fish and invertebrates.

Washes up in large drifts after storms and has historically been collected and used for the extraction of agar, a gelling agent. Also has potential as a mariculture species and is cultivated on a large scale in China and Taiwan.
taxon_text_6_7687: Mostly reproduce asexually by fragmentation and regrowth of the pieces. The sporophyte and gametophyte generation look similar.
taxon_text_7_7688: A second species, G. lemaneiformis is almost indistinguishable, but occurs on sand-cover rocks along the open coast.
taxon_text_8_7689:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Rebello, J, Ohno, M, Critchley, AT & Sawamura, M (1996). Growth rates and agar quality of Gracilaria gracilis (Stackhouse) Steentoft from Namibia, Southern Africa. Botanica Marina, 39, 273-279.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 300 as G. verrucosa).
taxon_text_1_7691:
Dark plum-red and forming long, flaccid strap-like blades which have margins that are longer than the central portions, such that the fronds have rippled edges.

The species level identifications of South African Grateloupia are currently confused. Stegenga et al. (1997) used the names G. doryphora and G. filicina for South African material, but De Clerk et al. (2005) described a new species G. capensis for material previously referred to G. filicina and also resurrected the species G. longifolia for material with broad, foliose fronds. Bolton et al. (2016) reported two more newly-discovered species from aquaculture rafts in Saldanha Bay, both of which appear to be introduced and one of which remains unidentified. Species in this genus are plastic in form and difficult to identify on the basis of morphology, so we do not commit to a species level identification here, although the specimens photographed seem to most closely resemble the shape and habits of the form known as ‘G. longifolia’.
taxon_text_2_7692: Total length can reach 303 mm, with fronds typically about 30 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7693:
Global: Species in this genus occur virtually worldwide.

Local/Regional: All along west coast, including Namibia.
taxon_text_4_7694: The ‘ longifolia’ form depicted here is common on the lower levels of sand-inundated rocky shores along the west coast, where it can form extensive growth, rolling back and forth in the breaking waves. Other species occur in rocks pools on rocky shores and on aquaculture rafts.
taxon_text_6_7696: Tetrasporangia widely spread across large sections of the fronds.
taxon_text_7_7697: Species level identifications difficult in this group, but the long, flaccid, rippled blades and preference for sand-inundated habitats in the depicted form are fairly characteristic of the longifolia form.
taxon_text_8_7698:
Bolton, JJ, De Clerck, O, Francis, CM, Siyanga-Tembo, F & Anderson, RJ (2016). Two newly discovered Grateloupia (Halymeniaceae, Rhodophyta) species on aquaculture rafts on the west coast of South Africa, including the widely introduced Grateloupia turuturu. Phycologia, 55(6), 659-664.

Systematics of Grateloupia filicina (Halymeniaceae, Rhodophyta), based on rbcL sequence analyses and morphological evidence, including the reinstatement of G. minima and the description of G. capensis sp. nov. 1. Journal of Phycology, 41(2), 391-410.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 288 as G. doryphora and G. filicina).
taxon_text_1_7700: Forms small cushions comprised of upright filaments, each composed of a branching chain of very large, elongate, sausage-shaped cells. Around the base of the terminal cell on each branch are a cluster of tetrasporangia at different stages of development. Colour bright, transparent pink.
taxon_text_2_7701: Small species forming cushions about 20-40 mm across and 20 mm tall. Individual cells about 2 mm long.
taxon_text_3_7702:
Global: Southern Africa and Antarctica. Also reported from Mozambique, but that record is considered suspect,

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7703: Small, but very distinctive species found in algal turfs in rockpools, low in the intertidal or on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_7705: Tetraspores borne externally around the tips of the branches. There are separate male and female clumps.
taxon_text_7_7706: Small and hence easily missed, but unmistakable when examined closely.
taxon_text_8_7707:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 433).
taxon_text_1_7709: Forms erect, broadly flattened axes, often several arising from the same holdfast, these then branch dichotomously several times before ending in rounded, truncated, forked tips (tips often arched). The surface of the fronds bear characteristic, large, ball-like knobs when fertile. Texture stiff and tough and colour dark plum-red. Colonies often encrusted with a pink epiphytic coralline alga and by bryozoans.
taxon_text_2_7710: Typically about 150 mm tall, with axes at least 5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7711:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7712: Attached to rocks in low-shore pools and on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_7714: Tetrasporangia in prominent hemispherical structures borne on the upper parts of the thallus lobes.
taxon_text_7_7715: The dark plum red colour, tough branching axes and large ball-like knobs on fertile specimens make this species fairly easy to identify.
taxon_text_1_7718: Forms extensive very dark, purple-black crusts on rocks high in the intertidal. Younger parts along margins fairly smooth, but older parts very knobbly, may incorporate sand grains and easily detached from the substratum.
taxon_text_2_7719: Crusts may be extensive, covering tens of cm, thickness typically 1-4 mm.
taxon_text_3_7720:
Global: Australia, New Zealand, Chile, South Africa, Falklands and some sub-Antarctic islands.

Local/Regional: Orange River to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_7721: Very distinctive, with growth form unlike that of almost any other regional red algal species. Also unusual in that extends far up into the intertidal, where at upper levels it is often the dominant algal form.
taxon_text_6_7723: Reproduces by producing tertaspores within the thallus.
taxon_text_7_7724: Unlike any other regional species, but sometimes not recognised as an alga at all, or confused as a lichen.
taxon_text_8_7725:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 280).
taxon_text_1_7727: Forked, strap-like blades emerge from a short stem attached to a root-like holdfast. Blades have more-of-less parallel rippled margins, branch dichotomously and are marked with several parallel veins. Colour pink to red, often with an iridescent sheen, like oil on water (hence common name).
taxon_text_2_7728: Up to about 300 mm tall, but more typically 150 mm.  Blades about 20-30 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7729:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7730: Attached to rocks from low water mark downwards, especially in kelp beds.
taxon_text_6_7732: Tetrasporangia in clusters scattered over the thallus surface and separated by veins.
taxon_text_7_7733: See also Neuroglossum and Botryoglossum, which have similar habits and growth forms but have a distinct midrib, less venation and often lateral leaflets on the blades.
taxon_text_8_7734:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 396).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 479).
taxon_text_1_7736: Usually found attached to other large sublittoral algae, especially kelps, to which it is attached by a small root-like structure. Colour dark red. Main axis thin and round and runs from base to tip, bearing numerous lateral branches, which in turn bear shorter laterals. Tips of branches not hooked.
taxon_text_3_7738:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7739:
Poorly documented species most often recorded attached to drift algae cast up on shore. Epiphytic of other algae especially the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima.

Like other species in this group has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_6_7741: Spore producing structures (tetrasporangia) near tips of branches.
taxon_text_7_7742: This genus contains about 8 regional species, some of which are very difficult to tell apart. Although these have been partially resolved in a genetic study by Johnson (see references) that work did not record H. ecklonii and appears not to have been formally published. Also sometimes confused with Flaccid kelp weed Carpoblepharis flaccida, which has a similar overall structure and is also epiphytic on kelp, but that species has a flattened main axis and more-regular and flattened side-branches and is purplish-brown in colour.
taxon_text_8_7743:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 406).

Johnson, VJ (2018). Molecular systematics of the genus Hypnea (Rhodophyta) in South Africa, with the description of a new genus, Tenebris (Cystocloniaceae, Rhodophyta). Unpublished Masters Dissertation, Department of Biological Sciences, University of Cape Town.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 331).
taxon_text_1_7745: Forms stiff, upright, greenish tufts on the lower levels of exposed rocky shores, these becoming purplish towards their bases (revealing that this is a red, not a green alga!). The upright shafts emerge from a matt of creeping rhizomes and are typically about 3 mm in diameter. Each upright is irregularly branched and bears numerous short, spiky lateral projections towards its tip.
taxon_text_3_7747:
Global: Southern Africa and widely distributed in Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia (and possibly into Angola) and all along the South African coast.
taxon_text_4_7748:
Very distinctive and common species on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore, particularly on the south and east coasts, where it can form a distinct green band. Less common and less vivid green on the west coast. Often found in areas subject to sand inundation.

Has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_6_7750: Spore producing structures (tetrasporangia) concentrated in the spiniform appendages branching from the ends of the main uprights.
taxon_text_7_7751: This genus contains about 8 regional species, some of which are very difficult to tell apart. Although these have been partially resolved in a genetic study by Johnson (see references) this work appears not to have been formally published. This species can be distinguished from other local members of the genus by its stiffer and much thicker stems (3 mm vs less than 1 mm).
taxon_text_8_7752:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.
