Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 335).
taxon_text_1_7754: Forms erect, tapering clumps of several main cylindrical axes arising from a single holdfast. Each main axis gives off alternating side branches that become shorter and more crowded distally. These in turn bear short secondary branchlets that resemble small bunches of grapes, hence common name. Colour dark red.
taxon_text_2_7755: Clumps up to 400 mm tall, but more typically 150 mm.
taxon_text_3_7756:
Global: South Africa, South America, India, Pakistan and Indonesia.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth on west coast to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7757: Found on low intertidal on exposed rocky shores.
taxon_text_7_7760: Fairly easy to identify to genus, but there are several closely-related species that differ slightly in branching pattern and shape of the terminal branchlets (see references for details).
taxon_text_8_7761:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 408).

Francis, CM, Bolton, JJ, Mattio, L, Mandiwana-Neudani, T & Anderson, RJ (2017). Molecular systematics reveals increased diversity within the South African Laurencia complex (Rhodomelaceae, Rhodophyta). Journal of Phycology, 53, 804-819.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 532).
taxon_text_1_7763: Fairly large and common species attached by a tiny, simple holdfast and short stipe. This expands into wide, leathery, tough, brown to greenish strap-like blades which have undulating margins and when mature are covered in dark spots. They are not slippery.
taxon_text_2_7764: Blades up to about 500 mm tall, but more typically 300 mm.
taxon_text_3_7765:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7766: Common species found on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore, all along the west coast.
taxon_text_7_7769: Often found together with Slippery orbits Pachymenia orbitosa, with which it can be confused, but the black spots are characteristic and  is not slippery to the touch.
taxon_text_8_7770:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 392).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 353).
taxon_text_1_7772: Small root-like holdfast leads to a branched and flattened stipe with a midrib and with fairly narrow margins, which may be severely eroded and also bear numerous proliferations, giving a tattered look. No longitudinal veins in blades. Colour transparent dark red.
taxon_text_2_7773: Up to about 200 mm tall. Blades about 20 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7774:
Global: Southern Africa and subantarctic islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_7775: Attached to rocks from low water mark downwards. Often associated with kelp beds especially in sandy, sheltered areas.
taxon_text_6_7777: Tetrasporangia in clusters on either side of the midrib in apical sections.
taxon_text_7_7778: Botryoglossum platycarpum is similar in habits and growth-form, but the midrib fans out into veins are the ends of the blades. Hymenena venosa is also similar, but has parallel veins along the blades and no midrib.
taxon_text_8_7779:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 396).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 487).
taxon_text_1_7475: Stiff, leathery and upright in form. Slightly-flattened, twig-like axes branch repeatedly and end in forked, pointed tips. Older axes may have branches projecting at right angles. Colour uniform dark red.
taxon_text_2_7476: Whole structure about 100 mm tall, axes 1-2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7477:
Global: South Africa and Tristan da Cunha.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about Port St Johns.
taxon_text_4_7478: Attached to rocks in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs, including sand-inundated areas.
taxon_text_6_7480: Carposporophytes may be visible as swellings on the main axes in reproductive individuals.
taxon_text_7_7481: There are several regional species in this genus, but the relatively large size and thin, twig-like axes distinguish this from most other related species.
taxon_text_8_7482:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 400).

Silva, PC & DeCew, TC (1992). Ahnfeltiopsis, a new genus in the Phyllophoraceae (Gigartinales, Rhodophyceae). Phycologia, 31, 576-580.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 343).
taxon_text_1_7781:
Forms branching yellowish-brown to almost black blades that emerge from a small holdfast. Edges of the blades, and sometimes the surfaces, bear numerous small, branched outgrowths (hence common name). May also incorporate swollen gas-filled bladders.

Becomes black and papery when exposed to air and dries out at low tide.
taxon_text_3_7783:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_7784: Fairly distinctive and common species found in patches on intertidal rocks, particularly in sand-inundated areas.
taxon_text_6_7786: The familiar form is the gametophyte and the sporophyte phase is crustose and capable of surviving long periods buried in sand.
taxon_text_7_7787: The outgrowths along the edges of the blades are a fairly distinctive identification feature.
taxon_text_8_7788:
Anderson, RJ & Stegenga, H (1985). A crustose tetrasporophyte in the life history of Nothogenia erinacea (Turner) Parkinson (Galaxauraceae, Rhodophyta). Phycologia, 24, 111-118.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 398).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 260).
taxon_text_1_7790: Forms characteristic reddish-brown, erect gas-filled bladders which arise from a common base to form small patches.
taxon_text_3_7792:
Global: Southern Africa and Tristan da Cunha.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Tsitsikamma.
taxon_text_4_7793: Distinctive species found in patches on intertidal rocks particularly on the west coast. Commonly in sand-inundated areas.
taxon_text_6_7795: The familiar form is the gametophyte and the sporophyte phase is crustose and capable of surviving long periods buried in sand.
taxon_text_7_7796: Very distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other species. The closely-related Hedgehog seaweed N. erinacea also sometimes also has gas filled bladders, but these are borne on flat fronds edged with numerous small lateral outgrowths (see that entry).
taxon_text_8_7797:
Anderson, RJ & Stegenga, H (1985). A crustose tetrasporophyte in the life history of Nothogenia erinacea (Turner) Parkinson (Galaxauraceae, Rhodophyta). Phycologia, 24, 111-118.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 398).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 260).
taxon_text_1_7799: Forms multiple dark orange-red to blood-red straps emerging from a cylindrical holdfast. Blades have smooth margins and are very tough, leathery, up to 1.5 mm thick and not slippery to the touch. They have been compared to rubber inner-tubing in texture!
taxon_text_2_7800: Blades typically about 500 mm long and about 100 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7801:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7802: Large and conspicuous species found all along the west coast, where can be abundant in low intertidal zones and on shallow reefs, often associated with kelps.
taxon_text_6_7804: Spore-producing structures, each producing 4- spores (tetrasporangia) are found across large areas of the blades.
taxon_text_7_7805: The related Slippery orbits P. orbitosa is lighter brown in colour, has wider and much thinner blades and is exremely slippery in texture.
taxon_text_8_7806:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 392).

Farrant, AJ, Nunn, JR & Parolis, H (1971). Sulphated polysaccharides of the grateloupiaceae family: Part VI. A polysaccharide from Pachymenia carnosa. Carbohydrate Research, 19(2), 161-168.

Russell, LK, Hurd, CL, Nelson, WA & Broom, JE (2009). An examination of Pachymenia and Aeodes (Halymeniaceae, Rhodophyta) in New Zealand and the transfer of two species of Aeodes in South Africa to Pachymenia. Journal of Phycology, 45, 1389-1399.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 291).
taxon_text_1_7808: Forms very large, tough, yellowish- to reddish-brown sheets emerging directly from a central holdfast (without any stipe). Margins of sheets broadly rounded and variously incised. Surface extremely slippery.
taxon_text_2_7809: Blades typically about 300 mm, but can grow to over 1 m long.
taxon_text_3_7810:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas, replaced to the east by another similar, but smaller, species P. uvoidea.
taxon_text_4_7811:
Common and conspicuous species all along the west coast, where abundant in mid- to low intertidal zones.

Has been considered as a possible source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_6_7813: Spore-producing structures, each producing 4- spores (tetrasporangia) are found evenly spread across much of the blades.
taxon_text_7_7814: One of several large, sheet-like algae found on west coast shores, but distinguished by its very large size and slippery texture.
taxon_text_8_7815:

taxon_text_9_7816: The recommendation that this species be incorporated into the genus Grateloupia, made by De Clerck et al. (2005) has not been accepted.
taxon_text_1_7817: Attached by a disc-like holdfast leading to a short stipe, from which large, flat, irregular blades emerge. The blades are tough, dark purplish-red, have a strongly corrugated surface and are often perforated with irregular holes.
taxon_text_2_7818: Blades typically 200 mm tall, but can be larger.
taxon_text_3_7819:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Point.
taxon_text_4_7820: Distinctive species usually found beneath kelps in the shallow subtotal region. No other details available regarding biology.
taxon_text_6_7822: Tetrasporangia found on the thallus surface, but are concentrated in the grooves and absent from the ridges.
taxon_text_7_7823: The coarsely corrugated surface distinguished this species from most other similar red algae.
taxon_text_8_7824:

taxon_text_9_7825: Grateloupia capensis, also incorrectly identified in some past publications as Grateloupia filicina, which is a valid species, but has a European distribution.
taxon_text_1_7826: Narrow, flat fronds arise from a disclike holdfast and give rise to numerous long, thin lateral branches, resulting in a characteristic ‘ragged’ appearance. Colour dark purplish-brown to almost black.
taxon_text_2_7827: Overall up to 300 mm tall, individual fronds only about 10 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7828:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Point.
taxon_text_4_7829: Common in rock pool along the west coast, where it can occur high on the shore and can be a dominant species. Has been considered as a possible source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_6_7831: Spore-producing structures, each producing 4- spores (tetrasporangia) are found evenly-spread across much of the blades.
taxon_text_7_7832: The numerous long, tattered side branches to the main fronds make this species fairly easy to identify.
taxon_text_8_7833:

taxon_text_1_7835: Epiphytic, mostly on Codium spp., where it forms dark red-brown, flat crusts with lobed margins and attached by root-like rhizoids. Small sausage-like reproductive filaments project from upper surface, especially around the edges, and are about 0.5 mm long.
taxon_text_2_7836: Patches can be several cm in diameter and are less than 0.5 mm in thickness.
taxon_text_3_7837:
Global: South Africa, Mozambique, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Peru and Tristan da Cunha.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7838: Common epiphyte on the surfaces of various Codium species, where is can cover much of the lower branches of the host. Also recorded from Zonaria and on the tests of the ascidian Pyura stolonifera.
taxon_text_6_7840: Reproductive structures borne on short, free, sausage-like filaments on the upper surface.
taxon_text_7_7841: The related P. monocarpa is a common epiphyte on the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima and apart from having a different host can be distinguished by the longer dorsal filaments, which are up to 5-10 mm long, giving it a velvety appearance.
taxon_text_8_7842:

taxon_text_1_7844: Forms small, bright-red tufts of thin, branching and gradually tapering filaments a fraction of 1 mm wide. These give off lateral branches of irregular lengths that each arise from a narrow base, widen slightly and then taper to a pointed tip.
taxon_text_2_7845: Whole structure up to about 100 mm tall and individual filaments less than 0.5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7846:
Global: Mainly Southern African, but also reported from St Paul Island.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7847: Forms small delicate tufts in intertidal pools and on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_7_7850: A smaller species P. delicata (previously called P. miniata) is common in algal turfs and epiphytic on other seaweeds from De Hoop eastwards into KwaZulu-Natal and is also widespread in tropical and subtropical areas worldwide, but does not occur on the west coast.
taxon_text_8_7851:
Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 491).

Wynne, MJ (1983). The current status of genera in the Delesseriaceae (Rhodophyta). Botanica Marina, 26, 437-450.
taxon_text_1_7853:
Delicate bright pink to red species emerging from a rhizome-like holdfast and forming small clumps. Each frond arranged in a single plane and with prolific branching. Branches may be simple, elongate and curved, tapering to a sharp tip (awl-shaped), or be shorter and strongly bent, bearing 2-3 curved laterals along their concave margin (these in turn may also bear smaller teeth).

Appears to be more common and grow much larger and more sparely-branched along the east and south coast, suggesting that the smaller, more compact Western Cape form may be a different species?
taxon_text_2_7854: On south coast reported to be up to about 150 mm tall, but specimens from False Bay much smaller at 20-30 mm. Branches less than 1 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_7855:
Global: South Africa and Angola.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7856: Very attractive and distinctively coloured species found from low intertidal to shallow sublittoral.
taxon_text_6_7858: Other species of Plocamium known to have a complex life cycle consisting of three phases. The diploid sporophyte produces haploid spores which develop onto separate male and female gametophytes. These look similar to the sporophyte, except for details of the small fertile branches in the axils of the fronds. The female gametophyte retains her eggs while they are fertilised by the male gametes and develop into wart-like discs, and these are finally releases as asexual carpospores that develop back into the sporophyte generation!
taxon_text_7_7859: There are several other regional species of Plocamium, all with curved branches. This species can be identified by its small size and delicate structure, flat branching pattern and bright pink colour.
taxon_text_8_7860:

taxon_text_1_7862: Fairly large species comprising multiple tall, erect fronds emerging from a well-developed holdfast. Colour deep-pink, often infused with an iridescent purplish-blue. Fronds flattened and give off alternating claw-like lateral branches, the margins of which are also serrated. Reproductive bodies form tiny clumps of leaf-like clusters in the axes of side branches.
taxon_text_2_7863: Blades up to about 300 mm tall and about 7 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7864:
Global: Mainly southern African, but also reported from Cape Verde Islands, Madagascar, Amsterdam and St Paul Islands.

Local/Regional: Yzerfontein on west coast to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7865: Distinctive and fairly common species on wave- exposed shores, occurring from low intertidal pools to a depth of about 5 m.
taxon_text_6_7867: Has a complex life cycle consisting of three phases. The diploid sporophyte produces haploid spores which develop onto separate male and female gametophytes. These look similar to the sporophyte, except for details of the small fertile branches in the axils of the fronds. The female gametophyte retains her eggs while they are fertilised by the male gametes and develop into wart-like discs, and these are finally releases as asexual carpospores that develop back into the sporophyte generation!
taxon_text_7_7868: There are several other much smaller regional species of Plocamium, all with curved branches, but this species is most likely to be confused with P. suhrii, which also has a blue hue, but is more delicate with frond only about 3 mm wide.
taxon_text_8_7869:

taxon_text_1_7880: Fairly tall but delicate species comprising multiple, erect fronds emerging from a well-developed holdfast. Colour deep red, often strongly infused with an iridescent purplish-blue. Fronds flattened and give off alternating claw-like lateral branches in groups of two, the margins of which are not serrated. Reproductive bodies form tiny clumps of leaf-like clusters in the axes of side branches.
taxon_text_2_7881: Fronds up to about 150 mm tall and about 3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7882:
Global: South Africa, northern Namibia, Angola, Madagascar, Amsterdam and St Paul Islands, as well as (doubtfully?) Korea.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7883: Very attractive and distinctively-coloured species fairly common from low intertidal to shallow sublittoral up to about 5 m depth.
taxon_text_6_7885: Has a complex life cycle consisting of three phases. The diploid sporophyte produces haploid spores which develop onto separate male and female gametophytes. These look similar to the sporophyte, except for details of the small fertile branches in the axils of the fronds. The female gametophyte retains her eggs while they are fertilised by the male gametes and develop into wart-like discs, and these are finally releases as asexual carpospores that develop back into the sporophyte generation!
taxon_text_7_7886: There are several other regional species of Plocamium, all with curved branches, but this species is most likely to be confused with P. corallorhiza, which also has a blue hue, but is more robust, growing to about 300 mm tall and with fronds up to about 10 mm broad.

taxon_text_1_7871:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This is a relatively large, robust and heavy-bodied species with a rounded head that is depressed behind the eyes, a wide mouth with thick lips and large eyes. There is a prominent brush-like cirri above each eye, made up of a flat stalk bearing a fringe of filaments. The dorsal fin has 30-34 spines and 5-6 rays, and has a slight notch after the third spine, but is not raised into and anterior crest. The pectoral fins are large and fleshy.

The eyes have a characteristic radiating pattern of alternating light and dark brown ‘spokes’. The rest of the body is mottled in light and dark brown, yellow and cream, arranges to form a series of seven darker brown vertical bars. There is often a large orange patch above the pectoral fins and behind the eyes.
taxon_text_2_7872: Up to 23 cm total length, males larger than females.
taxon_text_3_7873:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7874: A predominantly night active species and hence not often seen. Usually found on rocky reefs below the intertidal and to a depth of about 20 m. Actively hunting at night but docile when approached, likely an ambush predator. During the day hidden among seaweeds and benthic invertebrates on the reef.
taxon_text_5_7875: Stomach contents of only a few specimens have been analysed but these contained mostly amphipods and small molluscs, with one crab.
taxon_text_6_7876: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_7877: Klipfishes can be quite difficult to identify to species level but this species can be identified by its heavy build, large mouth and eyes and colour pattern.
taxon_text_8_7878:

taxon_text_1_7889: Forms stiff, erect, tree-like growths arising from a small, disc-like holdfast. Axes cylindrical to slightly oval, branch in all directions and are constricted at irregular intervals. Colour dark red to blackish.
taxon_text_2_7890: Clumps up to about 150 mm tall. Axes 1-2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7891:
Global: Southern Australia and southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7892: Low intertidal pools and gullies and in shallow subtidal zone.
taxon_text_6_7894: Spore producing structures (tetrasporangia) towards the ends of the main uprights.
taxon_text_7_7895: Dark colour and branching pattern fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_1_7898:
Form thin, flat, yellowish to dark-purplish blades just a single cell thick and spreading from a small holdfast. Hang from rocks in the high-shore. Flexible and slippery when wet, but become dry and crisp when exposed at low tide.

Originally just a single species was recognized from South Africa, but genetic work has shown that there are at least eight distinct forms along the west coast of South Africa but these still need to be formally diagnosed and described.
taxon_text_2_7899: Blades typically about 150 mm, but can grow much larger.
taxon_text_3_7900:
Global: Genus widespread in cooler waters, but Southern African species are most-likely endemic to the region.

Local/Regional: Namibia to South coast, but most abundant on the west coast.
taxon_text_4_7901:
Form extensive coating hanging from intertidal rocks in the mid- to upper intertidal where few other algae survive and are extremely tolerant of water loss, becoming dry and crip on hot sunny days, but rehydrating once submerged.

Edible and fast growing. In Asia Porphyra has been cultivated for centuries and is known as nori. It is most often encountered dried in sheets and used as a wrapping for sushi. In South Africa small amounts are collected by health food enthusiasts and there is also interest in exploiting Porphyra as a feed for cultivated abalone.
taxon_text_6_7903: The familiar macroscopic stage is the gametophyte and occurs as separate male and female individuals. These give rise to separate filamentous microscopic sporophytes.
taxon_text_7_7904: Fairly easily identified to genus both by form and by the unusual ability to survive high on the shore. Local species still need to be resolved.
taxon_text_8_7905:

taxon_text_1_7907: Fairly delicate and common species which forms dense branching clumps in pools in the lower intertidal and shallow subtidal. The main axes are flattened, fairly ‘woody’ and microscopically divided into segments (but these are hard to see in the field) and give off smaller flattened branches alternately to the left and right, these laterals rebranching 2-3 times before coming to pointed ends. Colour dark brown, sometimes almost black.
taxon_text_2_7908: Clumps can be up to 200 mm tall, but often much smaller. Blades only about 1.5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7909:
Global: Namibia, South Africa, Oman, Pakistan, Amsterdam and St Paul Islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Port Edward in southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7910: Can be very common in intertidal, especially in wave-swept areas, where sometimes forming a distinct zone in lowshore pools. Appearance and size quite variable and lower branches may be worn off in some specimens.
taxon_text_6_7912: Tetrasporangia are borne in apical parts of lateral branches.
taxon_text_7_7913: There are several other species of this genus in the region. Of these P. spinifera has round, not flattened axes and P. stegengae wider, more flattened fan-like branches. Undescribed species probably also present (see Pterosiphonia sp. entry).

taxon_text_1_7916:
Small, bright orange-red species with bushy fern-like appearance. Main axes flattened and minutely, but not obviously, separated into segments. Side branches emerge alternately and then re-branch at least twice, the terminal branches tapering to pointed tips. Whole plant forms a series of neat, flattened, fern-like blades.

Several similar species are known from the region, but this specimen if difficult to match exactly to any of these, although it seems closest in its branching pattern to P. stangeri or P. complanate. We thus treat this as a genetic level entry and do not commit to a species identification.
taxon_text_3_7918:
Global: As this is a generic entry, distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Several species of this genus reported from different parts of the coast.
taxon_text_4_7919: Distinctive and attractive little species with a neat, symmetrical appearance. Has been observed several times on rock pools in the lower intertidal in Table Bay, often attached to mussels.
taxon_text_6_7921: In this genus tetrasporangia are borne one per segment in the distal parts of the thallus.
taxon_text_7_7922: There are several species of this genus in the region. Of these P. spinifera has round, not flattened axes, P stegengae wider, more flattened ones, while P. cloiophylla is more finely branched and dark-red in colour. This species appears closest to P. stangeri or P. complanata, but neither of these have previously been reported from the South African west coast, the first being known from False Bay eastwards and the second from Europe southwards to Namibia, but not from South Africa itself.

taxon_text_1_7925: Forms  short, fleshy clumps with twig-like branches that fork at regular intervals. Branches slightly flattened and forked at the tips, which are swollen. Distinctive ball-like reproductive structures are borne in groups near the tips of the branches. Colour purple-brown.
taxon_text_2_7926: Typically about 100 mm tall, with branches about 3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7927:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_7928: Attached to rocks in low to mid-shore rock pools and on shallow reefs. Can form dense stands in suitable shallow intertidal pools.
taxon_text_6_7930: Reproductive structures form prominent spherical balls attached on the upper parts of the branches.
taxon_text_7_7931: The unusual purplish-brown colour and large spherical reproductive structures make this species fairly easy to identify.
taxon_text_8_7932:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 400).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 352, as Gigartina sculellata).
taxon_text_1_7934: Gametophyte thick, fleshy and succulent-like, main blades covered with numerous large, freshy papillae arranged in irregular rows. Sporophyte also thick, but with a forked blade that is spotted with dark spore-bearing tissue. Colour yellowish-brown.
taxon_text_2_7935: Blades up to about 300 mm tall, but more typically about 100 mm.
taxon_text_3_7936:
Global: Southern African and Tristan da Cunha.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7937:
Very distinctive species found on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore, where it is often found adjacent to the more dominant Gigartina polycarpa.

Has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
taxon_text_6_7939: The forked sporophyte phase and distinctive gametophyte are similar in size and often found adjacently.
taxon_text_7_7940: The fleshy succulent-like shape of the gametophyte, with its large rows of fleshy papillae, is unmistakable and distinguishes this from local Gigartina species.
taxon_text_8_7941:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 398).

Hughey, J, Silva, P & Hommersand, M (2002). ITS1 sequences of type specimens of Gigartina and Sarcothalia and their significance for the classification of South African Gigartinaceae (Gigartinales, Rhodophyta). European Journal of Phycology, 37(2), 209-216.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 352, as Gigartina stiriata).
taxon_text_1_7943: Bushy plant emerging from a small discoid holdfast. Fairly fat, robust cylindrical axes branch dichotomously at a narrow angle to each other and end with blunt, rounded tips. Well-developed specimens take on a hemispherical shape. Colour pale to bright red.
taxon_text_2_7944: Up to about 100 mm tall, more typically 50 mm, branches about 2-3 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_7945:
Global: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: Melkbosstrand on west coast to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_7946: Found in intertidal pools and in the shallow sublittoral. Sporadic in occurrence and seen mostly in spring and early summer.
taxon_text_7_7949: Easily confused with a number of other small, forked red species in genera such as Sarcothalia and Rhodymenia (see those entries) but with generally fatter branches.
taxon_text_8_7950:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Huisman, JM (1985). The Scinaia assemblage (Galaxauraceae, Rhodophyta): a re-appraisal. Phycologia, 24, 403-418.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 262).
taxon_text_1_7961: Forms dark-red bushy growths consisting of both prostrate filaments with root-like rhizoids and erect exes. Erect axes segmented, each segment composed of a ring of about 16 cells and branching about every third segment. Lateral branches rebranch into tufts of tapering filaments.
taxon_text_2_7962: Reaches about 50 mm tall. Main branches about 0.25 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7963:
Global: Southern African endemic, recorded from Angola, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to north coast of KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_7964: Common species on low intertidal among algal turfs.
taxon_text_6_7966: Tetrasporangia buried in rows in terminal branches of tufts.
taxon_text_7_7967: The tufted branching pattern is fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_7968:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 412).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 573).
taxon_text_1_7970: Thin, transparent purplish-red frond is attached directly to a discoid holdfast (without any stipe) and then splits and spreads out horizontally into a more-or-less circular form. Each branch has numerous smaller lobes along its tips and margins.
taxon_text_2_7971: May be up to 300 mm in diameter, but individual sections of blade typically only about 30 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7972:
Global: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_7973: Sublittoral fringe and below, usually associated with kelp beds.
taxon_text_6_7975: Spore-producing structures, each producing 4- spores (tetrasporangia) are found immersed in the blades.
taxon_text_7_7976: One of several large, red sheet-like algae found on west coast shores, but distinguished by its purplish-red colour and the small lobes around the edges of the much-divided blade.
taxon_text_8_7977:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 394).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 299).
taxon_text_1_7979: Forms comb-like fans of regularly-branching, narrow, flattened blades that branch dichotomously at close intervals and up to 12 times. Colour pale yellowish brown to reddish. Often forms dense beds in pools.
taxon_text_2_7980: Clumps up to 60 mm tall, blades 2-3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7981:
Global: Basically a Southern African endemic, but also records from St Paul and Amsterdam Islands in the Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_7982: Common in intertidal pools in the mid- to low shore, where it often forms dense beds. Extends to a depth of about 10 m.
taxon_text_7_7985: A second species, T. fragile, is found in Namaqualand and has much thinner branches that are rounded, rather than flat.
taxon_text_8_7986:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 400).

taxon_text_1_7988: Attached by a small disc-like holdfast which extends into a short cylindrical stipe and then an elongate, bright-red, tough but soft, fleshy blade. The blade forks once or twice before tapering to pointed tips.
taxon_text_2_7989: Blades elongate and can be up to 1 m long long, but more typically about 500 mm. Blades about 50-100 mm wide and 1 mm thick.
taxon_text_3_7990:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Hondeklip Bay on west coast to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_7991: Mostly subtidal to a depth of about 5m, but can occur in deep intertidal pools and gullies. Fairly commonly seen among drift material.
taxon_text_7_7994: The long, pointed, fleshy fronds and bright red colour are fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_8_7995:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 394).

taxon_text_1_7997: A small tan-coloured (occasionally purplish-red) dorid covered with small, pointed papillae. The rhinophores are usually darker with pale tips. The notum is densely covered with pointed papillae. The gills are luxuriant and bushy. Posteriorly rounded.
taxon_text_3_7999:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to False Bay, Knysna, endemic, 3–20m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8000: Usually seen on rocky reefs in association with bryozoans and sponges.
taxon_text_5_8001: This species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8002: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a convoluted white collar (see image).
taxon_text_7_8003: This species can be confused with the Velvet dorid, Jorunna tomentosa, and also with the Cape sucking dorid, Doriopsilla capensis, as well as several species of Doris, but is distinguishable from all these species by its pointed papillae and usual tan coloration.
taxon_text_8_8004:

taxon_text_1_8006: A tiny white-bodied dorid nudibranch covered with short white or brownish flat-topped tubercles. The head is white with several white tubercles, while the white rhinophores are surrounded by shorter knobbed appendages. The tubercles may have dusty to brownish smudges. The gills are white and surrounded by several knobbed extrabranchial appendages. The posterior end of the foot is tapered, white, and has short white tubercles.
taxon_text_3_8008:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay to Algoa Bay, found from the intertidal to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8009: Seen on densely colonised rocky reefs. Often seen on sponges and bryozoans.
taxon_text_5_8010: This species is thought to prey on calcareous sponges.
taxon_text_6_8011: Individuals are hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8012: The only species of Aegires in the region. Could be confused with the fluffy knobbed dorid, Aegires sp.1 from central KwaZulu-Natal but lacks the brown-speckled rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8013:

taxon_text_1_8015: A small oval-bodied dorid with a dull red to orange warty surface. The head is red, bearing red rhinophores. The tubercles on the  body may be pale. The gills are a darker orange or red than the rest of the body but have pale bases. The posterior end of the foot is rounded and warty.
taxon_text_3_8017:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula, western False Bay, 20 to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8018: Found on red sponges and coralline algae in relatively deep water.
taxon_text_6_8020: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8021: This species can be confused with the Red sponge dorid, Rostanga elandsia, but is distinguished by its warty surface.
taxon_text_8_8022:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 73).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 118).
taxon_text_1_8024: A small, oval-bodied, pale-coloured dorid with an orange warty surface. The head is pale orange and warty with slightly darker rhinophores. The body has indistinct darker blotches and a broad marginal band of opaque white spots. The gills are small and pale orange. The posterior end of the foot is rounded and warty.
taxon_text_3_8026:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, probably endemic, 22–30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8027: Rarely seen, though has been found on rocky reefs.
taxon_text_7_8030: This species can be confused with the Blotchy tentacled dorid, Geitodoris capensis, but is distinguished by the white-spotted marginal band.
taxon_text_8_8031: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 118).
taxon_text_1_8033: A small to medium-sized, rough-bodied, pale-coloured dorid with three dorsal, brown spots in a straight line. The head is pale, and covered with low tubercles. There is one brown spot between the rhinophores. The rhinophores are pale and the brown spot has pale spots within it. The body is covered with low pale tubercles and has two brown spots, also with pale spots within them. The gills are pale. The margin of the notum has a narrow band of densely clustered minute opaque white spots. The posterior end of the foot is rounded and covered with low pale tubercles.
taxon_text_3_8035:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay and Wild Coast, endemic, 10 to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8036: Rarely seen and found on rocky reefs. Not much else known about its biology.
taxon_text_6_8038: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8039: The pale spotted brown spots make this species unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_8040:

taxon_text_1_8042: A small pale creamy- to white-bodied aeolid with dark brown opaque white-flecked cerata. The head is white or pale with opaque white and dark speckling. The oral tentacles are translucent white with opaque white spots. The rhinophores are annulate, and translucent white with opaque white speckling. The cerata are arranged in distinct clusters along the notum; the notum also has opaque white speckling. The posterior end of the foot is slender, tapered, and translucent with opaque white speckling.
taxon_text_3_8044:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and western False Bay, intertidal to 15 m.
taxon_text_4_8045: Usually found on shallow reefs, may be associated with the Bamboo kelp, Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_5_8046: This species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8047: The species is hermaphrodite. The egg ribbon is likely a small coil of distinct white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8048: Though the species is relatively cryptic on reef substrates, it cannot be confused with other aeolids, since the dark white-speckled cerata are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8049:

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 95).
taxon_text_1_8051: A small, white-bodied almost transluscent dorid with irregular brown blotches. The head is white with brown blotches and the rhinophores are white with brown streaks and yellow tips. There is a pair of brown extrarhinophoral appendages with pale tips. The body is smooth. The gills are white with brown edging and yellow tips, and are flanked by brown-blotched white extrabranchial appendages. The posterior end of the foot is tapered, and white with brown blotches.
taxon_text_3_8053:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay, 1–30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8054: Usually found on arborescent bryozoans and the Stellar red sponge (Crambe acuata) that lives with commensal goblet worms. Frequently observed in pairs or several individuals together.
taxon_text_5_8055: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8056: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a series of messy cream spirals.
taxon_text_7_8057: The species can be confused with the Black-spotted longhorn dorid, Thecacera sp.1, but is distinguished by having white extrabranchial appendages with brown markings, and by having yellow tips to the gills and rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8058:

taxon_text_9_8059: Janolus capensis Bergh, 1907: unaccepted (original combination); Cape silvertip nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8060: A small- to medium-sized cladobranch with slanted, opaque white tips to its numerous lateral appendages. The rhinophores are white, and are separated by a distinct convoluted white caruncle (rhinophoral crest). The lateral appendages have dark brown bases and the notum is translucent or pale. The foot is tapered and may have a central opaque white stripe.
taxon_text_3_8062:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Central West Coast to Wild Coast, intertidal to 40 m.
taxon_text_4_8063: Found on temperate reefs, frequently observed on sponges and bryozoans.
taxon_text_6_8065: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is globular in shape and contains many capsules of eggs.
taxon_text_7_8066: The species can be confused with the Medallion silvertip flame, Antiopella longidentata, and is most easily distinguished in the field by the globular egg mass when present. Additionally, it can be distinguished by the angled transition between the opaque white tips and the dark bases of the lateral appendages. It can also be confused with the salmon morph of the Gasflame nudibranch, Bonisa nakaza, but is distinguished by the high profile caruncle and the well-defined separation in colour between the tips and bases of the lateral appendages.
taxon_text_8_8067:

taxon_text_1_8069:
Gobies are a diverse family of small, bottom-dwelling fish, most with a broad, depressed head, dorsal fin separated into anterior spiny and posterior soft-rayed sections and pelvic fins united to form a cup-like disc on which the fish rests when sitting on the bottom. The eyes are usually placed close together on top of the head. Some tropical species are brightly coloured, but temperate ones are generally pale and well camouflaged.

Although there are over 100 species in southern Africa, few extend to the Western Cape. This species is characterised by its pale body adorned with broken horizontal rows of numerous small black spots. The first dorsal fin has a yellowish margin and bears about three rows of dark stripes, plus a dark grey-blue spot at the rear of the fin (apparently absent in some individuals).
taxon_text_3_8071:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_8072: Occurs in rock pools, in estuaries and on shallow reefs to a depth of about 8 m. Commonly found sheltering under overhangs on the sand-rock interface. Sits on the bottom, supported by the pelvic fin and with pectoral fins extended for support.
taxon_text_7_8075: The Bareheaded goby C. nudiceps is similar but darker brown with large brown blotches and a distinct round black spot above the origin of the pelvic fin. The Banded goby C. caffer has about 10 marked vertical bars along the sides the body and the Prison goby C. gilchristi has similar but thinner bars arranged in about 8 pairs.
taxon_text_8_8076:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 330).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 784).
taxon_text_1_8078:
Gurnards are bottom-dwelling fish characterised by having a large, bony head and tapering body. The first few rays of the pectoral fins are separated into ‘feelers’ that are used to ‘walk’ along the bottom and feel for food, and the rest of the pectoral fin can be spread out laterally into a large, often strikingly-coloured ‘wing’.

This species is reddish as an adult, although juveniles (depicted) are silvery with dark spots. The eyes are very large and close together (much more so than in related bluefin gurnard). The enlarged pectoral fin has a dark blotch near its base which is speckled with white spots, but it lacks a blue edge.
taxon_text_3_8080:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_8081:
Found in sandy habitats from 10-390 m depth. Sedentary and usually found walking slowly along the bottom and feeling for prey using the three free pectoral rays under the head. The large swim bladder can be used for sound production. The large brightly-coloured pectoral fins may be used to startle predators.

An excellent eating fish and important commercial species caught mainly by trawlers. Maximum reported age 16 years.
taxon_text_5_8082: A predator feeding mostly on crustaceans, cephalopods and smaller fish.
taxon_text_6_8083: Females mature at and age of about 4 years and a length of 35 cm and males at an age of 5 years and length of 37 cm. Spawns mainly in summer and eggs planktonic.
taxon_text_7_8084: The Bluefin gurnard C. kuma has smaller and more widely spaced eyes and has a blue border to the pectoral fins.
taxon_text_8_8085:

taxon_text_1_8087:
Blennies are a diverse group of small, elongate, benthic fish that lack scales and usually have a blunt face with eyes placed close together high on the head and prominent cirri above the eyes. The dorsal fin runs almost the full body length and is separated into an anterior spined section and a posterior rayed section. The pelvic fins are placed far forward, anterior to the base of pectoral fins, and are reduced to one spine and a few rays.

Blennies are usually found sitting propped up on their pelvic fins in tide pools or on shallow reefs and sand and are very abundant and diverse on more tropical shores, with only a few species extending in the Western Cape.

This species has a hand-like branched cirrus above the eye and then another median longitudinal row of cirri along the back anterior to the dorsal fin (the ‘mane’). Head, body and fins are mottles brown with vertical bands and numerous small spots.
taxon_text_3_8089:
Global: Widespread across Atlantic and Indo-Pacific.

Local/Regional: Whole coast.
taxon_text_4_8090: Common in rockpools and on shallow reefs, where sits on the bottom supported by pelvic fins.
taxon_text_5_8091: Feeds on both red and green algae and on a wide range of small invertebrates including hydroids, mussels and small crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_8092: Sticky, translucent eggs are attached to the substratum and the larvae are planktonic and often found in shallow coastal waters.
taxon_text_7_8093:
Few other blennies occur in the region, of which this is the only one with a dorsal mane.  The Two-eyed blenny Chalaroderma ocellata has white-tipped cirri and a distinct black spot behind the eye and another in the anterior dorsal fin. The Horned blenny Parablennius cornutus has an orange-red cirrus with long side branches emerging from its base.

Blennies can also be confused with klipfishes and triplefins which have similar habits and reduced pelvic fins, but these families have more elongate faces.
taxon_text_8_8094:

taxon_text_1_8096:
Blennies are a diverse group of small, elongate, benthic fish that lack scales and usually have a blunt face with eyes placed close together high on the head and a prominent cirrus above each. The dorsal fin runs almost the full body length and is separated into an anterior spined section and a posterior rayed section. The pelvic fins are placed far forward, anterior to the bases of pectoral fins, and are reduced to one spine and a few rays.

Blennies are usually found sitting propped up on their pelvic fins in tide pools or on shallow reefs and sand and are very diverse and abundant on more tropical shores, with only a few species extending in the Western Cape.

This species has a prominent cirrus above the eye consisting of a broad base branching into several erect filaments with white tips. Head and body mottles brown and covered in numerous orange and dark spots, typically arranged into about 5 dark bars. There is a dark spot with a white upper margin (hence ‘two-eyed’ blenny) just behind each eye and typically a dark spot at the base of spines 3-5 of the dorsal fin.
taxon_text_3_8098:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_8099: Cryptic and seldom seen species usually found singly on reefs to a depth of at least 30 m. Often hide inside shells, including those of the Giant barnacle (Austromegabalanus cylindricus), with just the head protruding.
taxon_text_5_8100: Unknown but likely feeds on small invertebrates, possibly also algae.
taxon_text_6_8101: Sticky, translucent eggs are laid in empty shells and are guarded by the males as they develop.
taxon_text_7_8102:
Few other blennies occur in the region and the spot behind the eye is distinctive. The maned blenny Scarletta emarginata also has a distinctive mane-like row of cirri on the top of the head, while the Horned blenny Parablennius cornutus has an orange-red cirrus with a long central stalk and long side branches that emerge near its base.

Blennies can also be confused with klipfishes and triplefins, which have similar habits and reduced pelvic fins, but these families have more elongate faces.

taxon_text_9_8104: Janolus longidentatus Gosliner, 1981: unaccepted (original combination), Medallion silvertip nudibranch.
taxon_text_1_8105: A small- to medium-sized cladobranch with opaque white tips to its numerous lateral appendages. The rhinophores are white and separated by a distinct convoluted white caruncle (rhinophoral crest). The lateral appendages have dark brown bases, and there may be bluish shading along the horizontal border between the dark bases and the white tips. The notum is translucent to pale. The foot is tapered and may have a central opaque white stripe.
taxon_text_3_8107:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay and Knysna Lagoon, intertidal to 30 m.
taxon_text_4_8108: Found on temperate reefs, often seen on bryozoans.
taxon_text_5_8109: This species feeds on several species of bryozoans.
taxon_text_6_8110: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat medallion shape consisting of many capsules with a small number of eggs in each.
taxon_text_7_8111: The species can be confused with the Cape silvertip flame, Antiopella capensis, and is most easily distinguished in the field by the flat egg ribbon when present. addiotionally, it can be distinguished by the appearance of the border between the dark bases and white tips of the lateral appendages, which in this species is horizontal rather than oblique and may also have bluish shading. It is also confused with the salmon morph of the Gasflame nudibranch, Bonisa nakaza, but it is distinguishable by its high profile caruncle and the well-defined separation in colour between the tips and the bases of the lateral appendages.
taxon_text_8_8112:

taxon_text_9_8113: Aeolidiella multicolor Macnae, 1954: unaccepted; Aeolidiella saldanhensis Barnard, 1927: unaccepted (original combination); previously misidentified as Aeolidiella indica in Gosliner 1987, Zsilavecz 2007 and Jones 2008.
taxon_text_1_8114: A small to medium-sized translucent white-bodied aeolid with opaque white diamond-shaped patches on the notum and translucent orange opaque white-tipped cerata. The head has a U-shaped orange patch between the rhinophores and oral tentacles. The oral tentacles and rhinophores are smooth, and translucent white with opaque white speckled tips. The diamond-shaped patches on the notum have narrow orange margins. The cerata are densely clustered. In some individuals the ceratal tips may be pale yellow above a translucent white upper band. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and translucent white.
taxon_text_3_8116:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to western False Bay, intertidal to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_8117: This species can be found on temperate reefs, frequently observed on sponges, coralline algae and bryozoans.
taxon_text_5_8118: This species feeds on the Striped anemone, Anthothoe stimpsoni.
taxon_text_6_8119: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a relatively flat series of widely separated slightly undulating white coils.
taxon_text_7_8120: The species' U-shaped marking on the head and its dense cerata are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8121:

taxon_text_1_8123: A medium-sized, variably-coloured rough-bodied dorid. The head is pale with a variable patterning of browns, caramels and blacks. The rhinophores are usually white. The notum is pale, rough textured and has variable patterning. The most common colour morph in False Bay is mainly pale with dark brown streaks and blotches, or, less commonly, pale with brown spots. The most common morph around Algoa Bay, at the eastern end of the species' range, is caramel with darker brown blotches. The gills are white with variable amounts of caramel to dark brown in streaks and blotches. The foot may be transparent with darker blotches. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and as variably coloured as the body.
taxon_text_3_8125:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape, 1–40 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8126: Found on temperate reefs, relatively common at the eastern end of its range and relatively rare in False Bay.
taxon_text_6_8128: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8129: As the name suggests, this species is quite variable in appearance, however the colour morph that exhibits dark blotches can be confused with the Chocolate-chip true dorid, Aphelodoris sp.1, but is distinguished by its rough body texture and the higher proportion of dark blotches.
taxon_text_8_8130:

taxon_text_1_8132: A small to medium-sized, beige-coloured cladobranch covered with many broken longitudinal white ridges. The head has an oral veil with a white margin. The rhinophores are short, white and set close together at their bases. The notum is pale to beige-coloured and may be darker at the centre. The notum has an indistinct white marginal band. The gills are located between the mantle and the foot. The foot is also beige with an indistinct white marginal band.
taxon_text_3_8134:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to the Eastern Cape, endemic, 10–80 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8135: This species has been found in deep water trawls but it is also seen in shallow water on sand. Individuals have been observed burrowing.
taxon_text_5_8136: The species is thought to feed on sea pens.
taxon_text_6_8137: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8138: Armina gilchristi can be confused with the Pink-and-white pinstripe, Dermatobranchus albineus, but is distinguished by its broken longitudinal ridges; and also with the Brown-patched pinstripe, Dermatobranchus arminus, but is distinguishable by its lack of brown patches.
taxon_text_8_8139:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 109).

taxon_text_9_8140: Armina sp.7 NSSI, Armina sp.6 NSSI2, Armina sp. GZ, FGMA and Two Oceans, Pierre's armina, Striped sand slug.
taxon_text_1_8141: A large, black cladobranch with alternating broad and narrow cream to yellow stripes. The head has a black oral veil with a frilled yellow margin. The rhinophores are black, have pale to peach-coloured tips, and a white to pale blue patch between them. The stripes on the notum may merge or split. The notum has a yellow margin The gills are located between the mantle and the foot. The foot is peach-coloured with a yellow margin.
taxon_text_3_8143:
Global: South Africa, Mozambique, western Pacific.

Local/Regional: False Bay, 2 – 30m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8144: This species is usually found on sand or in seagrass fields. It has a very broad distribution, possibly because of the broad distribution of its prey species, but its occasional presence in False Bay may simply be due to warm water pulse events.
taxon_text_5_8145: The species feeds on the Radial sea pen, Actinoptylum molle.
taxon_text_6_8146: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8147: This species can be confused with several warm-water species of Armina, but so far it is the only warm-water Armina to have been observed in False Bay. It is distinguished from other tropical species by the head patch immediately behind and between the rhinophores.

taxon_text_1_8150: A medium- to large-sized white-bodied cladobranch densely covered with variably-coloured lateral appendages. The rhinophores have smooth bases and perfoliate tips, and are separated by a low caruncle (rhinophoral crest) with ridged edges. There are four distinct colour morphs: the blue gasflame has yellow-tipped rhinophores and blue-tipped yellow lateral appendages that may have pale bases; the orange gasflame has orange-tipped rhinophores and lateral appendages; the salmon gasflame has pale rhinophores and pale-tipped lateral appendages with dark bases, dark bases sometimes with a yellowish upper band; and the black gasflame has blue-tipped yellow rhinophores and dark, blue-tipped lateral appendages. All colour morphs have a tapered transparent or pale foot with a central opaque white stripe. Mostly white juveniles can sometimes be found. Individuals at the eastern end of the range tend to have a pinkish tinge to their coloration.
taxon_text_3_8152:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to Wild Coast, intertidal to 93 m.
taxon_text_4_8153: A relatively common species, usually found on temperate reefs crawling over sponges, crinoids, bryozoans etc. Eggs are often laid in a tangle on the Multicoloured sea fan (Melithaea rubra). This species is always a highlight for divers as it has a striking appearance.
taxon_text_6_8155: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is narrow, convoluted and white, and is often laid around sea fans or other projecting structures.
taxon_text_7_8156: The salmon morph of B. nakaza can be confused with the two species of Silvertip flame, Antiopella capensis and Antiopella longidentata, but otherwise the species is unmistakable. It is distinguished from the silvertips by the low caruncle and by the gradual transition in colour between the bases and tips of the lateral appendages.

taxon_text_9_8158: Aclesia africana Engel, 1926: unaccepted > superseded combination; Bursatella leachii africana (Engel, 1926): unaccepted > superseded combination. Identified as Notarchus (Bursatella) leachi in Day, 1969.
taxon_text_1_8159: A large, dark-bodied sea hare, densely covered with short, wool-like tubercles. The head has rolled rhinophores with a pair of black eye spots below them. The oral tentacles are widely separated. The body may be densely spotted in white or brown, as can the tubercles. The tubercles may be white, cream, grey or pink. The juveniles usually have less dense tubercles and dark-centred blue spots with dark rims and golden haloes.
taxon_text_3_8161:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast, False Bay, Knysna Lagoon, Keurboomstrand Lagoon, intertidal to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_8162: This species is sporadically common and found in sandy or muddy areas among seaweeds. In the eastern ranges of its distribution, they can be seen in great numbers, especially in estuaries during spring months.
taxon_text_5_8163: This species feeds by taking in and digesting any plant or algal matter.
taxon_text_6_8164: This species is hermaphroditic. They form dense breeding aggregations and sometimes rings of mating individuals. The egg ribbon is a tangled string of pale green eggs.
taxon_text_7_8165: The species can be confused with the Tropical shaggy sea hare, Bursatella leachii, but is distinguished by its dense covering of short tasselled tubercles in adults and the dark centres of the blue spots in juveniles.

taxon_text_1_8168: A medium-sized, creamy white aeolid with yellow-tipped pale purply-blue cerata. The head is translucent white and has a translucent yellow central patch. The oral tentacles are pale with orange bands and opaque white-speckled pale tips. The rhinophores are perfoliate, and have pale bases, orange central bands and opaque white tips. The cerata have darker purple at their bases and may have opaque white speckling. The foot is translucent and slender with an opaque white central stripe. This species (like many other nudibranchs in South Africa) remains undescribed with much left to discover on these fascinating animals.
taxon_text_3_8170:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, 10–20m.
taxon_text_6_8173: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon contains distinct white eggs in a globular mass.
taxon_text_7_8174: The perfoliate rhinophores, long orange-banded oral tentacles and yellow-tipped cerata are distinctive.

taxon_text_9_8185: Previously misidentified as the European species, Tritonia nilsodhneri, Duvaucelia sp., whipfan nudibranch.
taxon_text_1_8186: A small to medium-sized cladobranch, peach- to pale-coloured. The rhinophores have a central crown of papillae surrounding a longer single stalk. The rhinophoral sheaths are flared at the rims. The notum is covered with paler, opaque low tubercles of varying sizes. There are also several paired secondary gills on the notum.
taxon_text_3_8188:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay, 2–36 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8189: This species is usually found on reefs, almost always on the Whip fan Eunicella albicans, but occasionally also on other sea fans.
taxon_text_5_8190: The species preys on the Whip fan, Eunicella albicans.
taxon_text_6_8191: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy, narrow peach-coloured spiral coil laid around the prey sea fan.
taxon_text_7_8192: This species can be confused with the Purple soft coral lacedragon, Marionia sp.7, but is distinguished by its low tubercles.

taxon_text_1_8195: A medium- to large-sized tall-bodied caramel-, yellow- or purple-coloured dorid with scattered large purple spots surrounded by diffuse haloes. The rhinophores are pale. The notum may have patches of pink, peach or pale purple. The margin of the notum has a narrow white band. The gills are pale and may have purple spots. The foot matches the colour of the notum, though it is usually more pale, and has purple spots surrounded by diffuse paler haloes.
taxon_text_3_8197:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay, 10–40m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8198: On subtidal rocky reefs, frequently observed on the Stellar red sponge (Crambe acuata), several species of coralline red algae and among Red-chested sea cucumbers (Hemiocnus insolens).
taxon_text_6_8200: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a tall collar of large orange eggs laid in an obvious zigzag pattern within the collar (see image).
taxon_text_7_8201: The large purple spots are diagnostic, though the paler morph may be confused with the Red-spotted rainbow dorid (Goniobranchus heatherae), but can be distinguished by the colour of the spots dorsally, which are purple in C. Ingozi and red in G. heatherae.

taxon_text_1_8213: A tiny, cream-coloured, round-bodied dorid. Cryptically coloured to match the Rustic lace bryozoan (Membranipora rustica) on which it feeds. The head is cream-coloured with camouflage patterning. The rhinophores are cream-coloured. The notum is slightly humped, cream-coloured and patterned in a network of cream and brown. The gills are white with orange to yellow edging and blotches. The posterior end is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8215:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, 1–15m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8216: Individuals of Corambe sp. are exclusively found on the Rustic lace bryozoan (Membranipora rustica), which itself can usually be found growing on fronds of the Sea bamboo (Ecklonia maxima). These species are exceptionally cryptic and the patterning of the nudibranch matches that of the bryozoan it lives and feeds on.
taxon_text_5_8217: The species preys on the Rustic lace bryozoan, Membranipora rustica.
taxon_text_6_8218: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat white spiral.
taxon_text_7_8219: This tiny species is distinctive when found, but is hard to spot because of its small size and cryptic coloration.
taxon_text_8_8220:

taxon_text_1_8231: A small, translucent, white-bodied aeolid with opaque white-tipped red cerata. The head is translucent white with two orange patches. The oral tentacles are smooth, translucent white, and may have opaque white speckling towards the tips. The rhinophores are smooth, translucent white and with opaque white speckling towards the tips. The cerata are arranged in clusters and may also be brownish. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and has a central opaque white stripe.
taxon_text_3_8233:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 30m.
taxon_text_5_8235: This species feeds on hydroids, particularly those of the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_6_8236: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a coil of distinct white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8237: The species can be confused with several species of Cratena, but is distinguished by the two orange patches on the head, the white rhinophores and oral tentacles, as well as the rounded foot corners. It can also be confused with white morphs of the gorgeous triple-tooth, Flabellina funeka, but is distinguished by the orange head patches and smooth rhinophores.
