taxon_text_1_8204:
Spiders as a group are easily identified by having the body divided into just two sections – an anterior prosoma (equivalent to a fused head and thorax) and a posterior opisthosoma or abdomen. The prosoma bears a pair of poison fangs, a pair of leg-like feelers called pedipalps and four pairs of long jointed legs. Another characteristic feature is the presence of silk glands in the abdomen. Although diverse and abundant in almost all terrestrial environments, spiders are rare in marine habitats, a few occurring in the rocky intertidal and others in and above the driftline on sandy beaches.

Wolf spiders (Family Lycosidae) are free-running, ground-living spiders. They have a characteristic eye pattern with two large posterior eyes high on the head, below which are four smaller anterior eyes. Sand-dwelling species are typically pale in colour. This species appears to be an undescribed member of the genus Ocyale and is off-white with a grey dorsal patch around the eyes and another larger patch dorsally on the abdomen. The anterior eyes are relatively large and arranged into a rectangle. No previous spiders of this genus have been reported from temperate parts of South Africa, although O. ghost is known from a sandy beach around a freshwater lake in Madagascar and O. guttata from inland habitats from Tanzania southwards to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_3_8206:
Global: Unknown, but probably endemic.

Local/Regional: So far only recorded from the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_8207: Found above the high water mark on sandy beaches and on coastal dunes where it buries in the sand, emerging to hunt for prey. Leaves characteristic digging marks that consists of a central burrow and small roundish balls of sand left in a circular pattern around the central whole.
taxon_text_5_8208: Details unknown, but all wolf spiders are predatory, so probably feeds on beach-dwelling insects such as kelp flies, as well as possibly beach hoppers (Amphipoda), which are abundant in this habitat.
taxon_text_6_8209: Wolf spiders have a characteristic mode of reproduction in which the female secures her eggs into a large ball-like mass which she carries around attached to the spinnerets on her abdomen. Once the spiderlings hatch out, they climb onto the female’s back and are carried around by her for several days before becoming independent.
taxon_text_7_8210: No similar-looking pale wolf spiders are known from the seashore in this region and this is most likely an undescribed species.
taxon_text_8_8211:
Alderweireldt, M (1996). A taxonomic revision of the genus Ocyale Audouin, 1826 in Africa (Araneae: Lycosidae). Journal of Natural History, 30(9), 1349-1365.

Jocque, M, Wellens, S, Andrianarivosoa, JD, Rakotondraparany, F & Jocqué, R (2017). A new species of Ocyale (Araneae, Lycosidae) from Madagascar, with first observations on the biology of a representative in the genus. European Journal of Taxonomy, (355), 1-13.
taxon_text_1_7952: Due to its morphological similarity to brown algae it is placed within that group, even though it is a red algae. Forms flat, leathery, fan-like lobes resembling a bracket fungus. Lobes attached by a holdfast, but edges free of the substratum. Upper surface dark purplish-red, sometimes tinged with green, but lower surface off-white. Margins of lobes variously incised and surface smooth, but marked with concentric growth rings.
taxon_text_2_7953: Colonies up to about 120 mm across with individual lobes typically about 80 mm long and 30 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_7954:
Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate waters of Indo-Pacific. Also reported from Angola.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula eastwards to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_7955: Common on rocks in deep pools and gullies and to a depth of about 30 m. Especially under overhangs and in caves.
taxon_text_6_7957: Tertasporangia in groups on raised bumps on dorsal surface.
taxon_text_7_7958: Fairly unmistakable. Some other species, such as Lobophora variegata and Exallosaurus harveyanus form similar but thinner flat fan-like lobes, but these are brown algae, not red algae.
taxon_text_8_7959:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024. (As Peyssonniella capensis).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 283 as Peyssonniella capensis).
taxon_text_1_8177: A small pale- to pinkish-bodied aeolid with black-dotted white-tipped red cerata. The black dot is just below the white tips. The head is pale or pinkish and may have opaque white patches extending towards the oral tentacles. The oral tentacles have orange bases and pale or white tips with opaque white speckling. The rhinophores are perfoliate and orange with white tips. The foot is translucent, slender and has a central opaque white stripe. This species (like many other nudibranchs in South Africa) remains undescribed with much left to discover on these fascinating animals.
taxon_text_3_8179:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay, 5–15m.
taxon_text_4_8180: Found on temperate reefs, usually on hydroids or seaweed.
taxon_text_5_8181: This species feeds on small hydroids that grow on other hydroids or on seaweed.
taxon_text_6_8182: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon consists of distinct white or yellow eggs in a globular mass.
taxon_text_7_8183: The species can be confused with the Gorgeous triple-tooth, Flabellina funeka, but is distinguished by the dark spot on the cerata and its perfoliate rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8184:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 122).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 596, 791).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 152).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 91).
taxon_text_1_8222: A small, translucent, white-bodied aeolid with opaque white-tipped orange to red translucent cerata. The cerata have a darker band below their tips. The head is translucent white with two orange patches. The oral tentacles are smooth, translucent white, may be opaque white and may have opaque white speckling towards the tips. The rhinophores are smooth, orange, and are more vividly orange towards the tips. The cerata are arranged in an anterior arch followed by posterior rows. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and has a central opaque white stripe. Juveniles may lack the darker band below the ceratal tips, particularly at the eastern end of the range. Pale variants are sometimes seen.
taxon_text_3_8224:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to central KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to 30 m.
taxon_text_5_8226: This species probably feeds on hydroids, and has been observed feeding on dorid eggs and possibly also those of Antiopella spp.
taxon_text_6_8227: This species is hermaphroditic. The eggs are laid in a messy narrow white ribbon.
taxon_text_7_8228: The species can be confused with several species of Cratena, but is distinguished by the orange rhinophores and pale oral tentacles, as well as the tentacular foot corners and the darker bands below the ceratal tips where present.
taxon_text_8_8229:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 126).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 618, 803).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 97).
taxon_text_1_8240:
Numerous species of this family occur in the warmer waters along the east coast of south Africa, but this is one of very few which extend to the Western Cape.

A robust fish with a large mouth and eye and a brown body that fades to paler golden-yellow ventrally and is speckled with numerous white spots and blotches. The dark-brown dorsal, anal and tail fins often have white edges.
taxon_text_2_8241: Reaches up to 1.2 m cm total length, but fish found in the Western Cape are typically much smaller at no more than about 50 cm.
taxon_text_3_8242:
Global: Widespread in Europe and the Mediterranean, along the Atlantic coast of South America and down the west coast of Africa to Angola, but absent in Namibia and along the west coast of South Africa, re-appearing from Cape Point eastwards.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_8243: Found on rocky reefs from the shore to at least 200 m depth. Younger fish generally more inshore than larger ones and juveniles may occur in rock pools. Tend to be resident at single sites, which makes them vulnerable to overfishing. May live up to 50 years.
taxon_text_5_8244: Generalist predator feeding on larger bottom-dwelling invertebrates, such as crabs and octopus, as well as fish. The proportion of fish in the diet increases in larger individuals.
taxon_text_6_8245: First mature as females at an age of 6-8 and a body length of about 44-53 cm, then change sex to become males at age 15-17 years and a length of 80-87 cm. Spawn in spring and summer.
taxon_text_7_8246: The large body size, big mouth and colour pattern are fairly distinctive and this is the only rockcod found in the cooler waters off the Western Cape.
taxon_text_8_8247:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 280).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 169).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 62).
taxon_text_9_8248: Clinus superciliosus (part) - this is one of several recently described species within the C. superciliosus complex, thus any biological information (on diet, reproduction, etc) published prior to 2012 refers to the whole group and not to any one of the six component species now recognized.
taxon_text_1_8249:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are smallish, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This species has 38 spines and 8 rays in the dorsal fin, of which the first 3 spines are raised into a tall crest, but with only a shallow notch between the 3rd and 4th spines. First 6 spines also have a small filament at their tip. Cirrus above eye a small, narrow stalk ending in a few thin, tapering branches.

Colour primarily formed of about 5 longitudinal brown or green broken stripes consisting of alternating light and dark blocks. Head above middle of eye dark with radiating broken stripes, but below eye head characteristically pale yellow or white with a diagonal darker stripe.
taxon_text_2_8250: The single measured specimen reported was 13 cm total length, but this cannot be taken as a maximum length, which can only be established once more specimens are measured.
taxon_text_3_8251:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Betty’s Bay.
taxon_text_4_8252:
Very little is known about this species and the original description and later published accounts are based on just a single specimen captured at Betty’s bay (hence the species name, which refers to the exasperation of the researchers in being unable to find more specimens!)

Recently found to be fairly common in False Bay but shy and difficult to photograph.
taxon_text_5_8253: Unknown for this species but other similar clinids feed on a variety of small invertebrates, mainly crustaceans, molluscs and polychaetes.
taxon_text_6_8254: (as assessed for ‘C. superciliosus’ before splitting species) Females reach sexual maturity between about 110-120 mm and males between 50-60 mm, although males eventually grow much larger than females and there appears to be a dominance hierarchy based on male size (so large males probably monopolise females). Between 20-144 live young are born per brood at an average length of 20 mm.
taxon_text_7_8255: One of several closely-related species in the C. superciliosus complex, but recognised by the combination of tall crest on dorsal fin, small slender cirrus above eye and colour pattern, particularly the pale lower section of head.
taxon_text_8_8256:
Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 393).

Holleman, W, Von Der Heyden, S & Zsilavecz, G (2012). Delineating the fishes of the Clinus superciliosus species complex in southern African waters (Blennioidei: Clinidae: Clinini), with the validation of Clinus arborescens Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908 and Clinus ornatus Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908, and with descriptions of two new species. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 166(4), 827-853.
taxon_text_1_8258:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This slender, laterally compressed species has an elongate head, a small mouth and a long, slender peduncle to the small tail. The dorsal fin has 29-32 spines and 7-8 rays. The first three spines are raised into a distinct crest, but there is no notch in the membrane jointing the third and fourth spines.

The colour seems to be variable, perhaps depending on both size and the algal species on which the specimen is living.  Typically, the body is green with longitudinal darker green, yellow or iridescent stripes. The specimen shown here also has a prominent yellow nose-stipe.
taxon_text_3_8260:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from False Bay to Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_8261: This is a little known species with a very restricted distribution and has seldom been photographed alive. It appears to be associated mainly with kelps and is often seen along the fronds in the kelp canopy and in one case living inside a kelp stipe. Very little else is know about its biology.
taxon_text_5_8262: Details unknown, but other small-mouthed clinids feeds mainly on small crustaceans such as amphipods and isopods, as well as polychaete worms and small molluscs.
taxon_text_6_8263: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_8264: There are several similar and very easily confused species within this genus, although some can be distinguished by habitat (for example P. smalei occurs only on gravel bottoms), or are not found in the Western Cape (P. myae, P. mentalis, P laurentii).  The Bluespot klipfish C. caeruleopunctatus is particularly similar in both appearance and habitat, but has a notch between dorsal spines 3 and 4 and has characteristic round blue spots on the cheeks (after which the name is derived), while the very similar Peacock klipfish P. pavo has electric blue lines behind the eyes.
taxon_text_8_8265:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 390).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 402).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 767).
taxon_text_9_8266: Clinus pavo (split off from this species, which remain a valid species and has its own page on this site)
taxon_text_1_8267:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This small, slender and only recently described species has a dorsal fin with 29-33 spines and 1-3 rays. The first 3 spines are raised into a pronounced dorsal crest and there is a distinct notch after the third spine – the membrane between the third and fourth spine being transparent (making it look even deeper than it is). The head is fairly pointed and there are no cirri above the eyes.

Colour is fairly variable and mottled, but there are 6 vertical brown, pink or red bars on sides of the body and 6 others on the dorsal surface and extending onto the dorsal fin that are offset from those on the sides. The most distinctive features are the bright electric blue dots behind the eyes and also along the base of the dorsal fine and sides of the body, after which the species in named. The translucent pectoral fins usually have yellow tips.
taxon_text_3_8269:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Robben Island to Tsitsikamma.
taxon_text_4_8270: Found on shallow rocky reefs from about 6-30 m depth and strongly associated with various algae, or colonial animals such as hydroids or sea-fans, amongst which they nestle. Well camouflaged and colour varies depending on that of the host substrate. Placid and tend to remain still and rely on concealment to escape predators.
taxon_text_5_8271: Species-specific details unknown but a small-mouthed species that probably feeds on smaller invertebrates
taxon_text_6_8272: Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
taxon_text_7_8273: Similar to Peacock clinid P. pavo but fairly easily recognised by the characteristic blue spots (not lines) behind head and on sides.
taxon_text_8_8274:
Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 391).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 401).

taxon_text_1_8276: A small orange-bodied dorid with distinct black-tipped papillae. The rhinophores are orange and may have black tips or streaks. The anterior margin of the head has short black papillae. The papillae are small, pointed and branched; they may be orange with black tips. The gills are orange and may have black tips. The posterior end of the foot is orange, tapered, and with black papillae.
taxon_text_3_8278:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, 4 – 27 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8279: Found on rocky reefs where it is mostly observed on the Antlered false-coral bryozoan Chaperiopsis multifida upon which it feeds.
taxon_text_5_8280: Feeds on bryozoans where it scrapes off zooids using their rasping radula.
taxon_text_6_8281: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat orange spiral of several turns and has also been observed to be laid on C. multifida on which it lives.
taxon_text_7_8282: This species can be confused with the White-gilled peppercorn forked dorid, Crimora lutea, but is distinguished by its orange gills. Crimora lutea has also not been found in the region.
taxon_text_8_8283:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 95).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 216, 804).
taxon_text_1_8501: A small to medium-sized aeolid with blue- and orange-banded cerata. The head is broad with a central orange patch, bordered with broad stripes of opaque white or blue extending into the oral tentacles. The oral tentacles are broad and bordered by orange. They have opaque white patches at their bases, a broad orange central band and yellow tips. The rhinophores are finely ringed, and separated by a white patch. Their bases are orange, shading to translucent white, then an orange band and pale yellow tips. The notum is pale with orange patches and opaque white or blue stripes. The cerata have alternating dark blue-purple, vivid orange and bright blue bands; their tips are pale yellow. The foot is translucent with a central opaque white stripe.
taxon_text_3_8503:
Global: Introduced in international harbours.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 15 m.
taxon_text_4_8504: This species can be found on sand (even estuaries), reefs, in kelp and green seaweed beds.
taxon_text_5_8505: This aeolid has a rather varied diet, and feeds on other heterobranchs and the Striped anemone, Anthothoe stimpsoni. It has also been observed feeding on sea cucumbers.
taxon_text_6_8506: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is an untidy white zigzag spiral mass.
taxon_text_7_8507: The species can be confused with the tropical four-coloured aeolid, Godiva rachelae, but is distinguished by its orange head and multiple vivid orange ceratal bands.
taxon_text_8_8508:

taxon_text_9_8284: Dendrodoris kalkensis (Barnard, 1927) unaccepted; Doriopsis caesia Bergh, 1907, unaccepted (superseded combination); Doris kalkensis Barnard, 1927 unaccepted  (junior subjective synonym)
taxon_text_1_8285: A medium- to large-sized smooth-bodied dorid. The body coloration varies between pale to cream to yellow with variable blue or pink speckling. The rhinophores are darker than the speckling on the body and have pale tips. The body coloration is usually blue-speckled at the western end of the range, while individuals with cream or yellow coloration and pink speckling are more common towards the eastern end of the range. Orange-bodied variants are occasionally seen. The margin of the notum is wavy and pale with scattered patches of blue spots. The gills are luxuriant and cream-coloured with varying amounts of blue speckling.
taxon_text_3_8287:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to the Wild Coast, intertidal to 25 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8288: This variably coloured dorid can usually be found on rocky or sandy reefs and are pretty easy to spot due to their large size and bright colouration.
taxon_text_6_8290: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a large wavy rosette of small yellow eggs.
taxon_text_7_8291: The mottled coloration, frilly margin and luxuriant gills are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8292:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 212).

taxon_text_9_8293: Dermatobranchus sp.1 Gosliner 1987, GZ, and FGMA, wide-ridged nudibranch, white-ridged nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8294: A tiny to small pale- to pink-bodied cladobranch with several distinct opaque white or pink longitudinal ridges. The head has a smooth oral veil with a white anterior margin. The rhinophores are white or pale. Some of the ridges may be interrupted, or may split or merge. There is a marginal ridge that extends back from the head. The foot is smooth, pale or pink.
taxon_text_3_8296:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Central West Coast to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 39 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8297: This species is usually found on reef walls.
taxon_text_5_8298: The species feeds on the Sunburst soft coral, Malacacanthus capensis, and possibly other species of soft coral.
taxon_text_6_8299: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8300: This species can be confused with the Brown-patched pinstripe, Dermatobranchus arminus, but is distinguished by its coloration and small size.
taxon_text_8_8301:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 110).

taxon_text_1_8303:
Previously included within the family Scorpaenidae and still listed under that family name in same accounts. However, that family has now been divided into several smaller families.

Very small and cryptic, reaching a length of only about 5 cm. Body stubby and rough-skinned with a large, wrinkled head and prominent dorsal fin which bears 14-15 venomous spines and 5-6 soft rays. Pectoral fins large and pale, held out laterally. Body colour mottles orange and brown, with a distinctive broad white band in front of the tail.
taxon_text_3_8305:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_8306: A fairly common species, but seldom seen because of its very small size and cryptic colouration. Usually solitary or in small groups resting among benthic invertebrates and seaweeds and seen only when disturbed and swim and short distance before settling again. Spines on dorsal fin extremely venomous and inflict a very painful sting (hence common name of family - waspfish). Should not be touched. Usually on deeper reefs and recorded to at least 110 m depth.
taxon_text_5_8307: Details unknown but other waspfish predatory on small invertebrates.
taxon_text_7_8309: Similar to scorpionfish, but much smaller. Chubbier than the more slender klipfishes and only superficially similar for example to the Bull klipfish, Clinus taurus; deeply notched dorsal fin with protruding venomous spines obvious separation character. Broad white band in front of the tail in this species is a diagnostic feature.
taxon_text_8_8310:

taxon_text_1_8312:
This genus was previously placed within the family Olividae - the Olive shells – but has been separated into one of five families within what is now the Superfamily Olivoidea. As a group they are characterized by having elongate, cylindrical shells with a smooth, glossy surface and an elongated aperture lacking pleats on the inner lip.

This species has a short spire and a wide aperture and is typically cream to light brown in colour with two brown bands around the shell, one near to anterior end and one near the base of the final whorl.
taxon_text_3_8314:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_8315: Dead shells are fairly commonly found along the driftline but live specimens are more rarely encountered and little is known about their habits. Other members of the family are typically nocturnal and hide in crevices or burrow into the sand during the day.
taxon_text_5_8316: Details unknown for this species, but related species can be predatory on small invertebrates, or graze on organic debris or algae.
taxon_text_6_8317: In this group there are separate male and female individuals and sperm and eggs are released into the water, where they develop into planktonic larvae which drift on the ocean currents until they metamorphose into the adult form and settle onto the substratum.
taxon_text_7_8318: The group is mostly sub-tropical and this is one of few species extending into temperate waters. The combination of smooth shiny shell, short spire, long aperture and colour pattern are fairly diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8319:
Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 112).

Kilburn, RN (1993). Notes on some South African Ancillinae with descriptions of five new species of Amalda (Mollusca: Gastropoda: Olividae). Annals of the Natal Museum, 34(2), 369-389.

Smith, EA (1906). On South African marine Mollusca, with descriptions of new species. Annals of the Natal Government Museum, 1, 19-71, pls. 7-8.
taxon_text_1_8321:
As the name implies flatworms have flat, leaflike bodies and either glide around on a bed of cilia or, in larger species, by using ripples of muscular contraction that pass along the body. Most marine species belong to the Order Polyclada, which are generally fairly-large (10-40 mm) and broad and have a many-branched gut. Triclads, also known as planarians, are smaller (<10 mm) with a longer, narrower body shape and a 3-branched gut. The group is relatively uncommon in marine habitats, although diverse in freshwater and in damp terrestrial habitats.

This species has an elongate skittle-shaped body tapering towards a pointed head. The tip of the head is black and the rest of the body decorated with longitudinal brown and white bands, with two pronounced transverse white bands, one immediately behind the head and the other midway along the body. There is a pair of black eyes on the head, but these can be difficult to distinguish against the striped body pattern.
taxon_text_3_8323:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from the Cape Peninsula and vicinity.
taxon_text_4_8324: Normally found creeping on the undersides of boulders in the intertidal zone, where they can be extremely common, numbering in hundreds under an individual rock. Seem to prefer living in shallow pools high in the intertidal in the Littorina zone.
taxon_text_5_8325: The feeding organ of flatworms is a tubular proboscis on the underside and this leads into a blind-ending gut with no anus. The diet of this species is unknown, but most freshwater planarians feed either on small invertebrates of scavenge dead or dying organisms.
taxon_text_6_8326: Triclads are hermaphrodite but can reproduce both asexually and sexually. Asexual reproduction involves fission, after which each section regenerates the missing body parts. This may take place naturally or following injury. In sexual reproduction two individuals exchange sperm and the fertilized eggs develop inside the body before being shed in capsules or cocoons which hatch directly into fully formed juveniles. The brown spheres in the image provided are probably the egg cases.
taxon_text_7_8327: This is the only common marine triclad we have observed in the region and can be distinguished from local polyclads by the much more elongate body shape. It is also fairy easily recognised by the brown and white longitudinal and transverse bands on the body but colour appears to be variable and differs in different published accounts.
taxon_text_8_8328:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 60 as skittleworm).

Li, WX, Sluys, R, Vila-Farré, M, Chen, JJ, Yang, Y, Li, SF & Wang, AT (2019). A new continent in the geographic distribution of the genus Oregoniplana (Platyhelminthes: Tricladida: Maricola), its rediscovery in South Africa and its molecular phylogenetic position. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 187(1), 82-99.

Sluys, R (1989). A monograph of the marine triclads. Rotterdam & Brookfield: Balkema.
taxon_text_1_8330: Body firm and tough, quadrangular in cross-section with bottom surface somewhat flattened. Colour fairly uniform grey. Tube feet arranged in five fairly-indistinct bands, with 2-3 rows in each dorsal band and 2-4 rows in each ventral band. Tentacles 10, pale and transparent, each of same length and with fairly-short tree-like (dentritic) branching, the terminal branches ending in small swellings.
taxon_text_2_8331: Body length typically about 80 mm, excluding tentacles (some sources say max 50 mm).
taxon_text_3_8332:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert‘s Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_8333: A common species, but often found mixed with the Cask sea cucumber Pentacta doliolum, with which it is often confused. Typically found buried in course sediments composed of pebbles, broken shells etc. with the tentacles extended up into the water column, or among other sedentary invertebrates on reefs. A suspension feeder.
taxon_text_5_8334: Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again. The gut contents consist of a mix of organic particles including unicellular algae, pieces of algae, diatoms, sponge spicules, etc.
taxon_text_6_8335: No details for this species, but in most sea cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.
taxon_text_7_8336: Often confused with Pentacta doliolum with which if occurs in mixed aggregations. The two species are similar in size and shape, but P. doliolum is dark purple to black (especially dark in locations exposed to bright sunlight) and has a distinctly lighter flattened sole. (The main taxonomic feature separating the species is in fact the microscopic shapes of the ossicles in the body wall, which form round cup-like baskets and 4-holed buttons in this species).
taxon_text_8_8337:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 115).
taxon_text_9_8338: Misidentified as Doriopsilla miniata and Doriopsilla areolata. Scribbled nudibranch.
taxon_text_1_8339: A small to medium-sized orange-bodied dorid with irregular opaque white lines. The rhinophores are darker orange. The notum may have a central brown patch. The gills are orange. The posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8341:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 40 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8342: Usually found on or near reefs, especially on sponges and crustose coralline algae.
taxon_text_5_8343: Feeds on sponges (on which they are often observed).
taxon_text_6_8344: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8345: The irregular white lines on the dorsal surface are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8346:

taxon_text_9_8347: Dendrodoris capensis (Bergh, 1907): unaccepted, tan dorid, white-spotted nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8348: A small white, cream, peach or light brown dorid with a narrow opaque white margin of minute spots. The rhinophores are cream-coloured. The notum is covered with small white tubercles. The gills match the colour of the notum. The foot is pale and rounded.
taxon_text_3_8350:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay, Wild side of Algoa Bay, 5–40 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8351: Usually found in deeper water and offshore, often associated with red sponges.
taxon_text_6_8353: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is an upright translucent collar of several turns with large pale yellow eggs. The size of the eggs suggests a shortened larval stage or possibly direct development to the adult form.
taxon_text_7_8354: The absence of darker spots and the presence of small tubercles and the narrow opaque white margin are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8355:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 90).

taxon_text_1_8357: A small, rough-bodied pale pinkish dorid, with purple spots and scattered opaque white spots that may be in clusters. The head is covered with tubercles and the rhinophores are pinkish with opaque white flecks. The notum is covered with tubercles, and the tubercles are often covered with purple and opaque white spots. The notum has an indistinct hourglass-shaped reddish blotch. The gills are apricot-coloured. The posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8359:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay, 10–30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8360: Found on sand as well as vertical reef walls.
taxon_text_6_8362: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8363: This species can be confused with several undescribed species of Doris, but is distinguished by the hourglass-shaped blotch and scattered purple and opaque white spots. It is similar to Doris immonda from the western Pacific, but has a less extensive mid-dorsal white patch.
taxon_text_8_8364:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 86).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 102).
taxon_text_1_8366: A tiny to small white-bodied cladobranch with lateral appendages covered with elongate red- to pink-tipped spherical tubercles. The rhinophores are smooth, translucent, and have opaque white speckling towards the tips. The rhinophoral sheaths are flared, and may have opaque white speckling, and pink spots on their rims. The head is white. The centre of the notum has pink or red spots and stripes.
taxon_text_3_8368:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula, intertidal to 15 m.
taxon_text_4_8369: This attractive cladobranch is often found on sponges and bryozoans.
taxon_text_6_8371: The species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8372: This species can be confused with several species of Doto, but it is distinguished by its pink- to red-tipped lateral appendages. It is distinguished from the Crowned grapedragon, Doto coronata, by its pale head and more elongated tubercles.
taxon_text_8_8373: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 496).
taxon_text_9_8374: Doris pinnatifida Montagu, 1804: unaccepted; Doto armoricana Hesse, 1872: unaccepted (synonym); Doto nigra Eliot, 1910: unaccepted; Doto pinnatifida var. nigra Eliot, 1910: unaccepted (synonym); Doto pinnatifida var. papillifera Eliot, 1910: unaccepted; Feathered doto.
taxon_text_1_8375: A tiny to small creamy-bodied cladobranch with lateral appendages covered with black- or dark purple-tipped conical tubercles. The rhinophores are smooth, translucent, and have opaque white speckling towards the tips. The rhinophoral sheaths are flared, and may have opaque white speckling, and pink spots on their rims. The centre of the notum seldom has pink or red spots and stripes. A pale morph exists that has pale-tipped conical tubercles.
taxon_text_3_8377:
Global: North-eastern Atlantic, South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Knysna Lagoon, intertidal to 30 m.
taxon_text_4_8378: Observed on shallow reefs, often found on hydroids and bryozoans.
taxon_text_6_8380: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg mass is a white zigzag ribbon, often laid on hydroid colonies.
taxon_text_7_8381: This species can be confused with several species of Doto, but it is distinguished by its conical black- to dark-purple-tipped lateral appendages where present and also by the symmetrical tiered arrangement of spots on the lateral appendages.
taxon_text_8_8382:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 106).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 498, 789).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 144).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 70).
taxon_text_9_8383: Doris coronata Gmelin, 1791: unaccepted (original combination); Doto costae Trinchese, 1881: unaccepted (dubious synonym); Doto forbesii Deshayes, 1853: unaccepted; Doto splendida Trinchese, 1881: unaccepted (dubious synonym); Crowned doto
taxon_text_1_8384: A tiny to small white-bodied cladobranch with lateral appendages covered with numerous short red- to pink-tipped spherical tubercles. The rhinophores are smooth, translucent, and have opaque white speckling towards the tips. The rhinophoral sheaths are cylindrical or flared, and may have opaque white speckling, and pink spots on their rims. The head is white with dark pink or red speckling. The centre of the notum has pink or red spots and stripes.
taxon_text_3_8386:
Global: North Atlantic, South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to the Knysna Lagoon, intertidal to 28 m.
taxon_text_4_8387: Seldomly seen due to its small size, but frequently observed on sponges.
taxon_text_6_8389: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg mass is a white zigzag ribbon, often laid on hydroid colonies.
taxon_text_7_8390: This species can be confused with several species of Doto, but it is distinguished by its pink- to red-tipped lateral appendages. It is distinguished from the African crowned grapedragon, Doto africoronata, by the dark spots or streaks on its head and the shorter, more numerous tubercles on its lateral appendages.
taxon_text_8_8391:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 106).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 496).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 144).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 69).
taxon_text_1_8393: A tiny orange-bodied cladobranch with orange lateral appendages covered with opaque white and dark-tipped tubercles. The rhinophores are smooth, orange, and have opaque white speckling. The rhinophoral sheaths are flared, and have dark blotches and opaque white speckling. The oral veil has a white-speckled anterior margin and several opaque white blotches with dark spots. The notum has a sparse scattering of dark spots.
taxon_text_3_8395:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay, 15–24 m.
taxon_text_4_8396: This rarely seen undescribed species is usually found on hydroids.
taxon_text_5_8397: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8398: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is white, in a series of zigzag folds.
taxon_text_7_8399: This species can be confused with several species of Doto, but it is distinguished by the orange coloration and the opaque white and dark-tipped tubercles on the lateral appendages.
taxon_text_8_8400: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 498).
taxon_text_1_8510: A small to medium-sized white-bodied red-spotted dorid. The rhinophores are white and emerge from white sheaths. The sheaths may have red rims. The number and size of the red spots varies. The margin of the notum is transparent or opaque white, and occasionally has white mantle glands visible. The gills are white, sometimes with a red-rimmed pocket. The foot is white and usually has an opaque white margin. Individuals seen at the eastern end of the distribution range sometimes have an interior marginal yellow band, occasionally with red blotches.
taxon_text_3_8512:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Wild Coast, intertidal to 42 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8513: This relatively common species is a ‘fan-favourite’ among divers in the Great African Seaforest, where they can be observed on temperate reefs crawling on sponges, coralline algae and feather stars.
taxon_text_5_8514: This dorid is thought to feed on sponges.
taxon_text_6_8515: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_8_8517:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 76).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 284).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 136).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 42).
taxon_text_1_8402: A tiny to small white-bodied cladobranch with pink-coloured lateral appendages covered with opaque white or creamy spherical tubercles; the tubercles may have pink tips. The rhinophores are smooth, translucent, and have opaque white speckling towards the tips. The rhinophoral sheaths are widely flared, particularly at the anterior ends, and have opaque white speckling on their rims. Pink nodules are visible within the lateral appendages. The foot is translucent, tapered, and has opaque white spots.
taxon_text_3_8404:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, 2–7 m.
taxon_text_4_8405: Found on seagrass and seaweeds in shallow water.
taxon_text_5_8406: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8407: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8408: This species can be confused with several species of Doto, but it is distinguished by the anteriorly widely flared rhinophoral sheaths and the pink nodules visible within the lateral appendages.
taxon_text_8_8409: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 498, 790).
taxon_text_9_8410: Elysia punctata var. rubropunctata Macnae, 1954: unaccepted > superseded, misidentified as Elysia viridis in Gosliner, 1987, and listed as Elysia sp. in Zsilavecz, 2007, Jones, 2008 and Branch et al., 2022
taxon_text_1_8411: A small green- to brown-bodied sap-sucker. The body is smooth and has vivid blue spots. The head is green and may have opaque white spots. The rolled rhinophores have opaque white speckling. There are two black eyes. The paired parapodia are usually lacking in undulations and may have opaque white speckling and minute red spots. The body also has opaque white speckling. There exists an albino morph, with blue spots, red dots and opaque white speckling, but this is rare.
taxon_text_3_8413:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to southern Wild Coast, intertidal to 19 m.
taxon_text_4_8414: This species is found on various species of green seaweeds in the genera Codium and Bryopsis on which they are camouflaged.
taxon_text_5_8415: This species feeds on green seaweeds in the genera Codium and Bryopsis, using their ingested chloroplasts to produce sugars for its own nutrition (kleptoplasty), a rare behaviour of Sacoglossa species. These solar-powered sea slugs line their slugs digestive tract with chloroplasts from the algae which then provides resources through photosynthesis.
taxon_text_6_8416: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat spiral of one or two whorls, made up of distinct greenish-white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8417: The species is distinguished from other taco slugs by its relatively short parapodia and its narrow foot.
taxon_text_8_8418:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 214).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 51).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 21).
taxon_text_1_8420: A tiny orange-bodied aeolid with inflated cerata and opaque white markings. The oral tentacles and rhinophores are smooth, and may have opaque white spots. The cerata have a large lower bulb and a smaller upper bulb, usually with opaque white pointed tips. Clusters of viscera may be visible within the notum and cerata. The posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8422:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula, 5–10 m.
taxon_text_4_8423: Found in shallow water, often found on Bamboo kelp (Ecklonia maxima) fronds.
taxon_text_5_8424: The species feeds on campanularid hydroids, including Obelia geniculata.
taxon_text_6_8425: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a sparse white coil, folded at the external end.
taxon_text_7_8426: This species can be confused with the white- and silver-taloned roundheads, Tergipes sp.1 and 2, but the ceratal shape combined with the orange and opaque white coloration are diagnostic. One of four undescribed species for the genus included in this project, though more than 15 remain undescribed in South Africa!
taxon_text_8_8427:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 114).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 542, 795).
taxon_text_1_8429: A small brown and white-bodied aeolid with inflated papillate cerata. The oral tentacles are short, translucent, and have scattered creamy golden markings and a golden brown band below the tips. The rhinophores are smooth, and have creamy golden markings and a golden brown band below the tips. The cerata have minute opaque pale speckling, numerous papillae and pointed tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and mottled in creamy white, gold and brown. A pale morph has been found.
taxon_text_3_8431:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay, 10–20 m.
taxon_text_4_8432: Usually found on a red crater sponge where it closely resembles the reef debris found there.
taxon_text_5_8433: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8434: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a floppy white coil of one and a half turns. As the eggs mature they becomes less densely clustered in the egg mass.
taxon_text_7_8435: Though this species cannot be confused with any other, it is extremely cryptic, closely matching the reef debris where it is found. One of four undescribed species for the genus included in this project, though more than 15 remain undescribed in South Africa!
taxon_text_8_8436:
Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 542, 795).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 152).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 86).
taxon_text_1_8438: A tiny pale-bodied aeolid with plump, dark-spotted cerata narrowing to pointed tips. The oral tentacles and rhinophores are smooth, pale, and have brown-spotted bases and pale tips. The cerata may be rosy to brown with scattered opaque white spots and distinct pale tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8440:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, Knysna Lagoon, 3–18m.
taxon_text_4_8441: These tiny, cryptic aeolids are normally found associated with hydroids.
taxon_text_5_8442: The species most likely preys on hydroids, though more research is required.
taxon_text_6_8443: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a plump white collar of an almost completed two whorls.
taxon_text_7_8444: The species is unmistakable. One of four undescribed species for the genus included in this project, though more than 15 remain undescribed in South Africa!
taxon_text_8_8445: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 540, 792).
taxon_text_1_8447: A tiny white-bodied aeolid with oval, pointed-tipped golden brown cerata with white spots. The oral tentacles and rhinophores are smooth and golden brown. The cerata have pale to golden tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8449:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula, 8–20 m.
taxon_text_4_8450: This tiny aeolid can usually be found on temperate reefs, living on sponges and hydroids.
taxon_text_5_8451: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8452: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8453: The species can be confused with species of Tenellia, but the golden-brown white-spotted cerata are diagnostic. It can also be confused with species of Doto, but the presence of oral tentacles and lack of rhinophoral sheaths are distinctive. This species is one of four undescribed species for the genus included in this project, though more than 15 remain undescribed in South Africa!
taxon_text_8_8454: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 540).
taxon_text_1_8456: A small pale-bodied aeolid with inward-curving olive-green or brown cerata. The head is pale to pale pink and may have opaque white patches or speckling. The oral tentacles are pale to translucent white. The rhinophores are white and annulate. The notum has patches of opaque white. The cerata have opaque white tips.
taxon_text_3_8458:
Global: Namibia, South Africa.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to Algoa Bay, intertidal to 40 m.
taxon_text_4_8459: Found on temperate reefs and sandy areas, on various species of sponges, seaweeds and hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8461: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a tangled medallion of white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8462: The species can be confused with several species of aeolid nudibranch, but is distinguished by the annulate rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8463:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 121).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 592, 786).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 90).
taxon_text_1_8519: A medium-sized white-bodied dorid. The rhinophores are orange. The notum has streaks, dashes and spots of opaque white and scattered red blotches and spots. The margin of the notum has an opaque white band with red to purple spots surrounded by diffuse purple. The spots vary in size and shape and may be reduced to small purple dots. The notum may have a brownish tinge, particularly at the eastern end of the distribution. The gills are white with varying amounts of orange edging. The foot is white and may have purple spots.
taxon_text_3_8521:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Wild Coast, endemic, intertidal to 39 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8522: This common dorid is frequently observed on rocky reefs usually associated with sponges, coralline algae and feather stars. They are often seen in pairs or with other nudibranch species.
taxon_text_5_8523: Feeds on a pinkish sponge that appears light blue under natural light.
taxon_text_6_8524: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a loosely coiled slightly wavy white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8525: The species can be confused with the Wounded split-tooth dorid, Hypselodoris carnea, but is distinguished by the discontinuous purple spots at the anterior margin and a lack of marginal brown bars. In addition, the egg ribbon is a more upright collar with more densely laid eggs.
taxon_text_8_8526:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 81).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 332, 794).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 44).
taxon_text_9_8464: Aeolis plicata F. W. Hutton, 1882: unaccepted; Cavolina natans (A. d'Orbigny, 1836): unaccepted (junior subjective synonym); Dolicheolis longicauda (Quoy & Gaimard, 1832): unaccepted; Doris fasciculata Gmelin, 1791: unaccepted (ICZN opinion 773: placed on the official index of rejected names); Eolidia longicauda Quoy & Gaimard, 1832: unaccepted (synonym); Eolidia natans A. d'Orbigny, 1836: unaccepted (junior subjective synonym); Eolidia pinnata Eschscholtz, 1831: unaccepted (original combination); Fiona atlantica Bergh, 1857: unaccepted (synonym); Fiona marina Eliot, 1910: unaccepted (synonym); Hymenaeolis elegantissima A. Costa, 1867: unaccepted (synonym); Limax marinus Forsskål, 1775: unaccepted (dubious synonym); Oithona nobilis Alder & Hancock, 1851: unaccepted.
taxon_text_1_8465: A small translucent white-bodied aeolid. The cerata have a sail-like appendage at their posterior. The head is orange to translucent white and may have a diamond-shaped opaque white patch. The oral tentacles are short, pointed and translucent. The rhinophores are translucent white or orange, and are narrower at their tips. The notum may have opaque white patches. The dark brown digestive duct is visible within the notum. The cerata are brown or golden, and their sail-like appendages are white or yellow.
taxon_text_3_8467:
Global: Widespread in all oceans.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, on the surface.
taxon_text_4_8468: Found on floating objects in the open ocean and washed ashore, especially where goose barnacles are present.
taxon_text_5_8469: This species feeds on gooseneck barnacles of the genus Lepas.
taxon_text_6_8470: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a plump white coil attached to the surface by a stalk.
taxon_text_7_8471: The sail-like appendages on the cerata are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8472:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 120).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 548, 792).
taxon_text_1_8483: A tiny to small cream- to tan-bodied aeolid with dark greenish cream- to yellow-banded cerata densely speckled with opaque white. The head has opaque white speckling. The oral tentacles are cream to tan and have a broad stripe of opaque white speckling. The rhinophores are indistinctly annulate and pale grey, also with opaque white speckling, denser at the tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8485:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to western False Bay, 10m.
taxon_text_4_8486: This aeolid can be found on shallow reefs where it is usually on hydroids of the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_5_8487: This species is thought to feed on hydroids in the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_6_8488: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8489: This species is one of several undescribed Flabellina species in South Africa, and can be confused with the darker morph of the Frosted triple-tooth, Flabellina sp.4, but is distinguished by its indistinctly annulate rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8490:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 113).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 526, 790).
taxon_text_1_8474: A tiny pale-bodied aeolid with golden tan cerata heavily speckled with opaque white. The head is translucent with opaque white speckling. The oral tentacles have a broad stripe of opaque white speckling. The rhinophores are pale with opaque white speckling; speckling denser at the tips, and have many papillae. The cerata are translucent with golden tan cores. There is a yellow to greenish morph that has opaque white speckling on the oral tentacles, cerata and body. The cerata in this morph have darker greenish cores and yellowish tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8476:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay, 5–16 m.
taxon_text_4_8477: This variably coloured aeolid is usually found on hydroids of the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_5_8478: This aeolid is thought to feed on hydroids of the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_6_8479: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a convoluted white zigzag with distinct white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8480: Flabellina sp. 4 is one of several undescribed species in the genus and can be confused with other species of Flabellina in the area, but is distinguished by its papillate rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8481: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 526).
taxon_text_1_8528: A large smooth-bodied frilled nudibranch. The rhinophores are smooth and pale. The notum is pale or translucent with a distinctive wavy margin. The margin may be pink or creamy with a bluish white marginal band, or brownish with a blue marginal band.
taxon_text_3_8530:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal, 6–83 m. The species' depth occurrence varies around the region: 20–40 m around the Cape Peninsula and False Bay, 6–40 m in Algoa Bay, and 79–83 m off the Wild Coast and KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_8531: Usually found on temperate or deep-water subtropical reefs. Occasionally caught as bycatch in demersal trawling.
taxon_text_5_8532: This species feeds on a variety of soft corals and gorgonians, particularly the Multicoloured seafan, Melithaea rubra.
taxon_text_6_8533: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a fat sausage of large white or pink eggs. The egg size may indicate direct development.
taxon_text_7_8534: The striking species is unmistakable and is the only species in the family Lemindidae.
taxon_text_8_8535:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 210).

taxon_text_9_8491: Doris radiata Gmelin, 1791: unaccepted (synonym); Glaucus distichoicus A. d'Orbigny, 1836: unaccepted; Glaucus flagellum Blumenbach, 1803: unaccepted (synonym); Glaucus hexapterigius Cuvier, 1805: unaccepted (synonym); Glaucus lineatus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1861: unaccepted > nomen nudum; Glaucus lineatus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1864: unaccepted; Glaucus longicirrhus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1861: unaccepted > nomen nudum; Glaucus longicirrhus Reinhardt & Bergh, 1864: unaccepted.
taxon_text_1_8492: A small to medium-sized blue- and silver-bodied aeolid with distinctive blue-tipped cerata arranged in spreading rays. The head is dark bright blue with lateral silver stripes. The oral tentacles and rhinophores are short, smooth and blue-tipped. The notum is silver. The cerata extend from three translucent appendages with central blue streaks. The cerata have silver bands or central silver stripes. The foot has two dark blue stripes, and is transparent silver at the centre and sides. The posterior end of the foot is slender, tapered, and dark blue.
taxon_text_3_8494:
Global: Circumtropical and subtropical.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Mozambique, pelagic on the surface.
taxon_text_4_8495: This species lives in the open ocean and is only rarely seen inshore. The animals are sometimes washed inshore and onto the beach after strong onshore winds. They float upside down on the surface of the ocean and maintain buoyancy by gulping air into their stomachs.
taxon_text_5_8496: This species feeds on various species of pelagic colonial hydroids such as the Bluebottles, Physalia spp., the Blue buttons, Porpita spp., and the By-the-wind sailors, Velella spp. They use the highly toxic stinging cells of their prey for their own defenses. Though some studies suggest that these sequestered stinging cells cannot harm humans, it is probably safest to avoid touching these animals with bare skin.
taxon_text_6_8497: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon consists of extended densely coiled blue spiralling strings.
taxon_text_7_8498: The species can be confused with the Indo-Pacific sea swallow, Glaucus marginatus, as well as other species in that complex, but is distinguished by the single layer of cerata on each lateral appendage.
taxon_text_8_8499:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 210).
