Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 98).
taxon_text_9_8536: Orange-clubbed nudibranch GZ & FGMA, kelp orange-clubbed nudibranch (Two Oceans)
taxon_text_1_8537: A large white-bodied dorid with vivid orange blotches on the body and multiple orange clubbed lateral appendages. Rhinophores vivid orange with white bases, head with multiple orange-tipped cephalic tentacles. Gills vivid orange with white bases, body with scattered orange-tipped tubercles. Lateral appendages on the body absent at middle portion of lateral margin. Posterior end of foot white with scattered orange spots and orange-tipped tubercles.
taxon_text_3_8539:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to Knysna Lagoon, intertidal to 10 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8540: Lives on the Bamboo kelp (Ecklonia maxima), usually feeding on kelp-associated bryozoans such as Tuberculate lace bryozoan, Jellyella tuberculata, which grows as a mat on kelp fronds.
taxon_text_6_8542: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat, white spiral of several whorls.
taxon_text_7_8543: This species can be confused with the Reef orange-clubbed dorid, Limacia lucida, but is larger and has orange blotches on the body.
taxon_text_8_8544:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 99).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 210).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 142).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 63).
taxon_text_1_8555: A medium-sized pale-bodied aeolid with yellow-tipped pale yellow cerata. The head is pale with translucent yellow oral tentacles and smooth translucent yellow rhinophores. The cerata are densely arranged in indistinct clusters. The foot is translucent and slender.
taxon_text_3_8557:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Eastern False Bay, 10–15 m.
taxon_text_4_8558: Found on temperate reefs, associated with hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8560: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8561: One of several undescribed Caloria species. However, the congested ceratal arrangement and coloration are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8562: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 596).
taxon_text_9_8545: Triopa lucida W. Stimpson, 1855 unaccepted, also misidentified as the European species Limacia clavigera
taxon_text_1_8546: A small white smooth-bodied dorid with multiple orange-tipped clubbed appendages. The body may have a slight scattering of small orange spots. The head has multiple cephalic tentacles that are white with orange tips. Some tips mimic perfoliate rhinophores. The rhinophores are orange. The body has multiple orange-tipped clubbed lateral appendages. The gills are white but may have orange tips. The posterior end of the foot is white and tapered.
taxon_text_3_8548:
Global: Southern Atlantic and South Africa

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 20 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8549: Usually encountered on rocky reefs on various bryozoans, sponges and coralline algae.
taxon_text_6_8551: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat white spiral of several turns.
taxon_text_7_8552: This species can be confused with the Kelp orange-clubbed dorid, Limacia jellyi, but is smaller and lacking in orange blotches on the body.
taxon_text_8_8553:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 99).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 210, 805).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 142).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 63).
taxon_text_1_8564: Forms erect, broadly flattened axes, often several arising from the same holdfast, these then branch dichotomously several times before ending in rounded, truncated, forked tips (tips often arched). The surface of the fronds bear characteristic, large, ball-like knobs when fertile. Texture stiff and tough and colour dark plum-red. Colonies often encrusted with a pink epiphytic coralline alga and by bryozoans.
taxon_text_2_8565: Typically about 150 mm tall, with axes at least 5 mm wide.
taxon_text_4_8567: Attached to rocks in low-shore pools and on shallow reefs.
taxon_text_6_8569: Tetrasprangia in prominent hemispherical structures borne on the upper parts of the thallus lobes.
taxon_text_7_8570: The dark plum red colour, tough branching axes and large ball-like knobs on fertile specimens make this species fairly easy to identify.
taxon_text_8_8571:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 400).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 345).
taxon_text_9_8572: This species is currently accepted by WORMS as Coryphella capensis (Thiele, 1925), but this identification is erroneous according to Terry Gosliner and suggests it should be Flabellina capensis; Coryphella capensis Thiele, 1925: original combination, white-edged nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8573: A small to medium-sized white to translucent-bodied aeolid with red to dark red white-lined cerata. The head has a pair of opaque white-lined translucent oral tentacles. The rhinophores are rugose and translucent. The cerata are translucent with central red cores, and may have opaque white flecks as well as white lines. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and has a central opaque white stripe.
taxon_text_3_8575:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, shallow water to 39 m.
taxon_text_4_8576: Usually found on bushy hydroids of the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_5_8577: This aeolid is thought to feed on hydroids in the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_6_8578: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg mass is a convoluted white zigzag.
taxon_text_7_8579: The translucent red-cored white-lined cerata make this species unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_8580:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 113).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 528, 790).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 152).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 84).
taxon_text_9_8581: This species is currently accepted by WORMS as Paraflabellina funeka (Gosliner & Griffiths, 1981), but this identification is erroneous according to Terry Gosliner and suggests it should remain as Flabellina funeka; Purple lady
taxon_text_1_8582: A small to medium-sized purple-bodied aeolid with red white-tipped cerata. The head has a pair of purple oral tentacles and a pair of variably distinct purplish patches. The rhinophores are annulate, purple, and longer than the oral tentacles. The cerata are translucent with red cores, and may be joined at their bases. A white morph also occurs, with an opaque white-speckled pale translucent body, oral tentacles and rhinophores. The posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8584:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay , 2–40 m.
taxon_text_4_8585: Usually found on bushy hydroids of the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_5_8586: This aeolid is thought to feed on hydroids in the genus Eudendrium.
taxon_text_6_8587: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg mass is a convoluted white zigzag.
taxon_text_7_8588: The white morph of this species can be confused with two species in the genus Cratena, when the distinctive orange patches of Cratena are not visible (the Orange-eyed tentacle aeolid, Cratena capensis, and the Elegant tentacle aeolid, Cratena sp.1), but the annulate rhinophores are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8589:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 112).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 528, 790).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 152).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 85).
taxon_text_1_8600: A small cladobranch, purple, translucent or peachy pink with several branched secondary gills. The oral veil has several pointed papillae of varying lengths. The rhinophores have a central crown of papillae surrounding a longer single stalk. The rhinophoral sheaths are mostly cylindrical and slightly flared at the rims. The notum has indistinct low tubercles and may have opaque white speckles and margin in pale morphs.
taxon_text_3_8602:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, intertidal to 64 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8603: This species is usually found on reefs, in association with their prey, soft corals of the genus Tenerodus (T. fallax and T. pollex).
taxon_text_5_8604: This cladobranch is thought to prey on the purple and brown soft corals, Tenerodus fallax and Tenerodus pollex.
taxon_text_6_8605: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a fine string of white or purple eggs, usually laid on the prey soft coral.
taxon_text_7_8606: The species is usually cryptic on its prey, soft corals. It can be confused with juveniles of the brush lacedragon, Tritonia sp., but is distinguished by having shorter papillae on the oral veil, and lacking the opaque white marginal line on the rhinophoral sheaths. Also, the rhinophoral sheaths are mostly cylindrical and the notum is not smooth.
taxon_text_8_8607:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 108).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 470, 787).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 144).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 72).
taxon_text_1_8609: A small orange dorid covered with tiny tubercles, extremely well camouflaged to match the bryozoan on which it feeds. The head is orange and covered with tiny tubercles. The rhinophores are indistinct. The notum is slightly humped, and covered with tiny tubercles. The gills are orange but indistinct. The posterior is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8611:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to eastern False Bay, 10–30m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8612: Usually found on reefs in association with the Pore-plated false-coral bryozoan, Laminopora jellyae, on which it is incredibly cryptic and takes a keen eye to spot.
taxon_text_5_8613: This dorid preys on the Pore-plated false-coral, Laminopora jellyae, using its radula (a structure of tiny teeth) to scrape of the bryozoans zooids.
taxon_text_6_8614: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat spiral of narrow strings of pale orange eggs.
taxon_text_7_8615: This species could be confused with the Cape notch-gill dorid, Corambe sp., but so far has only been found on the Pore-plated false-coral, Laminopora jellyae, from which it is near indistinguishable.
taxon_text_8_8616: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 416, 806).
taxon_text_1_8618: A small to medium-sized brown to orange-bodied cladobranch covered with iridescent blue or green spots and blotches. The rhinophores are brownish with iridescent tips. The rhinophoral sheaths have a posterior ridge and are often covered with blue or green spots. The notum is covered with conical papillae. There are two pairs of lobed lateral appendages, often with iridescent margins. Finely branched transparent secondary gills extend from the base of each lateral appendage. The body is slender and elongated.
taxon_text_3_8620:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to Eastern Cape, intertidal to 15 m.
taxon_text_4_8621: Usually found on densely overgrown reefs, where it can be seen on various species of brown and red algae. Has previously been observed to have skeleton shrimp (Family Caprellidae) on its gills.
taxon_text_5_8622: This species feeds on various species of hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8623: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbons shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8624: The Frilled grassdragon, Scyllaea fulva, is similar but has less prolific secondary gills and a lobed crest at the posterior end of the foot. The Deepwater grassdragon, Notobryon sp. is also similar but it has shorter lateral appendages and a sparse covering of opaque white spots.
taxon_text_8_8625:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 210).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 67).
taxon_text_1_8627: A small white-bodied dorid with numerous orange-tipped lateral papillae and brown and opaque white flecks. The head is white with variable orange to yellow blotches and numerous orange-tipped velar papillae. The rhinophores are white with orange tips. The notum has a central orange stripe and variable stripes, spots and blotches of orange to yellow. The gills are white with orange to yellow edging and blotches. The posterior end of the foot is tapered with a central orange to yellow stripe.
taxon_text_3_8629:
Global: South Atlantic and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8630: On rocky reefs, usually close to its egg ribbon. Frequently observed in small groups. Often seen on bryozoans and coralline algae. Amphipods have been observed feeding on the papillae.
taxon_text_5_8631: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8632: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a sprawling white spiral.
taxon_text_7_8633: This species can be confused with the Flame-tipped pump dorid, Okenia aurorapapillata, but is distinguished by its yellow- or orange-tipped papillae.
taxon_text_8_8634:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 92).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 414, 804).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 140).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 53).
taxon_text_1_8636: A small white-bodied dorid with lateral papillae and brown and opaque white flecks. The head has a pair of velar papillae; the rhinophores are brown-flecked. The lateral papillae are white with brown flecks. The gills are also white with brown flecks. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and translucent white with opaque white flecks.
taxon_text_3_8638:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, 5–30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8639: This undescribed species has only been observed on coarse, algae-covered sand.
taxon_text_5_8640: The species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8641: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a small white twist.
taxon_text_7_8642: This species can be confused with the Starry pump dorid, Okenia siderata, but its location, more sharply pointed lateral appendages and brown speckling rather than white are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8643: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 412, 793).
taxon_text_1_8591: A medium-sized rough-bodied dorid that may be white, cream-coloured or brown with variable darker blotches, spots or stripes. The cream rhinophores have a small tip at the posterior end. The notum is covered with rounded tubercles and may have scattered darker spots, large dark blotches, radiating darker stripes, and may vary in colour from white to light brown. The spots may have pale haloes. The gills are white to cream, and sometimes yellow to orange. The posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8593:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay, Algoa Bay, 4–400 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8594: This variable dorid can be found on subtidal and deeper rocky reefs, often on sponges, Strawberry anemones and hydroids.
taxon_text_5_8595: Not much known regarding its diet, but thought to feed on sponges.
taxon_text_6_8596: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8597: The species can be confused with several species of dalmatian dorid, but the rhinophore shape with the tip at the posterior is unique.
taxon_text_8_8598:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 89).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 352).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 138).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 51).
taxon_text_9_8653: Bulla aperta Linnaeus, 1767: unaccepted (original combination); Bulla schroeteri R. A. Philippi, 1844: unaccepted; Bullaea capensis L. Pfeiffer, 1840: unaccepted; Bullaea schroeteri R. A. Philippi, 1844: unaccepted > junior subjective synonym
taxon_text_1_8654: A large, firm-bodied smooth-textured white- to cream-coloured headshield slug. The edge of the headshield is folded back over the body and the parapodia are folded.
taxon_text_3_8656:
Global: Mozambique and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to Mozambique, subtidal to 100 m.
taxon_text_4_8657: This species is usually found on sand or slightly burrowed underneath it. It secretes sulphuric acid as a defense mechanism to deter predators.
taxon_text_5_8658: This slug feeds on small molluscs and worms, swallowing them whole and crushing them in its muscular gizzard.
taxon_text_6_8659: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a translucent, hollow, sausage-shaped, and attached to the sandy substrate by mucus threads.
taxon_text_7_8660: The flat, broad body, white to cream coloration, smooth texture and the sandy habitat are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8661:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 204).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 13).
taxon_text_1_6953: Forms a clump of club-like fingers each emerging from a narrow base and expanding distally to a blunt, rounded tip. Each main branch gives rise to short lateral branches, each also emerging from a constricted base. Colour greenish to yellowish brown, wrinkled when dry, but smooth and turgid when wet.  Each branch consists of a thin outer ‘skin’ and is filled with a sticky, transparent mucilage.
taxon_text_2_6954: Total height typically about 10 cm, but can reach 30 cm, with branches about 1 cm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_6955:
Global: Southern Africa, Australia, New Zealand and sub-Antarctic Islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_6956:
A common species found attached to exposed rocks in the mid to low intertidal. Stores water in the mucus filling the branches and able to tolerate considerable water-loss when exposed at low tide, becoming flaccid and wrinkled, but regaining water when submerged again at high tide.

Considered a valuable source for the discovery of bioactive compounds of bacterial origin active against human pathogens.
taxon_text_6_6958: Spores produced by sunken conceptacles about 0.4 mm in diameter that are visible as dark spots on the branches.
taxon_text_8_6960:
Albakosh, MA, Naidoo, RK, Kirby, B & Bauer, R (2016). Identification of epiphytic bacterial communities associated with the brown alga Splachnidium rugosum. Journal of Applied Phycology, 28, 1891–1901.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 390).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 158).
taxon_text_1_8672: A small to medium-sized aeolid with curved iridescent-striped pink cerata. The head is pale or pinkish with a central opaque white stripe. The oral tentacles are smooth with opaque white speckling. The rhinophores are smooth, pale, and are indistinctly speckled with opaque white. The notum is pale to pinkish with a central opaque white stripe. The iridescent stripes on the cerata can appear blue. The foot is pale, slender and tapered with a central opaque white stripe.
taxon_text_3_8674:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to 30 m.
taxon_text_4_8675: This species can be found on temperate reefs, often on vertical reef faces and in association with the Multicoloured sea fan, Melithaea rubra.
taxon_text_5_8676: Feeds primarily on the Multicoloured sea fan, Melithaea rubra. It also feeds on other soft corals.
taxon_text_6_8677: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a gelatinous mass with individual cream-coloured eggs scattered throughout the mass or laid in double ribbons within it.
taxon_text_7_8678: The species' central stripe and striped pink cerata are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8679:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 208).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 124).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 154).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 94).
taxon_text_9_8680: Hermaea capensis Macnae, 1954: unaccepted > superseded combination, previously misidentified as Placida dendritica, a north Atlantic species.
taxon_text_1_8681: A tiny to small green-speckled sap-sucker. The head is pale with green to brown dendritic patterning and occasional opaque white spots. The rolled rhinophores have opaque white spotted pale tips. The body is pale with green or brown dendritic patterning. The cerata have opaque white or pink spots and the ceratal tips are spotted with opaque white. The posterior end of the foot is pale, tapered and has opaque white speckling.
taxon_text_3_8683:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 19 m.
taxon_text_4_8684: This sap-sucker is found on green seaweeds in the genus Codium, with which they have an interesting relationship. The sap-sucker feeds on the Codium species and use their ingested chloroplasts to produce sugar for its own nutrition, a process called 'kleptoplasty'.
taxon_text_5_8685: Feeds on green seaweeds of Codium species and produces sugar from ingested chloroplasts.
taxon_text_6_8686: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat white spiral of several turns.
taxon_text_7_8687: The species is unmistakable, but seldom spotted because of its small size and cryptic coloration.
taxon_text_9_8689: Previously misidentified as Aplysia parvula Mörch, 1863, a Caribbean species. Also misidentified as Aplysia spuria in Day, 1969. Identified as Aplysia cf. ghanimii Golestani, Crocetta, Padula, Camacho-García, Langeneck, Poursanidis, Pola, Yokeş, Cervera, D.-W. Jung, Gosliner, Araya, Hooker, Schrödl & Á. Valdés, 2019 in Two Oceans, 2022, but the species is currently under investigation.
taxon_text_1_8690: A medium-sized variably coloured sea hare with opaque white spots in clusters. The head has white-speckled rolled rhinophores, usually more densely speckled towards the margins. There is a pair of black eye spots below the rhinophores. The oral tentacles are widely separated. The body may be pale, olive green, brown or maroon, and may have indistinct white margins. The parapodial margins are frilled and may have narrow pink bands or dark marginal dashes.
taxon_text_3_8692:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to central KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to 34 m.
taxon_text_4_8693: This species is usually found in sandy areas among seaweeds, and if it is found on reefs, it is usually near sand patches. The species can swim by flapping its parapodia, and will secrete a purple dye if disturbed.
taxon_text_5_8694: This species feeds on various species of seaweeds.
taxon_text_6_8695: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a tangled mass of pink or orange spaghetti-like strings.
taxon_text_7_8696: The scattered clusters of white spots where present and the lack of continuous blue-black margins distinguish this species from other sea hares.
taxon_text_8_8697:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 206).

taxon_text_9_8698: According to WORMS, this species is unaccepted and is a probable synonym of Haminoea natalensis. However, Turani et al. (2023) maintains that it is a valid species. Also listed as Haminea alfredensis in Day, 1969.
taxon_text_1_8699: A small headshield slug. The mantle is mottled with black, green and orange spots. The shell is smooth, translucent, and covered with orange spots. The head has indistinct rolled rhinophores, the body is pale  and the parapodia fold over the shell.
taxon_text_3_8701:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West Coast to Wild Coast, intertidal to 4 m.
taxon_text_4_8702: Usually occur in dense colonies in eelgrass beds (Zostera capensis) and seaweed fields in estuaries and tidal pools.
taxon_text_5_8703: This species feeds on filamentous seaweeds or diatoms.
taxon_text_6_8704: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is wide collar of narrowly zigzagging, greenish-yellow eggs.
taxon_text_7_8705: The species can be confused with several species of Haloa, but the densely mottled mantle, greenish collar-shaped egg ribbon and temperate water location are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8706:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 204).

Day JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 171).

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 132).
taxon_text_1_8708: A medium to large tan-bodied sidegill slug: the body is covered with low pustules. The head has a pair of rolled rhinophores, set widely apart and a short, laterally flared oral veil. The anterior of the oral veil has irregular papillae. The body has dark and opaque white patches. There is a single gill on the right hand side of the body under the mantle. The posterior end of the foot extends beyond the mantle and is rounded and tapered.
taxon_text_3_8710:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Eastern Cape, found from the intertidal to 120 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8711: Found on rocky reefs, in seagrass beds and on sand. Occasionally caught as bycatch on demersal trawls.
taxon_text_5_8712: The species preys on a variety of species including other heterobranchs and tubeworms.
taxon_text_6_8713: Individuals are hermaphroditic and produce an egg ribbon consisting of a loosely coiled sausage of tiny white to cream-coloured eggs.
taxon_text_7_8714: This species is similar to the Dwarf warty pleurobranch, Pleurobranchaea tarda, a smaller species and which is readily confused with juveniles of Pleurobranchaea bubala, but P. bubala is larger and has a relatively rougher skin.
taxon_text_8_8715:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 206).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 61).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 27).
taxon_text_9_8833:
Catriona speciosa Macnae, 1954: unaccepted; Cuthona speciosa (Macnae, 1954): unaccepted (superseded combination)

Note that WoRMS identifies this species as Trinchesia speciosa, in the family Trinchesiidae, which Terry Gosliner says is erroneous.
taxon_text_1_8834: A tiny yellow-bodied aeolid with yellow cerata. The head is yellow with short oral tentacles and rhinophores that may have pale tips. The cerata may also be pale with yellow tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and yellow.
taxon_text_3_8836:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, 10–20 m.
taxon_text_4_8837: Found on temperate reefs. Not much else known about the biology of this poorly-known species.
taxon_text_5_8838: This species is thought to feed on hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8839: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8840: The species can be confused with other species in the Tenellia cf. speciosa complex, but is distinguished by its yellow body, rhinophores and oral tentacles, and its yellow or yellow-tipped pale cerata.
taxon_text_8_8841:
Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 568).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 89).
taxon_text_9_8725: Fourline nudibranch, previously misidentified as the European species Polycera quadrilineata
taxon_text_1_8726: A small slender dorid with a white body and variable numbers of black stripes. Characteristic yellow tubercles are randomly scattered over the body and foot. The head has six or more bright yellow cephalic tentacles, usually with pale tips. The rhinophores are black and bulbous with pale or yellow tips. The notum usually has paired yellow stripes at the central margin and often has a black outline around the genital pore. The gills are black with yellow central branches. A pair of bright yellow extrabranchial papillae flanks the gills. The posterior end of the foot is usually white with a bright yellow central stripe, but may have several black stripes and yellow tubercles.
taxon_text_3_8728:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to 25 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8729: Usually seen on reefs, especially on bryozoans. Not much else known on the biology of this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8731: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy loose white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8732: One of three undescribed species of Polycera found in the Great African Seaforest. This species can be confused with most other species of Polycera found in the region, but is distinguished by its single pair of extrabranchial papillae, and the presence of yellow tubercles.
taxon_text_8_8733:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 210).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 97).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 140).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 58).
taxon_text_1_8717: A small to medium-sized smooth-bodied dorid. The body is white with variable numbers of dark and yellow stripes or dashes, and may also have yellow tubercles. The head has six or more bright yellow cephalic tentacles and black rhinophores with yellow tips. The gills are black, usually with yellow tips. Two to three pairs of bright yellow extrabranchial papillae flank the gills. The posterior end of the foot is white, tapered, and with a bright yellow central stripe. The foot may also have black striping.
taxon_text_3_8719:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, central KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8720: Usually encountered on shallow-water reefs. Not much else known about this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8722: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy loose white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8723: One of three undescribed species of Polycera found in the Great African Seaforest. Can be confused with most other species of Polycera found in the region, but is distinguished by its multiple pairs of extrabranchial papillae, and generally smaller size.
taxon_text_8_8724:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 97).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 198, 797).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 142).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 59).
taxon_text_1_8735: A small to medium-sized smooth-bodied dorid, the most variably coloured of the crowned dorids. The body usually has variable numbers of orange stripes, but may also have black and yellow stripes, or lack stripes almost entirely. The body may also be greenish- or purplish-shaded and mottled orange morphs have been seen. The head has six or more bright yellow cephalic tentacles. The rhinophores are usually pale with black bands of variable width below the pale tips. The gills are usually white and may have yellow tips, orange flecks or be black with yellow tips. A pair of extrabranchial papillae flanks the gills; their top halves are yellow. The posterior end of the foot is usually white with a bright yellow central stripe.
taxon_text_3_8737:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to False Bay, intertidal to 35 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8738: Usually encountered on reefs, especially on bryozoans. Not much else known about this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8740: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy loose white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8741: One of three undescribed species of Polycera found in the Great African Seaforest. This species can be confused with the Crowned dorid, Polycera capensis, but is distinguished by its orange stripes or non-white coloration where present. Greenish and purplish morphs are distinctive. It is distinguished from the Twin-crowned dorid, Polycera sp.1, by its single pair of extrabranchial papillae.
taxon_text_8_8742:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 97).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 200, 801).

taxon_text_9_8743: Polycera conspicua J. K. Allan, 1932 unaccepted; Polycera nigrocrocea Barnard, 1927 unaccepted
taxon_text_1_8744: A medium-sized dorid. The notum is white with three broad black stripes. The head has six or more bright yellow cephalic tentacles. The rhinophores are black. The gills are black and may have yellow tips. A pair of bright yellow extrabranchial papillae flanks the gills. The posterior end of the foot is white and tapered with a bright yellow central stripe. Variants may have one or two narrow black stripes or may lack black stripes entirely.
taxon_text_3_8746:
Global: south western Pacific (probably introduced in ballast water), southern Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: southern Namibia to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8747: Usually seen on various species of hard and arborescent bryozoans, sponges and hydroids on shallow-water reefs.
taxon_text_5_8748: Thought to feed on various species of bryozoans.
taxon_text_6_8749: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy loose white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8750: This species can be confused with most other species of Polycera found in the region, but is distinguished by its single pair of extrabranchial papillae, a lack of yellow tubercles and its white body with broad black stripes.
taxon_text_8_8751:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 210).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 58).
taxon_text_9_8752: Polycera gnupa Er. Marcus & Ev. Marcus, 1967 synonym, unaccepted
taxon_text_1_8753: A medium-sized dorid. The body is pale but covered with dense dark speckling. The head has six or more banded cephalic tentacles with white bases, a median orange to yellow band and dark speckles at the tips. The rhinophores are dark speckled with long stalks supporting a bulbous tip. The rhinophoral tips are yellow with dark speckling. The notum has white marginal ridges that are less dark speckled, and infrequent yellow tubercles. The gills are dark speckled, with yellow tips. Multiple pairs of extrabranchial papillae flank the gills. The papillae have pale bases, median yellow to orange bands and darkly speckled tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and dark speckled with a central dark speckled white ridge, as well as infrequent yellow tubercles. The foot may also have black striping.
taxon_text_3_8755:
Global: Central and eastern Pacific, eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean, South Africa

Local/Regional: Western False Bay to Algoa Bay, intertidal to 5 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8756: Usually on sandy areas and reefs on various species of seaweeds and bryozoans.
taxon_text_5_8757: Feeds on the Purple dentate bryozoan, Bugula neritina.
taxon_text_6_8758: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy loose white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8759:
This species is distinguished from all other species of Polycera found in the region by its dark speckling, and by its banded cephalic tentacles and extrabranchial papillae.

It was most likely introduced to the region in ballast water from ships from the Californian coast.
taxon_text_8_8760:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 97).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 202, 795).
taxon_text_1_8762: A small to medium-sized cryptic red-bodied dorid with scattered black dots. The rhinophores are darker red than the body coloration. The notum may have scattered opaque white patches. The gills match the body coloration. The posterior end of the foot is rounded. Rare colour morphs of cream and purple have been observed.
taxon_text_3_8764:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: southern West Coast to the Eastern Cape, probably endemic, intertidal to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8765: Usually found associated with red sponges such as the Stellar red sponge (Crambe acuata) on which it is incredibly cryptic.
taxon_text_6_8767: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a low gelatinous collar of several whorls with large orange eggs. The species may exhibit direct development or a reduced larval stage.
taxon_text_7_8768: This species can be confused with the Dappled orange sponge dorid, Rostanga aureamala, but that species has so far only been seen in Algoa Bay and Rostanga elandsia is distinguished by its lack of indistinct pale patches. Somewhat similar Atalodoris sp., but can be distinguished by its lack of tubercles and the presence of small black dots.
taxon_text_8_8769:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 71).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 176, 793).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 136).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 40).
taxon_text_9_8644: Doris pareti Vérany, 1846: unaccepted (synonym); Goniodoris brunnea Macnae, 1958: unaccepted; Goniodoris castanea Alder & Hancock, 1845: unaccepted (superseded combination); Goniodoris castanea var. pallida Dautzenberg & Durouchoux, 1900: unaccepted; Pelagella pareti (Vérany, 1846): unaccepted (junior subjective synonym), Citrine nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8645: A small, extremely well-camouflaged dorid. The body varies in colour from translucent yellow to brown, with pointed tubercles, three longitudinal ridges on the notum and yellow and white speckles overall. The head has a frontal ridge; the rhinophores are dark with white tips. The gills are prominent and usually flattened over the notum. The posterior is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8647:
Global: North Atlantic, Mediterranean, central Pacific.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Eastern Cape, intertidal to 15 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8648: Usually found on rocky reefs, particularly on species of colonial ascidians.
taxon_text_5_8649: This dorid feeds on colonial sea squirts, particularly the White-ringed ascidian, Botrylloides magnicoecus.
taxon_text_6_8650: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a cream-coloured wavy rosette of several whorls.
taxon_text_7_8651: The remarkable camouflage of this species causes it, when seen, to be confused with its prey sea squirt.
taxon_text_8_8652:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 93).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 402, 800, 803).
taxon_text_1_8771:
A medium-sized, white-bodied dorid with varying numbers of brown or black spots of varying sizes. The rhinophores are cream. The notum is densely covered with minute caryophyllidia* and may have opaque white spots. The gills are white and relatively sparse. The posterior end of the foot is rounded.

 

*Caryophyllidia: Structures on dorid nudibranchs consisting of a ring of spines around a central specialised tubercle, possibly having a sensory function, since each has an individual nerve leading to the tip of the tubercle.
taxon_text_2_8772:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula, 5–29 m in depth.
taxon_text_3_8773:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula, 5–29 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8774: Found on temperate reefs, usually on various species of sponges.
taxon_text_6_8776: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8777: This species can be confused with several of the dalmatian dorids, but is distinguished by its white coloration, the presence of caryophyllidia and numerous glands around the mantle margin.
taxon_text_8_8778:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 72).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 174).
taxon_text_1_8789: A small, white-bodied aeolid with yellow-tipped dull blue-green cerata. The head is white with pale-tipped yellow-speckled oral tentacles. The rhinophores are pale, yellow-speckled and have pale tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and pale with an opaque white tip.
taxon_text_3_8791:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, 25 m.
taxon_text_4_8792: This rarely seen species has been found on temperate reefs on the Stellar red sponge, Crambe acuata.
taxon_text_5_8793: This species' food is not yet known.
taxon_text_6_8794: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8795: One of 25 undescribed species in the genus  from South Africa! The species can be confused with the fireworks roundhead Eubranchus sp.16, but is distinguished by the yellow-speckled oral tentacles and rhinophores and the blue-green cerata. It can also be confused with the yellow-tipped tentacle aeolid, Caloria sp.3, but has shorter yellow-speckled oral tentacles and smooth rhinophores.
taxon_text_8_8796: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 570).
taxon_text_9_8797: Catriona casha Gosliner & R.J. Griffiths, 1981: unaccepted (superseded combination); Sunset nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8798: A tiny, pale-bodied aeolid with dark red white-tipped cerata. The head is translucent white with white oral tentacles and smooth white rhinophores. The cerata have peach shading to white at their tips. The foot is translucent white and the posterior end of the foot is tapered.
taxon_text_3_8800:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to False Bay, central southern coast, intertidal to 25 m.
taxon_text_4_8801: Found in temperate water almost always on the Pink-mouthed hydroid Ectopleura crocea. Its eggs are also laid on the stalk of the hydroid.
taxon_text_5_8802: This species feeds on the Pink-mouthed hydroid Ectopleura crocea.
taxon_text_6_8803: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon has two forms: a densely clustered plump white zigzag and a dense tubular mass of eggs. These forms reflect different stages of maturity of the eggs.
taxon_text_7_8804: The species can be confused with several species of aeolid, but is distinguished by its coloration and habitat.
taxon_text_8_8805:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 119).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 562, 792).
taxon_text_9_8842:
Catriona speciosa Macnae, 1954: unaccepted; Cuthona speciosa (Macnae, 1954): unaccepted (superseded combination)

Note that WoRMS identifies this species as Trinchesia speciosa, in the family Trinchesiidae, which Terry Gosliner says is erroneous.
taxon_text_1_8843: A tiny green-bodied aeolid with orange-tipped purple cerata. The head is green with short pink-banded pale oral tentacles. The rhinophores are pink with pale tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and green. A pale morph exists with orange-tipped pale blue-green cerata; pale oral tentacles, and pale rhinophores with a basal orange band.
taxon_text_3_8845:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Central West Coast to southern Wild Coast, 2–25 m.
taxon_text_4_8846: Found on temperate reefs. This species complex remains unresolved and not much is known about the biology of these species.
taxon_text_5_8847: This species is thought to feed on hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8848: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8849: The species can be confused with other species in the Tenellia cf. speciosa complex, but is distinguished by its green body, pink rhinophores and oral tentacles, and its orange-tipped purple cerata.
taxon_text_8_8850:
Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 564).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 88).
taxon_text_9_8806: Catriona speciosa Macnae, 1954: unaccepted; Cuthona speciosa (Macnae, 1954): unaccepted (superseded combination). Note that WORMS identifies this species as Trinchesia speciosa, in the family Trinchesiidae, which Terry Gosliner says is erroneous.
taxon_text_1_8807: A tiny to small orange-bodied aeolid with orange-tipped turquoise cerata. The head is orange with short orange oral tentacles. The rhinophores are orange. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and orange.
taxon_text_3_8809:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Central West Coast to southern Wild Coast, intertidal to 35 m.
taxon_text_4_8810: Found on temperate reefs. Not much else known about the biology of this poorly known species.
taxon_text_5_8811: This species feeds on various species of hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8812: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a small upright spiral collar of orange eggs.
taxon_text_7_8813: The species can be confused with other species in the Tenellia cf. speciosa complex, but is distinguished by its orange body, rhinophores and oral tentacles, and its orange-tipped turquoise cerata.
taxon_text_8_8814:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 116).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 566, 793).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 152).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 88).
taxon_text_9_8815:
Catriona speciosa Macnae, 1954: unaccepted; Cuthona speciosa (Macnae, 1954): unaccepted (superseded combination)

Note that WoRMS identifies this species as Trinchesia speciosa, in the family Trinchesiidae, which Terry Gosliner says is erroneous.
taxon_text_1_8816: A small, orange- to yellow-bodied aeolid with orange- or yellow-tipped black-bordered blue cerata. The head is orange with short orange oral tentacles. The rhinophores are darker orange with pale tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and orange.
taxon_text_3_8818:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Central West Coast to southern Wild Coast, intertidal to 40 m.
taxon_text_4_8819: Found on temperate reefs on sea cucumbers. Not much else known about the biology of this poorly-known species.
taxon_text_5_8820: This species feeds on various species of hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8821: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8822: The species can be confused with other species in the Tenellia cf. speciosa complex, but is distinguished by its orange or yellow body, rhinophores and oral tentacles, and its orange- or yellow-tipped black-bordered blue cerata.
taxon_text_8_8823: Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 566).
taxon_text_9_8824:
Catriona speciosa Macnae, 1954: unaccepted; Cuthona speciosa (Macnae, 1954): unaccepted (superseded combination)

Note that WoRMS identifies this species as Trinchesia speciosa, in the family Trinchesiidae, which Terry Gosliner says is erroneous.
taxon_text_1_8825: A tiny, orange-bodied aeolid with white-tipped blue cerata. The head is orange with short pale-tipped pink oral tentacles. The rhinophores are pink with orange bases and pale tips. The posterior end of the foot is tapered, orange and pale-tipped.
taxon_text_3_8827:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay, intertidal to 39 m.
taxon_text_4_8828: Found on temperate reefs. Not much else known about the biology of this poorly-known species.
taxon_text_5_8829: This species is thought to feed on hydroids.
taxon_text_6_8830: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colour not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8831: The species can be confused with other species in the Tenellia cf. speciosa complex, but is distinguished by its orange body, pale-tipped pink rhinophores and oral tentacles, and its white-tipped blue cerata.
taxon_text_8_8832:
Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 568).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 152).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 88).
taxon_text_9_8851: Initially misidentified as the European species Tergipes tergipes, from which it is genetically distinct.
taxon_text_1_8852: A tiny, pale-bodied aeolid with transparent white-tipped cerata and a tan-coloured digestive duct visible within them. The head has short smooth oral tentacles; the oral tentacles are translucent with opaque white flecks and tan to greenish patches. The rhinophores are smooth, longer than the oral tentacles, and are also translucent and flecked with opaque white. The digestive duct is visible within the notum, branching to each ceras. There is a single ceras on each ceratal row, and the cerata may have darker flecks on them. The digestive duct may be greyish or brown. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and usually has opaque white flecks.
taxon_text_3_8854:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to the western side of False Bay, surface to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_8855: Often seen in association with the Silver-taloned roundhead, Tergipes sp.2. Found on the campanularid hydroids that grow on the Bamboo kelp, Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_5_8856: This species feeds on the campanularid hydroids that grow on the Bamboo kelp, Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_6_8857: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg mass is a small sphere of distinct white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8858: The species can be confused with the Silver-taloned roundhead, Tergipes sp.2, but is distinguished by the oval white cnidosacs at the ceratal tips.
taxon_text_8_8859:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 119).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 546, 791).
taxon_text_1_8861: A tiny pale- to golden orange-bodied aeolid with transparent silver-tipped cerata. The head has short smooth oral tentacles; the oral tentacles are translucent with minute golden orange flecks. The rhinophores are smooth, longer than the oral tentacles, and are also translucent and flecked with golden orange and opaque white. The head may have patches and streaks of opaque white. The notum may also have patches and streaks of opaque white. The digestive duct is visible within the notum, branching to each ceras. There is a single ceras on each ceratal row. The cerata have golden orange flecks, and sometimes also flecks of opaque white. The cnidosaces at the ceratal tips are thin, almost linear in shape. The posterior end of the foot is tapered and translucent.
taxon_text_3_8863:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Both sides of the Cape Peninsula, 2 m.
taxon_text_4_8864: Often seen in association with the White-taloned roundhead, Tergipes sp.1. Found on the campanularid hydroids that grow on the Bamboo kelp, Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_5_8865: This species feeds on the campanularid hydroids that grow on the Bamboo kelp, Ecklonia maxima.
taxon_text_6_8866: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg mass is a small ovoid  of distinct white eggs.
taxon_text_7_8867: The species can be confused with the White-taloned roundhead, Tergipes sp.1, but is distinguished by the golden orange coloration and the silver-tipped cerata with narrow cnidosacs. It can also be confused with the Amber roundhead, Eubranchus sp.15, but the ceratal shape and silver-tipped cerata are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8868:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 117).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 546, 791).
taxon_text_1_8870: A small, white-bodied dorid with black spots and orange markings and appendages. The rhinophores are orange with white tips and are surrounded by furled white sheaths, also with orange markings and white tips. The head is blunt-ended and has a pair of short white oral tentacles. The gills are white with orange and black spots. A pair of white extrabranchial papillae flanks the gills. The papillae have a broad orange band, white tips and black spots. The posterior end of the foot has a central orange streak and may have black blotches.
taxon_text_3_8872:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast of South Africa to southern KwaZulu-Natal, intertidal to at least 25 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8873: Usually observed on rocky reefs. Not much else known about the biology of this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8875: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a dense white rosette.
taxon_text_7_8876: This species can be confused with the Giraffe-spot pump dorid, Ancula sp., but is distinguished by its smaller black blotches and orange rather than yellow extrabranchial appendages.
taxon_text_8_8877:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 95).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 214).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 57).
taxon_text_1_8879: A medium- to large-sized cladobranch, peach-coloured with multiple bushy cream-coloured secondary gills. The oral veil has long pointed papillae. The rhinophores are cream-coloured and have a central crown of papillae surrounding a longer single stalk. The rhinophoral sheaths are widely flared with a pale rim. The notum has clusters of scattered opaque white spots in paired patches. There is a narrow opaque white margin. The foot is peach-coloured with an opaque white margin. Juveniles are pale, translucent and smooth-bodied. There is a narrow opaque white marginal line which extends to the rhinophoral sheaths.
taxon_text_3_8881:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Eastern Cape, 5–137 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8882: This species is usually found on reefs, in association with soft corals and sponges.
taxon_text_5_8883: Thought to prey on the Multicoloured sea fan, Melithaea rubra.
taxon_text_6_8884: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8885: The peach coloration with opaque white spots is distinctive, as is the opaque white marginal line. Juveniles can be confused with pale morphs of the Purple soft coral lacedragon, Marionia sp.7, but are distinguished by having longer papillae on the oral veil, the smooth notum and the opaque white marginal line on widely flared rhinophoral sheaths.
taxon_text_8_8886:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 108).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 458).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 146).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 73).
taxon_text_1_8888: A small pink- to cream-bodied dorid. The rhinophores are white to cream. The margin of the notum has a band of opaque white mantle glands. The gills are cream to white. The foot is pink to cream with a pale margin. Individuals on the western side of False Bay tend to be cream-coloured; further east the pink morph is more common.
taxon_text_3_8890:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Wildside of Algoa Bay, to 19 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8891: On temperate reefs usually associated with a spiky pink sponge on which it is quite camouflaged.
taxon_text_5_8892: Thought to feed on the spiky pink sponge.
taxon_text_6_8893: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and coloration not yet known.
taxon_text_8_8895:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 77).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 304).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 43).
taxon_text_1_8897: A small brown dorid with irregular white lines. The rhinophores are brown with dull red tips. There is a pair of smooth brown extrarhinophoral appendages. The gills are brown, and are flanked by a pair of brown extrabranchial appendages. The posterior end of the foot is tapered, and brown with white lines.
taxon_text_3_8899:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to Knysna, intertidal to 20 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8900: Usually found on sponges with commensal goblet worms (entoprocts). Has been seen in the intertidal in association with bryozoans.
taxon_text_6_8902: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is white, coiled, and large compared with body size.
taxon_text_7_8903: The species can be confused with the Scribbled sucking dorid, Doriopsilla sp.1, but is distinguished by its extrarhinophoral and extrabranchial appendages, and by having a more narrow, elongate body shape.
taxon_text_8_8904:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 94).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 396, 803).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 55).
taxon_text_1_8915: A small to medium-sized white-bodied dorid with a variable band of brown speckling across the middle of the notum, scattered brown spots and indistinct low opaque white tubercles. The head is white with pale rhinophores. The saddle may extend across the notum, or be visible only on the sides of the animal; in some cases the saddle may be very faint or even absent. The brown spots are of varying sizes. In some individuals the notum may have indistinct darker patches. The gills are creamy white. The posterior end of the foot is rounded and has scattered brown spots.
taxon_text_3_8917:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay, down to 20 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8918: Found on rocky reefs associated with sponges. Not much else known about the biology of this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8920: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8921: This species can be confused with several of the dalmatian dorids, but the saddle is diagnostic when it is present. It is hard to distinguish from the Brown-dotted toothy dorid, Cadlina sp.2, when the saddle is absent, although the spots tend to be dark brown rather than the black spots of Cadlina sp.2.
taxon_text_8_8922:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 85).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 122).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 138).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 46).
taxon_text_1_8924: A small white-bodied dorid with scattered dark brown to black spots and low opaque white tubercles. The head is white with pale rhinophores. The dark brown spots are of varying sizes. In some individuals the notum may have indistinct darker patches. The gills are creamy white. The posterior end of the foot is rounded and has scattered dark brown spots.
taxon_text_3_8926:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, down to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8927: Found on rocky reefs, usually associated with sponges. Not much else known on the biology of this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8929: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8930:
This species can be confused with several of the dalmatian dorids, and particularly with individuals of the Saddled toothy dorid, Cadlina sp.1, when the saddle is absent, although the spots tend to be black rather than the dark brown spots of Cadlina sp.1.

Genetic studies show this lineage of dorids to be distinct from the population of Cadlina sp.1 found in False Bay and that it appears to be restricted to the Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_8_8931:

taxon_text_1_8978: A cryptic medium-sized rough-bodied dorid. The body is peach-coloured with dark peach speckling and opaque white tubercles. The head has multiple branched cephalic tentacles. The rhinophores are stalked and perfoliate. There is a band of branched papillae posterior to the rhinophores. The margins of the notum have several paired branched appendages. The gills are peach-coloured with opaque white edging. The posterior end of the foot is tapered with a low central ridge of short branched papillae.
taxon_text_3_8980:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Wild Coast, 25 – >100 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8981: Mostly seen on reefs in deep water, rarely seen. Usually associated with bryozoans and coralline algae.
taxon_text_5_8982: Not yet known for this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8983: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8984: The peach coloration, tasselled appearance and relatively large size are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8985:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 98).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 204).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 142).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 61).
taxon_text_1_8942: A small to medium-sized rough-bodied brown dorid with indistinct brown blotches. The head has dark pale-tipped rhinophores. The notum has minute tubercles and is dull orange to yellow brown with darker brown blotches. The gills match the body coloration and are sometimes retracted. The posterior end of the foot is rounded. Pale morphs are sometimes seen.
taxon_text_3_8944:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape to Eastern Cape, intertidal to 20 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8945: Usually seen shallow reefs, associated with sponges.
taxon_text_5_8946: Probably feeds on various species of sponges.
taxon_text_6_8947: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8948: This species can be confused with the Fluffy pump dorid, Acanthodoris planca, or the Warty true dorid, Doris granosa, but the minute tubercles combined with dark blotches are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8949:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 65).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 126).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 33).
taxon_text_1_8780: A small to medium-sized dorid usually black with a blue margin or brown with a purple margin. The head has a dark blue or purple anterior margin. The rhinophores are dark with blue or purple tips and bases. There is a lobed blue or purple mouth. The body surface is wrinkled and the genital pore is blue or purple. The gills are black or brown. The posterior end of the foot is tapered, and with narrow blue or purple marginal lines meeting towards the tip. The margin is blue or purple. A rare orange morph with purple margin and gills has been seen.
taxon_text_3_8782:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Wild Coast, intertidal to at least 38 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8783: Common species frequently seen on rocky reefs. Often seen on the Blue dentate bryozoan, Viridentula dentata and the Elegant feather star, Tropiometra carinata.
taxon_text_5_8784: Feeds on a wide range of bryozoan species.
taxon_text_6_8785: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a vivid yellow-orange upright collar of several whorls.
taxon_text_7_8786: The blue or purple margin to the upper margin is distinctive.
taxon_text_8_8787:

taxon_text_1_8951: A small round-bodied dorid with scattered dark spots surrounded by pale haloes. The rhinophores are cream. The body colour varies from pale to dark purple in dense dots. The margin is often pale and the dark spots are often larger towards the centre of the notum. The gills are creamy and the posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8953:
Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay, intertidal to 15 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8954: Usually on reefs close to sponges or feather stars.
taxon_text_6_8956: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat spiral of widely spaced yellow- to cream-coloured eggs.
taxon_text_7_8957: This species can be confused with the Galaxy toothy dorid, Cadlina sp.3, but is distinguished by pale haloes surrounding the dark spots.
taxon_text_8_8958:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 70).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 162, 806).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 39).
taxon_text_1_8933: A small to medium-sized blue or grey dorid with dark spots rimmed by a halo of densely clustered white speckling. The head has cream-coloured rhinophores that emerge from distinct pockets. The notum may be blue-grey to pale cream or dark purple. The dark spots are often in regular rows. The gills are creamy. The posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8935:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay, southern Cape, Wildside of Algoa Bay, 5–39 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8936: Usually found on shallow reefs, associated with sponges and crustose coralline algae. Not much else known about the biology of this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8938: The species is hermaphrodite. The egg ribbon is an upright white rosette of several turns.
taxon_text_7_8939: This species can be confused with the Ocellate granular dorid, Gargamella gravastella, but the white-speckled haloes surrounding the dark spots are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8940:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 86).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 124).
taxon_text_9_8959: Gargamella sp.2 Gosliner 87, Aphelodoris sp.2 Zsilavecz 2007, Jones 2008, Brown-spot dorid, Brown-spotted nudibranch
taxon_text_1_8960: A medium-sized, white-bodied dorid with scattered brown spots. The rhinophores are cream to white. The notum has minute white granules and the brown spots may be irregular and are varied in size. The margin has a variable band of opaque white spots. Some variants have patches of pale and golden brown. The gills are creamy white and the posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8962:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, False Bay, southern Cape, 10–40 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8963: Usually found on offshore reefs close to sponges, bryozoans and coralline algae.
taxon_text_6_8965: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8966: This species is easy to confuse with several of the dalmatian dorids, but the minute white granules combined with varied brown patches are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8967:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 71).

taxon_text_9_8968: Doris johnstoni Alder & Hancock, 1845 unaccepted; Doris obvelata G. Johnston, 1838 unaccepted; Doris philippii Weinkauff, 1873 unaccepted (dubious synonym); Doris tomentosa Cuvier, 1804 unaccepted (original combination); Jorunna johnstoni (Alder & Hancock, 1845) unaccepted; Jorunna johnstoni var. alba Bergh, 1881 unaccepted.
taxon_text_1_8969:
A medium-sized velvety textured dorid in cream, grey or purple, sometimes with darker spots. The rhinophores match the body coloration but have darker tips. The notum is covered with minute elongated caryophyllidia*. The spots, when present, are irregularly distributed and varied in size. The gills match the body coloration, but can be paler; and the posterior end of the foot is rounded.

*Caryophyllidia: structures on dorid nudibranchs consisting of a ring of spines around a central specialised tubercle, possibly having a sensory function, since each has an individual nerve leading to the tip of the tubercle.
taxon_text_3_8971:
Global: North Atlantic, Mediterranean and South Africa

Local/Regional: southern West Coast to the Knysna Lagoon, intertidal to 20 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8972: Often found on various species of seaweeds. Also found grouping together in large numbers in tidal pools.
taxon_text_5_8973: Feeds on sponges, particularly turret sponges in the genus Haliclona.
taxon_text_6_8974: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a messy wavy cream-coloured rosette.
taxon_text_7_8975: This species can be confused with the Blotchy tentacled dorid, Geitodoris capensis, but is distinguished by its velvety texture and lack of blotches.
taxon_text_8_8976:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 70).
