taxon_text_1_9005: A large, variably-coloured sidegill slug: the body may be golden-brown, maroon, pinkish or cream-coloured. The head has a pair of rolled rhinophores set close together and a short oral veil. The body is covered with variably-sized tubercles, some of which may have dark tips. The tubercles sometimes have pale outlines at their bases. The body may have spots or patches of different colours. There is a single gill on the right hand side of the body under the mantle. The foot has reticulated patterning and short tubercles. The posterior end of the foot is rounded. A pale morph with yellow-banded rhinophores and very dark-tipped tubercles is found on the Atlantic side of the peninsula.
taxon_text_3_9007:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the south of the Wild Coast, found from the intertidal to 30 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_9008: Found under rocks and on rocky reefs and sand, probably nocturnal. The species is sporadically common.
taxon_text_5_9009: It may prey on sponges and ascidians.
taxon_text_6_9010: Individuals are hermaphroditic and produce large cream-coloured egg ribbons in a highly folded rosette.
taxon_text_7_9011: This species is similar to Pleurobranchus albiguttatus, the White-spotted pleurobranch, known from the Wild Coast and northwards, but it lacks white spots. It is also similar to Pleurobranchus grandis, the Giant pleurobranch, a tropical species that is sometimes swept into False Bay by gyres of the Agulhas Current, but the variably-sized tubercles and lack of distinct pale reticulation on the body are distinctive.
taxon_text_8_9012:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 58).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 72, 801).

taxon_text_1_8996: A small to medium-sized tan-bodied sidegill slug: the body is relatively smooth skinned. The head has a pair of rolled rhinophores set widely apart and a short, laterally flared oral veil. The body has indistinct dark reticulated patterning and may have opaque white flecks. There is a single gill on the right hand side of the body under the mantle. The posterior end of the foot is rounded and usually speckled with opaque white.
taxon_text_3_8998:
Global: Known from the northern Atlantic Ocean and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the south coast, found from the intertidal to 60 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8999: Found on rocky reefs, usually on various species of seaweeds.
taxon_text_6_9001: Individuals are hermaphroditic and produce an egg ribbon consisting of a short hollow tube of tiny white eggs.
taxon_text_7_9002: This species is similar to the Warty pleurobranch, Pleurobranchaea bubala, and is readily confused with juveniles of P. bubala, but it is smaller and has a relatively smoother skin. Its depth range also extends deeper.
taxon_text_8_9003:

taxon_text_1_8987: A small slightly rough-textured dorid with small dark spots. The head is white with pale rhinophores. The notum is also white with tiny bumps and scattered dark spots of relatively equal size. The density of the spotting may vary. Individuals may also have minute opaque white speckling. The gills are white and the posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8989:
Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula, western False Bay, Algoa Bay, subtidal to at least 15 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8990: Usually found on rocky reefs associated with sponges. Not much else known about the biology of this undescribed species.
taxon_text_6_8992: This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
taxon_text_7_8993: This species is easy to confuse with several of the dalmatian dorids, but the small dark spots are a main diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8994:
Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 64).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 132).

taxon_text_9_8662: Doridium capense Bergh, 1907: unaccepted > superseded combination; identified as Algaia capensis in Day, 1969; Slipper slug
taxon_text_1_8663: A small to medium-sized brown headshield slug. The body is slender, brown to tan, and covered with cream mottling. The headshield covers more than half of the body and  turns upwards like the lip of a slipper towards the posterior. The headshield has a narrow yellow marginal line and occasional yellow-orange stripes. It may also have darker bluish patches. The parapodia have a discontinuous dark submarginal band, discontinuous yellow stripes and occasional dark blotches. The posterior end of the foot has asymmetrical paired lobes with dark marginal banding.
taxon_text_3_8665:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to the Wild Coast, intertidal to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_8666: This species is usually found in sandy areas, and may also be found in tidal pools and estuaries.
taxon_text_5_8667: Thought to feed on other heterobranchs and flatworms.
taxon_text_6_8668: This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a translucent, hollow, and sausage-shaped.
taxon_text_7_8669: At the western end of this species' range, the coloration and upturned back of the headshield are distinctive. Towards the eastern end of the range, however, the species may be confused with the Beautiful swallowtail, Philinopsis speciosa, but the brown ground coloration and cream mottling are diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_8670:

taxon_text_1_3476:
Blennies are a diverse group of small, elongate, benthic fish that lack scales and usually have a blunt face with eyes placed close together high on the head and a prominent cirrus above each. The dorsal fin runs almost the full body length and is separated into an anterior spined section and a posterior rayed section. The pelvic fins are placed far forward, anterior to the bases of pectoral fins, and are reduced to one spine and a few rays.

Blennies are usually found sitting propped up on their pelvic fins in tide pools or on shallow reefs and sand and are very diverse and abundant on more tropical shores, with only a few species extending in the Western Cape.

This species has a prominent orange-red cirrus above each eye consisting of a central elongate tapering filament, from the base of which several other filaments emerge. In males the cirrus is larger than in females and it can be bright red.  Head large and very blunt with large mouth bearing thick lips. Body mottles brown with fleshy fins (specially pectorals) and numerous dark spots, typically arranged into about 5-6 dark bars.
taxon_text_3_3478:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_3479: Typically found under rocks or hiding in cracks and crevices and occurs from the intertidal to depths of about 20 m. Cryptic and skittish, so not often seen.
taxon_text_5_3480: Unknown at species level, but blennies typically feed on small invertebrates, possibly also algae.
taxon_text_6_3481: Sticky, translucent eggs are laid attached to the substratum by a filamentous pad. Juveniles are planktonic and often found in shallow coastal waters.
taxon_text_7_3482:
Few other blennies occur in the region and can be distinguished by the form of the cirri. The Maned blenny Scarletta emarginata has a distinctive mane-like row of cirri on the top of the head, in addition to those above the eyes. The Two-eyed blenny Chalaroderma ocellata has white cirri that have a central stalk and distal branches. That species also has a distinct eye spot just behind the actual eye (hence two-eyed).

Blennies can also be confused with klipfishes and triplefins, which have similar habits and reduced pelvic fins, but these families have more elongate faces.
taxon_text_8_3483:
Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 230).

Levy, A, Von der Heyden, S, Floeter, SR, Bernardi, G & Almada, VC (2013). Phylogeny of Parablennius Miranda Ribeiro, 1915 reveals a paraphyletic genus and recent Indo-Pacific diversification from an Atlantic ancestor. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, 67(1), 1-8.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 752).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 53).
taxon_text_1_5291:
Members of this unusual group are small, soft-bodied barnacles that lack their own shells, but instead occupy burrows excavated into other calcareous substrata, particularly mollusk shells (but also sometimes corals, limestone and even coralline algae). Sexes are separate (unlike other barnacles, which are hermaphroditic), but males are minute, non-feeding and live attached to the much larger females.

This species can be distinguished by its bottle-shaped body, long ‘neck’ and small, circular aperture. The body and feeding appendages are white to light red.
taxon_text_2_5292: Female up to 3 mm, aperture less than 1mm, males 0.4 mm
taxon_text_3_5293:
Global: Endemic

Local/Regional: Found only in SW Cape, from about Paternoster to Hermanus.
taxon_text_4_5294: Females excavate burrows in the shells of various larger gastropod molluscs, especially Turban shells (Turbo sarmarticus, and T. cidaris)  which may host up to 100 females per individual host. Much smaller numbers also recovered from Burnupena, Haliotis, Fucinus, and Crepidula shells. The burrow openings are very small and hence easily missed, so the species is probably much more common than present records suggest. There may be up to 17 dwarf males attached to each female.
taxon_text_5_5295: Females feed by projecting their feather-like limbs through the burrow opening and combing them through the water.
taxon_text_6_5296: Most barnacles are hermaphroditic, but burrowing barnacles are unusual in having separate sexes, the males being tiny, non-feeding and attached to the much larger females. In this group the early larvae are brooded inside the mantle cavity and later released to seek out new hosts.
taxon_text_7_5297: Replaced by the similar Australophialus utinomii in the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal. In the Western Cape may occur in the same shells as the larger and very common Weltneria spinosa; but that species is bright red, has a short neck and larger oval ‘boat-shaped’ aperture from which a pair of distinct hook-like processes project.
taxon_text_8_5298: Botha, TPA & Griffiths, CL (2021). South African Acrothoracia (Crustacea: Cirripedia). Zootaxa, 4949 (1), 048–078.
taxon_text_1_1766: This is a striking species easily distinguished from other regional feather stars by its 10 long, straight, upward-directed arms, which each bear up to 100 regularly-spaced lateral branches (pinnules) – each arm thus looking much like the flight feather of a bird! On the underside there are 20-30 long, robust cirri. Colour is usually dominantly yellow with various brown patches.
taxon_text_3_1768:
Global: Widespread in tropical Atlantic and Indian Oceans.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1769:
Usually seen singly or in scattered groups perched in shallow reefs, sometimes among other, smaller feather stars. Like most feather stars, if displaced is capable of swimming using a slow, graceful up and down movement of the arms. As the name suggests, the arms are brittle and easily broken off, but are quickly regenerated. Individuals with some shorter arms, or a reduced number of arms, are this regularly encountered.

Commensal organisms, such as the myzostomid worm Myzostoma fuscomaculatum and the crinoid shrimp Hippolyte catagrapha, are sometimes found on the arms.
taxon_text_5_1770: The arms are extended upwards into the water column to intercept floating plankton of other organic particles. Each pinnule is lined with tubefeet, which are held erect to form a mesh. The tubefeet grasp passing particles and pass them to an ambulacral groove running along the length of the arm, along which cilia propel a sting of mucus and food particles to the mouth, which is situated on the upper surface of the central disc. A fairly simple U-shaped gut fills most of the small body and ends in an anus that is raised on a cone close to the mouth and also on the upper surface.
taxon_text_6_1771: Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and the gonads are located in the basal pinnules, rather than in the small body itself. When the gametes are mature the pinnules rupture and release the eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Newly settled larvae are stalked (like may fossil crinoids), but the stalk is lost as they enter the adult stage.
taxon_text_7_1772: The rigid arms and the densely packed, straight pinnules readily distinguish this species from other common regional feather stars, which have thin, usually curled arms with fewer, more widely-spaced pinnules (more like a birds body-feather then a flight feather). A second much larger species, T. magnifica, which arms up to 300 mm in length, is found in deeper waters. It can also be distinguished by the fact that the arms are dorsally rounded, whereas in T. carinata they bear a prominent dorsal keel (hence its scientific name).
taxon_text_8_1773:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 228).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 17).

Hempson, TN & Griffiths, CL (2008). Symbionts of comatulid crinoids in False Bay, South Africa. African Zoology, 43(2), 237-244.
taxon_text_9_1755: Often spelt with a single ‘i’ but we follow WoRMS spelling here by giving a double ‘i’. The subspecies given by Clark and Courtman- Stock are no longer recognized.
taxon_text_1_1756: This species has between 10 and 22 (but usually 16-20) rather slender arms that are held curved over the body. Each arm has only 10-22 regularly-spaced lateral branches (pinnules). On the upper surface of the body the ambulacral grooves converge on the mouth, which is situated distinctly off-centre, whereas the anus (situated on a conical process) occupies the central position. On the underside there 12-25 fairly-stout attachment cirri. Colour is extremely variable, ranging from white to pink, blue or orange and often variegated.
taxon_text_3_1758:
Global: Widespread across Indian and Pacific Oceans.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_1759: Found in low intertidal pools and under rocks and overhangs, but most abundant on shallow reefs, where it can occur in the open in dense and extensive beds, often mixed with the similar-looking Southern feather-star Annamatra occidentalis, with which it is often confused (see below). Like most feather stars capable of swimming using a slow, graceful up and down movement of the arms if displaced from the reef. As the group name suggests, the arms are brittle and easily broken, but are quickly regenerated. Individuals with some shorter arms, or a reduced number of arms, are thus regularly encountered.
taxon_text_5_1760: The arms are extended upwards into the water column to intercept floating plankton of other organic particles. Each pinnule is lined with tubefeet, which are held erect to form a mesh. The tubefeet grasp passing particles and pass them to an ambulacral groove running along the length of the arm, along which cilia propel a string of mucus and food particles to the mouth, which is situated on the upper surface of the central disc. A fairly simple U-shaped gut fills most of the small body and ends in an anus that is raised on a cone close to the mouth and also on the upper surface.
taxon_text_6_1761: Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and the gonads are located in the basal pinnules, rather than in the small body itself. When the gametes are mature the pinnules rupture and release the eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Newly settled larvae are stalked (like many fossil crinoids), but the stalk is lost as they enter the adult stage.
taxon_text_7_1762: Easily confused with the Southern feather-star Annametra occidentalis but usually has more arms (10-22, but usually 16-20, vs 10). Also that species has the mouth central and the anal cone displaced to one side of the upper body surface. The two species are most easily distinguished by the very different number of ventral cirri, which are 12-25 in C. wahlberghii and 35-40 in A. occidentalis. In practice though, very few photographers turn specimens over and count their cirri, so the identity of species in , many published images is suspect! It would be a valuable study to properly identify the distribution patterns of these two species and to determine the relative abundances, size ranges and habitat preferences (and to record the range and proportions of different arm numbers and colour forms in each species).
taxon_text_8_1763:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 228).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 11).
taxon_text_1_5421: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating on its dorsal side, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Wide girdle covered with brownish clear, straight spines at the top margin, and smaller ones pressed together at the bottom, making this species easily distinguishable. When turned over, gills extend halfway along the foot. Middle plates sharpen to the hind margin. Texture of shell centrally with radial ribs and with flattened granules on the sides. Colour light beige with brown on small shell plates. Articulamentum whitish pink and with a slight gap between the two anterior shell extensions.
taxon_text_2_5422: Small, typically around 5-10 mm total body length.
taxon_text_3_5423:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Melkbosstrand to Bhanga Nek.
taxon_text_4_5424: Between rocks and crevices in the Intertidal zone, discrete and camouflaged, never exposed.
taxon_text_5_5425: Herbivorous - radula rasping algae off the rocks.
taxon_text_6_5426: External fertilization releasing eggs and sperm into the water. Eggs develop into planktonic trochohore larvae that settle as metamorphosized juvenile chitons.
taxon_text_7_5427: The related A. garnoti occurs from Saldanha Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal and has much shorter and bent tuft spines and marginal fringe spines. Granules on shell of A. variegata are flatter and more spread out than in A. garnoti. Less common.
taxon_text_8_5428:
Ashby, E (1928). South African chitons, being a description of the Polyplacophora represented in the Turton Collection. Proceedings of the Malacological Society of London, 18 (2), 76-92. (p. 79, pl. 6, figs 1-4 as Acanthochiton tortoni).

Els, M & Els, R (2022).On the variegata trail: finding a cryptic South African chiton beauty: Acanthochitona variegata.

Nierstrasz, HF (1906). Beiträge zur Kenntnis der Fauna von Süd-Afrika. VI. Chitonen aus der Kapkololonie [sic] und Natal. Zoologische Jahrbücher, Abteilung für Systematik, Geographie und Biologie der Tiere, 23, 487–520.
taxon_text_1_10:
Overall colour off-white with brown dorsal marking on each segment, eyes white with dark centre, first antennae much shorter than second. First pair of nippers small, second pair small in females but greatly enlarged in males, palm of the hand with a small, semi-circular excision near attachment of finger. Walking legs splayed to the side to support the animal upright in air, in males last two pairs of legs greatly elongated and basal segments greatly expanded into large posterior lobes. First two abdominal segments in males each with a single pair of triangular dorsal projections.

Also distinguished from most other amphipods by its terrestrial, air-breathing habits and ability to leap high into the air when disturbed.
taxon_text_3_12:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Knysna.
taxon_text_4_13: Found on sandy beaches, particularly those where large amounts of wrack are washed ashore. Normally remains buried in the sand by day to avoid heat and desiccation and emerges at night, or during cool-moist weather, to feed in the open on drift algae. When disturbed can leap high into the air, landing clumsily and staggering back into an upright position. At some sites populations may extend well above high watermark and into the dunes. There have been numerous reports of beach hoppers invading coastal properties in large numbers and dying in drifts inside homes. Some home-owners even erect barricades to keep them out!
taxon_text_5_14: Feed on drift algae under which they shelter and can be remarkably effective in consuming drift kelp when present in large numbers.
taxon_text_6_15: Like in all amphipods eggs are deposited into a brood pouch between the legs of the females, where they are fertilised by males and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.
taxon_text_7_16:
Co-occurs with another much more common beach-hopper Capeorchestia capensis, which has entirely black eyes. Males of that species  also lack the greatly elongated last two pairs of legs, these lacking expanded basal joints and they have smooth first two abdominal segments. It is not known how these two species interact and share the same habitat and food resources.

Replaced east of Cape Agulhas by another similar species, A. meridionalis, but this has two pairs of dorsal spines of the second abdominal segment and one pair each on segments 1 and 3. Also replaced in Northern Namibia by the similar T. skoogi, which is distinguished by the shape of the second pair of nippers and also has dorsal spines on all three abdominal segments.
taxon_text_8_17:
Lowry, JK & Baldanzi. S (2016). New talitrids from South Africa (Amphipoda, Senticaudata, Talitroidea, Talitridae) with notes on their ecology. Zootaxa 4144(2), 151-174.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 98).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 81).
taxon_text_1_2316: Shell small and globular with a fairly short spire and a round, horny operculum. External colour usually pale brown with darker flecks and a darker band around centre of each whorl, but sometimes almost completely black. The unusual habitat in the uppermost parts of the intertidal is also useful identification feature.
taxon_text_3_2318:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_2319:
A very well-known and abundant species that dominates the upper part of the intertidal on rocky shores, which is named the ‘Littorina zone’ as a result. Congregates out of water in large numbers in cracks and crevices and in any similar sheltered locations during low tide and during the heat of the day, emerging at night, or on moist days, to feed on lichens and microscopic algae on the rocks.

There is generally a size gradient within the population, with smaller individuals occurring higher on the shore to avoid severe wave action. As they grow, and are able to attach more firmly, they migrate lower on the shore, where food resources are richer.

Growth is fairly rapid, with a shell length of about 6-7 mm being attained in the first year and maximum length of about 10 mm after 3 years. Growth is slowest in winter and faster in spring or summer, probably as a result of greater food availability in the warmer months.

Can often be seen hanging from the rock surface via a sticky patch of mucus attached to the margin of the aperture, indeed may form ‘stacks’ several layers tall in this way, in an attempt to distance the body from the heat of the rocks!

At high spring tides individuals lower on the shore are often seen being consumed by the predatory dog whelk Nucella dubia, which grasps the periwinkle and drills a hole through its operculum, a process that takes several hours.
taxon_text_5_2320: Browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.
taxon_text_6_2321: Littorinids exhibit several modes or reproduction - in some species the larvae develop inside the mantle cavity and emerge as crawling juveniles, in others egg cases are released into the plankton and in yet another benthic egg capsules are attached to algae or rock. As no egg capsules, nor brooded young, have been observed in this species it is assumed they release egg capsules into the water column. Settlement appears to take place throughout the year and sexual maturity is attained within the first year of life, at a size of about 5 mm.
taxon_text_7_2322: The habitat – usually out of water and in the highest levels of exposed rocky shores – is fairly diagnostic and separates this species from most other small periwinkles. Progressively replaced along the south coast by the more tropical Littorina africana, which has similar habits, but is squatter in shape and blue-grey in colour, with a brown aperture.
taxon_text_8_2323:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

McQuaid, CD (1981a). The establishment and maintenance of vertical size gradients in populations of Littorina africana knysnaensis (Philippi) on an exposed rocky shore. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 54(1), 77-89.

McQuaid, CD (1981b). Population dynamics of Littorina africana knysnaensis (Philippi) on an exposed rocky shore. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 54(1), 65-76.

McQuaid, CD (1985). Differential effects of predation by the intertidal whelk Nucella dubia (Kr.) on Littorina africana knysnaensis (Phillipi) and the barnacle Tetraclita serrata Darwin. Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 89(2-3), 97-107.
taxon_text_1_4520: Elegant, cream or yellow upright stems emerge from a root-like base and give rise to closely-placed alternating side branches, giving a feather-like appearance. The zooids emerge from cup-like protective hydrothecae along only the upper margin of each branch. Under the microscope these cups have strong marginal teeth and are protected by 3 tiny, spout-like nematothecae. The reproductive individuals are protected by delicate, pine-cone-like structure called corbula which are the most distinctive feature of this group.
taxon_text_2_4521: Vertical stems typically 30 mm tall but much longer in some branching varieties (which may in fact be different species).
taxon_text_3_4522:
Global: Very widely distributed, mostly across both North and South Atlantic Oceans and around South Africa to at least East London, but some records reported from Asia, Australia and Pacific coast of North America.

Local/Regional: Whole coast, intertidal to 100 m.
taxon_text_4_4523: Extremely common fouling species found in pools on rocky shore and on reefs to a depth of 100 m. As colony form is depicted to vary widely in terms of branching pattern (single stems to tree-like branching), height, and length of side branches (short, forming parallel-sided colony, to long and forming oval and leaflike colony), several similar species are probably conflated under this one name on the basis of the distinctive corbulae.
taxon_text_5_4524: Feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water column.
taxon_text_6_4525: Colonies expand by asexual reproduction, with new vertical branches arising from the expanding network of stems.  Larvae are released from the cone-like corbulae into the plankton and settle to form new colonies.
taxon_text_7_4526: Apparently widespread and common, but in reality, there may be several species under this one name, as colony shape varies widely as depicted in different regions and sources.
taxon_text_8_4527:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 54).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 30).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 60).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 411).
taxon_text_1_7466: Forms small, stiff clumps of laterally spreading or upright fronds that arise from a central holdfast. Axes branch several times and somewhat flattened. Tips of fronds often curled and slightly expanded. Colour red-brown.
taxon_text_2_7467: Axes about 40 mm long and about 1-2 mm wide. Clumps up to about 60 mm across.
taxon_text_4_7469: Attached in small clumps to rocks in low-shore pools and on shallow reefs, particularly in sand-inundated areas.
taxon_text_6_7471: Immersed carposporophytes alternating with crustose tetrasporophytes may be visible on erect axes.
taxon_text_7_7472: There are several similar regional species in this genus including A. glomerata, which has a similar distribution and habitat, but axes are much more strongly expanded, arched back and have flattened tips; also A. polyclada which is much taller (100 mm) with long, twiggy, cylindrical axes with divergent pointed tips.
taxon_text_8_7473:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 400).

Silva, PC & DeCew, TC (1992). Ahnfeltiopsis, a new genus in the Phyllophoraceae (Gigartinales, Rhodophyceae). Phycologia, 31, 576-580.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 341).
taxon_text_1_1706: The largest and most familiar starfish in the region. The five elongate, gradually-tapering arms are ornamented with longitudinal rows of conspicuous spines. Each spine is surrounded by a pale halo of small pincer-like pedicellaria that are used to keep the body surface clean. Between the spines the body surface is covered in small bubble-like papulae, which act as organs of gas exchange. Colour quite variable, but usually mottled light to dark purple or mauve with blueish or white markings.
taxon_text_3_1708:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_1709: Commonly seen on intertidal rocks and on shallow reefs, where it is a voracious predator of a variety of benthic invertebrates. Can become extremely common at times and sometimes seen in dense feeding–fronts advancing across reefs, eating all in their path! Also frequently washed up in large numbers after storms.
taxon_text_5_1710: Feed on a variety of both sedentary and mobile invertebrates. The population in False Bay feeds mostly on mussels, ascidians and barnacles. Mussels are attacked by pulling the two shell valves apart with the tube-feet and insinuating the stomach between the parted shell valves. The size of the mussels selected increases with the size of the predator and the mean time taken to consume each mussel is about 5 h.
taxon_text_6_1711: Sexes are separate and there are five gonads, one in each arm. Eggs and sperm are released into the water in mass spawning events and the fertilized eggs develop into planktonic larvae. In the European species maximum size is reached after about 5 years.
taxon_text_7_1712:
Unlikely to be mistaken for any other species due to its large size and spiny appearance, but can be confused with the similarly-coloured Many-armed  starfish Coscinasterias calamaria, although this usually has 8-10 arms, of which some are almost always much shorter than others.

Although originally described as a local, African species the regional form was merged with the European M. glacialis almost a century ago and only in 2016 did a more detailed analysis of morphological and genetic evidence prove that the South African population does indeed comprises a distinct species, leading to re-erection of the original name M. africana.
taxon_text_8_1713:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 226).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 94).

Penney, AJ & Griffiths, CL (1984). Prey selection and the impact of the starfish Marthasterias glacialis (L.) and other predators on the mussel Choromytilus meridionalis (Krauss). Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology, 75(1), 19-36.

Wright, AG Pérez-Portela, R & Griffiths, CL (2016). Determining the correct identity of South African Marthasterias (Echinodermata: Asteroidea). African Journal of Marine Science, 38(3), 443-455.
taxon_text_1_685: Large, attractive species. Column with about 15 rows of adhesive pads to which sand and debris adhere. Pads in regular longitudinal rows, with about 48 pads per row. Column colour very variable, including dark green or brown, orange, pink, blue or grey. Dark stripes usually radiate across the oral disc from the mouth to the bases of the 96 thick tentacles. Tentacles long and tapering, coming in a variety of pale colours, often with a broad longitudinal white stripe running along the length of each, or with irregular white spots.
taxon_text_2_686: Column diameter up to 55 mm, up to at least 150 mm with tentacles expanded.
taxon_text_3_687:
Global: Endemic to Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to northern KwaZulu-Natal, but more common on Atlantic coast.
taxon_text_4_688: A striking, large and well-known species that comes in a wide range of bright colours and forms beautiful patterns when open, making it a popular subject for photographers. Regularly found partially buried in sand in rock crevices and sandy pools from mid-shore down to about 10 m depth. Usually occurs singly with column buried in sand and tentacles widely extended across sand surface.
taxon_text_5_689:
A classic wait-and-see predator that occupies low-lying crevices beneath densely colonized reefs and feeds almost entirely on tumbled prey dislodged from adjacent rocks, or swept in by the waves. Tentacles triggered by touch after which stinging cells (nematocysts) inject their target with a paralysing neurotoxin. Prey then guided by tentacles through mouth into digestive cavity.

 The diet is diverse with the most frequently-consumed items being gastropods (67%), barnacles (24%) and bivalves (18%), but also takes various other crustacean groups, echinoderms and even algae.
taxon_text_6_690: Anemones can reproduce sexually, but can also divide by fission. In sexual reproduction mature gametes are released into the internal cavity (coelenteron) and then spawned through the mouth. The zygote then develops into planktonic planula larva. After development this settles on a substrate and develops into a juvenile anemone.
taxon_text_7_691:
Can be confused with the Sandy anemone Bunodactis reynaudi, which also has sticky pads on the column, occurs in a wide range of colours and lives in dense colonies in sandy habitats on the same shores. However, A. michaeleni usually occurs singly, has much fewer and longer tentacles than B. reynaudi and has a brightly patterned oral disc.

There are also two other less common and paler-coloured Anthopeura species in the region. In A. insignis the oral disc lacks a radial pattern of stripes, while A. anneae has only 6-10 rows of widely-spaced sticky pads along the column.
taxon_text_8_692:
Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Cape Town, SURG.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
taxon_text_1_9014:
Colony consists of a flat, white, lacelike sheet growing on floating objects, especially the shells of the cephalopod Spirula and of bubble-raft shells of the genus Janthina, but also on floating pieces of plastic, pumice and seeds, etc.

Examined closely the individual zooecia are arranged in a single layer like brick paving with each zooid oval to rectangular, with rounded or pointed tubercles on each of the corners.
taxon_text_2_9015: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 1-2 cm across.
taxon_text_3_9016:
Global: Widely distributed across subtropical and temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Whole region, usually washed ashore after storms.
taxon_text_4_9017: Commonly found in the open ocean on hard surfaces and often seen on the cast up shells of Spirula and Janthina. Few other details available.
taxon_text_5_9018: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_9019: Hermaphrodite. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites but details unknown.
taxon_text_7_9020: Closely related to the tuberculate lace animal J. tuberculata but that species is found only on the blades of algae, whereas this one occurs on shells and other hard surfaces.
taxon_text_8_9021: Taylor, PD & Monks, N (1997). A new cheilostome bryozoan genus pseudoplanktonic on molluscs and algae. Invertebrate biology, 39-51.
taxon_text_1_9104: Moderate to large muscular octopus with a broadly oval and saccular mantle. Arms long and robust, between 4–5.5 time length of the mantle. First and fourth arms shorter than arms 2 and 3. Each arm with about 220–320 suckers and both sexes with enlarged suckers on position 14 and 15 (counted from the mouth), larger in males. Shape, texture and colour extremely variable and can change entire appearance within seconds. Skin with a regular pattern of circular patches surrounded by groves. Entire body with erectile papillae of which the largest four papillae are arranged in a diamond shape on the mantle. One specifically long papillae above each eye.
taxon_text_2_9105: Typically, 15–20 cm mantle length, arms spanning to about 1 m, and up to 4 kg in weight.
taxon_text_3_9106:
Global distribution: Used to be considered a circumglobal, temperate to subtropical species. Now distribution of the true O. vulgaris restricted to European and north-west African waters including the Mediterranean. Southern African lineage probably only in Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz to Durban, from intertidal to 200m.
taxon_text_4_9107:
Solitary, benthic species that prefers rocky reefs and adjacent soft substrates, especially around kelp forests. Excavates and occupies dens where octopuses spend most of their time and from where they go on hunting explorations. Reside in their dens for up to several weeks but eventually will move on to a new area, probably when resources around the den become depleted.

Octopuses are well-known for their intelligence, adaptability and complex behaviour. Because they have no internal skeleton but essentially consist only of flexible muscle, they can squeeze into the tightest spaces. Their skin contains specialised pigment cells called chromatophores, which enable rapid changes in colour and texture for camouflage, communication, or warning displays. Have a short life-span and are thought to live between 12-15 months.

Prey on a variety of food and play important roles as both predators as well as prey in South African coastal and kelp forest ecosystems. While a lot of research has been carried out on other species in the Octopus vulgaris species complex, little published information exists on the South African lineage and much of our knowledge comes from our own observations in the field.

Octopuses are present in the kelp forest all year round, but young (probably around 200-300g) animals appear in larger numbers in early summer (November/December). The observant diver can recognise little dens appearing especially in the coarse sand as young octopuses have less trouble excavating sandy dens than large adults. By this they also spatially segregate from larger individuals on the reefs that are potential threats, as octopuses can occasionally be cannibalistic. Young octopuses like to predate on bivalves, gastropods, polychaetes or crustaceans that are buried in the sediment around them. They do this by pushing and extending one or more of their arms deeply into the sand to excavate a shell.

Growing quickly, larger octopuses tend to move to dens in rocky substrate, which are often the same dens used by a new generation of octopuses every year. Octopuses are specialising generalists, and we have observed different animals predating completely different prey items, even if their dens are only a meter apart. Some individuals predominately eat Abalone Haliotes midae, whereas another hunts Rock crabs or Rock lobsters and another prefers a varied diet and takes any invertebrate. Smith (2003) identified 39 prey species taken by octopuses in False Bay, and prey size and prey diversity increased with increasing octopus’ size. We have since found numerous additional prey species taken by octopuses, such as the Giant chiton Dinoplax gigas. Octopuses in False Bay take more than 50 species of prey and play an important role in the prey species’ population ecology, which have ecological knock-on and control effects to the food web.  

It is often described in the literature that octopuses are anti-social animals, but in our observations, individuals often occupy dens that are right next to each other, being aware and tolerating of their neighbours. Apart from high food availability in the Great African Seaforest, individuals having personal, preferred diets and developing their very own hunting strategies may allow for high octopus densities. We sometimes observe four or five animals in an area of only a few square meters, and it is possible to see 20–30 animals at a dive site. Individuals can have extremely different personalities also in the way of how they approach and interact with divers.

Having gained global fame and recognition through our My Octopus Teacher documentary, it may be surprising that the taxonomy of this species, like for so many South African marine invertebrates, has remained unresolved. The name Octopus vulgaris is problematic for the South African population and detailed studies must be carried out to separate it from the European counterpart. Unresolved and poor taxonomy is a major concern for the more than 300 species that occur globally, as cephalopods are under increased fishing pressure, but fisheries management stays in the unclear of which species are being caught. Right now, octopuses caught in False Bay are sold globally and marketed in Europe as Octopus vulgaris, which is not an unsatisfying situation. The current catches of octopus in False Bay vary around 70 metric tons per year (if each octopus is 1 kg on average, then 70t means 70.000 animals). 

Preliminary research through the M.Sc. project by Gareth Fee provides both morphological as well as genetic support to give the South African species its own name.
taxon_text_5_9108:
As a species octopuses are generalist hunters that feed on almost anything they can catch. In False Bay octopuses prey on multiple invertebrates of over 50 different species, more rarely on fish or other vertebrates. The most common and preferred prey species are Rock crabs, Rock lobsters and Abalone but individuals can become highly specialised in food that is readily available in the direct environment of their den.

Fast moving prey such as Rock lobster are first ambushed and then caught by casting the arm web over the prey after which the victim is injected with a cocktail of a potent venom that both kills the Rock lobster and simultaneously digests and liquifies its muscular tissue. The octopus then cracks open the exoskeleton with its bird-like beak and essentially ‘drinks’ the content.

When catching shelled molluscs octopuses can use two strategies. Either they pull their victim directly off the substrate or open shells by force to access the meat directly, or, if this fails and the meat is still inaccessible, they have to drill through the shell using their salivary papilla to inject a venom. Depending on shell thickness this takes up to several hours. Shells are often taken back to the den and drilled in safety. The precision of drilling is of interest as a specific shell region is targeted under which certain muscles or organs lie. For his B.Sc. (Honours) thesis, Gareth Fee could show that octopuses drilled with great precision into the Helmet snail, but that in the Abalone with has a huge adductor muscle, octopuses drilled into any middle shell part. Once the octopus gets to the fleshy meat it is torn apart with the beak and broken down and scraped off with the radula, which is a muscular tongue with hundreds of tiny teeth.

Different to other habitats in which  benthic octopuses stay on the seafloor, in the Great African Seaforest octopuses have a three-dimensional ecosystem to explore and exploit. A number of prey species live on the kelp such as mussels that settle on the kelp heads or the specialieed Kelp limpet Cymbula compressa on the kelp stipes. Octopuses are the main predator of Kelp limpets and spend large amounts of their time foraging in the canopy. We realised this during a research project collecting limpet shells from the beach. At some beaches with high octopus abundance in adjacent waters 50% of Kelp limpet shells have octopus drill holes. 

Foraging activity is probably linked to predator density and can be adapted. Octopuses in the Great African Seaforest are a main prey of Pyjama catsharks, and to a lesser amount also to seals. Animals that have lost an arm to a shark predation are frequently observed, but this grows back within several months. Males are highly careful of how they use and project their third right hectocotylised arm as loosing or damaging it could mean a failure in reproduction. In addition to complex visual camouflage, octopuses have several strategies to avoid predation, which includes a chemical camouflage of the skin to not be smelled by sharks, jet-propulsion and swimming away, blasting of ink to confuse the predator and which also contains a substance to dull olfactory senses, leaving the water and escaping over a rock, attaching to the sharks back and riding the shark in a save place, sacrificing an arm in order to get out of the predators grasp.
taxon_text_6_9109:
Sexes are separate and other than by the hectocotylised third right arm males can be distinguished from females by enlarged suckers on the second and third arm pairs, although in the South African specimens the difference is not as profound as in the true European O. vulgaris. Enlarged suckers may be displayed to other males and signal dominance.

Mating occurs all year round and involves little physical contact. Male and female octopus are careful of each other, especially when animals are of different sizes. The male extends its third right hectocotylised arm towards the female. This is rarely seen as it is often done through gaps in rocks or through crevices to avoid physical proximity. Once contact is made the male ejects a spermatophore sperm package into the groove of its arm and uses its siphon to pump it through the groove towards the tip. The arm is extended directly into the female's mantle, and a specialised erectile structure, the ligula, places the spermatophore directly inside the female’s reproductive tract. Females can copulate multiple times with either the same or different males and store the spermatophore for several months until spawning.

It is thought that two spawning peaks occur, one at the end of winter (August/September) and one at the end of Summer (February/March). Females excavate dens in shallow waters that have overhanging rock ceilings, towards which they attach the clutches of eggs. Egg numbers are estimated to vary between 42 0000 to 790 000. Dens are barricaded against the outside and hence difficult to find. Females stop feeding and don’t leave their den to constantly guard, protect and care for their eggs until they hatch, after which the female dies. Depending on water temperature it takes 1-2 months for the paralava hatch.

Octopus paralarva are a few millimetres in size, translucent and swim into the open ocean after hatching, where they develop for about 45 days before settling to a benthic lifestyle, undergoing ecological and morphological transformation. Details and mechanisms of paralarva migration and requirements in the complex oceanographic waters of the Cape are not studied.
taxon_text_7_9110: The only common and medium-sized octopus in the Cape. The Brush-tip octopus Eledone schultzei occurs in the intertidal and shallow waters on the west coast, but is much smaller and also not as fast or muscular, has a more rounded body shape, and is predominantly uniformly brown. The larger Southern giant octopus Enteroctopus magnificus is much larger and more robust, occurs in deeper water and is rarely ever seen by divers.
<p>Octopus with a threat behaviour of en: Octopus with a threat behaviour of enlarged and brightened eyes.
taxon_text_1_9050:
Small, plump cuttlefish with short arms joined at their base by a strong membrane. Body surface relatively smooth but bearing small, scattered tubercles. Species easily recognised by the two rows of pores that run down the lower sides of the body; these typically number 10-13 on each side with unequal numbers on left and right sides. Colour pale, with mottled bands of brown pigmentation and a dark strip along junction of dorsal and ventral surfaces.

Cuttlebone broadly oval and lacking an anterior spine or dorsal ridge. Shape sexually dimorphic, being narrower and more pointed in males but broader and more rounded in females.
taxon_text_2_9051: Mantle length about 20 mm and total body length about 40 mm.
taxon_text_3_9052:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_9053: Fairly common along both west and south coasts from the intertidal to at least 500 m depth. The pores along the flanks are thought to act as attachment organs to prevent the animals from being washed around by strong surges.
taxon_text_5_9054: Details unknown but all cuttlefish are predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak. Small species such as this probably feed on small crustaceans and other mobile invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_9055: Details unknown but cuttlefish lay large round eggs which are attached to objects such as rocks, seafans and the like. There is no parental care in this group.
taxon_text_7_9056: There are several other small Sepia species in the region (see refs below), but this species is most likely to be confused with the Tuberculate cuttlefish S. tuberculata, which is also able to attach itself to the substratum. However, that species has a warty surface texture and the ventral attachment organs take the form of two large oval glandular patches.
<p>pores on the underside next to an inj: pores on the underside next to an injury
<p>magnification, pores on the underside: magnification, pores on the underside next to an injury
taxon_text_1_9023:
Tiny white bivalve with thin, almost completely transparent and fragile oval shell, through which the gills and other body organs can clearly be seen. Most easily identified by its obligate association with the Smooth heart urchin Spatagobrissus mirabilis.

When alive the transparent mantle extends externally to cover much of the shell and is produced forwards into a large tubular inhalant siphon and posteriorly into a smaller exhalent one. The foot is elongate and mobile and is used to actively move around on the host and wrap around and grip onto its spines.
taxon_text_2_9024: Very small, shell length typically only about 2 mm.
taxon_text_3_9025:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Only very recently discovered and currently known only from a single site in False Bay, but likely much more widely distributed, as the host urchin ranges between southern Namibia and Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_9026:
Only very recently discovered by the Sea Change Project team during examination of heart urchins Spatagobrissus mirabilis in False Bay. The urchins live in shallow burrows in course sand and large numbers of these tiny transparent bivalves can be associated with each urchin. The bivalves move around freely among the urchin spines, using the elongate foot to both locomote and to grip onto individual urchin spines.

The same heart urchins also hosted numerous small amphipods of the family Lysianassidae and larger scale worms of the family Polynoidae (Malmgreniella sp.) and both of these species also appear to be undescribed obligate commensals.
taxon_text_5_9027: Very little is known about the feeding biology of this species, but almost all bivalves are filter feeders, sucking in seawater and removing fine particulate material from it by passing the water though their enlarged sieve-like gills. The urchins probably simply act as a convenient solid substratum onto which the bivalves can attach.
taxon_text_6_9028: All members of this family are hermaphroditic and lack a larval stage. Instead, they brood their young, protecting them among their gills, and releasing them when fully developed onto the surface of the sea urchin occupies by the parent. Reproduction in this species has not been studied in any detail, but up to 10 shelled juveniles have been observed attached to the gills of mature specimens.
taxon_text_7_9029: Many species in this family have symbiotic associations with other larger invertebrates, including urchins. Although numerous other galeommatid species have been described from South Africa this is the only one currently known to be associated with urchins.
taxon_text_8_9030: Valentich-Scott, P, Griffiths, C, Landschoff, J, Li, R & Li, J (2024). Bivalves of superfamily Galeommatoidea (Mollusca, Bivalvia) from western South Africa, with observations on commensal relationships and habitats. ZooKeys, 1207, 301-323.
taxon_text_1_9059:
Medium- to large cuttlefish with a broad, finely papillose mantle, its frontal margin produced into a wide bulge mid-dorsally. Also capable of erecting several large knobbly papillae around the eyes and on the mantle, as additional camouflage or when in threat posture. Narrow fins run along entire lateral margins and are well separated at the tail. Arms short, with four rows of suckers. Tentacle clubs elongate and narrow with numerous small, equal-sized suckers. Cuttlebone broadly oval with a pointed knob at posterior end.

Colour variable and individuals can change their appearance within seconds: red-purple, orange-brown or yellow, or even completely white are possible background colours. A typical colouration is mottled pinkish-brown dorsally with yellow to orange fins, a pinkish-white underside, and sometimes dark longitudinal stripes along the arms. Sometimes threatens with large and deeply black eye-spots on either side of the second half of the mantle.
taxon_text_3_9061:
Global: Probably endemic to South Africa, but some accounts also list South West Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9062:
Little is known about this species from the literature as it seems to have been confused by scientists and divers with S. vermiculata (see remarks in similar species below). Change colours within seconds using chromatophores, which as highly specialised pigment-containing skin cells that contract or relax in order to reveal or hide a specific colour tone on the skin.

Common along the south coast and from shallow water to depths of at least 100 m. It appears that this is the common large Sepia species in the kelp forests of False Bay.

Occupies narrow caves and rock overhangs where it rests during the day and is more active at night. Often seen resting together and in close proximity with Pyjama catsharks.
taxon_text_5_9063: Details unknown, but all cuttlefish are predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak.
taxon_text_6_9064:
Lay large, roundly pointed eggs which are attached underneath rocky overhangs and caves. Colour of eggs variable and range from see-through pale to deep black. Colour variation due to the fact that cuttlefish can coat their eggs in a layer of black ink, likely as both a form of camouflage and protection. Although adults are sometimes still observed around their clutches of eggs, there is no proven parental care.

As the young develop the ink layer peels off, making it possible for the unhatched animals to observe their environment from the safety of the egg, before they hatch as perfectly developed tiny cuttlefish. Development probably takes several months and certainly depends on water temperature. The young of this species are never seen in shallow waters either because they have a highly cryptic lifestyle and hide in rock crevices or algae, or they spend the first months in deeper waters.
taxon_text_7_9065:
There has been considerable confusion in local and online field guides around the correct image identifications of local cuttlefish species, due to the fact that colouration, shape and posture are highly variable and that cephalopods can change their appearance within seconds. After the cuttlebone, which lies inside the animal and which is hence not useful to identify live specimens, one of the main identification characters are the tentacle clubs. However, these are the animals most important weapon and tool for catching prey, and are hence held safely and invisible in between the arms.

Treating our species identification with some caution, the Simon’s Town cuttlefish is the main and most common large cuttlefish in the shallow water kelp forest. The second common species, the Tuberculate cuttlefish Sepia tuberculata, is much smaller and fairly easily distinguished by the smaller size, the rough tuberculate surface, and perhaps most easily by the unusual behaviour of physically attaching to the substrate using the large glandular patch on the underside. Especially small specimens of S. simoniana can look similar to S. tuberculata but are able to show larger eye-spots as threat display (see images of juvenile).

Sepia simoniana is very similar in size and form to the slightly larger Patchwork cuttlefish S. vermiculata, the only species in the Western Cape that is known to enter estuaries and which is common in the Knysna Lagoon, as well as reported from Langebaan. In that species however the mantle is broader, the surface smoother, and the lateral fins broader. Colour displays are different in that it can show zebra-like, transverse patterns on the mantle, white spots on the base of the lateral fins and a narrow white line on the fin margin, which all seem to be characteristic. The cuttlebone of S. simoniana has a blunt knob on the posterior end rather than a sharp spine as in S. vermiculata.

Another species, identified in this guide with caution as the Southern cuttlefish, Decorisepia australis, has a similar colour tone and general appearance to S. simoniana. In the field it can be identified by being marginally smaller than S. simoniana and by having slightly different body proportions that include shorter arms, a larger eye, and a slightly more elongated mantle. At first glance the colour pattern seem almost identical, however, D. australis has a deeper red colouration including a pinkish red belly. The best live identification character appears to be the presence of iridescent skin beneath the eye and underneath the front of the fin.

A further species of similar size to S. simoniana and S. vermiculata that is so far not covered in this guide and potentially hidden in images presented, Spathidosepion papillatum, occurs in the same waters and has enlarged suckers on the tentacle club.
<p>remains of specimen predated by otter: remains of specimen predated by otter, cuttlebone and tentacle with broad club
<p>otter predation, broad club with very: otter predation, broad club with very small suckers
<p>microscope image of single club sucke: microscope image of single club sucker with ring of tiny teeth, about 150x magnification
taxon_text_1_9068:
Large cuttlefish with a broad, smooth-skinned mantle, its frontal margin produced into a bulge mid-dorsally. Wide fins run along entire lateral margins except for small gap at tail. Arms joined at base by a shallow web, the ventral arms longer than dorsal ones, arms III and IV keeled. Arm suckers in four rows, all suckers with finely toothed rings. Tentacle clubs with about four rows of suckers, median suckers much larger than marginal ones, rims of suckers smooth. Cuttlebone broadly oval with a pointed spine at posterior end.

Colour extremely variable and may be difficult to identify from photographs, where definitive characters (such as suckers) seldom visible. Individuals that show characteristic zebra-like transverse stripes, white spots on the base of the lateral fins and a narrow white line on the fin margin, are easily identified, but may not always display those characters.
taxon_text_3_9070:
Global: West coast of Southern Africa and South West Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Orange River to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_9071: Reported across region, but most common on south coast. Occurs from shallow water to depth of at least 290 m and is the only large Sepia to enter estuaries and river mouths such as Langebaan and Knysna lagoon. Very little is known about the species' biology.
taxon_text_5_9072: Details unknown, but all cuttlefish are predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak.
taxon_text_6_9073: Details unknown, but cuttlefish lay large round eggs which are attached to objects such as rocks, seafans and the like. There is no parental care in this group.
taxon_text_7_9074:
Since cuttlefish can actively change colouration, shape and posture within seconds the variation individual specimens can display can make species identification from images difficult. As a result, there has been considerable confusion in field identifications of local species. In the Western Cape, three to four common, large and medium-sized cuttlefish can be confused with this species; however it appears that the patchwork pattern/zebra-like transverse stripes displayed by S. vermiculata are characteristic. Neither the similar S. simoniana (also see similar species discussion under this species entry) nor the smaller and more elongated Decorisepia australis, have any similar zebra pattern in their colour repertoire. To our current knowledge, a fourth large species present in the Western Cape, Spathidosepion papillatum, has never been photographed or identified in its natural environment.

The cuttlebone of S. simoniana has a blunt knob on the posterior end rather than a sharp spine in S. vermiculata, although this character appears slightly variable.
taxon_text_1_9032:
Large, elongate squid with a slender body and triangular side fins that span over half the length of the body and have concave hind margins. The shell is reduced to a slender, transparent ‘pen’ that lies just under the skin on the dorsal surface.

Eye covered by a cornea. The eight short arms each bear two rows of suckers. The two retractable tentacles are elongate and end in a club armed with four rows of large suckers, those of central section (manus) being greatly expanded. The sucker cups are smooth and lack chitinous teeth. Colour ranging from dark red to translucent white when alive.
taxon_text_2_9033: Mantle length up to 400 mm, maximum weight over 1 kg.
taxon_text_3_9034:
Global: Mainly in South Africa but significant population also found in southern Angola.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to about Port Alfred.
taxon_text_4_9035:
A common species that forms the basis of lucrative trawl and jig fisheries based mostly along the south coast. Forms dense breeding aggregations in summer in shallow sandy bays between about Cape Point and Port Alfred. Sausage-shaped egg strands are deposited communally. Young are then transported westwards by the Agulhas Current and later return eastwards back to their spawning grounds.

Growth rate is rapid, with males growing faster and reaching a much larger terminal size (0.75-1.0 mm per day and reaching 400 mm) than females (0.2-0.3 mm per day and reaching only 240 mm). Live for less than two years, yet some uncertainty remains whether mortality occurs immediately post-spawning.
taxon_text_5_9036:
Predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak. Feed mostly at night and in the early morning. Diet of smaller individuals consists mostly of euphausiid shrimps while larger individuals take mostly fish. Polychaetes and cephalopods are also taken. Paralarvae feed on small plankton such as copepods.

Forms a vital part of the diets of local groundfish, sharks, rays and the Cape fur seal.
taxon_text_6_9037:
Mating and egg laying take place throughout the year but with peaks in spring and early summer. Squid migrate to shallow (<60 m) spawning grounds during austral summer months in sexually segregated groups. Temperature change is thought to trigger spawning as it occurs synchronously with increased upwelling. Ideal conditions for spawning are westerly winds, no turbidity and sea surface temperatures of 15-17°C.

Once at the spawning grounds, mating rituals involving fighting, guarding and sneaking begin. Large males pair and mate with mature females, while ‘sneaker’ males stealthily mate with paired-up females. Eggs are deposited on both hard and soft substrata mostly in sheltered bays along the South Coast and in large communal beds.

Potential fecundity is 17,000 eggs, and each egg capsule contains an average of 100-150 eggs. Eggs are contained in elongated (sausage-shaped) gelatinous casings, about 2.8 mm long and 2.0 mm wide. Capsules are attached to one another by threads that create large, spiralled clusters adhered to the seafloor. Development generally takes between 50 and 27 days at 12 and 17°C respectively.

Once hatched, planktonic larvae drift toward their nursery areas on the Agulhas Bank to feed and grow. Mature individuals then actively migrate eastwards to spawning grounds in summer.
taxon_text_7_9038:
The most abundant and most numerous of many squid species found in the region and recognised by a combination of body and fin shape and characteristics of the suckers on the arms and tentacles (for guide to local species see Leslie and Lipinski 2018).

The veined/long-finned squid Loligo forbesii has similar stripes to those found on the ventral side of the mantle of male Loligo reynaudii. However, those on L. forbesii are bigger, more abundant and more brightly coloured. 

The Indian Ocean squid Loligo duvaucelii (Port Alfred to Mozambique) has shorter fins (less than half the mantle length) and two light-emitting organs on the ink sac in the mantle cavity. 

The diamond squid Thysanoteuthis rhombus is one of the largest squid in South African waters with a body length of 1 m and mass of 20 kg. Diamond-shaped fins cover entire length of the mantle.
taxon_text_8_9160:
Brokensha, RM, Landschoff, J & Griffiths, CL (2022). Review of the South African and Mozambican stomatopod fauna. M.S. thesis, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa.

Griffiths, CL & Blaine, MJ (1988). Distribution, population structure and biology of stomatopod Crustacea off the west coast of South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 7(1), 45–50.

Manning, RB (1969). Notes on some stomatopod Crustacea from southern Africa. Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology, 1, 1–17.
taxon_text_1_9086:
Small to medium-sized cuttlefish in intertidal and shallow waters, although specimens caught in offshore trawls are reported to be large. Mantle short and broad with convex frontal margin not strongly produced. Mantle, head and arms covered with (name-giving) large and coarse tubercles that when erect create a highly variable and adaptable texture. Tubercles in any area can be either retracted into wart-like knobs or erected into spike-like protrusions. Underside of animal smooth and without such tubercles, but with large wrinkled, glandular adhesion patches on either side of mantle and on the outer area of ventral arms. Fins wide and rounded, separated posteriorly. Arms I to III attenuated and webbed for almost half the length of arms. Tentacle club long, slightly curved, and with large suckers proximally and small suckers distally.

Cuttlebone broadly ovular without posterior spine and with a narrow inner cone. Wider and shorter than other local species, creating angled V-shape of inner cone margin.

Colour extremely variable and changes within seconds from white, yellow, orange to deep red-brown, often purple, and generally with small or larger black dots. Often makes a broad lighter mid-band on the middle third of mantle, used to break body pattern against the background. A useful species identification character that is often displayed is a small white dot on the middle of the third arm (second arm from the side). In young animals this white dot resembles the round shell of the Spiral fan-worm Spirobis spp.
taxon_text_3_9088:
Global distribution: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Elands Bay to East London, common intertidally, but caught in offshore trawls to depths of 200 m.
taxon_text_4_9089:
Common intertidally and in shallow subtidal waters where it lives a highly secretive life hiding in crevices and small caves or overhangs. Master of camouflage using a large suite and combination of techniques to blend into its environment that involves colour, texture, shape as well as movement.

Perhaps most astonishingly, we frequently observe small animals pointing the arms and tail while contracting the mantle to take up the shape and appearance of a Burnupena spp. whelk. The whelk is also matched in terms of colouration, including patches of crustose coralline algae or even the very common small white Spirobis spp. fan-worms. Furthermore, because Tuberculate cuttlefish have sticky, wrinkled areas on the belly and under the arms of the side, they can adhere these to the ground and or move over the substrate in the form of a whelk (or even a hermit crab?). Animals make slow backwards forward rocking movement – just like the whelk would – to stay hidden from a potential predator and secretly move into safety.

The adhesion pads on the underside are significant ecological adaptations that allow the cuttlefish to cling on to the ground and thrive in strongly wave-swept environments. The highly specialised adhesion works through both a mechanical mechanism (the muscular wrinkled patched suck onto a rock) and are also supported by a chemical two-component adhesive glue that is secreted by two different types of skin cells. Chemical adhesion is rare in cuttlefishes and the combination of this with the physical suction pads is unique to S. tuberculata (although the closely related but very poorly known Sepia papillata that has never been documented alive, seems to have the same morphological adaptations).   

Being small and as a last resort to flee from predators Tuberculate cuttlefish use a “pseudomorph”-ink (‘false body’) exit strategy. Swimming away from an attacking fish the cuttlefish releases exactly the right ink volume to match the ink-cloud to its size. It also adds high levels of mucus into the squirted ink so it takes up the form and shape of its body. The cuttlefish then uses this moment of distraction to swim into another direction, usually completely fooling the predator (or the observing diver!). Rather than being a liquid cloud the pseudopmorph ink of this species has a firm, almost fabric-like texture. Its chemical composition has however never been studied for this species.
taxon_text_5_9090: Observed to take crustaceans like amphipods and shrimps, but also small fish, like all cuttlefish capturing live prey by the fast extension of their long tentacles with sticky sucker-bearing clubs, which are hidden between the arms when not in use. Larger individuals have been observed taking klipfish. Tuberculate cuttlefish are potential prey of any larger carnivorous fish species.
taxon_text_6_9091: Sexes are separate. Speculatively and due to their small size and hidden lifestyle, mating might occur in secrecy and has not been observed thus far. Females lay clutches of usually 30-40 eggs underneath rock overhangs where development time is temperature dependent but takes several months. Adults are sometimes still seen in the vicinity but not thought to guard the clutch. Eggs initially often black and covered in layer of ink, but turn translucent as embryos develop, which then start observing their environment from the safety of the egg. Hatch as fully developed tiny versions of their parents and immediately adapt to living a life hiding and hunting as their parents.
taxon_text_7_9092: All cuttlefish in the region change colour and hence potentially be confused, especially when information is taken only from a single photo. Could be confused especially with juveniles of the otherwise larger Simon’s Town cuttlefish S. simoniana, although the tubercles of S. tuberculata are much more prominent and generally a give-away. The Southern cuttlefish Decorisepia australis has a similar small size, but a different deep red colour, iridescent skin areas and also has a smoother surface. The Pore-bellied cuttlefish S. typica prefers a different, sandy environment, and also has a smooth surface and different colour pattern. There is one largely unknown species that has never been photographed alive, Spathidosepion papillatum. It appears to have great similarity with S. tuberculata differs morpholgically by having larger suckers on the club (which the animal never reveals when alive). Another character to look out for in the wild in potential S. papillatum encounters are therefore smaller, more densely packed tubercles on the mantle and perhaps differences in colour display.
<p>Clutch with just over 30 eggs - adult: Clutch with just over 30 eggs - adult animal behind it on the right
<p>animal contracting mantle and arms -: animal contracting mantle and arms - this posture is related to when animal mimic Burnupena whelks
<p>animal flattening the body and mantle: animal flattening the body and mantle to not be seen
<p>suckers on fourth arm against the cam: suckers on fourth arm against the camera glass
taxon_text_1_9041:
Cephalopod with a loosely coiled, calcareous, many-chambered (25 to 37) shell in the characteristically spiral form of a Ram’s horn, which is easily recognised and often washed ashore along the South African coastline. The live animal, which lives in the deep open ocean, is never seen. 

When alive, shell positioned internally at the back of the animal to provide buoyancy control. Eye large, without cornea. Mantle cylindrical and usually covered in smooth silvery to red-brown skin. Two long tentacles and eight arms; increasing in length from the top to the belly of the animal, suckers in rows of four or six and all (except fourth arm) united by webs. Arms and tentacles can be withdrawn into the mantle. No sexual dimorphism in sucker number and position. A large bioluminescent light organ or photophore positioned at the posterior end of the mantle emits a green glow observed to continue for hours at a time and surrounded by two ear-shaped fins.
taxon_text_3_9043:
Global distribution: Found in tropical and subtropical waters worldwide.

Local/Regional: Throughout the region.
taxon_text_4_9044:
A mesopelagic species known to undertake a diel vertical migration, inhabits depths around 1000 m during the day and migrates to the surface to depths between 100 to 300 m at night. Although shells get frequently washed ashore along the South African coastline, indicating that the species is common, live or even dead animals are extremely rarely seen. A living Ram’s horn squid was recently filmed in the wild for the first during a ship-based, deep sea exploration dive, bringing new insights into the biology of this remarkable cephalopod.

The internal many-chambered shell gets filled with gas to maintain buoyancy. Active motions of the fins further control the Ram’s horn squid’s position in the water column. Originally it was thought that the animals sat in a vertical position; head downwards and arms upward. However, it is now clear that the animal swims in a head-up position when at rest. 

Only known extant member of order Spirulida, with an average life span of 18 to 20 months. However, the taxonomic status is unresolved also because fresh specimens needed for morphological and genetic work are rare. Currently treated as one global species, but studies based on shell metrics and growth differences in shell characters revealed differences between geographical regions. Preliminary morphological studies suggest that populations between the Atlantic and Indo-West Pacific may represent different lineages.
taxon_text_5_9045:
Hunt nocturnally with peak activity at night. Mainly feeds on small prey items such as crustaceans.

The head-up position recently observed is supported by the presence of a photophore at the mantle tip which may be used to break up the animal's silhouette as a predator avoidance strategy. This counterillumination is a strategy commonly used by mesopelagic squid to break up silhouettes against light from above when the animal gets hunted from below. Although Ram's horn squid can use some jet propulsion, the fragility of the shell and effort involved in rapid movement suggests that stillness and camouflage are the ram's horn squid's main defense against predation. Known predators include the fish Splendid alfoniso, Bleryx splendens, swordfish as well as seabirds such as petrels and albatrosses. The latter suggests that Ram’s horn squids sometimes migrate into surface waters above 10 m depth.
taxon_text_6_9046:
Much remains speculative as mating or spawning has never been observed. Reproduction similar to most cephalopods in the fact that during mating the male uses a modified arm, called the hectocotylus, to insert a sperm sac into the female's seminal receptacle located in the buccal membrane of the mantle.
