Mature males also have two ventral arms modified without suckers and tipped with finger-like projections, which may aid in courting and the mating act. Sexual maturity is reached after 12 to 15 months at mantle length 30 mm. 

Sampling of juveniles at depth between 1000 and 1740 m may suggest that egg laying occurs on the benthic layer of continental slopes - no pelagic eggs have been observed. Eggs are small and the paralarvae resemble adults with a mantle length of 1.5 mm and a two chambered shell.
taxon_text_7_9047: Unmistakable and currently only one species recognised globally.
taxon_text_1_9095: Small, solitary and rarely sighted intertidal and shallow-water cephalopod with globular muscular mantle and head, no externally visible shell and eight contractile arms. Mantle surface with wrinkled skin and very small granules but otherwise smooth and without any larger papillae, cirri or tubercles. Each arm has about 60-80 suckers that are irregularly spaced. The genus Eledone is defined by a single row of suckers, however this species is an exception in having a non-uniform single to double zigzag row of suckers. Suckers on arm pairs 1-3 particularly enlarged around sucker numbers 6-10 (counted from the mouth). Right third arm hectocotylised, meaning it has a distinct spermatophoral groove along the side as well as a modified arm tip to deliver a sperm package to the female. All non-hectocoylised arm tips have bunches of long, sensory finger or brush-like projections instead of suckers (hence the name ‘brush-tip’). It is still unclear but possible that the brush-like arm structures only occur in males. Unable to change colour in the same way as other octopus species, and appearance is always uniformly red-brown and easy to identify.
taxon_text_2_9096: Mantle length to 10 cm, total length to 50 cm, weight to 350 g.
taxon_text_3_9097:
Global distribution: Endemic to the west coast of southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to Table Bay in South Africa, 0-18 m.
taxon_text_4_9098: Hardly any biological information exists for this probably solitary benthic species typically found in intertidal and shallow rocky reefs. Dens are undefined small holes between mussels and crevices and often found under larger rocks. Life expectancies of 1-2 years are estimates from other related species. The large and highly reflective eyes may suggest that the species could be majorly nocturnal. Probably more common than thought, but rarely seen due to its small size, secretive lifestyle, and since it lives along the highly wave-exposed west coast that can be difficult to access.
taxon_text_5_9099: Speculative but probably feeds on small crustaceans, gastropods and bivalves in the intertidal and shallow subtidal areas. Very likely a favourite prey of the shysharks and catsharks, as well as of the Crowned cormorant, and especially of the much larger Common octopus. Predations and the ecological interactions with the latter are of special interest as they may restrict the distribution of the Brush-tip octopus to the cold west coast where the Common octopus is less abundant.
taxon_text_6_9100: Sexes are separate and like in other octopus species the male uses the third right arm to pass on a spermatophore (sperm package) into the ovary of the female. Females probably create a den where they lay and guard their eggs, which then hatch and get released as paralava into the water column. There are no field observation of mating or reproduction of this species.
taxon_text_7_9101: Difficult to confuse with the Common octopus Octopus vulgaris Type 3 due to its smaller size, the more bulbous head and mantle and the uniformly red-brown colour that does not change. The brush-like arm tips or the unusual sucker rows are highly distinctive but difficult to see in the wild or from photos.
<p>Left and middle: adapted sucker rims: Left and middle: adapted sucker rims into brush-like projections on fourth right arm. Right: hectocotylized tip of third right arm. Original drawing from Roper and Mangold (1991)
taxon_text_1_9122:
Muscular, smooth-skinned pelagic octopus with extreme sexual dimorphism. Dwarf males never to rarely seen. Females typically occupying large brood case with their head forward, the lateral and ventral arms bent backwards adhering to the inside of the shell, and the dorsal arms either covering the outside shell faces or retracted within. First arm pair of the female has wide distal webs that secrete the thin calcium carbonate egg case. Identification is easily done based on shell morphology. In this species the bright white shell is characterised by the lateral ribs ending in a chain of separate tubercles, and the unpaired, alternating tubercles on the broad dorsal keel that grow in size with age. Shell aperture is moderately wide.

Arm lengths and sucker counts on the arms can be consulted to identify female specimens. In this species the second arms of female are the longest and the fourth arms are short. Approximately 280–360 suckers on first arms but only 110–140 on the fourth. Sucker counts on hectocotylised arms separate males of different species (58 to 64 in this species). The hectocotylus is the specialised arm of male octopuses (in argonauts the third left) that is structurally different from the others and is used to transfer sperm from to the female during mating.
taxon_text_2_9123:
Female mantle length up to 14 cm. Total length up to 50 cm. Shell length up to 30 cm.

Male mantle length about 1 cm. Total length only 2 cm (excluding hectocotylus), and up to 6 cm (including hectocotylus).
taxon_text_3_9124:
Global distribution: Temperate, circumglobal distribution in Southern Hemisphere between 10°S and 44°S. Reported to be most common in Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Pelagic species with South Africa being the only distribution for the African continent.
taxon_text_4_9125:
An oceanic epipelagic species typically found at the ocean surface but can also occur at depths of up to 200 metres. Females build large shells as brood chambers – structures that have fascinated biologists for centuries. In the 1800s, it was believed that the animals found inside the shells were parasites that had killed the rightful shell owners. The minute male was an even greater mystery. Since the male’s specialised third left arm detaches and crawls autonomously into the female’s mantle cavity to deliver a sperm package, female argonauts often contain multiple detached arms. These were also once mistakenly identified as parasites, until the species’ extraordinary reproductive biology was understood (see Reproduction section).

Females ‘gulp’ air into their shell cavity to maintain neutral buoyancy and stay afloat, swimming slowly using jet propulsion. They are usually solitary but have been observed forming schools, especially during the mating season. Due to their slow swimming, fragile shells, and lack of defensive arms, argonauts are highly vulnerable to predators. In response, they have developed several defensive strategies: females can retract fully into their shells and use modified arms to cover and camouflage the shell using chromatophores, which rapidly shift colour from maroon-red to silver. These chromatophores can also create pulsating, psychedelic colour patterns that help with countershading and disorient predators.

Inking is another defensive tactic. A thick, dark ink is released in bursts to create a pseudomorph – an ink cloud that resembles the shape of the animal. The ink hangs in the water, slowly changing shape and confusing predators, giving the argonaut time to escape. Large females have even been observed ‘towing’ Cyanea spp. jellyfish, possibly to use them as protection against predators.

This species was originally described from specimens collected in South Africa. Like other paper nautiluses, it is vulnerable to global climate change. Ocean acidification could either dissolve the calcium carbonate egg case or interfere with its formation altogether.
taxon_text_5_9126:
Argonauts likely feed on a variety of pelagic organisms, including molluscs, shrimp, plankton, and small fish. They have been observed feeding on euphausiids (krill), and large aggregations may coincide with the presence of euphausiid schools. In captivity, females have also accepted dead prawns and fish.

They can use their distal webs to detect food at the ocean surface – when a prey item touches the expanded web, an arm quickly extends from the shell to grab it. This passive ‘bump and grab’ feeding method contrasts with active hunting. In active predation, once prey is detected, the tentacles catch and draw it toward the mouth, where venom from the salivary gland is injected. In the case of shelled prey, the salivary papilla is likely used to drill through the shell before delivering the venomous cocktail.

Argonauts are potential prey for many larger ocean predators and rely entirely on their camouflage to avoid detection.
taxon_text_6_9127:
Argonauts have a highly evolved and fascinating reproductive biology. The sexes are strongly dimorphic: females are large and have webbed arms that form a brood chamber where they lay their eggs. Males, in contrast, are dwarfs and do not build such structures, living freely in the open ocean. Males possess a highly specialised third left arm, called the hectocotylus, which makes up a large portion of their body.

Although mating behaviour remains unknown, it is thought that when a male encounters a female, he transfers spermatophores into his specialised arm. This arm then detaches from his body, crawls autonomously into the female’s mantle cavity, and finds her reproductive tract, where it deposits a sperm packet. The detached arm may remain inside the female for weeks, with spermatophores stored until she is ready to spawn.

Like all octopuses, females spawn their eggs in festoons (long strands of eggs), which pass through the oviduct and are fertilised by stored sperm cells. The female then attaches the eggs inside the coiled brood chamber, which provides structure and protection. Eggs are laid repeatedly, and up to five different developmental stages can be present at the same time. This results in paralarvae hatching continuously, increasing the chances that some offspring encounter suitable ocean conditions for survival.

The eggs spawned within the shell are very small (less than 2 mm long and 1 mm wide) and are produced in large numbers, with up to 180,000 eggs per individual. In the final stages of development, the embryos form numerous chromatophores, which they can contract to appear white and transparent or expand to show bright orange. Development to hatching is estimated to take about seven days. The resulting paralarvae are tiny versions of the adults and immediately adopt a planktonic open ocean lifestyle.

Females are believed to be capable of reproducing multiple times during their lifespan, while males are thought to die after mating, having sacrificed their hectocotylised arm.
taxon_text_7_9128:
Although each argonaut’s shell is individually variable, the three species found locally can be easily distinguished by their shell features and size. The Greater Argonaut (Argonauta argo) and the Knobby Argonaut (A. nodosus) are similar in size, while the Winged Argonaut (A. hians) is significantly smaller.

Only A. nodosus has round tubercles on the lateral ridges, although these may be less developed in smaller specimens. After this feature, the keel is particularly useful for identification.

In A. nodosus, the keel ridge is broad, with unpaired, alternating tubercles that increase in size as the shell grows. The shell aperture is moderately wide.

In A. argo, the keel ridge is narrow, with paired, perfectly parallel tubercles or spikes that remain the same size throughout growth. The shell aperture is narrow.

The shell of A. hians is quite different: it is sculptured and brown in colour (unlike the white shells of the other two species). The lateral ribs are prominent and widely spaced, and they do not align with the large, alternating tubercles on the very widely spaced keel. The aperture is much broader and often features prominent wing-like extensions, although these traits can vary considerably between individuals.
<p>Eggs casings often get abandoned when: Eggs casings often get abandoned when animals are washed ashore. This one has some remaining eggs attached inside.
<p>View into the shell spiral with so ca: View into the shell spiral with so called festoons of eggs in two developmental stages.
<p>Abandoned shell with hatched embryos: Abandoned shell with hatched embryos that cling to the surface on the inside.
<p>Embryo on the inside of the shell wit: Embryo on the inside of the shell with developing eyes and functional chromatophores.
taxon_text_1_9077:
Medium-sized cuttlefish with a narrow, oval mantle with a smooth surface and regular small tubercles, its frontal margin produced into a bulge mid-dorsally. Fins running along lateral margins and widen towards the back of the animal, ending in a round flap and forming wide gap to the other side. Posterior end of the cuttlebone has a sharp spine that sticks out of the middle of this gap. Has large, almost bulbous eyes and short arms with four rows of suckers. Tentacles long with short, slightly curved clubs that have greatly enlarged medial suckers. Cuttlebone elongated and oval, tapering towards the downwardly curved end that bears a sharp, upwardly pointed spine. 

Colour variable, from white over pink to a deeper brown red. Skin of entire animal with a slight iridescent shine, but noticeable strongly iridescent areas below the eyes and beneath the the fins and on the belly. Can also display broad stripe along the base of the posterior half of the fins during mating, as well as creating a large, white circle on the frontal eye area.
taxon_text_3_9079:
Global: Probably endemic to the region, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Commonly caught in offshore trawls both on the west and south coast, down to 500 m but most commonly between 60-200 m. The records here are from my shallower waters of 8-25 m.
taxon_text_4_9080: Little is known about this species other than it being very commonly caught in offshore monitoring trawls, which makes it likely that few specimens observed from divable depths in False Bay are part of a much larger, offshore population. However, appear to be mating at deeper reefs and showing fascinating communication skin pattern.
taxon_text_5_9081: Details unknown, but all cuttlefish are predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak.
taxon_text_6_9082: All cuttlefish lay large round eggs which are attached to objects such as rocks, seafans and the like. There is no parental care in this group. The interesting mating behaviour observed by Georgina Jones that is shown here is perhaps the only available information on this species. It includes the display of a broad longitudinal stripe on the second half of the mantle, as well as an iridescent, almost glowing underside of the mantle. Whether the white ring on the frontal part of the eye is part of the courtship communication is intriguing.
taxon_text_7_9083: The species is superficially similar in colour to the Simon’s Town cuttlefish Sepia simoniana, but D. australis is less than half the size of that species, has a much more elongate body, proportionally much larger eyes and shorter arms, and can be fairly safely identified by the iridescent patches underneath the eyes, which are visible (other than the iridescence underneath) from most photographic angles. Unlikely to be confused with the similarly sized and also small Tuberculate cuttlefish S. tuberculata, which has different colour displays (no bright red), dense packed knobbly projections on the skin, as well as adhesion pads on the underside.
<p>close up of eye, freshly dead, washed: close up of eye, freshly dead, washed-up animal
<p>cuttlebone and remains of freshly dea: cuttlebone and remains of freshly dead, washed-up animal
taxon_text_1_9131:
Muscular, smooth-skinned pelagic octopus with extreme sexual dimorphism. Dwarf males never to rarely seen but females occasionally washed ashore, occupying a large brood casing shell, with their head forward, the lateral and ventral arms bent backwards adhering to the inside of the shell, and the dorsal arms either covering the outside shell faces or retracted within. First arm pair of the female has wide distal webs that secrete the paper-thin calcium carbonate shell for brooding the eggs. Identification is easily done based on shell morphology. In this species the bright white brood case is characterised by the lateral rib endings being smooth and not having any tubercles, and the keel being narrow with a paired row of spikes or tubercles that do not grow larger with shell age. The shell aperture is narrow.

Arm lengths and sucker counts on the arms can be consulted to identify female specimens. In this species the fourth (or ventral) arms of female are the longest and have 180–240 suckers, which is characteristic. Sucker counts on the hectocotylised arm separate males of different species (about 95 suckers in this species). The hectocotylus is the specialised arm of male octopuses (in argonauts the third left) that is structurally different from the others and is used to transfer sperm from to the female during mating.
taxon_text_2_9132:
Female mantle length up to 10 cm. Total length up to about 45 cm. Shell length at least to 30 cm.

Male total length to 1.5 cm (excluding hectocotylus).
taxon_text_3_9133:
Global distribution: Widespread tropical and subtropical cosmopolitan species with circumglobal distribution (between about 40°N and 40°S).

Local/Regional: Entire region.
taxon_text_4_9134:
An oceanic epipelagic species typically found at the ocean surface but can also occur at depths of up to 200 metres. Females build large shells as brood chambers – structures that have fascinated biologists for centuries. In the 1800s, it was believed that the animals found inside the shells were parasites that had killed the rightful shell owners. The minute male was an even greater mystery. Since the male’s specialised third left arm detaches and crawls autonomously into the female’s mantle cavity to deliver a sperm package, female argonauts often contain multiple detached arms. These were also once mistakenly identified as parasites, until the species’ extraordinary reproductive biology was understood (see Reproduction section).

Females ‘gulp’ air into their shell cavity to maintain neutral buoyancy and stay afloat, swimming slowly using jet propulsion. They are usually solitary but have been observed forming schools, especially during the mating season. Due to their slow swimming, fragile shells, and lack of defensive arms, argonauts are highly vulnerable to predators. In response, they have developed several defensive strategies: females can retract fully into their shells and use modified arms to cover and camouflage the shell using chromatophores, applying countershading to disorient predators. Inking is another defensive tactic. A thick, dark ink is released in bursts to create a pseudomorph – an ink cloud that resembles the shape of the animal.

Like other paper nautiluses, it is vulnerable to global climate change. Ocean acidification could either dissolve the calcium carbonate egg case or interfere with its formation altogether.
taxon_text_5_9135: Species-specific dietary information is lacking, but argonauts likely feed on pelagic molluscs, shrimp, plankton, and small fishes. Female argonauts have also been observed attaching to jellyfish, using their lateral and ventral arms to cling to the aboral surface. It is speculated that they might also feed on the jellyfish, as bite marks have been found on the jellyfish’s surface and pieces of tissue have been observed missing or damaged. These bite marks often lead directly to the gastral cavity, suggesting that the argonaut may use the openings to extract food particles from inside the jellyfish. This association may serve a dual purpose – providing both a food source and physical protection.
taxon_text_6_9136:
Argonauts have a highly evolved and fascinating reproductive biology. The sexes are strongly dimorphic: females are large and have webbed arms that form a brood chamber where they lay their eggs. Males, in contrast, are dwarfs and do not build such structures, living freely in the open ocean. Males possess a highly specialised third left arm, called the hectocotylus, which makes up a large portion of their body.

Although mating behaviour remains unknown, it is thought that when a male encounters a female, he transfers spermatophores into his specialised arm. This arm then detaches from his body, crawls autonomously into the female’s brood chamber or even the mantle cavity, and finds her reproductive tract, where it deposits a sperm packet. The detached arm may remain inside the female for weeks, with spermatophores stored until she is ready to spawn. 

Like all octopuses, females spawn their eggs in festoons (long strands of eggs), which pass through the oviduct and are fertilised by stored sperm cells. The female then attaches the eggs inside the coiled brood chamber, which provides structure and protection. Eggs are laid repeatedly, develop for several days and hatch continuously, increasing the chances that some offspring encounter suitable ocean conditions for survival.

Females are believed to be capable of reproducing multiple times during their lifespan, while males are thought to die after mating, having sacrificed their hectocotylised arm.
taxon_text_7_9137:
Although each argonaut’s shell is individually variable, the three species found locally can be easily distinguished by their shell features and size. The Greater Argonaut (Argonauta argo) and the Knobby Argonaut (A. nodosus) are similar in size, while the Winged Argonaut (A. hians) is significantly smaller.

Only A. nodosus has round tubercles on the lateral ridges, although these may be less developed in smaller specimens. After this feature, the keel is particularly useful for identification.

In A. nodosus, the keel ridge is broad, with unpaired, alternating tubercles that increase in size as the shell grows. The shell aperture is moderately wide.

In A. argo, the keel ridge is narrow, with paired, perfectly parallel tubercles or spikes that remain the same size throughout growth. The shell aperture is narrow.

The shell of A. hians is quite different: it is sculptured and brown in colour (unlike the white shells of the other two species). The lateral ribs are prominent and widely spaced, and they do not align with the large, alternating tubercles on the very widely spaced keel. The aperture is much broader and often features prominent wing-like extensions, although these traits can vary considerably between individuals.
taxon_text_1_6045:
Colony consists of irregular, salmon-pink, encrusting coral-like growths found on the undersides or rocks, or in shaded gullies and is usually extended into upright finger-like processes covered on small round turrets.

When viewed closely the zooecia are irregularly arranges and have large round apertures raised on a small turret and with a notch on one side.
taxon_text_2_6046: Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 3 cm across, but can reach 10 cm.
taxon_text_3_6047:
Global: Widely distributed in South Atlantic

Local/Regional: West coast to Durban.
taxon_text_4_6048: Few details available. Common under boulders where they form thick coral-like encrustations, periodically thrown up into tall, often branched, finger-like processes. The lophophores are pink and large, so the expanded colony has a furry appearance. When closed the salmon-pink skeleton has an irregular texture punctured with small, round openings.
taxon_text_5_6049: All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_6050: Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the edges or tips. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites.
taxon_text_7_6051: The colour is fairly characteristic, but otherwise easily confused with the Arched false-coral bryozoan, Gephyrophora polymorpha, which has a similar upright growth form and is often present under the same rocks. That species is paler, dull, pinkish-orange though and has quite different, regularly-arranged rectangular zooids, each with a pair of tiny avicularia bridging the aperture.
taxon_text_8_6052:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 129, as Cellepora cylindriformis).
taxon_text_1_9113:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2-3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This elongate, rather eel-like species has a low, even dorsal fin made up of 46-50 spines and 2-4 rays and the fin lacks both a crest and cirri at the tips of the spines. The cirrus above the eye is a flat stalk branching at its tip. Colour mottles yellowish to brown or purple reddish-brown with a large oval black blotch above the operculum (sometimes ringed in white) and numerous black markings around the eyes and on the body. The eye cirrus is black.
taxon_text_3_9115:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to about East London.
taxon_text_4_9116: Uncommon and found in lowshore tidepools or hiding in crevices on shallow reefs, especially in kelp beds on the west coast. Prefers hiding places such as small caves with narrow entrances and prefers to stay in the back watching the cave opening. This behaviour suggests that it is night active. Little else known about its biology.
taxon_text_5_9117: Unknown for this species, but other members of genus feed on a wide range of benthic invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_9118: All clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom. Details unknown for this species.
taxon_text_7_9119: Distinguished from most other clinids by the elongate, eel-like body shape. A second species in the genus, the Striped klipfish B. striatus, has similar range and habits but is reddish with pronounced horizontal white stripes and no blotch above the operculum.
taxon_text_1_9140:
Small, muscular, smooth-skinned pelagic octopus with extreme sexual dimorphism. Dwarf males never to rarely seen. Females typically occupying brood case with their head forward, the lateral and ventral arms bent backwards adhering to the inside of the shell, and the dorsal arms either covering the outside shell faces or retracted within. First arm pair of the female has wide distal webs that secrete the thin calcium carbonate egg case. Identification is easily done based on shell morphology. In this species the brownish white and sculptured shell is characterised by the smooth, prominent and widely spaced, lateral ribs that do not align with the large, alternating keel tubercles. The keel of the shell and the shell aperture are very wide, the latter with a width about 60–90% of aperture length.

Arm lengths and sucker counts on the arms can be consulted to identify female specimens. In this species the second arms of female are the longest with about 80–110 suckers, and the fourth arms are short with 30–50 suckers. Sucker counts on hectocotylised arms separate males of different species (37 to 44 in this species). The hectocotylus is the specialised arm of male octopuses (in argonauts the third left) that is structurally different from the others and is used to transfer sperm from to the female during mating.
taxon_text_2_9141:
Female mantle length up to at least 4 cm. Total length up to 12 cm. Shell length at least to 11 cm.

Male total length to 1.2 cm (excluding hectocotylus) and 4 cm (including hectocotylus).
taxon_text_3_9142:
Global distribution: ﻿Widespread pelagic temperate to tropical species throughout the Indo-West Pacific from South Africa in the west to Papua New Guinea in the east and Japan in the north. Absent from the Eastern Pacific, and the North and Southwest Atlantic.

Local/Regional: Found throughout region.
taxon_text_4_9143:
A small, oceanic epipelagic species typically found at the ocean surface but can also occur at depths of up to 200 metres. Females build small shells as brood chambers – structures that have fascinated biologists for centuries. In the 1800s, it was believed that the animals found inside the shells were parasites that had killed the rightful shell owners. The minute male was an even greater mystery. Since the male’s specialised third left arm detaches and crawls autonomously into the female’s mantle cavity to deliver a sperm package, female argonauts often contain multiple detached arms. These were also once mistakenly identified as parasites, until the species’ extraordinary reproductive biology was understood.

Females swim slowly using jet propulsion, are usually solitary but have been observed forming schools. Due to their slow swimming, fragile shells, and lack of defensive arms, argonauts are highly vulnerable to predators. In response, they have developed several defensive strategies that include camouflaging the shell using chromatophores to create countershading. The colour varies strongly from deep maroon to silver. Inking is another defensive tactic to further disorient predators.

This species is frequently associated with gelatinous organisms such as jellyfish and salps. Divers often observe individuals clinging to the bell of a jellyfish, riding on its back – likely using it both for transport and protection. This species has also been reported to form chains of up to 20–30 individuals of the same size, each holding onto the shell of one in front, with the first individual attached to a jellyfish.

The Winged argonaut has long been divided into two groups based on the female’s shell morphology of either having winged ear-like projections (A. hians) or not having such projections (previously recognised as A. boettgeri). Currently, only A. hians is a taxonomically accepted species. Like other paper nautiluses, it is vulnerable to global climate change and ocean acidification could either dissolve the calcium carbonate egg case or interfere with its formation altogether.
taxon_text_5_9144:
Females are reported to be specialised predators of pelagic molluscs, especially heteropods and pteropods, but also octopuses (potentially male argonauts), as well as crustaceans, comb jellies and fishes. Specimens held in captivity preferred soft-bodied prey items such as polychaetes.

Observed using jellyfishes as a ‘pseudo-hunting platform’ by steering the jellyfish to get closer to prey items. Tentacles then shoot out to grab the prey.

Preyed upon by a variety of oceanic predators such as fish and birds.
taxon_text_6_9145: Acute sexual dimorphism as large females have webbed first arms that secrete calcium carbonate egg cases, whilst males are dwarf with hectocotylised third arms that detach to fertilise eggs. Females reach maturity at about 2.8 cm shell length and carry about 5,000 eggs of three different developmental stages.
taxon_text_7_9146:
Although each argonaut’s shell is individually variable, the three species found locally can be easily distinguished by their shell features and size. The Greater Argonaut (Argonauta argo) and the Knobby Argonaut (A. nodosus) are similar in size, while the Winged Argonaut (A. hians) is significantly smaller.

The shell of A. hians is quite different to the other two species as it is sculptured and brown in colour (not white as in both the previous species). The lateral ribs are prominent, widely spaced and don’t align with the large, alternating tubercles on the very widely spaced keel. The aperture is also much broader and often has prominent wings, although these characters can vary greatly depending on the specimen.
taxon_text_1_9149:
Members of the family Spionidae are fairy easily recognized, as they have a characteristic pair of elongate grooved palps extending from the otherwise fairly featureless pointed or rounded head. Otherwise most are small and slender.

Members of the genus Polydora, and of the closely related and similar Boccardia, have swollen and enlarged 5th body segments, but are best known for their ability to bore into shell and limestone rock. The characteristic 8-shaped burrow openings they leave in limestone rocks are a frequently noticed characteristic of these worms.
taxon_text_3_9151:
Global: Not identified to species, so distribution cannot be given, but family cosmopolitan.

Local/Regional: Found throughout region.
taxon_text_4_9152:
Live in burrows excavated in shells, dead coral or limestone. The burrow is created using acid secretions and the stout setae of the enlarged 5th body segment and is lined with sediment.

 

If burrows are made into the shells of living bivalves, such as oysters, the mollusc reacts by secreting additional shell material and this can result in slowing of the growth rate, roughening of the interior shell and even mud-blisters in the shell. These all lower the economic value of the oysters, so the worms are considered significant economic pests in the oyster industry.


Populations which burrow into rock are often overlooked when the worms are alive, as the sediment used to line the tubes makes them difficult to spot. Limestone rocks cast up on shore though, often bear numerous very characteristic 8-shaped burrows left by the dead worms and these are a frequent cause of curiosity. If the rock is broken,  the burrows can be seen extending about 10 mm down into the rock. The worms tend to maintain a more or less constant feeding distance between individuals, so the burrow opening are often regularly spaced on the rock surface.
taxon_text_5_9153: Detritus feeders, using the elongate palps to gather organic matter either from the water column, or more commonly from the sediment surface.
taxon_text_6_9154: Most species in this group can reproduce both asexually and sexually. In asexual reproduction the worm may develop a daughter individual that then splits off, or may divide and each half then regenerates the missing portions. In sexual reproduction eggs and sperm are released into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. In some species larvae may also be brooded in the tubes.
taxon_text_7_9155: Fairly easily recognised to group because of the long, grooved palps (although similar palps do also occur in a few other families), but there are over 40 regional species that require detailed microscopic examination to identify to species level. Some species also burrow into soft sediments, such as the very common Scolelepis squamata which can occur in densities of thousands per square meter (see that entry).
taxon_text_8_9156:

taxon_text_1_6764: Forms solitary, erect, tough, upright growths emerging from a single, grooved, woody holdfast. Stems branch sparsely several times, especially towards tips. Colour yellow-brown.
taxon_text_2_6765: Total height up to about 30 cm with main branches about 6 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_6766:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Groen River on west coast to about Cape Infanta.
taxon_text_4_6767: Seldom exposed to air, but grows in deeper intertidal pools and shallow gullies, where it can be the dominant alga. A favoured attachment site for egg cases of Haploblepharus Shysharks species.
taxon_text_6_6769: Single macroscopic diploid stage produces gametes from receptacles
taxon_text_7_6770: Can be confused with Hanging wrack Brassicophycus sisymbrioudes (also because of similarly long generic name!), but that species has a much softer texture, hangs rather than stands erect, and grows in colonies emerging from a matted web of rhizones, rather than from independent holdfasts.
taxon_text_8_6771:

taxon_text_1_6800: Tall, narrow central frond arises from a small disc-like holdfast and gives off lateral spear-like branches, all in a single plane. Each lateral branch arises from a narrow base and has finely-serrated margins. Colour uniform light yellowish-brown, darkening with age.
taxon_text_2_6801: Large, reaching 100 cm in height, fronds about 3 cm wide.
taxon_text_3_6802:
Global: Chile and Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Betty‘s Bay.
taxon_text_4_6803: Common understorey species in kelp beds, where it ranges from sublittoral fringe to 25 m depth. Well-known for its ability to secrete sulphuric acid to deter herbivores. When stranded on rocks burns distinctive pale shadows into rock surfaces which often attracts interest.
taxon_text_6_6805: Alternating generations of the large spore-producing sporophytes and small filamentous separate male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6806: The large size and unusual branching pattern of fronds are good identification features.
taxon_text_8_6807:
Anderson, RJ (1982). The life history of Desmarestia firma (C. Ag.) Skottsb.(Phaeophyceae, Desmarestiales). Phycologia, 21(3), 316-322.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 384).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 175).
taxon_text_1_6836: A small species of kelp with sporophytes only about 1 m tall. Holdfast conical and made up of a tangle of branching root-like haptera. Stipe solid and cylindrical, typically about 50 cm tall, giving rise to elongate primary blade from which shorter secondary blades branch laterally. Both primary and secondary blades with prickly surface and bearing reproductive sori.
taxon_text_2_6837: Total length typically about 1 m, but may reach 2 m in deeper waters.
taxon_text_3_6838:
Global: South Africa, New Zealand, Australia, Canary Islands, Cape Verde Islands, Senegal, Madagascar, Oman.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana Bay.
taxon_text_4_6839: Found in deep intertidal pools and on shallow reefs along the south coast, but also in deeper waters (10-30 m) in False Bay and as far east as Sodwana Bay in northern KwaZulu-Natal, where extends to 60 m depth.
taxon_text_6_6841: Alternating generations of the familiar large spore-producing sporophytes and separate microscopic male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6842: Could be confused with small E. maxima, but has a solid stipe and prickly rather than smooth fronds and is absent from west coast.
taxon_text_8_6843:

taxon_text_1_6890: Brown, globular, slippery cushion often with strongly convoluted surface (hence common name). Walls relatively thick with a smallish internal cavity.
taxon_text_2_6891: Total length can reach 8 cm, but more typically 2-4 cm.
taxon_text_3_6892:
Global: Widespread in temperate seas.

Local/Regional: Entire coastline, but more common on west coast.
taxon_text_4_6893: Typically found attached to rocks or other algae on intertidal rocks or in pools.
taxon_text_6_6895: Sporangia not seen in South African material.
taxon_text_7_6896: Often confused with Oyster thief Colpomenia sinuosa, but that species is lighter in colour, has thinner walls and a large internal cavity.
taxon_text_8_6897:
Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

taxon_text_1_6908: Flaccid, slippery and light brown with a soft, furry texture due to surface covering of short filaments. Thallus sparsely branched, some of the branches as long as the main axes. Branches bend readily in the current and break up easily when handled. When viewed under the microscope the furry surface filaments are formed of a single chain of cells, longer towards the base and as broad as long distally and with oval sporangia near their bases.
taxon_text_2_6909: Total length can reach 30-50 cm, branches about 3 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_6910:
Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_6911: Typically in lowshore pools and gullies on wave exposed coasts.
taxon_text_6_6913: Oval sporangia found attached to filaments on surfaces of thallus.
taxon_text_7_6914: The flaccid, furry texture is fairly characteristic of this group. This species is characterised by having only a few elongate branches, but the more profusely and densely branched Myriocladia capensis, Myriogloia papenfussii and Myriogloia abbreviata occur in similar habitats (see Stegenga reference for details as to how to distinguish these).
taxon_text_8_6915:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 390, identified to group only).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 155).
taxon_text_1_6935: Bushy dark to yellow-brown species emerging from a conical holdfast. Primary stipes distinctly triangular in cross section and can have sharp edges. Lower fronds large, oval and smooth edged with a clear midrib and often streaked with dark brown. Upper fronds much smaller, spear-shaped and with serrated edges. Reproductive individuals bear bunches of grape-like vesicles each with a distal spike.
taxon_text_2_6936: Total length can reach 50 cm, but more typically 25 cm.
taxon_text_3_6937:
Global: Mozambique, Madagascar, South Africa and possibly Mauritius.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_6938: Typically in lowshore pools and gullies on wave exposed coasts, but survives in deeper pools high in the intertidal.
taxon_text_6_6940: Alternating generations of the familiar large spore-producing sporophytes and separate microscopic male and female gametophytes.
taxon_text_7_6941: The two different forms of frond and triangular stem are characteristic. The related S. elegans has a similar range but smooth, rounded stems.
taxon_text_8_6942:

taxon_text_1_9183:
Most easily identified by its unique association with feather stars, specifically Tropiometra carinata on which it is camouflaged. The shrimp has various colour morphs and patterns, mimicking that of its respective feather star host, and hence ranges from longitudinal red and yellow stripes to a spotted panther-like pattern.

The carapace (upper hard shell) is somewhat stout, leading into a straight rostrum (projection to the front) that is roughly as long as the carapace. The rostrum is smooth with a sharp spine at the end, and 2-3 ventral teeth on the underside. The diagnostic character separating this species from other South African species is a whorl of setae on the tip of the third maxilliped (mouth part). Since specimens would need to be collected and dissected to see this character, the identification in the field by its unique habitat and behaviour is highly useful.
taxon_text_3_9185:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Recently described, only known from False Bay (though some unverified records on iNaturalist include Australia, Phillippines, Tanzania and Gulf of Aqaba).
taxon_text_4_9186: Has a unique association and can exclusively be found on the Elegant feather star, Tropiometra carinata where roughly 20% of feather stars hosts between 1-3 shrimp. These are exceedingly difficult to spot due to their small size and camouflaged nature. The feather star provides protection and food for the shrimp.
taxon_text_5_9187: Thought to feed on the mucous and waste produced by the feather star, and also scavenges food particles from the ambulacral groove running down the arms of the feather star as it passes the food to its mouth.
taxon_text_6_9188: Suggested to exhibit simple protandry (where males become females), as observed in many others species in the genus elsewhere.
taxon_text_7_9189: Their association with feather stars (living and camouflaging on them) is diagnostic, though another species in the same genus, the Broken-backed shrimp H. kraussiana is also know from the region.
taxon_text_8_9190:
d'Udekem d'Acoz, C (2007). New records of Atlantic Hippolyte, with the description of two new species, and a key to all Atlantic and Mediterranean species (Crustacea, Decapoda, Caridea). Zoosystema, 29, 183-207.

Levy, T, Zupo, V, Mutalipassi, M, Somma, E, Ruocco, N, Costantini, M, Abehsera, S, Manor, R, Chalifa-Caspi, V, Sagi, A & Aflalo, ED (2021). Protandric transcriptomes to uncover parts of the crustacean sex-differentiation puzzle. Frontiers in Marine Science, 8, p.745540.
taxon_text_1_9192:
Small to medium-sized inconspicuous shrimp with various colour patterns, ranging from yellow, green, red and almost black to match its habitat.

Slender carapace (hard upper shell) terminating in a straight rostrum that is slightly shorter than the length of the carapace. Rostrum with 1-2 dorsal teeth and 4-5 ventral teeth. Pleon (hind body) bent in the middle giving it a distinctive hunch- or ‘broken’-backed appearance, separating it from other South African Hippolyte species.
taxon_text_3_9194:
Global: South Africa to Madagascar.

Local/Regional: Simon’s Town to East London.
taxon_text_4_9195: Lives among and on various seaweeds, estuarine weedbeds and seagrass. Broken-backed shrimps are slow-moving, cryptic and use camouflage to avoid predation.
taxon_text_5_9196: Not specifically known for this species, though others in the genus have been shown to have varied diet including diatoms, macroalgae, sponges, bryozoans and foraminiferans. Interestingly, studies on other species from elsewhere have shown that diet can lead to sex changes, as in the case of Hippolyte inermis when feeding on certain diatoms.
taxon_text_6_9197: Suggested to exhibit simple protandry (where males become females), as observed in many others species in the genus elsewhere.
taxon_text_7_9198: The bent abdomen giving a hunchbacked appearance is diagnostic.
taxon_text_8_9199:

taxon_text_1_9201:
Small to medium-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) variably colour ranging from tan to yellow-brown or salmon-red, while some found in muddy areas are more greenish-brown, brown or violet. Middle of carapace with diagnostic whitish spots.

Carapace mostly smooth, with some granules on the sternum (‘chest’ area). Carapace wider than long, widest in the middle portion, with a single tooth on side of carapace next to the eye. Chelae (pincers) unequal, smooth. Walking legs stout and strong, surface mostly smooth.
taxon_text_3_9203:
Global: Endemic to the region.

Local/Regional: From the Lüderitz in Namibia to Kosi Bay, KwaZulu-Natal, high shore and intertidally.
taxon_text_4_9204:
One of the most common shore crabs along the South African coast, frequently encountered aggregating under rocks or in between matted weeds on the upper shore. These crabs are also occasionally seen on mudflats in the lower reaches of estuaries. Interestingly, Shore crabs have also been observed constructing burrows. They are adapted being on land for extended periods as they have a specialised mechanism for keeping their gills wet.

Can tolerate high salinity around 40% (normal ocean concentrations vary around 35%) for extended periods in order to withstand high shore pools that dry out in the sun. However, cannot tolerate low salinity of 20% for extended periods.

 Populations are strongly male dominated. Males aggressively compete for shelter and mates, and show defensive behaviour of raising the pincers when threatened. Shore crabs are mostly nocturnal, rarely emerging during the day.
taxon_text_5_9205: Mostly scavenges at night during low tide, eating a variety of items, including mostly kelp wrack and high-shore invertebrates including the Broad sea slater (Ligia dilatata), Topshells (Oxystele spp.) and Southern periwinkles (Afrolittorina knysnaensis).
taxon_text_6_9206: Males and females hold each other with their bellies facing each other until the female moults and after which the male transfers a sperm package to the female and both go their own way. When the female is ready to spawn her eggs, they are fertilised by the stored sperm package on their way out, consecutively attached and held under the females tail where they develop into the first larval stage and are then released into the open ocean. The pelagic larva swims and develops in the plankton before settling back to the ground as a small juvenile crab. Ovigerous females are observed during Winter and Spring months (July – October).
taxon_text_7_9207: Their habitat, smooth carapace smooth chelae make this species unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_9208:
