taxon_text_1_9210:
Squat lobsters are anomuran crabs which have four pairs of visible pereiopods (walking legs), with a fifth reduced pair, usually hidden under the carapace (hard upper shell) or in the gill chamber. Squat lobsters superficially resemble true lobsters as they also hold their tails curled beneath their bodies, however squat lobsters are dorsoventrally flattened (from top to bottom) and are typically much smaller than true lobsters.

The Blue-spotted squat lobster is characterised by the carapace being roughly as long as it is broad, with 1–2 pairs of epigastric (just below the base of the rostrum) spines and mostly uninterrupted transverse ridges, while the lateral margins (the sides) each have 7 spines. The rostrum is broad with 4 deeply incised teeth on the sides.

The overall brick-red-orange colouration and blue (occasionally white) spots is characteristic. The pleon (hind body) is a lighter orange, often mottled, while the tail is white. Eyes generally green, while pincers and walking legs are orange with some mottling at the bases.
taxon_text_3_9212:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Durban Bay, 19–135 m.
taxon_text_4_9213: Lives on rocky reefs and consolidated habitats. Rarely encountered by divers as the species generally occurs deeper than the normal diving depth (though it was described from shallow-waters in Simon’s Town). Have been observed on coralline algae, sponges and hiding in shells such as empty barnacles.
taxon_text_5_9214: Not specifically known for this species, though most species in the genus are scavengers.
taxon_text_6_9215: All squat lobsters are gonochoric (separate sexes with males and females), with no hermaphrodites known currently. Males transfer a spermatophore to a female, which then is then attached to the ventral side of the female where the eggs are fertilized when spawned and attached underneath the tail where they develop until the larvae are ready to be released into the open water. Larvae are planktotrophic.
taxon_text_7_9216: This species is the only squat lobster known from the Great African Seaforest and can hence not be confused with any others.
taxon_text_8_9217:
Botha, TPA (2024). A taxonomic revision of the squat lobsters (Anomura: Chirostyloidea and Galatheoidea) of South Africa. PhD thesis, University of Cape Town.

Botha, TPA, Griffiths, CL, Atkinson, LJ & Macpherson, E (2025). The Galatheidae (Anomura: Galatheoidea) of South Africa, with a description of a new species. Zootaxa, 5661(3), 330-350.

Macpherson, E & Robainas-Barcia, A (2015). Species of the genus Galathea Fabricius, 1793 (Crustacea, Decapoda, Galatheidae) from the Indian and Pacific Oceans, with descriptions of 92 species. Zootaxa, 3913, 1 – 335.
taxon_text_1_1316: Test flattened, somewhat irregular in texture and shape and adhering to the rock surface by its entire left side (including the siphons). Colour semi-transparent yellowish to brown, with test incorporating large pieces of gravel of shell on exposed surface. Siphons unusually elongate and widely divergent, so that their openings can be 15 cm or more apart. Tips of siphons not lobed, but inhalant siphon bears pronounced circle of oral tentacles, aperture yellow or orange.
taxon_text_3_1318:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_1319:
An unusual species that lives in narrow crevices or attached to the underside of rocks in shallow water and is completely attached to the rock surface by its one side, one siphon usually extending from underneath the rock. Although quite common in its restricted habitat it has a very limited recorded range and was only re-discovered by Monniot et al. (2001) more than a century after its original description.

The structure of the outer test of solitary ascidians such as this is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material! In this species further protection is afforded by incorporation large pieces of shell or rock into the test matrix and concealing the body within narrow crevices.
taxon_text_5_1320: All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.
taxon_text_6_1321:
Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary ones like this reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilisation takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.
taxon_text_7_1322: There are several Ascidia species in the region and these can be difficult to distinguish, but A. caudata is best separated from related species by the fact that the siphons are glued to the rock and their tips are not lobed (as in both A. canaliculata and A. incrassata), nor have red spots between the lobes (as in A. incrassata). Instead the oral siphon has a ring of oral tentacles.
taxon_text_8_1323:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246 - note photo 110.7 is of incorrect species).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 65).
taxon_text_1_9228:
Small to medium sized prawn, body mostly pink to pale yellow and translucent, with internal organs visible, pleon (hind body) darker. Chelae (pincers) unequal in size (particularly so in males) a bright white colour.

Carapace (hard upper shell) slender, with frontal margin slightly concave on either side of the small rostral point. Pleon with specialized pleopods used for water filtration. Major chela can be either left or right side (more often on left), wrist (carpus) longer than broad.
taxon_text_3_9230:
Global: Temperate Southern Africa including Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Entire coastline from Namibian border to Mozambican border, intertidal to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_9231:
Sandprawns are common in estuaries, even ones that have been closed the sea for years! Known to be a prolific ecosystem engineer as it creates deep burrows (over a meter deep) manipulating sediments at high rates of up to 12.14 kg/m2/day. Water gets pulled into the burrow resulting in phytoplankton getting trapped on the sediment of the burrows walls. This is filtered by the sandprawn and food particles are subsequently eaten, and the cleaned sand is ejected from the burrow to create a small ‘volcano’ at the opening. The process of filtering sediment or ‘bioturbation’ positively affects the environment as it enhances bacteria, buries phytoplankton such as diatoms and inhibits larval settlement of many other species. In the process, sandprawns oxygenate the sediment and reduce eutrophication (build-up of nutrients causing algal blooms) by removing phytoplankton from the water column. 

 

Sandprawns are susceptible to human activities as they are a sought-after live bait for fishing, taken by recreational anglers through prawn pumps. They are also impacted by trampling as they share their habitat with beachgoers. Increased trampling, and more so too excessive ‘pumping’ compromises sandprawn habitat and its structural integrity, with knock-on implications on the surrounding ecosystem and diversity. Studies have shown that the % decline in harvested populations is far greater than just the number of prawns taken For example, Branch showed that in a population where only 6–13% of the population was harvested, they observed a 70% decline in the population.
taxon_text_5_9232: Filters sediment from its burrow, eating phytoplankton accumulated within (mostly diatoms).
taxon_text_6_9233: Known to have unusually high recruitment rates due to an adapted, non-planktonic reproduction mode with few but large eggs that have low larval mortalities. As in other decapod crustaceans, females attach the spermatophore (passed from the male) to the ventral side of the pleon (hind body), where the eggs are fertilized as they get spawned and then attached to the pleopods underneath the tail. The large and relatively few eggs (up to 200 per female) are then carried by the female for about 30 days before they hatch into small juveniles that, instead of swimming in the plankton, dig small side-burrows out of the parental burrow.
taxon_text_7_9234: The habitat, unequal white chelae and overall pink-translucent colour makes this species unmistakable. Frequently found co-occurring with the Estuarine mudprawn, Upogebia africana, but that species same-sized pincers and is green-brown in colour.
taxon_text_8_9235:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 112).

Forbes, AT (1977). Breeding and growth of the burrowing prawn Calianassa kraussi Stebbing (Crustacea: Decapoda: Thalassinidea). African Zoology, 12(1), 149-161.

Venter, O, Pillay, D & Prayag, K (2020). Water filtration by burrowing sandprawns provides novel insights on endobenthic engineering and solutions for eutrophication. Scientific Reports, 10(1), 1913.
taxon_text_1_9237: Carapace flattened, transversely ovate, gastric region slightly raised, dorsal surface with fine granules giving a sharkskin-like texture. Frontal region squarish, projecting forward, eyes hidden dorsally. Margins of carapace with 2-3 sets of minute granules around the edge. Pterygostomial region has large, flat-topped granules closely together, separated by deep crevices. Carapace mostly white/cream and often mottled with orange/red blotches or smaller spots. Chelipeds and walking legs mostly white/cream, though occasionally coloured darker orange.
taxon_text_2_9238: Carapace length up to 9 mm, width around 11 mm.
taxon_text_3_9239:
Global: South Africa, India.

Local/Regional: From False Bay to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_9240: This shallow-water species is often encountered in the intertidal under stones, within shell deposits where it is exceptionally cryptic. They have also been observed on free-floating seaweeds that accumulate in the surf zone.
taxon_text_5_9241: Not specifically known for this species, though many leucosid crabs are scavengers, while some are ambush predators that feed on small crustaceans.
taxon_text_6_9242: Not specifically known for this species, though for others in the family males transfer sperm to the female via the spermatophore, and eggs are either released and fertilised on their way out, or fertilization happens internally as some species have a brooding chamber for the eggs to develop.
taxon_text_7_9243: One of four species in the genus . It was recently moved by Poore & Ahyong (2023) from the subfamily Cryptocneminae Stimpson 1907 to the Ebaliinae Stimpson, 1871.
taxon_text_8_9244:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

Emmerson, WD (2016). A Guide to, and Checklist for, the Decapoda of Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique. Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars Publishing. Volumes 1 – 3, 526, 645, 711 pp.

Poore, GC & Ahyong, ST (2023). Marine Decapod Crustacea: A Guide to Families and Genera of the World. CSIRO publishing.
taxon_text_1_9246:
Medium-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) pale orange, with four distinctive grey blotches, each surrounded by a thin red line.

Carapace longer than broad, lateral margins (sides) with four sharp teeth. Antennae distinctive, almost as long as body. Chelae (pincers) have granules, with a sharp spine on inner margin of carpus (wrist). Legs, short and stout for burying in sand, tips of legs flat.
taxon_text_3_9248:
Global: South Africa, Namibia.

Local/Regional: Algoa Bay to Namibia, intertidal to 82 m (some reports up to 200 m from Namibia).
taxon_text_4_9249: Mostly found in sheltered sandbanks where it digs backwards, with its eyes and long antennae sticking out. Antennae specialised and forms a tube of interlocking hairs, through which the crab draws water in, enabling it to take in oxygen while completely burrowed. Have been observed to inhabit oxygen-deficient habitats.
taxon_text_5_9250: Not specifically known, but likely filter feeds water drawn in through the tube formed by the antennae.
taxon_text_6_9251: Not specifically known, though males likely transfer a spermatophore to a female, which then is then attached to the ventral side of the female where the eggs are fertilized when spawned and attached underneath the tail where they develop until the larvae are ready to be released into the open water.
taxon_text_7_9252: The four grey blotches with red lining around makes the species unmistakable.
taxon_text_8_9253:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).
taxon_text_1_9390: Small geophytic perennial with fairly-broad, soft, sword-shaped, upright, pleated leaves that are coated with soft hairs.  The large, fragrant blooms are borne on inflorescences of 2-6 blue or purple flowers. Each flower has 6 tepals (‘petals’) the upper 3 slightly larger than the lower three, which are partly merged basally and which bear white markings.  The flowers have a strong rose-violet scent.
taxon_text_2_9391: Plants 6-15 cm tall, flowers about 50 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9392:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution along dunes and coastal flats between about Saldanha and Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_9393: Very striking plant but has been depleted over much of its range due to urban development, agriculture and competition from invasive species and the population is now fragmented. The corms (enlarged underground stem that store food) are eaten by baboons and porcupines, hence the common name.
taxon_text_7_9396: This is a diverse genus with about 50 species found in the fynbos biome, but the blooms of the various species vary widely in form and colour ranging from white to yellow, blue or purple. The white-marked purple flowers in this species are fairly distinctive.
taxon_text_1_9255:
Medium to large-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) cream-grey coloured, speckled with reddish dots, a crescent-shaped red mark in the middle, with two larger oval red spots at the back. Chelae (pincers) tinged reddish-pink on inner surface.

Carapace much wider than long, with granules on surface, frontal margin with four teeth, with another next to each eye and four large teeth on the lateral (side) margins. Chelae inner side of upper margin with fringe of shaggy hair, outer surface of wrist and hand with granules. Second leg with horned ridge on end of the fourth joint, creating a stridulating mechanism (used for communication) when rubbed against its chelae (especially in older males). Dactyl (last segment) of fifth leg flattened, oval-shaped, used as a ‘paddle’ for swimming.
taxon_text_2_9256: Carapace length up to 55 mm, breadth up to 70 mm. Total animal width from tip of left legs to right legs about 200 mm.
taxon_text_3_9257:
Global: Widespread as found on both sides of South America (Chile, Argentina, Brazil), as well as several sub-Antarctic islands, Madagascar, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: From Walvis Bay, Namibia to Port Shepstone, KwaZulu-Natal, on sandy beaches in the surf zone to 38 m.
taxon_text_4_9258:
Three-spot swimming crabs are strong swimmers commonly encountered below the break zone of surf-beaten sandy beaches where they use the paddle-like hindlegs to navigate a dynamic environment. Move fast over the sand and can quickly dig themselves into the sand with a characteristic and dynamic backwards pumping movement. With just the eyes sticking out they are safely hidden from predators, and ready to attack bypassing prey. Mostly active at night.

Like all crustaceans, frequently moult as they grow, and this is done in the safety of being buried in the sand. Fresh moults that wash up are therefore often fragmented as parts of the fragile shells remain stuck in the sand. Studies have found larger individuals occur shallower (<20 m), while juveniles tend to occur in deeper waters, suggesting settlement of larva occurs deeper.

Biomass of these crabs have been estimated to around 1 crab per square meter of beach (based on a study in Gqeberha, formerly Port Elizabeth), and the species is commercially important in Chile and Argentina, though only taken as bycatch using beach-seine nets. In some instances mass mortalities occurred due to larvae of the alien invasive mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis settling on the eyestalks and mouthparts (as these are virtually the only hard substratum where mussel larvae can settle on sandy habitats), severely reducing the crabs ability to function, and this has led to mortalities of 2000-2400 crabs per kilometre of shore.
taxon_text_5_9259: Voracious predators of bivalves and gastropods, especially various Donax spp. and Bullia spp. Also found to eat polychaetes, fish or other crustaceans buried in the sand or swimming in the surf zone. In South America these crabs were found to also target some rocky shore species, though not specifically looked in South African populations.
taxon_text_6_9260: Occurs between males and recently-moulted females, mostly at night. The male turns the female upside-down using his chelae and holds her with his legs to transfer the spermatophore (sperm package). Have been found to stay paired up for up to 12 hours after. Short spawning period present in January, with a longer one in May, where female release the eggs to the underside of their body and carry them until they hatch. Studies have found females to be extremely fecund, carrying between 76000-490000 eggs. Have eight zoeal stages, with one megalopa stage, after which they develop into juveniles, settling in deeper waters.
taxon_text_7_9261: A sister species, O. iridescens also occurs in South Africa, though they are found in deeper waters along the south coast and unlikely to be confused. The habitat, the two red oval spots and median red mark are diagnostic of O. trimaculatus.
taxon_text_8_9262:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 122).

Du Preez, HH (1983). The effects of temperature, season and activity on the respiration of the three spot swimming crab, Ovalipes punctatus. Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part A: Physiology, 75(3), 353-362.

Du Preez, HH & McLachlan, A (1984). Distribution of the portunid crab Ovalipes punctatus (De Haan) in Algoa Bay and salinity and temperature tolerances of its zoeae. African Zoology, 19(4), 302-304.

Emmerson, WD (2016). A Guide to, and Checklist for, the Decapoda of Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique. Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars Publishing. Volumes 1 – 3, 526, 645, 711 pp.

Schoeman, DS & Cockcroft, AC (1996). A description of Ovalipes trimaculatus (De Haan, 1833)(Brachyura: Portunidae: Polybiinae) zoeae reared in the laboratory. South African Journal of Marine Science, 17(1), 113-134.
taxon_text_1_9273:
Small to medium sized porcelain crab, generally red or dark brown, covered in dull brown, dense setae (hairs) on the walking legs with fewer setae on the carapace (hard upper shell).

Carapace slender with fine setae on the surface and a trilobed frontal margin (between the eyes). Chelae (pincers) enlarged, flattened and unequal in size, with the left chela being smaller and bearing distinctive fine nodules on the surface. Three pairs of main legs for walking and a fourth reduced pair hidden underneath the pleon (hind body).
taxon_text_3_9275:
Global: South Africa (alien invasive) and coast of northwestern Africa, from Western Sahara to Senegal.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay, intertidal to 22 m.
taxon_text_4_9276: This species was only discovered in (2011) as alien species, and is currently restricted to Saldanha Bay. Commonly found underneath intertidal boulders and in mussel beds of the also non-native Mediterranean mussel, Mytilus galloprovincialis. Can occur in great densities of > 100 per m2 in some areas.
taxon_text_5_9277: Known to be a filter feeder that may also consume some detrital particles (remains of animal and plant matter) that accumulate under boulders.
taxon_text_6_9278: Not specifically known, though all porcelain crab males transfer a spermatophore to a female, which then is then attached to the ventral side of the female where the eggs are fertilized when spawned and attached underneath the tail where they develop until the larvae are ready to be released into the open water.
taxon_text_7_9279: The only other porcelain crab from the area, Pisidia streptocheles occurs on deeper reefs and not in the intertidal and is hence unlikely to be confused. The body of P. streptocheles is also not pubescent, the chelae are not strongly flattened, and the inner apex of the merus (third segment from the tip) is produced into a distinctive, strong, squarely-truncated tooth.
taxon_text_8_9280:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 112).

Griffiths CL, Roberts S, Branch GM et al (2018) The porcelain crab Porcellana africana Chace,1956 (Decapoda: Porcellanidae) introduced into Saldanha Bay, South Africa. Bioinvasions Records, 7, 133–142.
taxon_text_1_9282:
Small to medium sized prawn with robust body usually a green/brown colour. Walking legs and underside of body paler.

Front of carapace (hard upper shell) ‘tridentate’, meaning the longer rostrum in the middle has two side teeth, and these are less than half the length of the rostrum. Chelae (pincers) equal in size and not conventionally chelate, but rather the thumb is almost absent, with finger bending back to meet it. First two pairs of walking legs with no spine at their bases.
taxon_text_3_9284:
Global: South Africa and Mozambique.

Local/Regional: From the border of the Western- and Northern Cape to Mozambican border, intertidal to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_9285: Creates unique U-shaped burrows intertidally in estuarine muddy sands. The prawn pumps water through its burrow, where it filters out food particles using its hairy mouthparts. Susceptible to human activities and are frequently taken as bait for recreational fishing. Mudprawns are also at risk to trampling from beachgoers as their burrows collapses and sediment becomes compacted, making burrowing increasingly more difficult. Research has shown that bait-harvesting of these animals have far greater effects on the population than just the number of animals removed. Mudprawns are not as tolerant as sandprawns to diverse conditions and unlike them are completely absent from closed estuaries in which salinity levels are low.
taxon_text_5_9286: Filter-feeder that sits in the burrow filtering water that is pumped in through the U-shaped burrow. Their guts are laden with symbiotic bacteria that are thought to supplement its diet.
taxon_text_6_9287: Seems to be inactive in winter months (May, June), but have a Spring (July-October) cycle and Summer (December-March) cycle, with females producing 2–4 broods per year. As in other decapod crustaceans, females attach the spermatophore (passed from the male) to the ventral side of the pleon (hind body), where the eggs are fertilized as they get spawned and then attached to the pleopods underneath the tail. Known to produce small, but numerous eggs (often several 1000 per brood per female). Larvae are released into the water column where they have a planktonic larval phase before they settle in the sediment, creating their burrows.
taxon_text_7_9288: Similar to the larger Coastal mudprawn, Upogebia capensis, however the first two pairs of walking legs have a spine at the base in U. capensis, while it is absent in the U. africana. Frequently found co-occurring with the Common sandprawn Kraussilichirus kraussi, however the habitat, subequal chelae and green-brown colour distinguishes the Estuarine mudprawn from K. kraussi.
taxon_text_8_9289:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 112).

Forbes, AT (1977). Breeding and growth of the burrowing prawn Calianassa kraussi stebbing (Crustacea: Decapoda: Thalassinidea). African Zoology, 12(1), 149-161.

Wooldridge, TH & Loubser, H (1996). Larval release rhythms and tidal exchange in the estuarine mudprawn, Upogebia africana. Hydrobiologia, 337, 113-121.

Wynberg, RP & Branch, GM (1994). Disturbance associated with bait-collecting for sandprawns (Callianassa kraussi) and mudprawns (Upogebia africana): long term effects on the biota of intertidal sandflats. Journal of Marine Research, 52, 523–528.
taxon_text_1_9291:
Small to medium sized prawn with robust body usually a green/brown colour. Walking legs and underside of body paler.

Front of carapace (hard upper shell) ‘tridentate’, meaning the longer rostrum in the middle has two side-teeth, and these are less than half the length of the rostrum. Chelae (pincers) equal in size and not conventionally chelate, but rather the thumb is almost absent, with finger bending back to meet it. First two pairs of walking legs with no spine at their bases.
taxon_text_3_9293:
Global: South Africa and Namibia.

Local/Regional: From the border of Namibia to Mossel Bay, subtidal to 10 m.
taxon_text_4_9294: Very little is known regarding the biology. Similar to Upogebia africana, this species prefers sediment with a mud content between 5–11%. Occurs in habitats deeper than U. africana and Kraussilichirus kraussi, such as subtidal channels; completely absent intertidally. It is noted that U. capensis is absent from estuaries (though present in Langebaan Lagoon, which has higher salinity than is common) and mostly found on the open coast, as it lacks the ability to osmoregulate below a salinity of 15-18 parts per thousand (ppt). Species specific ecological studies on the burrow structure, mode of feeding, detailed sedimentary requirements or interactions with other species such as the Common sandprawn and Estuarine mudprawn are lacking.
taxon_text_5_9295: Not specifically known for this species, but likely similar to that of U. africana, which filter-feeds by sitting in their burrow filtering water that is pumped in through the U-shaped burrow.
taxon_text_6_9296: Not specifically known, but likely similar to U. africana with females producing 2–4 broods per year (mostly in Summer and Spring). As in other decapod crustaceans, females attach the spermatophore (passed from the male) to the ventral side of the pleon (hind body), where the eggs are fertilized as they get spawned and then attached to the pleopods underneath the tail. Known to produce small, but numerous eggs (often several 1000 per brood per female). Larvae are released into the water column where they have a planktonic larval phase before they settle in the sediment, creating their burrows.
taxon_text_7_9297: Similar to the larger Coastal mudprawn, Upogebia africana, however the first two pairs of walking legs have a spine at the base, while it is absent in the U. africana.
taxon_text_8_9298:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 112).

Nel, P & Branch, GM (2013). Assessment of the abundance and distribution of burrowing sandprawns and mudprawns (Callichirus and Upogebia species) in Langebaan Lagoon, South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 35(2), 195-208.
taxon_text_1_9484: Attractive, sprawling, ground-hugging, perennial coastal daisy. Leaves fleshy and broadly rounded, edges minutely toothed, borne on distinct petioles (‘stems’). Compound flowers solitary and borne on naked stalks, the rays (‘petals’) white above and pale lilac below, minutely toothed at tip. Disc flowers reddish-purple. Fruit triangular in cross-section.
taxon_text_2_9485: Typically reaches a height of only about 30 cm, but forms dense patches many meters across.
taxon_text_3_9486:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa. Has been introduced to New Zealand where it is classified as a weed.

Local/Regional: West coast to KwaZulu-Natal, only near the coast.
taxon_text_4_9487: Common along the coast, where it can form spectacular displays in winter and spring. Extremely hardy and grows right down to high water mark in stony beach sand. The succulent leaves can withstand salt spray and strong winds. Popular as a groundcover in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_6_9489: Flowers July to October.  Seeds dispersed by wind.
taxon_text_7_9490: The closely-related D. pluvialis has a similar range and sprawling habit and white flowers, but the base of each ray (petal) is purple. It also extends much further inland.
taxon_text_1_9219:
Medium- to large-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) reddish brown, walking legs with orange-yellow ridges and chelae (pincers) with rows of yellow tubercles.

Carapace texture smooth and velvety, frontal margin between the eyes with two notches where the antennae sprout from. Lateral margins (sides) with three marginal teeth. Walking legs with numerous teeth on upper margin of fourth joint.
taxon_text_3_9221:
Global: Currently considered a southern hemisphere species, ranging from the Indo-Pacific, including Australia, New Zealand, Chile and South Africa.

Local/Regional: From the Namibian border to Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal border, intertidal to 50 m.
taxon_text_4_9222: The most common shore crab along the southwest coast of South Africa, where they are frequently seen on shallow, rocky reefs and intertidal pools in crevices or can be seen on low-growing seaweeds, feeding on small organisms. Incredibly strong legs and hooked dactyls make them perfectly adapted to the wave-exposed shores which they dominate. Can also be observed on anthropogenic habitats such as jetties, quays, artificial reefs and also the bottom of ships (which could explain its widespread distribution). Do not occur in estuaries, as they cannot tolerate salinities below 70% seawater. Cape rock crabs are an important prey species for many kelp forest inhabitants, especially the Common octopus (Octopus vulgaris) that can reach into crevices and other hiding spots to pull the crab out. Escape responses are often observed as Cape rock crabs are excellent swimmers, using their flattened legs and hair fringes on them as efficient paddles, fleeing onto higher reefs, the water column, the kelp canopy, or even onto exposed intertidal rocks where the octopus can’t easily follow.
taxon_text_5_9223: Cape rock crabs have incredibly diverse diets and are known to take a wide variety of small invertebrates including barnacles, amphipods and small crustaceans, chitons, bivalves, gastropods and polychaetes. As these crabs are omnivores, they are also known to pick off and eat various species of seaweeds, with coralline algae being a large component thereof. As their diet indicates, they have a wide variety of gut enzymes, allowing them to be incredibly opportunistic feeders, taking prey as and when they are available. Active during the day but mostly feed at dusk.
taxon_text_6_9224: Males and females hold each other with their bellies facing each other until the female moults and after which the male transfers a sperm package to the female and both go their own way. When the female is ready to spawn her eggs, they are fertilised on their way out and attached and held under the females tail where they develop into the first larval stage and are then released into the open ocean. The pelagic larva swim and develop further in the plankton before settling back to the ground as a small juvenile crab. Ovigerous females are observed during Summer months (October – January).
taxon_text_7_9225: The large size and distinct colouration make this species unmistakable. South African specimens may be a separate lineage from the Indo-Pacific on, though more research is required to confirm these suspicions.
taxon_text_8_9226:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 120).

Griffiths, CL, Hockey, PAR, Van Erkom Schurink, C & Le Roux, PJ (1992). Marine invasive aliens on South African shores: implications for community structure and trophic functioning. South African journal of marine science, 12(1), 713-722.

Le Roux, PJ (1991). The population ecology and feeding biology of rocky shore crabs on the Cape Peninsula. M. Sc. thesis, University of Cape Town: 167 pp.
taxon_text_1_9309: Medium-sized sponge crab, carapace (hard upper shell) reddish with short, stiff yellowish or brownish bristles giving rise to its common name. Carapace broader than long, with the frontal margin bearing three acute teeth, while the lateral margin (side) has four teeth (three anterolaterally, with one behind branchial groove). Fifth leg distinctly shorter and more slender than the fourth. Does not carry a sponge or ascidian like many other species in the family.
taxon_text_2_9310: Up to 95 mm in width, length up to 70 mm.
taxon_text_4_9312: Not much known regarding their biology, though these animals often exhibit nocturnal habits, though they are also occasionally encountered during the day. Interestingly, Scrubbing brush crabs do not have an association with a sponge or ascidian like other members in the family and is thus bare.
taxon_text_5_9313: Scavenger, mostly eating dead animals they come across, though also observed to take some slow moving prey.
taxon_text_6_9314: Sexes are separate, with females storing sperm in chitin-lined spermathecae, though this is not retained after moulting. Very little is known regarding reproduction of the group, though sperm and eggs meet externally in an abdominal chamber. Ovigerous females carry eggs below the abdomen until the larvae hatch.
taxon_text_7_9315: This is one of six species of this endemic genus, five of which are found in False Bay. Superficially similar to the shaggy sponge crab D. hirsutissima, though it has longer bristles giving it a shaggy appearance and has two to three spines laterally. Also, somewhat similar to Lewindromia unidentata (Mozambique), though it has short brown/reddish fur and a single tooth at the carapace mid-margin.
taxon_text_8_9316:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

McLay, CL (2019). Podotreme reproduction: occurrence of sperm plaque in sponge crabs (Decapoda: Brachyura: Dromiidae). Journal of Crustacean Biology, 39(1), 82-87.
taxon_text_1_9318: Small to medium-sized crab with a carapace (hard upper shell) covered in shaggy coat of short, stiff hair and long dense fibrous brown, grey or yellow hairs giving a shaggy appearance. Base colouration of carapace maroon or brick-red. Carapace broader than long, frontal margin with two or three teeth. Anterolateral margin (front corner of carapace) with one sharp tooth. Fourth and fifth walking legs equal in length, the latter twisted up over the carapace.
taxon_text_3_9320:
Global: Regional endemic.

Local/Regional: From Namibian border to Plettenberg Bay.
taxon_text_4_9321: Commonly found intertidally as well as deeper waters, observed carrying a cloak of sponge, ascidian or seaweed. These objects are often carefully trimmed to fit the crab and are occasionally larger than the crab, offering protection (often through chemical defense) and camouflage. These animals often exhibit nocturnal habits, though they are also frequently encountered during the day.
taxon_text_5_9322: Not much known about this species, but thought to be scavengers and opportunistic feeders, eating dead animals they come across and occasionally observed to take slow moving invertebrates.
taxon_text_6_9323: Sexes are separate, with females storing sperm in chitin-lined spermathecae, though this is not retained after moulting. Very little is known regarding reproduction of the group, though sperm and eggs meet externally in an abdominal chamber. Ovigerous females carry eggs below the abdomen until the larvae hatch.
taxon_text_7_9324: This is one of six species of this endemic genus, five of which are found in False Bay. Superficially similar to the scrubbing brush crab D. aegibotus, though it only has short, stiff bristles and has four spines laterally, while D. hirsutissima has. Also, somewhat similar to Lewindromia unidentata (Mozambique), though it has short brown/reddish fur and a single tooth at the carapace mid-margin.
taxon_text_8_9325:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

McLay, CL (2019). Podotreme reproduction: occurrence of sperm plaque in sponge crabs (Decapoda: Brachyura: Dromiidae). Journal of Crustacean Biology, 39(1), 82-87.
taxon_text_1_9327: Small to medium-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) yellow, cream or reddish, while finger and thumb of cheliped (pincer) is crimson with white tips. Carapace covered in short, dense coat of hair (setae), similar to a sponge texture. Carapace broader than long, with short rounded frontal lobes. Anterolateral margin (front corner) with 4 rounded projections. Chelipeds and walking legs are knobbed. The fifth leg is bent upwards and is longer and more slender than the fourth leg.
taxon_text_3_9329:
Global: Endemic, except for a record in Indonesia, which should be revisited.

Local/Regional: From Namibian border to Coffee Bay.
taxon_text_4_9330: Commonly found under subtidal rocks as well as deeper waters, observed carrying a cloak of sponge or ascidian. These objects are often carefully trimmed to fit the crab and are occasionally larger than the crab, offering protection (often through chemical defense) and camouflage. These animals often exhibit nocturnal habits, though they are also frequently encountered during the day.
taxon_text_5_9331: Scavenger, eating dead animals they come across.
taxon_text_6_9332: Not specifically known for this species, but generally for this group sexes are separate, with females storing sperm in chitin-lined spermathecae, though this is not retained after moulting. Very little is known regarding reproduction of the group, though sperm and eggs meet externally in an abdominal chamber. Ovigerous females carry eggs below the abdomen until the larvae hatch.
taxon_text_7_9333: This species is somewhat similar to the Cloaked sponge crab (Pseudodromia latens), though P. latens can almost fully retract into the ascidian it carries on its back. Moreover, P. spongiosa has broader limbs and a rostrum ending in a single projection, as opposed to slender limbs and a rostrum with two projections.
taxon_text_8_9334:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

McLay, CL (2019). Podotreme reproduction: occurrence of sperm plaque in sponge crabs (Decapoda: Brachyura: Dromiidae). Journal of Crustacean Biology, 39(1), 82-87.
taxon_text_1_9336: Medium-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) crimson red, often mottled covered with short, dense yellowish or brownish hair (setae), with some longer hair towards the edges of carapace and chelipeds (pincers), legs. Carapace longer than wide, frontal margin with three projections (though only two are visible from dorsal view). Anterolateral margin (front corner) indented at the branchial groove, with no projection behind indent. The fifth leg is much longer than the fourth and is bent upwards.
taxon_text_2_9337: Up to 36 mm in length, 32 mm in width.
taxon_text_3_9338:
Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: From Saldanha Bay to East London.
taxon_text_4_9339:
This species is almost completely encased in a ball-shaped ascidian cloak. It is commonly found on sea fans, which it likely consumes.

It is though that the ascidian offers protection (often through chemical defense) and camouflage. These animals often exhibit nocturnal habits, though they are also frequently encountered during the day.
taxon_text_5_9340: Likely consumes sea fans, which it is often encountered on.
taxon_text_6_9341: Not specifically known for this species, but generally for this group sexes are separate, with females storing sperm in chitin-lined spermathecae, though this is not retained after moulting. Very little is known regarding reproduction of the group, though sperm and eggs meet externally in an abdominal chamber. Ovigerous females carry eggs below the abdomen until the larvae hatch.
taxon_text_7_9342: This species is somewhat similar to the Cloaked sponge crab (Platydromia spongiosa), though P. latens can almost fully retract into the ascidian it carries on its back. Moreover, P. spongiosa has broader limbs and a rostrum ending in a single projection, as opposed to slender limbs and a rostrum with two projections.
taxon_text_8_9343:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

McLay, CL (2019). Podotreme reproduction: occurrence of sperm plaque in sponge crabs (Decapoda: Brachyura: Dromiidae). Journal of Crustacean Biology, 39(1), 82-87.
taxon_text_1_9300: Small to medium-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) dark red to purple-orange, while fingers are black/’chocolate-tipped’. Carapace wider than long, oval-shaped, while the dorsal surface bears dense tubercles, margins lined with different sized teeth. Chelipeds (pincers) similarly sized with tubercles, while walking legs are short and stocky.
taxon_text_3_9302:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: From Skeleton Coast, Namibia to False Bay.
taxon_text_4_9303: Often found intertidally under stones, among mussels, in sponges or in kelp holdfasts. Other members of the group are mostly found in and among algae. Previously thought be an invasive species from South America before its description as a local endemic in 1987.
taxon_text_5_9304: Not specifically known, though others in the genus is known to feeds on small molluscs.
taxon_text_6_9305: Not specifically known for this species, but generally for this group sexes are separate. Males transfer spermatophores (capsules that contains sperm) to females, which they use to fertilise their eggs. The larval development for species in the genus includes five zoeal and one megalopal stage.
taxon_text_7_9306: Superficially similar to pilumnids in habitat and setation, however these crabs are not as tuberculated and more hairy. These species include Pilumnus minutus and Serenepilumnus pisifer, however P. rubus differs from the former in that it has more marginal teeth (only 3 in P. minutus) and has no tubercles on walking legs (4 large tubercles in S. pisifer).
taxon_text_8_9307:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 132).

Guinot, D & Macpherson, E (1987). Révision du genre Pilumnoides Lucas, 1844, avec description de quatre espèces nouvelles et création de Pilumnoidinae sub fam. nov.(Crustacea Decapoda Brachyura). Bulletin du Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, 211-247.
taxon_text_1_9399: Bulbous perennial plant with very large, velvety, tongue-shaped leaves that lie flat on the ground during winter. The leaves die off during summer and in February to March the plant sends up a thick red stalk topped by a large spectacular ball of 20-80 upcurved red flowers.
taxon_text_2_9400: Flowerheads about 40 cm tall and up to 50 cm diameter, leaves 30 cm or more long.
taxon_text_3_9401:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Sandy coastal habitats from Namaqualand to about Plettenberg Bay.
taxon_text_4_9402:
Has a strong annual cycle. The leaves appear in about May and die down from about October. The bulb then lies dormant during the summer before producing the spectacular flower head in late summer (February to March). The flower heads often emerge from bare ground and in large groups and are topped by a large ball of flowers. Once dry the flower heads break loose and are tumbled by the wind, dispersing the seeds.

Dense natural clumps are a spectacular sight, much sought after by photographers. Also a popular garden plant easily grown from seed. Birds are the main pollinators, perching on the sturdy flower stems. The bulbs contain toxic compounds to protect them from being eaten by mole rats.
taxon_text_6_9404: The seeds are fleshy with a short period of viability and germinate quickly, sometimes while still in the flowerhead.
taxon_text_7_9405: The most common coastal representative among several regional species in this genus. Among more coastal species the similar B. gregaria has pink rather than red flowers, while B. littoralis has 8 or more erect twisted leaves - both these species occurs mostly along the south coast.
taxon_text_1_9264:
Small sized porcelain crab, generally various shades of red, with the chelae (pincers) usually a darker shade and mottled. Walking legs irregularly banded and also mottled.

Carapace (hard upper shell) with some sparse setae (hairs) scattered on the surface, with two distinct tufts behind the eyes. Lateral margins (sides) of carapace with four or five spines, while the frontal margin is trilobed, with the middle projection being broadly triangular. Three pairs of walking legs present (as in most anomuran crabs), with a fourth reduced pair hidden underneath the pleon (hind body).
taxon_text_2_9265: Carapace width up to 6 mm, length up to 6.5 mm.
taxon_text_3_9266:
Global: South African endemic.

Local/Regional: West coast (Namaqualand) to Algoa Bay, intertidal to 90 m.
taxon_text_4_9267: This species is usually found on deep- and shallow-water reefs, where these animals can be found on sponges and bryozoans. Like many other members in the porcelain crab family (Porcellanidae) these crabs will readily let go of their chelae that breaks off at a predetermined place as a diversion when they are in danger to fool predators (much like a gecko would let go of its tail). This intentional breaking is also the origin of the name porcelain crab for the family. The pincers can be regrown at a later stage if the escape act was successful. This species is occasionally caught as bycatch on deeper demersal trawls, where they can be commonly along the south coast.
taxon_text_5_9268: Known to be a filter feeder that uses specialised mouthparts with long setae to trap plankton from the water column. These food particles are then brought to the mouth where they are ingested.
taxon_text_6_9269: Not specifically known for this species, though all porcelain crab males transfer a spermatophore to a female, which then is then attached to the ventral side of the female where the eggs are fertilized when spawned and attached underneath the tail where they develop until the larvae are ready to be released into the open water.
taxon_text_7_9270: The only other porcelain crab from the area, Porcellana africana, is unlikely to be confused with this species, as that species’ body is pubescent, the chelae are strongly flattened, and the inner apex of the merus is not produced into a distinctive, strong, squarely-truncated tooth. At present, P. africana is also only known from shallow waters in Saldanha Bay and hence the distribution of these two species do not overlap.
taxon_text_8_9271:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 112).

Griffiths CL, Roberts S, Branch GM et al (2018) The porcelain crab Porcellana africana Chace,1956 (Decapoda: Porcellanidae) introduced into Saldanha Bay, South Africa. Bioinvasions Records, 7, 133–142.
taxon_text_1_9345: Easily identified, flat-growing, spiky-leaved geophyte. The lobed leaves lie flat on the ground and emerge from a large tuberous root which exudes a sticky resin when broken. Each leaf has spiny margins and bears recurved thorns. Plants are either male or female, with male flowers cream and borne on stalks, while female flowers are green, stalkless and borne in a spiny head.
taxon_text_2_9346: Plants up to about 6 cm tall, but up to 60 cm in diameter. Flower spikes up to 15 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_9347:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9348:
Distinctive species found on damp sand and rocky areas both close to the coast and further inland. The spiny leaves are thought to provide protection against herbivores, and spines on the fruit may also aid dispersal by sticking to the fur of animals.

This species has a long history of use in traditional medicine. A decoction of the root has been used for treatment of a wide range of disorders including syphilis, gonorrhea, epilepsy, bladder ailments, glandular swellings, etc. The resin from the root may also be used to treat ringworm.
taxon_text_6_9350: Flowers May to July. Separate male and female plants. Fruit dry, brown and spiny.
taxon_text_7_9351: Easily recognised to genus by distinctive leaves and flowers. There are three regional species of which this is the most common. Could be confused with Hedgehog lilies Massonia spp. which also have large leaves that lie flat on the ground and a central clump of stemless flowers, but these are distantly-related bulbous plants and the leaves are tongue-shaped and either smooth or grooved, but not spiky.
taxon_text_1_9354: Creeping, mat-forming pioneer species found low on foreshore dunes. The large, slightly-succulent leaves may be paddle-shaped or deeply lobed and are covered with white felt. The flowers are borne on short, wooly, curving stems and often overtopped by the large leaves. The narrow outer petals are bright yellow and often well-spaced and the central flowers a more greenish yellow.
taxon_text_2_9355: Plants up to about 200 mm tall, 2 m or more across, leaves about 50-60 mm long and 50 mm wide and flowers about 30 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9356:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: About Hondeklip Bay on the west coast to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_9357:
Common pioneer species found low on coastal dunes, where can extend almost down to high water mark. Performs important function in dune stabilisation and often creates hummocks on the sand. Flowers pollinated by a variety of bees and flies. Seeds dispersed by wind and remain viable in both salt and freshwater, so can be widely dispersed by ocean currents.

Has been introduced to Australia, where it is now a common weed of coastal areas.
taxon_text_7_9360: Fairly distinctive in both habitat and appearance.
taxon_text_1_9363:
A very diverse genus including over 270 species, most of which occur in the fynbos region, many along the coast.  Prostrate or erect shrubs with clusters of sessile leaves that can be needle-like or rounded and are often spine-tipped. Typical pea-like flowers are usually bright yellow (rarely lilac or white) and can be borne singly or in groups at the tips of the branches. Compressed pods may contain from one to several seeds.

Since species identification is complex only a genus level entry is provided here.
taxon_text_3_9365:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Most species restricted to Cape Floristic Region.
taxon_text_4_9366:
A diverse group occupying a range of habitats including marine sands, but many species occur on mountains.

The best known and most economically valuable species is the Rooibos tea plant A. linearis, which forms the basis of a multimillion rand industry including not only herbal teas but also a variety of cosmetic products.
taxon_text_6_9368: Most species flower in spring from September to December Seeds can survive in the ground for many years and plants often germinate profusely after fire.
taxon_text_7_9369: Numerous species in the genus with a variety of growth forms, leaf shapes and flower arrangements. Can also be confused with other yellow-flowered genera in the pea family including Lebeckia, Rafnia and Cyclopia (which includes the Honeybush tea plant C. genistoides).
taxon_text_1_9372: Small, dense, thorny shrub. Stems stiff, woody, each surrounded by whorls of short needle-like branches encircled by tiny needle-shaped leaves – the whole branch appearing like a bottle-brush. Flowers small and white, star-shaped and strongly scented, give rise to small berries that are initially green, turning red then black.
taxon_text_2_9373: Growing to about 1m height. Leaves 3-5 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9374:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9375:
Common both inland and along the coast on stony substrata.

As with many species in this genus the young shoots can be eaten.
taxon_text_7_9378: There are many other regional species in this genus of which more then 30 occur in the fynbos region. This is one of the most common and widespread of these, but species level identification can be tricky. Asparagus lignosus occurs in the same habitat but is more open and upright with wide-spreading zig-zag  branches, and has much longer clusters of leaves and larger berries.
taxon_text_1_9381: Spindly shrub-like creeper with pale-grey zig-zag branches and a large single recurved thorn at each node along the branches. Leaves occur in stiff, tufts and are cylindrical with sharp tips. Flowers white with a green strip on each sepal and orange anthers. These give rise to large green berries.
taxon_text_2_9382: Growing to at least 1 m height. Leaves 10-20 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9383:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Fairly restricted distribution in Southwestern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9384: Common both inland and along the coast on both rocky and sandy substrata.
taxon_text_7_9387: There are many other regional species in this genus of which more then 30 occur in the fynbos region. This species is best recognised by zig-zag stems and unusually long clusters of leaves.
taxon_text_8_9410:
Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 118).

Emmerson, WD (2016). A Guide to, and Checklist for, the Decapoda of Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique. Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars Publishing. Volumes 1 – 3, 526, 645, 711 pp.
taxon_text_1_9412: Tall perennial grass species emerging from long, thick, creeping underground rhizomes. The very elongate leaf blades are greyish green and come to a point at the tip. They are initially upright, but bend over and spread across the sand as they lengthen. The upper surface is hairy but the lower surface smooth. The flowerhead is long and cylindrical and contain numerous densely-packed flower spikelets.
taxon_text_2_9413: Leaves can reach 1.2 m long and rhizomes can spread laterally by 2 m per year. Flower spikes up to 30 cm long.
taxon_text_3_9414:
Global: Endemic to Europe and North Africa. Widely introduced for dune stabilisation to North America, Australia, New Zealand, Chile, Falkland Islands and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Urban areas along coasts of Western and Eastern Cape Provinces where artificial dune stabilisation has been undertaken.
taxon_text_4_9415: Often used as a pioneer species during artificial dune stabilisation projects and so is most often seen in urban areas, where it has been planted to stabilise drifting sand. May become problematic if it spreads to natural dune systems as it can crowd out endemic species.
taxon_text_6_9417: Flower October to February. The seeds can be naturally dispersed by wing, water or animals. Pieces of rhizome and seeds can also be unintentionally transported to new sites if sand is transported from one location to another.
taxon_text_7_9418: Easy to confuse with the indigenous Sea wheat Thinopyrum distichum which is also abundant on primary dunes and is an effective sand stabiliser. However, that species only grow to about 50 cm, has rolled leaves and the flower spike is flattened with alternating branches on either side and is only 15 cm long.
taxon_text_1_9421:
Well-known, large, abundant coastal plant forming long, creeping stems bearing stout, curved green or red-tinged leaves that are triangular in cross section (hence scimitar-shapes or ‘acinaciform’).

Large, flat flowers encircled with many radiating petals are produced in spring and summer and are magenta (purplish-red) in colour. The fruits are like a spinning top enclosed in a winged stalk and become wrinkled and leathery with age. Internally the many small seeds are enclosed in a sticky jelly.
taxon_text_2_9422: Stems can be many meters long, leaves from 60-130 mm long and flowers up to 100 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9423:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Yzerfontein to Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_9424:
Well known plant forming extensive mats in sandy areas along the coast, where it often grown adjacent to and is confused with the better-known yellow-flowered sour fig C. edulis. Popular as a garden plant in coastal areas and has been introduced to South-West England, where it has become naturalised.

An ecologically significant species that provides shelter and habitat to numerous species including snails, reptiles and many insects. The flowers are pollinated by a variety of bees and beetles and flowers and fruits are eaten by rodents, antelope, porcupines and baboons. The leaves are also eaten by tortoises.

The edible fruit are widely collected to make a popular tart jam. Various parts of the plant are also used in traditional medicine. Preparations of the fruit are taken orally for the treatment of tuberculosis and other pulmonary infections. Leaf juice is applied to sores or burn/scald wounds and used as antiseptic. Preparations of leaf juice, taken orally, are said to be diuretic.
taxon_text_7_9427: There are several similar species in this and related genera. Frequently confused with the sour fig C. edulis which is also a large trailing species with a similar range and habitat preferences, but which has yellow flowers.
taxon_text_1_9493: Dense, erect coastal shrub with silvery or greyish, elongate, pointed leaves that are slightly curled upwards and lie opposite and alternate along the stems. They smell of thyme. Flowers borne in hanging groups on long stems and lack petals. Fruit elliptical and very wooly.
taxon_text_2_9494: Typically reaches a height of about 150 cm.
taxon_text_3_9495:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_9496:
Coastal species common on sandy dunes in dryer areas.

Brandy-based infusions used in traditional medicine as a diuretic. Also used as a source of essential oils for perfumes and has antimicrobial properties.

The fluff surrounding the seeds is a sought-after nesting material for birds such as the Karoo prinia, but the birds reject the seeds when collecting fluff so play a limited role in seed dispersal.
taxon_text_7_9499: The closely-related Wild rosemary E. africanus occurs in the same region, but also extends much further inland. It can be distinguished by the presence of conspicuous white petals on the flowers that are absent in E. racemosus.
taxon_text_1_9430: Well-known, large, abundant coastal plant forming long creeping stems bearing robust, paired, upright succulent leaves that are triangular in cross section. Large, flat flowers encircled with many radiating petals are produced in summer and are initially yellow, turning pink as they age. The fruits are like a spinning top enclosed in a winged stalk and become wrinkled and leathery with age. Internally the many small seeds are enclosed in a sticky jelly.
taxon_text_2_9431: Stems can be many meters long, leaves from 60-130 mm long and flowers up to 100 mm or more across.
taxon_text_3_9432:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9433:
Well-known plant forming extensive mats both along the coast and further inland. Popular as a garden plant and has been introduced widely to other regions with similar climates, such as Australia, New Zealand, California and the Mediterranean region, where in some cases it has escaped from cultivation and become a pest. Easily spread by seed or from cuttings and is widely used to stabilise slopes, or as ground cover, such as along freeways.

An ecologically significant species that provides shelter and habitat to numerous species including snails, reptiles and many insects. The flowers are pollinated by a variety of bees and beetles and flowers and fruits are eaten by rodents, antelope, porcupines and baboons. The leaves are also eaten by tortoises.

The edible fruit are widely collected to make a popular tart jam. Various parts of the plant are also used in traditional medicine and to treat ailments including bacterial infections, digestive problems, to sooth sore throats and as a skin lotion for treatment of sunburn, bruises and cracked lips.
taxon_text_6_9435: Flowers April to October. Also grows readily from fragments.
taxon_text_7_9436: There are several similar species in this and related genera, but most likely to be confused with the Elands sour fig C. acinaciformis, which is also a large trailing species with a similar range and habitat preferences, but which has purple flowers.
<p>Dried Sour figs sold at Muizenberg ma: Dried Sour figs sold at Muizenberg market
taxon_text_1_9439: Common, small, dense shrub found close to the shore on both rocky coasts and on soft substrata in lagoons and estuaries. The soft, straggling stems are red to purple and grow horizontally, putting up vertical branches that are surrounded by velvety silver leaves pointed at their tips. Small yellow flowers occur between the leaves in summer.
taxon_text_2_9440: Typically reaches a height of about 10 cm, but horizontal stems much longer, up to 1 m.
taxon_text_3_9441:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa from Namibia to Mozambique.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but most common in Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_9442: Salt-tolerant plant that is abundant both low on rocky shores, almost down to the high water mark, and in saltmarshes surrounding marine lagoons and estuaries. Usually erect, but can dangle from crevices.
taxon_text_7_9445: The red stems, silvery leaves and coastal habitat make this plant fairly distinctive and unlikely to be confused with other species.
taxon_text_1_9448: Creeping perennial herb with finely divided fern-like leaves. Flower heads are small yellow buttons borne on a branching stem. The flower heads have a narrow outer rim of very short petals.
taxon_text_2_9449: Plants about 20 cm tall but occur in creeping mats at least 1 m across, leaves about 60 mm and flowers about 8 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9450:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. Naturalised in New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Along the coasts of Cape Provinces.
taxon_text_4_9451:
Fast-growing evergreen species found along the coast extending almost down to high water mark. The button-like flowers are borne on long stalks that extend above the leaves. Until recently confused with the inland C. sericia, but in 2013 the coastal form was separated off and given a separate name.

Has been introduced to New Zealand.
taxon_text_7_9454: There are some 50 species in this genus, of which about 20 occur in the fynbos region, so species level identification can be difficult. The seashore habits of this species and the deeply divided, fern-like leaves are the best traits for identification.
taxon_text_1_9457: Distinctive succulent shrub with erect stems. The thick, cylindrical, tapering leaves are light transparent-green to blue-green and have a waxy covering. They are grooved above and encircle the tips of the branches. The inflorescences poke above the leaves and divide into several flower heads each on short stalks. The compound flowers are yellow and the ray florets (‘petals’) tend to bend downwards. They develop into fluffy seeds.
taxon_text_2_9458: Can reach 2 m but typically about 1 m. Leaves up to 60 mm long, flowers about 20 m across.
taxon_text_3_9459:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to South Coast also Eswatini.
taxon_text_4_9460: On rocky soil close to the coast and also some way inland, not much else known.
taxon_text_7_9463: There are numerous species in this diverse genus of which about 50 occur in the fynbos region but this species is fairly distinctive due to its elongate succulent leaves and clustered, branching flowerheads.
taxon_text_1_9466: Sprawling perennial with a woody base and large, fleshy, parsley-like leaves that are twice-divided into numerous narrow-toothed leaflets that often curl inwards. Leaves usually green, but may be grey or tinged with purple. Compound clusters of small white flowers form on a flat head borne at the end of an erect fleshy stalk. Fruits broadly oval with five thick longitudinal ribs.
taxon_text_2_9467: Plants up to about 30 cm tall. Flower spikes up to 15 cm tall.
taxon_text_3_9468:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_9469: Common salt-tolerant coastal species found on coastal dunes, where it is among the most abundant plants near to high water mark.
taxon_text_7_9472: Easily recognised by distinctive leaves and flowers and the only regional species in the genus.
taxon_text_1_9475: Attractive, sprawling, rounded shrub growing up to about 1m high. Leaves thick, fleshy and finger-like, pointed at tips and tapering to the base and covered with white hair or grey felt. Abundant, large, bright-yellow flowers present from about July-October. Flowers solitary and borne on leafless stalks with two visible collars of bracts below the flower head.
taxon_text_2_9476: Typically reaches a height of about 50 cm, and forms patches at least 1m across.
taxon_text_3_9477:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Wilderness on South Coast.
taxon_text_4_9478:
Common on coastal dunes where can extends almost down to high water mark. The dense covering of white hairs on the leaves reflect light and reduce transpiration. Flowers face to the north and thus heat up rapidly during the day, thus increasing their attractiveness to pollinating bees, flies and beetles.

The plant is spectacular when in flower and is popular in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_6_9480: Flowers July to October. The hard, flat, saucer-like seeds are covered in spines and this is though to facilitate dispersal by soft-footed mammals.
taxon_text_7_9481: The closely-related D. spinosa has wider oval leaves that lack hairs and forms taller, woody shrubs that occurs further inland.
taxon_text_1_9502:
Medium-sized, densely-branched, succulent shrub with thin, segmented, green stems that branch dichotomously. Usually erect but may be spreading. Stems emit a milky latex when damaged.

Leaves reduced to tiny scales. False flowers bright yellow and appear in dense clusters at ends of stems, surrounded by five green lobes.
taxon_text_2_9503: Plants can grow to 1 m tall. Branches 30-50 mm diameter. Leaves 2-3 mm long. Flowers about 2-4 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9504:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9505:
Most common in coastal sands and flats but also further inland where it often grows together with the related but more robust and widespread E. mauritania.

Used as an ornamental in coastal and waterwise gardens.
taxon_text_6_9507: Flowers June to September. Pollinated by bees and flies. Seeds borne in capsules. Also grows readily from cuttings or division.
taxon_text_7_9508: The genus Euphorbia contains over 2000 species and is one of the most diverse of all genera of flowering plants. Numerous species occur in the region, but these differ greatly in growth form varying from trees to small species that lie close to the ground. Many are also spiny. This spineless shrublike species is most easily confuted with the Yellow milk bush E. mauritanica which is common across the same range and sometimes occurs in mixed stands with E. burmanii. That species differs by having much longer leaves (8-15 mm long) and has a central male flower surrounded by 5-7 bisexual false larger flowers 7-15 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_1_9511: Distinctive succulent forming a low rosette of thick lateral stems arranged in a circle around a short, knobbly main stem. Branches covered in tubercles and lie on the ground with the tips bent upwards. Branches bear reduced leaves that soon fall and small pseudo-flowers that are arranged in groups around the tips of each branch and are light yellow. The plant exudes a milky latex when damaged.
taxon_text_2_9512: Plants can grow to 1 m in diameter. Branches about 30 mm diameter. Flowers about 10-18 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9513:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Southern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9514:
Distinctive species most common in coastal sandy but also further inland in Namaqualand and the Western Cape. The latex is toxic and used as a defense against herbivores.

Used as an ornamental in coastal and waterwise gardens.
taxon_text_6_9516: Flowers June to September. Pollinated by bees and flies. After flowering produces small three-lobed capsules containing the seeds. Also grows readily from cuttings or division.
taxon_text_7_9517: One of many Euphorbia species in the region, but the distinctive round, sprawling growth form distinguish it from most other species.
taxon_text_1_9538:
Chironomid midges resemble small mosquitoes and have a humped thorax, long slender front legs and relatively short wings that are normally held folded along the back when at rest. Males can be distinguished by having conspicuous tufts of hairs encircling their antennae.

Members of the genus Telmatogeton are best identified by their unusual habitat on the upper reaches of rocky shores and their association with seaweeds as a larval food source. There are two very similar species in the region that are difficult to distinguish without microscopic examination. Larvae are greenish–brown and have a dark head capsule.
taxon_text_2_9539: Adults about 4 mm body/ length excluding antennae. Larvae up to 10 mm.
taxon_text_3_9540:
Global: T. sancti-pauli is known form various islands in the Atlantic Ocean and from South Africa. T. minor is endemic.

Local/Regional: Both from about Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_9541: Females can be seen at low tide fluttering among seaweeds, where they lay their eggs. Larvae live and feed amongst the folded fronds of algae, especially Porphyra but probably also Ulva on which they are often seen. Larvae may be an important component in the diets of intertidal fishes.
taxon_text_5_9542: Larvae feed on marine algae, particularly species of Porphyra. Many chironomids do not feed as adults and that is probably the case with these species as well.
taxon_text_6_9543: Eggs are laid on intertidal algae and the larvae feed on these. Pupation also takes place amongst the algal fronds.
taxon_text_7_9544: There are over 175 chironomid species in South Africa, but members of this genus are the only ones in the Western Cape region to be associated with marine algae and hence unlikely to be confused with other members of the group. There is one other marine chironomid known from South Africa  (Clunio africanus Hesse, 1937) but this has only reported from KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_1_9520: Widespread, distinctive bulb found on rocky sites, mainly along the coast. Stem concealed by long, narrow upward-pointed, pale-green leaves that have a raised midrib. Striking flowers with six tapering, pointed petals arranged in a star-shape, dark brown to black with yellow ruffled edges. Stamens united into a cylindrical column. Flowers last just a single day and have an unpleasant smell.
taxon_text_2_9521: Plants up to about 100 cm tall, but more typically 50 cm.
taxon_text_3_9522:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Along the coast from Lambert’s Bay to George, also inland in fynbos biome.
taxon_text_4_9523:
Very striking plant with distinctive dark flowers that bloom in spring between August and October. Common on rocky shores forming clumps extending almost down to high water mark. Pollinated by flies, which are attracted to the unpleasant scent.

Has been introduced to Australia, where it is known as Black flag and has become an invasive weed.
taxon_text_6_9525: Forms stacked disc-like corms and usually propagates by dispersal of these.
taxon_text_7_9526: One of several regional species in this genus of which F. crispa has cream to yellowish flowers and F. uncinata blue to purple flowers with yellow or brown margins.
taxon_text_1_9529: Beetles of the family Staphylinidae (‘rove beetles’) are fairly easily recognized as a group, in that most have narrow bodies and very short wing-covers, leaving the elongate abdomen largely exposed. However, as most species are very small, and many different genera are found on the seashore, species level identification is challenging. The tiny species depicted here is usually referred to as ‘Bledius sp’ and is best recognized by its unusual habits of creating dense networks of mole-like surface burrows on the upper tidal levels of sheltered sandy beaches.
taxon_text_3_9531:
Difficult to establish, as species not identified

Global: Unknown.

Local/Regional:  Common on sheltered beaches along west and south coast, including in estuaries.
taxon_text_4_9532: Colonises the upper intertidal sections of fine-grained sandy beaches. Seldom noticed due to their small size and narrow bodies (meaning that they pass thought the collecting nets and sieves used by most researchers) but can be extremely common, reaching densities of thousands per square meter. At high tide, adults retreat into vertical burrows, which trap a bubble of air to breath while underwater. When the tide recedes they emerge and construct mole-like burrows just beneath the sand surface, picking up and cleaning individual sand grains of diatoms etc before packing them above their heads. Within a few hours the entire sand surface can become crazed with their meandering burrows. As the tide rises again they retreat back into their burrows. Best collected by digging up the sand and tossing this into a dish or puddle of water – the sand sinks while the beetles float!
taxon_text_5_9533: Feed on diatoms attached to the sand grains.
taxon_text_6_9534: The South African species has not been studied, but similar species from the USA lay their eggs attached to individual sand grains on the burrow wall. Small larvae occupy the maternal burrow, but larger larvae establish their own burrows and appear to feed in the same way as adults. Pupation also takes place in the sand.
taxon_text_7_9535: Staphylinid beetles are extremely common in intertidal habitats and hundreds of coastal species are known globally. The South African fauna is poorly described and many species remain un-named. Although several other staphylinid species are found associated with rotting algae in the region this one is easily recognized by the shallow meandering surface burrows it makes on fine, clean sand.
taxon_text_1_9549: Tall, grass-like, rhizomatous sedge with rigid, smooth, yellow-green stems that grow up to 1 m tall (more typically about 70 cm). The inflorescence appears as a tight ball of 10-30 dark-brown spikelet borne near the pointed tip of the stems. When in flower (Dec – March) yellow anthers project from each spikelet. Irregularly-shaped dark brown nuts of about 1 mm diameter form in November – May, but flowerheads may persist on the plants throughout the year.
taxon_text_2_9550: Plants up to about 100 cm tall, more typically 70 cm. Flower spikes 7-20 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_9551:
Global: Widespread in Southern Hemisphere and native to Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Throughout the region.
taxon_text_4_9552:
The taxonomy of the species has a complicated history and it has had several previous names.

Able to grow in a variety of habitats and under a wide range of soil conditions, salinities, temperatures and pH levels. Widespread in sandy, salty soils and found both inland and along the coast, where it often grows in dense clumps in back-dunes. Controls sand movement on dunes and can be used in dune stabilization projects. Also used in biofiltration systems, especially in saline environments, where it can remove heavy metals, nitrogen and phosphorus from storm water runoffs. Also used for constructing floating wetlands to clean polluted waters.
taxon_text_6_9554: Wind pollinated and windborne seeds readily distributed to new sites.
