taxon_text_7_9555: There are several similar sedges in the region with which this can be confused. The Dune slack sharp-rush Juncus krausii has flowers in longer, more open clusters near the ends of the stems. The Triangular club-rush Schoenoplectus triquetra has similar ball-like sessile flowerheads, but these are borne on triangular stems.
taxon_text_1_9558: Attractive, sprawling perennial daisy with leathery leaves that are divided into 3-7 elliptical lobes. The leaf margins tend to be rolled under, with the upper surfaces smooth and the undersides white-felted. The large, attractive, compound flowers can be either yellow or orange and the petal-like rays each have variable dark and white marks at the base and a stripe along the underside.
taxon_text_2_9559: Typically reaches a height of 20-40 cm, leaves up to 110 mm long and flowers up to 40 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_9560:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution along the coast from Namaqualand to about Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_9561:
Common on coastal rocks and sands dunes where can extends almost down to high water mark.  Colour vary variable and most commonly yellow rather than the orange depicted here.

Plants in this genus are spectacular when in flower, attract a variety of pollinators and are popular in coastal gardens or in containers.
taxon_text_6_9563: Flowers November to February. The seeds are small and easily dispersed by wing. Patches also spread via rhizomes leading to dense patches of flowers of the same colour.
taxon_text_7_9564: There are several similar regional species in this genus. This species is easily confused with the Dune gazania G. rigens, which is also common along the coast, but ranges along the south and east (but not west) coasts into Mozambique. That species also usually has simple, lance-shaped leaves (sometimes 5-lobed) and has yellow to orange rays that may or may not have a single black mark at the base.
taxon_text_1_9567: Creeping, prostrate annual. Stems elongate, reddish and spreading out to form mats in sandy areas. Leaves soft, with deep rounded lobes, slightly hairy. Flowers with five bright yellow petals, cup-shaped, becoming paler towards the centre, which bears 10 prominent yellow stamens. Fruit depressed, pentagonal, with a peripheral wing and central knobs.
taxon_text_2_9568: Stems about 60 cm long. Flowers about 25 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9569:
Global: Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula, also inland.
taxon_text_4_9570: Occurs in sandy areas both inland and along the coast, where it can extend almost down to high water mark. Flowers only open in bright sunshine.
taxon_text_7_9573: A second, similar species, the Green-eyed desert primrose G. grandiflorum, is also found along the West Coast, but has more finely branched and wooly leaves and the flowers have a green centre.
taxon_text_1_9576: Bulbous perennial lily with a deep, flattened bulb that gives rise to two (rarely three) tongue-shaped, leathery leaves during winter. Leaves lie flat on the ground and are hairy at least along the margins. Leaves dry or absent during flowering season. Flowers borne in January-April on an erect red stem that can be hairy or spotted. This gives rise to 4-5 large scarlet fleshy bracts that from a funnel-shaped structure slightly longer than and surrounding erect, bunched flowers with their prominent yellow stamens.
taxon_text_3_9578:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_9579: Confined to coastal sandy habitats along the West Coast, where can form spectacular displays in late summer when the ground is often otherwise bare of vegetation. A popular garden species that attracts pollinating birds and insects. Used in traditional medicine as a diuretic and to treat asthma and stomach complaints, or to dress ulcers and wounds.
taxon_text_6_9581: Pollination is by insects and sunbirds. Easily propagated from the soft, translucent berries.
taxon_text_7_9582: Easily recognized to genus, but there are several similar species that occur in the same region. The April fool, H. coccinus, lacks hairs on the leaves and has deep-red spots on the flower stalk, which has 6-9 bracts that are slightly shorter than the flowers.  In the Smooth bloodlily, H. sanguineus, the leaves are edged with scarlet hairs and the unmarked red stalk bears 5-11 bracts surrounding a very dense tuft of many flowers.
taxon_text_1_9585: Small shrub with multiple stiff, erect stems. The broad, heart-shaped, waxy leaves have pointed tips and are arranged alternately and neatly packed hard against the stem to form a cylindrical shoot. The small flowers emerge from between the terminal leaves to form a dense spike. Each flower has white to cream petals, becoming yellow or pink at the base and has 4 stamens in unequal pairs.
taxon_text_2_9586: Plants up to about 30 cm tall. Leaves about 5 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9587:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9588: Common, tough, salt-tolerant species found poking up though coastal dunes, where it can occur right down almost to highwater mark.
taxon_text_7_9591: There are several other regional species in the genus, but this one can be recognised by its coastal habits and characteristic flower spike.
taxon_text_1_9595: Upright, dense, intricately – branched, spiny shrub. Branches bearing tight clusters of small succulent leaves on short shoots. Leaves bright green above and paler below. Flowers solitary, small, white to pale mauve, bell-shaped. Fruit a small berry, turning bright red when ripe.
taxon_text_2_9596: Growing to at least 2 m height.  Leaves about 10 x 3 mm. Flowers 12 mm. Berries 3 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_9597:
Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Along the west coast from Namibia to almost Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_9598: Mostly along the coast in sandy areas and can be found almost down to high-water mark. Drought and salt tolerant. Berries eaten by wildlife.
taxon_text_7_9601: There are several other regional species in this genus. The most common of these in the study region is the Snake-berry L. ferocissimum, which has a more open structure with larger, wider leaves, bigger flowers and much larger more obvious berries.
taxon_text_1_9604: Large, upright, spiny shrub with greyish, woody branches that spread mostly horizontally and are armed with thick, sharp spines. Leaves broadly paddle-shaped and borne in tufts on short shoots. Solitary flowers white to pale mauve and bell-shaped with darker purplish markings in the throat, emerging from leaf axils. Conspicuous, shiny, egg-shaped berries initially green, becoming bright red, partially enclosed in a persistent green calyx.
taxon_text_2_9605: Growing to at least 2 m height. Flowers about 12 mm across. Berries 5-12 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_9606:
Global: Native to South Africa, but has been widely introduced to Mediterranean region, Australia and New Zealand, as well as to the USA, where it is a declared noxious weed.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Lesotho, both along the coast and inland.
taxon_text_4_9607:
Common both inland and along the coast, where it can extend almost down to high water mark. The berries are eaten by birds and small mammals, which also disperse the seeds. Used in traditional medicine to treat swollen legs and as a tonic to cure cattle ailments. The fruit are known to produce narcotic symptoms if eaten.

Drought and salt tolerant make it useful as an ornamental plant in coastal gardens and its longevity and spiny nature make it an excellent hedging or barrier plant.
taxon_text_6_9609: Flowers July to November.  Berries contain numerous small seeds and are present year-round, but most abundant in autumn.
taxon_text_7_9610: There are several other regional species in this genus. Most likely to be confused with the Mouse bush L. tetrandrum, which is also common along the west coast, but that species has much smaller, more elongate and succulent leaves and much smaller fruit.
taxon_text_1_9613: Stout, erect perennial shrub growing from a single woody, greyish stem that gives rise to spreading branches which bear large, 5-8 lobed, velvety leaves shaped like an open palm. The flowers are hibiscus-like and emerge from the leaf axils. The petals are pink to lilac with dark veins and throat and the stamens and branching stigmas branch from a central column. The seed head is a dry capsule.
taxon_text_2_9614: Grows to 2-3 m height. Leaves up to 20 cm wide. Flowers 30-40 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9615:
Global: Native to Mediterranean region but widely introduced to western USA, South America, Tasmania, New Zealand and Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern, Western and Eastern Cape Provinces, especially along the coast.
taxon_text_4_9616:
Hardy plant able to grow very close to the sea, excreting salt through glands on its leaves. An introduced species in South Africa, where it grows mostly in exposed positions along the coast.

Used as an ornamental plant in coastal gardens. In Europe the leaves were traditionally used in herbal medicine as a poultice to treat strains and burns.
taxon_text_6_9618: Flowers from spring to Autumn. Seeds form inside round, flat capsules.
taxon_text_7_9619: A fairly-distinctive large shrub. The indigenous Sand rose Anisodontea scabrosa is similar and also common along the coast from Saldanha Bay to KwaZulu-Natal, but is more delicate and has smaller 3-lobed leaves (20-70 mm long) and light to dark pink flowers that lack a dark throat.
taxon_text_1_9622:
Smallish shrub with branches spreading along the ground and then curving upwards. Young branches with raised longitudinal ridges but become woody when older. Leaves arranges alternately along branches, spear-shaped with a short stalk and prominent mid-vein.

Inconspicuous pale-yellow flowers occur in clusters at the end of the stems. Striking brown to orange fruitlets appear lower down the stems and are enclosed in fleshy bracts. They have a strong melon-like small when crushed.
taxon_text_2_9623: Plants up to about 1 m tall. Leaves about 25 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9624:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa. Introduced to St Helena.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9625:
Widely distributed in arid regions both along the coast and further inland and can survive in saline soils right along the coast. Heavily browed by grazing herbivores and its presence is an indication of good land management. Thought to have potential for the rehabilitation of saline soils.

Also used by indigenous people to wash hands or clothes, hence the common name soap bush.
taxon_text_6_9627: Flowers September to January. Easily propagated from seeds by collecting and planting the bracts enclosing the fruit and tiny seeds and is useful in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_7_9628: The only species in the genus and fairly easily recognised by the unusual succulent bracts around the fruit.
taxon_text_1_9631: Stress resistant, low-growing annual with succulent stems and large, paddle-shaped leaves that have wavy, often red, margins and are usually folded lengthwise. The distinctive, glistening, bladder-cells on both the stems and leaves resemble ice-crystals, giving the plant its common name. The attractive, daisy-like flowers have a fringe of thin white to pink petals surrounding a tuft of short yellow stamens and appear in spring and early summer. The 5-segmented, star-shaped fruits contain many seeds per cell.
taxon_text_2_9632: Height typically about 15 cm but can reach 50 cm, with lateral stems typically extending about 20-60 cm, leaves 10 cm or more long and flowers about 25 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9633:
Global: Widespread across southern and North Africa and in southern Europe. Also introduced to South America, Australia and USA.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9634:
A hardy species that occurs in dry areas both along the coast and inland, but particularly common adjacent to the coast, as it is very tolerant of salt spray. The flowers are pollinated by insects and close at night.

The leaves are edible and are eaten like spinach, or can be pickled. They are sold in supermarkets in Japan under the names ice plant or salt leaf. The plant is also used as an ornamental in gardens and is useful in fire prevention (firescaping) and in bioremediation (to extract salt from brack soils). The species also has various potential biomedical applications.
taxon_text_6_9636: Annual species that germinate with the first winter rains, glowing to maturity and flowering around November-December.
taxon_text_7_9637: Common and familiar species fairly-easy to recognise due crystalline appearance of leaves.
taxon_text_1_9640: Slender climbing plant with twining hairy stems and narrow, arrow-shaped, opposite velvety leaves that curl under at the sides. The striking tubular flowers are bright pink or red and have long pointed petals with green tips that close the mouth of the tube. Flowers are borne in heads of about 5-8 flowers each. The forked fruit split open along the seam when ripe to release distinctive brown seeds each topped by long, silky hairs.
taxon_text_2_9641: Grows to at least 1 m, supported by other plants. Leaves about 30 mm long. Flowers up to about 11 mm tall.
taxon_text_3_9642:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9643:
Found in the winter-rainfall regions, where it clambers into other shrubs. Plants are heavily grazed by stock and game and the young fruits are a popular wild food with a milky-sweet taste. The flowers are also sometimes eaten.

Makes an attractive pot or garden plant but difficult to grow from seeds, which survive best if sown just before the winter rains.
taxon_text_6_9645: Flower June-September. Pollinated by sunbirds that penetrate the closed flowers, resulting in the pollen sacs attaching to the birds’ tongues – a unique and specialized form of bird pollination. Butterflies and ants also visit the flowers for their sweet nectar. The parachute-like hairs on the seeds assist with wind dispersal.
taxon_text_7_9646: Distinctive growth form and flowers. The closely-related Coral creeper or Redwax creeper M. tenuifoloum has much the same range and habits, but has narrow thread-like leaves and urn-shaped, open-ended bright-red flowers with rounded petals.
taxon_text_1_9649: Stiff, rounded shrub growing to at least 1 m and with short spike-like lateral branches. Leaves small, stalkless, thick and oblong. Bears numerous small, solitary flowers that can be purplish or pink and white. The flowers are somewhat pea-like with the inner two sepals enlarged and petal-like and much longer than the others and a fringed crest on the lower, keeled petal. Fruit are conspicuous yellow-to-red fleshy globes.
taxon_text_2_9650: Plants up to 1 m tall, flowers about 10 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9651:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9652:
Common in coastal sands, but also widespread inland and come sometimes be the dominant species in the landscape. The fruits are astringent but are rich in Vitamin C and were eaten by early inhabitants of the Cape and are favoured by ostriches and other wildlife, including tortoises, hence the common name.

Popular in coastal gardens due to its profuse purple flowers and pretty berries, which also attract birds. The leaves and stems have been used to brew a tea that is believed to help with abdominal and digestive issues and the roots are also used in traditional medicine to treat malaria.
taxon_text_7_9655: This are numerous gorse-like regional species in this genus, but many of these have dry rather then fleshy fruits rather than fleshy berries. Can be confused with M. scoparia, which also has red thinly-fleshy fruits, but that species grows to 2.5 m, has longer, willowy branches and is confined to the West Coast.
taxon_text_1_9825:
Shrub or small tree with brownish-greyish, rough bark and often multiple stems. Leaves leathery and elliptical with strong venation and sunken central vein. Upper surface dull green, lower surface paler greyish-white and velvety, margins of leaf minutely toothed. Smells strongly of camphor.

Flower heads in terminal sprays, individual flowers creamy white and covered with white woolly hairs. Fruit a small nut covered in woolly hair, the heads resembling balls of cotton wool.
taxon_text_2_9826: Growing to about 5 m height. Leaves 40-80 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9827:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About Saldanha Bay to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_9828: Coastal species that can occur almost down to high-water mark. A versatile plant used in traditional medicine for respiratory and digestive conditions and as a source of perfume and insect repellent. The wood is also hard and durable and can be used for fence posts, furniture or even musical instruments.
taxon_text_7_9831: The Camphor bush T. camphoratus is similar and has an overlapping rang but also occurs far inland across eastern and northern parts of South Africa and northwards to Somalia. It grows larger, to 6 m, and has longer pointed leaves up to150 mm long.
taxon_text_1_9658: Upright, evergreen, perennial shrub with elongate, lance-like, lush-green leaves that emerge opposite one another all the way up the multiple erect stems. Both stems and leaves have small white hairs, giving them a velvety feel. Large, showy, bright pink flowers form at the tips of the stems in summer, usually in clusters. Each flower has five broad, glossy petals that are slightly sticky and these surround a prominent group of bright-yellow, twisted anthers.
taxon_text_2_9659: Grows to about 60-80 cm height. Flowers about 35 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9660:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambert’s Bay to George.
taxon_text_4_9661:
Hardy plant able to grow very close to the sea and to cope with strong winds, brackish soil and salt spray. The flowers are adapted to pollination by carpenter bees and release their pollen only in response to the vibration of the bees’ wings – a phenomenon known as buzz pollination!

Useful as an ornamental plant in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_6_9663: Flowers November - February. Produces fruit capsules (rather than the berries found in many other members of this family) that split along lines of the septa to release numerous small seeds.
taxon_text_7_9664: Distinctive and the only species in the genus. The Christmas berry Chironia baccifera also has bright pink flowers with yellow anthers, but has smaller, slender leaves and produces fruit that are bright red berries.
taxon_text_1_9667: Fairly large shrub growing to at least 3 m and with woody stems becoming green and fleshy distally. Leaves fleshy and pointed with serrated edges, surfaces of young leaves covered in cobweb-like hairs which are lost as they mature. Yellow daisy-like flowers born in groups of about 5. Unusual fleshy fruit are borne in groups and are initially green becoming blackish when mature (hence allusion to ‘ticks’ in the common name)
taxon_text_2_9668: Plants up to at least 2 m tall, leaves about 45 mm long and 24 mm wide and flowers about 40 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9669:
Global: Widespread in Southern and Eastern Africa.

Local/Regional: Common not only along the coast, but also far inland including mountain regions.
taxon_text_4_9670:
A very common and well-known species. Can occur right against the coast, on dunes just above the highwater mark, but also widespread in fynbos, grassland and rocky areas and widely grown in gardens. Flowers mainly from March to September and pollinated by a variety of insects. The fruit are sought after by frugivorous birds which play an important role in seed dispersal.

Has been introduced to Australia and New Zealand to stabilize soils and has now become a serious pest there.
taxon_text_6_9672: Flowers throughout the year, but mainly in autumn and winter.
taxon_text_7_9673: Fairly distinctive in both habitat and appearance and best recognised by the unusual fruit. There are several recognised subspecies.
taxon_text_1_9676: Well-known and common herb. Leaves on long stalks, each with three heart-shaped, notched leaflets that are smooth above but sometimes hairy below. The funnel-shaped flowers are borne in groups on tall stems that extend well above the leaves, have five fused petals and are bright canary yellow. They furl at night. Underground the plants produce numerous small bulbs.
taxon_text_2_9677: Flower stems up to about 30 cm tall. Flowers up to 40 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_9678:
Global: Endemic to South Africa, but has been widely translocated and now found in many parts of the world, including USA, South America, Europe, North Africa, Middle East, India, Tasmania and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9679:
Well-known and abundant species both along the coast and inland, sometimes forming dense beds of bright flowers. Is considered a weed in many areas to which it has been introduced and is difficult to control since it produces copious small bulbs which remain in the soil even if the plants are uprooted.

The plants contain high concentrations of oxalic acid, giving them a bitter taste, but are nevertheless used in foods and in traditional medicine. The raw bulbs have been used to treat tapeworms and the plant as a diuretic. If sheep are allowed to gorge on the plant this may have fatal results.
taxon_text_6_9681: Flowers July-October. Propagation is mostly by dispersal of the small bulbs.
taxon_text_7_9682: There are over 100 Oxalis species in the region, many of which have pink, white or purple, rather than yellow flowers. Among the yellow flowered species Oxalis flava has a similar distribution, but the leaves have up to 12 folded finger-like leaflets and the flowers are borne singly not in groups.
taxon_text_1_9685: Low, many-stemmed shrub growing to about 1 m and with long, stems that bear small, fat, oblong leaves in four ranks pressed closely against the stem. Tips of stems woolly. Flowers yellow to pink, in spikes, anthers protrude from the flowers. Fruit attractive, round red berries.
taxon_text_2_9686: Plants up to about 1 m tall, leaves about 3 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9687:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted distribution in Southwestern Cape from about Melkbosstrand to Bredasdorp district.
taxon_text_4_9688: Found on coastal dunes and between rocks along the coast. The berries are eaten by tortoises and are attractive to birds which play an important role in seed distribution. Has an extensive root system and is a useful plant for dune stabilization. Also popular in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_1_9699: Smallish perennial shrublet with fleshy stems coated in glandular hairs and soft velvety oval and crinkled lobed aromatic leaves. Flowers pink and borne in groups on upright stems usually about 10 cm long. Each flower has two larger upper petals decorated with dark, branched stripes and three smaller lower petals with less prominent or no markings. There are seven strong pink stamens in the centre of the flower.
taxon_text_2_9700: Plants up to about 50 cm tall. Leaves about 5 cm diameter, Flowers 2.5 cm across.
taxon_text_3_9701:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_9702: Common, salt-tolerant species found on coastal dunes. Brushing against the hairs on the stems releases a sweet to rosy scent. Has been introduced to Western Australia, where it has become an invasive species. Cultivated for its aromatic leaves, which are used in potpourris, perfumes, and herbal teas, as well as for its essential oils, which are also a component of geranium oil, utilized in cosmetics and aromatherapy. The leaves have also been used in traditional medicine to treat skin conditions like rashes and cracked heels, digestive issues and kidney/bladder ailments.
taxon_text_6_9704: Flowers July to October. Easily propagated from cuttings.
taxon_text_7_9705: This large genus contains about 270 species, of which some 150 occur in the fynbos region, but this is usually the most abundant species on coastal dunes. Also common along the coast is the Dune pelargonium P. suburnanum, but in that species the leaves are narrower and flowers are usually paler with the lower petals much narrower than the upper pair.
taxon_text_1_9708: Spectacular, succulent-stemmed coastal shrublet with scrambling habits – often growing among and supported by other plants. Leaves oblong and deeply incised with serrated margins and are covered with silvery hairs. Flowers scarlet and in groups of 4-9 on long hairy stems that extend well above the foliage.
taxon_text_2_9709: Plants typically about 50 cm tall but can reach over 1 m if supported by other plants. Leaves up to 10 cm long, flowers about 20 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_9710:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Orange River to about Yzerfontein.
taxon_text_4_9711: Coastal species confined to west coast. One of the most colourful pelargonium species and is the parent of many commercially marketed hybrids. The young leaves and be used as a wild food.
taxon_text_6_9713: Flowers June to November. Pollinated by sunbirds. Popular in coastal gardens and easily propagated from cuttings.
taxon_text_7_9714: This large genus contains about 270 species, of which some 150 occur in the fynbos region, but this species is easily recognised by ists very bright scarlet flowers.
taxon_text_1_9717: Tough, compact evergreen shrub with many-branched stems bearing closely-set, needle-like leaves which have the margins rolled under. Flowers white, borne in multiples in rounded, button-like heads and have a fairly-strong honey scent.
taxon_text_2_9718: Shrubs grow to about 100 cm tall, leaves 5-8 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9719:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Fynbos endemic found from about Saldanha Bay to Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_9720: Hardy species found in coastal areas and resistant to drought, wind and fire, so well suited to water-wise coastal gardens. Flowers can be present year-round, but most profuse in late summer and autumn. Pollinated by bees, butterflies and beetles. Plays a significant role in dune stabilization and is harvested and sold as a filler for floral arrangements.
taxon_text_6_9722: Flower year-round. Seeds survive for several years in the soil and their germination is stimulated by fire.
taxon_text_7_9723: There are over 100 regional species in this genus. Of these P. cephalantha is similar in appearance and habits, but has yellow rather than white flowers and occurs only along the west coast. The smaller P. parviflora has a similar range and habits, but only grows to 40 cm tall and has only a few (5-8) woolly florets on each flower head.
taxon_text_9_9725: Plantago crassifolia (Until recently confused with P. crassifolia, which is found in Europe and the Mediterranean coast of north Africa, but recent genetic evidence has shown that the South African species is distinct and the name P. carnosa has been resurrected as its correct name.)
taxon_text_1_9726: Short perennial forming a dense rosette of elongate, fleshy, lance-shaped light-green leaves, sometimes wooly in axils. Common along the margins of estuaries, lagoons or sheltered beaches. Upright stems reaching well above the leaves and each bear a spike of tiny white flowers.
taxon_text_2_9727: Typically reach a height of only about 20 cm. Leaves about 10-20 cm long.
taxon_text_3_9728:
Global: Endemic to South Africa,

Local/Regional: In estuaries and salt-water lagoons extending from about Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9729: Salt-tolerant plant that occurs low on sandy and muddy shores in both estuaries and fully-marine salt marshes ,often forming dense stands.
taxon_text_7_9732: Distinctive and unlikely to be confused with other species.
taxon_text_9_8905:
Original name: Pleurobranchus granulatus

Synonymised names: Berthella granulata, Oscaniella granulata, Pleurobranchus granulatus

Lemon Pleurobranch
taxon_text_1_8906: A small to medium-sized dull orange sidegill slug: the body may have spots or clusters of opaque white speckles. The head has a pair of rolled rhinophores set close together. The anterior corners of the foot are angular. The body is smooth-textured. There is a single gill on the right hand side of the body under the mantle. The posterior end of the foot is rounded.
taxon_text_3_8908:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay as well as the Knysna Lagoon, found from the intertidal to 5 m in depth.
taxon_text_4_8909: Frequently found under rocks during the day, nocturnal. The species is often found in pairs.
taxon_text_5_8910: The species may take live shrimps, but is thought to mainly scavenge for food.
taxon_text_6_8911: This species is hermaphroditic and produce a thick egg ribbon in a collar shape of one whorl, containing distinct densely-clustered orange eggs.
taxon_text_7_8912: This species is similar to other species of Berthellina, but none are known to be present in the region. The three images of the specimen below were taken in False Bay but may represent a different species.
taxon_text_8_8913:
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 206). 

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 173).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 60).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 68, 793).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 132).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 26).
taxon_text_1_9735: Dense, coastal shrub that forms a sprawling mound of slender stems bearing woolly, greyish, soft oval leaves that tend to bend down at their tips. Flowerheads small and congested and form brush-like clusters at the ends of the branchlets. Flowers with small white petals surrounded more obvious elongate brownish to purplish finger-like bracts.
taxon_text_2_9736: Typically reaches a height of about 1 m.
taxon_text_3_9737:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa. Introduced to Spain, Portugal, UK, California and Western Australia, where it is considered a weed.

Local/Regional: About Melkbosstrand on west coast to KwaZulu-Natal and into Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_9738:
Coastal species common on coastal flats near the sea, but also on damp lower mountain slopes. The grey colour of the plant and its small hairy leaves are both considered adaptations to surviving summer drought.

Popular as an easy-to-grow and attractive silvery ground cover in coastal gardens and effective in stabilizing mobile sands. Contains essential oils which have antimicrobial and antifungal properties.
taxon_text_6_9740: Flowers March to May. Easily gown from both cuttings and from seed. Germination increased by exposure to smoke primer.
taxon_text_7_9741: Could be confused with White bristle-bush Metalasia species which also forms silvery shrubs with similar flower clusters, but these tend to have narrow, stiff, needle-like leaves.
taxon_text_1_9834: Sprawling, much-branched succulent abundant on fore dunes. The soft pinkish branches creep along the ground and give rise to oval bluish-green leaves that lack stalks and are downward-curled lengthwise (like a shield). Leaves and young branches covered in tiny glistening bumps. Flowers with 4 petals, small and bright yellow, borne is short clusters hidden at the base of the leaves. Fruit with 4 stiff wings.
taxon_text_2_9835: Plants up to about 20 cm tall with sprawling branches at least 1 m long. Leaves about 5 cm diameter. Flowers 3-4 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9836:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa. Introduced to Western Australia.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9837: A very common foredune species extending down to almost high water mark. Forms dense growths and is an important dune stabilizer. Young leaves can be harvested and eaten like spinach.
taxon_text_6_9839: Flowers August to March. The four-angled fruit are easily blown about by the wing, aiding their dispersal.
taxon_text_7_9840: There are several other regional species in the genus. Most likely to be confused with Trailing dune spinach T. fruiticosa, which is also common along the coast, but also occurs inland. However, that species is taller, has longer, thinner leaves and has larger flowers borne on a much taller flower spike.
taxon_text_1_9744: Rounded perennial shrub with jointed stems. Leaves succulent and emerge from stems as paired, rounded leaflets. Flowers small, pale-yellow with four petals, each with small reddish marking at base. Large, abundant fruits are reddish, elongate and each have four conspicuous wings.
taxon_text_2_9745: Typically reaches a height of about 2 m. Fruits about 15 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_9746:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9747: Common on sandy and stony slopes mostly along the coast, but also extending well inland. Typically in arid conditions. Species in this genus are often grazed by stock.
taxon_text_7_9750: A large genus containing about 50 species, of which about 20 occur in the fynbos region. Among the larger shrub-like species most likely to be confused with Thin twinleaf R. flexuosa, which occurs along the coast in the South Western and southern Cape. However, the flowers of that species have five petals and the fruit are globular, wider than long and have five rather than four wings.
taxon_text_1_9753: Erect, perennial, succulent shrub found close to the high-water mark on rocky shores. Usually with thick woody stems (remains of dead stems often present around base of clumps). Main stems bearing lateral branches covered in succulent bead-like segments, terminal segments rounded knobs. Leaves minute and difficult to observe and tiny white flowers emerge from terminal segments of stems, usually in groups of three. Tips of branches often orange to red.
taxon_text_3_9755:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Orange River to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_9756:
Salt-tolerant plant that occurs low on rocky shores, almost down to the high water mark. Usually erect, but can dangle form crevices, although tips of branches usually turn upwards.

Species in this genus have a long history of use as food plants in Europe and can be eaten raw in salads, pickled, or cooked as a vegetable.
taxon_text_6_9758: Members of this genus are typically wind pollinated and produce small seeds which are dispersed by wind or water.
taxon_text_7_9759: This genus contains several other local species. This species is most likely to be confused with S. littorea is S. pillani, which forms similar largeish shrubs just above the driftline on but in salt marshes. Several other species are also found on soft substrate in the upper intertidal zone of saltmarshes and estuaries. These include the taller bushy Marsh samphire S. wayeriana which has succulent rather than woody stems and several shorter species which form creeping underground runners and send up numerous short vertical stems to create a ‘lawn’.
taxon_text_1_9843: Sprawling, perennial succulent with long, reddish stems and soft, narrow, fleshy alternating leaves, the margins of which are rolled under. Both stems and leaves are covered in tiny papillae that glisten in sunlight. Flowers borne in the leaf axils of upright stems and are small and yellow with four petal-like sepals surrounding a bundle of yellow stamens.
taxon_text_2_9844: Plants up to about 25 cm tall. Flowers 3-4 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9845:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.  

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9846:
Common coastal species, but also occurs inland in arid and semi-arid areas. Sometimes on open ground, but often scrambles among other plants. Palatable to game and stock and is an important fodder plant. The young shoots can also be boiled, chopped up and eaten.

Also a useful and attractive pioneer plant in coastal gardens and useful in stabilization of dunes.
taxon_text_6_9848: Flowers August -November. Flowers rich in pollen and nectar and pollinated by bees. Seeds borne in 4-winged capsules that becomes papery and light when mature and are easily dispersed by wind.
taxon_text_7_9849: There are several other regional species in the genus. Most likely to be confused with Sprawling duneweed, T. decumbens which is very common along the coast, but also occurs inland. However that species has broader, oval leaves and tiny flowers that are largely concealed around the bases of the leaves.
taxon_text_1_9762: Low, succulent, salt-tolerant annual bush with a short taproot and fleshy branching stems that are regularly jointed. Leaves not obvious and reduced to small fleshy lobes. Small flowers arranged in threes at joints in stem – the central flower the largest. Usually green but turns red when older or salt stressed.
taxon_text_3_9764:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.
taxon_text_4_9765:
Salt-tolerant plant that occurs low on soft substrata both on the margins of marine lagoons and in estuaries, close to the high water mark. Also found in saline environments inland. May consist of more than one regional subspecies.

Species in this genus have a long history of use as food plants in Europe and North America. The stem segments can be eaten raw in salads, pickled, or cooked as a vegetable.
taxon_text_6_9767: Members of this genus are typically wind pollinated and produce small seeds which are dispersed by wind or water.
taxon_text_7_9768: This genus contains several other local species. The Coastal samphire S. littorea forms similar or larger, woody bushes, but is a perennial and is found above the high water mark on rocky shores, rather than on soft substrate. Several shorter species such as the Glasswort samphire S. tegetaria form creeping underground runners and send up numerous short vertical stems to create a ‘lawn’ in the upper intertidal of estuaries and lagoons.
taxon_text_1_9771: Creeping species with underground runners rooted at the nodes and sending up short vertical stems that usually arise in pairs from the nodes and are covered by plump, barrel-shaped segments 7-15 mm long and 2-5 mm wide. The tiny white flowers are arranged in threes on the distal segments. Colour can be transparent light green, but often reddish.
taxon_text_2_9772: Typically reach a height of only about 20 cm, segments 2-5 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_9773:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa, extending from Namibia to Mozambique.

Local/Regional: In estuaries and salt-water lagoons along entire coast of South Africa.
taxon_text_4_9774:
Salt-tolerant plant that occurs low on sandy and muddy shores in both estuaries and fully-marine saltmarshes, where regularly inundated by the tide. Often forms dense beds such as in Geelbek, Langebaan.

Species in this genus have a long history of use as food plants in Europe and can be eaten raw in salads, pickled, or cooked as a vegetable.
taxon_text_6_9776: Members of this genus are typically wind pollinated and produce small seeds which are dispersed by wind or water. This species flowers from November to June with a peak in December and seed production peaks in February.
taxon_text_7_9777: The most abundant of several other similar species found in the region. Detailed examination is required to distinguish these – see references provided.
taxon_text_1_9780: Erect, coastal, perennial shrub with broad, grey leaves that are slightly hairy and aromatic. Golden-brown flowers crowded at ends of branches and have distinctive hooded upper petals that resemble a parrot beak, the long stamens protruding beneath the hood. The rusty coloured saucer-like calyx persists long after the flowers fall.
taxon_text_2_9781: Typically reaches a height of about 2 m.
taxon_text_3_9782:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to about Algoa Bay.
taxon_text_4_9783:
Coastal species very common on sandy dunes in dryer areas.

Popular in coastal gardens due to long flowering season and unusual flowers. Flowers also rich in nectar and attract birds and insects.

Widely used in traditional medicine for respiratory ailments, influenza, gynaecological complaints, fever, headaches and digestive disorders and by settlers as a tea to treat colds, tuberculosis, and chronic bronchitis. Like other Salvia species, the plants are also rich in essentail oils.
taxon_text_7_9786: The closely-related Rusty sage S. lanceolata occurs along the west coast as well as further inland and has rusty-red to greyish-blue flowers.
taxon_text_1_9789: Sprawling shrub, sometimes becoming a small multi-stemmed tree. Branches characteristically angular with pale grey bark. Leaves compound, with a distinctive blueish hue, glossy, but sometimes with resinous coating that dries to a grey powdery layer. Each leaf made up of three sessile leaflets, the central one being the largest, tips of leaves slightly indented with a small central spike. Delicate sprays of minute greenish-white or yellow flowers are followed by clusters of small spherical berries in female plants. These are initially green, becoming chestnut brown in summer and dry to black in autumn.
taxon_text_2_9790: Typically height 1-3 m tall, but can form small trees up to 4 m. Flower spays about 50 mm across. Berries 3 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_9791:
Global: Zimbabwe, Mozambique and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Along the coast from Velddrif on the West Coast to Eastern Cape, but also widespread inland.
taxon_text_4_9792:
Common both inland and along the coast. Tolerant to drought, salt-spray and high wind and an important pioneer species. Leaves have a resinous smell when crushed. Pollinated by insects. This and other Searsia species are food plants for a variety of butterfly larvae. Birds eat the ripe berries and help disperse the seeds.

Is used as a garden plant, especially in coastal gardens subject to harsh dry conditions. The fruit are edible but sour and can be fermented to make traditional beer. Branches of female plants in berry are sometimes used in flower arrangements.
taxon_text_6_9794: There are separate male and female plants. Flowers in late winter with berries in female plants most abundant in summer.
taxon_text_7_9795: There are many other easily-confused regional species in this genus.
taxon_text_1_9798: Annual herb with fleshy, erect, branching stems that are slightly hairy. Leaves somewhat hairy and glandular, up to about 8 cm long and deeply divided into several toothed lobes. Compound flowers made up of 13 petal-like ray florets and yellow disk florets in the centre. Bracts black-tipped. Colour of ray florets can be almost any shade of pink to purple.
taxon_text_2_9799: Plants about 60 cm tall, leaves about 80 mm and flower heads about 30 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9800:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. Naturalised in Australia, New Zealand, Azores and California.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9801: Common in coastal sands and can occur almost down to high water mark. Flowers mainly in September- November, but some flowers present July-March. Widely cultivated for its colourful flowers. The leaves are sometimes cooked and eaten as a vegetable and various parts of the plant are used in traditional medicine.
taxon_text_6_9803: Flowers mainly in Spring. Produces fluffy white seeds which germinate readily in well-drained soil.
taxon_text_7_9804: This is a large and complex group with some 80 regional species, making species level identifications challenging. Similar coastal species include S. arenarius, which has mauve to white rays and S. maritimus which has entirely yellow flower heads.
taxon_text_1_9807:
Well-known evergreen coastal tree with a sturdy trunk and shady, rounded crown, growing to at least 10 m. Bark brown, young branches covered in fine hairs. Leaves oval, leathery and arranges spirally around stems, dark shiny-green above and dull below.

The abundant small, white, bisexual flowers have a strong and unpleasant smell and give rise to small, round, fleshy black berries. Both leaves and fruit release milky latex if damaged.
taxon_text_2_9808: Trees can grow to at least 10 m tall, but are often spreading and merge to form tangles clumps. Leaves about 80 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9809:
Global: Somalia down the east coast of Africa to South Africa, including some Indian Ocean islands.

Local/Regional: Melkbosstrand to Mozambique.
taxon_text_4_9810:
Usually form tangled coastal forests which often have a dense outer canopy of leaves sculpted by the wind and enclosing a dimly lit interior supported by tangles of horizontal branches. Can occur as elegant sturdy trees with rounded crowns. Widespread and common but are protected, meaning they cannot be cut back or felled without permission.

Popular as an ornamental and shade tree in coastal gardens. Birds, bats and monkeys eat the fruit. The bark and roots are used in traditional medicine to treat broken bones, fevers and dispel bad dreams. The wood is hard and fine grained and has been used for building boats and other structures. The ripe berries are also said to be edible.  Trees do not burn easily and can be used as a firebreak.
taxon_text_6_9812: Flowers November to April. Most easily propagated by seed sown in Summer, but can also be grown from cutting.
taxon_text_7_9813: The only regional member of the genus and unlikely to be confused with other local trees.
taxon_text_1_9816: Course, robust, upright, perennial grass growing from creeping rhizome. Leaves slender, in-rolled and tapering to a blunt point. Inflorescence with unstalked downy spikelets produced on all sides of the stalk and pressed closely against it.
taxon_text_2_9817: Leaves 20-70 cm long and 0.5-1 cm wide. Inflorescence about 15 cm long.
taxon_text_3_9818:
Global: Endemic to Europe and North Africa. Introduced to USA, Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western and Eastern Cape Provinces.
taxon_text_4_9819:
Occupies upper intertidal zone on soft substrata in areas sheltered from strong wave action, both in estuaries and fully saline lagoons and saltmarshes. Usually forms dense beds along the upper shore.

Known to be an ecosystem engineer, profoundly influencing the physical environment and fauna of areas where beds are established. Sediments inside the beds are consolidated by the roots and are richer in organics than adjacent bare areas. The beds favour rigid-bodies, surface-dwelling and tube building species, but burrowing species are more abundant, and overall species richness higher, in adjacent bare areas.
taxon_text_6_9821: Beds expand asexually by expansion of the rhizomes. Rhizome fragments can also be broken off during floods or storms and carried to new sites. Seed production is low or even absent at some sites. In Europe flowers in Summer.
taxon_text_7_9822: Fairly easily distinguished by its fully intertidal habits, although several other similar grasses occur in the same ecosystems, but above the high-water mark.
taxon_text_1_9852: Tall perennial grass species emerging from long thick creeping underground rhizomes. Leaves long, hard, narrow and sheath the main stem. The large straw-coloured, flattened flowerhead bears a row of alternating flowers/seeds on either side.
taxon_text_2_9853: Plants up to about 50 cm tall. Flower spikes up to 15 cm long.
taxon_text_3_9854:
Global: Endemic to South Africa. Introduced to Western Australia.

Local/Regional: Coasts of Western and Eastern Cape Provinces.
taxon_text_4_9855:
Common coastal species that occurs in dunes and upper reaches of sandy beaches, extending down almost to high water mark, where plays an important role in dune stabilization.

The introduced European Marram grass Calamagostis (previously Ammophila) arenaria is often used as an alternative pioneer species during artificial dune stabilisation project.
taxon_text_7_9858: The introduced marram grass has similar habits and is often planted in areas where artificial dune stabilisation is being undertaken. It grows taller (up to 1m) though and has a cylindrical inflorescence up to 30 cm long rather then a flattened one.
taxon_text_1_9861: Largish perennial plant with elongate, soft, quill-like green leaves that lie prostrate on the sand and are covered with papery brown sheaths at their bases. The stout, upright, tree-like, branching flower head bears small nodding white, aromatic flowers from July to October.  Petals of flowers are strongly curled backwards and only a few of the flowers on the head open each day.
taxon_text_2_9862: Leaves up to 1m long. Flower head up to about 50 cm tall. Leaves about 5 cm diameter, Flowers 2.5 cm across.
taxon_text_3_9863:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Eastern Cape. Introduced to Australia where it is considered a weed.
taxon_text_4_9864: Very common species on coastal dunes, where it is sometimes a dominant plant. An edible species that has several uses - the buds and leaves can be eaten and the sap has been used in traditional medicine as a lotion for sores. There is current interest is re-establishing the species as a wild vegetable.
taxon_text_7_9867: This is a diverse genus with about 50 regional species of which 24 occur in the fynbos biome. This species can be confused with the Cape spinach T. ciliata, which as a similar distribution and coastal habitat, but that species has flowers that do not curl backwards and are borne closely-packed along a single long spike, opening sequentially from the bottom of the spike. Namaqualand wild cabbage T. falcata is restricted to the west coast and has just a few, broader, lance-shaped leaves and an upright flower spike with just a couple of parallel branches.
taxon_text_1_9970: Low-growing tufted annual with tongue or paddle-shaped leaves that are covered in glistening bladder cells. The exquisite flowers are solitary and borne on naked stalks about 40 mm long. The flowers open only in sunlight and are flat with numerous, long, pink, orange or yellow petals. There is usually a paler halo towards the base and a darker center.
taxon_text_2_9971: Plant typically about 10 cm across, flowers 20-30 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_9972:
Global: Endemic to South Africa, but widely marketed worldwide as an ornamental garden plant.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Southern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9973:
Short-lived species adapted to disturbed areas and found both along the coast and inland, usually on sandy substrata. Forms spectacular displays along the west coast in spring where is a favourite for photographers.

A popular garden plant that has been distributed around the world and is available in many colours.
taxon_text_6_9975: Flowers July to October. Fruit a five-compartment capsule that expands in wet weather to reveal tiny, smooth, light-brown seeds. Seeds germinate with the first autumn rains and reach maturity by the spring.
taxon_text_7_9976: A distinctive species but vary variable in flower colour so has a complicated taxonomic history and many synonyms.
taxon_text_1_9870: Largish perennial plant with 2-4 fairly-broad, bluish-green, lance-shaped leaves that emerge in opposite rows during autumn and winter.  Flowers borne on a thick upright stalk that is sparsely branched, each branch subtended by a leafy bract. Flowers have 6 white petals, each with a brownish midrib and yellow spot at the base. Flowers open a few at a time in sequence from base of spike and are followed by oblong green fruit.
taxon_text_2_9871: Leaves about 250-600 mm long and 15-20 mm broad. Flower head up 200-400 mm tall cm tall. Flowers about 12 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9872:
Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional:  Southern Namibia to SW Cape.
taxon_text_4_9873: Very common species in semi-arid regions both in sands along the coast, especially in Namaqualand, but also in rocky areas further inland. The young flower spikes can be collected and eaten like asparagus shoots or added to meat dishes.
taxon_text_6_9875: Leaves emerge in autumn and winter and flowers July to October. Flowers pollinated by bees. Dormant during summer, surviving as a bulb. Easily propagated by seed.
taxon_text_7_9876: This is a diverse genus with about 50 regional species of which 24 occur in the fynbos biome. This species is most likely to be confused with the Cape spinach T. ciliata, which as a similar distribution and coastal habitat, but has much longer, narrower sprawling leaves up to 1 m long.
taxon_text_1_9879: Smallish grass-like plant lacking rhizomes and usually occurring in dense beds. Elongate needle-like leaves emerge from tapering brown or black bulbs covered in stiff fibres. Flowers arranged in a spike, small and greenish with conspicuous, elongate ovaries. Slender, elongate fruits branch laterally from main axis, turning black when mature.
taxon_text_2_9880: Plants 20-50 cm tall. Leaves 1-3 mm wide. Flower head up to 20 cm long, fruits up to 10 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9881:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Velddrif to Kenton on Sea.
taxon_text_4_9882: There are several subspecies, some restricted to the coast and others occurring inland associated with temporary pools. Coastal forms usually in dense, more-or-less monospecific stands in high shore salt marshes, but sometimes in mixed beds with Soutbossie Chenolia diffusa.
taxon_text_7_9885: In the similar Streaked arrow grass T. striata the leaves splay sideways and then up and the fruit are more spherical.
taxon_text_1_9925:
Very diverse genus a small, bulbous plants with one to several pointed or flat leaves that emerge from a basal sheath and that are often spotted or barred with dark green or purple. Funnel or bell-shaped flowers usually borne on a fleshy vertical stem and can be red, pink, purple or white, depending on species

There are over 100 species in South Africa, of which about 70 occur in the fynbos region, including many that are common along the coast. Difficult to identify to species level both because of their great diversity and because individual species can differ widely in colour. Only a generic level entry is thus provided here.
taxon_text_3_9927:
Global: Numerous species, but most endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Most diverse in the Western Cape.
taxon_text_4_9928: Common group of attractive perennial bulbous plants, many of which are commercially cultivated as garden plants. Most species flower in the spring from about July-October. Often form dense colonies especially in sandy areas. Often pollinated by sunbirds.
taxon_text_6_9930: Usually propagate by bulb offsets and can also be grown by leaf cuttings taken from the base of the leaf. Also grow readily from seed.
taxon_text_7_9931: There are many regional species in this genus and identification to species level is difficult. See references below for wider range of species.
taxon_text_1_9888: Distinctive tree-like shrub with a very thick, fleshy stem covered in peeling, papery bark. Stout lateral branches bearing thick, bright-green paddle-shaped leaves in winter, but these are shed during flowering season in summer, leafing distinct knobbly leaf-scars. Nodding, urn-shaped yellow-to-red tubular flowers are borne on upright branching stems in summer.
taxon_text_2_9889: Up to 1.5 m tall. Flower tubes 12-16 mm long.
taxon_text_3_9890:
Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9891:
Distinctive and attractive species tolerant of a wide range of conditions and found both on rocky and sandy habitats along the coast and far inland. Coastal specimens can extend almost down to high water mark.

The largest species in this group and a spectacular sight both when covered in leaves in winter and when bare of leaves and in flower in summer.
taxon_text_6_9893: Flowers November-January. Flowers are bird-pollinated. Fine seeds are released form the seed capsules during Autumn (March-April) in time for the winter rains. A popular pot plant and can be propagated both by seed and via cuttings.
taxon_text_7_9894: Unlikely to be confused with other species due to its large size and distinctive flower heads.
taxon_text_1_9897: Small, dainty annual which branches from the base. The upright stems bear backward-pointing hairs and blunt, hairy, lance-shaped leaves. The attractive flowers are borne on branching spikes that extend up above the leaves. Each flower has five flat, white-to-mauve, heart-shaped petals arranged around a central yellow star that leads into a deep throat fringed by hairs and containing two stamens.
taxon_text_2_9898: Stems 60-300 mm long; flowers up to 10 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9899:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Coastal regions in the S.W. Cape from about Saldanha Bay to Pearly Beach. Also inland in Namaqualand and Karoo.
taxon_text_4_9900:
The long-tubed flowers in this genus are mostly strongly-scented and pollinated at night by hawk-moths, but in this species the flowers are open during the day, are not scented and are pollinated by long-proboscis bee-flies. The yellow star in the centre changes to pink after pollination and this is though to be a signal to the flies that nectar is no longer available!

Can be grown from seed and used as an ornamental in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_7_9903: There are over 50 species in this genus in South Africa, of which at least 17 species occur in the fynbos region. The mini-drumsticks Z. parviflora has minute flowers that are cream with a yellow centre. The Sandvelt drumsticks Z. affinis has scented white flowers that close during the day and open at might to attract pollinating moths.
taxon_text_1_9907: Well-known, rhizomatous perennial lily. The tall, stalked leaves have a spongy stem and very large, arrow-shaped blade. The single inflorescence is borne on a tall, soft, green stem or scape and surrounded by a large funnel-like white spathe, the edges of which overlap at the base. The actual flowers are minute, lack petals and are borne on a central spike within the spathe – the female flowers at the base and the male ones above. Fleshy green fruit are attached to the central spike and after the spathe had faded they become orange.
taxon_text_2_9908: Leaves about 45 cm long and flowerheads up to about 1m tall.
taxon_text_3_9909:
Global: Native to southern Africa, but has been widely translocated around the world and is an invasive weed in Australia and New Zealand.

Local/Regional: Damp habitats across the region.
taxon_text_4_9910:
A very well-known and abundant species both along the coast and inland, where it is abundant along the banks of streams and ponds. Can be evergreen in suitable habitats, but in the Western Cape is dormant in summer.

Extensively used as an ornamental plant and cut flower. A number of ornamental cultivars have been developed with different colours and spathe shapes.

Can be used for the treatment of waste-water and the leaves have been used in traditional medicine as a poultice for the treatment of headaches. The rhizome is eaten by porcupines and wild pigs.

Raw plants contain calcium oxalate crystals and eating them can cause burning of the lips, tongue and throat, as well as stomach pains and diarrhoea.
taxon_text_6_9912:
Flowers June-December. Pollinated by a variety of insects which often accumulate around the flowers. Although each plant produces both male and female flowers cross pollination occurs, as the male flowers mature before the female ones.

Also attracts crab spiders which come to feed on the insects and the Arum lily frog which shelters within the spathe. Seeds dispersed by birds but can also be propagated using pieces of rhizome.
taxon_text_7_9913: Easily recognized and unlikely to be confused with any other species.
taxon_text_1_9916: A short aquatic eelgrass that can form dense beds on intertidal and subtidal sand flats in both sheltered lagoons and estuaries. Creeping rhizomes below the sediment surface give rise to narrow, elongate flat leaves with rounded tips. Leaves have about eight parallel veins with periodic crossbars.
taxon_text_2_9917: Blades 10-30 cm long and about 2 mm wide.
taxon_text_3_9918:
Global: Angola to Kenya.

Local/Regional: Entire coast, but scarce in Northern Cape due to lack of suitable habitat.
taxon_text_4_9919:
Well-known species forming extensive intertidal beds at some sites, especially Langebaan Lagoon and Berg River Estuary within the area covered by this study. An important ecosystem engineer having profound effects on the composition and abundance of associated invertebrate and fish assemblages.

Classified as endangered, as populations is several bays and estuaries along the east coast, notably Durban Bay and St Lucia, have been lost as a result of development and those in several other estuaries appear to be in decline.

The only habitat of the endangered Eelgrass False limpet Siphonaria compressa which occurs in just two sites, Langebaan and Knysna.
taxon_text_6_9921: Relies primarily on vegetative reproduction via the spreading rhizomes. The tiny green flowers are inconspicuous and housed within specialized structures called spathes, which resemble leaf sheaths. Flowering occurs throughout the year.
taxon_text_7_9922: The only eelgrass species in the study area, although other more tropical species species occur along the east coast. Sometimes mistaken as being an alga due to its aquatic habits and could be confused with the green alga Caulerpa filiformis, but that species has much wider (5 mm) blades that lack longitudinal veins.
taxon_text_1_9934:
Bulbous perennial plants with two very large, tongue-shaped leaves that lie flat against the ground and are surrounded below-ground by a transparent, membranous sheath. The leaves may be smooth, longitudinally grooved, hairy, or dotted with pustules and are sometimes blotched with maroon, depending on species.  The distinctive flowers form a spike or dense cluster borne at ground level at the junction of the leaves. The petals are inconspicuous and joined for much of their length, but the stamens form a prominent upright tuft (hence the ‘hedgehog’ name).

Easily recognised to genus, but there are several similar species in the region so only a generic entry is provided. Common coastal species include M. angustifolia which has shiny, grooved leaves and orange stamens and M. depressa, which has smooth, sometimes blotched leaves and white, yellow or pinkish flowers. Both M. pustuata and M. longipes have grooved, warty leaves and white to cream flowers.
taxon_text_2_9935: Flowerheads up to about 5 cm tall, leaves 10 cm long.
taxon_text_3_9936:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: There are about 10 regional species, mostly in the drier winter rainfall areas to the west.
taxon_text_4_9937: Common in drier regions, with some species restricted to the coast but others also occurring far inland. Leaves and flowers appear at the same time, mostly from May to September, often on bare ground. Popular garden plants requiring a well-drained soil and sunny conditions. If grown from seed flower after 2-4 years.
taxon_text_6_9939: Pollination is by small mammals such as gerbils which are attracted by the ground level flowers, strong yeasty small and copious sucrose-dominated nectar, which is secreted mostly in the evening, when rodents are active.
taxon_text_7_9940: Easily recognized to genus but can be difficult to identify to species as flower colour can vary within species and most guides depict only some of the regional species. The species depicted is probably M. angustifolia.
taxon_text_1_9943:
A diverse group of small succulent plants containing some 400 described species of which about 60 occur in the fynbos region. The large number of species makes species identification taxing, so only a genus level entry is provided here.

Species can be erect but are often creeping and have succulent leaves that are usually triangular in cross section and emerge opposite one another, often joined together at the base in a sheath. The flowers open in sunlight, vary in colour from white to pink or purple and petals are arranged in one to several cycles. The stamens are arranged to form a central cone.

The depicted species is common on coastal dunes in the South-Western Cape and forms small shrublets with radiating creeping stems and plump leaves. It has small pink flowers about 15 mm across and with a paler centre. We tentatively identify it as R. macowanii.
taxon_text_2_9944: Depicted species about 20 cm tall with flowers about 15 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9945:
Global: Most species endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Uncertain as species level identification tenuous, but R. macowanii is restricted to coastal sites in SW cape.
taxon_text_4_9946: Most local species form either small shrublets or creeping mats and many species tend to be coastal. They are often covered in a dense carpet of flowers in Spring, forming spectacular displays.
taxon_text_7_9949: This is a confusing group with very many species in both this diverse genus and in other related genera such as Oscularia and Lampranthus. Species level identification requires good close-up images and use of specialised guides or expert advice.
taxon_text_1_9952: Sprawling annual herb with fleshy, erect, branching stems that are hairless. Leaves fleshy and oblong and formed into blunt lobes, smooth and glossy on upper side but underside hairy. Flowers borne in loose clusters that extend above the leaves, each with only about 8 blunt vibrant-yellow rays and yellow disc.
taxon_text_3_9954:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to about Cape Agulhas.
taxon_text_4_9955:
A coastal species that is very tolerant of saline conditions and occurs right down to the high water mark, where it can form a dense mats just above the driftline. Sometimes occurs in mixed beds with other purple Senecio species.

Can be used as an ornamental in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_6_9957: Flowers July to October. Pollinated mostly by honeybees. Produces head of fluffy white seeds which are dispersed by wind. Can be propagated both by seed and from cuttings.
taxon_text_7_9958: This is a large and complex genus with some 80 regional species, making species level identifications sometimes challenging. This is one of several coastal species with yellow flowers and is most likely to be confused with S. littoreus, which has lance-shaped leaves and S. abruptus which has more deeply-divided leaves.
taxon_text_1_9961: Sprawling perennial daisy with spreading stems that can form a carpet several metres across. The soft, silvery leaves are long and narrow with jagged margins and are woolly and sticky, with a strong bitter-sweet smell when touched. The showy compound flowers are large, solitary and borne on long, hollow, woolly stems. The outer ray florets (‘petals’) are cream to yellow on the upper-side and marked with a maroon stripe on the underside, while the central florets are dark to black.
taxon_text_2_9962: Typically reaches a height of some 35 cm, and may form patches at least 1 m across.
taxon_text_3_9963:
Global: Endemic to a restricted range in South Africa, but has been introduced widely as a garden plant and commonly grown in areas like California and Australia, where it may become invasive.

Local/Regional: Limited natural distribution from Saldanha Bay to Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_9964:
Has a very limited natural distribution in coastal areas of the western Cape where it can be form extensive bads right down to high water mark.

An excellent groundcover in coastal gardens and widely cultivated in South Africa and around the world.
taxon_text_6_9966: Flowers September to December. Pollinated by bees that visit the flowers during the heat of the day.  Can be readily propagated by seed or from cuttings.
taxon_text_7_9967: This is a large and diverse genus containing some 50 regional species, of which about 30 occur in the fynbos biome. Species level identification can thus be difficult, but this species is fairly distinctive, both because of its silvery, white-felted leaves and its restricted coastal distribution.
taxon_text_1_9999: Stiff, upright, much-branched shrublet with white stems densely covered with small, stiff, pointed, glossy leaves that have bristly margins and are curved back at their ends to form sharp tips. The end of the stems each bear 2-3 blue-to-mauve daisy-like flowers with one whorl of about 25 marginal florets (‘petals’) and yellow centres. After flowering fluffy seed-heads develop.
taxon_text_2_10000: Typically reaches a height of about 60 cm, flowers about 30 mm diameter.
taxon_text_3_10001:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Some sources give distribution from Mossel Bay to Eastern Cape, but others record the species from Table Bay eastwards and iNaturalist depicts many images from the Cape Peninsula.
taxon_text_4_10002:
A coastal species that occurs naturally only in a narrow coastal strip, but is widely cultivated in gardens and now found more inland.

The plant is spectacular when in flower and is popular in coastal gardens.
taxon_text_6_10004: Flowers August to October. The one-seeded fruits are egg-shaped and crowed by a circle of long bone-coloured hairs which aid in wind-dispersal.
taxon_text_7_10005: This is a diverse genus containing about 85 species of which some 50 occur in the fynbos region, but this species is fairly distinctive due to its stiff, prickly leaves.
taxon_text_1_9979: Sprawling succulent with prostrate stems that are orange in colour and have long internodes. Leaves spindle-shaped and borne in finger-like bunches, dark green, often becoming red towards the tips.  Flowers only open during the day, solitary and with several series of long, bright-yellow petals surrounding a yellow centre.
taxon_text_2_9980: Plants typically about 50 cm across, flowers 30-40 mm in diameter.
taxon_text_3_9981:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Restricted to coastal sands in the Western Cape from about Lambert’s Bay to Mossel Bay.
taxon_text_4_9982: Tolerant of dry, windy conditions. Common in coastal sands in the Western Cape, where can form attractive displays in otherwise bare areas. Easy to propagate from seed and a popular groundcover for coastal gardens.
taxon_text_6_9984: Flowers May to September.  Pollinated by bees, wasps and butterflies. Fruit a rounded 10-25 segmented capsule.
taxon_text_7_9985: The only surviving species in the genus and fairly distinctive. The closely-related J. anemoniflora has larger white to pink flowers and is extinct in the wild, although still available in cultivation as a garden plant.
taxon_text_1_9990: Low bushy plant which forms a mound of soft, finely divided leaves that are smooth above but greyish and hairy below. Bears numerous delicate pink to mauve flowers which are borne on slender, naked stalks and have five equal petals, each marked with darker veins and paler towards the base.
taxon_text_2_9991: Plants up to about 30 cm tall and can form clumps at least 1 m across. Flowers 15-30 mm across.
taxon_text_3_9992:
Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
taxon_text_4_9993:
Found in sandy and rocky soils along the coast, but is also a popular garden plant especially suited to trailing over rockeries of retaining walls, or in hanging baskets, and is now cultivated well outside its natural range. Attracts a variety of pollinating insects and is also a food plant of butterfly and moth caterpillars.

The leaves and flowers can be used to make a refreshing tea. This was traditionally also used to treat bladder infections, venereal disease and menstruation problems.
taxon_text_6_9995: Flowers August to December. The seeds are born on a distinctive structure of five curling threads attached around a central stalk. Easily propagated from both seed or from cuttings.
taxon_text_7_9996: Distinctive and the only common member of the genus in the region.
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are sm: Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.
<p>Argonauts are a group of pelagic octo: Argonauts are a group of pelagic octopuses that inhabit the world’s temperate and tropical oceans. Four species are recognised globally of which three can be found in South Africa. Argonauts evolved from benthic octopuses to spend their entire life cycle in oceanic waters. They are best recognised by the delicate, beautiful white shells of females referred to as ‘paper nautiluses’, which regularly wash ashore especially during prevailing southeasterly summer winds. These are no true molluscan shells but are built as brood chambers for the eggs by the females using specialised, shell-secreting webs at the tip of the dorsal arms. Females can leave, repair and rebuild their shells at any time. Argonauts display extreme sexual size dimorphisms as males are diminutive and shell-less, and even more rare to find. Three of the four globally recognised species occur in South African waters: Argonauta argo, A. hians, and A. nodosus. In recent years, the latter washed ashore most frequently, even if the literature says it is the rarest of the three species.
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are par: Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.
Feather stars are unmistakable as a grou: Feather stars are unmistakable as a group, as they sit ‘upside–down’ with the mouth facing upwards and the long, graceful arms extended up into the water column. They also attach themselves to the substratum by means of a unique ring of claw-like segmented appendages on the underside of the body. They are abundant in the fossil record dating back over 500 million years and in early forms the body was often borne on a long stalk with the cirri at its base. Such stalked forms are rare today, but the larval stages of sedentary (i.e. stalkless) species still go though a stalked developmental stage.
Octocorallia: Sea fans, sea pens & soft: Octocorallia: Sea fans, sea pens & soft corals
Small, fine or feathery red algae: Small, fine or feathery red algae
While snakelets and brotulas are only di: While snakelets and brotulas are only distantly related, they are grouped together here for practical reasons, as they share a somewhat similar body shape and lifestyles.
Soles (the related flounders), as well a:
Soles (the related flounders), as well as tonguefishes are easily recognised as a group, as they have become extremely flattened and lie on their sides, often partially buried in sediment. The eye from the lower, unpigmented, side of the body has migrated to the upper side, which is typically cryptically patterned. 

Soles lie on their left sides with both eyes placed on their right. Identification to species level is difficult, as there are about 50 regional species and colour patterns are both extremely variable within species and can quickly change in the same individual to match the background. Tonguefish lie on their right side (not left side, as in soles) with both eyes displaced onto the left side. The pectoral fin is absent and the dorsal and anal fins join seamlessly to the anal fin, so the fish comes to a point at the posterior end.
